column2: ST. PETERSBUG, Fla., March 28--Having already clinched the championship of St. Petersburg for 1966, the Mets could not work themselves up for another game against the St. Louis Cardinals today, and neither could the public.

When the Soviet Communist party opens its 23d Congress today, it will be under the leadership--for the first time in that party's history--of men born in the twentieth century, individuals who came to maturity after the conquest of Soviet power and who have no personal adult memories of life under the Czar.

Dr. Linus C. Pauling, twice winner of the Nobel Prize, explained to a jury here yesterday his connection with several causes that the House Committee on Un-American Activities characterized as subversive 15 years ago.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 28 (UPI)--Topseeded Roy Emerson of Australia was taken to five sets by the South African junior champion, Keith Brebnor, today before winning a two-hour match, 3-6, 6-3, 1-6, 6-0, 6-1, on the...

PITTSBURGH, March 28-- Mr. and Mrs. Alex Reich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith May Reich, who plans to be married July 17 to Mark Gilbert Grand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Grand of Patterson, N.Y.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange drifted lower yesterday as the forthcoming national election dampened enthusiasm of buyers.

BERLIN, March 19 (Reuters) --A Government-appointed panel of scientists and musicians will investigate a claim by a West German violin student that military service would coarsen his hands and keep him from passing his examinations.

TRENTON, March 28--The legislative minority leaders warned Gov. Richard J. Hughes today that there "would not be a single Republican vote for a sales tax" unless his budget was drasticalty changed to their liking.

The Health Department was given carte blanche yesterday to hire physicians and nurses, after charging that the Lindsay administration's job-freeze had led to severe staff shortages and curtailed services.

CHICAGO, March 28 (UPI) --Ben Bentley, the former publicity director for the defunct International Boxing Club, was named today the publicity director of the Chicago Bulls, the new entry into the National Basketball Association.

The program for "complete modernization" of the Police Department put forward by Commissioner Howard R. Leary generally makes excellent sense, though he will have two problems--money and morale --in putting it to full effect.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 28--Indonesia's new Government, announced last night by President Sukarno, represents a compromise between the armed forces and the President, with the balance heavily in favor of the armed forces.

JERSEY CITY, March 28 (AP)--Superior Judge Robert A. Matthews of Hudson County, signed a permanent injunction today enjoining members of a striking independent union from "obstructive" picketing at the Colgate-Palmolive Company plant here.

The inadequacy of volunteer enlistments to meet all the military manpower needs of the war in Vietnam has made draft procedures, and especially the criteria for deferring college students, a matter of intense controversy. The new deferment rules issued by the Selective Service System make only a limited contribution toward a more equitable draft or a reduction in controversy.

With the mounting of "It's a Bird ... It's a Plane ... It's Superman" as a musical comedy --it opens tonight at the Alvin --a new phase in the amazing phenomenon of pop is upon us. Wherever one turns on the cultural, subcultural...

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 28 (UPI)--The Maryland House of Delegates refused today to pass a constitutional amendment opening the door to a state lottery. The vote, 76 to 49, failed to reach the required constitutional majority of 85 votes.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 28 --The New York Yankees' search for a young pitcher to help lead them out of the wilderness may have ended today.

CHICAGO, March 28--Revision of the Federal Communications Act to reduce and define government control over radio and television broadcasting was urged today by Vincent T. Wasilewski, president of the National Association of Broadcasters.
WASHINGTON, March 28-- A new footnote was quietly written into the long history of the Senate today as the chamber's first Puerto Rican page was sworn in.
A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the Constitution prohibited all suits that could "conceivably involve delicate matters of international relations."
A poll of airline travelers indicates that only 39 per cent favor age ceilings for stewardesses and only 17 per cent believe stewardesses should be unmarried.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI)--Airman Patrick J. Nugent, Luci Bames Johnson's fiance, has finished his active duty with an Air National Guard unit in Washington.

Sales of oil products are expected to increase this year by 9 per cent over 1965 in the free world outside the United States according to a pamphlet report issued yesterday by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
TORONTO, March 28--A member of the Canadian Stock Exchange in Montreal expressed confidence today that trading would be resumed in United States securities on an unlisted section of the exchange.

Five midwestern utilities announced yesterday the proposed construction of two extra-highvoltage transmission lines to link major power systems in Michigan with Indiana and Ohio. A companion agreement will add two other utilities to...

In an apparent effort to reverse slipping sales of Kent cigarettes by making them more competitive, the P. Lorillard Company announced its withdrawal yesterday from the industry's voluntary advertising code.
A WOMAN going out for the evening in a Paco Rabanne dress of plastic and metal might slip pliers into her purse along with a comb and lipstick.
DETROIT, March 28--The Detroit Symphony and Local 5, American Federation of Musicians, have reached agreement on a new three-year contract.

TORONTO, March 28--In a match made possible by greed, hypocrisy and desperation, Cassius Clay will defend his world heavyweight championship here tomorrow night against George Chuvalo. Hardly anyone is holding his breath.
The Justice Department's Antitrust Division filed suit yesterday in Federal court here to block the proposed merger of National Cleaning Contractors, Inc., with the Kinney Service Corporation.
LONDON, March 28--Edward Heath, forsaking partisanship for poetry, called on Britain tonight to face the need for change in all the ties of tradition that bind this country.
A dispute between Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel and Mayor Lindsay's Commissioner of Investigation, Arnold G. Fraiman, broke out yesterday in the meter milking inquiry.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday that it was "inalterably opposed" to a part of Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary's reorganization program and would fight it during forthcoming salary negotiations.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- The Government is pondering with deep concern a new analysis that indicates the nation's balance of international payments, far from improving this year as expected, will actually show a larger deficit than last year.

AS the Russians were preparing in full view to hurl 13 armies with more than a million men at Berlin, Colonel Gen eral Ferdinand Schoerner, one of the more stupid and brutal of Hitler's generals, owlishly warned the Fuehrer, "Remember Bismarck's words, 'Whoever holds Prague holds Europe.'" Hitler agreed, promoted Schoerner to field...

PRAGUE, March 28 (Reuters)--Millions of Czechoslovak TV viewers tonight watched a surgeon cut open the heart of a young girl in a long and delicate operation. The live transmission showed the heart being stopped and an artificial heart...
Two big mergers involving payments in stock totaling $98million were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- The Government is pondering with deep concern a new analysis that indicates the nation's balance of international payments, far from improving this year as expected, will actually show a larger deficit than last year.

AS the Russians were preparing in full view to hurl 13 armies with more than a million men at Berlin, Colonel Gen eral Ferdinand Schoerner, one of the more stupid and brutal of Hitler's generals, owlishly warned the Fuehrer, "Remember Bismarck's words, 'Whoever holds Prague holds Europe.'" Hitler agreed, promoted Schoerner to field...
BALTIMORE, March 28 (AP)--Coach Paul Seymour of the Baltimore Bullets of the National Basketball Association said today that he was leaving basketball to tend to his businesses in Syracuse.

The scene could be the plaza of Lincoln Center Enter separately, with their companies, Rudolf Bing general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, and Julius Rudel, general director of the New York City Opera.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 28--Communist China would probably get fewer votes for membership in the United Nations now than it did in the last General Assembly, Arthur J. Goldberg said today at a news conference.

PRAGUE, March 28 (Reuters)--Millions of Czechoslovak TV viewers tonight watched a surgeon cut open the heart of a young girl in a long and delicate operation. The live transmission showed the heart being stopped and an artificial heart...
Two big mergers involving payments in stock totaling $98million were announced yesterday.

BELFORD, France, March 28 (AP)--A Regional-Council candidate with Popular Front support easily defeated a Gaullist candidate in an election yesterday. Michel DreyfusSchmidt won over Raymond Schmittlein, 10,292 to 6,401.
WASHINGTON March 28-- A move is under way in Congress to extend the deadline for enrollment in the voluntary Medicare program of medical insurance for the elderly.
PARIS, March 28--An inventive wine merchant mixed a red Beaujolais with a white Beaujolais and what did he get? A stiff fine. He was lucky he did not get lynched.

PITTSBURGH, March 28 (AP)--Judge Austin L. Staley was installed today as chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in special ceremonies here. The judge, who is 64 years old, was appointed to the...

ACCRA, Ghana, March 28-- Alex Quaison-Sackey, former President of the United Nations General Assembly, was released from protective custody by Ghanaian authorities last weekend, relatives confirmed today.

BOSTON, March 28 (UPI)-- Johnny Bucyk, who has scored 26 goals this season, including 16 in the second half of the campaign, was named today the winner of the Elizabeth Dufresne Trophy as the outstanding Boston Bruin in the National Hockey League club's home games.
RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 28 (AP)--Jack Devine, assistant and freshman coach at Villanova for the last five years, became today the second man ever to coach basketball at Fairleigh Dickinson.
Sears, Roebuck Co., the world's largest merchandising organization, again took top place in retailing last year.
A request made by President Johnson about two years ago is hampering the city's campaign to clean the air, Arthur J. Benline, Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, said yesterday.
The Board of Education could have built two new elementary schools last year for what it cost to repair damage to school property caused by vandals.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., March 28--The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested 13 men and sought a 14th today on Federal charges of violating the civil rights of a prosperous Negro leader who was slain by fire bombs near here Jan. 10.
COLLEGE baseball coaches from the Metropolitan area appealed again to organized baseball yesterday to stop signing undergraduates and taking them out of college before they complete their studies.

AUGUSTA, Maine, March 28 (AP)--Proponents of Sunday liquor sales in Maine conceded defeat today and abandoned the recount of the referendum Feb. 21 after 11 working days of the ballot review. The official tabulation shows that with approximately...

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) --Federal officials said today that two "mystery" witnesses would be brought before a grand jury investigating charges of mob terrorism in the ill-fated Cassius ClayErnest Terrell heavyweight title bout.

KNOCKOUT championships generally produce some upset results, but it is not often that the defending champions are eliminated in the first round by a team of unknown players. This occurred in the Regional...
PHILADELPHIA, March 28 --Five of seven men charged with creating disturbances during picketing at Girard College last summer were found guilty today after their jury trial ended abruptly.

NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28 (UPI)--Carol Lawrence, the Broadway star, gave birth to a son yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. Her husband is Robert Goulet, the singer. The couple have another son, born last year.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- The Interstate Commerce Commission in an effort to help relieve the plight of equipmentshort shippers of lumber has issued an order allowing the railroads to substitute single-deck stock cars for boxcars.
YONKERS, March 28-- Howard A. Kelly, supervisor of school buildings in the public schools here for 18 years, died today at his home, 66 Colgate Avenue. He was 66 years old.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 28--The Turkish National Assembly today elected Gen. Cevdet Sunay, former chief of the Turkish General Staff, to a seven-year term as President.

Dr. and Mrs. William James Butcher of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Kay Butcher, to Arden Glen Doss Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Doss of Miami.

THE American Broadcasting Company, whose stated intention is to bring as much newness and variety to the summer television schedule as we possibly can," last night unveiled "The Avengers," a British-made, hour-long...
GLEN COVE, L.I., March 28 --Edward D. Radin, author and criminologist, died today of cancer at Community Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 30 Red Spring Lane.

Matt Meyer, president and business manager of The New York World-Telegram and The Sun, will be the president of the new corporation scheduled to be formed through the merger of three New York newspapers-- The World-Telegram...

WASHINGTON, March 28-- The United States Supreme Court admitted the following New York lawyers to practice today: Robert L. Conklin, Anne Gross Feldman, Eugene Feldman, Thomas Barrett Leary, David Sive, and Ralph B. Neuburger.
WASHINGTON, March 28--In the Supreme Court of the United States today the follow ing proceedings were had.
Stock prices closed with gains yesterday although some late selling reduced part of the advance.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 28 --A new method to fortify the weak defenses of an animal with cancer was described here today by a California scientist.

CHICAGO, March 28--United Air Lines announced today the election of Capt. I.E. Sommermeyer as senior vice presidentflight operations, and Capt. Lloyd L. Treece as vice president of flying. The appointments are effective May 1, Mr. Sommermeyer...

Rex Sparger, a former Congressional investigator who is being sued for efforts to rig television ratings, said yesterday he had retained J. Howard Edmondson, former Governor of Oklahoma, as his legal counsel.
BULAWAYO, Rhodesia, March 28 (UPI)--"Owing to existing circumstances" Rhodesia will not be sending a team to the Empire and Commonwealth Games at Kingston, Jamaica, in August.

WASHINGTON, March 28--President Johnson announced tonight plans to establish an Indian-American foundation to promote progress in all fields of learning in India. He pro posed that the foundation be set up with $300-million worth of Indian currency held by the United States in Indian banks.

Ten years ago Tong Il Han was a soloist with the New York Philharmonic in one of its Young People's Concerts. Last night, the Korean-born United States-trained pianist, now 25 years old, made another appearance with the orchestra, this...

WASHINGTON, March 28-- The Alleghany Corporation, which 12 years ago fought a bitter proxy contest to acquire control of the New York Central Railroad, offered today to distribute its 15 per cent interest in the big carrier.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, March 28 (AP)--A black student who was offered a scholarship to study at Oxford University in England has been confined to his home district by the South African Government.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 28 (AP)--Marvin Bass, the head football coach and athletic director at South Carolina, announced today he had signed a three-year contract as head coach and general manager of the Montreal team in the Continental Football League.

Two United States oil companies announced yesterday that they had reached agreements with the Arabian Oil Company, Ltd., of Japan, to participate with the Japanese concern in producing oil in the Persian Gulf.
Ground will be broken Thursday by the Strick Corporation for a new $5-million plant in Chicago that will produce modern transportation equipment for integrated freight systems...
STAMFORD, Conn., March 28 --Miss Katherine T. Murphy, retired principal of the Stamford Elementary School named in her honor, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Manor in Trumbull. She was 88 years old.
With two days to deadline, elderly persons swamped district offices of the Social Security Administration here yesterday to enroll in the voluntary part of the Medicare program.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- A group headed by Louis Yaeger was identified by usually reliable sources today as the purchaser of a controlling interest in the International Railways of Central America from the Transportation Corporation of America.
Shareholders of the Kinney Service Corporation and National Cleaning Contractors, Inc., is separate meetings yesterday approved plans to merge the two concerns.

HAVANA, March 29 (AP)--A flight engineer killed an armed guard and a pilot in hijacking a Cuban airliner in a vain attempt to fly it to Miami Sunday night, the Government announced today. The authorities were hunting him throughout the Havana area.
Bob Nevin, the captain of the New York Rangers, was named yesterday the team's most valuable player of the 1965-66 National Hockey League season.

Governor Rockefeller's "war on narcotics" legislation, which has passed the State Senate so overwhelmingly, carries special significance for New York City. Roughly 50,000 addicts, or half the total in the nation, reside here; and the police estimate that 50 per cent of the city's crime is linked to the drug habit.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 29-- Former President Juan Bosch has begun a radio campaign charging that those who try to link him to Communism are guilty of "monstrous" deceptions.
LONDON, March 29--British steel prices will be raised by 4 per cent on Friday, it was announced today.
The bulls and the bears in Wall Street gave way to a horse over the weekend, and she was as balky as the market has been.
President Johnson is showing signs of abandoning the strangely inflexible stand that he has taken against raising taxes to combat inflation. His concession yesterday that he
A new floor, its third selling level, was opened yesterday by Barney's, the country's largest individual men's and boys' wear store.
SAIGON, March 29--South Vietnam's powerful Roman Catholic minority asked today that the military regime surrender power in an orderly way.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Something has gone wrong with the art of reporting human misery. We know the facts, but we do not feel them. We hear and read the news, but somehow miss the truth and its meaning.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 29-- The Panama Canal organization is conducting a tolls study covering both the existing and alternative systems for assessing tolls for ship transits as well as an evaluation of the effects of tolls on freight rates.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 29--White South Africans will go to the polls tomorrow and the universal expectation is that they will record a resounding vote of confidence in the apartheid or racial segregation policies of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd's Nationalist party.
With a display of bipartisan unity, the City Council has agreed--almost to a man--to have nothing to do with the Night Owl watch at City Hall.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 29 --At least 12 high-ranking Iraqi army officers were dismissed, deported or retired two weeks ago after discovery of a conspiracy to overthrow the Government, according to reliable information from Baghdad.

MOSCOW, March 29--Cheers and applause echoed in the Kremlin's Palace of Congresses today when, promptly at 10 A.M. the 12 members of the Presidium of the Soviet Communist party walked onto the stage, led by Leonid I. Brezhnev, to open the party's 23d Congress.
A recommendation that the Legislature study the feasibility of extending free tuition to undergraduates at the State University will be made by the Joint Legislative Committee on Higher Education.
A group headed by Jackson A. Edwards took title yesterday to the Manhattan Club property at the Southeast corner of 26th Street and Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Republicans and Democrats joined battle openly and fiercely today on the question of inflation, which both sides believe may become the primary issue of the 1966 election campaign. The fighting was spurred by a rise of 0.5 per cent in the Consumer Price Index, the sharpest

If anyone asks what went wrong in Ecuador the answer can be given in one word--everything. The result was inevitable, a palace revolution. The military junta is out of office and out of the country. A civilian government is next in order, but there the question is: for how long?
CLEVELAND--Every year, more than 3,000 customers of the Halle Bros. Company here receive a letter from the president of the department store.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 29--Even an honest-to-goodness tobacco merchant could not get on the auction floor today.

New York City's boxing fans, perhaps misled by the 7-to-1 odds that favored Cassius Clay over George Chuvalo, stayed away from the closed-circuit theater telecast in droves last night and missed one of the best heavyweight battles in recent years.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 29--Rhodesia warned Zambia tonight that it would not put up indefinitely with Zambia's refusal to meet to discuss the problems of running their jointly owned railway.

GREAT FALLS, Va., March 29 --Mr. and Mrs. John G. Laylin have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Laylin, to Dr. Christopher Scott Smith. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rayburn Clark Smith Jr. of Wynnewood, Pa., and Dark Harbor, Me.
A Nationalist China agency stepped yesterday into the controversy over a recent proposal by a group of Asian specialists that the United States recognize Communist China.

Georges Pretre, a true Frenchman and a rather special one, took over the Philadelphia Orchestra for a concert at Carnegie Hall last night, and the music-making was as fresh and clear as cloudless spring day. This, mind you, with a program that held Beethoven's "Egmont" Overture and Fifth Symphony and Honegger's Fifth Symphony, as well as the more spring-like Suite No. 2 from Ravels "Daphnis et Chloe."

MOSCOW, March 29--The Communist party leadership declared today that the Soviet Union stood ready to improve relations with the United States, but only after the United States Government "ends its policy of aggression" against Vietnam.

A realignment of the Caterpillar Tractor Company's staff was announced yesterday in San Francisco following the annual stockholder meeting. Elected chairman and chief executive officer of the nation's largest producer of tractors and farm machinery was William Blackie, a 59-year-old native of Glasgow, Scotland.
The spot rate on the British pound improved yesterday in active trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

LOS ANGELES, March 29 (UPI)--The Los Angeles Dodgers made a "final offer" to Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale today. The club increased by $25,000 its original "package" ofer to $210,000 for the two pitchers, but the Dodgers said the holdouts rejected the proposal.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- President Johnson announced today that he had signed a bill extending the safety and mandatory Federal inspection provisions of the Federal Coal Mine Safety Act to small underground coal mines.

LAHORE, Pakistan, March 29 --Foreign Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto declared tonight that Pakistan "will do nothing to endanger our relations with the United States in our relations with other countries, including China."

LONDON, March 29--An anxious and perhaps deeply divisive debate about the future of the Atlantic alliance is being waged among the 14 governments that have formally joined in tactical opposition to President de Gaulle.
TORONTO, March 29 (AP)-- George Chuvalo said if he had had more time to train for his bout with Cassius Clay he would have beaten him.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 29--India's population, threatened by famine, increased two million in the two months that a United Nations mission on family planning spent there last year.
CHICAGO, March 29 (AP)-- The Chicago Black Hawks kept alive their slim hopes for the National Hockey League championship tonight with a rugged 4-2 triumph over the last-place Boston Bruins.
The General Tire and Rubber Company began its 51st year with record first-quarter earnings and increased sales, M.G. O'Neil, president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The Defense Department said today that four of the Army's six emergency combat divisions in the continental United States were below combat-ready status.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company sold $250million of debentures yesterday.
THE Society of American Historians will hold its an nual dinner in Washington tomorrow, and the speaker will be Dean Acheson, former Secretary of State. His subject will be "History as Literature."

A paroled convict with a literary gift for being funny about the grim life behind bars came to New York yesterday to receive a $10,000 literary award for his first novel. Coward-McCann, Inc., which gave him the prize, will publish his book, "The Riot," early next year.
WASHINGTON, March 29--In years of rapid growth in the nation's output of goods and services, imports grow even faster, a new Department of Commerce analysis disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The nation's Federal judges are debating a law proposed by the United States Judicial Conference that would establish a commission to handle removal of unfit Federal judges.

ATHENS, March 29--Gen. Stylianos Gonatas, one-time revolutionary Premier of Greece who ousted two Greek kings to set up a republic between 1924 and 1935, died in a hospital here today after a long illness. He was 90 years old.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 29 (AP)--The launching of an Atlas-Centaur rocket, whose goal is the first double ignition of a hydrogen engine in space, was called off seconds before lift-off today when a power cord failed to disconnect from the booster.
The Lindsay administration notified City Council leaders yesterday that it would have its tax legislation ready for Council consideration on Friday.

The Brunswick Corporation, which in 1961 set a record of $44.9-million in net earnings, showed a loss of $76,932,000 last year, as estimated in December, the company's annual report disclosed yesterday.
The stock market traced an uncertain course yesterday. Prices declined in the morning, recovered slightly in the afternoon and then weakened again in the final half-hour of trading.

The Appellate Division struck down yesterday the State Supreme Court ruling that had opened the door to restriction of automatic dismissal of public employes who refused to sign waivers of immunity when called to testify.

LSD is the most dangerous of "under-the-counter" drugs, including narcotics, the New York County Medical Society said yesterday in calling for severe penalties for its illicit manufacture, distribution and sale.
A Florida publisher who invested $260,300 in yearlings last summer had his first chance to collect a dividend yesterday at Aqueduct. He didn't quite make it.
TORONTO, March 29--At a few minutes to midnight, Cassius Clay strutted out of his dressing room tonight wearing a brocaded black tuxedo, but no smile.
The emergency pumping station that was rushed to completion to provide Hudson River water for the drought-parched city was ordered shut down yesterday to prevent a possible reservoir overflow.
BUENOS AIRES, March 29-- The United States advised its Latin American partners in the Alliance for Progress today that it would continue to put "buy American" strings on its foreign aid.

St. Patrick's Cathedral welcomed 62 priests, nuns, rabbis and ministers who were on a march for Vietnam peace yesterday, and in the process held what was probably the first interfaith service in the cathedral's 106-year history.

TORONTO, March 29--Circling endlessly through a hammering barrage of low blows, Cassius Clay whipped George Chuyalo's face into a swollen red lump tonight and successfully defended his world heavyweight championship with a 15round unanimous decision here at Maple Leaf Gardens.

The Phillips Petroleum Company has agreed to purchase the Western refining and marketing facilities, as well as the related transportation assets, of the Tidewater Oil Company for $309-million, the two companies announced yesterday.
ALBANY, March 29--Mayor Lindsay, pressing to win passage of his transportation plan for New York City, has agreed to make major changes in the legislation.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 29 (UPI)--In the first meeting this year of the 1965 World Series contestants, the American League champion Minnesota twins topped the world champion Los Angeles Dodgers, 2-0, in an exhibition game today. Both runs were unearned.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 29--United States Marines killed 83 Vietcong guerrillas in an operation launched yesterday in quick reaction to an attack on a hamlet 330 miles northeast of Saigon.

The Consumer Price Index for the New York metropolitan area rose 0.7 per cent from January to February, the largest monthto-month increase since June, 1963, the Department of Labor reported yesterday.

Bob Castiglione pitched a nohitter yesterday to lead New York University to a 16-0 victory over Hunter College at Ohio Field in the Bronx. The game was called after seven innings by agreement. It was N.Y.U.'s first local game of the season.
BRUSSELS, March 29 (UPI) --Albert-Edouard Janssen, a former Belgian Finance Minister, diplomat and banker, died here today. He was 83 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The Federal antipoverty agency which has moved with great caution into the controversial field of family planning, is dramatically enlarging birth control help for the poor.

TORONTO, March 29--White dinner jackets and evening gowns were the ringside attire that summer in 1956 when Toronto was the rare host to what was billed as a championship fight between Archie Moore and James J. Parker. The crowd of 19,800 and a gross gate of $148,500 set Canadian boxing records.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 29-- If all Americans were nonsmokers, there would be 12 million fewer cases of chronic illness reported in this country, a new national survey indicates.
In Britain, when a businessman wants to borrow from his bank, he simply overdraws his bank account, and pays interest on the amount of the overdraft.
Unusual "wolf in sheep's clothing" behavior can confer on some viruses the ability to cause cancer in animals, according to recent research reports.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29--New York City's baseball championship was decided today in Florida's Sunshine City--by rain.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 (UPI)--Stuart T. Saunders, chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said today its 1965 operations and earnings were encouraging, but added that the company's greatest potential for a satisfactory return on investment lay in a merger with the New York Central.

When the Ringling Bros. and Barnum Bailey circus train pulled into Philadelphia yesterday morning, Nagana, the Czechoslovak dog trainer, checked the weather, hung her leotards out to air in the vestibule and made sure her poodles were all right--in that order.

BOWIE, Md., March 29 (UPI) --Pastrengo, the winner of two races during the winter at Florida Downs, had no trouble winning his first start of the year in Maryland today when he scored by 4 lengths in the $6,000 Dogwood Purse at Bowie.
ALBANY, March 29--Governor Rockefeller vetoed tonight a bill that would have allowed corporations to advertise in political campaign journals.

Dates for the season's sailing competition were ratified at yesterday's spring meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound at the New York Yacht Club. They included 34 regattas counting toward mid-Sound championships, 36

The Bowater Paper Corporation announced yesterday in London that it had notified its customers that it would increase the price of newsprint by the equivalent of $5.60 a ton, to $164.50, effective July 1.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., March 29--The Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed today that it had found a "small arsenal" in the home of a Laurel businessman who allegedly heads the South's most violent Ku Klux Klan organization.

President Johnson seems to be backing into a decision on a tax increase to keep the economy from overheating. He has decided how much of an increase ought to be made, although he still gives no sign of readiness to make it. He wants more time to diagnose the state of the economy, but it is doubtful that there is anything to be gained by such a wait.

Symposium on "Enzymes in Mental Health," Carl Neuberg Society for International Scientific Relations Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, 9 A.M. Dinner, 7:30 P.M. "Science and World Problems," Dr. Linus C. Pauling.
THE latest fly catalogue arrived from Dan Bailey's fly shop in Livingston, Mont., the other day and on the cover was a photograph of a hairwing Royal Coachman floating on water.

The nation's three largest religious bodies, representing the Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths, have thrown out a proposed accord on the reduction of discrimination in housing that they had drafted in unpublicized discussions with the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

THE New York City Ballet, which last night opened its 42d New York season at the New York State Theater, owes its existence primarily to one man. And that man is unexpectedly not its resident genius and creative force, George Balanchine, but someone else, who

While Referee Jackie Silvers watched Cassius Clay absorb more than 100 punches below the belt, Clay successfully defended his world heavyweight boxing championship by outpointing George Chuvalo in Toronto last night.
BONN, March 29--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany appealed to Poland and Czechoslovakia today to start "dialogues" with Bonn on disputed matters.

LOS ANGELES, March 29--A program to provide training and jobs for Negroes, the most ambitious expansion to date of a new Negro-run national organization called Opportunities Industrialization Centers, was disclosed here today.
BALTIMORE, March 29-- Man can learn more about Mars sooner and at less cost by sending electronic robots there instead of going himself, a space engineer said today.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Three weeks ago, Charles M. Maguire, a White House Fellow, wrote a memorandum stressing the educational value of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings on China. The memo was read by President Johnson, who eventually praised the hearings.

WASHINGTON, March 29 --The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had filed a complaint in Federal District Court in New York City against Karl H.P. Swensson, his brothers, Kenneth and J. Donald, and their firm of Karl H.P. Swensson Co. of Seattle.
ALTMAN'S imported five designs from the French couture this season and expects to get 12 to 15 advance ideas from them.

HAINES FALLS, N.Y.--There is a twisting, turning, rock-rimmed road that leads to La Cascade, a hotel and restaurant that has for a slogan, "A Touch of France in the Catskills." It is a precipitous route with views of valleys brown and white in winter when there is skiing, green

Cooper-Horowitz, Inc., mortgage brokers, have placed a blanket first mortgage of $3,250,000 on the Lancaster and Allerton Hotels, two of three hotels recently purchased here by the realty investing partnership of Sol Goldman and Alex DiLorenzo.

PARIS, March 29--A majority of the NATO countries was reported today to have taken the position that France's decision to withdraw from the military organization of the alliance could be contested as not legitimate but that no retaliation should be contemplated against her.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 29--Mrs. Gladys Gordon Fry, ornithologist and naturalist known as the "Bird Lady," died yesterday in her home, 92 Eagle Rock Way, after a brief illness. She was the widow of Dr. Henry J. Fry, biology professor at New York University.
Long Island University presented yesterday its 18th annual George Polk Memorial Awards for excellence in journalism to nine persons.

QUITO, Ecuador, March 29 --The high command of the armed forces deposed the ruling military junta at 8 A.M. today and asked Ecuador's major political parties to choose an interim President to govern until elections could
The New York State Dormitory Authority awarded yesterday two bond issues totaling $13.58-million.

GOTTERDAMMERUNG is, vaguely, the theme of these two new novels, which themselves represent the dammerung of something, if not of the gotts. One is set in the recent past, one in the immediate future. Both seem concerned with extreme human corruption, but both fink out when it comes to producing more than a wrinkled brow of hypothetical and rather distant worry.

George Champion, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, New York's largest bank, told stockholders at Chase's annual meeting yesterday that he saw "no need" at present for an increase in the Federal Reserve discount rate, now 4 per cent.

Red Auerbach, the coachgeneral manager of the Boston Celtics, and Paul Seymour, the coach of the Baltimore Bullets, have announced their retirements as National Basketball Association coaches at the end of the current playoffs, but may wind up quitting before they had expected.

The Kips Bay Boys Club will hold its 14th annual dinner dance on April 19 in the Roof of the St. Regis-Sheraton. Mrs. Anthony M. Del Balso is general chairman for the benefit, which this year will include a discotheque for junior guests in the adjacent Penthouse.

TORONTO, March 29--With the referee assuming the role of an innocent bystander, George Chuvalo pounded Cas sius Clay from kneecap to skullcap at various times in Maple Leaf Gardens tonight. But he didn't hit him often enough or effectively enough to take away the world heavyweight championship, even though he lasted the Derby distance of 15 rounds.
Widespread short covering and a steady tone in the cash market pushed Main potato futures prices higher yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

In an attempt to secure a greater number of conventional theatrical bookings for independent and experimental films, three of the better known figures among America's so-called underground filmmakers are forming the Film-Makers' Distribution Center.
A mother of 10 children whose husband was killed by muggers in Brooklyn Monday night kept repeating in a daze yesterday one of the few English words she knows: "Why?"
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--The Government announced today its intention to encourage additional domestic copper production through new purchases or commitments to buy copper.
The Burroughs Corporation introduced yesterday two new members of its third-generation computer family, the 500 series.
WASHINGTON, March 29--Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India expressed sympathy today for the American position in Vietnam and for the Johnson Administration's
Pots of white azaleas on yellow tablecloths brought spring to the ballroom of the Plaza last night for the Botticelli Ball, a benefit for the Orphans of Italy.
Nearly 60 leading singers and 11 conductors will take part in the Metropolitan Opera's last performance in its old home at Broadway and 39th Street on Saturday, April 16.

HONG KONG, March 29-- Marked differences in the relations of Communist China and North Vietnam with the Soviet Union were underlined today in their contrasting reactions to the opening of the 23d congress of the Soviet Communist party in Moscow.
MANY bridge players make their living from the game as teachers, writers or organizers. A small minority of experts are able to exploit their talents by more direct means.
YONKERS, March 29--A late scratch and a dead heat in the eighth race caused all sorts of complications in the twin double tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- President Johnson indicated today that, if he decided a tax increase was necessary to cool off the economy, he would ask Congress for a "modest" rise of 5 to 7 per cent in the taxes paid by individuals and corporations.

CHICAGO, March 29 (UPI) --The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that Bernard (Bernie) Glickman, a fight manager, had been brought to Chicago from St. Louis under protective custody, presumably to testify at a Federal grand jury investigation of gangland influence in boxing.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz agreed today to help arbitrate a New Jersey labor dispute that has become a focal point of the Johnson Adminis tration's effort to sustain its wage-price guideposts.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The Government set limits today on the amount of damaging air pollution that new automobiles may emit into the atmosphere after the fall of 1967.
"There is no reason why we shouldn't make the playoffs next year," said Dick McGuire. If we don't, it will partly be my fault."
Students of the meter-milking school on Long Island were taken to it blindfolded for classes and threatened with bombing to prevent them from going into business on their own.

NEW ORLEANS, March 29 (AP)--Prospective voters in Alabama may not be asked to state if they can read and write as a requirement for registering, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today.

NEW YORK CITY never seems quite itself with out the New York City Ballet, which last night, happily and impressively, opened its 42d New York season at the State Theater at Lincoln Center. Absence, as always, has made the heart at least seem to grow fonder, and the company at this first viewing looked battle-fit and performance-sharp.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner has held that it is not necessarily unsafe or illegal for the pilot of a fourengine jet airliner to continue flying to his destination after the failure of one engine.
OTTAWA, March 29--Some tax rises and several "restraints" in public and private spending were prescribed by the Government tonight to "control" Canada's booming economy.

"SUPERMAN" is fun. The full title, it insists, is "It's a Bird ... It's a Plane ... It's Superman." It opened last night at the Alvin (I saw the last preview), and the sum of everything to be said about it is: It's fun.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--A Federal Aviation Agency official said today that principal cities in the near future might require two major airports, one for short-range planes and the other for longrange ones.
Did you ever see a truck walking?
JOHN KLOSS is a designer on his way up--in designs and location.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- A bill to create a Department of Transportation began today a trip through Congress that promised to be long and slow-- but probably safe.
Most stocks declined on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as trading cooled off a little from Monday's frantic pace.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Analysts of Soviet-Chinese affairs said Moscow's plea today for better relations with Peking appeared to be an effort directed more toward insuring a smooth course for the Soviet Communist party congress than toward any substantial hope of easing the quarrel with the Chinese.

THE first of the Sports Car Club of America's na tional amateur championship races for 1966 will be run Saturday and Sunday at Upper Marlboro, Md. More than 200 cars have been entered in nine races. The principal event is for the Governor's Cup, and Gov. J.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)--The Defense Department called today for the drafting of 34,600 men in May. It had asked for 21,700 for April.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Bill D. Moyers, Presidential press secretary, said today that the only reason he had delayed his trip to Saigon was that another Government official with whom he was supposed to travel had added additional stops to his tour.
ALBANY, March 29--The Legislature tried today to soften the effects of the statewide sales tax in an election year by eliminating taxes on some consumer goods and services.

The 15-member City Commission on Human Rights will be asked by its chairman today to approve immediate public hearings on alleged discrimination in the building trade unions here and to issue subpoenas ordering several labor leaders to testify.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--A Senate Judiciary subcommitte was told today that letters addressed to a private firm but missent to the Patent Office had not only been opened but also answered by the agency's former solicitor, C.W. Moore.

LONDON, March 30--Prime Minister Wilson said tonight that the choice for British voters was between those who wanted to see Britain as a glorified supermarket and those who wanted her economic strength and efficiency tempered with compassion.

Cooperation and solidarity is one of the main sources of strength of the socialist system. Development and deepening of this cooperation meets the vital interests of each country separately and of the world socialist system as a whole, helps rally our ranks in the struggle against imperialism.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- The star witness at a Government hearing today on ways to improve survival rates in air crashes was a tall, soft-spoken engineer with no aviation background who came as a private citizen on "a personal mission."
The city's Board of Election's reversed itself yesterday and announced it was preparing to conduct primary elections on June 21 as required by law.

SYDNEY, Australia--Singapore is the hinge of the defense system haphazardly put together by cold war co-belligerents in the East. Until there is some rational Asian settlement it is imperative that Britain retain its base facilities there. Almost everyone concerned in the hodgepodge of Pacific security agrees--except the British.
ALBANY, March 29--Senator Robert F. Kennedy was accused today of scheming to prevent Governor Rockefeller from getting credit for the state's participation in the Federal Medicare program.
ALBANY, March 29--Governor Rockefeller moved today to relieve overcrowding in New York City jails, including the much-criticized Women's House of Detention.
THE house rules at one of New York's newest and most unusual supermarkets include reimbursing the owner for any breakage of the bric-a-brac he sells.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 29 (UPI)--A final decree making The Newark (N.J.) StarLedger the owner of the Springfield newspapers was filed today in Superior Court.
WHAT is "horrible, objectionable, boring and offensive" to most women? And only occasionally "goodhumored, helpful and entertaining?"

GENEVA, March 29--Eric Wyndham White, director general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, expressed serious doubt today about the possibility of concluding the Kennedy-round negotiations successfully.

MUTTONTOWN, L.I., March 29--Three safecrackers stole carefully into the Muttontown Golf and Country Club early this morning, started to work on the office safe and suddenly found eight detectives armed with shotguns, revolvers and rifles looking over their shoulders.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday plans to overhaul the curriculum of the Police Academy to insure that "prospective policemen get their training from the civilian viewpoint."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 29 (AP)--James M. Pendergast, the last of the Pendergast politicians and the son of Mike Pendergast, who gave former President Harry S. Truman his start in politics, died last night. He was 70 years old.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 29 (UPI)--Senator John Sherman Cooper, announced today that he was a candidate for re-election in November.

MOSCOW, March 29--Leonid I. Brezhnev, Soviet Communist party leader, proposed today that the old Bolshevik name "Politburo" be restored to the party's ruling body. The Politburo was named the Presidium in 1952 at the last party congress before Stalin's death.

Leonid I. Brezhnev's speech opening the 23d Congress of the Soviet Communist party should set to rest any remaining doubts about the reality of "collective leadership" in Moscow. The flamboyant promises and bold new ideas that marked Nikita Khrushchev's keynotes at the party congresses of 1956, 1959 and 1961 were conspicuously absent.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- President Johnson scored a solid victory tonight as the House passed a supplemental appropriations bill with the rent subsidy program and teacher corps intact.
ALBANY, March 29--The Assembly honored the late Hyman E. Mintz today for his contributions to the Legislature and service to the people of Sullivan County.
SURFSIDE, Fla., March 29 (UPI)--The kidnapping yesterday of 18-year-old Daniel Goodman might have been in revenge for one of the financial deals of his father, Aaron, a banker and contractor.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 29, (UPI)-- Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, won his opening-round match in the South African tennis championships today with a 6-1, 6-2, 6-3 decision over Louis Sylvester of South Africa.
The longshore industry and the Waterfront Commission have agreed on a new legislative measure on the controversial work register issue.
Prices on the London stock exchange continued to ease yesterday on light offerings and absence of buyer interest.

THE Beaux-Arts String Quartet has been playing since 1958, but last night's Town Hall concert was like a debut. Last fall, the quartet won the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation's first Chamber Music Award, and that has focused attention upon the group. The award consists of $20,000 and three Town Hall concerts, of which this was the first.

The directors of the new corporation, the World Journal Tribune, Inc., that would control the operation of the newspapers under the proposed merger of The New York Herald Tribune, The New York Journal-American and The World-Telegram and The Sun, were announced yesterday. Each principal will have three members of the board.

Ninety-seven persons worked feverishly yesterday on the 18th floor of the Biltmore Hotel from 11 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. to effect the final closing of the Williams Brothers Company's acquisition of the Great Lakes Pipe Line Company for $287.6-million.

A $1.3-million program to train and license nurse's aides, many of whom already perform jobs for which they should be trained and licensed, was announced yesterday by the Federal Government and the Department of Hospitals.

MOST of "The Policeman's Lot," last night's "C.B.S. Reports" study of police problems, was as unexciting as the title. What was fascinating, though, was the way the filmed show served as a come-on for the wares of its sponsor, International Business Machines.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 29--Lieut. Gen. Stanley R. Mickelsen, who was chief of the Army Air Defense Command when he retired in 1957, died yesterday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

Development with democracy in conditions of stability has been a major Indian contribution to world peace and human welfare. Yet poverty remains our main enemy. We are dedicated to victory in this struggle and we are convinced that we shall win.
GENEVA, March 29--The Soviet Union termed unacceptable today the latest United States proposals for a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Legislation to fix minimum safety standards for passenger car tires and to establish uniform requirements for grading their quality was unanimously approved today by the Senate.

Dr. Donald F. Shaughnessy, assistant to Mayor Lindsay, picked his way over mountains of junk yesterday to discover that "not one spadeful of dirt" had been turned at Flatlands Industrial Park, the 96-acre tract that was to give factory jobs to thousands of blue-collar workers.

CHICAGO, March 29--E. William Henry, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, today criticized radio and television for broadcasting cigarette advertising that ignores the smoking controversy.
HONG KONG, March 29-- Communist China accused the Johnson Administration today of feigning a desire for better relations while preparing for war.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)--Secretary of State Dean Rusk will visit Finland May 31June 2 and Norway June 2-4, the State Department announced today.

Loew's Theatres, Inc., which derives the major part of its business from hotel operations, achieved record results in the three-and-six-month periods ended Feb. 28, according to the company report yesterday, which will be mailed to some 16,000 stockholders.
Wall Street tried to tune in on Washington's tax thinking yesterday, but all it got was static.

THE American Kennel Club registration of Old English sheepdogs rose smartly last year and Mr. and Mrs. Hendrik Van Rensselaer of Basking Ridge, N.J., leading breeders and exhibitors, were not delighted. The breed was getting popular and high popularity often led to low qual

Special Federal income-tax procedures apply to investors who Last year received cash dividends or other cash distributions on the corporate stocks they own. At least one benefit--tax exemption of the first $100 in "ordinary dividends" from qualified domestic companies--helps to alleviate the double taxation of corporate income--once at the corporate level and again at the investor level.
A former scholarship student in college who was convicted of assaulting three young girls was sentenced yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court to serve from 30 to 60 years in prison.

All elements on New York's turbulent waterfront have shown a sound sense of public obligation in working out their differences over legislation to close the longshore hiring register. The legislation, which passed the State Senate unanimously yesterday, is needed to assure the success of the new labor agreement on the docks, with its promise of vastly increased efficiency in cargo handling.

ALBANY, March 30--The Senate unanimously approved today a bill that would allow the Waterfront Commission to close the longshoremen's register, or work list, with an eye to making employment on the New York and New Jersey piers more regular.

ALBANY, March 30--Two days after Mayor Lindsay came to Albany to urge legislative action on his New York City tax program, Controller Mario A. Procaccino visited legislative leaders today and offered his own tax proposals.
The City Investing Company bought 1,292,702 shares of common stock of the General Development Corporation yesterday, acquiring a 17 per cent interst in the Florida, land-development concern.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)--A new Commeree Department report indicates that it would cost as much as $700million to improve the New Haven Railroad for high-speed train operations to travel the 230 miles between New York and Boston in 2 hours.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 --The creation of a Pennsylvania - New Jersey - Delaware agency to provide leadership in developing the Delaware River port area from New Castle, Del., to Trenton, N.J., was proposed today by the Pennsylvania planning Board.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy enlisted today in a rapidly growing movement for stronger auto safety legislation than President Johnson has proposed.

The directors of Certainteed Products Corporation and of the Gustin-Bacon Manufacturfing Company approved a merger plan in principle yesterday, involving an exchange of stock valued at close to $30-million.

BARBRA STREISAND'S success on her first hour long special last year was no lucky accident. She proved that last night when, in "Color Me Barbra," her second annual appearance on the Columbia Broadcasting System she did variations on the formula of her first show and, if anything, topped herself.
LOS ANGELES, March 30-- Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale ended their holdout against the Los Angeles Dodgers today and became the two highest-paid players ever to perform on the same baseball team.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- United States banks reduced their outstanding foreign loans and investments by $385-million in the first two months of this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The textile industry is just now discovering that man-made fibers are not inferior substitutes for natural fibers but rather the dominating factor in the trade.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- The Johnson Administration will find itself tomorrow on the spot more than ever before in defending the integrity of its controversial wage-price guideposts.

Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving was described last night before 1,000 department employes as "an intelligent and personable young man [who] doesn't know what the hell is going on with the working men and women in the Department of Parks."

TORONTO, March 30--Once upon a time there was a British heavyweight fighter known as Fainting Phil Scott and also as the Swooning Swan of the Soho. In the true tradition of British heavyweights he had a tendency to attain a horizontal posture because of an embarrassing vulnerability to punches on the whiskers and punches to the body, particularly those in the vicinity of his beltline.
BERLIN, March 30--Erwin Piscator, one of Germany's foremost theatrical producers and directors, died today at a hospital in the small Bavarian town of Starnberg at the age of 72.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 30-- Is it possible that one tiny organism might cause many, if not all, kinds of cancer?
LIVERPOOL, England, March 30--Prime Minister Wilson came back in triumph to his political base tonight, confident of a smashing victory in Britain's general election tomorrow.
LAGOS, Nigeria, March 29-- "We got tired of drawing our water from a well right smack next to the cesspool so, with the kids helping, we dug ourselves a new well. Now the whole village uses it."

A $500,000 damage suit accusing Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City and John V. Kenny, Hudson County Democratic leader, of demanding a bribe was dismissed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
SAIGON, Thursday, March 31 --Buddhist student leaders denounced the United States and South Vietnam's ruling military junta at a rally this morning in downtown Saigon.
A sharp rally in wheat and soybean futures took place on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday following President Johnson's offer of an extra 3.5 million tons of grain to India.
LONDON, March 30--Britain handed over to Ireland today the emerald green flag that flew over the Dublin post office during the Easter Rebellion 50 years ago.

ST. LOUIS, March 30 (UPI) --The St. Louis Hawks won their third straight semi-final playoff game from the Baltimore Bullets, 121-112, tonight and advanced to the Western Division finals against the Los Angeles Lakers.

BONN, March 30--A spokesman for the West German Catholic News Service said today that Poland has issued an order that would prevent West German Catholic bishops from going there next May to help celebrate the 1,000th anniversary of Poland's conversion to Christianity.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)--A former auditor for the Internal Revenue Service in San Francisco charged today that he had been dismissed because he would not "keep my mouth shut" about tax records that, he said, he had been ordered to falsify.

IF brand-new curtains or a chair's fresh upholstery suddenly look as familiar as one of great-grandmother's tea cozies, chances are that the patterns are even older. A good many designs, some dating back three quarters of a century, have a tendency to go on forever in such long-established and prestigious fabric houses as Brunschwig Fils, Scalamandre Silks, Inc., F. Schumacher Co., Arthur H. Lee Sons, Inc., and Jofa, Inc.
Persons who reached age 65 before last Jan. 1 must be enrolled by midnight tonight to qualify for benefits of the voluntary portion of the Medicare program, which will become effective next July 1.
Uncertainty over President Johnson's plans for a tax increase depressed most shares on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and volume continued to subside from Monday's hectic pace.
THIS is a melancholy romp about fertility rites at Oxford. I enjoyed it, and I look forward to the screenplay based on it by Harold Pinter.
Roger Miller, the song writer, singer and guitarist who has been receiving much popular notice in recent months, made his Carnegie Hall debut last night.
The looting or parking meters in this city through the use of duplicated keys was described yesterday by District Attorney Nat H. Hentel of Queens as part of a nationwide criminal conspiracy.
A group of dissident stockholders of the Studebaker Corporation moved significantly closer yesterday to a proxy fight with the company's management.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Many persons seem to think that $750,000 is an outrageous price to pay for a new home for the Vice President. These people do not understand Washington real estate.
SEOUL, South Korea March 30 (AP)--Gen. Kim Chong Oh, former South Korean Army Chief of Staff, died yesterday of a lung tumor. He was 44 years old.

A major plan for a new independent seven-member agency to oversee the city's labor relations with 175,000 employes has been drawn by city, union and public representatives. It would include fact-finding and public recommendations to settle disputes without strikes.
Alcoholics may suffer delirium tremens because continual use of alcohol has suppressed their tendency to dream, a scientist said here yesterday.

PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30--Spring training is also like this: two babies are born to ballplayers' wives, two boys leave the Marines and rush to resume their baseball careers, two pet dogs 1,100 miles from home chase seagulls all day, Yogi Berra's golf game suffers, 30 bed boards are ordered for athletes' aching backs and 53 aspirants for jobs in the big leagues are reduced to 28 six weeks later.

Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel announced yesterday that the police had seized a cache of 192 contraband pistols, worth about $20,000 on the illegal market, in a novelty shop in the IND subway arcade at Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Congress completed action today on legislation to place much of the nation on uniform daylight saving time.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday ruled out any reductions in sales taxes this year. He said he doubted that a compromise could be reached on sales tax exemption bills that have been passed by both houses in Albany.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- An airline union official said today the airlines were "negligent" in preparing passengers and flight attendants for crash emergencies.
Mayor Lindsay, Sammy Davis and Max M. Fisher, general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, will receive awards of the Reform Jewish Appeal on April 17 at the Americana.
PARIS, March 30--One of the world's most renowned anthropological museums tomorrow opens to the public a display of one of the world's most important private collections of African art.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 30 (AP)--Arnold Palmer warmed up for the $100,000 Greater Greensboro Open today by carding an eight-under-par 63 in a pro-amateur preliminary to the tournament, which begins tomorrow.

FOR the eight days of Passover, which begins next Monday evening, many dietary restrictions will be observed by Jewish families, including the substitution of matzohs (wafers baked from unleavened flour) for leavened bread.

OTTAWA, March 30--A 5 per cent refundable tax on corporation cash profits to sop up excessive investment capital is the most novel feature of a new Canadian tax package designed to counter what the Government recognizes as an inflationary threat.

The case involving the Harvard historian Prof. H. Stuart Hughes and his right to travel in Europe without snooping by American embassies has had one useful result. Secretary of State Rusk and Attorney General Katzenbach have been embarrassed into reviewing the procedures concerning security and freedom of travel for American citizens.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday appointment of George F. McGrath, a former head of Massachusetts state prisons, as Commissioner of Correction, and immediately swore him in. WASHINGTON, March 30-- Representative Adam Clayton Powell announced today he would ask Congress for $7-billion for next year's poverty program instead of the "timid," "wrist-tapping" sum of $1.75billion sought by the Johnson Administration.
Shares of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company dipped point yesterday to 56 1/8, the lowest price since late 1962. Volume was heavy, with 104,900 shares changing hands.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- The United Mine Workers of America today called its national policy committee to meet here tomorrow amid reports of progress in labor negotiations with soft coal producers.
The bond market acted yesterday as though it were thoroughly convinced Federal taxes would be increased to cool off the economy.

AFRICA, a continent that has been of growing in terest in interior decorations during the last few years, is about to make a ripple in fashion. Bonwit Teller and Martin's have just ordered a group of sport and at-home clothes made from African printed cottons.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)--A House subcommittee on freedom of information unanimously approved today a bill designed to strengthen public access to Government news.
BALTIMORE, March 30--A private corporation to establish a worldwide system of weather satellites was proposed today by a United States Representative.

TORONT0, March 30 (UPI) --The Montreal Canadians scored three goals in the last period tonight to beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3-1, and clinch at least a tie for first place in the National Hockey, League.
FLOWERS aren't the only things that bloom in the spring; fishing contests sprout right and left.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara denied here today suggestions that the Army's home-based strategic reserves were seriously below combat readiness because four divisions were now filled mainly with recruits and enrollees and were assigned to training duties.

PLAINFIELD, N.H., March 30--Maxfield Parrish, the painter and illustrator whose lush vistas, fairy-tale castles and good-humored caricatures made him one of the most popular and successful artists in the first two decades of the century, died early today in his sleep. He was 95 years old and had been ill for several weeks.
OF all the festivals of the Jewish year, there is none followed with more ritual and devotion than is Passover. It begins at sundown next Monday and will continue for eight days.
When Constantine Caramanlis was Premier of Greece from October, 1955, till June, 1963, his trademarks were bluntness and a set of fierce black eyebrows.
Gold shares rose on the London Stock Exchange yesterday in an otherwise dull market.
CHICAGO, March 30--A Federal grand jury, trying to avoid the glare of publicity, shifted the site today of its closed hearings on racketeering in boxing.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- In what has become standard procedure, House Republicans provided the votes yesterday by which a Democratic Administration was saved from defeat on a key project of its domestic program. This was the President's rent supplement proposal, for which the Democratic party majority owns the political patent rights as a basic structure of the Great Society.

The Rockefeller administration moved yesterday to curb abuses in the building of Mitchell-Lama cooperatives by placing all such projects under the supervision of the Attorney General.
First-quarter earnings of the American News Company will be 20 per cent above last year, Henry Garfinkle, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

CHUPRONG, South Vietnam, Thursdays, March 31--Two hundred outnumbered United States soldiers fought their way out of a ring of North Vietnamese troops last night just south of where the biggest American action of the war was fought last November.

Jose Bonillo, the eldest of the 10 children of Agripino Bonillo who was beaten to death on a Brooklyn street Monday night, will leave high school to take his father's job as a $71a-week restaurant porter. His father had wanted him to stay in school.
MASSENA, N.Y., March 30 (AP)--The St. Lawrence Seaway's Montreal-Lake Ontario section will open this Friday, three days earlier than scheduled, amid forecasts for record cargo movement.

GENEVA, March 30--The Vatican's recent relaxation of rules governing marriages between Roman Catholics and members of other faiths represents only a "slight step forward," a leading Protestant spokesman said today.

"In My Father's Court," by Isaac Bashevis Singer, will be published by Farrar, Straus Giroux on May 2. This is a collection of reminiscences of the author's childhood. His father was a rabbi whose "court" was held in Warsaw. Young Isaac watched and remembered while his father heard disputes, performed marriages, issued divorces and settled questions of religious law.

Lyndon Johnson is at his best when challenged by some staggering task of human need. His message to Congress--and to the world--calling for aid for India, and pledging a truly generous measure of American assistance, is in the best tradition of Johnsonian philosophy. It is in no sense a detraction from his gesture to add that it is good, sound American policy to help India.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30--The New York Mets were held hitless for six innings tonight, but the Washington Senators changed pitchers in the seventh and the Mets scored four runs and went on to win, 5-2.
WASHINGTON, March 30 --The House Banking Committee voted today to give the Administration standby authority to impose controls on consumer installment credit terms.

DOUBLING a game contract on the basis of long, strong trumps held on declarer's left is a slightly risky occupation. But doubling from the other side of the table, with trumps massed under the declarer, is almost always a losing venture.

ONE of America's--no, one of the world's--live liest young ballet companies embarked upon the great adventure of its first Broadway season last night at the New York City Center. The Robert Joffrey Ballet, only 28 dancers strong, is, as classic companies go, small in size. But it is big in heart, big in aspirations and big in achievement.
