In all the furor over Mayor Lindsay's proposal for a 50 per cent increase in New York's stock transfer tax and the threats by the New York Stock Exchange to move out of town, the more than 10,000 men and women who work in the stocktransfer departments of major banks and corporations in New York have been overlooked.
Mrs. Joyce Ward Mackenzie, a leader in civic, charitable and educational enterprises, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. She was 46 years old and lived at 11 East 73d Street.
The Mobil Oil Company has finally reassigned the last of the business it took out of Ted Bates Co., Inc., last January, when it ended its relationship with that agency.
ATLANTA, March 30--Gov. Carl E. Sanders announced today that he would not challenge Richard B. Russell for his Senate seat.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, served notice yesterday that public school teachers who went on strike in the future could lose their licenses.

LAJES PORTISCH, the Hungarian grand master, stole the limelight in the early rounds of the current international tournament at Mar del Plata, Argentina. Scoring 6-1, he eclipsed such pretournament favorites as Vasily Smyslov and Leonid Stein, both of the Soviet Union, and Sammy Reshevsky of the United States in this 16-man round robin.
BUENOS AIRES, March 30 --Senator Jacob K. Javits said today amid rumors and denials of army unrest in Argentina that military coups were "the cause for great hemispheric concern."

CONVICTS at the Walpole, Mass., state prison were in rebellion. By telephone, their ringleader threatened to burn to death a Roman Catholic chaplain being held as hostage. On the other end of the telephone line was George Francis McGrath, who only three days before had

The $28,050 Correction Handi cap, won by the favored Queen Empress, occupied the chief spot on Aqueduct's program yesterday, but an extra-curricular sequence in the second race really had the crowd of 24,767 buzzing.

TORONTO, March 30-- George Chuvalo's manager, sensing intimations of immortality from last night's defeat, today foresaw a rematch with Cassius Clay after the Canadian heavyweight has beaten a contender of the champion's choosing.
DORTMUND, Germany, March 30 (AP)--Two West German companies announced today they had been contracted to build a $3-million glass-rolling plant for Communist China.
Mayor Lindsay was put on notice last night that he is unlikely to get top Democratic support for his transportation plan until he gives up virtually all veto power.

STANDING on the corner, watching all the girls go by for 30 years is no fun. So the owners of the Coty Salon, 612 Fifth Avenue (corner of Channel Gardens in Rockefeller Center), have done something to attract more of the girls in--$100,000 worth of redecoration. The salon, now known as the Coty Showcase, will reopen next Monday afternoon.
OTTAWA, March 30--The trial of Raymond Denis, a former Federal ministerial aide, ended abruptly today when the judge declared a mistrial.
The Washington University Choir and Madrigal Singers, both beautifully trained, spirited groups, gave a concert at Town Hall last night.
A full exploration into ways of saving the auditorium of the present Metropolitan Opera House, by building over it rather than demolishing it, was suggested yesterday to the City Planning Commission.
The city's homeless women, who spend their nights at an ancient, walk-up hotel on the Bowery, may at last get better quarters.
A drug treatment said to erase in a few days the symptoms of schizophrenia--a devastating mental disorder for which there is yet no cure-- was described at a scientific meeting here yesterday.
ALBANY, March 30--Governor Rockefeller's "war on narcotics addiction" won overwhelming approval in the Assembly today, after the Legislature's longest debate of the

The National Broadcasting Company news division will prepare a three--and--a--halfhour program on organized crime and its infiltration of legitimate business. It will be televised in color on Thursday, Aug. 25, from 7:30 to 11 P.M. under the title "American White Paper: Organized Crime in the United States."
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Thursday, March 31--The Nationalist party of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd scored sweeping gains throughout the country in yesterday's election.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Reports received here suggest that a widespread military and governmental shake-up is taking place in Cuba.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- President Johnson denied, today that he had named Deputy Under Secretary of State U. Alexis Johnson as Ambassador to Japan. It was not clear from his denial, however, whether he was, or had been, planning to.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- President Johnson sought Congressional endorsement today for a $1-billion emergency famine relief program for India and asked all other nations, whatever their "political faiths," to match the American efforts.

HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., March 30--Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Barkley Boldrey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Ellen Boldrey, to Eric Ernst Frische, son of Dr. and Mrs. Carl A. Frische of Glen Head, L.I.
RINGWOOD, N.J., March 30--A pilotless Air Force jet fighter crashed into a house at nearby Cupsaw Lake this morning and demolished it.

The Paramount Pictures Corporation officially informed the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that it would solicit proxies for a complete slate of directors at its forthcoming annual meeting.

Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India warned last night that without a greater inflow of private foreign investment her country would continue to need help from friendly countries. The next 10 to 12 years will be crucial for the Indian subcontinent, Mrs. Gandhi said at a dinner of the Economic Club of New

WASHINGTON, March 30-- A specialist on Far Eastern affairs said today that the United States should recast its policy toward Communist China to provide "incentives for moderation" on the part of the Peking regime.
The city started an experiment in urban planning yesterday in which community groups will help draft a blueprint for the redevelopment of a 13.7acre tract in Yorkville.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- Leaders of the New York newspaper unions questioned today the legality of the proposed merger of The New York Herald Tribune, The Journal American, and The New York World Telegram and The Sun.

BONN, March 30--Roman Catholic priests in the Archdiocese of Munich have been advised to allow married couples who use contraceptives "not lightly and habitually but rather as a regrettable emergency solution" to receive communion, a spokesman for the Catholic News Service said today.
American discussions with the Vietcong to free a United States civilian captive bring into question the Administration's long-held thesis that a Vietnamese peace can be negotiated only with Hanoi.
A plan to send public school teachers into parochial schools to help disadvantaged pupils drew praise and protest last night at a special meeting of the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- Administration officials indicated today that the United States was prepared to bow to the demands of President de Gaulle for the withdrawal of all American allied military installations from France by next spring.
Robert Moses, oblivious to time or political shifts, outlined yesterday his billion-dollar highway program for the next ten years.
CLEVELAND, Thursday, March 31--The Brotherhood of Firemen and Enginemen struck eight railroads from Maine to the West Coast at 12:01 A.M. today.

The nation's psychiatrists are overwhelmingly in favor of liberalizing the laws against abortion, but less than one-fourth want to legalize it entirely, according to a poll conducted by the Association for the Study of Abortion.
QUITO, Ecuador, March 30-- Clemente Yerovi Indaburu was sworn in this afternoon as Provisional President of Ecuador.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., March 30 (UPI)--A once popular teen-age community center closed today because of alleged rowdiness by trainees from a nearby Job Corps Camp.
Prices for semifabricated aluminum were advanced by 4 per cent in London yesterday by Alcan Industries, the British subsidiary of Aluminium, Ltd.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 29--Taksim Square in downtown Istanbul contains one of the most arresting monuments in the Middle East: a 15-foot bayonet jutting skyward from a pile of rough rocks.
BUFFALO, March 30--An independent research organization announced today a major effort to rate the relative importance of different causes of automobile accidents.
Julius Garfinekel Co., whose management believes it is "obviously winning the fight with Genesco, Inc., disclosed yesterday that it would spend well in excess of
Two real estate promoters, whose syndication scheme for the purchase of a Texas motel collapsed, causing investors to lose $280,000, have been barred from selling securities in New York State.
LONDON, March 30--Britain's highest court ruled today that the Aintree race course, home of the Grand National, could be sold for housing.

BUENOS AIRES, March 30 --A United States-Latin American stalemate over trade policy has introduced a note of frustration here into a meeting reviewing the Alliance for Progress on its fifth anniversary.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- He was an old man, living on a monthly $96 Social Security check, when he underwent an eye operaton.
UNLIKE most of the antiques shows in or out of New York, an exhibition arranged and managed by nonprofessionals opens today in Princeton, N.J.
COLUMBIA, S.C., March 30 (UPI)--The South Carolina Democratic party revolted against old-line segregationists today and made an open appeal for the Negro vote.

BOULDER, Colo., March 30 (UPI)--Cazzie Russell and four other members of the Dearborn (Mich.) team that won the Amateur Athletic Union basketball title were named today to an 11-man squad for the world amateur championship at Santiago, Chile, April 16 to 30.

After much political shadowboxing between New York and Albany to establish the rules of the game, the City Council is finally about ready to go to work on the Lindsay tax-reform program. A trip to Albany by Mayor Lindsay brought agreement with legislative leaders on procedural legalities, but not on the taxes themselves.

CINCINNATI, March 30-- Most of the 12,107 persons in Cincinnati Gardens tonight hoped to witness the end of the longest championship reign of any major sports team in history--that of the Boston Celtics. Even the Cincinnati Royals had champagne on ice awaiting a celebration.

LONDON, March 29--Western Europe is unanimous in only one analysis of President de Gaulle's virtual resignation from the Atlantic alliance. It believes that with a single stroke he has enormously and dangerously enhanced the importance and the role of West Germany in world affairs.

Twenty-two kindergarten pupils went on stage at the Carmelite School on East 29th Street yesterday and lifted tiny voices in praise of the policeman who has watched for the safety of school children there for 25 years.

Eight fathers have been charged with trying to buy immunity from military service for their sons. Seven of the fathers were arrested in the metropolitan area yesterday, along with the young men who allegedly expected to benefit.

RICHMOND, Va., March 30-- The Richmond school board agreed today to desegregate its teachers, with more Negro teachers to be assigned to predominantly white schools and white teachers to predominantly Negro schools.

Regine Crespin is such a fine singer and solid actress that she is good in almost any role. Yet when she sang the title role in Puccini's "Tosca" last night at the Metropolitan Opera for her first time this season, while her work was always admirable and sometimes genuinely exciting, the characterization on the whole lacked the temperamental flair that makes Tosca, Tosca.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 30--Indonesia's Cabinet was formally installed by President Sukarno today, but there was increasing public criticism of its make-up. Indications were that it would be changed again.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)--Farm product prices fell one-third of 1 per cent during the month ended March 15.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- A Baptist church in Florida and its pastor have been charged with fraudulently offering for sale $14.5-million of unregistered bonds.
A 46-year-old woman who has been dancing, acting and backstaging for 25 years has come up with a hit her first time out as an associate producer.

ALBANY, March 30--Republican and Democratic leaders of the Legislature were reported nearing agreement today on postponing the primary election until June 28 and advancing the statewide nominating conventions to about Sept. 7.
Rosa Bonillo, her shockmarred face surrounded by a black bandana, escaped with her 10 children from a Brooklyn slum yesterday, but only long enough to bury her husband.
The cigarette industry has a new irritant the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 The Kansas City Athletics are a baseball team with green and gray traveling uniforms, gold suits for ceremonial occasions, a mule that takes a bow at home plate, a catcher who summons the mule with a hog call, a manager from the Giants, a coach from the Yankees and the worst record in the big leagues last year outside of the New York Mets.
WASHINGTON, March 31 The District of Columbia's highest court ruled today that a chronic alcoholic could not be convicted of the crime of public drunkenness.
More than 800 news, advertising and office workers would lose their jobs under the planned merger of three New York newspapers.
Miss Frances Kahn, 37-yearold lawyer, and two men codefendants have been sentenced by Federal Judge Edward C. McLean to two years in prison for conspiring to obstruct justice.
BOSTON, March 31 Boston absorbed 12,000 extra commuters in its parking facilities and transit system today with a minimum of problems.
TRENTON, March 31 (AP) The New Jersey Racing Commission indicated support today for a bill to permit night harness racing in the state.
SAIGON, Friday, April 1 Vietcong terrorists exploded a huge bomb at a United States military billet this morning and battled their pursuers with machine guns as they fled.

SINGAPORE In the near future Singapore's shrewd Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew will demand that London renegotiate the contract for Britain's enormous base on this island off Southeast Asia's coast. The subsequent bargaining is bound to be of critical importance to U.S. Pacific defense.

CHICAGO, March 31 (UPI) Cassius Clay's lawyer appeared in court today and paid Clay's $10 traffic fine for passing a stop sign moments after a magistrate threatened to issue a warrant for the heavyweight champion's arrest.
CORDELLE, Ga., March 31 (AP) Negro youths climaxed a wild demonstration on the courthouse lawn today by hauling down the United States and Georgia flags and ripping them from the lanyard.
WASHINGTON, March 31 Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman expressed pleasure today with the fact that the prices of farm products had dropped recently.
ROME, March 31 (UPI) Poland has ruled out a visit this year by Pope Paul VI, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission announced tonight it would dismiss a 14-year-old antitrust case against the Pillsbury Company, but would review carefully any future acquisitions proposed by the concern.
Gabriel Lowenstein, a retired businessman, died yesterday at his home, Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South. He was 93 years old.
TAMPA, Fla. March 31, (UPI) The Baltimore Orioles acquired today Vic Roznovsky, a catcher, from the Chicago Cubs for Carl Warwick, an outfielder.

With Arthur, Sybil Burton Christopher's East 54th Street discotheque, due to reach the ripe old age of one year on May 5, the avant-garde of Manhattan's Restless Set may well be game for a new scene, a nice, noisy home-away-from-home where one can frug without appearing to conform.

At 8 A.M. today a longshoreman will appear at one of the 13 hiring centers maintained by the Waterfront Commission with his identification and seniority card. It is plastic with square holes for computers and upside-down, or backward, digits and letters.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 112.5 on Wednesday from 112.7 on Tuesday.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 31 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William E. Pardoe of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Grace Pardoe, to Lee McCluer Marshall Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall of Rye.

The naval architectural firm of Gibbs Cox announced yesterday the appointment of Matthew G. Forrest to the new post of executive vice president. Mr. Forrest had been vice president in charge of naval architecture.
More stockholders will be attending a greater number of annual and special meetings in a wider range of cities on April 26 than in any other day of the year.
A former student at James Monroe High School and his elder brother, said to be the "prime operators" of a Marijuana traffic at the school, have been arrested with a Monroe student.
Three upstate banks found a welcome at the Bankers Trust Company yesterday. Stockholders at the annual meeting approved a previously announced proposal to form a new holding company.

The Studebaker Corporation was granted a temporary restraining order by the Federal District Court in Grand Rapids, Mich., blocking the Allied Products Corporation and Burt Kleiner of the California investment firm of Kleiner, Bell Co. from "inducing the purchase or sale of Studebaker or Allied stock."
The May Department Stores Company and the McCrory Corporation, two of the nation's leading retail-chain companies, reported yesterday record earnings for the fiscal year ended last Jan. 31.
WASHINGTON, March 31 Three key Democratic members of the House proposed today significant revisions in President Johnson's Demonstration Cities Bill.
A 200,000-share offering of the Harnischfeger Corporation's common stock priced at $43 a share has been completely sold, the First Boston Corporation managing underwriter, reported yesterday.
Jacob B. Steinfeld of 135 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, a lawyer at l6 Court Street in that borough, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 68 years old.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., March 31 Harry H. Pethick, a retired management and marketing executive of the Standard Oil Company of New York and successor companies, died Tuesday at Moore Memorial Hospital. His age was 78.
WHEN President Johnson announced yesterday that a newly appointed special assistant named Robert Ed monds Kintner would advise him on a broad range of matters, he was not speaking loosely.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 31 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean Moffitt King of Long Beach, Calif., defeated Gail Russell of South Africa, today, in the third round of the women's singles in the South African tennis championships.
SAIGON, March 31 A struggle seemed to be developing within the Buddhist movement today, complicating the political crisis in South Vietnam.

ALBANY, March 31 (AP) The Court of Appeals dismissed today an indictment accusing a former Long Beach official of taking more than $25,000 to assure the sale of more than 1,500 parking meters to that city.
ALBANY, March 31 The Assembly approved a bill today that would allow the revocation of DPL license plates of diplomats who commit three parking violations within one year.
FOUR of the six members of the North American team that will battle for the World Championship against Italy later this month will be engaged in training matches this weekend at Grossinger's, ...
WASHINGTON, March 31 Representative Adam Clayton Powell accused "phony liberals" today of trying to split his House Education and Labor Committee "because I am a Negro."

ALBANY, March 31 With the grace of an elephant and the confusion of a circus backlot on move-out day, the Legislature shoveled a heap of bills into the approved bin, made some last-minute deals and scurried off tonight to enjoy a two-week spring recess.
ALBANY, March 31 The state's highest court, rejecting a score of protests, refused today to change its order of last week that mapped new districts for members of the Legislature.

The snick of nibbling scissors and the flap of hot towels sounded for the last time last night in the Astor Hotel barber shop. The shop closed after 62 years of continuous operation. The hotel is to be torn down to make way for a 40-story skyscraper.

WASHINGTON, March 31 A survey of India by a team from the American food Industry has found a danger of further violence and of a political upheaval arising from frustrated hopes, hunger and preelection agitation.

THE HAGUE, March 31 Gysbert Van Hall, the Mayor of Amsterdam, has refused permission for groups of youths calling themselves the Provos, short for provocateurs, to demonstrate Saturday to protest police action against them.
WASHINGTON, March 31 Congress served notice today that it intends to have a voice in the decisions of the national arts and humanities endowments.

MOSCOW, March 31 Criticism of writers who "smear the heroic past of the Soviet people" and "depict Soviet life in black colors" is developing as a sharp theme of the 23d congress of the Soviet Communist Party.

Union leaders representing 113,000 city employes announced their approval yesterday of a new plan for the city's labor relations. Support for the plan, which affects 175,000 employes, was urged by George Meany, President of the American Fed eration of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) A 2.9 per cent pay rise for 1.8 million Federal employes was unanimously approved today by the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee.

BOSTON, March 31 High school boys punched and kicked seven anti-Vietnam demonstrators on the steps of the South Boston District Court House today after four of the protesters had burned their Selective Service cards.
WASHINGTON, March 31 President Johnson estimated today that enemy fighting strength in Vietnam was reduced by approximately 50,000 men in the first three months of this year. [Question 10, Page 18.]
The New York University Medical Center has received its first contribution, $500,000, toward the construction of an unusual 25-story tower atop its Alumni Hall at 550 First Avenue.
WASHINGTON, March 31 Following is the transcript of President Johnson's news conference at the White House today:
NEWARK, Friday, April 1 (AP) Employes of three supermarket chains began what a union spokesman called a "limited" strike at midnight, but negotiations continued with management.

BOSTON, March 31 (UPI) A scheduled demonstration outside Richard Cardinal Cushing's residence was called off today after his promise to review the cases of seminarians expelled from St. John's Roman Catholic Seminary. The seminarians had participated in a silent vigil for academic freedom.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) The Justice Department said today it planned to go to court tomorrow in an attempt to block the merger of the Central-Penn and Provident National Banks of Philadelphia.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 31 Liu Shao-chi, chief of state of Communist China, promised Pakistan today that she could count on Peking's "unswerving" support in case of "aggression."
Six students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology expect to emerge this morning at the Pelham Bay Park station on the IRT Lexington Avenue subway line with a record to their credit.

WASHINGTON, March 31 President Johnson today appointed Robert E. Kintner, former head of the National Broadcasting Company, and Walt Whitman Rostow, a high ranking official of the State Department, as special assistants.
Schenley Industries, Inc., the large distiller, announced the elections here yesterday of Bernard Goldberg and William E. Devereaux as vice presidents and directors.
The Federal Reserve may be pausing in its long, steady drive toward tighter money.

Zip, and off come a woman's bangs. Another zip, and her topknot comes off. The trick is a framework of Velcro, the fastening that adheres to itself. One half is pinned to the woman's hair, the other half is glued inside the hairpiece.

Minute specks of life that a fisherman might dredge from the sea or a child scoop up from a pond or lake and brush off have been turned into dazzling Cinderellas by the magic wand of the American Museum of Natural History.

State Senator Samuel L. Greenberg, Democrat of Brooklyn, sponsored yesterday a bill that would permit commercial banks to establish branches in seven major cities throughout the state. The bill was introduced through the rules committee.
WASHINGTON, March 31 Spokesmen for a controversial Negro-led boycott of merchants who oppose home rule for the District of Columbia announced today a major expansion of their tactics.

LONDON, March 29 Although the Western alliance is preoccupied these days by its internal diplomatic and military crises, many of its most distinguished public figures are more deeply troubled by the longterm outlook for world trade and distribution of wealth.

CHICAGO, March 31 Bernard Glickman, a little man who entered sports through the back door 15 years ago, arrived under heavy guard today to recount his sad story to a Federal grand jury hearing testimony on racketeering in boxing.
"Yes, I do play, I think," Vladimir Horowitz said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 30 Continuing political unrest in South Vietnam may bring the Johnson Administration face to face with a tormenting double question:

Hiter H. Lowry, former director of apparatus and system engineering for the Bell Telephone Laboratories in New York, died Wednesday in Princeton (N.J.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 56 Elm Road, Princeton.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 31--This was ego-deflation day for some of the younger New York Yankees who had been doing well during most of spring training. Bobby Murcer, Dooley Womack, Jack Cullen and Roy White had their troubles in the course of a 10-inning, 6-3 loss to the Minnesota Twins.
ALBANY, March 31 (AP) Thousands of sportsmen will crowd New York's streams and lakes tomorrow for the opening of the trout season.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 31 The 7,000 workers in the Kennecott Copper Corporation's copper mine at El Teniente, who went on strike Jan. 3, today approved a management offer for resumption of a 15-month contract.
Richmond Newspapers, Inc., plans to make its first public offering of stock.
Mayor Lindsay announced yes- terday that he had set up a spe- cial program to reduce the increasing number of false fire alarms in the city.

Frank D. O'Connor, President of the City Council, who is generally considered the leading Democratic contender for Governor, has informed the party's state committee that he is willing to appear in a series of party forums starting May 14.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., March 31 Sam Holloway Bowers Jr., Imperial Wizard of the White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, surrendered here today to face Federal charges in the fire-bomb death of a Negro leader.

BUENOS AIRES, March 31 The Inter-American Economic and Social Council, the policy making body for the Alliance for Progress, adopted today an "immediate action program" of 23 points to make the project more effective.
SAIGON, March 31 United States troops swept a stretch of the Central Highlands near the Cambodian border today, a day after a brief but sharp clash with North Vietnamese regulars.
Mayor Lindsay has agreed to give business the same incentives under his proposed city corporate income tax that it now receives from the state.

WASHINGTON, March 31--There has been a substantial increase in the average cost per ship to the Government since the start of the $4.3-billion, 300-vessel fleet replacement program for the country's 14 subsidized steamship lines, Congress was told today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Ontario Securities Commission indicated today that they suspected an attempt at a "bear" raid on the stock of Consolidated Halliwell, Ltd., listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
CAIRO, March 31 The United Arab Republic has asked the United States for roughly $100-million in loans to finance three major development projects, usually reliable sources reported today.

THE second division teams in the National League have been forced to aban don all plans of welcoming the Los Angeles Dodgers to their undistinguished company. Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale have ended their holdouts, thereby restoring to the champions of the blooming universe their only hope of remaining a living, breathing, vital entity.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 31 Jimmy Kaspar scored with 5 minutes 24 seconds remaining in the game to break an 8-8 tie and give Hofstra a 9-8 lacrosse victory over the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 31 Bill Matusz pitched a fourhitter today as Seton Hall University defeated St. Francis College of Brooklyn, 5-1. It was the Pirates' second straight victory and the Terriers' opening game.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday vetoed all the 17 changes in the 1966-67 capital budget made by the City Council that had not been concurred in by the Board of Estimate.

SAYVILLE, L.I., March 31 Robert A. Curcio of Babylon was elected Republican chairman of Suffolk County here this morning, after a sharp challenge from a candidate backed by Perry B. Duryea, the Assembly minority leader.
The General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday that it would redeem 787,214 shares of its convertible preference stock on April 15.
A committee of major airlines proposed yesterday that its members take over the cost of redeveloping and operating Newark Airport from the Port of New York Authority.
Some balanced mutual funds have been placing greater stress on bonds at the expense of common stocks in the light of recent market conditions.

A surprisingly easy victory by Samuel Lefrak's Choke Point in the $10,000 Blue Grotto Handicap, word that Ogden Phipps's ailing Buckpasser was acting frisky in Florida and Braulio Baeza's decision to return to the races were the chief items of interest at Aqueduct yesterday.
City officials have ordered 20 Jeep-like vehicles to patrol parks at night; and are thinking of using police dogs in the subways.

Newbold Morris, former pressident of the City Council and Commissioner of Parks and twice a reform candidate for Mayor, died of stomach cancer Wednesday night at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 64 years old.
ST. LOUIS, March 31 (AP) The chairman of E.J. Korvette, Inc., said today that a declining trend in comparative store sales has been reversed.

PARIS, March 31 France has chosen to break the bilateral NATO agreements with the United States and Canada without making an attempt to challenge the view of the majority of her partners that these agreements contain no provisions for unilateral renunciation.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India will have an opportunity to tell Soviet leaders Sunday of her new understanding of the United States position in South Vietnam.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 31 Charles Lichtenstein, a New York City lawyer, died of pernicious anemia yesterday at Mount Vernon Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 36 Pryer Place.
LOS ANGELES, March 31 Sandy Koufax will receive about $130,000 from the Los Angeles Dodgers under terms of the 1966 contract he signed yesterday, rather than $120,000, as first believed.
The Colgate-Palmolive Company is moving more than $7million in billings from the D'Arcy Advertising Company, Inc., to the Wm. Esty Company, Inc.
ALBANY, March 31 The state's highest court ordered a new trial for a convicted killer today, because the police had fended off his lawyer while extracting a confession from him.

BALA-CYNWYD, Pa., March 31 A May wedding is planned by Miss. Wendy Acker and Elliott J. Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Weiss of Great Neck, L.I. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Acker, parents of the future bride.
GATLINBURG, Tenn., March 31 A.R. Jones, vice chairman and a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, will leave the TVA when his term expires on May 18.

Louis Ginsberg and Allen Ginsberg father and son, the one well tailored and clean shaven, the other shirt-sleeved and bearded matched rhymed stanzas against free verse last night before the Poetry Society of America. Judging by the applause, the contest ended in a tie.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) The United Mine Workers Union delayed today until noon Saturday a meeting of its 200-member Wage Policy Committee.

THERE were only two big standard names, Beetho ven and Wagner, on the program of the New York Philharmonic in Philharmonic Hall last night, but the program was far from standard. Lukas Foss, who was opening a four-week engagement as guest conductor of the orchestra's subscription series, can be depended on to come up with the unusual, and he did just that.

CHICAGO, March 31 Thousands of Chicago workers had a frustrating day getting to their jobs and back home today as a result of the strike that stranded 32,500 regular commuters on the electrified Illinois Central Railroad.

With its aide-memoire of March 11, 1966, the French Government informed the governments of (blank) of the measures that it was led to take where it is concerned, because of the impossibility of modifying by common agreement and in satisfactory conditions the arrangements in force in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
NEW ORLEANS, March 31 (AP) A Federal Court of Appeals trying to set guidelines for jury selection in the South reversed today the conviction of a Louisiana Negro sentenced to death in a rape case.

NO other ballet company in the world ever has offered, ever would or, as yet, ever could offer the kind of emotional and intellectual stimulation that was provided at the New York State Theater by the New York City Ballet last night.

FOR a thousand years during the Dark and Middle Ages something was hap pening in Western Europe that nobody at the time noticed. They were too busy surviving plagues, famines, wars and all the assorted hardships that made life short and violent. There were sharp ups and downs in ...

WASHINGTON, March 31 The United States, departing from the channels of diplomatic communication, has told the French people that President de Gaulle's decision to withdraw from allied military arrangements "seems to constitute a step backward toward a disastrous past."
WASHINGTON, March 31 A nation-wide system of scenic trails was proposed today.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 31 Premier Thanom Kittikachon of Thailand and Prime Minister Prince Souvanna Phouma of Laos today signed a joint communique to usher in what is hoped will be an era of closer cooperation between the two countries. Premier Thanom then left for home, completing a four-day official visit to Laos.
Gabriel Realty of Paramus, N.J., has named Chester A. Pynn president, succeeding the late John M. Gabriel, founder of the company.

WASHINGTON, March 31 The firemen's union, which struck eight major railroads early this morning, refused to return to work tonight and said it would appeal a Federal court order demanding that it end the strike.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 31 (UPI) A three-judge Federal panel dismissed today a suit filed by Negroes seeking to invalidate the election of all public officials in Lowndes County.
SEA GIRT, N.J., March 31 A giant steel pipe 28 inches in diameter stretched out of the ocean spewing sand and water onto a battered, eroded strip of beach here today.
Shrugging off the possibility of an increase in income taxes and the reality of an eight-line railroad strike, the stock market managed a half-hearted rally yesterday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 31 (AP) Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd and his segregationist Nationalist party today won the greatest election victory in South Africa's history.

The New York Hospital will benefit from a luncheon and fashion show to be held in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on April 21. Mrs. Crawford Hill is benefit chairman, and Mrs. William M. Duryea is president of the Women's Auxiliary of the Society of the New York Hospital, sponsor of the event.
LONDON, March 31 (AP) Pancho Gonzalez played more like a youngster than a 38-yearold tonight and won the $7,000 first prize in the London professional tennis championship.

Sir John Barbirolli made an indelible impression with his performance last night of Nielsen's "Inextinguishable" Symphony No. 4. It closed the second and last concert at Carnegie Hall by the Houston Symphony, part of that hall's valuable International Festival of Visiting Orchestras series.
Columbus, Ohio, sold $20.58million of bonds yesterday to a syndicate of underwriters led by the First National City Bank, Phelps, Fenn Co. and Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co.
Ramon Vinay started his long operatic career in 1938 as a baritone, switched to tenor and in that capacity made his Metropolitan Opera debut in 1946.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) Republican Congressional leaders said today that a tax increase was coming because the Johnson Administration "does not have the wish nor the wit nor the will" to cut spending.
CASA GRANDE, Ariz., March 31 (AP) Shozo Yoshinari, the ambidextrous pitcher from Japan, has failed to show enough ability with either arm to impress the San Francisco Giants.
The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7934, down 6 points from the previous day's level.

Ellen Zoe Hassman, a 17year-old celist, has won the $1,000 first prize in the Concert Artists Guild 1966 Award Competitions, it was announced yesterday. Miss Hassman, who attends the Professional Children's School and studies cello with Leonard Rose at the Juilliard School of Music, will have a Town Hall debut and appear with five orchestras.

MENDHAM, N.J., March 31 William H. Blake has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Laurie G. Blake, to John Franklin Sawyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Sawyer of Dorset, Vt., formerly of Tarrytown, N.Y.
The City Council committee studying air pollution control is likely to recommend measures somewhat stronger than those proposed by Mayor Lindsay, City Councilman Robert A. Low said yesterday.

Frank Theodore Greving, executive director of Community Research Associates, Inc., 124 East 40th Street, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 56 years old and a resident of Hastings-onHudson, N.Y.
The New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association has arranged a bridge party for April 18 at the York Club. Proceeds will go to the College of Church Musicians, scholarship fund.
What teen-agers can and can't wear to school is a topic that has evoked reactions ranging from anger and amusement to admiration, depending largely on the eye of the beholder.

ALBANY, March 31 Standing outside the back door to the Assembly chamber late this afternoon, Governor Rockefeller said he thought that the 189th session of the Legislature had been "pretty productive so far."
WHEN the Norwegian freighter Farland arrived here Wednesday, she carried 9 million feet of finished lumber and one 33-foot aluminum racing boat.
ROME, March 31 Western European nations have been urged to join in building a nuclear-powered submarine fleet to counter the Soviet Union's growing undersea power.
Two film and theatrical producers Seven Arts Productions Ltd., and Filmways, Inc. have proposed a merger involving more than $16-million in stock.
A May wedding is planned by Miss Audrey Haeberle and Richard Carl Gamage of New York. Their engagement has been made known by Miss Haeberle's brother, Henry Haeberle of New York.

Shea Stadium, the home of the Mets, Jets and occasionally the Beatles, will get its first prize-fight on May 21, when Jose Torres defends his world light-heavyweight title against Wayne Thornton of Fresno, Calif.
PARIS, March 31 A portrait of an inscrutably smiling woman strikingly similar to Mona Lisa and once attributed to Leonardo da Vinci was sold at auction here today for $3,400.

WASHINGTON, March 31 President Johnson issued a fervent appeal today to all segments of American society ranging from housewives to labor leaders to businessmen to municipal officials to members of Congress to hold down unnecessary spending.
Copper futures rose sharply yesterday in trading here. Buyers were attracted by gains in London, and reports that the Chilean Senate would debate a bill next week, which ...
DANANG, South Vietnam, Friday, April 1 (AP) A group of demonstrators detained one of the top military leaders of South Vietnam while he was visiting Hue today.

Christo's, 143 East 49th Street, EL 5-6531. This is a pleasant, comfortable, neat and frequently crowded steak house, and what's more the food is good. Although the emphasis is on steaks and chops, the evening menu has Italian entrees; at lunch there are several American dishes such as shirred eggs with country sausage.
TORONTO, March 31 (UPI) George Chuvalo has joined the growing ranks of those claiming to have spotted unidentified flying objects in the sky.
Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn announced yesterday it would erect an $11million building, to be called the Academic Tower, on its main campus at 333 Jay Street, near the Brooklyn Civic Center.
WASHINGTON, March 31 Manufacturers' inventories rose $424-million in February, somewhat less than in January, the Commerce Department reported today.

The marine section of the National Safety Council ended its two-day meeting yesterday with speeches that stressed the increasing cost of insurance, despite labor, industry and Government efforts to avert death and accidents on the waterfront.
LONDON, Friday, April 1 The Labor Government swept back into power early today with an indicated majority of more than 100 seats.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 31 Prof. and Mrs. Thomas Lloyd Reed of Providence and Wentworth, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Penelope Billings Reed, to Anthony Newcomb Doob, son of Prof. and Mrs. Leonard W. Doob of Woodbridge, Conn.
PHILADELPHIA March 31 The Provident National Bank and the Central-Penn National Bank said today they would fight an injuction suit to be brought against their merger.
HONG KONG, March 31 President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam, in a letter of greeting to the Soviet Communist party congress, has made a strong appeal for unity in the Communist bloc.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 31 (UPI) James M. Pendergast, nephew and political heir of the late Thomas J. Pendergast, was buried today with military honors in a family plot at Calvary Cemetery.
The New York Post unit of the Newspaper Guild voted 192 to 3 last night to authorize its executive committee to strike. The Post whenever it sees fit.

The bond market went through a series of moderate price swings yesterday and closed with most Government issues showing declines and most recently offered corporate bonds California school-aid bonds, up a bit.
Yesterday it was bargain day on the American Stock Exchange. The low-priced issues received much of the attention.

Harold Wilson has won an overwhelming endorsement from a British electorate that only seventeen months ago returned his Labor party to power with obvious reservations and the narrowest of majorities. The political leaders all said publicly that the issue of this 1966 campaign should be the state of Britain's economy; but everyone knew that, in fact, the issue was Harold Wilson.
TOKYO, March 31 The Government announced today a seven-year program to establish a system of artificial earth satellites to aid navigation.
ROME, March 31 The Italian film industry outdid its rivals in Europe again last year, according to Achille Corona, the Minister of Tourism and Entertainment.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 31 Joseph Otis Hammitt, a former vice president and director of the American Cyanamid Company and a former civic reform leader in New York, died yesterday in Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived on a 14-acre estate on Spring Brook Road here.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Dietrich Gruen of Chevy Chase, Md., of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Margery Ash Gruen, to Robert Pearce Myers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Myers of San Marino, Calif.
MOSCOW, March 31 (Reuters) The London Zoo's female panda, Chi Chi, and Moscow's panda, An An, had their first meeting today.

GEORGE BALANCHINE was wrong or perhaps misquoted when he said "Ballet is a woman." Just how wrong was demonstrated by the Robert Joffrey Ballet at New York's City Center last night when the company gave the world premiere of Gerald Arpino's ballet "Olympics."
MOSCOW, March 31 The Soviet Union, in another step aimed at putting a man on the moon, launched Luna 10 today with the announced plan of putting it into orbit around the moon.

WASHINGTON, March 31 James Farmer expressed today "concern, some irritation and puzzlement" over the unexplained delay in the allocation of Federal antipoverty funds for a massive literacy program that he connot yet get off the ground.
MIAMI BEACH, March 31 Four gunmen escaped today with possibly $2-million in jewels and other belongings by ransacking safety deposit boxes in a hotel health spa next door to the police station.
BUENOS AIRES, March 31--Mrs. John F. Kennedy and her children will visit a large cattle ranch in the hilly inland state of Cordoba.

Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas M. Grushko of Forest Hills, Queens have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandra N. Grushko, to John William Mitchell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Mitchell of Milwaukee.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 31 (Reuters) Fighting broke out along the EthiopianSomali border today for the first time in two years, it was announced here.
AUSTIN, Tex., March 31 Gov. John B. Connally Jr. and the United States Justice Department were at it again today.

MOSCOW, March 31 The Soviet Union gained an impressive show of support as against Communist China today as leaders of major Communist parties endorsed Moscow's attempts to heal the ideological and political schism of world Communism.
A capsule summary of ski conditions will be published until the end of the skiing season.

YONKERS, March 31 Murdock Hanover proved a 13-to-1 prize package for those among the 21,201 fans who backed the 4-year-old son of Torpid in the $25,000 American Preview Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
WASHINGTON, March 31 The United States gold stock showed no net change in February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

City officials hope to lease prison facilities soon from the State and also to attempt to release more prisoners awaiting trial in a move to relieve overcrowding at the Women's House of Detention and other jails.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 31 Three generals have now entered the race to succeed President Humberto Castello Branco, whose Government celebrated tonight the second anniversary of the revolution that placed it in power.

Twenty-six of the country's resident theater companies, including the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center and the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn., have formed an organization called the League of Resident Theaters.
Three men have been given new positions at the J. Walter Thompson Company, at the publication of the National Retail Merchants Association and at McGraw-Hill Publications.
The London Stock Exchange closed unchanged to fractionally lower yesterday while results of the general elections were awaited.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz called New Jersey labor and management negotiators to a meeting next Wednesday to discuss arbitration of a labor contract that aroused high-level Federal criticism for exceeding President Johnson's wage guidelines.
The Government expects to prosecute at least 15 more young men from Long Island on charges of having evaded military service by buying forged papers.
LONDON, March 31 (AP) Pickles, the mongrel dog that found the stolen World Soccer Cup, was left the only claimant today to the 3,000 ($8,400) reward.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 31 (UPI) Doug Sanders, mildly complaining of illness and camera jitters, shot a six-underpar 65 today for a stroke lead in the first round of the $100,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

Only one grain of comfort can be extracted from the elections in which South Africa's white minority has asserted more emphatically than ever its determination to dominate forever the voteless 80 per cent of the population. That is the survival with an increased, if still precarious, majority of Mrs. Helen Suzman, the only genuine opposition voice in a 170member House of Assembly.
WHITE PLAINS, March 31 James A. Shea of 44 Windsor Road, Port Chester, a lawyer for the All-State Insurance Company, died of cancer today in St. Agnes Hospital here. He was 52 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 31 In an 11th-hour move, President Johnson asked Congress late today for a two-month extension in the sign-up period for the medical insurance portion of the Medicare program.

The engagement of Miss Eileen Phyllis Bedell to Elliott Morton Kraus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred S. Kraus of Kearny, N.J., has been announced by Miss Bedell's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Bedell of Brooklyn.
NEWTON, Mass., March 31 (AP) Dr. Samuel Albert Levine, a pioneer in the treatment of coronary thrombosis, died today at the age of 75.
Harold Allen will join Josepthal Co. today as a limited partner, the member firm of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday.
TORONTO, March 31 Canadian subsidiaries of United States and other foreign corporations were asked by the Canadian Government today to file periodic confidential reports on operations and financing.
SALT LAKE CITY, March 31 Coffee shop employes and sightseeing bus drivers at the Union Pacific station had an unusually busy day today as a result of the strike.
MILWAUKEE, March 31 (AP) The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company said today it would ask the United States Supreme Court to reverse a San Francisco district court's antitrust decision against the concern.

WASHINGTON, March 31 Two men listed as trustees of a church accused of a $14.5-million bond fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that they had severed their connections with the church.

The New York Times Company increased its consolidated net income last year to $5,131,301, equal to $11.26 a common share, from $4,252,854, or $9.16 a share, in 1964, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

A special investigating committee of the American Association of University Professors has found St. John's University guilty of a "grievous and inexcusable" violation of academic freedom in the dismissal of 21 faculty members.
DETROIT, March 31 (UPI) Third-period goals by Bruce MacGregor and Norm Ullman lifted the Detroit Red Wings to a 5-3 victory over the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game tonight.

JEFFREY WALLIS, who switched from aircraft en gine design to providing women with clothes of the latest design when he inherited 28 "cheap, rough-tough retail shops" from his father, was in New York last week "to have my bottom smacked." More formally, he was here to see how his clothes are selling and how they look on customers. He pronounced himself happy on both counts.

WASHINGTON, March 31 Intercity truck tonnage and railroad freight traffic volume generated by carloadings in the latest week ending March 26 were both ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1965.
The National Basketball Association named the dates yesterday of the Western Division final playoff series between the Los Angeles Lakers and the St. Louis Hawks.
James E. Marcus, who is temporarily heading the Water Department, will recommend universal water metering in a report he will make soon to Mayor Lindsay, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 Following are excerpts from President Johnson's speech this morning to the second national legislative conferene of the National League of Cities in the International Ballroom of the Washington Hilton Hotel:
QUITO, Ecuador, March 31 Ecuador began to calm down today after two large towns had been released from control by Communist-led students.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., March 31 (UPI) Mayor Harry Wilklow Jr. asked the near-by Fort Custer Job Corps Center today to keep its trainees out of town for the next 30 days.
LONDON, March 31 After an internal, secret struggle, the Samuel banking family and allies, including the First National City Bank of New York, have become the dominant force in Hill, Samuel Co., Ltd.
The time has come when man can no longer continue using the land, sea and air as his "trash basket." He must find ways to cycle his wastes, both solid and liquid, back into the economy.
QUITO, Ecuador, March 31 Ecuador began to calm down today after two large towns had been released from control by Communist-led students.

GENEVA, March 31 The United States sought to assure the Soviet Union today it would consider no arrangement within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that would lead to the spread of nuclear weapons.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 31 (AP) Eleven 3-year-old colts will compete Saturday in the $100,000 added Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park.

WASHINGTON, March. 31 Walter O'Malley of the Los Angeles Dodgers, who is supposed to be tighter than an airplane window, has just agreed to pay Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale at least $225,000 for throwing a baseball this coming season.

New Yorkers can save $1 or $1.50 and in some instances more on a bottle of whisky, but only if they are adventurous and alert. Their problem is to find the relatively few package stores that have cut prices that much in defiance of suits and threats of suits by distillers.

The Board of Ethics ruled yesterday that there was no conflict of interest in the case of Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler, whose father-in-law owns part of several slum buildings in the Bronx.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, April 1 (UPI) The California boys team and the Washington girls squad won the giant slalom events today and took the firstday lead in the Western States junior team ski championships.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 1 (AP) Southern Illinois, the favorite in the 24th National Collegiate Athletic Association gymnastics championships, gained nine berths in qualifying rounds today for the final competition.
MILWAUKEE, April 1 (UPI) "Even the scoreboard is set up," said William Anderson, County Stadium manager, today. "We've got Pittsburgh vs. Milwaukee for opening day."

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 (AP) Maxie Baughan, disen chanted with his salary and the style of defense used by the Philadelphia Eagles, was traded to the Los Angeles Rams today, for two younger players and a future draft choice.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 1 The engagement of Miss Nancy Karen Griffin to Robert F. Schaul has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Bryant W. Griffin of Summit and Shelter Island, N.Y., parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Schaul is the son of Mrs. Thomas Moffat of Berkeley Heights and the late Harry Schaul.
SHORT HILLS, N.J., April 1 Edwin Franklin Britten Jr., former president of the Monroe Calculating Machine Company in Orange, died today in his home at 18 Lake Road. His age was 81.
By vetoing legislation that would have permitted corporations to advertise in campaign journals, Governor Rockefeller has ended, for New York State, a scandalous political practice.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (UPI) The Essex Wire Corporation of Fort Wayne, Ind., was named as defendant today in a $960,000 civil damage suit filed by a former company vice president, who claimed the concern violated the Securities and Exchange Act.

The Commonwealth Edison Company increased its commitment yesterday to nuclear power. In conjunction with Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Company it announced plans to build a jointly owned nuclear generating station about 20 miles north of Clinton and Davenport in Iowa and Rock Island and Moline in Illinois, the socalled "Quad Cities."
WASHINGTON, April 1 United States officials declined to comment publicly today on Ankara press reports that Turkey had asked the United States to terminate "spy flights" from Turkish airfields.
ROME, April 1 (AP) Clarence James of Oakland, Calif., outpointed Bruno Santini of Italy tonight in an eight-round middleweight bout.
Peter Weiss's play "Marat/ de Sade," is not only providing New Yorkers with a superbly theatrical evening, but may be doing something even more rare: arousing New York audiences ...

The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has heard an appeal by The New York Times seeking the reversal of a $40,000 libel judgment obtained from a lower court by Eugene Connor, former police commissioner of Birmingham, Ala.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 1 The Soviet Union is expected to open a bank here soon, its third in Western Europe. The Swiss banking community a nervous clan by nature and ever wary of outsiders who might violate their secrecy is unhappy but helpless.
Mayor Lindsay's half-billiondollar tax program was introduced in the City Council yesterday and touched off angry charges and countercharges of delay between the Mayor's office and the Council.
Automobile production in the United States fell 5.3 per cent in March, according to reports received yesterday from Detroit.
WASHINGTON, April 1 Two General Electric Company's engineers have invented a system of communication that uses extremely short pulses of light.
LONDON, April 1 Britain is talking with Greece about the possible use of force, with approval of the Greek Government, to divert a Greek tanker bound for Beira, Mozambique, with oil for Rhodesia.
Edward Garcia, a 32-yearold welder, dropped into Supreme Court to say hello to a friend yesterday and went to jail for a year.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India departed last night for London, Moscow and New Delhi convinced that her six-day visit to the United States was a solid triumph.
MILAN, Italy, April 1 (AP) All five defendants in a trial arising out of a high-school sex survey were acquitted tonight.

Four major lumber associations reported an increase of 8.4 per cent in production in the week ended March 26 as compared to the level in the corresponding 1965 week. Output was up 1.3 per cent from the preceding week.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 1 Southern New York fishermen had to shake snowflakes off the worms today before casting their offerings on the waters to celebrate the annual spring rites of opening day of the trout season.
LIMA, Peru The famous wooden balconies that over hang the streets of "Old Lima" are pulpits today for irate antiquarians trying to stop the bulldozers.

"It's just like at the trots," an overcoated follower of form said yesterday after watching Mrs. Edward Lasker's Indulto win the featured $10,000 onemile Sun Archer at Aqueduct before 26,008 patrons. "All you have to do is play No. 1."
DAKAR, Senegal, April 1 (AP) Lance-wielding tribal dancers in leopard skins lent a roaring welcome today to the World Festival of Negro Arts, Africa's largest such event.

SINKING SPRING, Pa., April 1 Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Thun have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia C. Thun, to George J. Willauer Jr. of Old Lyme, Conn. His parents are Dr. and Mrs. Willauer of Germantown, Philadelphia.
The appointment of Irving Layton as vice president and director of fashion and styling for the Pacific Mills divison of Burlington Industries, Inc., was announced yesterday.
BOLOGNA, Italy, April 1 (AP) Simmenthal of Milan, paced by two American stars, Skip Thoren and Bill Bradley, beat Slavia of Prague, 77-72, tonight for the European basketball championship.
Department stores in New York City during March showed an average gain in sales of 12.2 per cent above the volume in the month last year, according to the monthly survey made by The New York Times.
LONDON, April 1 Harold Wilson returned to 10 Downing Street today to begin shaping the new Labor administration that will govern Britain for the next several years.
WASHINGTON, April 1 After six months of delay, the Office of Education has made its first move to cut off funds from a school district accused of failing to live up to its desegregation pledge.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 112.3 on Thursday from 112.5 on Wednesday.

Delays and accident risks in fog in the Staten Island ferry service may be considerably reduced later this year. The city's Department of Marine and Aviation so indicated when it announced yesterday that it has ordered a bad weather navigational system.

PLASTIC hats, shoes and dresses, pants suits to wear to parties, at home and in the rain, and fashions combining two or more colors and patterns these are some of the trends for fall presented yesterday by The Fashion Group.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) Lawyers for the Congressional committees that handled a new uniform daylight saving act said today that all states that had planned to observe daylight time this summer could do so.

The Riverdale Chapter of the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital in Denver will observe its 10th anniversary on April 23 with a spring luncheon and fashion show in the Trianon Ballroom of the New York Hilton.

Genesco, Inc., which has been seeking control of Julius Garfinckel Co., through a tender offer, renewed yesterday its attempts to obtain a list of shareholders of the Washingtonbased retail organization.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., April 1 (AP) Northrop Clarey, retired executive of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), a former newspaper reporter, editor and publisher and a founder of the National Better Business Bureau, died yesterday at a local hospital. He was 84 years old.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 1 In an effort to make its parks safer after sundown and to reduce increasing vandalism, Nassau County has enlisted the services of 300 volunteer policemen.

PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, April 2 (AP) The Transport Workers Union struck the Pennsylvania Railroad today. John Mellon, president of Local 213, said the union was striking over job losses caused by the firemen's strike.

ALL those years that it was fashionable to make fun of Ernest Hemingway, to say that he no longer had it and that he was one big bundle of death wishes and compulsive masculinity, the man still seemed to remain so invincible.

Robert L. Cooper, executive director of Harlem Teams for Self-Help, the youth group formerly known as Associated Community Teams, Inc., or ACT, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 615 West 145th Street.
MADRID, April 1 The hydrogen bomb lying in the Mediterranean near Palomares since Jan. 17 has sunk into the mud of the steep underwater slope where it was located on March 16.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The Federal National Mortgage Association set new restrictions tonight on mortgage purchases in an attempt to slow up its secondary market dealings. These dealings are now running at a high rate because of the tight money market.
Holy Week, marking the eventful seven days that culminate in Easter on April 10, begins tomorrow Palm Sunday for Christians around the world.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The Senate Interior Committee deferred action today on the nomination of Robert L. Bennett as Commissioner of the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The delay came after the bureau wars subjected to sharp criticism.
ACORA, Ghana, April 1 (Reuters) Three leading aides of the deposed President Kwame Nkrumah, freed from protective custody four days ago, have been taken back to prison.

The National Academy of Design has elected Alfred Easton poor, architect and architectural adviser, is its new president. Mr. Poor succeeds Edgar I. Williams, also an architect; who, served four years.

Saul I. Birnbaum, a 43-yearold certified public accountant, was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison by Federal Judge Irving Ben Cooper for arranging a $20,000 bribe of an Internal Revenue Service agent.

Sason I. Zacharia, proprietor of Aria Lingerie, 555 Broadway, a manufacturer of women's underwear, died yesterday at the Sephardic Home, 2266 Cropsey Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 58 years old and lived at 2 Regent Drive, Lawrence, L.I.
Nine municipal courses will open for New York golfers today at 6 A.M. This will bring the number of public courses available to 13, as four are in use on a year-round basis.

Billy Rose's two sisters sought yesterday to gain administrative control of their brother's estimated $30-million estate including the late showman's 45-room mansion, which they want to give to the United States for use as a "New York White House."
The touchy issue of legislative ethics, which most lawmakers happily thought would lie dormant in the Legislature this election year is, about to explode again.

WASHINGTON, April 1 Birth control instruction and contraceptives will now be supplied to all American women who need and request them under a significant new policy laid down by John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
BUFFALO, April 1 Alfred H. Kirchhofer retired as editor of The Buffalo Evening News, ending a newspaper career of 56 years. The 73-year-old newsman had been editor of The News since 1956.

Behind the five-hit pitching of Dave Hillis, Columbia opened its baseball season with a 6-2 victory over Vermont yesterday at Baker Field. The junior lefthander struck out six and walked only one man.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., April 1 Marie E. Gaudette, former nature adviser of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America, died today at the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. Her age was 73.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 1 (UPI) The Senate approved today a Government measure to guarantee foreign loans to Chilean industry.
The president of the New York Building Trades Council charged yesterday that the city was delaying the start of largescale construction work.

BRIGHTON, England, April 1 The Labor Government's coolness toward the Common Market and the idea of an independent European force in the world was attacked tonight during a discussion by European officials at Sussex University.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 1 Indonesia's students went into the streets of Jakarta again yesterday and every politician and Cabinet minister stopped to watch what they were doing.
The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced here yesterday the election of Howard H. Hennington as vice president in its group department.
VENICE, Fla., April 1 (UPI) Clifford Ann Creed of Alexandria, La., shot a one-over-par 73 today and took the firstround lead in $8,500 Venice women's open golf tournament.

Handel's "Esther," thought to be the first English oratorio composed, was given its second performance here in five years at Town Hall last night. Johannes Somary, the conductor who revived the work in 1961, was again charge. The performers were the Amor Artis Chorale and Orchestra and nine soloists, including Netania Davrath, Betty Allen, Blake Stern, Stafford Wing and Kenneth Smith.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 1 Ireland notified Secretary General Thant today that she would withdraw her contingent of 518 troops from the Cyprus peace-keeping force on April 18.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The Federal Board of Parole granted freedom today to Harry Gold, a key Government witness in the espionage convictions of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, and to Irvin C. Scarbeck. Scarbeck was serving three concurrent 10-year terms for providing the Polish security police with classified documents while he was employed at the United States Embassy in Warsaw.
A CENTER-CUT pork loin roast deserves special at tention. Preparing it with a sugar glaze and a garnish of fruit slices, as in the recipe given here, makes it festive enough for a dinner party.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) Eleven senators called today for a fresh start in determining whether the controversial drug Krebiozen has any value.
Chief Inspector Sanford D. Garelik said yesterday that he hoped the public would report cases in which policemen lure homosexuals into breaking the law and then arrest them.

Three giant industrial companies said yesterday they would review plans for capital spending in response to President Johnson's concern over inflationary pressures. The President has appealed for restraint in expenditures from all segments of American society from business and labor to housewives and Congressmen.

Harold Fredericks, for 23 years night bartender at Bleeck's (pronounced "Blake's") Artist and Writers restaurant and a favorite of the newspapermen who frequented it, died of cancer at Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday. He was 54 years old and lived at 115-42 117th Street, Ozone Park, Queens.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1 Whether the Mets will be any better this season than they were last year is a matter of conjecture, but it is an undeniable fact that they have already won as many games as they did all last spring and still have nine exhibitions in which to improve their record.

Busoni lovers and there are few had a high time last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. A small, but dedicated throng turned up to hear Gunnar Johansen play a recital of his piano music, and the event proved three things: that Busoni is an abandoned gold mine, that Mr. Johansen is a first-class oldschool pianist and that more attention should be paid both.
WASHINGTON, April 1 The Administration, increasingly concerned over the political crisis confronting the Saigon Government, ordered a postponement today of all Congressional trips to South Vietnam.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., April 1 Mrs. Helen Murray Deegan, a retired public school teacher and the wife of Joseph F. Deegan, a lawyer here, died today in Perth Amboy General Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 75 Lewis Street.
SAN JUAN, P.R., April 1 (UPI) Tony Roche and John Newcombe of Australia advanced to the men's singles semi-finals of the Caribe Hilton tennis tournament today.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company observed its 81st birthday on Feb. 28 with record-breaking earnings and revenues for the first fiscal quarter and 12 months ended on that date.

BONN, April 1 The Government approved today a proposal by West German television authorities for a discussion program between West and East German politicians to be beamed simultaneously to both parts of their divided nation.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The Labor Department foreshadowed an end of the steep rise in consumer food prices today when it reported that the weekly wholesale price index had declined. This was the sixth consecutive week in which the index had declined or remained stable.

An order by the city that would have deprived hundreds of hospitalized children of holiday visits home was rescinded just in time to allow a few to go home for the weekend, a hospital director said yesterday.

Dr. George R. Santoro of 1293 Plandome Road, Plandome, L.I., clinical instructor in anesthesiology at University Hospital, New York University Medical Center, died in the hospital Thursday of a heart ailment. He was 53 years old.
WASHINGTON, April The Senate approved today a twomonth extension of last night's deadline for enrollment in the voluntary insurance program under the Medicare law.

Harry W. Perlman, who owned the H.W. Perlman piano manufacturing company at 54 Canal Street and its retail outlet at 345 Grand Street for many years, died yesterday in his home at 1199 Park Avenue. His age was 95.

Leonard Bernstein will conduct the New York Philharmonic in a Long Island Festival concert on July 30. This is the first event to be announced for the festival's 1966 season. THE recovery and rediscovery of 19th-century American painting continues. In the wake of the scholarly researches and critical revaluations now taking place, exhibitions are being organized that permit us to examine these earlier (and often all but lost) chapters in American art history with a fresh eye. The results are sometimes exciting, sometimes emphatically not.

Two experimental safety cars with sliding doors, ejectable front and rear windows, a new type of steel body construction, collapsible steering columns and heavily padded interiors were shown yesterday at the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park.

President Johnson's appointment of Walt W. Rostow to his staff brings back to the White House one of the architects of John F. Kennedy's foreign policy. With McGeorge Bundy's one-time deputy designated to take over many of Mr. Bundy's former functions, there is an assurance both of professional competence and of continuity in one of Washington's most critical posts.

THE fastest moving material in dress fabric departments these days is patent vinyl, a slick-looking plastic-coated cotton. Manufacturers are rushing it into the stores the minute they get a supply on hand and customers are carrying it out so quickly that wholesalers are constantly behind with orders.

PARIS, April 1 The French Government today vetoed the release of a film version of a 200-year-old work, Denis Diderot's "The Nun."
