WASHINGTON, April 3 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the week ending yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 3 Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert E. Jones have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Coats Jones, to Lieut. (j.g.) Lewis Atterbury Clarke Jr., U.S.N.R. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis A. Clarke.
MOSCOW, April 3--Leonid I. Brezhnev is leading the Communist party of the Soviet Union back to orthodoxy.

An incomplete Defense Department compilation showed yesterday that families of military personnel serving in Vietnam had received 100 threatening, abusive or crank telephone calls or communications in the last year.

A House appropriations subcommittee warned last week against "many potential pitfalls" to be avoided in the Government's new program to support the arts and humanities. The pitfall it did not mention was intrusion by subcommittees like itself.

President Johnson's latest pleas to businessmen and consumers for hold-downs in spending may have some effect in reducing inflationary pressures. Exhortation, after all, is a legitimate and sometimes useful weapon of economic policy. Certainly it contributed to the remarkable stability in wages and prices that prevailed until late in 1965. Without Mr. Johnson's unceasing efforts to induce labor and industry to accept voluntary restraints, the economy would now be in much more critical shape.

LONDON, April 3 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has protested to Ghana over the expulsion last month of several Soviet Embassy officials and other Russians serving in the country, the Moscow radio reported today.

Russel Crouse, whose 32year collaboration with Howard Lindsay in the theater has been hailed as the most successful since that of Gilbert and Sullivan, died of pneumonia yesterday afternoon in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 73 years old.
ATHENS, April 3 Greece has agreed to cooperate with Britain in any way, short of using force, to stop a Greek tanker from delivering oil to Rhodesia in defiance of the British embargo.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., April 3 Nolan Harrigan, chairman of the Republic Industrial Corporation and a retired senior vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died of a stroke last night in Mercy Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 32 Wellesley Road.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Anna Roeder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Roeder of New York, to James Michael Rosenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan H. Rosenberg of Roslyn, L.I., took place yesterday afternoon.

The schedule of bond offerings this week lists several sizable offerings, although none is as large as the American Telephone and Telegraph and California issues that met enthusiastic response last week.
VINELAND, N.J., April 3 Jules A. Morland, of Haddonfield, an executive of the Timken Roller Bearing Company, died last night at the age of 62.

THE defenders have somewhat fewer opportunities than the declarer for brilliant play, but the opportunities they do have often deserve study. To get the full flavor of today's deal, the reader is urged to cover up the South and West hands in the diagram.

THE portly president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen seemed relaxed and relieved yesterday in Washington as he issued a statement agreeing to end a four-day strike against railroads from Maine to the West Coast.

THE enterprising and brilliant Robert Joffrey Ballet ended its first Broadway season last night at the New York City Center. Its next season should be both soon and longer than this all-too-brief first encounter. Indeed, it would be fine if the Joffrey company could find a permanent place in the City Center organization.
BIG BEND NATIONAL PARK, Tex., April 3 Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson survived five and a half hours on the Rio Grande today, but it was a wonder.
A dinner to mark the 35th anniversary of the Jewish Braille Institute of America has been arranged for April 18 at the Pierre.

LE MANS, France, April 3 (UPI) Walt Hansgen remained on the critical list today in a United States military hospital at Orleans, after he smashed into a barrier on the famed Le Mans auto circuit yesterday during preliminary trials for the 24-hour classic June 18 and 19.

Now that the government is hotly investigating auto safety, or the lack of it, the shortcomings of structural design of cars finally are getting much needed attention. Jeffrey O'Connell, Professor of Law at the University of Illinois, and Arthur Myers, a free lance writer, contend in "Safety Last" that Detroit still wants to shift attention from its "dangerous" machine to the industry's favorite whipping boy, the bad driver.
VENICE, Fla., April 3 (UPI) Mickey Wright, who postponed her college career to return to golf, shot a par 72 today to gain a seven-stroke victory in the $8,500 Venice women's open golf tournament.
JAKARTA, April 3 President Sukarno is being urged by high-ranking officials in his new Cabinet to take a long holiday abroad.
ATHENS, April 3 Five more army officers and one in the air force have been arrested on charges of participating in a secret political organization known as Aspida.
WHEN Louise Barth, California housewife, boards the plane for Los Angeles today at Kennedy Airport, will she have found the house of her dreams?
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission reported tonight that motor vehicles and drugs were the most profitable industries during the 10-year period ended in 1964.
MEXICO CITY, April 3 (AP) The World Oil Congress will be held here in April of 1967, it was announced over the weekend.
WASHINGTON, Monday, April 4 The firemen's union last night ended its four-day strike against eight railroads about 12 hours after it had promised to go back to work.

In a financial link spanning thousands of miles. David Crystal, Inc., the oldest women's sportswear producer in the United States, has made an investment in the Star of Siam, a silk grower and fabric producer in Thailand.
Automation may make the jobs of office managers, department heads and even vice presidents more difficult if automation doesn't put them out of work.

"Why is this night different from all others?" The youngest members of Jewish households the worldover will ask this question tonight as they have for thousands of years past to start the week-long celebration of Passover.

LONDON, April 3 Observers at the Jodrell Bank radio astronomy station speculated tonight that Luna 10, the Soviet moon rocket, was tumbling uncontrollably in an orbit around the moon at a distance of 300 or 400 miles from it.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., April 3 Linda Marsh, an actress, was married today to Richard Sinatra, an actor. Judge Andrew W. Weiss of the Beverly Hills Municipal Court performed the ceremony at the Beverly Hills Hotel.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 3 Fred Peterson, the 24-year-old left-handed rookie who has won a place on the New York Yankee pitching staff, put forth his credentials for a starter's role by pitching seven innings today in an 8-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois said today that Republicans were going to call the Johnson Administration to account for what he described as wasteful spending in the foreign aid program.
HAMLET, N.C., April 3 (AP) A woodlands fire that crossed the South Carolina border and was raging out of control toward this North Carolina community was blocked before entering the city tonight.

SAIGON, April 3 (AP) United States infantrymen exchanged mortar and artillery fire with the Vietcong today near the Cambodian border in the Central Highlands. Enemy fire appeared to come from the border area.

SAIGON, April 3 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky announced today that loyal troops would be sent to "liberate" Danang from the crowds that have been demonstrating there for the overthrow of his military Government.
The influx of Spanishspeaking people into New York, which had tapered off during the last few years, is on the rise again, causing new changes and tensions.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 3 Miss Barbara Susan Hoffman daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Hoffman of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Jay Hilyard Rodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl C. Rodman of Flush ing, Queens.
UPPER MARLBORO, Md. April 3 Hal Keck of Heller town, Pa., in a Class A Shelby Cobra, won the Governor's Cup before a capacity crowd of 10,000 today on Marlboro's 1.7-mile road course.
A folk concert was presented at Town Hall Saturday night by the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee. About 700 persons attended the benefit for civil rights projects.

WASHINGTON, April 3. After eight years of argument, the proposal to fix a single Government policy on the ownership of rights to patents resulting from Federal contracts has moved closer to Congressional enactment.
A seamen's union with $92million in its pension fund is about to build $14-million of skyscraper apartment houses in four major cities of members and their families.
Vladimir Ashkenazy was the piano soloist with the London Symphony Orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall, and he brought down the house.
Miss Wendy Jo Tasch, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph J. Tasch of Rye, N.Y., became the bride last evening of Theodore C. Salomon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Salomon of Kings Point, L.I.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 3 (AP) The Naval Academy won two of the day's three races and emerged as the champion today in the John F. Kennedy Memorial Regatta.

BOSTON, April 3 (UPI) The Boston Bruins ended a record five-year residency in the National Hockey League cellar tonight with a 4-2 victory over Chicago in their final game. The victory moved them into fourth place in the league standings, ahead of the New York Rangers.

Jim Lombardi of the Central Jersey Track Club pulled away from Ed Bowes of the New York Athletic Club in the final 300 yards yesterday and won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union 10,000-meter run at Macombs Dam Park in the Bronx.
Capt. Phillip E. Shaw ,U.S.C.G. retired, died Saturday of a heart attack in his home at 106 Woodland Avenue, Shore Acres N.J. He was 69 years old.

The Society of the Silurians, an organization of New York newspapermen, announced awards yesterday for three reporters, three photographers, an editorial writer, a cartoonist, a graduate student and a newspaper.

The annual meeting of the Studebaker Corporation, scheduled for April 28, may be postponed because of litigation stemming from action by a group of dissident stockholders, according to a Studebaker spokesman last night.
WASHINGTON, April 3 Gen. Wallace M. Greene Jr., Commandant of the Marine Corps, disputed today Premier Nguyen Cao Ky's statement that the city of Danang in South Vietnam was in a state of revolt.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), March 30 "he Arab states will not integrate the Palestine refugees because integration would be a slow process of liquidating the Palestine problem," Ahmed Shukairy, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, declared in an interview today.
NEWARK, April 3 A new agreement covering wages and fringe benefits was reached this afternoon between three supermarket chains and leaders of 10,000 striking employes.

NAPLES, Italy, April 3 (AP) Cheer Honey, an Americanborn mare, captured the Agnano trotting grand prix today and earned $240,000 for the winner of a national lottery held in conjunction with the race.
TORONTO, April 3 The abnormal manner in which Canada financed her chronic trade deficit last year is raising questions concerning the financing of an equally large deficit expected in 1966.
The Police Department has set up a special detective unit to try to halt the increasing flow of bootleg untaxed cigarettes into New York City.

Rod Steiger's acting in the title role of "The Pawnbroker" and Julie Andrews's work in the musical "The Sound of Music" were judged the best performances by movie stars last year in the poll of critics conducted by The Film Daily, the trade paper.

MOSCOW, April 3 In a dark corridor at the head of the stairs in Moscow's Central Synagogue this morning, about 50 middle-aged and elderly men and women stood pressed together before an open door. They were waiting for their portion of matzon.
CLEVELAND, April 3 The children of Hough walked through a spring snowfall today carrying small bags of groceries past garbage and debris into dark, cavernous buildings.
PITTSBURGH, April 3 Reports from steel mills last week pointed to a full test of production capacity.

THE man was short-changed and that's no way to treat Jimmy Johnston, as colorful, imaginative and clever a fight manager to have used flimflammery to manipulate an assortment of second-raters into an endless succession of lush paydays. So this is an attempt to make amends to a lovable rascal who was such a vibrant figure in that golden era when boxing was a vibrant sport.

TRENTON, April 3?Republican oldliners reject it and most of the party's professionals tend to loathe it, but at least two key Republican leaders see a sales tax as giving their party an unusual chance to come in from the cold.
Robert Moses attacked his critics today while calling for the blessings of beauty on the nation's public works, especially its roads.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 3 A large group of black political prisoners, due to be recharged under the Suppression of Communism Act with the crime of supporting African nationalist causes, will apparently go on trial without legal defense.

WASHINGTON, April 3 President Johnson, in his State of the Union Message, announced plans to relax trade restrictions against the Communist countries of Eastern Europe. However, no bill to accomplish this has been published or sent to the Capitol by the White House.
The owner of a Manhattan advertising agency was nominated for Governor yesterday on the Socialist Labor party ticket.

Charles H. Ashton, an actor and theatrical producer, died yesterday in the Los Angeles Veterans Hospital. He was 63 years old and had moved to Los Angeles two months ago from here, where he had lived at 29 East 20th Street.
WILMINGTON, N.C., April 3 Conservationists and beach developers are at war here over the future of Cape Fear, one of the East Coast's oldest navigational landmarks.

Temple Emanu-El was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Miss Lisa Kimmel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Kimmel of Montreal, to Robert L. Steele, son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Stelboum of New York. The bridegroom changed his name.
The Rangers slipped quietly into last place last night as 14,310 fans pleaded for goals that never came against the Montreal Canadiens' finely honed hockey team.
NICE, France, April 3 (UPI) Istvan Gulyas of Hungary won the men's singles in the Nice international tennis tourney today when he beat Daniel Contet of France, 6-1, 6-0, 13-11.
SARASOTA, Fla., April 3 (AP) The Houston Astros obtained Felix Mantilla from the Boston Red Sox in exchange for Eddie Kasko today.

THE London Symphony, on a world tour, paused in New York on Friday evening for the first of four Carnegie Hall concerts. Its conductor is Istvan Kertesz, the 37-year-old Hungarian who is being spoken about as one of the up-and-coming maestros.
It was announced yesterday that John B.M. Place, a banker and civic leader, had been named general chairman of the 87th annual appeal of the United Hospital Fund.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 3 Eighteen years after the war, Israel's Arab population seems to be economically integrated but appears to be encountering many of the problems of a national minority.
MARY MARTIN and Radio City Music Hall pooled their considerable resources last night for an hour of song and spectacle that was as pleasant and mild as spring itself.

NEW DELHI, April 3 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi returned home from her 10-day foreign tour tonight with pledges of food relief for her country and promises of visits to India by three world leaders.
SAIGON, April 3 (AP) A high-ranking United States official reported today that North Vietnam had vastly increased the flow of men and materiel to the South in the last two months.
BOSTON, April 3 (UPI) Students at St. John's Roman Catholic Seminary began today a "holy fast" protesting the expulsion of eight seminarians and "an atmosphere of dusty medievalism."
WHAT with the way knitted fabrics are booming these days, a woman is likely to make the first addition to her fall wardrobe in May before she has even thought about her swimsuit.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 The Philadelphia 76ers are considered the team with the best chance to dethrone the Boston Celtics as champions of the National Basketball Association, but they gave no such indication today as the Celtics routed them, 115-96. The game in the rickety old Philadelphia Arena was the first in the Eastern Division final playoff.

SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., April 3 (AP) Jean-Claude Killy led a French sweep of the first three places in the two-run men's slalom today over a bumpy, icy course in the High Sierra Cun ski championships.
Last year, the National Symphony of Washington, which had never played here regularly, decided to inaugurate a lowpriced series of Sunday afternoon "family" concerts at Philharmonic Hall.

Joseph A. Casanova, an art director and owner of an advertising sales promoting agency, died of a heart ailment Saturday in his home at 40 West 45th Street. He was 57 years old and also resided in Falls Village, Conn.

ROCHESTER, April 3 (AP) Bob Kwiecien and Tony Loiacano, a pair of Detroit keglers who never had bowled before as doubles partners, moved into first place today in the regular two-man standings at the American Bowling Congress tournament with a 1,351-pin series.
Miss Patricia Sue Konheim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Konheim of New York, was married last evening to Joel S. Heffron. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Heffron of Brooklyn.
SAN JUAN, P.R., April 3 (UPI) Arthur Ashe of Richmond displayed a lightning-fast service today in defeating Cliff Richey of Dallas, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4, in the final of the Caribe Hilton tennis tournament.
The last 23 World's Fair torn down by July and Flushing Meadow Park, restored and improved, will be returned to the city by December, Robert Moses, president of the fair, announced yesterday.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 3 The marriage of Miss Judith Kleinman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kleinman of Kendall Park, to Norman Arshan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Arshan of Highland Park, took place today. Rabbi Jack D. Spiro performed the ceremony in the Bow and Arrow Manor.

Starting next fall, 170 first graders at the Brentwood School in East Palo Alto, Calif., will be introduced to the three R's by an infinitely patient, infinitely tactful teacher who knows all the answers: a computer.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 3 (AP) Frank Schmitz of Southern Illinois captured two gold medals as gymnasts from the Midwest dominated the final round in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship at Penn State last night.
WHITE PLAINS, April 3 In the Jewish Community Center this afternoon, Miss Judith P. Meshberg became the bride of Samuel E. Oberman. Rabbi Richard Sternberger performed the ceremony.

Paul Cranis, with a game geared to slick board courts, moved into the fourth round of the Empire State indoor tennis championships yesterday at the 369th Regiment Armory, Fifth Avenue and 142d Street.
Welfare Commissioner Mitchell I. Ginsberg said yesterday that he would not reshuffle his department merely to put Negro social workers in Negro areas.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) The Treasury Department estimates that sales of Series E Savings Bonds, which trace their origin to the first Victory Bonds issued 25 years ago, will reach 105 million issues in fiscal 1967, up 3.3 million from the fiscal 1966 level.

Average interest rates charged on short-term loans to business during the first 15 days of March by large New York City banks rose to 5.35 per cent, the highest level since early 1930, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The New York Legislature has accomplished little in its first three months, except perhaps to get ready to make law. It has approved a somewhat reduced Rockefeller budget, but will probably repent its economy before adjournment. A considerable number of minor bills has been disposed of; anything controversial has been put aside.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Monday, April 4 Foreign Minister Adam Malik said today that Indonesia would return to the United Nations and seek to improve relations with the United States.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 3 (AP) Malaysia's Prime Minister made a confession today: the ponies were his undoing.
With the April 15 deadline less than two weeks away, more than 25 million taxpayers have not yet filed their personal income-tax returns, according to the Internal Revenue Service.

TRIPOLI, Libya, April 3 (AP) New Government legislation makes production of Libyan oil more expensive, but the wells, which have made the country self-sufficient for the first time since the Roman era, are expected to continue to pay off.
PEKING, April 3 (Reuters) More than two million people voted in bright sunshine here today for representatives of eight local people's congresses.

LONDON, April 3 While Britain is expected, following Labor's victory at the polls, to take a tougher line toward Rhodesia, Government experts were cautious today about predicting the results of economic sanctions.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) President Johnson is meeting opposition from some members of his own party to his plan to move the Coast Guard, now in the Treasury Department, into the proposed department of transportation.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 3 (AP) Malaysia's Prime Minister made a confession today: the ponies were his undoing.
A council of leading corporation executives rejected Mayor Lindsay's tax program in its entirety yesterday, calling it "self-defeating" and potentially injurious to the economy of the city.
Mrs. Randolph Guggenheimer resigned yesterday as co-chairman of the city antipoverty Head Start committee to protest "chaos" in the operation of the program.
Trading continued at a hectic pace yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as advances outnumbered declines by a wide margin.
CHICAGO, April 4 Return to normal service on eight railroads after the four-day firemen's strike proceeded smoothly today, but repercussions were felt in many areas.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 4 Former President Juan Bosch said yesterday he would support the candidacy of Col. Francisco Caamano Deno if the Dominican Revolutionary party nominated the colonel for the Presidency or Vice Presidency in the scheduled June 1 elections.

CAIRO, April 4 Soviet warships in the Mediterranean and trawlers in the Red Sea have been quietly stepping up their use of port facilities in the United Arab Republic, diplomatic sources here have reported.

AT 5:30 last night, it was a toss-up which was more crowded the BMT or the vernissage for Mrs. Wyatt (Gloria Vanderbilt) Cooper. And if it had been the BMT, most of the fashions at the Hammer Galleries' preview cocktail party would have been perfectly at home.

Pro football, as represented by the National Fooaball League, will take another bite of the major league baseball season this year. The N.F.L.'s schedule announced yesterday, is the biggest in the league's history, with 105 games involving 15 teams; the longest, covering 15 weekends, and the one with the earliest starting date, Sept. 10.
WEBSTER, N.Y.?A major industry has joined with municipal authorities in a farranging plan to abate water pollution without stalling progress in this town on the shores of Lake Ontario.
LONDON, April 4 A second major British steel company today said it would end standard pricing for British customers.

GREAT NECK, L.I., April 4 Miss Elinor Ruth Bernstein and Sigmund Ronell Balka, of Washington plan to marry here May 29. Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Bernstein have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr, and Mrs. I. Edwin Balka of Philadelphia.

LAWRENCE, L.I., April 4 Norton A. Tannenbaum, vice president of Whitney Stores, Inc., a nationwide chain of women's apparel stores with headquarters at 370 West 35th Street, New York, died Sunday in his home, 7 Kee Wayden Road, of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.
Braniff International Airways has decided to leave Jack Tinker Partners and to join an agency that was set up formally only yesterday.
LONDON, April 4 The board of directors of Hill, Samuel Co., Ltd., merchant bankers, issued the following statement today:

Stevedoring and steamship companies said yesterday that they would invoke the full penalties embodied in their fouryear contract with the International Longshoremen's Association against wildcat strikers here.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service reminded taxpayers today that most would want to file a new form W-4 to prepare for the new graduated payroll withholding system.
BONN, April 4 The United States has given its unqualified support to the "peace note" West Germany sent to 110 Governments a week ago, a West German Government spokesman said today.

JERUSALEM (Jordan sector), March 30 Adults among the more than two million Palestinians outside Israel will elect their first "National Assembly" this year, Ahmed Shukairy, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, announced here.
PRATTVILLE, Ala., April 4 (AP) Police Chief O.C. Burton fired several shots in the air today to break up a march by 100 Negro demonstrators and then collapsed shortly after the march.
PRETORIA, South Africa, April 4 (Reuters) Prime Minister Verwoerd announced a Cabinet shuffle tonight.
James E. Branigan Jr., a former assistant United States attorney, was indicted yesterday for first degree manslaughter in the death of a detective lieutenant who was one of his best friends.

The net profit of the Consolidated Foods Corporation in the 36 weeks to March 12, rose to $13,376,959, or $1.55 a share up 20 per cent from $10,968,238 or $1.29 a share, in the 36 weeks to March 6, 1965, it was reported yesterday.
"The slums have always been treated like they were sick," Harry Rosenbloom said yesterday. "when in fact they should be treated like they're dying."

LONDON, April 4 (Reuters) Big oil tankers will be allowed to increase the weight of their cargo by thousands of tons as a result of a new load-line convention to be signed here tomorrow by 60 maritime nations. It will mean that a 100,000-ton tanker probably will be able to carry an extra 10,000 tons of cargo.

FRESH caviar and baby foods, potatoes and papayas, crown roast of lamb and canned tuna are among the products offered at Gotham Foods, 980 Lexington Avenue (between 71st and 72d Streets). This is the first of a new kind of store owned and operated by the Grand

GUILFORD, Conn., April 4 I.P. Macauley, retired vice president of Reynolds Metals Company and a member of the board of directors for the last 30 years, died of a heart attack in his home here Sunday night. He was 75 years old.

SINCE the early nineteenthirties when, as a young mother herself, she became interested in the care of children of working mothers, Mrs. Randolph Guggenheimer has been speaking out in defense of children.

The Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theater and Academy, with a membership of about 2,000, has "temporarily suspended" activities. A report that the chapter had disbanded was denied yesterday by a representative of ANTA.
A strike of chorus girls, dancers and other performers against the Latin Quarter forced the Broadway nightclub to close last night.

TOKYO, April 4 With a policy of presenting regularly top foreign productions with imported casts and Japanese adaptations of Western hits, as well as purely local creations, the New Imperial Theater will be an important addition to the busy Tokyo theatrical scene in September.

The International Finance Corporation announced yesterday it was joining investors in Mexico, France and the United States in subscribing to a new issue of shares of Industria del Hierro, S.A., a Mexican company manufacturing a wide range of construction and industrial equipment.
A hearing on a Federal attempt to prevent a merger of National Cleaning Contractors, Inc., into the Kinney Service Corporation was postponed yesterday to April 12.
SAIGON, April 4--Buddhist students, defying Government orders, thronged through the streets of downtown Saigon tonight in a frenzied demonstration against Premier Nguyen Cao Ky and his military rule.
It was spring on Wall Street yesterday and the voice of the bull was heard.
Princeton and New York Universities announced yesterday that each had established the post of Provost to meet changing needs and new requirements in administration.
PHOENIX, Ariz. One of the signs outside the office of Robert W. Goldwater, president of Goldwaters, the specialty store here, reads "Barry's Brother's Office."
ALMOST anyone who is anyone in or around net work television got a word in edgewise on Channel 13 last night.
Those lines on a stock market chart are not always what they seem. In the eyes of a chartist, a support level, once it is penetrated on the downside, becomes a resistance level.

TRENTON, April 4 The State Supreme Court ruled today that a bar is liable for damages if an intoxicated man it has served is killed or injured. Today's decision upheld a $49,000 award to the widow of a man who stepped from a bar stool, fell and died of a fractured skull.

TRENTON, April 4 Democratic Gov. Richard J. Hughes and Republican legislative leaders reached substantial agreement today on a new budget financed by a sales tax. They expressed optimism that both the budget and the tax would pass the Legislature, perhaps by the end of the month.

CORDELE, Ga., April 4 (AP) Seventy-one Negroes, most of them school children, were ar rested today after marching from a church to a Negro school facilities and segregation, agers were released on condition they return to classes.
GENEVA, April 4 The United States rejected today a Swedish proposal that would eliminate on-site inspection as the basis for policing a projected ban on underground nuclear tests.
WASHINGTON, April 4 The Supreme Court ruled today that New Hampshire cannot imprison a person for refusing to answer an investigating committee's questions about alleged past Communist activities.

Gwen Verdon, star of "Sweet Charity," said yesterday she had recommended to the owners of the Palace Theater, where the musical hit is running, that the 301 seats in the unused gallery there be made available at no charge to servicemen, drama and dance students.

WASHINGTON, April 4 The Supreme Court pressed its drive to upgrade the administration of criminal justice in the states today by agreeing to review procedures in juvenile courts and double jeopardy situations in the states.

Leonie Rysanek was certainly welcome at the Metropolitan Opera House last night when she burst into the Hall of Song at the beginning of Act II of "Tannhauser" and sang "Dich, teure Halle, gruss' ich."
Mrs. Matilda Cohen Kleban Anhalt, mother of Francis J. Kleban, builder, died Sunday in her home at 186 Riverside Drive. She was 86 years old.
NEW DELHI, April 4 The United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East ended today what was described as "one of its most successful" sessions.

NEW HAVEN, April 4 Bill Hazard of New York has the distinction of being Yale's 100th captain of crew, but would gladly renounce it for the privilege of winding up his varsity career in June with a victory over Harvard.

LONDON, April 4 (AP) A decision by the investigating committee looking into charges that two British bridge players cheated at the Buenos Aires bridge world championships last year has been delayed until this summer, bridge circles said today.
James A. Thomas, a retired engineer, died Sunday at the Robert B. Brigham Hospital in Boston. He was 74 years old and lived at South Chatham, Mass.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 4 Casey Stengel said good-by today to the first baseball team in New York Met history that will open a season without him.
PHILADELPHIA, April 4 Manning J. Smith Jr., a public relations man and former newspaperman, died yesterday. He was 56 years old.

The House Appropriations Committee has recommended a cut of $1 million in the already miniscule $5 million sought for direct grants in the coming fiscal year by the National Arts Endowment: Compared to annual public grants to the arts in other major countries, the American appropriation even if the full $5 million should be provided would be disproportionately small.

The management of Julius Garfinckel Co. turned down for the second time yesterday a request by Genesco, Inc., for its stockholder list. The company also sent a letter to its stockholders re-emphasizing its opposition to Genesco's bid for control of the company.

Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon has been elected a trustee of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Elihu Root Jr., who has retired from the post after 37 years.

Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., announced in London yesterday plans to build an $84-million fertilizer complex at Kanpur, India. The company said its own investment in the project would total about $11.4-million.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) The Supreme Court approved today a temporary realignment of North Carolina's Congressional districts that a lower court had allowed for elections this year.

TAMPA, Fla., April 4 A squall line bristling with tornadoes cut across central Florida today from the west coast to the east, killing at least nine persons and injuring more than 300. Hundreds more were left homeless.

BOSTON, April 4 (AP) Police Commissioner Edmund L. McNamara said today he had ordered a full report from all officers involved on why mob violence occurred at the South Boston Courthouse during an antiwar demonstration.

NEWARK, April 4 (AP) In an unusual case stemming from cancer experiments on chickens, an Essex County Court judge ruled today that high school students may experiment on live animals for educational purposes.
The Federal Reserve Board has reconsidered a 1917 decision and has ruled that demand notes are acceptable as collateral on borrowings from the Federal Reserve Banks.
WASHINGTON, April 4 The Department of Defense will give its ocean shipping business to the lowest bidder, beginning July 1, a high-ranking offical said here today.

LONDON, April 4 Unsettled foreign-exchange markets during last month's general election campaign produced the first loss in British reserves in seven months, the Treasury reported today. But the results were somewhat better than expected in the financial district, and the immediate reaction was continued improvement for the pound.
The Houston Lighting and Power Company sold $40-million of first mortgage bonds yesterday in an offering that is likely to give some indication of the value investors now place on call protection.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) Stiff opposition appeared today to some parts of a Johnson Administration bill to tighten Government regulation of commodity futures trading.
The Pacific Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday 1965 highs in sales and revenues, earnings and construction outlays.
The Carnegie Corporation of New York announced yesterday the election of Louis W. Cabot as a trustee of the educational foundation.

PARIS, April 4 Three trained seals wearing napkins gulped raw fish before television cameras in the Rue Saint Benoit the other morning to symbolize what is to come for Saint-Germain-desPres and its hungry visitors.

George J. Auer, president of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association in 1934-35, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived at 25 Hathaway Road, Bronxville.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 4 A barrage of charges has been leveled against the deposed Ghanaian President, Kwame Nkrumah, now a political refugee in Guinea, since his Government was toppled in a coup d'etat Feb. 24.
ORLEANS, France, April 4 (UPI) Doctors gave Walt Hansgen, the injured United States racing driver, a good chance of recovery today, but said he probably would never race again.
WASHINGTON, April 4 President Johnson's nomination of Mrs. Constance Baker Motley for a seat on the Federal District Court was approved unanimously today by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Supreme Court granted today a hearing in a controversy over Interstate Commerce Commission orders for redistribution of freight charges among various railroads on transcontinental shipments.

A stockbroker was awarded $500,000 by a Brooklyn Supreme Court jury in his case against a chiropractor yesterday and a Manhattan fashion designer has accepted a $100,000 settlement after a jury awarded him $250,000 in his case against a plastic surgeon.

DETROIT, April 4 The General Motors Corporation said today that about 1.5 million of its Chevrolet models now on the highways would be recalled to correct a throttle that sticks under certain conditions.

Six hour-long farces by Georges Feydeau, French playwright, will be televised over Channel 13 (WNDT) on successive Fridays at 8:30 P.M. beginning April 15. The series of programs, produced in London by Granada Television, Ltd., will be distributed in this country by the National Educational Television network under the title "Paris: 1900."

Politics of City Taxes With the State Legislature in recess for two weeks and the City Council waiting until late April to begin hearings, Mayor Lindsay's tax program will probably undergo in the interim a sustained attack designed to weaken it by compromise. The Mayor shows no sign of surrender thus far; but his program suffered a sharp setback yesterday from the Economic Development Council, which disagrees drastically with some of his major proposals.

The Corning Glass Works achieved the highest earnings in its March quarter than for any quarter in its 115-year history. The gain also was 44.8 per cent above the initial three months last year, the report disclosed yesterday.

Algiers, April 4 The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) has completed a six-week survey of Algeria's economy in preparation for a detailed report to be submitted this fall to the government and other bank members.
POMPANO BEACH, Fla., April 4 (UPI) Don Larsen, who gained fame by pitching the only perfect game in World Series history, was apparently at the end of his major league career today.

Mr. and Mrs. Mario Cooper of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Cooper's daughter, Miss Dale Crittenden Moss, to John Frederick Hellegers. His parents are Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Riker Hellegers of Washington, Pa.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4 (UPI) Doug Sanders, the hottest golfer on the circuit, took his time showing up at the Masters today and discovered that he was no better than third choice in the betting behind the defending champion, Jack Nicklaus, and a four-time winner, Arnold Palmer. The tournament starts Thursday.
Passover, commemorating the liberation of the Israelites from Egyptian bondage more than 3,000 years ago, began at sundown yesterday.

LORMAN, Miss., April 4--State troopers used tear gas to drive brick-throwing students out of a dormitory at an all Negro college today and Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. ordered in a company of National Guardsmen to quell further violence.
Sugar dealers' doubts about the Cuban Government's attitude toward the International Sugar Agreement appeared to have paid off partially yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 4--Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd said tonight that he was depending on "the common sense and sane judgment" of the United States and Britain to "guarantee the safety of the whites in this country."

After three months of meetings in Washington. Los Angeles and New York, the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Amateur Athletic Union, according to a Government-appointed mediation panel, "have narrowed the area of disagreement" in their dispute over control of amateur athletics in the United States.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 4 (UPI) Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, upset fourth-seeded Pierre Darmon of France, 6-2, 8-6, 11-13; 4-6, 6-4, today and advanced to the semi-finals of the South African lawn tennis championships.
The Newspaper Guild of New York disclosed yesterday the details of its major demands on the three newspapers seeking to merge here.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 112.7 on Friday from 112.3 on Thursday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 4 Indonesia has moved in at least two directions to bolster her economy.

YONKERS, April 4 Only 19,577 harness racing devotees showed up for action at Yonkers Raceway tonight. This represented a drop of approximately 14 per cent from the average of 22,748 through the first 26 nights of the current meeting.

MIRAMAR ISLES, Fla., April 4 Anthon H. Lund, who headed an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the failure of a common-stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, automobile manufacturers, in 1948, died today in his home here at 3612 East Shore Road after a long illness. He was 62 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 4 The Treasury bill rate continued its decline at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday that recorded complaints of burglary and robbery in the city had almost doubled after police commanders were ordered "to insure factual recording of crime statistics." He said, however, that there had been no increase in the actual amount of crime.
A Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn yesterday denied a request for a grand jury investigation of a pending case involving racial tensions in the Park Slope section.
PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (UPI) Dick Harter, a member of Pennsylvania's 1953 Ivy League basketball champions, was named head coach at Penn today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it would no longer contest the payment of insurance claims to depositors in a closed bank on the ground that the bank made illegally high interest payments to the depositors.
SAIGON, April 4 The war effort against the Vietcong is faltering while South Vietnam's Government strives to crush an internal challenge to its authority by a Buddhist-led political movement.

WASHINGTON, April 4 John P. Story, a real estate dealer here for many years, died Friday after a long illness. He was 93 years old. Mr. Story was the oldest member of the Metropolitan Club of Washington. He formerly belonged to the Chevy Chase Country Club.
The youngsters come down the Harlem street every day, violin cases swinging from their fingers or score-filled Schirmer envelopes under their arms.

The youth movement in New York banking got another lift yesterday as the Bankers Trust Company, the city's sixth largest bank, announced an executive reshuffle that would put Alfred Brittain 3d, 43, into the president's chair. By a wide margin, Mr. Brittain, whose appointment will ...
Open Interest
AUSTIN, Tex., April 4 Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson came to the end of her West Texas trail and river riding today.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 4 Three home runs by Roger Repoz, Jim Bouton's first victory in nine months, Lou Clinton's game-winning single and a coveted award won by Roy White spread joy through the New York Yankee clubhouse today at the conclusion of a 10-9 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

CLEVELAND, April 4 Members of the United States Commission on Civil Rights charged today that urban renewal and other Federal programs were major causes of the despondency and decay that exist in acute form in Hough, a Cleveland ghetto.
The Chief Judge of the State of New York ended the case of Gareth Martinis yesterday by refusing to allow further prosecution.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 4 For the Englishman who enjoys a cigarette, for the American who admires the chrome trim on his car, for the black woman in Rhodesia who buys a fancy head scarf or a candle to light her mud hut at night, a new man has entered the business picture in this part of the world. They call him Mr. One Per Cent.
The automobile industry roared through March like a lion, breaking sales records all along the way.
A cocktail buffet dance arranged for the evening of April 21 at the St. Regis-Sheraton will raise funds for the Judson Health Center.
WASHINGTON, April 4--The House voted approval today of President Johnson's emergency food relief program for India.

The slow, devious, careful process of checkmating President Sukarno is being skillfully managed by the Indonesian Army leaders. Sukarno, even in defeat, is evidently too popular to be liquidated. His role has been such a dominant one since the end of World War II that there is no comparable substitute. He stands alone but he still stands.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell and his wife, Yvette, were held in contempt of court yesterday for having ignored subpoenas ordering them to give a financial accounting in connection with a $575,000 judgment they owe.

The C.I.T. Financial Corporation, a large sales finance company, announced yesterday that, together with the LeFebure Corporation, a manufacturer of bank equipment and supplies, it will sell completely equipped, packaged bank buildings, completely installed 30 days after an order is received.
Output of steel in the nation's mills resumed its upward climb last week. A week earlier volume had turned downward for the first time in 12 weeks.
IF men have decided to preen like peacocks, John Stephen can claim a fair share of the credit.

Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Burman of New York and Eastchester, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Danby Sue Burman, to Marvin H. Ring, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Ring of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

RYE, N.Y., April 4 The United Hospital in Port Chester will receive the proceeds of a benefit tennis match to be held April 29, at 7 P.M., in the Midtown Tennis Club, 341 Eighth Avenue, in New York. The Golden Twig of Rye, one of the 32 volunteer groups of the 800member Twig organizations of the hospital, is sponsoring the benefit.
SURFSIDE, Fla., April 4 (UPI) Daniel Goldman, 18year-old son of a banker and contractor, was kidnapped at gunpoint a week ago today. He is still missing.
The election of Leo H. Schoenhofen and Bruce M. Robertson as directors of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company was announced yesterday at the annual meeting in Akron, Ohio.
NEW DELHI, April 4 (Reuters) The Indian Government threatened today to close down Air India if striking navigators did not return to work within 24 hours and if pilots refused to fly without them.
WASHINGTON, April 4--A Federal pay bill costing nearly double the sum proposed by President Johnson won tentative House approval today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to review the disorderly conduct convictions of 11 persons arrested during a demonstration on New York's Lower East Side against asserted racial discrimination by building trades unions.
The Very Rev. Lawrence D. Flanagan, Provincial of the Carmelite Fathers here from 1931 to 1943, died Sunday at the novitiate at Williamstown, Mass. He was 83 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 4 Senator John J. McClellan of Arkansas, head of the Senate investigating committee that looked into last year's failure of the San Francisco National Bank, said today that the losses arising from that failure might have been prevented if the Government had wider powers to police banking activity.
LONDON, Tuesday, April 5 The British frigate Plymouth last night intercepted the Greek tanker Ioanna V, which is believed to be carrying oil for Rhodesia.

The appointment of Julius Kaufman as vice president of J.I. Sopher Co., a concern that acts as rental agents for builders of luxury apartment houses in New York and New Jersey, has been announced by Jacob I. Sopher, the company's president.
MADRID, April 4 The Government today issued 14 decrees to guide implementation of the new press law, which will come into effect at midnight Saturday.
HOUSTON, April 4 (AP) Nineteen new astronauts joined the nation's space team today to train for flights to the moon and other space missions.

MESA, Ariz., April 4 (UPI)--The Cleveland Indians, with two big scoring innings, defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7-2, today and snapped a three game exhibition baseball winning streak for the world champions.
ASHLAND. Ky., April 4 (AP) The Armco Steel Corporation plant was closed today by a wildcat strike of about 3,900 members of the United Steelworkers of America.

WASHINGTON, April 4--A United States District Court official said today that the firemen's union and its president had been fined a total of $27,500 for failing to end a strike against eight railroads by noon yesterday. But a union lawyer asserted that the firemen would not pay without a hearing.
WASHINGTON, April 4--The chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers said today "there are signs" that inflationary pressure is coming under control.
The election of F. Stuart Miller as president was announced here yesterday by the Pacific Tin Consolidated Corporation, which conducts tin-dredging activities.
First-quarter sales and, earnings of the Magnavox Company set marks, Frank Freimann, president, reported yesterday.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 4 H. Miller Lawder, senior vice president of the Irving Trust Company, New York, died today in his home, 32 Fairview Road, after a long illness. He was 64 years old.
PARIS, April 4 France's official monetary reserves rose by $69-million in March, the Government reported today. It was the biggest increase in four months.
Joel L. Carr, vice president and general counsel of Levitt Sons, Inc., has been named to the new post of senior vice president legal, Mr. Carr joined Levitt last year.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., April 4 The mother's association of the Hackley School for Boys in Tarrytown plans to raise funds April 17 from 5 P.M. to 7 for scholarships for boys from all over this country and Europe at a cocktail party and Oleg Cassini fashion show. It will be at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club here. Mr. Cassini will be commentator.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) One of the nation's largest private shipbuilding concerns signed an agreement today with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to provide new promotion opportunities for Negroes.

Convinced that the spirit of freedom that characterized the Second Vatican Council justifies their cause, groups of Roman Catholic seminarians and laymen in Boston appear to be prepared for a major struggle with Richard Cardinal Cushing over the issue of eight suspended seminarians.

The General Public Utilities Corporation looks for 1966 earnings of "about $2.05 a share," W.G. Kuhns, vice president told about 175 stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting at One Chase Manhattan Plaza. This would compare with the previously reported $1.95 a share in 1965.

The appointment of Edwin A. Morris, president of Blue Bell, Inc., Greensboro, N.C., as chairman was announced yesterday by J.C. Fox, chairman and treasurer. The appointment is effective April 30, when Mr. Fox will retire on reaching the age of 65.
Copper shares advanced on the London stock market yesterday on strong hints that a rise in the producers' price of the metal is on the way.
The American Museum of Natural History closed its doors yesterday as a result of a protest by electricians that caught hundreds of schoolchildren, strollers and tourists by surprise.

MIAMI BEACH, April 4 Mrs. Sheila Potter Prentice of Old Westbury, L.I., widow of Lieut. Comdr. Sheldon E. Prentice, U.S.N., and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Potter of Roslyn, L.I., was married here this afternoon to James W. Paul of Delray Beach, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. A.J. Drexel Paul of Radnor, Pa., and Dark Harbor, Me.

PITTSBURGH, April 4 The Rockwell Manufacturing Company expects to report soon the highest first-quarter sales in its history, W.F. Rockwell Jr., vice chairman, told 80 shareholders at the annual meeting today.

NOT since Alec Guinness played Gulley Jimson in "The Horse's Mouth" and vitalized that sly bohemian scapegrace with charm and poignancy have we seen an artistic nonconformist as wild as David Warner's Morgan Delt, the infernal hero of "Morgan!" which came to the Sutton yesterday. Neither have we seen one as appealing and pathetic, in his brash, obnoxious way, as the fellow Karel Reisz flings at us in this howlingly funny British film.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has acquired its third musical instrument company in a little more than a year.

ATHENS, April 4 Britain informed Greece today that she would intercept the 12,920-ton Greek tanker Ionna V if the ship attempted to enter the port of Beira to deliver oil for Rhodesia in defiance of the British blockade.

A cross-section sketch of the original atom bomb that has been impounded since the 1951 Rosenberg spy trial will be made available to counsel for Morton Sobell, who is serving 30 years for conspiracy to commit wartime espionage.
RALEIGH, N.C., April 4 (AP) Rain and diminishing winds have brought a temporary end to the critical forest fire situation in the Southeast, forestry officials reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 4 Consumer installment credit rose $537-million in February, the smallest increase for a month since November, 1964, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

SAIGON, April 4 (UPI) United States jets streaking northward in 72 missions today dealt North Vietnam its heaviest air attack of the year. In the South, B-52 bombers struck an area where the North Vietnamese were reported to have infiltrated 25,000 regular troops.

A seven-point program to revitalize the domestic segment of the American merchant marine, prepared by a subcommittee of the President's Maritime Advisory Committee, was endorsed yesterday by the Seafarers International Union.
TRENTON, April 4 The State Supreme Court set aside a state-ordered half-cent rise in the minimum price of milk today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) The Supreme Court refused today to examine the complaint of a Jewish doctor, convicted in Norfolk, Va., of performing an illegal abortion, that Jews were improperly kept Off the jury panel.

Harry J. Brix, former superintendent of maintenance for the metropolitan truck lease division of The Hertz Corporation, died Sunday in his home, 29-15 160th Street, Flushing, Queens. He was 75 years old.
New York University, the defending Metropolitan Conference baseball champion, scored four runs in the seventh inning yesterday to defeat Manhattan, 6-2, at Ohio Field.
Two former officers of Analogue Controls, Inc., sued the Manhattan Sound Corporation and its president, Fred B. Adair Jr., yesterday for $1-million.

MOSCOW, April 4 The Soviet Union said today that the mission of Luna 10, which is circling the moon every three hours, is "to carry out a broad study of the physical characteristics of the moon and nearlunar space."

The city school system will start late-afternoon kindergarten classes on April 25 for some 2,200 children who could not be accommodated in the regular program because of a shortage of classroom space.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., April 4 Mr. and Mrs. Richard Burwell Persinger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Tilghman Persinger, to Charles Gray Montgomery, son of Mrs. Thomas Hope Johnson of Boston and Denmark, Me., and the late Prof. Carol Gray Montgomery.
BRUSSELS, April 4 The European Common Market's Council of Ministers reached conditional agreement today on two important Kennedy-round matters.

TENAFLY, N.J., April 4 Bertram D. Shepard, vice president and secretary of the Grand Union Company, an Eastern food chain with headquarters in East Paterson, died here today of a heart attack. He was 58 years old and lived at 144 Highwood Avenue.

MOSCOW, April 4 Serafima I. Gopner, an 86-year-old survivor of the early years of the Communist struggle in Russia, has died in the Ukraine. The death of Miss Gopner, who joined the Communist party in 1901, and sided with Lenin's Bolshevik faction in 1903, was reported Friday by Pravda Ukrainy, newspaper of the Ukrainian Communist party.
The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here, closing at $2.7938, down 3 points from Friday's final level.

TORRINGTON, Conn., April 4 (AP) George D. Roberts Jr., president of the Turner Seymour Manufacturing Company, died yesterday at Charlotte Hungerford Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Litchfield.

LONDON, April 4 If there is an author in search of a television character, he does not have to look beyond Lew Grade. Nominally, Mr. Grade is managing director of Associated Television, Ltd., one of the companies that produce commercial TV programs in Britain, but actually he is London's Mr. Show Business.
James T. Prendergast, an attorney, yesterday became the third Reform Democrat to enter the primary race for a City Council seat from Manhattan's Second District.
WESTPORT, Conn., April 4 Eighteen former narcotics users packed their belongings today and quit the 15-room Victorian mansion that had been their treatment center.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) Two Regular Army brigades mentioned by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara as among "several important steps" taken to increase readiness still exist only on paper.

The head of the Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday that the all-night subway, patrols had become "unbearable" to the force and he called for an increase of 2,500 in the transit police.

OCEANSIDE, L.I. April 4 The engagement of Miss Karen Kane Hoppen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Hoppen, to John Charles Rasmus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Rasmus of Rochester, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A wedding in August is planned.

PAUL DIETZEL, Army's head football coach since 1962, is the odds-on favorite to become the new head coach and possibly the director of athletics at the University of South Carolina. If the negotiations between South Carolina and Dietzel run true to form he could ...

MAN is corrupt, his destiny is tragic, but his Quixotic defiance of the odds, his capacity for love, commitment and hope, may be his triumph. This is the theme that runs through and binds together the 100 or so "master poems" collected in this volume by the late poet and anthologist, Oscar Williams.
FORT PIERCE, Fla., April 4 (UPI) A retired businessman, his wife and his mother-in-law were found strangled with nylon stockings today, apparently by robbers.

"A Patch of Blue," MetroGoldwyn-Mayer's sentimental film about the relationship between a blind white girl and a Negro office worker, is proving to be as big a box-office hit in the South as it is in the North.
The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Charles J. Chapman as executive vice president of its mining and metals division.

MOSCOW, April 4 (UPI) A leading Russian general said today that thousands of Soviet soldiers and sailors had volunteered to fight against American and allied troops in South Vietnam. He said the volunteers included entire Soviet military units.
The Transit Authority yesterday denied allegations by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People that its bus subsidiary practiced "flagrant and willful imbalance" in hiring.
The American Motors Corporation has set up an executive committee of its directors for the first time since the company was founded in 1954.
Frank Gottsch, a retired research chemist, died Sunday at Memorial General Hospital in Union, N.J. He lived at 1068 Kensington Avenue, Plainfield, N.J.
FOR the second year in a row Bloomingdale's, long known for its sophisicated model rooms, has turned a flock of its youngest designers loose to see what would happen.

A secondary offering of 225,000 shares of common stock of A.H. Robins Company, Inc., at $68 a share sold out quickly yesterday after it was placed on the market by a group headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Smith, Barney Co., Inc.
CAN a possum be happy in suburbia? This is a question that may not have important implications, but nevertheless one that does deserve an answer.

WASHINGTON, April 4 A tent town set up across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House by Mississippi Negroes who want antipoverty money will be left unmolested as long as the protesters want to stay.
The report from Moscow that Luna 10 carries a jet system has led American space officials to speculate that the system might be used to aim a camera.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company sought approval yesterday of the Federal Power Commission for a $12-million expansion of pipeline facilities to deliver new Canadian gas supplies to the Pacific Northwest.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 4 Justice Jim Johnson, one of Arkansas' best-known segregationists, resigned from the Arkansas Supreme Court today to run for Governor.

ALBANY, April 4 Governor Rockefeller has appointed Dwight F. Metzler, executive secretary of the Kansas Water Resources Board, to head New York State's $1.7-billion "pure waters" program. Mr. Metzler will be sworn in May 26 as a deputy commissioner of health at a salary of $28,000 a year.

Thomas S. Gates, chairman of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, told stockholders at the bank's annual meeting March 16 that earnings would rise only "modestly" in the first quarter. Yesterday, Morgan Guaranty disclosed that the "modest" gain resulted in a historic first-quarter high in net operating earnings.

WASHINGTON, April 4 The United States cautiously broke its silence on the unrest in South Vietnam today by endorsing a rapid meeting of the country's contending political factions. The hope is to avert or at least soften what officials here fear could develop into a tragic armed fight.
Eaton and Howard, Inc., a Boston investment management company, announced yesterday the appointment of H. Day Brigham Jr. as vice president and general counsel.

FOUR, of the six members of the North American team that will contest the World Championship later this month in St. Vincent, Italy, took part in training matches at Grossinger's, N.Y. last Saturday and Sunday.

WASHINGTON, April 4 The following facts about China are compiled for the use of Americans who have loyally refused to think about the place for the last sixteen years and may therefore need a refresher course in order to understand the present Washington debate about China policy.

WASHINGTON, April 4 President Johnson's call on the union of railroad firemen and enginemen to end their illegal strike was gratefully employed by its leader as a pretext to order the men back to work, though at first with conditions. But it was the Federal judiciary which furnished the real muscle that crushed the strike.
A new and mature Manuel Ycaza, not the one who picked up 245 days in suspensions in 10 years riding horses that earned more than $13-million, came back to Aqueduct yesterday.

At 10 A.M. yesterday, Dick Clark, 25 years old, of 134 Elm Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y., stepped to the window of the Carnegie Hall box office and purchased four tickets to Vladimir Horowitz's piano recital of Sunday April 17.
LONDON, April 4 Influential segments of British opinion are coming to the conclusion that political betting affects the voting in elections and should be discouraged.

The top management group of Carl Ally, Inc., has been increased by one with the addition of Paul J. Caravatt Jr., the former executive vice president for marketing and account management at LaRoche, McCaffrey and McCall, Inc.
Hundreds of thousands of dollars in Federal grants for highway projects here may be in danger because the Lindsay administration is reviewing plans for the projects.

SINGAPORE, April 4 Singapore and the United States agreed today to exchange ambassadors, four months after Washington proposed that its consulate in this predominantly Chinese island state be raised to embassy status.
Price reductions were put into effect yesterday on various forms of broad-spectrum antibiotics by Lederle Laboratories, a division of the American Cyanamid Company.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 5 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky flew to Danang before dawn today, several hours after a regiment of 1,500 South Vietnamese marines loyal to the Government had landed at the allied air base here.
WASHINGTON, April 4 President Johnson pledged today that the United States would not abandon the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

MARILYN HORNE gave her second New York recital last night, at Carnegie Hall, attracting a full house of devotees of brilliant vocalism. The soprano deserved all the acclaim she got on this occasion, as she produced the vocal fireworks that were expected of her.

Equipped with English Ayling oars, garbed in white, turtle neck shirts and employing a new technique in a shell rigged in the German style popularized by the Ratzeburg Club, Columbia's new rowing establishment will undergo its first test Saturday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 5 Charlie Dressen had just finished saying that Baltimore was the toughest team he had seen this spring and that he wished he had two more left-handers to pitch against the Yankees. Then the bomb went off.
Fred W. Friendly, former president of news for the Columbia Broadcasting System, has been named a professor of journalism at Columbia University and an adviser on television to the Ford Foundation.

CORNWALL, N.Y., April 5 Air bubbled noiselessly to the calm surface of the heated, indoor pool. A yellow rubber raft floated on the blue-green water. Perched on the diving board, a man in the gray uniform of the New York State Police spoke slowly and clearly into to small, hand microphone:
CHICAGO, April 5 The formation of a Chicago chapter of an armed racial equality group known as the Deacons for Defense and Justice was disclosed here today.

CALCUTTA, India, April 5 (UPI) A new wave of arson and sabotage of essential public services erupted in various cities of the state of West Bengal today, three weeks after a previous long spell of rioting.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) The Secretary of the Air Force assured a Congressional committee today there was no evidence that the earth ever had been visited by strangers from outer space.

Rewards totaling $1,500 were offered yesterday by the two line organizations of the Fire Department for the arrest and conviction of the person who pulled a false alarm March 19 that resulted in the death of Fireman Robert T. Smullen of Ladder 142, Ozone-Park, Queens, who had responded to the call.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) A step was taken today toward agreement on an English version of the Roman Catholic mass for use by all Englishspeaking countries.
NEW DELHI, April 5 Mrs. Indira Gandhi, India's Prime Minister, is suffering from "a mild attack of influenza," her physicians reported today.
BUENOS AIRES, April 5 Mrs. John F. Kennedy arrived today with her two children to spend a week-long Easter holiday with Algentine friends of her husband.

WASHINGTON, April 5 President Johnson presented the Teacher-of-the-Year Award today to a first grade teacher from Tucson, Ariz., whose classroom techniques include using cow eyes from a local slaughterhouse to illustrate the principle of magnification, and building model volcanoes that really erupt.
DETROIT, April 5 (AP) About 60 Striking switchmen of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad's Pontiac, Mich., yards returned to work today, obeying a court order.
Dr. Samuel Weiss, a leading specialist on diseases of the digestive system, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home and office, 435 East 79th Street. He was 80 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 5 The Federal Bureau of Investigation will no longer be able to make unsupervised requests for reports by United States embassies on Americans traveling abroad.

Staten Island ferry boat pulled into Manhattan one warm June day and young Clarence Francis stepped off and trudged up Broadway with a single aim: to find a job that would help pay the cost of his sophomore year at Amherst College.

LONDON, April 5 (UPI) Stirling Moss will appear in public at the wheel of a racing car Friday for the first time since a near-fatal accident forced him to retire from motor racing nearly four years ago.

WASHINGTON, April 5 The tent camp erected by homeless Mississippi Delta Negroes within sight of President Johnson's White House bedroom may become "more or less" permanent, spokesmen for the group said today.

Spoke to Agriculture Department employes whose suggestions saved the government $26-million; presented "Teacher of the Year" award to Mrs. Mona M. Dayton of Tucson, Ariz., lunched with Secretary of State Rusk, Defense Secretary McNamara and Special Assistant Rostow; nominated Findley Burns Jr., to be Ambassador to Jordan.
Mayor Lindsay agreed last night to meet with officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who had threatened to cut off deliveries of food and medical supplies to the 24 city hospitals.
Plans to reduce air fares across the Pacific primarily between West Coast cities and Tokyo were announced yesterday by the major airlines on the route.

WASHINGTON, April 5 The Senate Agriculture Committee moved with such speed today in approving President Johnson's food relief program for India that two Cabinet officers and a roomful of spectators were unaware of its decision.
AS buyers nibbled on egg rolls in a showroom decorated with paper fish, two Seventh Avenue manufacturers announced yesterday that they planned to conquer the world with American fashion.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 5 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach has said that the McCarran Act accomplishes very little and can justifiably be repealed.
WASHINGTON, April 5 The country's major automobile manufacturers appealed to Congress today for a final chance to prove their determination to build safer cars without Federal regulation.
Mayor Lindsay was asked yesterday to assess the first three months of his own administration, and, not surprisingly, he decided he'd done a good job.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 5 Four youths who were told that a 7-year-old girl had been abducted by a man in a blue station wagon, spotted a car fitting the description here today, chased it three miles and held the driver, a 29-year-old minister, who was arrested by the police.
"It's a Bird .. It's a Plane It's Superman" at the Alvin Theater. CI 5-5226.
AN interesting city apartment apparently doesn't require's woman's touch.

LONDON, April 5 Shell UK Exploration and Production, Ltd., operating in the North Sea on behalf of both Shell and Jersey Standard, announced today that preliminary results of undersea exploration and exploitation indicated a gas find of "considerable importance."
HONG KONG, Wednesday, April 6 Peking called on the Chinese people today to be prepared for war with the United States this year, next year or sometime in the future.
LAKELAND, Fla., April 4 (AP) The property damage caused by the tornadoes that killed 10 persons and injured 300 in central Florida yesterday was estimated by officials today at $29.4-million.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 5 Dr. Ernst Herz, a psychiatrist and neurologist with an office at the Neurological Institute, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, New York, died here yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 89 Sheridan Avenue. He was 65 years old.
The Controversy over the socalled "Doyle Dane Bernbach look" in advertising is apparently becoming more serious.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, New York's third-largest bank, reported yesterday net operating earnings of $12,527,792, or $1.00 a share, up 4.88 per cent from the $11,944,533, or 96 cents a share, reported for the 1966 period.
AUSTIN, Tex., April 5 (UPI) Two New York City lawyers were cited yesterday for failure to appear here in Federal Court as counsel in a $2.5-million marijuana case.
The United Fruit Company is expanding its interest in the drive-in food-service business through the proposed acquisition of A W Drive-Ins of Canada, Ltd.
WASHINGTON, April 5 The railroad firemen's union faced today the serious prospect of several damage suits totaling millions of dollars as a result of its four-day strike against eight railroads.
Dr. John E. Deitrick, dean of the Cornell University Medical College, was elected yesterday to the board of the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

CHICAGO, April 5 Walter E. Heller Co., the Chicagobased commercial finance firm, may not show as much growth in finance receivables this year as in the last five years, but the receivables are still expected to set a new high, stockholders were told here today.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 5 (AP) Two workmen were missing and nine others injured, one seriously, when a scaffold on a new Delaware River bridge near here collapsed today.

The 15 largest mutual savings banks in New York City, whose assets total more than $17-billion, showed a combined drop in deposits of $110-million during the last three days of March, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Apr. 5 (AP) The Office of Education announced tonight the first major step toward shifting its college student loan program from a system of direct Government loans to an insured and partly subsidized basis.

The wildcat strike of longshoremen against new efficiency rules, which spread yesterday to five military ships at Army piers in Brooklyn, is a basic challenge to the integrity of waterfront industrial relations and to the future of the port.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill today to extend for two months the deadline for signing up for voluntary Medicare insurance to pay doctors bills.

MADRID, April 5 The hydrogen bomb lost off the Spanish coast was reported tonight to have been located again by United States Navy underwater searchers, and there were cautious new hopes for its recovery.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sturgis Potter of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Russell Potter, to Robert Swain Ross Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Ross of Haverford, Pa., and Nonquitt, Mass.
The rally on the American Stock Exchange continued yesterday as most issues advanced in active trading.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 5 (AP) Garry Stensland of Portland, Ore., the National Amateur Athletic Union GrecoRoman heavyweight wrestling champion, was eliminated tonight in his bid for a repeat title at the 1966 A.A.U. championships.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 5 The lord of the manor and the Suffolk County Executive are having polite differences about the future of Gardiners Island, home of flora, fauna and colonial descendants.
Office leasing in Manhattan continued to show strength in March when 367,297 square feet were leased in new buildings.
AUSTIN, Tex., April 5 (UPI) Lynda Bird Johnson plans to go to Europe in June but the White House is not about to announce it.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa April 5 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean Moffitt King of Long Beach, Calif., moved into the semi-finals of the South Africa tennis championships today but Mrs. Carole Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, was eliminated in the quarter-finals.

SILLY programing spoiled last night's opening of the Bavarian State Theater for me. There were no previews; I went therefore to the opening night (at the City Center). It began with a tedious early comedy by Goethe, which ran for more than an hour. This was intended as a curtainraiser, an apt term because I thought the curtain would never lower.
Another big step was taken yesterday in the effort to bring fruits and vegetables to the table with as much of their natural freshness and flavor as possible.
WASHINGTON, April 5 The Federal Government today stepped into the growing controversy over the use of hallucinatory drugs on college campuses.
A leading West German lawmaker and industrialist proposed here yesterday that Western governments set up a special consultative group to avoid frictions over trade dealings with Communist countries.
BOWIE, Md., April 5 (AP) Making his third start in eight days, Glassell B. won the feature race at Bowie today and paid $2.60, $2.20 and $2.20 for $2 across the board.
BETHESDA, Md., April 5 Miss Robin Marie Hurleigh and John Lincoln Bernbach plan to be married in August.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 5 Sidney J. Stacey, vice president in charge of the services division of the California Texas Oil Corporation, died today in his home, 49 Mulberry Lane, after a short illness. He was 55 years old.
Abraham Straus, a retailing division of Federated Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of John Cullen and Joseph Goldweitz as operating vice presidents.
When Hialeah banned betting on its nine-horse, $136,400 Flamingo Stakes last month, the racing world yelled "chicken."
ALBANY, April 5 The State Insurance Department has added its opposition to a bill that would increase workmen's compensation benefits to injured employes.
DANANG, South Vietnam, April 5 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky appeared today to have backed away from a threat to use force against this rebellious city.
The proposed merger of The New York Herald Tribune, The New York Jounal-American and The New York World-Telegram and The Sun will not take place before April 18, it was learned yesterday.

Skip Rottkamp's three hits, including his fourth home run of the season, powered Long Island Univerity to a 7-6 victory over Adelphi in 10 innings yesterday. Bob Grzelaczyk gained the triumph although he threw only one pitch, which led to an inning-ending double play in the 10th.
WASHINGTON, April 5 Following are excerpts from a statement of the Automobile Manufacturers Association presented today to the Senate Commerce Committee:

GAMES IN THE DARKENING AIR, by Peter Boynton (Harcourt,. Brace World, $5.95). A story about a boy growing up to manhood. I HAVE FRIENDS IN HEAVEN, by Max Catto (Little, Brown, $4.95). A novel about an orphan and his journey to Rome.
The American Can Company announced yesterday the election of aides for its two top executives.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the charge by Mrs. Randolph Guggenheimer of "chaos" in the city's Head Start program was "entirely valid."
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 113.0 on Monday from 112.7 on Friday.
