Joseph Kevin O'Brien breathed a huge sigh of relief this week as he laid down his pencil after taking the New York Stock Exchange and National Association of Securities Dealers examination to become a registered representative.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5 The first official portrait of the late Dag Hammarskjold was unveiled today by Secretary General Thant in the lobby of the Secretariat building.

CHICAGO, April 5 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was enjoined today from interfering with the operation of a six-flat slum building taken over by civil rights group under his direction last Feb. 23.

WASHINGTON, April 5 A Federal District Court has ruled that the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) may not go through with its planned acquisition of the Potash Company of America, the nation's largest producer of potash.
"There was a lot of shouting," a dealer on the London Metal Exchange said yesterday in describing copper trading there in what seemed to be a typically British understatement.
WASHINGTON, April 5 President Johnson received today a bit of statistical reassurance that his energetic campaign to prevent the economy from soaring into inflationary orbit is having an impact.

The threat of civil war within a civil war in Vietnam has been averted but only for the present. Hope for a peaceful solution of the internal crisis now lies in the summoning as soon as possible of a convention, or "assembly of leaders" who can agree on a more representative regime.
Malcolm F. Mallette, managing editor of The WinstonSalem (N.C.) Journal, was appointed as an associate director of the American Press Institute at Columbia University yesterday.
Yonkers and northern New Jersey have lifted all emergency water restrictions, but New York City residents face another springtime of drought regulations.

CAIRO, April 5 The authoritative Egyptian newspaper Al Ahram, reflecting irritation in the United Arab Republic with the latest American arms sale to Jordan, indirectly accused the United States today of trying to divide the Arab world.
The stock market advance continued into the fourth consecutive session yesterday.
ATHENS, April 5 The owners of the Greek tanker that has arrived at Beira applied today for the removal of their ship from the Greek shipping register.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) Findley Burns Jr., a career diplomat now serving in London, will be the new United States. Ambassador to Jordan, the White House announced today.

William Morris Girden, a retired real-estate operator who was deputy state controller from 1955 to 1961, died yesterday in Tucson, Ariz., where he had been living in retirement for three years. He was 69 years old.
MOSCOW, April 5 The Soviet leadership proclaimed a vigorous economic policy today. It insisted on reform at home and called for a new offensive in foreign trade, including that with the West.

The Board of Education announced yesterday that it would establish 10 pilot "intermediate" schools next fall as part of its planned reorgarnization to improve instruction and promote greater integration.
MIAMI, April 5 (AP) The heavyweight boxing champion, Cassius Clay, was ordered today to pay $26,250 in alimony and legal fees within 48 hours or go to jail for 30 days.
The Park Department is considering a low bid of $187,470 that it opened yesterday for the rebuilding of the Coney Island boardwalk.

Dr. Elliott Samuel Hurwitt, chief of the surgical division of Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center, Gn Hill Road and Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, died yesterday afternoon, apparently of a heart attack, in his office at the hospital. His age was 53. He lived at 126 Carthage Road, Scardsdale, N.Y.

WILLIAMSVILLE, N.Y., April 5?Capt. George William Lautrup Jr., U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Lautrup have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Lois Lautrup, to Edgar Zell Steever 5th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Steever 4th of Devon, Pa., formerly of Darien, Conn.

JIM HURTUBISE of North Tonawanda, N.Y., who won the 500-mile race at Atlanta on March 27 in a Plymouth, was in New York City yesterday to discuss his campaign plans for 1966. Hurtubise is the lion-hearted young man who made a...
OTTAWA, April 5 The Canadian House of Commons voted by a wide margin tonight to retain the death penalty for murder convictions.

MOSCOW, April 5 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin promised the Soviet people today that they would have higher wages and lower prices, more consumer goods acid fewer taxes, expanded housing and a reduced work week.

CEDARHURST, L.I., April 5 A June wedding is planned by Miss Jessica Dee Waldbaum and Carl Bender, graduates of Cornell University. Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Waldbaum have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Bender of Great Neck.

WASHINGTON, April 5 The Secretary of the Treasury, Henry H. Fowler, said today that restraint by the Federal Reserve on the expansion of credit was "appropriate" but that it should be accomplished "without skyrocketing of interest rates."

The Manhattan Chapter of Brandeis University's National Women's Committee will hold its annual spring luncheon on April 18 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria after an 11 o'clock meeting and noon reception.

It was not inappropriate that the Panama Conference called to propose changes in the Charter of the Organization of American States came to a close on April Fool's Day. The Inter-American Economic and Social Conference in Buenos Aires, where the first five years of the Alliance for Progress were reviewed and proposals were made for the future, had ended the day before the Panama meeting with equally futile results.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 5 President Humberto Castelo Branco has been celebrating the second anniversary of the revolution that brought him to power by inaugurating huge industrial works started by his banished predecessors.

The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus came to Madison Square Garden last night with its annual puzzle: Which ring do you watch when there is something astounding, breath-stopping, comic, dazzling, eerie, fantastic, gorgeous, hippodromic and even quite interesting wherever you look?
Two new high-rated issues of utility bonds were offered to investors yesterday at rates that indicate that investment bankers think interest rates are inching downward.

Michael C. Lowe, a retired construction expediter and a former member of the staff of The Wall Street Journal, died of a heart attack Monday. He was 62 years old and lived at 730 St. Luke's Place, Baldwin, L.I.
M.A. Schapiro Co., Inc., the bank-stock house, said yesterday that it expected bank profit margins to recover from the squeeze that they had been suffering.
The Police Department is planning to move reinforcements into 187 recreation areas that Parks its Department officials say "require intensified police action."

WASHINGTON, April 5 Compulsory four-month enlistment extensions in the Navy and Marine Corps will be eliminated, beginning this month for the Navy and in October for the Marines, the Defense Department announced today.
The Soviet Union's Luna 10, in orbit around the moon since Sunday, may be making several vitally important observations, American specialists believe.
The family of Agripino Bonilla now has $6,428,75 in the bank.
WASHINGTON, April 5 A Republican move to delete a $7-million arts appropriations from a big money bill was tentatively rejected today by the House.
Wall Street stands to get an answer within a few weeks of the frequently asked question; "What is Jerry Tsai buying in the stock market?"
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) United States District Judge Alexander Holtzoff today dismissed a suit by a 22-year-old Army private who asked the court to prevent him from being sent to Vietnam.
SAIGON, Wednesday, April 6 A Buddhist leader demanded yesterday that South Vietnam's governing military junta organize elections for a constituent assembly within three months.

The Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that it might go along with some price increases on polyethylene-plastic resins, but that it would not cut any prices. The Union Carbide Corporation recently announced slight price increases on average.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5 Secretary General Thant was asked today to visit the Middle East to observe the worsening predicament of the Palestinian Arab refugees.
YONKERS, April 5 Bedford Jamie, the wire-to-wire winner of the third race at Yonkers Raceway tonight, is the breadwinner of Ralph Arone's fourhorse harness racing stable.

SAIGON, April 5 Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge decided on his own to use American transport planes to carry pro-Government Vietnamese troops to central Viet- nam last night, authoritative sources said today. The White House was reported to have concurred.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5 The Masters tournament, which starts here Thursday, will serve as a testing ground for a new golf regulation known as the "one-clean" rule, and the professionals will be adhering to it for the first time in a major championship.

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced yesterday that it would begin hearings May 4 on the competing applications of the Chicago North Western Railway to control the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad and of the Union Pacific Railroad to merge with the Rock Island.

MESA, Ariz., April 5 (UPI) A week after ending their 32day holdout with the richest contracts ever given to two pitchers, Don Drysdale and Sandy Koufax took the mound for the Los Angeles Dodgers today and were charged with six runs in a 7-2 loss to the San Francisco Giants.
A champagne reception will he held on the stage of the Elysee Theater on April 24 after the performance of "13 Stars for Channel 13."

Mayor Lindsay disagreed yesterday with any idea that the state and city would lose any Federal highway funds because his administration had cast some projects into doubt. He intimated that Robert Moses, proponent of such projects, was raising such an issue.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., April 5 (UPI) A Federal grand jury indicted 10 oil companies today on charges of rigging bids in the sale of liquid asphalt to the State of Kansas.

TAMPA, Fla., April 5 (AP) Gene Freese singled in the winning run in the 17th inning to give the Chicago White Sox a 2-1 exhibition baseball victory over Cincinnati today, extending the Reds' losing streak to four games.
The first Father General of the Society of Jesus to visit the United States celebrated his first folk mass to guitar accompaniment yesterday and liked it.
MONTREAL, April 5 (UPI) Bobby Hull wrapped up a collection of scoring records as well as $2,000 in award money during the 1965-66 National Hockey League season.

JAKARTA, Indonesia As usual, one group of people, the Chinese minority, suffered automatically when political convulsion seized Indonesia. Chinese minorities always suffer in Southeast Asia when there is political convulsion. It doesn't matter whether the shift goes left or right. In either case someone will always start looting Chinese shops and beating their proprietors.
BRUSSELS, April 5 The European Common Market moved forward on several important fronts today.
Broadway's loveliest pickets took their places yesterday afternoon outside the Latin Quarter, the night club at 200 West 48th Street.
LUSAKA, Zambia, April 5 President Kenneth Kaunda said tonight that his Government sympathized with the grievances of the striking African copper miners, which he said were "very real."
The Nopco Chemical Company, a Newark producer of industrial chemicals, announced yesterday the election of Louis J. Owen as a vice president.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 5 Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale, after holding out for most of spring training, will be paid nearly a quarter of a million dollars by the Los Angeles Dodgers in 1966. According to the most recent estimates, Koufax will get $130,000 and Drysdale $115,000. Are they worth it?

When Eugene Ormandy leads the Philadelphia Orchestra in a Brahms program, as he did last night at Philharmonic Hall, one can expect an evening of the most comfortable and secure sort, beautiful but utterly predictable.

THE NATIONAL INCOME TAX TEST," presented by C.B.S. News last night on Channel 2, hardly was light entertainment, but it did manage to induce a few smiles while providing a lot of basic tax information.

The Alleghany Corporation's plans for offering its stockholders its 15 per cent interest in New York Central Railroad common stock in exchange for preferred and common shares of Alleghany have been challenged by a dissident stockholder of Alleghany.

CAIRO, April 5--Egyptian authorities have broken up two military smuggling rings operating from the office of the nation's First Vice President without his knowledge, reliable sources have disclosed. The rings allegedly dealt in hundreds of thousands of dollars worth at contraband goods.
LOS ANGELES, April 5 (AP) The National Basketball Association announced today the dates for the championship playoff.
Mayor Lindsay replied angrily yesterday to big business interests that had criticized his proposed tax program.
The new $11.5-million freighter Prudential Seajet, the first of a fleet of five new highspeed cargo ships for Prudential Lines, Inc., is scheduled to make her debut here this morning.

LOS ANGELES, April 5 Federal loans and private grants totaling $6-million will facilitate construction of a new university of the arts some 30 miles north of Los Angeles, it was disclosed today. Called the California Institute of the Arts, the institution will offer instruction in music, fine arts, theater and performing arts.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) J.L. Robertson, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve System, testified today that Federal banking agencies should be armed with "intermediate sanctions" to guard against "an upsurge in the number of problem bank cases."
OF all the Balanchine and Stravinsky collaborations, the one that was of historic importance was that of "Apollo," for here the seeds of neoclassicism had their first opportunity for growth.

BARCELONA, Spain, ApriL 5 The Spanish Government, acting on a three-week-old decision by the Council of Ministers, has imposed unexpectedly heavy fines on nearly 40 Catalonian intellectuals and artists for their participation in last month's sit-in by university students at a Capuchin monastery here.
United States marshals arrested a mail-fraud suspect in residential Queens Village yesterday and unexpectedly turned up a cache of Nazi paraphernalia.

The first major challenge to Joseph, Curran in his 29 years as president of the National Maritime Union gained momentum yesterday, a week after a rival for the post said that he had been refused a place on the ballot.

COMPETITIVE bridge is likely to see increasing emphasis on head to head team events in future years. The Greater New York Bridge Association recently made a progressive and popular move by introducing two double elimination events in which play goes on over several months.

SENATOR CLIFFORD P. CASE, Republican of New Jersey, has urged a $400,000 program to dump automobile bodies in the Atlantic Ocean for artificial fishing reefs, employing antipoverty program workers as car cleaners.
BOSTON, April 5 Two striking newspaper unions voted today to end a 31-day-old strike that has suspended the publication of five daily and three Sunday newspapers in Boston.

GENEVA, April 5 The 17nation disarmament conference adjourned today for an eightday Easter recess without any prospect of early progress on the projected treaty for halting the spread of nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, April 5 The most vivid personality in Washington today outside of the Big Man himself is Dean G. Acheson, the former Secretary of State, who is now almost 73, going on 50.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., April 5 President Johnson's eldest daughter added some natural beauty to this city today. With her mother looking on, Lynda Bird Johnson formally presented six live oaks to the community to grace Main Street.

Harold M. Stewart of 105 New England Avenue, Summit, N.J., former executive vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, of America died Monday in his winter home in Mount Dora, Fla., after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

JOHNNY WEISSMULLER headed home to Fort Lauderdale yesterday after a weekend of television exposure in New York. The election of Dr. Howard Rusk as medical and rehabilitation consultant for the Pension Corporation of America, was announced yesterday.
TORONTO, April 5 Communist China has exercised an option to increase its three-year wheat purchases from Canada by about 50 per cent, Finance Minister Mitchell Sharp announced today.

Milton Pollack, a court-appointed referee, said yesterday that "at least" 150 noteholders had approved a proposed $4.3million settlement with the World's Fair Corporation.
LONDON, April 5 Prime Minister Wilson reshuffled his Government tonight in the wake of the Labor party's election victory, but he made no changes in the principal foreign, defense or economic posts.

LONDON, April 5--The Greek tanker Ioanna. V, carrying oil presumably destined for Rhodesia, was anchored two miles from the Harbor of Beira, Portuguese Mozambique, tonight with her exact intentions still in doubt.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 5 President Charles Helou named a 65-year-old lawyer, Dr. Abdullah Yaffi, today to form a new government.
The spot rate on the British pound dipped slightly yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7937, down 1 point from the preceding day's level.

LONDON, April 5 (AP)--Prince Andrew, who is 6 years old, will receive in a few days an $11,000 model of James Bond's souped-up sports car, complete with toy machine guns, bulletproof windshield, two-way radio and real radar.
KINGSTON, Pa., April 5 Miss Marilyn Mager and Morton H. Berman plan to marry in June.

Edward Mishkin, whose conviction for publishing obscene material was upheld by the Supreme Court on March 21, was arrested yesterday in a raid on a Times Square bookshop. He and two other men were charged with violating a state antismut law.
A new version of the circumstances under which the first shots were fired in the war for control of the Mafia "family" long headed by Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno emerged yesterday.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 5 (AP) The fifth attempt to launch an Orbiting Astronomical Observatory was halted at the last moment today when an automatic sensing system closed down the engines of the booster rocket after they had ignited.

WASHINGTON, April 5 The Johnson Administration was somewhat encouraged today as a result of a secret meeting yesterday between Premier Nguyen Cao ky of South Vietnam's beleaguered military Government and his most militant Buddhist opponent, Thich Tri Quang.
HIS is a fine book about the games people play to make armatures for vanity. It is cradled in American his tory but its fiery elementals have burned every land and era.

SAIGON, April 5--United States fighter-bombers, striking within 25 miles of Hanoi, yesterday attacked the main rail supply link between North Vietam and China.
The Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., England, reported yesterday record net sales in 1965 of $519,167,600, against $478,491,600 the year before.
GENEVA, April 5 Member nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade opened the way today for the admission of Yugoslavia to their ranks.
LORMAN, Miss., April 5--Negroes clashed with state highway, patrolmen here tonight in a wild, 15-minute melee that pitted bottles against rifle butts, nightsticks and tear gas.

The last "Madama Butterfly" at the old Metropolitan Opera House last night received a routine performance with but few high points. Harold Wilson has taken an impressive first step toward fashioning that role for Britain in Europe that realists on both sides of the Channel and of the Atlantic have advocated with increasing urgency. He hardly could have made a better choice than that of George Thomson to be minister with special responsibilities for Britain's relations with Europe.

TOYKO, April 5 When top finance authorities of six Southeast Asian nations meet with Japanese leaders tomorrow, the Tokyo Government is expected to propose that the countries draw up an integrated economic development plan and hold regular conferences with Japan to promote it.
The National Hockey League completed its six-team expansion plan yesterday by awarding the last franchise to Sidney Salomon Jr., of St. Louis, an insurance executive.

MOBILE, Ala., April 5 J. Max Harrison, a labor relations specialist in the shipping field, who resigned last Oct. 31 as president of the American Maritime Association, died of a heart ailment yesterday at the Mobile Infirmary after an illness of four days. He was 51 years old and lived in Mobile.

CONCORD, N.H., April 5 (AP) Top-ranked Jim Poole of Pasadena, Calif., and Mrs. Judy Hashman of Baltimore led the United States badminton team to a 6-3 lead over Canada last night as a two-day international meet opened.

WARSAW, April 5 (Reuters) Polish authorities announced today that they would stage mass celebrations April 16 and 17 at the same time and place as Roman Catholic Church festivities marking 1,000 years of Christianity in Poland.

Robert O. Pritchard of Haverstraw, N.Y., has been named assistant manager of the Hackensack, N.J., office of the Home Title division of the Chicago Title Insurance Company. He will be in charge of sales. Mr. Pritchard had been assigned to the division's agency at New City, N.Y.
Leading copper shares tumbled on the London Stock Exchange yesterday following the drying up of American buying and worsening labor troubles in the Zambian copper belt.
A check on the mail that Mayor Lindsay is receiving at City Hall revealed strong opposition yesterday to virtually every phase of his $520-million tax package.

"A Sampling of American Music of This Century" was presented in New York University's Eisner and Lubin Auditorium last night by the university's music department in cooperation with Composer's Showcase.
BALTIMORE, April 5 (AP) Mrs. John L. Whitehurst, a regent of the University of Maryland for 33 years, has resigned in protest of the Board of Regents' policy permitting Communist speakers on campus.
PARAMUS, N.J., April 5 (AP) The police searched today for the strangler of a teen-age bride.
Melvyn Douglas is the second star to join the repertory group known as the Association of Producing Artists-Phoenix. In February, Helen Hayes was announced for the troupe.
LONDON, April 5 (AP) Beatles John Lennon and Paul McCartney have sold their shares in the company that collects composers royalties for their songs. They received 146,000 ($408,800) apiece.
Striking longshoremen spread their boycott yesterday to the Brooklyn Army Terminal, halting work on five ships. Two of them were being prepared for voyages to the Southeast Asian war area.
John S. (Bud) Palmer, the city's Commissioner of Public Events, said last night that he would like to hire Miss Sharman Douglas as a hostess for official visitors.

Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving asked the police yesterday to close the East and West Drives in Central Park to automobiles on three Sunday mornings, but was quickly opposed by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes.
Dr. Emy A. Metzger of 350 Central Park West, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, died Monday in Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, after a long illness. She was 71 years old.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (AP) California intervened today in the court battle of a Walnut Creek writer-photographer to regain custody of his 7-year-old son from Iowa grandparents.

An offering of 368,250 shares of Becton, Dickinson Co. common stock was placed on the market yesterday at $56.75 a share by an underwriting syndicate headed by F. Eberstadt Co. and White, Weld Co.

TORONTO, April 5 Canadian Government officials are assuming that the United States Securities and Exchange Commission has dropped its controversial plan to regulate foreign securities held by United States residents.
FRANKFURT, Germany, April 5.--West German television gave the needle last night to Dr. Heinz Nordhoff, head of the huge Volkswagen automobile concern, for raising the prices of his cars.

A British scientist has reported crossing human cells with cells of mice, rats, rabbits, frogs and chickens. Some of the hybrids were said to have propagated normally by cell divi sion for months.

Copper futures yesterday did what comes naturally to futures contracts after a spate of new highs. Prices declined under the influence of profit taking, although the basic reasons for the recent increases remained much the same.

ROMANTICS AND REALISTS," opening to the public today at Wildenstein, 19 East 64th Street, turns out to be one of the best shows of the season. Not very large for an exhibition of its scope, with only 70 paintings to represent eight artists of major stature, the selection nevertheless...

BERLIN, April 6--The Western allies barred armed Soviet military personnel tonight from undertaking salvage operations for a twin-engine ...

The advance in Government bond prices that has been going on with little interruption since early March ran into a setback yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 6-- Congress voted today to extend to May 31 the enrollment deadline for the medical insurance portion of Medicare.

A lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the city's juryselection system on the ground that it systematically excludes Negroes and Puerto Ricans from jury service has been filed in State Supreme Court.
WARMINSTER, England, April 5--Lions are the new come-on in the English stately homes business.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that a comprehensive study of New Jersey construction contracts would be undertaken as part of the effort to arbitrate a labor dispute that has gained national attention.
The Christian Church today, says Bishop James A. Pike, is like a restaurant in a Jewish area that suddenly discovers the reason people haven't been coming in to eat: The food isn't kosher.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- Judge Alexander Holtzoff indicated today that he would not seek to collect fines against the railroad firemen's union unless a specific request to do so was made in his United States District Court.
WASHINGTON, April 6-- Woody Guthrie, the folk composer, balladeer and citizen of the open road who has spent the last 11 years seriously ill in a Brooklyn hospital, was honored...

BRANDON, Fla., April 6-- Don Schollander, whose bathing suit seldom gets wet, faces a three-day drenching in the Amateur Athletic Union's 41st annual national indoor swimming championships. The competition consists of four events tomorrow, seven on Friday and seven on Saturday.
P. Lorillard Company, which withdrew last week from the industry's voluntary advertising code, announced yesterday a new cigarette "designed to deliver reduced tar and nicotine."

Two well-known names in the consumer cleaning products business--Lever Brothers and Glamorene, Inc.--became linked yesterday through an acquisition.

ALBANY, April 6--Governor Rockefeller has vetoed as "premature" a bill that would have allowed a motorist charged with a violation to plead not guilty by mail.
ESTEE LAUDER, the head of the cosmetics concern, was lunching with Mildred Custin, the president of Bonwit Teller, near the pool of the Colony Hotel in Palm Beach a few weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, April 6-- The cherry blossoms are out and Washington is beginning to fill with American tourists, many of whom will be baffled by life in this strange city.

Alert to hay fever sufferers: Now is the time to start desensitization injections for the ragweed pollen season that begins in August.
LORMAN, Miss., April 6-- Calm returned to Alcorn A. and M. College for Negroes today, but civil rights forces said it was only a temporary truce in their battle to oust the college president.
WASHINGTON, April 6-- The automobile industry's voluntary car safety plan has apparently failed to slow a Senate drive for regulatory legislation.

PITTSBURGH, April 6-- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, in line with the Johnson Administration's policy, is taking a close look at its 1966 expansion program, Donald C. Burnham, president, told some 1,000 stockholders at the annual meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, April 6--The serene university campus, warming under the spring sunshine, bore no hint this morning of a storm that raged inside an ancient laboratory building.
Within certain limits, Federal income-tax law allows an individual to deduct from his taxable income all charitable contributions made in 1965 to qualified organizations.
The Chase Manhattan Bank, New York's largest bank, reported yesterday the highest first-quarter earnings in its history.

The City Commission on Human Rights has directed the owner and renting agent of a Queens apartment house to lease a $192-a-month apartment to a Negro nurse who complained she was the victim of discrimination.

Stanley H. Lowell has expressed his willingness to serve as chairman of the hearings scheduled by the City Commission on Human Rights into reported bias in the construction industry if certain legal questions can be cleared up.
The Allied Stores Corporation, one of the nation's largest department store chains, announced yesterday a 25 per cent increase in earnings on a 7 per cent sales gain for the year ended last Jan. 31.

Dick Tiger and Emile Griffith, who will box for Tiger's world middleweight championship in Madison Square Garden April 25, came down from their Catskill Mountain training quarters yesterday to sign official contracts for the 15-round bout.
TRENTON, April 6--Gov. Richard J. Hughes and the State Department of Education clashed sharply today.
WASHINGTON, April 6--The uneasy truce between Governor Rockefeller and Congressional Democrats over legislation to protect the Hudsion River appeared to collapse today.
New York State has disclosed the largest short-term borrowing it has wet undertaken--a $650-million issue of tax anticipation notes.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he would conduct telethons so that New Yorkers could phone him directly "with their suggestions, complaints and other comments."
WASHINGTON, April 6-- The Republican minority in the House laid down today the first definitive line of cleavage with the Democratic Administration on the issue of inflation.
Returning to the South after a four-year interlude at West Point, Paul Dietzel signed yesterday as the new head football coach and director of athletics at the University of South Carolina.

WAYNE, Pa., April 6--Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Warren Marshall Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Marshall, to Nicholas Biddle Paumgarten, son of Mrs. John Tyson of Philadelphia and Northeast Harbor, Me., and the late Harald Paumgarten.
A famous jockey who disappointed the bettors, a relatively unknown young colt who dazzled them and a 59-to-1 shot who stunned them provided the major news at Aqueduct yesterday.
Animal brains cooled almost to the point of freezing have been brought back to life after several hours in cold storage.

Dave Brubeck could do no wrong last night at Philharmonic Hall. Appearing with his quartet before a full house as part of the "Great Performers at Philharmonic Hall" series, Mr. Brubeck even tried to brush off the subscription audience, but to no avail.
Thomas J. Murphy, executive vice president of the Newspaper Guild of New York, said last night that he did not see how the dispute over the newspaper merger here could be settled without a strike.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- Illness today struck the camp ground here of 90 Mississippi Delta Negroes who are protesting delays in antipoverty grants by tenting out in Lafayette Square, across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House.

DADA was the first Happening, also the longest. It started at 6 P.M., Feb. 5, 1916 at the Cabaret Voltaire in Zurich and was declared officially ended at the Bauhausfest in Weimar in May, 1922.

OSLO, Norway, April 6 (Reuters)--Hans Kristian Engen, Norway's Ambassador to the United States died of a cerebral hemorrhage at Lillehammer in eastern Norway today. He was 53 years old and had come from his post for a skiiing vacation over Easter and talks with his Government.
Rival unions representing 12,000 nurse's aides sought yesterday to ease their differences and avert a threatened boycott on deliveries to city hospitals.
WASHINGTON, April 6-- Republicans failed twice in the House today as they sought to force the Administration to trim domestic spending by 5 per cent in the coming fiscal year.
Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving and Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes ended their squabble yesterday over plans to close the East and West Drives of Central Park on three Sunday mornings.
Mike Nichols, the comedy performer who turned to directing stage plays and motion pictures, has signed a long-term television contract with the Columbia Broadcasting System.

THE original idea was to hold a testimonial dinner for Vince Lombardi, the coaching wizard of the Green Bay Packers. But it developed into something of an Old Home Week for Fordham's football heroes of yesteryear and no one was more pleased with this share-the-plaudits extension than Lombardi.

PARIS, April 6--Maria Callas, the opera star, has renounced her United States citizenship to become a Greek citizen. She said she had taken the step to nullify her marriage to an Italian industrialist.
MILL NECK, L.I., April 6-- Miss Katherine Roe Babcock and Dr. Charles Michael Yates of London plan to marry here on May 20.
RICHARD VERBER, a student at Loyola University, captured the first prize in the recent Greater Chicago Open tournament, an eightround Swiss system with a 145-man field.

The New York Bank for Savings, New York's third-largest mutual savings bank and one of the most aggressive competitors in the savings-bank field, is quietly offering to pay a 5 per cent dividend rate to its major depositors, it was learned yesterday.

The alternative tax program for the city recommended by the Economic Development Council merits the rebuke it received from Mayor Lindsay and from Murray Drabkin, the Mayor's fiscal adviser. The council, representing some big business interests, criticized both the Mayor's spending and his taxing proposals as "stopgap" and "self-defeating" plans that would threaten employment.

CLEVELAND, April 6--The United States Commission on Civil Rights has found evidence here of separate and unequal schools for Negroes and whites, along with underlying racial antagonisms that exceed those in the South.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 6--Prof. Emil H. Brunner, internationally known Swiss theologian, died today near the University of Zurich hall in which for many years he had been professor of theology. He was 77 years old.
Only a week after his election triumph, Harold Wilson finds himself under heavy fire from left and right because of the demonstrable ineffectiveness of British policy on Rhodesia.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 6 (UPI)--Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, won the first set from Roy Emerson in the semi-final of the South African lawn tennis championship today, but the match was halted because of rain and poor light.

The city's 34,500 policemen and firemen asked the Lindsay administration yesterday for a joint contract package of wage increases and fringe benefits estimated by their leaders at $200million for one year.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, moved today to force a large part of foreign aid loan funds under the management of international agencies like the World Bank.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- The Hanna Mining Company has agreed to pay the Government a total of more than $500,000, representing overcharges and damages in connection with a 13-year-old contract to supply the Government with nickel from a Government-financed facility.
EVERY season brings a new crop of beauty products. Some of the ones introduced for spring are listed here.

A 5-year-old Brooklyn girl was admitted to Kings County Hospital yesterday in critical condition, suffering from convulsions believed to have resulted from the swallowing of a sugar cube impregnated with LSD, a hallucinogenic drug.

A broad program to reform the way the state takes over private property for public improvements was announced yesterday by a special committee set up by Governor Rockefeller.

OF all of George Balanchine's ballets, his two act "Harlequinade," seen again last night at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center and danced by the New York City Ballet, is among the most accessible, and, for that matter, the most entrancing.

CHICAGO, April 6--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will fight a court order halting his "trusteeship" of a South Side slum building, a top aide of the civil rights leader said today.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) --The Defense Department and the Secret Service have agreed on steps "to insure the timely exchange of information" about possible threats to the President's life.

A decline of 2,655,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, April 6--The Johnson Administration's overriding concern in South Vietnam's political crisis is said to be the survival of the 10-man military junta, with or without Premier Nguyen Cao Ky at its head.
An ornately designed wooden organ was unveiled yesterday morning as the first phase of Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving's plan to "bring the joy of living to Central Park."
LONDON, April 6--The first full-scale price war in more than 30 years has broken out in the British steel industry.

Westchester County's brief water revolt seems virtually over. The round man from Belgium is one of several remarkable statesmen able, through vision, drive or plain common sense, to exert an influence out of proportion to the size of their countries.

From the stoop of the Yorkville brownstone where he lives in a railroad flat with his wife and four young daughters, State Senator Jerome L. Wilson announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives in the 17th (Silk Stocking) Congressional District.

BOCA RATON, Fla., April 6 --Dr. James L. Goddard, the new chief of the Food and Drug Administration, told the nation's drug manufacturers today that some of them were more interested in profits than in patients.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)--Leslie L. Biffle, a former secretary of the Senate and a close friend of former President Harry S. Truman, died of pneumonia today in a nursing home. He was 76 years old.
SAIGON, April 6 (AP)-- United States marines have destroyed a complex of Vietcong camps, hospitals and storage areas 18 miles southeast of Saigon, a spokesman announced today.
The Manger Vanderbilt Hotel at Park Avenue and 34th Street, which has been closed since the first of the year, has been sold for $3,625,000 to a group of investors headed by John Marqusee.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- The Ripon Society, an organization of young Republicans, urged the Republican party today to "fill a leadership vacuum" in developing a more flexible American policy toward Communist China.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., sold 1.4-million shares of common stock yesterday at competitive bidding.

The Composers Cooperative Society presented works by four Americans last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. All were present. Organized in 1964, the society lists, its purpose as being "to further the cause of mainstream idioms in contemporary music."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 6--Secretary General Thant said today that he would be "the first to advocate Security Council involvement" in Vietnam if the North Vietnamese and Chinese Communists could present their side of the case.

WHILE most hairdressers are wavering between Peter Pan and Alice in Wonderland, a small, dapper Frenchman has solved the question (if there really is one) with a steps-and-stairs hairdo that makes the best of both lengths.
THE London Symphony Orchestra's third Carnegie Hall program last night established the orchestra again as an ensemble of powerful expression.

MOSCOW, April 6--A musical invocation of Stalin, composed 29 years ago by Sergei Prokofiev, was suddenly withdrawn from a work performed at a Moscow concert last night, apparently to avoid provoking Soviet intellectuals' fears of a return to Stalinism.
ELMSFORD, N.Y., April 6-- Westchester agreed today to reconsider its lifting of restric tions on the use of water supplied by New York City.
Governor Rockefeller signed into law yesterday his $81-million program to fight narcotics addiction and named an experienced youth worker to direct it.
Four senior officers of the First Charter Financial Corporation, the nation's largest savings-and-loan holding company, have resigned in recent weeks, it was indicated yesterday.

LONDON, April 6--George Brown is still Britain's Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Economic Affairs, but there is puzzlement over his true position in the Government after yesterday's Cabinet reshuffle.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., April 6--The American Tobacco Company "has no intention" of rescinding its recent wholesale price increase for cigarettes, Robert B. Walker, chairman and president, declared today.
The Police Department disclosed yesterday that its Civilian Complaint Review Board had received 186 complaints so far this year, a record for the period.

BONN, April 6--An investigation into the alleged Nazi past of Dr. Erwin Schule, West Germany's principal investigator into Nazi crimes, was reinstated today as a result of the Soviet Union's surprise offer to supply "eye witnesses to the crimes."
The 10 largest banks in the city declared yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's proposed income tax on banks was "economically excessive as well as illegal."
ALBANY, April 6--Thousands of New York housewives have received forms assessing them for unemployment takes based on wages paid to fulltime household domestics in the first three months of the year.

Mrs. John R. Fell and Mrs. Gardner Cowles have been named co-chairmen of the Twentieth Anniversary Salute to Summer, a dinner dance of the Society of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to be held at the Plaza on May 18.
Securities valued at $500,000 have been stolen from the main office of the stock brokerage firm of Thomson McKinnon, the concern told the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, April 6 (UPI)-- Joe Caldwell's two consecutive baskets late in the fourth quarter helped the St. Louis Hawks defeat the Los Angeles Lakers, 120-113, tonight for their first victory in three games in the Western Division National Basketball Association playoff finals.

ROBINSONVILLE, Miss.-- "When we have company," the slender, stylish Mrs. Richard Leatherman Jr. said, "we give them a very country lunch--fried ham, corn bread, quail every way in the world, wild turkey, deer and everything you can find in the garden.
PARIS, April 6--The French Government cut the pay of Air France jet crews today and threatened to replace them if they did not call off a series of 48-hour stoppages.

The Speedwell Services for Children will benefit from the opening day game of the Mets against the Braves on April 15 at Shea Stadium. George S. Leisure Jr. Donald F. McManus and Jerry H. Weiss are cochairmen for the third annual event.

LOS ANGELES, April 6--The seven-month-old grape strike appeared to be nearing settlement today as Schenley Industries, Inc., a major grape grower, formally agreed to bargain with a labor union representing field workers.
YONKERS, April 6--In harness racing, as in other games of chance you win a few, you lose a few and sometimes you break even. Del Insko is one who accepts the situation.
The American Stock Exchange failed to show decisiveness yesterday on which way to move after four consecutive days of broad gains.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) --The Senate defeated 42 to 32 today an effort to kill President Johnson's shift of the Civil Rights Community Relations Service from the Commerce Department to the Justice Department.

A continuing downward trend in privately owned American merchant shipping has reduced United States maritime strength to below the pre-World War II level, a leading shipping trade association said yesterday.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6-- Jack Nicklaus became the reluctant favorite today in the Masters golf tournament, which starts here tomorrow.
Jules Lou Haut, an architect who had been administrator in the Board of Education's buildings department here for many years, died Monday in Little Rock, Ark. He was 65 years old.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 6--The most damn ing, and most accurate, description one can give of the New York Yankees is "just another ball club."
WASHINGTON, April 6-- President Johnson refused today to let the American League limit his options.
The six-day wildcat waterfront strike apparently began to crumble last night.
The Lindsay administration was characterized yesterday by Paul R. Screvane, former City Council President, as "arrogant, stemming from the top."
The Allied Chemical Corporation was reported yesterday by trade sources to be planning a large increase in the price of sulphuric acid, a key ingredient in fertilizer and thousands of other products.

At least 50 concerns, because of the electric utility blackout and the transit strike, are "giving more consideration than formerly" to moving out of New York City, according to an American Management Association survey.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 6-- Ghana will return to civilian government "as soon as possible, in a year or 18 months," Lieut. Gen. Joseph A. Ankrah, chairman of the National Liberation Council, declared yesterday.
The Board of Education decided last night that all afterclass and summer programs to help disadvantaged parochial school pupils must be conducted on public school property or other public premises.
The American consumer is not as confident of the economic outlooked as he was a few months ago but is still "guard-, edly optimistic."
Eli Lilly Co., the Indianapolis pharmaceutical producer, achieved record first-quarter results, Eugene Beesley, presi dent, reported yesterday.
Like some other male strongholds in the city, the New York Chamber of Commerce has never permitted women members. The bylaws don't forbid this, but tradition apparently has.

BOSTON, April 6 (AP)-- Eggs were thrown today at demonstrators marching to protest what they called a lack of police protection for pacifists who were mobbed and beaten outside the South Boston Court House last Thursday.

The Teamsters Union's threat to cut off deliveries of food and medical supplies to all municipal hospitals is apparently fading. But the unconscionable thing is that the threat could ever have been made. It represented a declaration of war on the sick and dying by a bad loser in an interunion power struggle.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday announced that an injunction had been obtained to bar Marquis Guy de la Passardiere, producer of the short-run musical, "PousseCafe," from doing other shows until various accountings, required by law, were submitted...
A last-minute campaign to raise $8-million to save the old Metropolitan Opera House at Broadway and 39th Street was announced yesterday.
CARMEL, Calif., April 6 (AP) --Maj. Gen. Caleb V. Haynes, U.S. A.F., retired, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home. He was 71 years old.

A spokesman of the Chinese Foreign Ministry was authorized yesterday to issue the 400th serious warning in relation to the crimes of aggression the United States has committed by encroaching on China's territorial waters and air space.
Priceless Gem and six other 3-year-old fillies were entered yesterday for today's $27,750 Prioress Stakes.
The Radio Corporation of America reported yesterday the best first quarter in its history.
A Bronx man was sentenced to 20 to 40 years in prison yesterday for a $2 robbery.
DARIEN, Conn., April 7 Miss Nancy Cale, an editorial researcher for The Reader's Digest, and Edward Thorwald Thompson, a senior editor there, are planning to be married on May 28.

BUENOS AIRES, April 7 (AP) The world lightweight champion, Carlos Ortiz of New York, was held to a draw with Nicolino Locche, the Argentine and South American titleholder, in a 10-round nontitle fight tonight.
SAIGON, April 7 (AP) United States infantrymen surprised a Vietcong company in the woods northwest of Saigon today and killed 24.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 7 (AP) A hydrogen-powered space rocket failed to achieve a successful double ignition in space tonight in what could be a serious setback to the United States lunar program.
Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson will receive a George Foster Peabody television award for the program on which she guided viewers around Washington and campaigned for a more beautiful America.
American Airlines is "off the cartoon kick." A new advertising campaign just starting is strictly business.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) The Polish Ambassador, Edward, Drozniak, said tonight that Roman Catholic prelates from the United States and elsewhere would not be allowed to attend the observance May 3 of the thousandth anniversary of Christianity in Poland.
TOKYO, April 7 Japan and six Southeast Asian nations decided today to continue their joint consultations on regional economic development policies at a meeting in Manila next year.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 7 Prime Minister Terence O'Neill, facing the prospect of violence on the 50th anniversary of the Irish Republic's Easter rebellion, alerted the security forces of Northern Ireland today and appealed to the good sense of Roman Catholics and Protestants alike.
GREENVILLE, Miss., April 7 (UPI) A civil rights group announced today the purchase of 400 acres south of Greenville for $140,000 to establish homes and jobs for Mississippi Delta Negroes.
DETROIT, April 7 The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation promised today to comply with a Congressional request for records of any mechanical defects in their automobiles.
TRENTON, April 7 Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed into law today a controversial fairhousing measure that assures the right of a Negro or anyone else to purchase any home anywhere in New Jersey.
Zinka Milanov, for many years queen of the Italian repertory at the Metropolitan Opera, will retire from the company after her appearance in "Andrea Chenier" next Wednesday.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that he would recommend four bills to the Legislature dealing with "shocking abuses" in the service of summonses.

Foward-looking and constructive themes dominated Premier' Kosygin's report to the current Soviet party Congress, a refreshing change from the reactionary tone of many earlier speakers. His emphasis was on the need to make the Soviet economy work better so that it could provide a higher standard of living.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 7 (AP) Raymond Sanchez, who became a national Amateur Athletic Union free-style wrestling champion as a high school senior last year, launched his defense of the title today by pinning David Keller of the Torio (Ohio) Health Club in 9 minutes 36 seconds.

The Federal Communications Commission dismissed yesterday objections filed by the Western Union Telegraph Company to a proposal by the American Telephone and Tele graph Company that customers using their own data equipment be permitted to create additional transmission channels.
Joseph E. Wheeler, production vice president and director of Commercial Solvents Corporation, died last night in Monroe, La., where he lived. He was 54 years old.
Four boys from the upper West Side, all victims of thieves who stole their bicycles in city parks, have collected about 700 names on a petition asking Mayor Lindsay to help them.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 7 (AP) Three assistants were being considered today to replace Paul Dietzel as the head football coach at West Point. Dietzel resigned to become coach and athletic director at South Carolina.

The impending withdrawal of 15,000 more military specialists from the United States Army in Europe, announced yesterday in Washington, emphasizes the severity of the manpower "squeeze" to which the services are being subjected.

BELLEAIR BEACH, Fla., April 7 (UPI) A former champion, Bruce Coffin of Marblehead, Mass., defeated Joel Shepherd of Kalamazoo, Mich., in 21 holes today to advance to the semi-finals of the American Seniors Golf Association championship.
Small twin-engine planes will make 10 daily round trips between Bridgeport, Conn., and the Trans World Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport starting May 1, it was announced yesterday.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., April 7 The Rye Neck Board of Education voted unanimously last night to dismiss a sixthgrade teacher who has created a local controversy by his vigorous opposition to the American involvement in Vietnam.

Bernard Klieger, Abraham D. Beame's campaign director last fall, has been named by the Lindsay administration to a key past in the Economic Opportunity Committee, which conducts the city's campaign against poverty.

Limping back with as much dignity as he could afford, Willie Shoemaker was booed by his backers at Aqueduct yesterday after failing to win for the 28th consecutive time since he came East 15 in Florida and 13 at Aqueduct.
Government and corporate bond prices slipped yesterday in a continuation of the decline that began Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Apri1 7 The Senate Commerce Committee is preparing to stiffen the Administration's auto safety bill along lines proposed by some of the industry's sharpest critics.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 7 Princeton takes to the water on Carnegie Lake here Saturday against Rutgers for its first test under its new coach, Pete Sparhawk.
DETROIT, April 7 (AP) With only four working days this week, United States auto production dipped to an estimated 145,787 units, compared with 195,157 last week and 213,366 in the year-ago week.
Choo Choo Coleman, who once earned $1.50 an hour painting signs that now festoon the back roads of Florida, finally made the Mets after two seasons in Buffalo.

The Paramount Pictures Corporation reported yesterday that consolidated net earnings last year totaled $6,243,000, or $3.90 a share. In addition, it earned $1,092,000, or 68 cents a share, from the sale of investments.
The London Symphony Orchestra, with Istvan Kertesz conducting, gave the fourth and final concert of its Carnegie Hall series last night, on the way back from Australia.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 7 An internal controversy at the United States Naval Academy here over academic vs. "trade school" emphasis in the education of midshipmen broke into the open today with a call by Senator Jennings Randolph, Democrat of West Virginia, for an investigation.
MAX PRUZAN and his wife left for the Caribbean yesterday morning at the request of the Jamaican Government to serve as advisers on development of the resort's fashion industry.
LONDON, April 7 A festival of American arts and humanities, broader in scope than anything that has been attempted by Americans here before, will open next week at the United States Embassy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7 It took five years of effort by women in the Fiji Islands to realize their dream of a training course in nutrition. It was ignored or ridiculed by the men when it opened in 1963, but two years later the men were asking for their own course.

The First National City Bank, New York's second largest and most profitable bank, reported yesterday that its net operating earnings for the first quarter were $25,042,000, or 94 cents per chare, up 11 per cent from the $22,602,000 reported in 1965.
WASHINGTON, April 7 Intercity truck tonnage and rail freight ton-mileage for the latest week ended April 2 were both considerably ahead of the corresponding period the preceding year.

CHICAGO, April 7 A second rundown Chicago apartment building was taken over by a civil rights group under assurned trusteeship today despite a court order Tuesday holding that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s earlier similar seizure of another slum building was illegal.
LONDON, April 7 Television cameras will be allowed in the House of Commons for the first time April 21, when Queen Elizabeth II presides at the opening of Parliament.

MONTREAL, April 7 (AP) Jean Beliveau's goal with just over two minutes to play gave the Montreal Canadiens a 4-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in the opening game of their National Hockey League Stanley Cup semi-final playoff.

WASHINGTON, April 7 The Hanna Mining Company and the Justice Department are still negotiating a settlement of the Government's suit against the company for overcharges on a nickel contract, both sides said today.

SAIGON, April 7 Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi, whose ouster as a member of the governing junta and as commander of the I Army Corps precipitated South Vietnam's current political crisis, combines the flamboyance and impulsiveness of a French paratrooper with the guile of ...
JAKARTA Indonesia, April 7 (Reuters) President Sukarno declared today that he still held real power in Indonesia, but he said many forces were trying to undermine his authority.
The American Stock Exchang moved into high gear yesterday after slowing down on Wednesday.

THE Association of College Unions announced re cently the results of the qualifying stage of the 1966 National Intercollegiate Bridge Tournament. One hundred thirty colleges throughout North America were divided into eight regions and the leading North-South and EastWest pair in each region qualified for the final in Peoria, Ill., May 6-8.
The London stock market closed steady yesterday after a dull preholiday session.

Kings County Hospital reported yesterday that the 5year-old girl who accidentally swallowed a sugar cube that was said to have been saturated with LSD was in good condition. She will probably be released after another "day or two" of observation, a spokesman said.
A college girl's guide to successful dating at the better Eastern men's colleges was published yesterday by two enterprising Amherst men.
WASHINGTON, April 7 The Government's plan for a sweeping redevelopment of Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House to the Capitol cleared a major obstacle today.
ORLEANS, France, April 7 (UPI) Walter Hansgen, an auto racing driver from Bedminster, N.J., died today without regaining consciousness after a crash at Le Mans five days ago. He was 46 years old.
A publisher, a lawyer, a certified public accountant and four businessmen were charged yesterday with income tax offenses in seven indictments and informations filed in Federal Court.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 How far are golf's top players hitting off the tee in this day of the lively golf ball?
SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 7 (UPI) A $1-million gift to the University of Notre Dame's College of Business Administration was announced today by the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, University president.

BRANDON, Fla., April 7 A year ago, in the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championships, Greg Buckingham entered the 400yard individual medley as an afterthought, then won it and broke the American record.
The election of Bert K. K. Bergenfield as vice president for finance and corporate controller of E.J. Korvette, Inc., was announced yesterday. He also has been named a director.
Mayor Lindsay met yesterday with a dozen leaders of the city's business community in an effort to mend a deteriorating relationship involving taxes and other affairs.
LONDON, April 7 A leading British company has to its embarrassment apologized to stockholders for failing to inform them of a scheme to enrich its top executives.
GLEN HEAD, L.I., April 7 Miss Mary Malcolm Gaylord and Don Michael Randel plan to marry in June.
WHITE PLAINS, April 7 Conservationists lost a long and costly fight today to prevent Interstate Highway 87 from being built along Chestnut Ridge in Bedford and North Castle.
American Metal Climax, Inc., announced yesterday it planned to expand its petroleum and aluminum operations.

Thirty angry mothers marched on City Hall yesterday to protest conditions in a Brooklyn public school where a youthful intruder has molested two little girls and tried to rape a third in the last month.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 7 Whitey Ford, who will be the opening-day pitcher for the New York Yankees at Yankee Stadium against Detroit on Tuesday, tuned up today by pitching seven innings in a 7-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

The Rockwell-Standard Corporation showed record firstquarter net income of $10,021,000, or 84 cents a share, the Pittsburgh producer of truck and heavy duty vehicle parts reported yesterday. This compared with $6,915,000, or 58 cents a share, a year earlier.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 7 (UPI) President Johnson announced today that he would sign the Medicare enrollment extension bill at a ceremony here tomorrow.
The telephone company announced a new tactic yesterday in its war on "bootleg phones."
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 Jack Nicklaus carded a 4-underpar 68 for a three-stroke lead as the Masters golf tournament got under way today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Apri1 7 Indonesia's new Government has estimated that the country will need at least $400-million in aid during the coming year to repair its shattered economy.

Joseph Jacob (Joe) Foss, the commissioner of the American Football League, resigned his job yesterday at a hastily called meeting of the league executive committee in Houston. There were strong indications that the resignation came at the request of the league's owners, although they denied it.

SAIGON, April 7 The United Buddhist Church, the driving force behind the campaign to topple the governing military junta, announced today that it had worked out a tentative truce with Premier Nguyen Cao Ky.
PARIS, April 7 Mrs. Dorothy Lewis Vercken, an American fashion editor who wrote under the name of Dorothy Vernon and worked here for more than 35 years, died here yesterday. She was 68 years old.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 113.2 on Wednesday from 113 on Tuesday.
Miss Karen Lazarus and Douglas Clifford Smyth were married yesterday afternoon at the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, by Jerome Nathanson, a leader of the society.
Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello rejected yesterday the demands of the police and firemen for $200-million in wage increases and fringe benefits in a new one-year contract.

William H. Booth, the chairman of the City Human Rights Commission, testified yesterday that two cab drivers lighted up their "off duty" signs and drove downtown on the East Side Drive to avoid picking up "minority group" passengers.

BONN, April 7 Foreign Ministry sources said today that West Germany would not agree to negotiate the continued presence of French troops on its territory before receiving satisfactory assurances about their relationship to defense of the Atlantic community.
WASHINGTON, April 7 The Defense Department will temporarily withdraw 15,000 specialists from the Army's forces in West Germany to meet mounting needs connected with Vietnam.
ST. PETESRBURG, Fla., April 7 The New York Mets, who had been going through the Citrus League like a frost, suffered another catastrophic inning tonight and never recovered.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) Rumors circulated in some Washington circles today that Francis Keppel had resigned as Assistant Secretary of Welfare for Education.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schlesinger of 11 Fifth Avenue and Neponsit, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Fern Schlesinger, to Jeffrey Roy Ashkin, son of Dr. and Mrs. David Ashkin of Belle Harbor, Queens.
WASHINGTON, April 7 The Federal Reserve Board gave its approval today to two more bank holding companies in New York State.

NEW DELHI, April 7 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi made it clear today that she would proceed with President Johnson's proposal for a $300million Indian-United States foundation despite criticism of the plan in India.
Frank De Marchi has never seen George Cannata, but today or tomorrow he's going to walk the eight blocks that separate their homes in Woodside, Queens, to talk about the Vietnam war.

The Diamond Alkali Company has purchased more than 400,000 shares of common stock in the Nopco Chemical Company, it was disclosed yesterday. The acquisition represents about 29.2 per cent of Nopco's 1,368,995 common shares and a market value of $18,450,000.
Taking a leaf, if not a menu, from the airlines, the affiliated Chesapeake Ohio and Baltimore Ohio railroads have now begun a new eat-at-your-seat meal service.

WASHINGTON, April 7 The Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation has overruled a Maritime Subsidy Board decision refusing to authorize the American President Lines to increase crew quarters on five new freighters now under construction for the West Coast steamship line.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 7 Copper production in Chile returned today to near-normal levels, the equivalent of about 620,000 tons a year for the first time in 1966. Legal and illegal strikes at both Anaconda and Kennecott mines had seriously held down output since the beginning of the year.

LISBON, April 7 Portugal rejected today British requests that she block oil shipments to Rhodesia. She stood on the principle of "nonintervention in the free access to the sea of landlocked countries."
WHETHER the late Trafford Price was a hero was a matter of some dispute among the more prosperous citizens of the New England fishing-and-tourist town of Hawley.
The Central Opera Service will hold a three-day conference at the Park Sheraton Hotel beginning Thursday.
Former Markets Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta defended Mayor Lindsay yesterday against criticism expressed the day before by former City Council President Paul R. Screvane.

SAIGON, April 7 (UPI) The enterprising Americans in the green berets the elite jungle fighters of the Army's Special Forces were doing a booming business in the sale of bloodstained "Vietcong battle flags" to United States airmen in Saigon. But their business, a fraud, has been dissolved.
Robert H. Brome, general counsel of the Bankers Trust Company, has been elected, a senior vice president of the bank, according to William H. Moore, chairman.
The Federal Reserve is continuing to pursue a steady course of moderately firm credit restraint, according to data released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.

Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat of Virginia, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said yesterday there would be a delay in acting on an Administration-backed proposal to give Federal agencies new powers to curb abuses in the banking and savings-andloan industries.

LOS ANGELES, April 7 The president of the student body of Loyola University said today that he and other student leaders were collecting signatures for a letter to the Pope protesting the policies of James Francis Cardinal McIntyre, Archbishop of Los Angeles.
The second annual luncheon and fashion show of the Young New Yorker League of the women's division of United Cerebral Palsy will be held at Delmonico's on April 19.

WASHINGTON, April 7 American officials voiced hope today that the agreement reached between the South Vietnamese Government and the Unified Buddhist Church might open the door to a solution of South Vietnam's political difficulties.

Joseph Colombo, known in real estate circles as a highly successful salesman but listed by the police as the head of a powerful Mafia "family," was given a 30-day stay yesterday from going to jail for his refusal to answer questions of a Brooklyn grand jury.

CLEVELAND, April 7 (UPI) The Cleveland Indians traded Ralph Terry, a pitcher, the last holdout in the major leagues, to the Kansas City Athletics today for John O'Donoghue, a left-hander, and $25,000.
Traders made ready for the long three-day holiday weekend yesterday by evening their positions. In most commodities, trading moved at a relatively quiet pace.

UTICA, N.Y., April 7 Mohawk Airlines received the approval of the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to become an affiliate of Midland Charge Plan, a bank credit-card plan of eight Marine Midland banks in New York State. Mohawk will offer the credit plan to passengers beginning today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 The Philadelphia 76ers gained their first victory over the Boston Celtics in the Eastern playoff finals of the National Basketball Association tonight, 111-105, after coming close to blowing a 24-point lead at Convention Hall.
Christians in the city will recall today the Crucifixion of Jesus on Calvary in rites ranging from solemn and traditional Good Friday liturgies to a service of prayers with devout jazz accompaniment.

WASHINGTON, April 7 Senator Karl Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, advised the Citizens Committee for the Preservation of the Metropol itan Opera House in New York today that he will propose an amendment to an appropriations bill to help prevent the structure's destruction.
SAUGERTIES, N. Y., April 7?Donald D. McLennan, night city editor of The Daily News, died here today at his home, 3 Malden Avenue, after a long illness. He was 54 years old.
The Coca-Cola Export Corporation has refused a franchise to an Israeli bottling concern.

TRENTON, April 7 More visitors than ever before in its 75 years have come to the New Jersey State Museum since its opening in October in the gleaming, spacious, new quarters it has as part of the state cultural center. Tonight, hundreds of guests attended a preview of native paintings, sculpture and prints.

WASHINGTON, April 7 Mrs. John Wendell Jamison has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jill Molly Jamison, to Walter Eaton Langsam, son of Dr. Walter Consuelo Langsam, president of the University of Cincinnati, and Mrs. Langsam.

PARIS, April 7 French and allied diplomats in Paris expressed confidence today that France and West Germany would eventually be able to reach an agreement permitting French forces to remain on German soil.
More than half of the $500,000 worth of securities reported stolen by Thomson MeKinnon, a brokerage firm of 2 Broadway, were recovered yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, April 7 (AP) Meredith Willson, composer of "The Music Man," apologized today for making money in his profession.

Seven new books by Pearl Buck are scheduled for the next two years, according to her publisher, the John Day Company. Next summer there will appear "For Spacious Skies," an autobiographical dialogue between Miss Buck and Theodore F. ...
The spot rate on the British pound eased slightly yesterday in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here.
NEW DELHI, April 7 Three persons were killed in Calcutta today when policemen opened fire on demonstrators.

FARGO, N.D., April 7 (AP) Former Gov. Fred G. Aandahl, who served as Assistant Secretary of the Interior in President Dwight D. Eisenhower's Administration, died in a hospital today. He would have been 69 years old Saturday.

CHICAGO, April 7 (UPI) The Chicago Black Hawks made first-period goals by Bobby Hull and Ken Wharram stand up for a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in the opener of their four-of-seven semi-final Stanley Cup playoff.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 7 Robert H.W. Welch Jr., founder and head of the John Birch Society, today called the membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints "a very good recruiting ground" for the society to go to.

Mayor Lindsay, who has checked personally into many of the institutions and agencies he heads, went to jail yesterday morning. He visited the city's jail on Riker's Island to celebrate a forward step in what he called "human renewal."
WASHINGTON, April 7 Negroes who had camped for four days across the street from the White House folded their tents today and prepared to return to Mississippi.

WHEN a college football coach faced a disastrous season in days of yore, he would smile wanly and offer the standard quip, "If I can't build a winner, at least I'll build character." This was not quite as far-fetched as it might sound because most had so much character themselves that they could impart some to the impressionable undergraduates in their care.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7 Arthur J. Goldberg, chief United States delegate, led a "sit-in" tonight in the Security Council chamber in an attempt to bring about an immediate meeting to discuss the Rhodesian situation.
Nine Easter Candy Hunts will be held next Wednesday for the city's boys and girls 13 years of age and under, according to Thomas P.F. Hoving, Commissioner of Parks.
HONG KONG, April 7 North Vietnam affirmed today its four-point stand for settlement of the war in Vietnam and repected consideration of any point separately.

REVOLUTION is an overworked label both in tele vision and in education. The one-hour documentary "Revolution in the Three R's," which the American Broadcasting Company presented last night, could justify the use of the word only in the first segment.
The annual Fete Champetre for the benefit of Fountain House will be held in the Grand Ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria on May 3.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 7 A seaplane hovers over the beach towing the streamer, "BEER PARTY 5-7 ALL U CAN DRINK." And on the sand the bronzed boys and girls squint in the sun, gaze at each other and casually listen to the strolling and singing evangelists.
BOSTON, April 8 "Superman" is earthbound compared to Rameau's "Hippolyte et Aricie," which the Opera Company of Boston staged at the Back Bay Theater here last night.

The Justice Department is expected to announce today or early next week that it has found no basis for opposing the proposed merger of three New York newspapers The Herald Tribune, The Journal-American and The World-Telegram and The Sun.
WASHINGTON, April 7 Dr. Thomas W. McKnew was elected chairman of the National Geographic Society's board of trustees today.
Down by old Carnegie Hall there will be barbershop singing on Monday night.

DALLAS, April 7 Gen. Bernard A. Schriever, commanding general of the Air Force Systems Command, stepped from the cockpit of the XC-142A V/STOL today and described the plane as "particularly applicable for use in congested city areas like New York, Washington and Philadelphia where congestion is becoming progressively worse."
Reports that Calumet Hecla, Inc., had discovered a 35million-ton copper ore body touched off so heavy a spate of buy orders in the stock yesterday that it could not be opened for trading.

The Metropolitan Opera has commissioned Virgil Thomson to write a work "for possible production" the Met has announced. Funds for the commission are being made available through grants from the Ford Foundation and the Koussevitzky Music Foundation.

The abuses in commodities trading exposed by the soybean scandal have led the Department of Agriculture to request sweeping powers over the nation's commodity exchanges. It is seeking amendments to the Commodity Exchange Act that will enable the Secretary of Agriculture to set margin requirements, regulate trading and take legal action against anyone suspected of manipulation.

The week-long revolt of some of the port's longshoremen protesting new work rules dwindled yesterday and most of the 2,000 men who had immobilized a score of ships said they would be back to work this morning.

The unanimous report submitted to Governor Rockefeller by his Committee on Public Employe Relations ranks as a landmark in the search for a dependable way to bar stirkes in the civil service. It provides comprehensive machinery for assuring equity to state, county and municipal workers; it also proposes realistic penalties to protect the community against interruptions in governmental functions.
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters in effect dropped its two-day-old threat to cut off deliveries of food and medical supplies to the 24 city hospitals.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 7 Army posted its third straight baseball triumph today with a 4-2 decision over Fordham. Three runs in the sixth inning, without benefit of a hit, sealed the verdict for the cadets.

JAKARTA, Indonesia Indonesians adore shadow plays in which two-dimensional puppets cast unreal images for the benefit of expert audiences. Such a shadow play is now being produced with the entire country as a stage and, as usual, the main figure is President Sukarno.

WASHINGTON, April 7 The railroad industry has decided to press the United States District Court here to levy fines against the firemen's union and its president for their strike against eight major carriers.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 The largest employer of vineyard workers in the strikecentered Delano area came out today in favor of organizing farm labor.

A panel of labor relations experts recommended yesterday that the state's Condon-Wadlin Law be replaced with a totally new law against strikes by government employes, changing the emphasis from punishment of strikers to improvement of the bargaining machinery.

The Kootz Gallery, one of the country's major art dealers and an early champion of the abstract expressionist school that brought international fame to American painting, is going out of business. When its current show, the work of Ray Parker, ...
Dr. Lewis D. Eigen, former associate director of the Job Corps, was appointed yesterday as vice president of the Grolier Educational Corporation.

Irving and Morris Dankner, brothers who have accumulated a substantial amount of property in the East Village area, have sold 35 parcels of fivestory and six-story walkups to a group of investing clients of Charles H. Levey, lawyer, for cash over mortgages of $1.2million.

HONG KONG, April 7 The police opened fire on a group of rioters in the Kowloon area tonight as thousands of demonstrators took to the streets for the second successive night. They wrecked vehicles, looted or wrecked stores, clashed with British troops and policemen and set fire to buildings.

ATLANTA, April 7 (UPI) A Cuban Baptist minister who was imprisoned along with two United States missionaries a year ago has been freed by the Cuban Government, the Southern Baptist Home Mission Board said today.
BUYING a sailboat has always been a lot easier than learning how to make it go.
As a governor, representative and Assistant Secretary of the Interior, Mr. Aandahl held adamantly to the conservative Republicanism often found in his native North Dakota.
WASHINGTON, April 7 President Johnson received today a special award from the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation for "outstanding contributions to the health of the American people."

WASHINGTON, April 7 Senator Ernest Gruening today accused John W. Gardner, the secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, of hiding "under the table" the department's efforts to spread birth control knowledge.

The appointment of Roger C. Bulkley as vice president in charge of sales for the Pepsi-Cola Metropolitan Bottling Company, Inc., was announced yesterday by Charles C. Davis Jr., president of the company.
GARRUCHA, Spain, April 7 The missing United States hydrogen bomb was recovered intact today off the coast on the 80th day of a search in which the odds were often against the searchers.
MOSCOW, April 7 The Soviet Communist party's 23d congress elected a new policymaking Central Committee tonight.
As a governor, representative and Assistant Secretary of the Interior, Mr. Aandahl held adamantly to the conservative Republicanism often found in his native North Dakota.
