Numismatists and ordinary spenders take note: There is no longer any shortage of dimes and quarters.

"This Winter's Hobby," starring E.G. Marshall, will be withdrawn tomorrow night in Philadelphia after a brief tryout. Mr. Marshall had signed a two-year contract to act in the suspense play after appearing for five years as the senior lawyer in the television serial, "The Defenders."

WASHINGTON, April 7 The Department of Labor said today that the nation's manpower supply had not grown significantly tighter during the first quarter of 1966 despite an expanding economy and lower unemployment.
"A Midsummer Night's Dream" will be transformed into the first major feature-length ballet film to be made in this country.

The late Dag Hammarskjold once called Norway's Hans Kristian Engen "my friend in time of trouble," a description as apt as it was simple. Such times came often at the United Nations during Mr. Engen's long service as Norway's permanent representative and then Secretary of State prior to his appointment as Ambassador to Washington in 1963.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 Edward Hopkinson Jr., financier and civic leader, died last night, apparently of a heart attack, art the Greater Pittsburgh Airport. He was 80 years old and lived in the Chestnut Hill section here.
WASHINGTON, April 7 President Johnson received today a special award from the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation for "outstanding contributions to the health of the American people."

WASHINGTON, April 7 Senator Ernest Gruening today accused John W. Gardner, the secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, of hiding "under the table" the department's efforts to spread birth control knowledge.

The appointment of Roger C. Bulkley as vice president in charge of sales for the Pepsi-Cola Metropolitan Bottling Company, Inc., was announced yesterday by Charles C. Davis Jr., president of the company.
GARRUCHA, Spain, April 7 The missing United States hydrogen bomb was recovered intact today off the coast on the 80th day of a search in which the odds were often against the searchers.
MOSCOW, April 7 The Soviet Communist party's 23d congress elected a new policymaking Central Committee tonight.
SALT LAKE CITY A visitor to the Z.C.M.I. department store here shortly before the peak of the Easter shopping season finds that the elevator operators are living advertisements for the store.
Less than 100 days after his reappointment by Mayor Lindsay, Hospital Commissioner Alonzo Yerby is expected to resign to accept a chair at Harvard University.
A new production of Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande" staged by Gian Carlo Menotti will open the ninth Festival of Two Worlds at Spoleto, Italy, on June 24. The festival ends on July 17.

Mrs. Margaret McHugh Mara, long associated with The Brooklyn Eagle and widely known in newspaper circles, died yesterday at Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, after a long illness. She was the widow of Joseph A. Mara, assistant superintendent of mails in Brooklyn, who died in 1958.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 7 Frank J. Ronan, an executive vice president of the New York Hanseatic Corporation, members of the American Stock Exchange, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn after a brief illness. He was 57 years old and lived at 22 Hampton Court here.
CHICAGO, April 7 Many of the so-called "primitive" peoples of the world may not be so primitive after all, according to reports presented at a scientific meeting here today.
The promotion of Robert C. Shriver, 54, senior vice president since 1961, to the new post of senior vice president and treasurer, was announced yesterday by the United States Trust Company.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 7 After having been dragged along the primrose path by Kwame Nkrumah, Ghana has taken the hard road back to economic, political and social stability under the National Liberation Council.

New Jersey has faced an unpleasant dilemma since defeat of the graduated income tax proposed by Gov. Richard J. Hughes. The choice lay between cutting the Governor's $870-million budget by at least $160 million, thereby eliminating many urgently needed state services, or enacting a sales tax to provide the revenue. It now appears that a bipartisan coalition will choose the latter course, clearly the lesser evil.

WASHINGTON, April 7 The United States is now caught up not only in a war but in what amounts to a revolution in South Vietnam, and its first official reaction to the political turmoil there amounts to a contradiction.
VANCOUVER, Wash., April 7 (AP) City police shot and killed two full-grown male African lions tonight within an hour after they escaped into a residential area.

PITTSBURGH, April 7 The increase in national interest in urban mass transit and transportation between major metropolitan areas is having a marked effect on developments at the Westinghouse Air Brake Company, A. King McCord, chairman and president, told about 350 shareholders at the annual meeting today.

CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) The Department of Justice filed suit in United States District Court today seeking an injunction stopping the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company from alleged antitrust violations.
BERLIN, April 7 The Western Allied command strengthened its guards at East-West border crossings today to bar entry into West Berlin of armed Soviet military personnel.

Msgr. Francis P. Connelly, said to be the oldest priest in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, and pastor since 1931 of Our Lady of Refuge Church, Foster and Ocean Avenues, Flatbush, Brooklyn, died yesterday in Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 88 years old and lived at the church rectory, 2020 Foster Avenue.

YONKERS, April 7 On a pleasant night, when both the track and the horses were razor sharp, the 4-year-old Murdock Hanover made it two in a row at Yonkers Raceway tonight with another late-closing victory, winning the $25,000 1 mile Hal Dale Pace and paying $9.40 for $2.

Burglary and grands larceny charges against an 18-year-old youth were dismissed yesterday in Brooklyn when the court was told he had joined the Job Corps and was "developing into a serious, realistic and well-adjusted individual."
WASHINGTON, April 7 Uncertain whether to crow or run for cover, members of Congress headed home today to sample the mood of the electorate.

Barbra Streisand, whose contract with the Columbia Broadcasting System guarantees her $5-million over a 10-year period, is going to pick up more than $1-million this fall on a fiveweek concert tour of 20 United States cities.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 7 (UPI) Roy Emerson of Australia rallied to whip Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, in the semi final of the South African lawn tennis championship today. The scores were 2-6, 6-2, 3-6, 6-2, 7-5.
BERLIN, April 7 The Western Allied command strengthened its guards at East-West border crossings today to bar entry into West Berlin of armed Soviet military personnel.

Msgr. Francis P. Connelly, said to be the oldest priest in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, and pastor since 1931 of Our Lady of Refuge Church, Foster and Ocean Avenues, Flatbush, Brooklyn, died yesterday in Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 88 years old and lived at the church rectory, 2020 Foster Avenue.

YONKERS, April 7 On a pleasant night, when both the track and the horses were razor sharp, the 4-year-old Murdock Hanover made it two in a row at Yonkers Raceway tonight with another late-closing victory, winning the $25,000 1 mile Hal Dale Pace and paying $9.40 for $2.

Burglary and grands larceny charges against an 18-year-old youth were dismissed yesterday in Brooklyn when the court was told he had joined the Job Corps and was "developing into a serious, realistic and well-adjusted individual."
WASHINGTON, April 7 Uncertain whether to crow or run for cover, members of Congress headed home today to sample the mood of the electorate.

DARIEN, Conn., April 7 The engagement of Miss Stephanie Loe Wold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Antheney Wold, to Peter Terrell Maxwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Huff Maxwell of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., has been announced by the future bride's parents.
ROME, April 7 Pope Paul VI lamented today a modern tendency to seek "human prestige and true wisdom" in forgetfulness of God.
Twenty-six persons were arrested last night in what a police official called "the biggest narcotics crackdown ever" in the Times Square area.
BRUNSWICK, Ga., April 8 (AP) A Federal judge declared the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen in contempt of court today the second contempt citation against the union here this week.
MOSCOW, April 8 The Soviet Union proclaimed today the solidarity of a broad front of Communist and other revolutionary parties advocating unity of action against "American imperialism" in Vietnam.

All of the excitement in the auto world won't be at the 10th International Auto Show at the Coliseum. A "rival" show, restricted to antique automobiles, will be at the Lincoln Square Motor Inn, Broadway and 66th Street.
LONDON, April 8 Harold Charles Drayton, one of the most powerful financiers in the City of London, died last night at the age of 64. He had been ill for two months.
The American Stock Exchange has reported changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

HOWARD HUGHES'S uncle, the late playwright Rupert Hughes, summed up almost 20 years ago the mystique surrounding his nephew when he said: "I can get through to the Almighty by dropping to my knees, but I don't know how to get in touch with Howard."
The National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures, formerly the National Legion of Decency, is taking pity on distributors of condemned films that are re-edited to eliminate "objectionable" elements.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex. April 8 President Johnson said today that he would propose to the next session of Congress broad improvements in the Social Se- curity System. They would include a new program of Federal assistance for financing dental care for children under the age of 6.
"Hulleci," a 41-year-old Turkish hit, will be performed in the original at International House, 500 Riverside Drive, tonight and tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, April 8 David E. Bell, director of the Agency for International Development, told Congress today that despite urgent, chronic population problems, India "has not succeeded to this date in mounting a successful family planning program."
Robert Giordano, a former Democratic assemblyman from the 23d District, Brooklyn, died Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 2346 Pacific Street, Brooklyn.
HONG KONG, April 8 The authorities imposed a dusk-todawn curfew today in the Kowloon area, where mobs have rioted for two nights.

The New York State Banking Department has begun an investigation of methods developed by two large New York City mutual savings banks to minimize withdrawals of large deposits by religious and charitable institutions, it was indicated yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 8 The John Birch Society netted about $5,000 last night from a predominantly Mormon audience that paid $15 a plate to hear Robert H.W. Welch Jr. denounce Federal policies as the product of insanity.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., April 8 Directors of the Westchester County Water Works Conference reluctantly but unanimously endorsed a continuance of restrictions on water use today after four and a half hours of debate.
WASHINGTON, April 8 The Government said today that it would impose new, tougher controls on the use of pesticides.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission says common carriers that furnish local distribution facilities to Community Antenna Television systems must file their rates for commission approval.
SAIGON, April 8 Hopes for a truce between South Vietnam's Buddhist leaders and the governing military junta faded today. Both sides appeared to be preparing for renewed confrontation.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 8 Mr. and Mrs. L. Paul Bremer Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Lynette Bramer, to Arthur Beecher Chivvis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chivvis. An August wedding is planned. I
BATON ROUGE, La., April 8 (AP) Southern University set four meet records, two of them tentative, as the eighth annual Pelican Relays opened today.
COLUMBIA, S. C., April 8, (UPI) Paul Dietzel, South Carolina's new head football coach, said today that Bill Shalosky had left the Army coaching staff to join the Gamecock staff.
For three hours and 25 minutes yesterday peace reigned on the waterfront.
Morton Baum has been chosen board chairman of the City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., it was announced yesterday.
An abandoned blue sedan linked to two fugitives in an investigation of a citywide parking meter theft ring was impounded yesterday by Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel.

BERLIN, April 8 Spring weather has arrived in Berlin just in time for the Easter pass agreement between the two parts of this divided metropolis. On Thursday, with the sun streaming brightly over the city, gaps were opened in the wall again to allow West Berliners to ...

SEATTLE, April 8 (AP) A Seattle insurance broker has been awarded a $150,000 judgment against Richardson-Merrell, Inc., a New York drug concern, for injuries he said he suffered from taking an anti-cholesterol medicine for a year and a half.
ALBANY, April 8 A pilot project to transmit fingerprint records by a facsimile machine to speed criminal identification is reportedly a great success.
Although his customers have switched from the utilitarian Model T to the plush Thunderbird, John J. Hart's philosophy has remained unchanged in the 50 years he has been selling cars in the city.

An 18-year-old paratrooper who was shot while defending his father during a holdup attempt in a Bronx tavern was in critical condition last night. He was transferred from Morrisania Hospital to the Naval Hospital in St. Albans, Queens.

The United Financial Corporation of California, a $361-mililion Savings-and-loan holding company based in Los Angeles, announced yesterday that it was holding preliminary and tentative negotiations headed toward eventual acquisition of the $186-million Van Nuys Savings and Loan Association.

The weary battle to organize workers on California's corporate farms, conducted for a dozen frustrating years, has finally scored its first successes. The decision of Schenley Industries to recognize a striking union of Mexican-American grape pickers is a major breakthrough for industrial democracy. So is the willingness of the giant Di Giorgio Fruit Corporation to cooperate in a state-supervised union election.
NYACK, N.Y., April 8 The stockholders of Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., approved here today the creation of up to 400,000 shares of no-par cumulative preference stock.
MOSCOW, April 8 The Soviet Communist party's 23d congress ended today with Leonid I. Brezhnev in enhanced authority as the party's general secretary.
PITTSBURGH, April 8 The executive offices of the Universal Atlas Cement division of United States Steel Corporation will be transferred from New York to Pittsburgh Aug. 1.

DUBLIN, April 8 The President of the Sinn Fein party, Thomas MacGiolla, today endorsed violence as the only way to achieve his party's aims the expulsion of the British from Northern Ireland and the unification of the North and South.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 8 (UPI) John Rauch, a former star quarterback at the University of Georgia, and Scotty Stirling, a former Oakland sportswriter, emerged today as the men who would guide the Oakland Raiders in the wake of Al Davis's selection as commissioner of the American Football League.
The Trans World Airlines stock-offering plan disclosed suddenly yesterday will make Wall Street history.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 The Masters tournament is generating further evidence in favor of the United States Golf Association's new rule requiring continuous play by a competitor on the putting green until he holes out.
LONDON, April 8 (UPI) Leeds United moved into second place in the English Soccer League's First Division today with a 3-1 victory that snapped Fulham's five-game winning streak.
HOUSTON, April 8 (AP) Al Davis was named today to succeed Joe Foss as the commissioner of the American Football League.
DETROIT, April 8 (UPI) The rail strike aftereffects and the Good Friday holiday cut auto production this week to the lowest level since last Christmas, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) A New Jersey Job Corps counselor was found dead of multiple stab wounds in a motel room today.

Charles Orlando, an American citizen who was arrested last August in Sicily in a roundup of suspected members of the Mafia, said yesterday that he was still seeking to have an Italian court clear his name.

SNETTERTON, England, April 8 (UPI) A New Zealander, Dennis Hulme, negotiated the tight bends of the Snetterton track superbly today to win the Archie Scott-Brown Memorial Trophy automobile race in a Lola Chevrolet 70.
CHICAGO, April 8 The world anthropological profession bestowed tonight its highest award on Professor Claude Levi-Strauss of the College de France in Paris.
Columbia and Princeton open their rowing seasons today under new coaching staffs.
The New York Chapter of the American Scandinavian Foundation has arranged a reception, dance and fashion show for the early evening of April 20 at Delmonico's.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 18 (AP Cliff Richey of Dallas defeated Dimitri Sturdza of Switzerland, 6-4, 6-4, 7-5, today and moved into the final of the Masters invitation tennis tournament.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 8 (AP) Wayne Baughman, a former Oklahoma wrestler now an Air Force lieutenant, won his third-round match in the national Amateur Athletic Union free-style wrestling championships today to remain a strong bidder for a repeat crown in the 191.5-pound class.

Joseph Mallord William Turner, the 19th-century British artist, is providing the Museum of Modern Art with the highest attendance figures in its history. The show of Turner's late water-colors and oils, which opened on March 23, has drawn a daily average of 5,414 persons, and more than 8,000 on Sundays.
BERLIN, April 8 Western officials said today that the Soviet jet fighter plane that crashed into a West Berlin lake Wednesday was a type not before known in the West.
The United Filter Corporation announced yesterday in Los Angeles the appointment of Sherwood H. Egbert as chairman of its finance committee.
ROME, April 8 Pope Paul VI carried the cross tonight through silent crowds of Romans and pilgrims in an open air re-enaction of Biblical accounts of the Crucifixion of Jesus.
ATHENS, April 8 Gen. George Grivas, Athens-appointed head of the armed forces on Cyprus, flew back to Nicosia tonight after talks with Greek leaders.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he was a candidate for a third term.
It was not the best of all possible birthdays for Hirsch Jacobs at Aqueduct yesterday.
Most stock and commodity exchanges were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday.
All evidence indicates that the birth control pills are safe, except perhaps in some special circumstances, an international committee of scientists has concluded.
Some 500 cars with enough horsepower to propel three luxury superliners will go on display today as the International Automobile Show opens a nineday stand in the Coliseum at Columbus Circle.
The International Association of Chiefs of Police plans to study the operations and management of the Police Department at the request of the Lindsay administration.

Henry Hastings Curran, a retired Chief Magistrate and former city official, died of a heart disease early yesterday morning at St. Barnabas Hospital here. He was 88 years old and had been ill for some time.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced yesterday that it arranged for the United Bank of Union, Mo., about 50 miles southwest of St. Louis, to take over the $1.8-million deposit liabilities of the Bank of Gray Summit, Mo. The Bank of Gray Summit, which is about 16 miles from Union, was closed by Missouri banking officials on March 28.
ACAPULCO, Mexico, April 8 (UPI) A flash fire destroyed the outdoor palm-thatched restaurant and bar of the Acapulco-Hilton Hotel today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 The possibility of labor trouble in the nation's soft coal fields arose here today as the United Mine Workers of America and one top-ranking producer signed a contract that other leading companies indicated they would not accept.

KABUL, Afghanistan, April 8 The sun shone unseasonably brightly today for the Chinese Communist chief of state, Liu Shao-chi, Pushtu tribesmen whirled in a frenzied dance in his honor and muscular Uzbek horsemen tore into each other in a wild, polo-like game played for distinguished guests.

RYE, N.Y., April 8 Mr. and Mrs. Andrew S. Ganter have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Ann Gantner, to Richard John Kennet, son of Mrs. Roy Kenney of Evanston, Ill., and the late Mr. Kenney.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 8 (AP ) The nation's First Lady has chosen a slim tunic for her Easter Sunday outfit.

WASHINGTON, April 8 The United States is preparing to reject President de Gaulle's recent demands for the transfer of all American military personnel and installations from French soil by April 1, 1967. It plans to ask for more time.
The Oberlin College Choir, an ensemble long known for its technical and musical excellence, sang a program of sacred music in Philharmonic Hall last night under the direction of Robert Fountain.

ALBANY, April 8 (AP) New York State collected $566.3-million in state and local sales taxes since last August, and $298.4-million of this was credited to the state for the fiscal year that has just ended.
The joyful liturgy of the Resurrection, the crowning glory of Christianity, will mark Easter tomorrow in worship services throughout the world.
Howard R. Hughes, long a controversial and elusive figure in the airline business, is going to sell his 75 per cent stock interest in Trans World Airlines, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 8 Thanks mainly to sales of gold by the Soviet Union for wheat payments, official gold holdings of the non-Communist world rose $31-million in the final quarter of last year, the International Monetary Fund reported today.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 8 (AP) The Northern States Power Company plans a $75-million, 500,000-kilowatt atomic generating plant near here.

WASHINGTON, April 8 College students are not the only persons who may take the Selective Service system's forthcoming college qualification test in applying for 2-S student deferment, Selective Service headquarters noted today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 E. William Henry has resigned as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission and will return to his native Tennessee to campaign for a candidate for Governor who has close Kennedy ties.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J. April 8 A Newark fire captain and a luncheonette proprietor were electrocuted here this afternoon while attempting to rescue a 13year-old boy entangled in highvoltage wires of the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad. The boy survived.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 Gov. Edmund G. Brown won the endorsement today of California's largest body of organized labor in his bid for a third term.

The garment industry's trade association, with a membership that is about 85 per cent Jewish, about 15 per cent Italian and 0 per cent Arab, received a startling communication yesterday from the United Arab Republic.

BRANDON, Fla., April 8 the 200-yard free-style, says Don Schollander, is "my baby." Any doubters were converted when the 19-year-old Yale sophomore won the race today in the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championships.
W.R. Grace Co. announced yesterday that an agreement had been signed for it to acquire the assets and business of Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc.
Congressman [Henry B.] Gonzalez, your excellency Archbishop Lucey, Mr. Mayor, judge, other public officials, ladies and gentlemen:

Lawrence Turnure, retired New York stockbroker, former member of the New York Stock Exchange and father of Pamela Turnure, secretary of Mrs. John F. Kennedy, died yesterday in his home here. He was 63 years and lived at 220 East 63d Street and at Southampton, L.I.

The newspaper unions warned yesterday of the possibility of a strike against the new corporation being formed for the merger of The New York Herald Tribune, The New York Journal-American and The New York World-Telegram and The Sun.
JACKSON, Miss., April 8 (UPI) A three-judge Federal Court outlawed today Mississippi's $2 poll tax as a requirement for voting in state and local elections.

TOKYO, April 8 A Japanese mission will leave for Washington tomorrow to urge greater autonomy for the Americanadministered Ryukyu Islands. One of them is Okinawa, where the United States has a large air base.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 Cesar Chavez, leader of the grape workers in the Delano area of California, accepted with reservations today a proposal by the Di Giorgio Corporation, one of the state's largest growers, for ending a sevenmonth-old vineyard strike.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 8 (Reuters) The topseeded American duo of Gardnar Mulloy and Marty Riessen were beaten by Istvan Gulyas and Andreas Scitkszay of Hungary, 6-1, 8-6, 6-3, today in the quarter-finals of an international tennis tournament.

MOSCOW, April 8 (UPI) A squadron of nuclear-powered Soviet missile submarines kept a close watch on American planes and ships encountered during a recent round-the-world voyage, Krasnaya Zvezda said today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) Agriculture Secretary Freeman raised by 200,000 tons today his estimate of United States mainland sugar consumption this year. About twothirds of the sugar will come from foreign countries whose import quotas were raised.
CHANNEL 2 and the Prince Street Players presented a big bright lollipop to the children last night with their production of an amusing if slightly unorthodox musical "Jack and the Beanstalk."

WITH a flutter of moonbeams and a quiver of quavers Balanchine's magical realization of Mendelssohn's "A Midsummer Night's Dream" flitted into the New York State Theater last night, taking up Easter residence at Lincoln Center. It is a lovely, iridescent thing, full of gentle dancing and sweet music.
When the Easter Week Rebellion came 50 years ago in Dublin, James McNamara was in the thick of it. Tomorrow afternoon he will march down Broadway with other veterans of the Irish independence cause.
WASHINGTON, April 8 Wholesale prices, the Government's best single indicator of inflation, held steady in March after four months of sizable increases, the Labor Department reported today.
DETROIT, April 8 The Ford Motor Company agreed today to send Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, information of any design defects in its cars.
The election of Edwin Clark Davis as a vice president was announced here yesterday by the Borden Company, a large food producer.
Basil Davenport, for the last 10 years a member of the Book-of-the-Month Club's board of judges, died Thursday at his home at 132 East 19th Street. He was 61 years old.
"I HAVE this marvelous stand-up cocktail dress," Margery Rubin of Macy's remarked to a group of young co-workers at lunch the other day.
At least one key Republican in the Lindsay administration is prepared to advise a pro-Lindsay Democrat in a battle for a party nomination.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 8 They thought they would keep laughing at the New York Mets when Wes Westrum sat in Casey Stengel's managerial seat six weeks ago, but when Westrum stood up today to take his team north, they weren't laughing.
THE best short stories about World War II are still the ones told in Bill Mauldin's cartoons. His Willie and Joe characters caught that Armageddon's acrid humors perfectly.
WASHINGTON, April 8 The Johnson Administration openly berated one of South Vietnam's prominent Buddhist leaders today as a divisive element, and in effect encouraged other groups to resist him.
Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving has returned some severe serves from Central Park tennis players and there is temporary peace on the public courts as the outdoor season opens today.

GENEVA, April 8 Switzerland and Yugoslavia have been approved for full membership in the club that sets the rules for international trade, and thereby hangs a tale. Australia, a charter member, has just received clearance for a flagrant violation of the rules; same tale: The rules are changing.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 Peter Butler of England and Paul Harney of Worcester, Mass. took over the lead in the Masters golf tourney today as Jack Nicklaus tumbled back with a 76. Their 36-hole totals were 143.

Secretary of Labor Willard W. Wirtz and George Meany, President of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, initiated another Federal effort yesterday to settle a manning dispute that has kept a new automated American freighter idle for 10 weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) Sixty of the Mississippi Delta Negroes who camped near the White House to seek antipoverty funds left for their homes on two chartered buses today with a pledge to return with a bigger and better demonstration.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 8 The United States orbited an astronomical satellite today, giving man his first view of the stars uninhibited by the earth's atmospheric blanket.

YONKERS, April 8 A final quarter in 28 4/5 seconds, a phenomenal clocking over a half-mile track, sent Cardigan Bay across the line a two-length winner over Marbelhead in a nonbetting one-mile race tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
MILAN, Italy, April 8 (AP) A new device went on display here today, praised by its parents as "the smallest electronic computer in the world."
Despite a facade of almost languid nonchalance, Charles Snitow, the president of the International Automobile Show, is a hard-working, hard-driving executive.
ESSEX, Conn., April 8 Lawrence Joel Eckstrom, a lawyer and consultant to companies with foreign operations, died yesterday in Old Saybrook. He was 69 years old and lived on Gates Road here.
DAKAR, Senegal, April 8 (Reuters) Louis Armstrong and Mahalia Jackson are among the first prize-winners of the first World Festival of Negro Arts, which opened here on April 1.
CINCINNATI, April 8 (AP) Governor Rockefeller was invited today to come to Cincinnati to see the New York Mets begin another baseball season on Monday.

Four major lumber associations reported an increase of 7.5 per cent in production in the week ended April 2 compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week. Output was down 0.6 per cent from the level in the preceding week.
JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), April 8 Christian pilgrims followed today, as they have for generations, the path revered as the one taken by Jesus on His last day on earth.

The Civil Aeronautics Board in Washington endorsed yesterday as "a step in the right direction" proposals filed this week for lower trans-Pacific fares by five major airlines. But it added it hoped the lines would "move toward greater reductions" on the route. The changes would apply principally to flights between the United States and Tokyo and points as far south as Manila.
MAPLEWOOD, N.J., April 8 John H. Schmidt of 12 Warner Road, former vice president and secretary and a director of the General Time Corporation, died Wednesday in Philadelphia at the age of 74.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 9 More than 700 American and Filipino civilians were evacuated this morning from Danang, apparently out of fear that Vietnamese marines were about to try to seize the city from dissident forces.

LOS ANGELES, April 8-Sources close to Howard R. Hughes expressed doubt tonight that the proposed sale of his Trans World Airlines stock would end his projected liti gation with the management of the airline unless this was an unannounced stipulation in his relinquishment of ownership.
MIAMI, April 8 A dramatic rescue in predawn darkness saved 484 persons today abroad a sleek Caribbean cruise ship that was swept by fire, about 50 miles southeast of Guantan- amo Bay, Cuba.
Commissioner of Buildings Charles G. Moerdler accused two Criminal Court judges yesterday of being too lenient with chronic violators of the Building Code.
Eight salary increases ranging from $1,500 to $4,000 a year have been granted by Mayor Lindsay. They became known yesterday through publication in The City Record.
Jacob H. Gilbert, a lawyer in this city for more than a halfcentury, died yesterday in his home at 404 Riverside Drive. He was 83 years old.
CLEARWATER, Fla., April 8 (AP) Roger Craig was signed today by the Philadelphia Phillies in an effort to bolster their relief pitching.

WARREN, R.I. April 8 A $155,500 ferry will be built here to operate between Fishers Island, N.Y., and New London, Conn., starting next fall, it was announced here today by the Blount Marine Corporation.

BONN, April 8 Shares of Lufthansa, the West German airline, will be listed on West German stock exchanges next Thursday after a prelude of hectic speculation and uncertainty concerning their future price development.
A dispute between the Brooklyn Public Library and city officals who administer the municipal job freeze is keeping the Flatbush area of Brooklyn without library service, and no solution is in sight.

Recovery of the missing American hydrogen bomb from the depth of half a mile beneath the surface off Spain's Mediterranean coast was a superb demonstration of the Navy's technical capabilities in the field of oceanography.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 8 (UPI) Lynda Bird Johnson is wearing a gold "friendship" ring on her third finger left hand, a gift from George Hamilton, the movie actor.
PARIS, April 8 (AP) Lucien Chauviere, an aviation pioneer, died yesterday in his Paris home. He was 90 years old.

ABOARD U.S.S. ALBANY off Garrucha, Spain, April 8 A 20-megaton United States hydrogen bomb, a bit dented but otherwise intact after 80 days on the sea bottom, was put on display before officials and correspondents today to establish the "international credibility" of the United States. It was the first time a nuclear weapon had been shown in public.

The announcement of the first two staff appointments by the Temporary State Commission for the Constitutional Convention reflects the fact that essential preparatory work is going on for the meeting that will convene in Albany a near from now.

A MAJOR-SUIT game is usually chosen in prefer ence to three no-trump when the combined hands have 8 or more cards in the major. But the no-trump game may be at least as good if two conditions are fulfilled: all side-suits must be well stopped; and there must be no ruffing trick available in the short trump hand.

A 38-year-old amateur theater group, the Barn Theater Guild, will open its new playhouse in Morris County, N.J., tonight with an invitation performance of William Gibson's drama "The Miracle Worker." The play will be repeated Saturday through Sunday of next week and April 21 through 24.
The prospect of using a computer to simulate vast changes in weather and climate has been raised by a leading specialist in research on earth's atmosphere.
The Green Giant Company, a LeSueur, Minn., vegetable canner, announced yesterday the appointment of M. Crawford pollock and C.J. Tempas as senior vice presidents.
MEN'S fashion, which has steadily been turning back the clock to the heyday of the Victorian dandy, has rediscovered the flapping necktie that covers the shirt front.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) The Army, expediting still further its Vietnam buildup, announced today it would open three more reception and training centers, each capable of handling an average of 10,000 recruits.

"The New Class Divided," by Albert Parry, will be published by Macmillan on May 2. The author, a native of Russia, is Professor of Russian Civilization and Language at Colgate University. His book analyzes the actions of the new elite of Soviet society physicists, economists, artists, industrial managers, writers and physicians. He holds that they are increasingly out of step with the party line, but are beginning to shape Soviet ideas and ideals.

To the chant of religious hymns, 12,000 students staged a solemn demonstration and procession yesterday near the headquarters of the Soviet mission to the United Nations, charging suppression of Jewish religious and cultural rights in the Soviet Union.
RACINE, Wis., April 8 (AP) It may be quite a while before 9-year-old Danny Christensen understands why adults find golf difficult.
WASHINGTON, April 8 A Connecticut industrial physicist believes he has developed a major improvement in the basic aluminum-production process discovered 80 years ago.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) The whooping cranes have started their northward flight to nesting grounds near Canada's Wood Buffalo National Park, the Interior Department announced today.

The Camp Nyda Service Group will hold its annual spring luncheon and fashion show April 19 in the WaldorfAstoria's Sert Room. Mrs. Ben Massell, Mrs. Jacob Manne and Mrs. Henry Firestone are in charge of plans for the event.
TEANECK, N.J., April 8 Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey Cohen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Arlene Cohen, to Martin Katzman, son of Mr, and Mrs. Ira Katzman of Englewood.
The French-built Viking Princess sailed under three names and three flags before catching fire on a Caribbean cruise run.

A lion that had been prodded with sticks and pulled from its cage to pose with a model at the Coliseum yesterday, turned on the model, sank its teeth into her thigh and held on until a handler pried its jaws open.
It is impossible to believe that many of the African governments condone the behavior of Moussa Leo Keita of Mali in holding up a United Nations Security Council meeting on Rhodesia for two days.

PITTSBURGH, April 8 The United Negro Protest Committee has set up picket lines at Gimbels and the Joseph Horne Company, department stores, to protest alleged racial discrimination in hiring practices.
ISLAMORADA, Fla., April 8 (AP) John Alden Knight, widely known outdoorsman and author, died at his winter home here early today. He was 75 years old.
The Polite Department will add 100 members to its Narcotics Bureau, raising it to a record permanent strength of "slightly more" than 300 men and women, Commissioner Howard R. Leary said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April,8 The International Brotherhood of Teamsters will be asked for a $20.4-million increase in annual dues to meet "the ever-increasing cost of trade unionism in today's market."
As a result of the first major policy change in several years, visitors to the Central Park Zoo will include animals as well as people by the time summer arrives.

ATLANTA, April 8 Mickey Mantle, unexpectedly and at his own request, played six innings in left field tonight, came to bat four times left-handed and drove in a run with a single in his first real game activity of the 1966 baseball season.
The chairman of the Commercial Credit Company resigned yesterday and applied for early retirement.
A complaint to the Appellate Division yesterday charged that Mayor Lindsay had violated judicial practice in being photographed in a Bronx courtroom Wednesday night.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 8 (UPI) Fifteen cars, including one driven by the favorite, Mrs. Pat Moss Carlsson, withdrew today from the 14th East African Safari Rally following a torrential rain on the route to Dar-es-Salaam that made driving a nightmare.
BOSTON, April 8 (UPI) Local newspapers again hit the streets today, officially ending a costly 34-day strike.

OAKTON, Va., April 8 Mr. and Mrs. John Welles of Oakton and Hull, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Evelynne Welles, to Alan M. Bekelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Bekelman of Providence, R.I.

More than 25 major insurance companies, uphappy at being taken for a ride on small claims for damage to convertible car tops, have decided to have the cars fixed rather than pay cash to claimants here.
LONDON, April 8 (UPI) The total tonnage of the world mercantile fleet, which is crippled through lack of work, fell to a new low last month.
Graustark, the winter-book favorite for the Kentucky Derby, and Moccasin will return to competition today in a pair of six-furlong dashes that overshadow the remainder of the national turf program.
Tax experts said yesterday that Howard R. Hughes, upon the sale of his 6.5 million shares of Trans World Airlines stock, would be subject to a long-term capital-gains tax.

JACKSON, Miss., April 8 Mississippi's 1908 prohibition law the last such law in the nation was ruled today by a county judge to have been repealed by the state through the systematic taxing and regulating of illegal liquor.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 8 A meeting of the Security Council on the new Rhodesian crisis was put off until tomorrow morning despite fresh attempts by Britain and the United States to induce the Council President to convene it today or tonight.

William Dean Embree, a retired lawyer who had represented J.P. Morgan Co. and John D. Rockefeller Jr., but probably won his greatest distinction in legal service for the poor, died Thursday in his home, 2 Marcotte Lane, Tenafly, N.J., after a short illness. His age was 85.

Secretary of State Dean Rusk will be interviewed during a one-hour news documentary on China April 27 at 10 P.M. Mr. Rusk will discuss past, present and possible future contacts between the United States and Communist China and the threat of war in Southeast Asia in a broadcast over the American Broadcasting Company's television network.

An attractive young fashion coordinator adjusted her bellbottom slacks under her Norwegian blue fox coat yesterday with two rubber bands so she could appear before a fashionminded judge and pay a traffic fine.
LISBON, April 8 Portugal accused Britain today of trying to make her the scapegoat in the Rhodesian affair.

The Park Avenue Synagogue has arranged a champagne preview next Saturday evening for members, art critics and collectors at its seventh annual art show and sale. The event will be open to the public from 4 P.M. to 11 P.M. for three days starting April 17.
CLEARWATER, Fla., April 8 (AP) An experienced tournament player and a rookie gained the final today of the American seniors golf cham pionship.
SAIGON, April 8 (AP) United States Navy fighterbombers sank 12 cargo junks and damaged 22 yesterday in the drive to curb North Vietnam's movement of supplies, a military spokesman announced today.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 8 (AP) James J. Corbett, athletic director of Louisiana State University for the last 10 years, underwent emergency surgery early today after he was found in his wrecked car with a bullet wound in his chest. His condition was listed as good.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) The communications Satellite Corporation asked its shareholders today to re-elect its directors and reject a proposal to place an age limit of 72 on them.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., April 8 (AP) A 15-year-old heiress who was missing for two weeks said today that she had left home to be with her boy friend.

The Kroger Company, one of the nation's largest food chains, had record sales in the first quarter this year but earnings declined because of increased costs of goods, materials, wages, and taxes, Jacob E. Davis, president, reported yesterday.

BOSTON, April 8 While thousands of Roman Catholics observed the traditional threehour vigil of Good Friday in churches here today, a small group of laymen began a 72hour watch outside the official residence of Cardinal Cushing.
Seven categories of classic cars ranging from real live antiques to model racers will be among the special exhibits at the 1966 Automobile Show, opening today at the Coliseum.

The liturgical gave way to the colloquial yesterday at the Broadway United Church of Christ as more than 1,000 persons observed Good Friday with a gentle blend of Bach, the blues and prayer in the contemporary vein.

TO poker fans, "The Sky's the Limit" will prove a great pleasure. Its knowledge of the game is impressively detailed and its use of this knowledge absorbing. Its story is bluntly melodramatic but how much easier it is to be persuaded by blunt melodrama than by the spurious drama of "The Cincinnati Kid," a poker novel of a few years back! Both books would have to be called far-fetched.
The Mako Shark II, Chevrolet's experimental car is everything from a James Bond-style car to a streamlined servant and a traveling laboratory, depending on who is looking at it.
CIRCUMSTANCES such as those surrounding the missing V.M.I. class ring that turned up 30 years later are not common.
PIERRE, S.D., April 9 (UPI) The South Dakota Supreme Court today ordered the State High School Interscholastic Activities Association to accept parochial and private schools as members.
KABUL, Afghanistan, April 9 Communist China's chief of state, Liu Shao-chi, left Afghanistan this morning after failing to win Afghan support for China's position on Vietnam.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 9 In the Appleton Chapel of the Harvard Memorial Church today, Miss Mary Anna Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Campbell of Moorestown, N.J., became the bride of Peter Barry Bloch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bloch of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Jack Mendelsohn performed the Unitarian ceremony.
THE auto industry, in its tortuous approach to racing, is pushing the accelerator and the brake at the same time.

Sanford Allen, a violinist who is a member of the New York Philharmonic, and Lawrence Smith, a pianist who is an assistant conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, joined forces to play five sonatas for their instruments in combination at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. The works were by Bach, Handel, Mozart, Faure and Hindemith.

WITHOUT question the book of the day here is Capote's "In Cold Blood." It reached us with the biggest fanfare of publicity that has accompanied any American book since "By Love Possessed." This alone guaranteed it the full critical treatment, in the most fundamental sense, since it is the inevitable tendency of reviewers of English, reviewers at least to believe that no book can be as good as it is said ...

Yet another volume on Keats! Douglas Bush hopes "there may still be room for a small book which, after a fashion, covers both his life and his poetry." THE standard conversational opening among diplomats at Havana cocktail parties is no longer "Como esta?" ("How are you?") but "Donde esta?" ("Where is he?"). "He" is Ernesto Che Guevara, once the most powerful man in Cuba next to Premier Fidel Castro. Che vanished a year ago, becoming the central figure in a still-deepening mystery that frustrates international intelligence services, and something of a mythic hero to many LatinAmerican radicals.

FRANKFURT, Germany. THE essential conclusion to be drawn from a sampling of European television is the importance of balance in evening programing. HOUSTON, April 9 (AP) The Minnesota Twins of the American League overcame a five-run deficit to beat the Houston Astros of the National League, 7-6, before 20,553 fans tonight in the night half of a baseball double-header.

JAKARTA, Indonesia China's grand strategy for Southeast Asia received a mortal blow last month when anti-Communist leaders seized power here and reoriented Indonesia's foreign policy. An imminent political wedding Between Jakarta and Peking was brusquely forestalled and today this country, in search of genuine neutrality, is on increasingly bad terms with Mao Tse-tung's regime.

BONN, April 10 The political and legal issues raised by President de Gaulle's decision to withdraw French forces in West Germany from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's command are so complex that no final settlement is expected before September or October.
WASHINGTON, April 10 The United States does not intend to prescribe, much less impose, a political solution for South Vietnam, Under Secretary of State George W. Ball said today.
Wellington Wales, a member of the editorial board of The New York Times, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 236 East 32d Street. His age was 48.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to $94,434,434,472. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
The Queens District Attorney's office reported yesterday that 32 Duncan parking meters, presumably once used in New York City, had been found in a clearing along a wooded path in East Patchogue, L.I.
The city's Commissioner of Purchase, Richard Lewisohn, said last night that he was trying to design a standard letterhead for city officials.

COMPETITIVE bridge flourishes in many remote countries that are outside the main stream of international competition. India, for example, holds regular national championships but has only once been able to meet the heavy financial burden of sending representatives to a world event.

LONDON, April 10 Evelyn Waugh, who wrote deeply moral satires that flayed the English aristocracy he identified himself with, died today at his home in Taunton, Somerset, 140 miles west of London. He was 62 years old.
Assemblyman Bertram L. Podell said yesterday that he would conduct hearings on universal water metering here next month.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 (UPI) The Los Angeles Lakers suffered a 112-100 defeat at the hands of the St. Louis Hawks in the National Basketball Association's Westtern Division playoff series here tonight.
The School Settlement Association will hold its annual luncheon and fashion show Thursday at the Pierre. Mrs. Henry M. Hunter is chairman of the event.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 10 Sixteen thousand persons here have signed pledges of support for the principle of "fair housing."

ALBANY, April 10 The Supreme Court"s one-man, onevote ruling and the state-court assigned reapportionment plan that grew out of it are expected to be attacked from several sides at the 1967 State Constitutional Convention, according to a source close to the convention planning.

ROCHESTER, April 10 (AP) Dave Camp of Brattleboro, Vt., celebrated his debut in the American Bowling Congress tournament today by tying for fifth place in regular all-11 events with a nine-game total of 1,912.
LUCENS, Switzerland, April 10 Sherlock Holmes and his friend Dr. Watson have abandoned London's fog to take up residence in a 12th-century castle on a hillside dominating this sleepy Swiss hamlet.

First-quarter earnings of the Hammermill Paper Company rose to $1,957,000, equal to $1.04 a share, from $1,556,000, or 83 cents a share, in the 1965 quarter, it was reported yesterday. Sales of the producer of fine papers increased to $41,883,000, from $31,820,000 a year earlier.

When the first horse-cars began to roll through New York City's streets shortly after 1850 the fare was five cents. When the first subway train rumbled uptown in 1904 the fare was five cents. It was, in fact, nearly a half-century later before this standard, to which every politician repaired as warmly as to mother love and the flag, had to yield.

WARSAW, April 10 (UPI) Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski said today that "great obstacles" had made it impossible for Pope Paul VI to come to Warsaw for this spring's celebrations of 1,000 years of Christianity in Poland.
The head of the printers' union urged a postponement yesterday of the proposed merger of three New York newspapers.
BERLIN, April 10 Bishop Otto Dibelius stepped down today as head of the Lutheran Church in Berlin with a bitter denunciation of "modern barbarism" and the loss of religious belief.
Four thousand Irish-Americans and Irishmen marched down Broadway yesterday to commemorate the Dublin Easter Rising of 1916.

Morris A. Goodman, a partner and a founder in 1925 of the real estate construction and investing firm of Tishman Goodman, 19 West 44th Street, died yesterday in his home at 115 West 86th Street. His age was 83.
PITTSBURGH, April 10 Steel officials were keeping a close watch on automobile, defense and machinery markets last week.
Easter in New York yesterday became once again the occasion for song, for meditation on the mysteries of life and death and, in the midst of joy, for solemn prayers for a peaceful world.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 10 (UPI) Mrs. Jerrie Mock, a 40year old housewife, touched down safely tonight after a record-breaking, non-stop, 4,550mile flight from Honolulu.
Atlanta officially becomes big league tomorrow night. The new home of the Braves will play opening-day host to the Pittsburgh Pirates in the city's new $18-million, 57,000-seat stadium.

Although Bill Casper finished at 294, in a tie for 10th, he treasured another honor he received. As a commendation for entertaining troops in Vietnam, the San Diego professional was advised he had been awarded an honorary membership in the Fifth Special Forces Group Airborne, the "Green Beret," by their commanding officer.
A 33-year-old man and his young son were killed in Brooklyn last night when their Station wagon hurtled a six-inch abutment on a dead-end street and plunged into Gowanus Bay.

BOSTON, April 10 The Boston Celtics took a 3-1 lead in the four-of-seven Eastern final playoff of the National Basketball Association today with the most exciting finish of the set so far, beating the Philadelphia 76ers, 114-108, in overtime.
A further substantial growth in economic activity over the months ahead was predicted over the weekend by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
KANSAS CITY, April 10 (UPI) Ralph Terry, the major leagues' last holdout, agreed to terms today with the Kansas City Athletics.

The arduous struggle for Puerto Ricans and Negroes here and the handicaps with which they start their climb upward for better living have been indicated anew in data drawn together by social scientists of three universities.
A group of 50 pickets brought their protest against the Vietnamese war yesterday to a Fifth Avenue sidewalk jammed with Easter Sunday strollers.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the sweeping reforms he is pushing could not have been undertaken by former Mayor Robert F. Wagner because the state and Federal governments had not then developed an interest in urban problems.

MILWAUKEE, April 10 (AP) Circuit Court Judge Elmer W. Roller said tonight that his ruling in Wisconsin's antitrust suit against baseball might not come until Tuesday, when the Braves are scheduled to open the season in Atlanta.

Within certain restrictions, a Federal taxpayer may deduct the cost of medical care for himself, his wife and his dependents. He may claim the deduction, of course, only if he itemizes all deductions, rather than taking the 10 per cent standard deduction or the minimum-standard deduction, in figuring his tax return due Friday night.
MOSCOW, April 10 (UPI) About 100,000 Russians crowded Moscow's 40 active Russian Orthodox churches for Easter services.
An ex-convict allegedly made $100 a day for the last 10 weeks by posing as a police captain and shaking down tavern owners in Harlem and Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The Vice President will get an official residence, but not any time soon.
Guests taking the fourth annual art tour for the benefit of the National Council of Women of the United States on April 19 will get an intimate view of artists in their places of work.
ZAGORSK, U.S.S.R., April 10 The rasping cries of ravens perched in trees above the Troitse-Sergiyeva Monastery provided a cacophonous background today for Russian Orthodox Easter services.
News about irregularities involving the military service academies evokes unbendingly stern public reaction more so than when similar word comes out of an ordinary civilian college.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 10 One of the immediate problems facing the new Government of Indonesia is how to end the undeclared war against Malaysia, without appearing to do so.

Senator Stennis and his Preparedness subcommittee have done the nation and the armed forces a service is pinpointing the Army's serious deficiencies of personnel and materiel. The temporary withdrawal of 15,000 Army specialists from West Germany to meet military needs in Vietnam confirms the strain.

BUFFALO, April 10?Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Rich Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Jeanne Rich, to Winston Lauder of New York, son of Mrs. Seymour Worrall Hyde of Greenwich and Hartford.
The first quarter of 1966 was a spectacular one for the stock market, according to Harold Clayton, market analyst for Hornblower Weeks-Hemphill, Noyes.

The seizure by a British naval vessel of a Greek tanker on its way to Beira in Portuguese Mozambique with oil believed destined for Rhodesia dramatizes the effort to constrict Rhodesia's economy. It would be unrealistic to consider it in any stronger light because Rhodesia can manage without oil from that source, thanks mainly to South Africa's help.
NEW DELHI, April 10 Asoka Mehta, Minister of Planning, will leave for the United States this week to begin detailed talks on Indian requirements for foreign aid.
CORDOBA, Argentina, April 10 (UPI) John F. Kennedy Jr., 5 years old, managed to take a dip in a country stream without a bathing suit yesterday when his mother wasn't looking.
The king-size cargo container the kind that doubles as a barge rather than the much widely used lift-on variety has made its debut in the Port of New York.
MELISSA HAYDEN returned to Balanchine's "A Midsummer Night's Dream" at the State Theater, Lincoln Center, over the weekend, and not being a young lady to skimp anything, she returned twice.

Two leaders of unions of municipal employer engaged in a heated public argument yesterday over Mayor Lindsay's proposed substitute for the Con don-Wadlin Law regulating the city's labor-management relations.

Samuel L. Deitsch, a retired garment manufacturer who had quit school in his early teens but ended up as acting president of a college last year, died last night at University Hospital after an illness of three weeks. He was 76 years old and lived at the Oliver Cromwell Hotel, 12 West 72d Street.
Robert L. Rowe, chairman and president of Rowe Industries, Inc., has been elected a director of the Aurora Plastics Corporation, it was announced over the weekend by Abe Shikes, president of Aurora.

CINCINNATI, April 10 Dr. and Mrs. Johnson McGuire have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Johnson McGuire, to James Alexander Muspratt, son of Mrs. V.R. Muspratt of Tying, Hertfordshire, England, and Oliver Musuratt of Estepona, Spain.
A tug sent by the owners of the Viking Princess to salvage the still-smoldering hull of the $16-million cruise ship was waved off by the Liberian freighter Navigator late yesterday afternoon.
The shipping industry may seek to impose financial penalties on longshoremen who have violated the port's labor contract provisions and defied a court restraining order against their wildcat strike.
ROME, April 10 Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will come to Rome April 21 for talks with the Italian Government and, probably, with Pope Paul VI, according to informed sources.
BRANDON, Fla., April 10 If swimmers have their way, their national indoor championships will never again be held outdoors.

MILANO MARITTIMA, Italy, April 10 (UPI) A young mechanic was killed and four drivers were injured today in a series of accidents at a motorcycling competition. A Milano Marittima city employe and an Italian police captain also were injured in two of the accidents.

Opposition in the Legislature to Mayor Lindsay's plan to tax commuters may kill his entire proposal for a personal-income tax, Murray Drabkin, the Mayor's special consultant on taxes, said last night.

On Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon, a 6-year-old girl pulled a rabbit around on a leash, a poodle wearing a wrist watch and red nail polish was paraded by its owner, and a woman smuggled a cat named Nebuchadnezzar into St. Patrick's Cathedral to be blessed all in celebration of Easter.
DUBLIN, April 10 Ireland's Proclamation of Independence, first heard in Easter week 50 years ago, was read here again today.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 10 (UPI) George Hamilton, the actor, said today he had given Lynda Bird Johnson a friendship ring, but that the two were not engaged.
The Luther E. Woodward School for Emotionally Disturbed Children in Freeport, L.I., will benefit from a charity ball at the Colony Club in Lido Beach, L.I., on April 30.

HAVING celebrated the chocolate-bunny, aspects of Easter with Mary Martin and the Rockettes the week before, NBC-TV observed the spiritual side of the holiday yesterday afternoon with a program of sacred music taped at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family on New York's East Side.

WASHINGTON, April 10 A new approach to the preservation of historic sites was disclosed today in a joint announcement by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

The 23d Soviet Communist party Congress strengthened the evidence that the Soviet Union has become one of the world's great conservative powers, far more interested in the international stability it needs for rapid internal economic development than in revolutionary adventures on a global scale.

The New York Flea Market, an outdoor arts and antiques show, will open its third season next Sunday. Proceeds from the opening day will benefit the educational programs of the Community Committee of the Brooklyn Museum.
NOGALES, Mex., April 10 (AP) An Easter vacation for 12 residents of Tucson, Ariz., ended in tragedy today when they perished in the crash of their twin-engine plane at this Mexican border town.

NEWARK, April 10 Three hundred people made homeless by a fire early yesterday that destroyed nearly an entire block here spent Easter with relatives, friends, neighbors and generous strangers, and in apartments provided by the Newark Housing Authority.
LEO Durocher may have shaped his baseball thinking," a friend of Wes Westrum's said yesterday, "but Wes's philosophy is closer to Norman Vincent Peale's."

LINCOLN, Neb., April 10 (UPI) Steve Combs, a 24year-old Deerfield, Ill., science teacher, last night was named the outstanding wrestler of the Amateur Athletic Union's national free-style wrestling tournament.
FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., April 10 President Johnson, looking relaxed and genial, attended Easter services today with his family and his neighbors at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church here.

Mayor Lindsay, yielding to heavy pressure, has indicated willingness to accept important modifications in his legislative proposals for consolidating the city's transportation agencies. The changes are in the right direction. They tend to cut down the excessive concentration of power in the hands of the Transportation Administrator and the Mayor himself without in any way weakening the sound fundamental objective of coordinating basic policy.

DAVIS, Calif., April 9 While the nation has been worrying about problematical dangers of high-powered farm pesticides, supposedly innocuous farm chemicals have been contaminating many urban water sources.
"The Papers of Woodrow Wilson, Volume I: 1856-1880," sponsored by the Woodrow Wilson Foundation and Princeton University, will be published by the university's press in September.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 10 (UPI) Manuel Santana of Spain reached the singles final in the Monte Carlo tennis championships today by beating Ken Fletcher of Australia, 7-5, 9-7.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, April 10 Matriarchy, polygamy and the purchase of brides are the targets of a sweeping program of social and political change that is planned to accompany the present rapid expansion of the Ivory Coast's economy.

The Lindsay administration, as a result of the city's deepening fiscal crisis, is studying the possibility of seeking higher payments on tax-exempt properties of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and the Port of New York Authority.
Fordham University plans to increase its enrollment by more than 50 per cent, turning its largely local student body into an "exciting" one drawn from all over the country.
SALT LAKE CITY, April 10 (AP) A high official of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints issued a plea today for tolerance and understanding among the races and creeds of the earth.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) Estimates by Justice Department officials have indicated that Negro voter registration in five Deep South states has risen almost 50 per cent since Congress passed the Voting Rights Act last summer.
The decline in interest rates on new corporate bond issues that began in mid-March and ran into rough going last week will be tested thoroughly this week.
Val Goff Norton, pianist from Tulsa, Okla., made her New York debut yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 10 (AP) Motorists were urged today to avoid using the New Jersey Turnpike in the vicinity of Elizabeth during morning and evening rush hours for the next three weeks, to avoid traffic delays.

WAUWATOSA, Wis., April 10 Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph G. Kuss have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ann Kuss, to Rob- ert Cooper Simmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Simmons of Pittsfield, Mass.
Eric Andersen and a trio gave a concert at Town Hall Saturday night that filled the auditorum and turned away 400 ticket-seekers.
SAN DIEGO, April 10 (AP) An air-sea search found debris today but none of the 11 crewmen aboard a Navy patrol plane that crashed in the Pacific last night, the Navy said.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) William C. Foster, the Chief United States disarmament nebotiator, said today he believed a treaty might be signed this year to halt the spread of nuclear weapons

LONDON, April 10 Armed with a new United Nations resolution, Britain today used force for the first time in the fivemonth-old Rhodesian crisis to prevent oil from reaching the regime of Premier Ian D. Smith.
TORONTO, April 10 The St. Lawrence Seaway has opened for its eighth season amid speculation that this year will produce a decision for increased tolls on the still controversial waterway.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 10 Mrs. Peter Wood has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lyn McIntyre Sifton, to Bruce Malcolm Westwood of Montreal and Toronto, son of Mrs. George Westwood of Montreal and the late Mr. Westwood.

CAPETOWN, April 10 In this traditionally tolerant city but one where racial barriers are on the rise those with the greatest opportunity for full freedom are light-skinned colored persons who have managed to obtain identity cards as whites.
WASHINGTON, April 10 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday:
BOSTON April 10 Thirty Roman Catholic laymen ended a 72-hour vigil at noon today with prayers and Scripture readings outside the residence of Richard Cardinal Cushing.
WALTER BROWNE, 16 years old, and Paul Ro bey, 55, the youngest and oldest competitors in the 14man field, tied for first place in the recent Marshall Chess Club championship.
Alaska, the largest of the fifty states, a magnificent wilderness empire stretching from the temperate zone to hundreds of miles north of the Arctic Circle, has long excited men's imaginations.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 10 Police Chief David Keyser said tonight that James J. Corbett, Louisiana State University athletic director, was shot by mistae last week while seeking help during a heart attack.
The 16-story Diamond Tower at 55 West 47th Street, which combines a jewelry exchange, office space and apartments has been sold for cash over a mortgage of $1,431,000 to Newport Associates.

The Institute for Advanced Studies in the Theater Arts is planning to present an English version of Georges Feydeau's 72-year-old French bedroom farce, "Un Fil a la Patte," or "How to Cut the Thread That Ties You to Your Mistress," on Broadway in the fall.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 10 Arthur F. Moore, manager of marketing services for the petrochemical division of the Mobil Chemical Company, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home on Woodland Drive. He was 45 years old.

Most scheduled airlines in the United States, both major and local-service lines, had the best March in their history this year from the standpoint of both passenger miles and freight miles, reports show.

WOMEN dressed up for spring, Easter Sunday and their favorite charity in a conservative manner this year. Leaving the unorthodox byways of fashion to some ostentatious paraders on Fifth Avenue, those who turned up for brunch and games benefitting the Easter Seal Society, the Leukemia Society and the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals were a traditional lot.
DES MOINES A woman recently walked into the department store here operated by Younker Brothers, Inc., and asked for a refund for defective knitting yarn she had purchased there.

IT ONCE was as simple as pressing the starter button on a computing machine. There was no stress, no strain, no thought. The doggone thing worked automatically, dropping cards into the proper slots. But the New York Yankees have messed up the operation so completely that the mechanism for producing the order of finish in the American League pennant race has been shortcircuited distressingly.

SINGAPORE, Monday, April 11 (Reuters) Noxious chemicals spread by United States troops in South Vietnam killed newborn babies of Roman Catholic families before they were baptized, the North Vietnam press agency charged today.
MASONTOWN, Pa., Monday, April 11 Thousands of soft coal miners seeking substantial contract improvements struck coal operations in four states early this morning.

CAIRO, April 10 The Egyptian Government has formally asked the United States to renew and expand its present "Food for Peace" aid by sending $150-million worth of food in the fiscal year beginning July 1, reliable sources disclosed today.
Welfare Commissioner Mitchell I. Ginsberg warned yesterday that, instead of reducing its welfare expenditures, the city faced increased budgets.
The tape-recording industry, once confined to tape recorders for use in the home and the office, is taking to the highways. And, according to industry spokesmen, it's paying off.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 10 (AP) America's $50million stargazer satellite, which scientists had hoped would open a new era in astronomy, failed in its space mission today when its battery system lost power after only two days in orbit.
The chairman of Mayor Lindsay's 10-man task force on air pollution says the city will experience a "disaster of substantial proportions" unless something is done about cleaning the air.

SAIGON, April 10 Senior United States officials here are understood to feel that South Vietnam's military junta must combine political concessions with a policy of firmness toward dissidence and street violence if it hopes to survive.
Gay Brewer, Tommy Jacobs and Jack Nicklaus finished in a three-way tie yesterday at the end of the regulation 72 holes of the Masters golf tournament at Augusta, Ga.

In eight brief months as a member of the editorial board of The Times, Wellington Wales made a valued imprint on this page. His death made doubly tragic by the fatal accident that befell his son only hours earlier deprives us of a colleague who combined the beat qualities of crusader, analyst and friend.
ROME, April 10 (AP) Following, in official traslation from the Italian, is the text of Pope Paul's Easter message, delivered today:

WHAT does one wear to go dancing at the movies? Anything.
ATHENS, April 10 A spokesman of the Greek Government tonight endorsed the interception of the Manuela by the British Navy.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 10 (AP) Fourteen cars, all that are left of the 88 that started the East African Safari three rain-lashed days ago, traveled close to the Equator en route to the Uganda capital of Kampala today, with a French Peugeot 404 still way out in front.
BURBANK, Calif., April 10 (AP) Willie Mosconi of Haddon Heights, N.J., defeated Onofrio Lauri, New York, 150-56, last night in eight innings in the world pocket billiards championship.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 10 Australis, the national champion, made her first start of the year a successful one today by winning the open jumper title at the Glen Head horse show, the first outdoor event of the metropolitan season.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 The parties to the three-way tie for first place in the Masters tournament had mixed reactions after posting their par-equaling 288's over the Augusta National Golf Club course today.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 10 Nine months of waiting for the European Common Market to settle its internal differences have stalled the Kennedy round of trade negotiations and have seriously damaged its momentum.
ELIZABETH, N.J., April 10 Mrs. Thomas F. Higgins Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Diane A. Higgins, to Joseph H. Perrone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Perrone.
JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), April 10 The rhythmic clapping and singing of Syrian Christians in the courtyard of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher gay a variety to Easter celebrations here today.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Monday, April 11 (AP) Amid cheers of "Daulat Tuanku" ("long live the King"), Malaysia enthroned a new constitutional monarch today.

ROME, April 10 Pope Paul VI appealed today for an Easter "rebirth of mankind" to overcome the "totalitarian ideologies," racism, ambitious nationalism, class warfare and "political games of dangerous forces" that threaten to blight man's best hopes.

WESTPORT, Conn., April 10 A fire destroyed the interior of a building last night at 147 Main Street here, in the heart of the business district, wiping out several business establishments. Damage was unofficially estimated at about $50,000.
The major league baseball season with six new managers two new cities and three new stadiums will open today in Cincinnati and Washington.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 10 Across the littered beach today the boys and girls with peeling faces and weary smiles rolled up their sleeping bags, packed in their blankets and trudged to the "Hello Booth" to say good-by.
Paul Cranis, a tall 31-year-old left-hander, won the Empire State indoor tennis championship yesterday by beating Steve Turner in the final, 7-5, 6-2, at the 369th Regiment Armory.
HOUSTON, April 10 (AP) The Houston Astros sent Walt Bond to Denver, a Minnesota Twins farm club, today in exchange for a catcher, Ken Retzer, and an undisclosed amount of cash.

JACKSON, Miss., April 10 A Federal court begins reviewing Mississippi's new Congressional redistricting plan tomorrow under a lawsuit brought by the predominantly Negro Mississippi Freedom Democratic party.

Directors of the Pennzoil Company and the United Gas Corporation have agreed to submit a plan for the consolidation of the two companies through an exchange of stock, according to a statement released over the weekend.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 10 (UPI) Nicola Pilic, a Yugoslav Davis Cub player, won the Masters international tennis tournament today with a 9-7, 7-5, 8-6 defeat of Cliff Richey of Dallas.

AT 34, Dan Wakefield is acknowledged to be one of the country's most perceptive and sensitive independent corn mentator-reporters. He is the author of two books "Island in the City" (1959), an account of life in Puerto Rican Harlem, and "Revolt in the South" (1961), a collection of his reports on the civil rights movement and the editor of a third, an anthology on narcotics called "The Addict" (1964).
CHICAGO, April 10 Robert E. Smylie, the Republican Governor of Idaho, charged today that the Johnson Administration was "underplaying our difficulties in Southeast Asia."
Mr. and Mrs. Alan Valentine Tishman of New York and Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Ann Tishman, to Neil David Bramwell.
The election of Jose de Cubas as a vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation was announced over the weekend by D.C. Burnharm, president.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Under Secretary of State George W. Ball suggested today that a French withdrawal from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization integrated command system might force the West to use nuclear weapons "earlier than we might otherwise do" in a world conflict.

ATLANTA, April 10 This proud, ambitious and growing city, which has just acquired major league baseball and football teams, has visions of comparable development in the arts. It is in the midst of a determined push to raise its standards and prestige in music, dance, theater and painting and sculpture.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 10 A 5-year-old female pointer, Sugar and Cream, was named winner of the $1,000 open shooting dog stake today at the 59th annual spring bird dog trial of the English Setter Club of America.
BUENOS AIRES, April 10 (Reuters) Argentina beat Chile, 3-2 in the Davis Cup American Zone qualifying round today.

The marriage of Mrs. Lucianne S. Cummings, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond L. von Steinberger of Alexandra, Va., to Sid Goldberg took place yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emmanuel Goldberg of the Bronx.
A young man and a woman were held as suspects yesterday in the death of a 40-year-old man who was found Saturday night on the Lower East Side with a bullet wound in the back of his head.

Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, the House Republican leader, believes that American casualties in Vietnam will triple by November and that the war will produce election gains for the Republicans.

ATLANTA, April 10 The New York Yankees closed a generally satisfactory spring-training season today by beating the Atlanta Braves, 2-1, and departing immediately for New York, where they will open the season Tuesday against the Detroit Tigers.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 10 A weary but jubilant band of striking vineyard workers ended a 300-mile, 25-day march here today with an "unconditional demand" upon the absent Gov. Edmund G. Brown.
MADISON, Wis., April 10 The Democratic gubernatorial primary in Wisconsin is taking on all the aspects of a popularity contest between Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Vice President Humphrey.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 Jack Nicklaus made dramatic attempts on the last two holes to win the Masters golf title outright today. Instead, he finished with a 72-hole total of 288 for a three-way tie with Tommy Jacobs and Gay Brewer.
ALICANTE, Spain, April 10--Direct press censorship ended in Spain last midnight, but today there were no immediate signs of the new freedom, which still is subject to considerable limitations.

WASHINGTON, April 10 A young New Yorker, protesting the war in Vietnam, doused himself with gasoline today in front of the White House, but was seized by the police before he could light a match to his clothes.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) Easter Sunday in the nation's capital was cold, but the unseasonable weather did not daunt the steady stream of young and old still coming to pay their respects at the grave of President Kennedy.
Alan Steinfeld of the New York Pioneer Club won the Road Runners Club eight-mile handicap race through Bronx streets yesterday.
"The Saga of Flushing Meadow," written by Robert Moses, master planner, builder and sometimes vitriolic literary stylist, was published yesterday by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
