Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel said yesterday that his office was investigating what he called "intimations" of kickback payments by assistant district attorneys to the Democratic party organization under his predecessor, Frank D. O'Connor, now President of the City Council.
CHICAGO, April 10 (UPI) The Detroit Red Wings tied their semi-final four-of-seven games Stanley Cup playoff series with the Chicago Black Hawks at one game each today with a 7-0 victory.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., April 10 Wes Westrum has insisted all along that the New York Mets' ability to storm from behind is their strong point and this was proved again today when they spotted the Baltimore Orioles two runs in the first inning before rallying with four in the sixth for a 6-3 victory.
"A new hairdo," in the words of one beauty shop patron, "makes me feel like a new woman."

David Goodstein, a men's clothing manufacturer in New York for 71 years and a leader in Jewish philanthropies here died yesterday in his home at the Park Royal Hotel, 23 West 73d Street, after an illness of one month. He was 95 years old.
Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice Samuel S. Leibowitz was slightly injured Saturday night in a automobile collision on the Long Island Expressway in the village of North Hills.

ATLANTA, April 10 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare plans to begin a widespread inspection program tomorrow to bring the nation's hospitals into compliance with the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
BERLIN, April 10 The Russian supersonic fighter-bomber that crashed into a West Berlin lake has proved of extraordinary importance to Westeern military intelligence, according to informed sources.
Navy and Army were extended to maintain their unbeaten lacrosse records Saturday.

UNION, N.J., April 10 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John J. Vardzal of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne J. Vardzal, to Lewis Stabile, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Stabile of New York.

VANCOUVER, B.C., April 10 (Canadian Press) George Victor Spencer, who is alleged to have sold information to Soviet agents, was found dead in his home here last night. A Federal inquiry into his dismissal without pension from the Vancouver post office was to have opened in four days.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 (UPI) Don Drysdale and Don Sutton combined to pitch a sixhitter as the Los Angeles Dodgers shut out the Cleveland Indians, 6-0, today in the final baseball exhibition game for both clubs. The paid attendance was 13,422.
SAIGON, April 10 (UPI) B-52 jet bombers of the United States' Strategic Air Command bombed Vietcong strongholds today 100 miles west of Saigon and 75 miles northwest of Danang.

VANCOUVER, B.C., April 10 (Canadian Press) George Victor Spencer, who is alleged to have sold information to Soviet agents, was found dead in his home here last night. A Federal inquiry into his dismissal without pension from the Vancouver post office was to have opened in four days.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 (UPI) Don Drysdale and Don Sutton combined to pitch a sixhitter as the Los Angeles Dodgers shut out the Cleveland Indians, 6-0, today in the final baseball exhibition game for both clubs. The paid attendance was 13,422.
TAILORED WOMAN, which, despite its name, does the bulk of its business in furs, is showing its new fall line with emphasis, as usual, upon mink.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 11 A high source in the Foreign Ministry said today that Indonesian recognition of Singapore would be "the first step" toward ending the policy of confrontation against Malaysia.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 Jack Nicklaus set another golfing record today by winning the Masters title for the second year in a row. In the 18-hole playoff necessitated by a three-way tie for first place yesterday, Nicklaus scored a two-under-par 70 to beat Tommy Jacobs by two strokes and Gay Brewer by eight.
WASHINGTON,April 11(AP) The Air Force is limiting its fliers to 100 missions against targets in North Vietnam during any one tour of duty in the war zone.

HOUSTON, April 11 The Shell Oil Company announced plans today for a 54-story office building is downtown Houston. The building will be the tallest in Houston and perhaps the tallest west of the Mississippi River 1,650 feet high.
MOSCOW, April 11 (AP) Leaders of the Soviet and North Vietnamese Communist parties met here today.

Mr.and Mrs.Paul Contento of Saigon, South Vietnam, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isobel Ruth Contento, to Paul Hampton Corneil, son of Mr.and Mrs. H. G. Corneil of Summit, N. J. The couple plan to marry July 30 in Berkeley, Calif.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 11 Three Princeton football players jointly received the John Prentiss Poe Award, presented annually to the outstanding Tiger football star, at the team's dinner tonight.

When Francis Keppel was appointed United States Commissioner of Education in 1962 his prediction that Congress could be persuaded to authorize Federal aid to schools and colleges was generally considered whistling in the dark. Yet, with the aid of two education-minded Presidents, Mr. Keppel proved the pessimists, wrong.

Some 3,000 high school children yesterday started out for one place, ended up in another and became part of musical history. They were the audience that attended the very first performance in the new Metropolitan Opera in Lincoln Center. "La Fanciulla del West" by Puccini was the opera.
A citadel of long-hair music was invaded last night by three well-groomed quartets and a chorus to proclaim Barbershop Harmony Week.
MOSCOW, April 11 (UPI) A young Soviet truck driver fatally burned himself in central Moscow because officials would not let him fight in Vietnam, Soviet sources said today.
LONDON, April 11 Vandals, using at Vehicle and heavy rope, tried to topple a statue of Sir Winston Churchill on Woodford Green last night.

WASHINGTON, April 11 While pursuing a deliberately cautious policy in the Rhodesian crisis, officials here feel that as time passes the stakes of the United States in Africa are becoming increasingly endangered.

Isidor Baum, an immigrant, who started his career as a pushcart peddler on the Lower East Side and became a leading paper manufacturer, died Sunday in Mount Sinal Hospital after an illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 77 Jerome Avenue, New Rochelle, N.Y. His office was at 633 Third Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) Robert Adams, a senior Foreign Service officer, will become Under Secretary of State Thomas C. Mann's special assistant for population matters.
Negotiations are under way for the acquisition by Pepsico, Inc., of the North American Van Lines, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Donald M. Kendall, president
Two teams of lawyers flew to Jamaica late yesterday to relieve two sea captains of the task of determining the right to possession of the fire-blackened cruise ship Viking Princess.
The stockholders of the Consolidated Edison Company will be asked at the annual meeting on May 16 to authorize an additional 650,000 shares of the company's $100-par cumulative preferred stock.
The World Journal Tribune, Inc., announced last night that the new merged newspaper corporation would publish its first issue on April 25.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a 10-day suspension of trading effective immediately, in securities of the A.C. Gilbert Company of New Haven, Conn., and the rather Cprporation of Beverly Hills, Calif.

The Villager, Inc., which has one of Seventh Avenue's highest net profit margins about 9 per cent on its sales of women's sportswear, will try to match this high return with a new line of women's shoes.

Sidney Davidoff, who was serving on the night owl shift at City Hall last night, accompanied a Bellevue ambulance on an emergency call. He found that the crew was unable to administer oxygen to a patient because an oxygen mask was missing.
DUBLIN, April 11 (AP) Twenty Irishmen went on a hunger strike today in protest against celebrations of 1916 Easter Rising.
MOSCOW, April 11 The Defending champion, Tigran Petrosian, drew with Boris Spassky this evening in the opening game of their match for the world chess championship.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (UPI) Percy Manning of Philadelphia scored an upset tonight bay gaining a split decision over Luis Rodriguez in a 10-round welterweight bout. Rodriguez, the former champion from Miami, had won 15 straight.
ALBANY, April 11 The leaders of 11 upstate Republican County Committees released today a resolution supporting Governor Rockefeller in his campaigin for a third term.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 11 (AP) The civilian dean of the United States Naval Academy today denied that civilian teachers at the academy were controlled strictly from above.
WHITE PLAINS, April 11 The voiceprint, a dramatic new identification device, was introduced at a criminal trial here today in what was believed to be its first application in a courtroom.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor, vacationing in Bermuda, expressed anger yesterday at allegations that assistant district attorneys in Queens alight have kicked back part of their salaries to the Democratic party during his 10-year tenure as District Attorney.

SAIGON, Tuesday, April 12 The South Vietnamese chief of state told political and religious leaders today that the military regime was eager to surrender power to a civilian government "as soon as possible."
ONE of last year's successes on the British commer cial television series called "Play of the Week" was presented last night by noncommercial American television over Channel 13.
Alice Harold Murphy, a well known art teacher who was also an artist, died at her home in the Chelsea Hotel, 222 West 23d Street, Sunday. She was 69 years old.

NEW HAVEN, April 11 (AP) The former Mayor of New York City, Robert F. Wagner, said today that his successor, John V. Lindsay, had been a little too hasty in proposing one way to help solve the city's fiscal problems.

Twenty pianists, each from a different New York City public high school, are participating in the quarter-finals of the "The WQXR, Young Artists Competition," yesterday and today in the WQXR Concert Hall.
Young Rubicam, Inc., has resigned its Celanese Corporation of America business an account that included European advertising and a special international television assignment.

WASHINGTON, April 11 The Justice Department plans to warn the publishers of the proposed morning-afternoonSunday newspaper combination in New York City against engaging in practices designed to injure the other three newspapers that will remain in New York City.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 11 One hundred and forty homes near the Marshall Elementary School have been designated islands of safety for children in need of help.

THE law of diminishing returns has applications in duplicate bridge, but not in rubber bridge, as today's deal shows. It, and the East-West players, helped Fred Karpin of Silver Spring, Md., to win the Open Pair event in a recent Washington, D. C., tournament. This noted writer, making one of his rare tournament appearances achieved a considerable performance by winning twice and placing second once in three starts.

BUFFALO, April 11 Mischa Schnelder, cellist of the Budapest Quartet rapped a pencil against a black metal music stand a few times this morning and four tease young musicians launched into Mozart's Quartet in B major. The third annual series of master classes for high-school string players organized by the State University of New York and Buffalo was underway.
An embargo on the delivery of Coca-Cola to Mount Sinai Hospital's coffee shop and vending machines was ordered yesterday by a hospital aide, but by nightfall the ban was lifted.

Bob Hope is one of the "angels" of In the Round Inc., the producing division at the new $3.5-million Houston Music Theater, built by Frank W. Sharp, a real estate developer. "Camelot" will be the opening bill at the 2,907-seat house on May 20.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Brightly colored eggs bounced and rolled in the White House backyard today as about 2,000 children, plus their parents, took part in a traditional fete.
NEWARK, April 11 (AP) Another predawn fire, termed suspicious by fire officials, raged in Newark's Central Ward today, leaving more than 30 persons homeless and destroying three frame homes.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 11 (AP) Motion for the dismissal of a suit concerning a stock control fight involving the Studebaker Corporation was taken under advisement today by United States District Court Judge Noel P. Fox.

THE Cafe La Mama is a downtown experimental theater club, open to members and to membership, which serves uninteresting coffee and often serves interesting plays. Six of those plays have recently been performed in Copenhagen and Paris by a troupe of five young actors. The troupe is now presenting them as "6 From La Mama" at the Off Broadway Martinique in two bills of three plays each.
A medical research team at Wayne State University reports some initial success, with a new technique, in waking up the sleeping immune systems of cancer patients.

Jack Nicklaus became the first player to win two consecutive Masters golf tournaments yesterday when he defeated Tommy Jacobs and Gay Brewer in an 18-hole playoff at the Augusta National Golf Club, Augusta, Ga.

EL PASO, April 11 Billie Sol Estes, the convicted swindler, testified for the first time today that various finance companies had agreed to deal with him in mortgages that they had known were fraudulent.

The Freedom National Bank, a Harlem institution, and several of its officers will be required at a hearing today to show cause why they should not be restrained from holding an annual or a special meeting of the stockholders. A meeting is set for tomorrow.
BOSTON, April 11 (AP) Carl Yastrzemski was elected the first official playing captain in Boston Red Sox history today.
There was no trading again yesterday in Calumet Hecla stock on the New York Stock Exchange. A continued heavy influx of buy orders found specialists still unable to open the stock for trading.

ALBANY, April 11 Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill that would allow a municipal corporation as well as a private employer or a public authority to provide a paid sick-leave plan for its employes through the state's Disability Benefits Law.

AIKEN, S. C., April 11 (AP) The first of tons of mildly radioactive Spanish soil, packed in steel drums, was buried today under 10 feet of South Carolina soil at a huge nuclear burial grounds near here.

Vornado, Inc., which operates a 26-unit Two Guys discount department-store chain, turned in a net income of $8,011,748, equal to $5.74 a share on 1,397,037 shares outstanding for the year to Jan. 31, 1966.

DUSSELDORF, Germany Dusseldorf is an acquis itive woman's dream. It is the richest city in Germany, and looks it. The buildings are modern but not drab, the streets are broad, and the stores are exceedingly tempting.

Dr. Shailer Upton Lawton, a psychiatrist, internist and edu cator, who put many medical and other students through school and gave them free medical treatment, died Friday of leukemia in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 72 years old. His home was at 425 East 75th Street and his office at 147 East 50th Street.
SAIGON, April 11 Many observers are expressing surprise that the Vietcong have been quiescent during the anti-Government political campaign in South Vietnam.

Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia 76ers, the league's most valuable player, and Rick Barry of the San Francisco Warriors, the rookie of the year, were named yesterday to the National Basketball Association All-Star team.
LISBON, April 11 The Ioanna V was authorized by the Portuguese to dock today "to facilitate the normal movement of the port," an official spokesman said this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 11, (AP) An agreement has been reached with a group of public and private electric utilities for the development of a huge coalfired steam electric generating and transmission complex in the Southwest.
The McCrory Corporation now owns more than 60 per cent of the voting securities of S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., which operates S. Klein's in Union Square.
The National Labor Relations Board yesterday certified the Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee as the collective bargaining agent for 5,500 drivers in 29 fleet-owned garages.
Organized labor is considering a program to broaden its support of the arts.
DETROIT, April 11 (AP) A Japanese ship whose captain is a baseball fan is the first overseas vessel to arrive in Detroit this spring.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) An amusement park riot involving thousands of teenagers in suburban Washington spilled over into the capital tonight in the form of isolated acts of rock- and bottle-throwing vandalism.

EXICO CITY, April 11 (UPI) Barry Goldwater said today that he was planning to run for the Senate again in 1968. He also reiterated his belief that the day could come when Russia would join the United States in a war against Communist China.
Steel production declined 2.1 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Abe Feldman, the skin buyer and manager of production of fur garments for the Bergdorf Goodman Fur Corporation, which manufactures fur garments for Bergdorf Goodman, the women's specialty store at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street, died Sunday in Beth Israel Hospital after a long illness. He was 62 years old and lived at 73-51 195th Street, Flushing, Queens.
HOLLYWOOD, April 11 (AP) William Wyler has been voted the Motion Picture Academy's Irving G. Thalberg Award for his consistently high level of film-making.
The election of Stuart Z. Krinsly as vice president and general counsel was announced here yesterday by the Sun Chemical Corporation.
CHICAGO, April 11 Representative Barratt O'Hara, Democrat of Illinois, today offered to box six rounds with any of 15 newsmen at a news confer-...
Federated Department Stores, Inc., the nations largest department-store chain, whose New York stores include Bloom ingdale's and Abraham Straus, achieved record sales and earnings last year.

Showing the nerve and talent that have made him the greatest purse-winning hockey in thoroughbred history, Willie Shoemaker whipped Malhoa home first in the $10,000 onemile feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.

THE ruddy-faced, slightly stout young man with the short-cropped blond hair appears phlegmatic on the golf course. Jack William Nicklaus is coldly serious, but once he walks off the 18th green, he is normally so relaxed that he could probably fall asleep in the middle of Times Square.

TORONTO, April 11 (UPI) Despite Toe Blake's protests, the Toronto Maple Leafs will continue to play a rough, hardhitting brand of hockey when they meet the Montreal Canadiens in the third clash of the four-of-seven-game Stanley Cup semi-final series tomrrow night at Maple Leaf Gardens here.

WASHINGTON, April 11 The Washington Senators switched firstball tossers from the President to the Vice President in their season's opening game today, but the outcome of the game was the same as it usually is the Senators lost.
Barry Edelstein hit a grandslam home run during a ninerun rally in the fifth inning as City College defeated Brooklyn College, 14 2, at Roosevelt Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Ten fire alarm boxed is a Brooklyn slum will soon be equipped with aerosol-operated whistles that bellow like ships' horns. Others will be caught in the bright beams of floodlights. And alarm boxes throughout the city will receive special attention from the police.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) Former Secretary of State Dean Acheson will be the first witness later this month when a Senate subcommittee begins public hearings on the NATO alliance. Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, announced today.
Five rebellious dockworkers were warned yesterday that they would be jailed today unless they returned to work at the Holland-America Line Pier.
JERSEY. CITY. April 11 Mrs Charlotte Vogel Whelan, mother of Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City, died yesterday in Pollack Hospital here. She was 84 years old and the widow of Joseph Whelan.
The spot rate on the British pound improved moderately yesterday in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7941, up two points from Friday's level.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., April 11 Plans for the restoration of the 1787 courthouse on the Bedford Village Green will receive impetus from funds raised at a concert at the Fox Lane High School on Route 172 between Bedford Village and Mount Kisco on Friday.

BEREA, Ky. "I like to hunt and trap muskrat mostly," 19-year-old Johnnie Akers said as he pulled a tray of French bread from a big oven in the Berea College bake shop. "I missed that awful bad last winter."

"The Sound of Music," 20thCentury-Fox's screen version of the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d hit stage mu sical, was voted the best picture of 1965 in the 43d annual poll of critics conducted by The Film Daily, a trade publication.

WASHINGTON, April 11 John J. McCloy, a former United States High Commissioner to West Germany, has been designated by Secretary of State Dean Rusk as special consultant on the current North Atlantic Treaty Organization crisis.
The Livingston Oil Company announced yesterday in Tulsa, Okla., the election of Wayne E. Swearingen, 41, as president and chief executive officer.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 9 As a part of what newspapers are calling "the fresh wind blowing," Indonesia's press is demonstrating new freedom and daring in its reporting.
GREAT NECK, L. I. Although learning new tricks can be difficult, Nathanial Katz, a man who has been in the business of selling children's shoes for more than 26 years, has proved he can do it.

Mrs. Anne Halle Seymour of 176 East 71st Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne Halle Seymour, to James Rush Jarrett of Albuquerque, N. M., professor of architecture at the University of New Mexico.

LONDON, April 11 (AP) Slogan-chanting and scuffles between anarchists and banthe-bomb marchers at a Trafalgar Square rally today nearly drowned out a speech by Prof. Staughton Lynd of Yale University.

WASHINGTON, April 11 The temporary grave of President Kennedy, virtually unchanged since the day of his burial 28 months ago, will soon be transformed into a $2-million permanent monument of marble and granite.

BEIRA, Mozambique, April 11 The tanker Ioanna V pulled anchor at high tide in the harbor today and moved to the quayside, where she could discharge her cargo of crude oil, intended to be piped to Rhodesia.
Harry Jompulsky, a voice teacher in New York for more than 40 years, died yesterday at the Medical Arts Center Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 14-19 159th Street, Beechhurst, Queens.

DETROIT, April 11 (AP) Automobile makers in the United States are expected to speed production lines this week to make up for sharp losses caused by the recent railroad strike and the Good Friday holiday.

Mayor Lindsay gave tangible evidence yesterday that he has the city moving ahead. He demanded that a 48-star American flag, dating to the White House days of William Howard Taft, be replaced in the Board of Estimate chamber with the one that became official with the admission on Aug. 21, 1959, of Hawaii as the 50th state.

First-quarter net earnings of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation are estimated at $8.5-million, equal to 65 cents a share, compared with $7,275,000, or 54 cents a share, in the initial three months last year. The figures were reported yesterday by John E. Bierwirth, chairman, at the New York Security Analysts.

Franklin Hardinge Jr., executive vice president of the California Savings and Loan League, said yesterday that delinquent loans had been reduced by nearly 16 per cent in the quarter ended Dec. 31, down by $41million from the Sept. 30 figure. He said these were the latest figures available.

The impartial labor relations chairman of the nursing home field has upheld the dismissal of an employe at a Brooklyn home who refused to go to work during the latter part of the transit strike in January.
WASHINGTON, April 11 The Treasury bill rate rose sharply at today's auction, the Treasury reported tonight.
ST. LOUIS, April 11 (UPI) The St. Louis Hawks returned home today to map strategy for taking three straight from the Los Angeles Lakers in the Western Division final playoffs.
Dr. Alonzo Yerby, the city's Commissioner of Hospitals, was appointed a professor and department head at Harvard University's School of Public Health yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The National Association of Securities Dealers plan to try court action to block the creation of the first bank-sponsored mutual fund in the United States by the First National City Bank, New York.
WASHINGTON, April 11 The biggest convention on poverty since the Economic Opportunity Act was signed in August, 1964, will open here this week.

Routed by several thousand youngsters who disrupted a practice session and chased the players off the field yesterday, the New York Yankees will be trying to restore order in more ways than one when they open the 1966 baseball season at Yankee Stadium today against the Detroit Tigers.
Mayor Lindsay planned legal tactics yesterday to safeguard the votes of 5,000 New Yorkers largely Puerto Ricans
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Taxpayers will not get an extension this year of the deadline of April 15 for filing income tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service said today.
CINCINNATI, April 11 The New York Mets equaled the best start in their five-year history today. They were rained out.
Miss Rhoda J. Kesler and Burton Unger, graduates of Brooklyn College, were married here yesterday in the Municipal Building by Thomas F. McLaughlin, Acting Deputy City Clerk.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Delta Air Lines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today for permission to change its youth fare from a 50 per cent reduction to one of 33 1-3 per cent off the regular fare. It also asked for approval to offer confirmed space.
PLAINVIEW, L.I., April 11 Dr. Benjamin Freedman a specialist in diseases of the lung, died Saturday at the Nassau County Hospital for Pulmonary Diseases. He was 61 years old.
CINCINNATI, April 11 Mr. and Mrs.Joseph Beech Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Anne Beech, to John Kerns Lane, son of Mr.and Mrs.John Wallace Lane of Kenilworth, Ill.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 11 (AP) Investors in E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., can expect 1966 to be the eighth consecutive year of the corporation's sales growth, Lammont du Pont Copeland, president, told more than 800 of its shareholders today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 11 Miss Suzanne Atwater Kent was married to Thomas Hitchcock 3d at 5 P.M. today in the Episcopal Church of Bethesdaby-the-Sea. The Rev.Dr.Robert B.Appleyard officiated.

ATLANTA, April 11 The last pledges for the $12-million Memorial Cultural Center are not yet in, but Atlantans have begun to face up to the realities of such a complex. Those who will have to run it are discovering that bricks and mortar are not enough. Now they must answer the insistent question that ...

BUFFALO, April 11 Fordham's crew defeated Canisius College by half a length today in a mile and one-eighth race on the Erie Barge Canal, approximately 15 miles north of Buffalo. Fordham's time for the course was 5 minutes 34.2 seconds. Canisius finished in 5:36.
BERLIN, April 11 (Reuters) The bodies of the two Soviet airmen killed when their jet fighter-bomber crashed in a West Berlin lake last week were flown to Moscow today.
The Continental Can Company said yesterday that it had de veloped what it described as the first commercially practical welded can.

RUTGERS, New York University and Army were among other Northeastern college baseball teams that went south last month 20 work out and compete in warm weather. It was the first such expedition for Rutgers, which previously was unable to pay for such trips from its ...

PARIS, April 11 (UPI) Baron Guy de Rothschild's Diatome, the winner of the $150,000 Washington, D.C. International at Laurel last November, won the Prix Ganay at Longchamp today by three-quarters of a length.
Price increases were announced yesterday for a variety of industrial raw materials.
BURBANK, Calif., April 11 (AP) Willie Mosconi continued his winning streak in the pocket billiard championship last night as he defeated Bob Woods of Los Angeles, 150-67.
BOSTON, April 11 Seven persons distinguished for their work in the field of mental retardation were given awards totaling $226,000 tonight by the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation.
Four boys from Manhattan, who have had six bicycles stolen from them in public parks, took their complaints right to the top yesterday. They had a 15-minute session with Mayor Lindsay at City Hall.
The Bulkley Horton Company, real estate brokers, has moved its Brooklyn office from 660 Fulton Street to the Kings County Lafayette Trust Company building at 650 Fulton Street.

JOHANESBURG, April 11 (UPI) Mrs. Billie Jean Moffitt King of Long Beach, Calif., took advantage of mistakes by Margaret Smith, the Wimbledon champion, today to win the South African women's tennis title, 6-3, 6-2.
MIAMI, April 11 (AP) The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. arrived here today and said his staff researchers had found "hostility and alienation."

WOODBRIDGE, Conn., April 11 Miss Maria Veronica Cooper, daughter of the late Gary Cooper, the movie actor, and of Mrs.John Converse of New York and Southampton, L. I., was married here today to Byron Janis, the concert pianist. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs.Samuel Yanks of Pittsburgh.
The expanded police review board being planned by the Lindsay administration will have a civilian director with civilian assistants and stenographers, informed sources said yesterday.
Erlon H. Parker, an early military and airline pilot, died Saturday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, N. J. He was 69 years old and lived at 10 Euclid Avenue in Summit.

Two decades ago strikes in the soft coal fields were so frequent that the country was astonished if a year passed without one. The impact of these strikes on the nation embroiled the United Mine Workers and its strong man, John L. Lewis, in constant conflict with the White House, Congress and the courts.
The Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc., yesterday named Miss Toni Robins as president and chief executive officer of Johnstone, Inc., an agency specializing in women's interest products.
Joseph C. Wilson, president and general manager of the Xerox Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of the First National City Bank of New York.

The 1966 major league baseball season, the 91st for the National League and the 66th for the American, opens today on nine fronts, with the New York Yankees facing the Detroit Tigers at Yankee Stadium in the local opener.

Arthur H. Zinner said here last night that he had not intended to immolate himself in front of the White House in Washington on Sunday. The 20-year-old Boston University student had doused himself with gasoline before he was seized by the police. He told them he was protesting the war in Vietnam.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 (UPI) Jack Nicklaus plans to start building golf courses although he intends to spend at least 10 more years tearing them up with his clubs.

A suit seeking damages of $48-million was filed yesterday by the trustee of the bankrupt concern of Ira Haupt Co. against the New York Produce Exchange and 14 other defendants in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., April 11 (UPI) Clarence L. (Kelly) Johnson, designer of the P-38 airplane in World War II, was named today winner of the Thomas D. White National Defense Award for 1966.

Joseph Cardinal Beran, they 77-year-old Archbishop of Prague, who was released last year after nearly two decades of Nazi and Communist imprisonment, arrived here yesterday to begin an 18-day tour of the United States.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday. Most of the speculative favorites were up and many of the blue chips were down.
Industries using soft coal were reported yesterday to have sufficient stocks on hand to cushion against any immediate effects of the bituaminous coal strike.

THE largest brown trout this writer ever saw was 10 pounds. That was an estimate, since the fish did not cooperate by fastening himself to the hook. Estimating the size and weight of fish, caught and uncaught, is a precision skill learned by every angler within 30 minutes after he begins fishing.

MEMPHIS Although there are hundreds of restaurants in this city on the banks of the Mississippi River, it is by no stretch of the imagination what is commonly thought of as a restaurant town. If there is a category of restaurant, however, that seems singularly Memphian, it is the barbecue house. Following a tour of the town, there is an after-image of a barbecue establishment on every corner.
ATHENS, April 11 Greece was threatened with a new polit ical crisis tonight after Foreign Minister Elias Tsirimokos resigned in disagreement with the Government's Cyprus pol icy.
The money market-faced with the April 15 tax deadline and dividend payment date and more than $1.29-billion of Government agency issues this week did not seem as
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 113.2 on Friday from 113.1 on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 The Johnson Administration acknowledged today that the political turmoil in Vietnam had begun to disrupt the war effort. Officials were sparing, however, with facts that would portray the degree of disruption.
MONTE CARLO, April 11 (UPI) Manuel Santana of Spain beat Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy, 8-6, 4-6, 6-4, 6-1, in the final of the Monte Carlo international tennis tournament today.

WASHINGTON, April 11 The United Mine Workers of America ordered more than 50,000 striking members in nine states back to work today so that contract negotiations with leading soft coal producers could be resumed.

Stanley H. Feldberg, president of the Zayre Corporation, said 1965 was the most successful year in the company's 46year-history. He forecast another major increase in volume during 1966, with earnings expected "to keep pace with our growth in sales."
SAN ANTONIO, April 11 President Johnson announced today his intention to nominate Stanley H. Ruttenberg as Assistant Secretary of Labor for Manpower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 11 Tran Van Huu, who was Premier of Vietnam under Emperor Bao Dai in the early nineteen-fifties, has had conversations with Secretary General Thant on the role the former Premier might play in a future government.
LONDON, April 11 A proposal by a lawyers' group to collect the value of ill-gotten gains from thieves or their families is begin debated here.

ALBANY, April 11 State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. today took the side of Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia in a feud with Governor Rockefeller over how to increase state aid to education.

WASHINGTON, April 11 What this country needs is a Riot Bureau, Equipped with global satellites, spotter planes, political thermometers and passion anemometers, it would perform functions like those of the U.S. Weather Bureau.
TOKYO, April 11 (AP) Statements reported to have been made in Japan last month by Nicholas Johnson, United States Maritime Administrator, have started a controversy.
Two young men who answered a knock on the door of their one-room apartment at 439 Macon Street, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, early last night were shot dead by a third man.
CHICAGO, April 11 Roman Catholic parochial school officials were admonished here today for not taking full advantage of Government money available to them for improving their facilities.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 The estimated total of 15,000 spectators who swarmed over the Augusta National Golf Course today for the 18-hole playoff for the Masters tournament title constituted only a fraction of the huge galleries that turned out Saturday and yesterday for the third and fourth rounds.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 A beaming Jack Nicklaus attributed his second straight Masters tournament victory to the overnight correction of a flaw in his putting technique.

"Anyone want to work late?" Sgt. Joseph Slattery asked the fingerprint identification section of the Bureau of Criminal Investigation. In the grimy fourth floor Broome Street offices a half-dozen police trainees were sorting out fingerprint cards not of criminals, but of policemen.
WASHINGTON, April 11 Retail sales rose significantly again in March, exceeding by 1 per cent the February sales total, which has been revised upward significantly from the original estimate.

Prices of soybean futures rose sharply yesterday. Though $3-abushel beans remain a question. mark for the future, four of the most distant contracts set new lifetime highs September and November, 1966, and January and March of 1967. All are new crop deliveries.
CINCINNATI, April 11 (AP) Clarence (Choo-choo) Coleman officially rejoined the New York Mets today for the start of the 1966 baseball season.

New music, a lot of it, was played at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by the Contemporary Chamber Ensemble, a group that is in residence at Rutgers University and that is also assisted in its missionary work by the Rockefeller Foundation.
The first reaction of Wall Street yesterday to Howard Hughes's decision to liquidate his 75 per cent interest in Trans World Airlines, Inc., was to mark the price of the stock down.
MOSCOW, April 11 (UPI) The Soviet Union's Luna 10 space vehicle is trying to determine "how far the shape of the moon differs from a sphere," the Government newspaper Izvestia said today.

The 1968 film festival season will be officially opened May 5 with the start of the annual Cannes festival. Celebrating its 20th anniversary this year, Cannes is still the best known and most widely covered of the 100 or more festivals held around the world each year.
TRENTON, April 11 The New Jersey Supreme Court dismissed today a long-fought suit against the state's aerial spraying program to combat the gypsy moth.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 A large fleet of Russian trawlers has appeared off the Oregon coast in the last two weeks, and complaints from commercial fishermen are mounting.
Spurred by interest in airline issues the American Stock Exchange took off on another trading splurge yesterday. Volume reached the fifth-highest level in the exchange's 117-year history.
A GROUP of hostess clothes designed by Silvia of Fiorentina, the shoe designer, will be introduced here in early June.

A corporation that will build a $55-million residential community in Allamuchy Township, N.J., has been formed by the Travelers Insurance Companies of Hartford, Conn., and Frank H. Taylor Son, real estate concern of East Orange, N.J. The new corporation called Panther Valley, Inc., will operate under a New Jersey charter.

The withdrawal yesterday of New Zealand-bred Gay Robin from Thursday night's $100,000 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway and the addition of one extra American-bred horse gave the United States a 5-3 numerical advantage over Down. Under competitors in the 1 mile race.

One of the Soviet Union's major maritime achievements the building up over the last decade of the world's largest and most modern deep-sea fishing fleet is a source of envy and concern throughout the Western world for economic and military reasons.
Rear Adm. Lorenzo C. Farwell. U. S. C. G., retired, died Sunday at the Veterans Administration Hospital, First Avenue and 24th Street. He was 87 years old and lived at 7 Peter Cooper Road.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 11 (AP) Premier Aklilou Abde Wold appointed his own Cabinet today, a function formerly reserved by the Emperor.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 11 The acting chief of staff of the Iraqi Army and three other officers flew to Moscow today to obtain new Soviet arms.

Two brothers and their young sister died early yesterday, victims of a fire that swept the Brooklyn apartment of their grandmother, who had taken them in while their parents prepared to attend a funeral.
TOKYO, April 11 (AP) North Vietnam announced today that Cambodia had been allowed to install a diplomatic mission in Pnompenh for the first time.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) Communist China has used the Chinese Buddhist Association to stir up anti-American sentiment in Southeast Asia, a Senate staff study reported today.
VIRGINIA CITY. Nev., April 11 (AP) Lucius Beebe, newspaperman, railroad historian and bon vivant, remembered his dog in his $2-million will.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The Agriculture Department forecast today that this year's important winter wheat crop would reach 1,110,051,000 bushels, about 8 per cent larger than the crop last year.
ST. PAUL, April 11 Vice President Humphrey is second to no one not even President Johnson when it comes to pride in his home state.

For the millions of golfers who have been humbled and chagrined by a tiny white ball weighing only 1.62 ounces, Jack Nicklaus's victory in the Masters tournament was a vicarious kind of vengeance against that old devil par.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 11 President Johnson appealed today to private businesses, labor unions, trade associations, churches, colleges and other large organizations to hire one million extra young people this summer to alleviate youth unemployment.

New Jersey car owners will pay $2 to $19 a year more for basic liability insurance under rates approved yesterday by the state's Banking and Insurance Department. In addition, $50 deductible collision coverage will cost $7 to $28 more.
Walter N. Frank, a 58-yearold partner in the specialist firm of Marcus Co., was renominated yesterday for a one-year term as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., April 11 (UPI) The 11-year-old daughter of the head of President Johnson's Secret Service detail at the LBJ Ranch was fatally injured tonight when she apparently fell from a horse and was dragged.
WASHINGTON, April 11 The Government increased today to 5 from 5 per cent the maximum permissible interest on mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration.
The new Spanish press law, which has just gone into effect, can be rated as a timid step toward a still distant freedom of the press.
Mayor Lindsay told six suburban Congressmen yesterday that there would not be "any concession or compromise" on the matter of the commuter income tax.

The Department of Licenses announced early yesterday that it had ordered an immediate hearing on the license of a small East Vilage theater where an American flag was burned during a production Saturday night.

Universal metering of water in New York City has been so long advised and so long deferred, because it is politically obnoxious, that Mayor Lindsay if he does achieve it will have accomplished a historic first. Paying for what one uses is a logically fair method, timetested in many other cities and comparable to metering of other utilities such as electricity and gas.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 11 Seven San Antonio businessmen have bought about an acre of property directly across the Pedernales river from President Johnson's ranch. They plan to develop it as a tourist attraction if they can avoid land condemnation proceedings.
A 30-year-old dropout medical student who told the police he had been "flying' for three days on LSD, the hallucinatory drug, was charged yesterday with the slaying of his 57-year-old mother-in-law.
WASHINGTON, April 11 Under the green thumb of Mrs. Lyndon B: Johnson, a change bigger than springtime is overtaking this city of vivid, famous springs.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 11 (UPI) Bert Shankland and Chris Rothwell of Tanzania were officially declared the winners of the 14th East African Safari automobile rally tonight after one of the most grueling events on record.
Senator Wayne Morse sharply criticized President Johnson last night for attempting, he said, to suppress "those in Congress who seek peaceful solutions in Asia."

IN the 1925 season the New York Yankees tumbled into seventh place, the team collapse coinciding with and caused by the personal collapse of Babe Ruth. Never one to restrict his gargantuan appetite, the Babe returned from spring training on a hospital litter with what was then labeled "the world's most important stomach ache."
RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 11 A former national officer of the Congress of Racial Equality today was appointed director of the Suffolk County antipoverty program.
Miss Joan Frances Chaloner and Douglas Steen are planning to marry June 18 at the Anglican Church of St. Thomas in Montreal.
Criminal Court Judge Neal P. Bottiglieri ruled yesterday that George Lincoln Rockwell, the leader of the American Nazi party, must stand trial on two charges of disorderly conduct on May 16.
SAIGON, Tuesday, April 12 United States B-52 strategic bombers were used in attacks on North Vietnam for the first time early today.

William F. Buckley, Jr., who was the Conservative party candidate for Mayor here last year, has made an agreement to buy radio station KISD in Sioux Falls, S.D. He already owns stations KOWH-AM-FM in Omaha, Neb.

WESTWOOD, N. J., April 11 Otto Asciutto, former advertising and business manager of II Progresso, an Italian-language daily newspaper in New York, died yesterday in Pascack Valley Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 162 Kinderkamack Road.

LAST weekend, two well-known political columnists came up in their respective newspapers (not this one) with exactly opposite diagnoses of President Johnson's Easter mood. Happy, garrulous, outgoing and even effulgent, said one. Dour, angry, put-upon and depressed, said the other.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., April 11 David A. Lowry, 57year-old New-York stockbroker, was found shot to death last night in his home on Lattington Road. The police found no note but listed the death as an apparent suicide, pending the results of an autopsy.
The proposed sale of the Curtis Publishing Company's timber and mineral holdings to the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company has been approved by a court-appointed referee.

Victor Borge, the entertainer, has sued Traps World Airlines for $1-million in damages, charging that the airline used his name and photograph in advertising without his consent, it was revealed yesterday.
BOSTON, April 11 (AP) Sixty-two passengers were injured today in the derailment of a two-car. New Haven Railroad commuter train that was shunted onto a siding by a switch that had been tampered with.

WASHINGTON, April 11 John W. Gardner, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, assured Southern political and educational leaders today that his department was not trying to impose a formula of racial balance in schools or "instantaneous desegregation" of every teaching staff.

BRACKETT OMENSETTER was an innocent, a hulking, hairy, happy preAdam man. He had no faith; no re ligion, only optimism and good fortune, a body to work with, a loyal wife, two cheerful daughters, a son Omensetter could tell by "the signs" on the way. He was in tune with things without thinking about them; he was lucky.
Because of a Department of Welfare regulation, the widow and 10 children of a man who was beaten to death 16 days ago near his Brooklyn home may lose $17,000 they have received from sympathizers.
A year ago Sammy Davis Jr. scraped stubborn, Alabama red clay from his expensive cowboy boots. It was a memento of his trip to entertain the Selma-to-Montgomery civil rights marchers.
ALL sorts of fascinating diversions can be found at Abercrombie Fitch, the sporting goods merchants of Madison Avenue.
The International Longshoremen's Association has asked the shipping industry to reconsider the new work rules that have caused wildcat strikes in the port since April 1.

CONEY ISLAND is putting on its summer mask of fun this week. With the World's Fair closed, the area near the boardwalk is attempting to make a comeback this year as an amusement center for the millions.
At 2 A.M. yesterday, in the tomb-like quiet of the financial district, an electronic computer began the daily margin run for E.F. Hutton Co., Inc., with the squeaking sounds of magnetic tape.

MOSCOW, April 12 (UPI) Marshal Konstantin Vershinin, head of the Soviet Air Force, marked the fifth anniversary of the first manned space flight today with a prediction of a new spectacular Soviet space feat that could take astronauts farther into space than man has ever ventured.
Richard H. Buford, Philadelphia's Commissioner of Licenses and Inspections, will become an assistant to Mayor Lindsay in charge of the city's summer antipoverty operations.
Max Hirsch would rather win a Belmont Stakes than a Kentucky Derby, but this year the 85-year-old trainer may be forced into going to Louisville.

The April 20 annual meeting of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation at Marion, Ohio, may be the last at which Donald C. Power, 66 year of age, will preside as chairman and chief executive officer.
BOSTON, April 12 Obstacles are being placed in the path of State Attorney General Edward W. Brooke's bid for the Republican nomination for Senator.

A 77-year-old widow who spent most of a $10,000 insurance check sent to her in error was ordered yesterday to pay back the $800 of it that remains. A jury trial also was ordered to determine whether she should repay the full amount with interest.

Frances M. Bell, proprietor of the Frances Bell restaurant at 125 West 55th Street near the City Center, a popular place for Southern dishes, died yesterday in Beekman-Downtown Hospital. She was 81 years old and lived at 530 West 114th Street.
Two passengers were killed yesterday when a violent Atlantic storm pounded the Italian luxury liner Michelangelo as she headed for New York.
LAWRENCE, Kan., April 12 (AP) A retired United States Supreme Court Justice criticized civil rights demonstrations today and then was accused of speaking "the sheerest hyprocrisy and rubbist."

CHICAGO, April 12 The National Catholic Educational Association disclosed here today that Roman Catholic grade school enrollment declined for the first time this last year, while high schools rolls had reached a plateau.

The Buildings Department charged yesterday that almost half the public schools it inspected in the last six weeks had peeling paint, broken plaster, cracked masonry, inadequate toilet facilities and other, Building Code violations.

The Premier Industrial Corporation, a producer of industrial-maintenance products, firefighting accessories and specialty chemicals, announced yesterday in Cleveland the election of John A. Staples as a vice president.
The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation sold 1.4 million shares of common stock at competitive bidding yesterday.
MASONTOWN, Pa., April 78 A rank-and-file revolt against the international leadership of the United Mine Workers of America is sweeping the mining towns of the southwest corner of Pennsylvania.
Two large utility bond issues and four substantial tax-exempt bond offerings were marketed yesterday in sales that did not show much change in interest rates from the levels last week.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) What should a Democratic party worker do if in trying by telephone to get persons to register he finds a Republican on the other end of the line?

Worldwide operations of the International Business Machines Corporation in the first quarter resulted in the highest sales and earnings for any opening quarter in the company's history, it was reported yesterday.
It was mostly men who can take an afternoon off without feeling guilty and boys on vacation from school who poured through the gates of Yankee Stadium for the opening game of the season yesterday.
The Ford Motor Company appeared yesterday to be the only automobile manufacturer to increase sales in the first 10 days of April from year-earlier level.

Mrs. John V. Lindsay received an art work by Larry Rivers yesterday as the honorary chairman of a fund-raising drive for the Congress of Racial Equality's Scholarship, Education and Defense Fund, Inc., sponsored by Artists for CORE.
Whitey Ford will seek special permission to use some device to keep his pitching hand warm in cold weather.
The best thing the United States can do about the political turmoil in South Vietnam is to exert every possible effort to stay out of it.

WOODSTOCK, Vt., April 12 Harold C. McCollom, retired New York City lawyer who was an authority on railroad reorganization and racing law, died today at his home here after a long illness. He way 83 years old.
BRAWLEY, Calif., April 12 (AP) Ens. Daniel S. Kapner of Brooklyn was identified today as the victim of a Navy plane crash at the Chocolate Mountain target range east of the Salton Sea.
WASHINGTON, April 12 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach tonight designated five additional counties in Mississippi for Federal voting examiners.

THE Yankees still show the scars from last year's collapse into sixth place. Opening day is usually a joyous occa sion for them, the start of another romp toward the inevitable pennant. So the clubhouse usually bubbles with laughter and noisy insults. But it was surprisingly sedate yesterday because the Bombers have been hit where it hurts most in their pride and their pocketbooks.

MOST good bridge players would admit to some psychological weaknesses. Some allow themselves to be upset by their own misjudgments, their partner's stupidities, or excessive conversation from their opponents. Some play the first deal of a session carelessly because they have not settled down, or the last deal too quickly because they have grown tired of thinking.

Some day biographers will rattle their library heads, toss up the words and have them come down in interesting disorder. Until then the writers' lives they describe will be neatly chronological and, as in this biography of Mrs. Gaskell (Victorian novelist and biographer of her friend Charlotte Bronte), as much space given to their best-selline novels as to their best-written.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 12 Herbert C.F. Bell, an emeritus professor of history at Wesleyan University, a former Mayor of Middletown and an author, died today at Middlesex Memorial Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 22 Wyllys Avenue here.

LAST night "6 from La Mama" presented its sec ond set of three plays at the Off Broadway Martinique. (I saw the last preview.) There are two interesting plays in this bill, and they share certain characteristics.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) A suburban Virginia radio station pitched a tent in Lafayette Square opposite the White House today to protest last week's "camp-in" by Mississippi Negroes.
The Greater New York Fund's 1966 appeal, which will begin May 1, will be led by Edward L. Steiniger, chairman and chief executive officer of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April, 12 Singapore was told today to choose between friendly relations with Malaysia and with Indonesia. The condition, virtually an ultimatum, was set here by Prince Abdul Rahman, the Prime Minister, after an emergency meeting of the Malaysian Cabinet.
White Plains High School, scoring seven victories in the 11 events, finished first yesterday in a quadrangular relay track meet at New York University's Ohio Field in the Bronx.
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced late yesterday it was calling a board meeting Friday to consider a two-for-one stock split.

A spokesman for the General Theological Seminary charged yesterday that the Landmarks Preservation Commission's proposed designation of part of the Chelsea area as a historic district would violate the constitutional guarantees of freedom of religion.
John M. Murtagh, Criminal Court administrative judge, said yesterday that arrests of drunks in New York "are truly becoming a thing of the past."

John J. Burns, the Democratic state chairman, accused Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel yesterday of "a clumsy attempt at character assassination" when he said he was investigating allegations of political kickbacks during Frank D. O'Connor's tenure as District Attorney.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 12 (UPI) Col. Al Lingo, charging he was made the "scapegoat" at the Edmund Pettus bridge at Selma last year, called on Negroes tonight to help elect him sheriff of Jefferson County.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 12 Hamengku Buwono IX, Sultan of Jogjakarta and Deputy Premier in charge of economic affairs, pledged the Indonesian Government's support for private enterprise today. His statement reversed the socialist trend of the last few years.

Of all the complexities involved in eradicating racial discrimination in employment, perhaps the most vexing is how to erase the effect of historic patterns of bias on the promotion prospects of workers in longestablished industries.

YESTERDAY'S newspaper is dull today, but 50 years from now it regains interest of a quite different kind. The naturalistic dramatists of the early part of the century set out to tell the truth and shame theatricality, but today it is sometimes not their truth but their theatrical skill that holds us.

The common stock of Calumet Hecla, Inc., failed to trade yesterday for the third consecutive session on the New York Stock Exchange because a torrent of buy orders prevented specialists from opening the stock.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 Gov. Edmund G. Brown, a Democrat, and George Christopher, one of the leading Republican aspirants for his job, were in agreement today on a controversial political issue growing out of a 300-mile march to the State Capitol by striking vineyard workers. Ronald Reagan, also a Republican, dissented.
The General Eelectric Company reported yesterday a 17 per cent gain in first-quarter net income and a 21 per cent increase in sales.

John Henry Teeter, former executive director of the Damon Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research, died of cancer yesterday at Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old and had been ill for several months.
Igor Stravinsky will be the subject of a one-hour program to be televised on Tuesday, May 3, at 10 P.M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, April 12 The Census Bureau reported today that construction activity had dropped significantly in March. There are strong reasons, however, for believing that the statistics are not accurate.
The election of James E. Burke Jr. to the vacant post of president was announced yesterday in New Brunswick, N.J., by the Johnson Johnson Domestic Operating Company.

The Storer Broadcasting Company had profit of about $3,939,000 in the first quarter this year, before tax and other adjustments. In the period last year, Storer earned $3,571,000. Broadcasting revenues increased by about $1-million, or 9 per cent, above the level in the initial quarter last year, while expenses climbed 7 per cent.
Amory L. Haskell, founder and president of Monmouth Park Race Track in New Jersey, died of a heart attack yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 72 years old.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was briefly disrupted yesterday when a group of demonstrators hurled antiwar leaflets onto startled brokers from the visitor's gallery.

MIAMI, Fla., April 12 (AP) The burned-out liner Viking Princess arrived at the old pirate stronghold of Port Royal, Jamaica today but was denied entrance to the nearby port of Kingston for fear she might sink.

TORONTO, April 12--As a city Toronto is not yet exactly swinging, but it is beginning to vibrate quite disturbingly. The girls on the sidewalk have a far more mod-London look than the nowadays somewhat square New York girls. And Toronto's new City Hall, extravagantly leaping skyward, should make Mayor Lindsay green with envy.
DETROIT, April 12--The Chrysler Corporation acknowledged today that thousands of its 1966 models were being recalled to dealers for replacement of an improper throttle linkage.
A hearing scheduled yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals on an appeal of a minority stockholder of the Alleghany Corporation was put off until 2:30 P.M. today.

Complaints about the handling of the abortive plans to merge with the Nopco Chemical Company and the executive stock option plan were voiced from the floor yesterday at the annual meeting of General Aniline and Film Corporation.

Deputy Mayor Robert Price advised foes of the World Trade Center yesterday that his concurrence in the demolition of buildings on the downtown site did not represent any commitment on the city's part for the project as planned.
Bobby Avena, a Brooklyn light heavyweight, took an eight-round split decision from Ronnie Geoffrion, Mineola, L.I., in last night's main boxing event at Sunnyside Garden.
PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., April 12 (AP) Jack Nicklaus, the playoff victor in the Masters yesterday soared to a place among the top 10 money winners on the Professional Golfers' Association list.
The Kansas City, Mo., Metropolitan Junior College District awarded yesterday $10-million of building bonds to a group of under writers headed by the First National City Bank.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) The national cherry blossom festival was formally opened in a downpour of rain today with the ceremonial lighting of an ancient Japanese stone lantern.
The late Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, yesterday was posthumously awarded the MacArthur Medal for "his achievements as a patriot and a statesman."
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) The manpower shortage struck home today at the Labor Department.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy and former Gov. Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico were among 500 persons who attended a ribbon-cutting ceremony and dinner last night at a new home for El Diario-La Prensa, the Spanish language daily newspaper here.

Frederick H. Boland, former United Nations delegate from Ireland, said last night that the fighting in Vietnam is "not a chance occurrence or an isolated, episode" but a calculated move by Communist China.

The Amateur Athletic Union announced yesterday that Kipchoge Keino of Kenya will make his first outdoor track appearance in the United States on May 13 in a special two-mile event at the Los Angeles Coliseum relays.

The spot rate on the British pound continued a moderate improvement yesterday in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7945, up four points over the previous day's level.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)--The new income tax withholding rates that go into effect May 1 could eliminate the need for some taxpayers to file a declaration of estimated income tax for this year, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

What began as an only slightly chilly, sunny spring day, ended cold and overcast at Yankee Stadium yesterday, and the fortunes of the New York Yankees paralleled the weather. They opened the 1966 baseball season brimming with confidence and observed by the largest opening-day crowd in 15 years, but wound up losing to the Detroit Tigers, 2-1.
Cocoa futures continued their recent show of strength yesterday, moving up to new lifetime highs for all contracts.

LONDON, April 12 Britain's Independent Television Network broke new ground in documentary television tonight by presenting a 30-minute film on the sensitive subject of the enormous wealth of the Roman Catholic Church.
Joseph Cardinal Beran, Archbishop of Prague, said last night he believed President Kennedy had interceded with the Soviet Union to free him from 17 years of confinement in Czechoslovakia.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 12 (AP) Sandy Valdespino's single in the ninth drove in Zoilo Versalles with the deciding run and gave the Minnesota Twins a 2-1 victory over the Kansas City A's today in an American League opener.
NEWARK, April 12 (AP) A Federal judge has confirmed a bankruptcy court's approval of a $40,000 settlement in the DeAngelis case.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., April 12 (UPI) Luci Baines Johnson will be attended by 12 bridesmaids when she is married to Patrick J. Nugent, a family friend said today.
A 23-year-old man was shot and killed by a patrolman on Broadway at 99th Street early today after the man and a friend, who were riding in a stolen car, were chased several miles by the police.
Stock prices turned downward yesterday as the recovery from the low levels touched in March ran out of steam.
MILWAUKEE, April 12--A Federal mediator stepped today into a labor dispute that has kept the Port of Milwaukee closed while other Great Lakes ports have opened for the season.
Rich Brown's two-run homer with two out in the seventh inning capped a five-run rally that led Columbia to an 8-5 victory over Lehigh yesterday at Baker Field.
ESHER, England. April 12, (Renters) Sydney Allard, a leading British car designer, manufacturer, and rally driver, died at his home here tonight after a long illness. He was 55 years old.

"Even the chairman of the board is well-designed," Walter Hoving, the chairman of Tiffany Co., said yesterday amid laughter as he presented an award for leadership in design to Thomas J. Watson Jr., chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation.

The city's Health Research Council will be continued for an indefinite period. Mayor Lindsay's office confirmed last night that the council would not be eliminated as an economy measure, a move he had indicated previously.
MEXICO CITY, April 12 The Mexican Government is planning for Mr. Johnson the biggest popular welcome it can muster on short notice.
NEW shapes in, and fittings for, kitchen sinks were introduced yesterday by American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation.

NASHVILLE, April 12 Buford Ellington, former Governor of Tennessee and a close friend of President Johnson, announced today he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor in the primary on Aug. 4.

BERKELY, Calif., April 12 (UPI) President Johnson and Vice President Humphrey were hanged in effigy tonight by an unruly crowd of about 2,000 antiwar demonstrators protesting United States military action in Vietnam.
ALBANY, April 12 Proposals by a panel of laborrelations experts to replace the state's Condon-Wadlin Law were rejected today by the Legislatures top Democrat. The law bans strikes by public employes.
The Brill Engineering Corporation of 160 West Broadway has elected John T. Carroll to a new post of vice president and general manager.

ATLANTA, April 12 Major league baseball made its debut in the Deep South tonight and the scattered remnants of a near-capacity crowd of 50,671 paying, spectators didn't leave Atlanta's new $18-million Civic Stadium whistling "Dixie."

Without waiting for the State Legislature to awaken from its Easter siesta, the leader of the Assembly's Democratic majority has passed a death sentence on the exemplary proposals made by Governor Rockefeller's panel for a new law banning strikes by public employes.
ALBANY, April 12 Governor Rockefeller's office announced today that a school for the mentally retarded would be built on a 38-acre site next to the Bronx State Hospital.

Certain allegations have been made regarding the Coca-Cola Export Corporation, the most damaging of which could be the assertion that the company is somehow unalterably opposed to giving a bottling franchise to an enterprise in Israel, thus supporting the Arab boycott. These charges are completely unfair and unfounded.
SAIGON, April 12 B-52bombers of the Strategic Air Command will be used regularly against targets in North Vietnam, informed sources said today.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., April 12--Surrounded by an array of massive turbo-jet engines and other company products, a record 1,200 stockholders of the United Aircraft Corporation were on hand here this morning for their annual meeting.
The American Stock Exchange had its busiest trading session yesterday since Oct. 29, 1929.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 12 President Johnson will fly to Mexico City Thursday for his first visit to a foreign capital and his first overnight stay outside the United States since he became President.
DURBAN, South Africa, April 12 The tanker Manuela, flying the Greek flag, arrived in Durban today but Was not allowed to enter the harbor because no berth was available at the bulk discharge wharves.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced yesterday in Newark the election of Charles W. Engelhard as a director and Alfred C. Linkletter as a vice president.
DETROIT, April 12 (AP) The future of the Chrysler Corporation's turbine powered automobile is still uncertain, the company disclosed today.

SAIGON, Wednesday, April 13 An audacious squad of Vietcong guerrillas mounted a mortar attack early this morning against Tansonnhut Air Base, only three miles from downtown Saigon. Eight people were killed.
President Johnson was reported "encouraged" yesterday by the response from businessmen to his plea for restraint in capital spending.
CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) Tom McCraw scratched a single with the bases filled in the 14th inning today to enable the Chicago White Sox to defeat the California Angels, 3 to 2.
"The Sound of Music" at the Rivoli Theater.
WASHINGTON, April 12 The United States is turning to the World Bank as the adviser and in some ways international arbiter on the future pace of American aid to India and Pakistan.
A group of Protestant clergymen declared yesterday that employes of charitable, educational and religious institutions had a right to bargain collectively.

The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company put weeks of speculation to rest yesterday and moved one of its cigarette brands out of the J. Walter Thompson Company. But it was not the one that the speculation had centered on.

BEIRA, Mozambique, April 12 There were indications tonight that the tanker Ioanna V would discharge at least some of her cargo of crude oil at Beira and attempt to justify the action on the ground of necessity and legal rights.
BARABOO, Wis., April 12--Mrs. Henry Ringling, last firstgeneration member of the circus family, died here today. She was 97 years old.

TRENTON, April 12 The leader of the New Jersey Ku Klux Klan announced today that the organization was planning its first big, cross-burning rally since the late nineteen-twenties, when klansmen were a power in the state.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 (AP) Juan Marichal of the San Francisco Giants lost a bid for a perfect game in the seventh inning today but went on to whip the Chicago Cubs, 9-1, on a three-hitter in their National League baseball opener.

BURBANK, Calif., April 12 (AP) Willie Mosconi started with a run of 45 and went on to a 150-80 victory last night over Bill Staton of Alexandria, Va., in the world invitation pocket billiards championship.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 12 "The only thing the Mayor gives us is lead in our bodies," an embittered occupant of a large squatter settlement in central Bogota said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 12 A member of the British delegation accused the chairman of the Committee of 24 on Decolonialization today of misrepresentation and betrayal of confidence during the debate in the Security Council on Rhodesia last week.

Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass, whose records have been dancing through the upper reaches of the music trade's popularity charts in recent months, made their New York concert debut last night at Carnegie Hall.

Mildred Miller, a mezzosoprano who seems to acquire more of the accoutrements of glamour with each passing year, swept into Town Hall looking like a high-fashion model last night and sang a lieder recital.
John (Sonny) Franzese, widely reputed to be a rising power in the Mafia here, was arrested in midtown yesterday afternoon for bank robbery.
Marian Edwards, a former actress, wife of Irwin Shaw, the novelist, will make her debut as a Broadway producer in October with the $200,000 production of "Welcome to the Club."

HATTIESBURG, Miss, April 12 (UPI) Thirteen members of one of the most militant ku Klux Klan groups in the nation were bound ever to a Federal grand jury today in connection with the death of a Negro civil rights leader.

The chairman of the ErieLackawanna Railroad told stockholders yesterday that the carrier must continue its efforts to become part of the Norfolk Western Railway despite a recent improvement in its own profits picture.
Prices of copper and brass fabricated products--rod, wire, sheet, strip, tube, pipe, roofing and others--are moving upward.
Ira Guilden, chairman of the Trade Bank and Trust Company and head of a syndicate that controls Cartier Co., the Fifth Avenue jeweler, was elected chairman of Best Co. yesterday.

The operators of the embattled Bridge Theater obtained a postponement yesterday of their hearing before the Department of Licenses. They are charged with having permitted the burning of an American Flag.

Major league baseball players have chosen Marvin J. Miller, an economist for the Steelworkers Union, as the fulltime director of the Major League Players' Association, The New York Times learned yesterday. Formal announcement of Miller's appointment is due tomorrow.
Four of the 11 directors of Fenestra, Inc., including the president, plan to resign following the loss of control of the company to the Gulf American Land Company.

WASHINGTON, April 12 The Federal Maritime Commission announced today that a prehearing conference would be started "within a few days" on higher steamship freight rates in the Alaska trade. This is the first step in a formal investigation.
Jay Frank was appointed yesterday as vice president in charge of licensing and export sales for the Van Heusen Company's, a men's wear and toiletries division of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation.
MIAMI, April 12 Otto A. Grundmann, the oldest certified public accountant in Florida, died today at Jackson Memorial Hospital. He was 94 years old.

MILWAUKEE, April 12 (AP)--Judge Elmer W. Roller put the finishing touches on his decision in Wisconsin's antitrust suit against baseball today and said the ruling would not be made public until tomorrow.
BUENOS AIRES, April 13 (Reuters) Mrs. John F. Kennedy, vacationing in Argentina with her two children, postponed her plans to fly back to New York tonight because of bad weather.
By FRANK M. BLUNK CHARLES HAYES, the Chevy Chase, Md., driver, is planning a heavy assault on both driver and manufacturer titles this year.

A COCKTAIL party to introduce Tzaims (pro- nounced Zames) Luksus, to prospective investors (preferably women who are interested in fashion) will be given this evening at the Park Avenue apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Auchincloss.

TORONTO, April 12 (AP) Ralph Backstrom, Bobby Rousseau and Terry Harper scored within a three-minute span in the second period tonight as the Montreal Canadians rallied to beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5-2, and take a 3-0 lead in their National Hockey League playoff series.

An importer of artificial flowers who was sentenced to one year in prison in 1950 for income-tax evasion was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of evading $30,599 in income taxes for 1959. He was one of four persons indicted on charges of violating the Internal Revenue laws.

OSWEGO, N.Y., April 12 Senator Jacob K. Javits, beginning a political survey of Republican sentiment in the state, refused today to commit himself to supporting the renomination of Governor Rockefeller.
Hayden, Stone, Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced here yesterday the election of Albert J. Eisenberg as a vice president.
PARIS, April 12 Secretary of State Dean Rusk declared in a newspaper interview published today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization could function perfectly well without France.

NEW HAVEN, April 12 Prof. James W. Fesler of Yale University stood outside his political science classroom today, peered down a sunny street and said: "I don't have a lecture to give if he doesn't show up."
WASHINGTON, April 12 Two liberal Republican groups urged the Republican National Committee today to help register Southern Negroes and to discipline "lily-white" G.O.P. organizations in the South.
DETROIT, April 12 Former Mayor Louis C. Miriani of Detroit, now a city councilman, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on four counts charging willful income tax evasion.
LONDON, April 12 A scheduled "Evening With Leonard Bernstein" at the United States Embassy here tomorrow will be a nonevent. Mr. Bernstein will not be there.
WASHINGTON, April 12 Peking asserted today that Chinese Communist aircraft had shot down an American "A-3Bheavy attack plane" that had intruded over southern China.
The 16-story former Daily Mirror building at 235 East 45th Street is being converted into an office building.
Las Vegas Freddie Little 158 pounds, Chicago, knocked out Ernie Burford, 156, Cleveland, 8 rounds.
LONDON, April 12 Three big British electronics companies with combined assets of 550-million ($1.54-billion) have joined forces to sell communications satellite ground terminals in world markets.

HAVANA, April 12 (AP) at least 16 persons, including two Roman Catholic priests, have been arrested on charges of harboring and aiding a Cuban accused of having killed two men in an attempt to hijack a Cubah airliner.
NEWARK, April 12 A large oil painting depicting the purchase of the site of Newark from the Indians in 1666 was hung today in the Robert Treat Hotel to commemorate the city's founding 300 years ago.

WASHINGTON, April 12 The Tariff Commission ruled unanimously today that no American industry was being injured even though titanium dioxide from West Germany was being sold in the United States at "dumping" prices.
A charge of discrimination against Negroes was dropped yesterday in the case of a taxicab driver who acknowledged that he had improperly used his off-duty sign.

Members of the New York Police Department and medical experts will meet with municipal and Federal officials in Brooklyn on Friday to consider ways of curtailing the increasing use of LSD, the hallucinatory drug.

A scheduled hearing yesterday on a move by a group of minority shareholders of the Freedom National Bank, a Harlem institution, to prevent it from holding an annual or a special meeting was canceled at the last minute.

Meeting on "Nursing in Disasters" under the auspices of the New York State Nurses Association, Statler Hilton Hotel, 9:30 A.M. Speakers: Lieut. Gen. Manuel J. Asensio, New York State Civil Defense Director, Alice Spellman, L. Louise Ziegeler, Allbert Palm, Mrs. Elinor Owens.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained Monday the level it reached Friday, which was 113.2.

A tantalizing plan for an investor's paradise in the form of a crash-proof stock market has been put forward by the former chief economist of the Securities and Ex change Commission's celebrated Special Study of the Securities Markets.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which already owns 99.8 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Western Electric Company, Inc., appears to be buying additional shares in the company on the open market.

BOSTON, April 12 (UPI) Lieut, Gen. James M. Gavin, retired, called today for the recognition of Communist China, increased trade with Iron Curtain nations and sharing United States scientific and technological advances with emerging nations.
SAIGON, April 12 South Vietnam's "other political problem" the growing discontent of its mountain tribesmen may soon erupt into a full-scale revolt, qualified sources said today.
