A leader of the Newspaper Guild of New York warned yesterday that the chances were "very slim" that a new contract agreement could be reached with the World Journal Tribune, Inc., before April 25 the date the new newspaper corporation plans to publish its first issues.
The London stock market was quiet and dull yesterday, affected by the Rhodesian crisis and caution over the forthcoming national budget.
EL PASO, Tex., April 12 (AP) A finance company executive accused of lying in 1863 at the fraud trial of Billie Sol Estes steadfastly maintained today that he had told the truth.
WASHINGTON, April 12 More than 55,000 soft coal miners remained on strike tonight in eight states despite a back-to-work order by their union leadership.

FROM nowhere to the center of the stage: the old but thrilling story had a replay last night in Philharmonic Hall. John McCollum, the solo tenor who had appeared in the first part of the Philadelphia Orchestra concert, could not go on after intermission to sing the solos in the Bruckner Te Deum. He had a cold, and became laryngitic.

The Diners' Club, Inc., and the Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that they had discontinued their discussions on the possibility of the bank's acquiring the creditcard business of Diners' Club.
MEMPHIS Mrs. William Kent may be the only woman in the world to refuse a gift of a Jaguar automobile because she coveted a set of china.
BREATHEDSVILLE, Md., April 12 (AP) Policemen with riot guns, tear gas, dogs and clubs stood by to maintain order today in the aftermath of rioting at the Maryland Correctional Institution.
PEKING, April 11 China reported today that it had a militia of about 100 million men and women and that it was taking far-reaching measures to tighten political control over them.
Joel J. Tyler, the City License Commissioner, apparently takes a dim view of "fetish footage," the new "in" term for the more explicit of the avant-garde films being shown locally.
PALO ALTO, Calif., April 12 The Stanford chapter of Sigma Chi fraternity, which included a Negro among its pledges last year, has been reinstated by the national body after a one-year suspension.

Until effective measures are taken to cleanse New York City's polluted air, the city will live under the threat of disaster. That is the warning offered by Norman Cousins, chairman of Mayor Lindsay's task force on air pollution. And he makes the warning very specific:
WASHINGTON, April 12 The biggest race in aviation history is entering its last lap. The prize: sales of supersonic airliners that may exceed $20billion the estimated cost of the Apollo lunar program.
Hempstead, L.I., sold $11,835,000 of tax-exempt bonds yesterday to a syndicate led by the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Bankers Trust Company and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.
HOUSTON, April 12 (AP) Dennis Ralston had no difficulty in leading the advance of favorites through the first round of the River Oaks tennis tournament today.
A model of Jesse H. Jones Hall for the Performing Arts, which will be opened in Houston on Oct. 2, was unveiled yesterday by Mayor Louie Welch of Houston in Philharmonic Hall at Lincoln Center.
SAIGON, April 12 The new commander of the Vietna mese I Army Corps, Lieut. Gen. Ton That Dinh, is a man in search of a hero's role.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., April 12 (UPI) The XB-70, a forerunner of supersonic transports, made its longest flight at March 3, about 2,000 miles an hour, today.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 13 Vincent A. Smalley, a vice president and trust officer of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York, died yesterday in his home at 8 Normandy Road. His age was 63.
AKRON, Ohio, April 12 (AP) John S. Knight, president of Knight Newspapers Inc., was named chairman and chief executive of the newspaper chain, it was announced today.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 12--A four-run rally in the sixth inning gave Brown an 8-4 victory over Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game today.

The chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality's Harlem chapter yesterday called the Lindsay administration's plans for the police review board "a cruel hoax" and "an affront to the intelligence of the black community."
Puccini's "La Boheme" and "Tosca" have been added to the new productions announced for the New York City Opera's seven-week fall season at the New York State Theater.
PITTSBURGH, April 12 Dr. Rufus H. Fitzgerald, chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh from 1944 to 1955, died yesterday. He was 75 years old and lived in Ligonier.
A review of all legislation that grants tax exemptions on certain real estate in the city was urged yesterday by Lewis Whiteman, executive director of the Investing Builders and Owners Association.
CINCINNATI, April 12 The New York Mets and Cincinnati Reds were rained out today for the second straight time.
HARRISBURG, Pa., April 12 (AP) Downtown Harrisburg, Pennsylvania's capital, was darkened for several hours last night and today after a fire and a series of explosions in an underground transformer.

T. George Silcott, executive director of the Forest Neighborhood House, a settlement house at 955 Tinton Avenue, the Bronx, announced yesterday that he would enter the Democratic primary in the Bronx's 22d Congressional District.
WHITE PLAINS, April 12 Voiceprints were exhibited to a judge and jury in a perjury trial in Westchester County Court here today.

Louis Wolfson's total compensation from the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation and its subsidiaries will be slashed from $525,000 to $150,000 for the next 10 years under a proposed settelment reached yesterday in a series of stockholder suits against the big shipbuilding and engineering company.

A long period of suspense has now ended with the nomination of Juan Bosch by the Dominican Revolutionary party for the presidential election on June 1. Provisional President Garcia Godoy's patience has been rewarded, although only at the cost of leaving the right-wing military officers still in charge of the armed forces while the "constitutionalist" officers obeyed Mr. Garcia Godoy's orders and went abroad.
LENINGRAD, April 12 The gleaming black and White ocean liner Alexsandr Pushkin made ready tonight to open the Soviet Union's first regular passenger ship link with North America.
BOSTON, April 12 (UPI) Jim Lonborg committed a balk in the 13th inning today to give the Baltimore Orioles a 5-4 opening-day victory over the Boston Red Sox.

"C.B.S. REPORTS" made a whole shift in em phasis last night in television coverage of the war in Vietnam. It avoided further scenes at the battlefront in favor of a study of efforts to win the confidence of the peasants.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 12 (AP) The Chilean Government was reported planning today to raise the price of copper, perhaps as much as 20 cents per pound.

James A. Farley, chairman of the Coca-Cola Export Corporation, said yesterday that the charge that his concern had yielded to threats of an Arab boycott in denying a franchise to an Israeli bottler was "completely unfair and unfounded."
SAIGON, April 12 A Government-sponsored national political congress that is to make recommendations for the convening of a constitutional convention discussed procedural questions today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 The Boston Celtics have not been dethroned as National Basketball Association champions yet. In fact, they never looked stronger than they did tonight in beating the Philadelphia 76ers, 120-112, to win the Eastern Division playoffs, four games to one, moving on to the league finals, which start Friday night in Boston.

PALOMARES, Spain, April 12 The bombs are gone, but they are far from forgotten here Representatives of the United States and Palomares are trying to settle the bill for damages resulting from last January's nuclear accident.
Bobby Dobbs, the head football coach at Texas Western, met yesterday with members of the West Point athletic department to discuss the Army coaching job.
The P. Lorillard Company has yet to make its final decision on whether to list the tar and nicotine content on each package of its new king-size filter brand, called True.
WASHINGTON, April 12 The American Government, with all its power, has never seemed more helpless than it does now in the face of the political turmoil in Saigon.
The Los Angeles County Flood Control District sold yesterday $20-million of bonds to an underwriting group managed by the Bank of America and the First National City Bank.
YONKERS, April 12 David James (Doody) Townley of Ashburton, New Zealand, has no "mount" in Thursday night's $100,000 International Pace, but the 40-year-old visitor is keeping active.

WASHINGTON, April 12 Secretary of State Dean Rusk is expected to make a courtesy call of considerable political significance on President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Repubic later this month.
LOS ANGELES, April 12 (UPI) Claude Osteen got the Los Angeles Dodgers off to a winning start tonight by hurling them to a 3-2 victory over the Houston Astros. The lefthander allowed six hits.

Dr. Sinaida Grunholtz Melamid, a physician and the widow of Dr. Michael Melamid, industrial chemist and chief founder and chiairman of Raffinerie Belge de Petroles, S.A. of Antwerp, an oil refining company, died of a heart attack Sunday aboard the Greek liner Olympia, returning from Bermuda to New York. She was 79 years old and lived at 263 West End Avenue.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 12 (AP) Manny Jimenez was supposed to have started the 1966 baseball season in right field for the Kansas City Athletics against the Minnesota Twins today. But, shortly before game time, it was learned that Jimenez was a holdout.
BOSTON, April 12 (UPI) Richard Cardinal Cushing refused today to call for Roman Catholic opposition to legislation that would modernize Massachusetts laws against birth control.
FREDONIA, N.Y., April 12 (AP) The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation plans to spend between $15-million and $20-million to expand its plants in nearby Dunkirk and in Watervliet, near Albany.
The Transit Authority has asked Joseph E. O'Grady, whose retirement was to have taken effect March 31, to stay on temporarily as chairman. He has agreed to do so.

Two books about the sculptor Henry Moore will appear on April 25. Praeger will publish "Henry Moore: A Study of His Life and Work;" by Sir Herbert Read, who is an old friend of the sculptor. The book is illustrated with hundreds of photographs, many taken by Moore himself. Harper Row is issuing "Henry Moore: The Life and Work of a Great Sculptor," by Donald Hall, with 100 photographs and drawings.

The Government of the United States acknowledges receipt of an aide-memoire from the Government of the French Republic on March 29, 1966. The United States Government has been and will continue to be in consultation with its other allies in NATO on the questions to which the actions of the Government of the French Republic give rise, and which affect the security of all members of NATO.

NEW DELHI, April 12 The Indian Goverment today voiced its strong objections to the "partisan" behavior of the Rev. Michael Scott, a British clergyman who is seeking a settlement between India and rebels in Nagaland.

JAKARTA, Indonesia One of history's most vicious massacres has not yet ended in Indonesia. More people have been slaughtered here during the past six years than in the entire Vietnam war. It is impossible to give any precise figure on the number slain. One careful diplomatic estimate puts the total at 300,000. Others range higher.

The common stock of Calumet Hecla, Inc., failed to open for trading yesterday for the fourth straight session. It was the longest period that trading in a Big Board stock has been stalled by the New York Stock Exchange.
TOKYO, April 13 A leading pharmaceutical company here believes that the place to find qualified Japanese recruits is in the United States.
MEN had an opportunity yesterday to model tow els, curtains and slip covers designed by leading fashion houses not to look like towels, curtains and slip covers at a previously all-woman show.
About 500 people heard a recital by Nicolai Gedda, the tenor, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries last night, and then got back the $6 apiece they had paid to hear him.

BABYLON, L.I., April 13 Miss Sybil Gilmore Healy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Howard Healy, was married this afternoon to Peter John Pagnamenta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Pagnamenta of Llanblethian, Wales.

WILMINGTON, N.C., April 13 (AP) Randy Glover, a 24year-old Florence, S.C., professional, shot an eight-under-par 64, his best competitive score since turning pro five years ago, to win top money of $250 in the $2,500 Azalea pro-amateur golf tournament today.
Two commodities took off yesterday on a price rise spree in terms of futures trading. Behind one was a rumor and behind the other, higher cash prices.

The American Stock Exchange will hold its first annual membership meeting today with strong Wall Street interest focused on its heavy trading volume and the rapid rise in price of certain of its stocks.

TORONTO, April 13 The National Ballet of Canada, now embarked on its 15th anniversary season at the O'Keefe Centre here, added its spectacular production of Prokofiev's "Romeo and Juliet" to the repertory tonight. This enormous and highly successful undertaking became the first native North American production of the ballet two years ago.

Mayor Lindsay is expected to propose a record expense budget of about $4,674,500,000 for the fiscal year 1966-67, an increase of $709,100,000 over the budget for the fiscal year that ends June 30.
This week's heavy volume of new securities reached its peak yesterday as investment firms set the terms on half a dozen key issues totaling more than $1.2-billion.

HOUSTON, April 13 (AP) Roger Taylor, the former British Dsvis Cup Player, used a strong volleying attack to upset Cliff Richey of Dallas, 0-6, 6-4, 6-3, in the second round of the River Oaks clay court tennis tournament today. The 24-yearold British left-hander had lost a three-set match to the young Dallas star last week in Florida.

BURBANK, Calif., April 13 (AP) Willie Mosconi extended his winning streak to five today, beating Richie Florence of Torrance, Calif., 150-minus 3, in the Billiard Congress of America invitation championships.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) After 55 years, the Navy is getting out of the dairy business.

MOSCOW, April 13 Aleksandr Tvardovsky, controversial editor of the journal Novy Mir, has offered a new defense of liberal trends is Soviet literature, calling artistry in writing a higher measure of value than "schematized" portrayal of reality.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 13 Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Babbitt Kelley of Fairfield, formerly of Chester Springs, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Wanamaker Kelley, to Thomas Knickerboker Curtis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis of West Chester, Pa.

MOSCOW, April 13 (AP) The Soviet Union has accused the United States of trying to kidnap the First Secretary of the Soviet Embassy in Tokyo.

SAIPAN, Marianas Islands This lovely, lonely island's unused airstrips belong to the birds, the lizards and the creeping tangan-tangan bush. The great B-29's took off from them to bomb Japan in World War II.
The head of an Israeli bottling concern said yesterday that James A. Farley's explanation of the Coca-Cola Export Corporation's refusal to grant him a franchise was "utterly without foundation."

WASHINGTON, April 13 The United Mine Workers of America and leading Eastern soft coal producers appeared today to be nearing agreement on a new labor contract that would end a strike by nearly 55,000 miners in eight states.

ALBANY, April 13 (AP) The Public Service Commission authorized the Western Union Telegraph Company today to raise by an average of nearly 3 per cent its rates for telegrams and most related messages handled entirely within New York State.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation set new first-quarter records in sales and earnings, D.C. Burnham, president, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (AP) The Susquehanna Corporation filed a supplemental complaint today in United States District Court here charging the General Refractories Com pany with giving false and misleading information to shareholders in its proxy statements.
SHOREHAM, L.I., April 13 The Long Island Lighting Company announced plans today to build a nuclear-powered electricity generator here.

WASHINGTON, April 13 Concern over the political crisis in South Vietnam was voiced in Congress today as Senators spoke of the need to make "reappraisals" and reach "new decisions" if the Saigon Government could not solve its problems.
MOSCOW, April 13 (Reuters) France and Russia are expected to sign an agreement on cooperation in color television tomorrow, a Soviet offical said here today.
WEST LOS ANGELES, April 13 (UPI) Five persons, including John Conte, actor, fled from a Bel Air mansion yesterday when exploding shells, turned the basement into a shooting gallery.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Negotiations aimed at averting a nationwide aerospace strike of Boeing Company workers resumed here today after a week's recess.

Harlem's Freedom National Bank, which bills itself as New York's only interracial commercial bank, has been authorized to open its first branch office in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, William R. Hudgins, president, told the bank's annual meeting yesterday.
Six New York City high school students have a brand new deskside tool to help them with their housework an I.B.M. computer.

In New York City, American Express is located at 65 Broadway, 374 Park Avenue, 61 West 51st Street, 150 East 42nd Street, and also at Abraham Straus, B. Altman Co., Bloomingdale's, Gimbel Brothers, and Macy's.
Paperboard production rose 11.2 per cent with 466,600 tons in the week ended April 9, from 416,606 tons in the corresponding week of 1965, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.

Maritime Administrator Nicholas Johnson, who is due back in Washington from the Far East on Saturday, is expected th defend statements he allegedly made last month in Tokyo concerning the possible construction of American ships in Japan.
The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7942, off 3 points from the preceding day's level.

Machinery to study the case histories of all persons treated in the city's hospitals after having used LSD will be set up at a conference on hallucinatory drugs tomorrow in Brooklyn.

An increase of 331,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 220,026,000 barrels, compared with 219,695,000 a week earlier and 231,518,000 a year ago.

SAIGON, Thursday, April 14 South Vietnam's ruling junta formally agreed today to hold national elections for a constituent assembly in three to five months.

WASHINGTON, April 13 At the great heights that supersonic airliners will fly, the housings around the engines actually shrink because of drastic temperature changes. Lubricants do not act like lubricants, electrical relays do not act like electrical relays.
MILWAUKEE, April 13 A 21-hour contract bargaining session ended on the waterfront at 7 A.M. today. It is expected to end a strike that began March 31.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis Trotman of Hollis, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Joyce Trotman, to Irvin Reid, son of Mrs. Etta Reid of Charleston, S.C., and Joseph Reid of Newark.

WASHINGTON, April 13 Several top-level staff changes and a reorganization of the functions of two of the agency's divisions were announced today by Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MARCUS HOOK, Pa., April 13 (AP) The Coast Guard succeeded today in floating a 182foot dredging barge that was sinking slowly in the Delaware River.

WASHINGTON, April 13 The Federal Reserve Board, by a vote of 6 to 1, disapproved today the application of the Wells Fargo Bank of San Francisco to acquire the Bank of Sonoma Countv, in Sebastopol, Calif.
Columbia University has elected Harold F. McGuire, a New York lawyer, a life trustee, Dr. Grayson Kirk, the university's president, announced yesterday.

The General Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had filed patent infringement suits against four companies involving a method for blowing polyurethane foam in the manufacture of certain plastic products.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, April 13 Dr. Robert Voelker, professor of civil engineering at Antioch College, died today, his 59th birhtday, at Springfield City Hospital.

Dr. Herbert Schueler was appointed president of Richmond College yesterday. The "upper division" college will open on Staten Island a year from September and will offer the third and fourth years of undergraduate study and graduate courses.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 112.9 on Tuesday from 113.2 on Monday.

THREE new convenience foods have just arrived from France for the rushhour chef. Among them are three-inch high, fully cooked puff pastry patty shells, packed six to a box under the label of Biscuitiere Maurice de Paris.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (AP) Bob Bolin pitched a fourhitter tonight as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Chicago Cubs, 4-0.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 13 Scores of Palestinian refugee leaders were arrested in Jordan last Saturday and Sunday, according to reports from Amman published here today.
CINCINNATI, April 13 Winston Churchill probably did not have the New York Mets in mind when he described Cincinnati as "the cleanest inland city in America."
A long-planned program that would establish a two-year course for firemen at New York Cite Community College is awaiting the approval of Mayor Lindsay.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, was appointed today as a one-man subcommittee to check on the academic standards of the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md.
Ludwig Mies van der Rohe received the first Thomas Jefferson Mamorial Foundation medal in architecture yesterday at the university of Virginia is Charlottesville.
PARIS Princess Virginia Ira von und zu Furstenberg the name on her calling card is the kind of girl who keeps the haute couture alive and full of hope.

ATLANTA, April 13 The Southern Christian Leadership Conference, headed by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., called on the Johnson Administration today to abandon the ruling military junta of South Vietnam and consider withdrawing from the country altogether.
LISBON, April 13 Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar warned today that the Rhodesian problem could "set off a vast fire" with risks for even those afar.
PAWLING, N.Y., April 13 Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Dann have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Fahy Dann, to Carl Miller Claus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Claus of Chappaqua.
WASHINGTON, April 13 Manufacturing and trade inventories rose at least $750-million in February, about the same as the revised figure for January, the Commerce Department reported today.

Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, the defending chess champion of the world, had a pawn advantage over his compatriot, the challenger Boris Spassky, when the second game of their title match was adjourned last night.

OSLO, Norway, April 13 (AP) A maritime hearing will open here Monday to determine the cause of the fire that swept the Norwegian cruise ship Viking Princess in the Caribbean last Friday.

The election of Robert Stevenson as an executive vice president of the Ford Motor Company was announced in Dearborn, Mich., yesterday by Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the company.

Theater party agents and their clients are getting a sample of "I Do, I Do," the musical in which Mary Martin will appear next season, as guests of Tom Jones and Harvey Schmidt, who wrote the show.

MILWAUKEE, April 13 (UPI) Attorney General Bronson C. LaFollette said tonight the decision in Winconsin's antitrust suit against baseball should mean that the effects of organized baseball's abuse of its monopolistic powers would be eliminated.
PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (UPI) The Philadelphia 76ers voted today distribution of $29,000 received for their appearance in the Eastern Division finals of the National Basketball Association playoffs. .

BERLIN, April 13 Two East Germans and a West Berliner charged with spying for the United States Central Intelligence Agency and the West German Secret Service went on trial today in the Supreme Court in East Berlin.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) The Defense Department made public today the names of four crewmen aboard a tanker plane listed as missing on a flight from the Philippines to the carrier Kitty Hawk off Vietnam.

Theodate Johnson took a Sentimental look at the past in her Town Hall recital last night. The program was dedicated to the memory of Eva Gauthier, the Canadian soprano who died in 1958 at the age of 73 and who was known for mixing modern music with classics in her vocal programs.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 13 A millionaire's wife and infant son have been kidnapped and released after the payment of $196,000 in ransom, the South African police disclosed today.
CLEVELAND, April 13 (AP) The United States Census Bureau is considering questioning the American people on religious beliefs in 1970 for the first time.
The duties of chief executive officer of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company were transferred yesterday to Charles H. Schaaff, president, from Leland J. Kalmbach, chairman.

CHICAGO, April 13 A critical report on Roman Catholic higher education called today for re-examination of the roles of those who run the colleges and for special attention to the selection of a well-rounded faculty with particular reference to lay participation.
A reception, buffet supper and concert next Wednesday at the Colony Club will benefit the scholarship fund of the Paderewski Foundation's women's auxiliary.
Officials in the administration of Mayor Lindsay favor giving the Police Department's proposed civilian review board a team of policemen to do its investigating, informed sources said yesterday.

The Times Square area was all that visitors could expect yesterday afternoon. There was a fire on Broadway and the circus in nearby Madison Square Garden; there were matinees in every theater and Easter week crowds on the sidewalks, and there was a glorious traffic jam.
DETROIT, April 13 A design fault that could damage oversize tires on nearly 15,000 1963model Buick Specials was disclosed today.

Frustrated by the opposition to Mayor Lindsay's tax proposals, his financial advisers are considering ways of raising revenues from those institutions, governmental and private, that own property valued at more than $4 billion within the city on which they pay no taxes at all.

BROOKLINE, Mass., April 13 Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. McLean Jr., of Brookline, formerly of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Stevens McLean, to James Desmond Lizotte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Desmond J. Lizotte of Summit.

A Manhattan builder has received state permission to test public response to what, if completed, would become the state's first nonresidential condominium. The structure planned is a five-story professional office building in Hempstead, L.I., that is expected to contain about 40 offices for physicians and dentists.
PHILADELPHIA, April 13 Dr. Edward H. Worthington, former president of the Pennsylvania High School Principals Association, died yesterday at his home in Wyncote. He was 73 years old.
Rugoff Theatres, operators of movie houses in Manhattan, Long Island and Philadelphia, has appointed William J. Dwyer Jr. as vice president in charge of theater acquisitions.

MOZART, William Schuman and Brahms. Those were the three composers on last night's Boston Symphony Orchestra in Philharmonic Hall. The Mozart A major Symphony (K. 201) was a special treat. While Mozart's reputation is as high as ever fashions in music may shift, ...

BOSTON, April 13 Stockholders of the Boston Maine Corporation won't know before 11 A.M. tomorrow whether the incumbent management or an insurgent group is going to direct the carrier for the next year.

YONKERS, April 13 "Bring money," the advice that has been given to and heeded by local horseplayers since parimutuel betting started in the metropolitan area in 1940, also will apply to management at Yonkers Rarceway tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, April 13?A United States spokesman denied today a report from London that the United States had offered to discuss with Communist China a normalization of relations and the admission of Peking to the United Nations.

Prima donnas on the point of retirement should sing nothing but farewell performances. Zinka Milanov, one of the reigning sopranos at the Metropolitan Opera for the past 28 seasons, sang her final complete opera last night, Giordano's "Andrea Chenier," and sounded better than she has in a long time. (She will be heard again, but only in an operatic excerpt, in the gala program that closes ...

The antomobile industry is the subject of yet another investigation. Now, it is its advertising that is under scrutiny. A spokesman for the Federal Trade Commission confirmed yesterday that the agency was conductng "a preliminary stafflevel study" on automobile advertising. He said that the prime interest was in speed and racing claims made for cars, but that the study would cover a broad spectrum.

Those concerned about the socalled "string shortage" among young American musicians should have been in Carnegie Hall last night. A symphony, orchestra of about 90 highschool instrumentalists was the main attraction, and the bite and polish of its string section was cause for nothing but joy.
CAMBRIDGE, England, April 13 (AP) Cambridge University has decided to put a halt to the 40-year-old King Street Run Club, a student beer-drinking society.
LOS ANGELES, April 13 The Henry E. Huntington Library of San Marino, Calif., announced today the appointment of James Thorpe as its new director, effective Oct. 1.
LONDON, April 13 At Sadler's Wells Theater tonight, Britain's smallest major ballet company gave the first performance of "Sun Into Darkness," in many ways British ballet's most ambitious production.

Events today: Verdi's "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Haarlem Philharmonic Society, Waldort Astoria, 11:45 A.M.; Valentina Levko, mezzo soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

CAIRO, April 13 Western diplomatic circles here have concluded that President Gamal Abdel Nasser has decided to keep Egyptian troops in Yemen and is consolidating them for a renewed campaign to put Arab nationalists in control in South Arabia after the British leave in 1968.

Collections of furs, jewelry, sports cars and other luxury items will be displayed in the New York Hilton on May 6 at the Million Dollar Ball, a benefit for Waldemar Medical Research Foundation in Woodbury, L.I. The foundation is seeking $1-million for expansion of its cancer and leukemia research program, directed by Dr. Norman Molomut.
"The Day of the Americans," by Nerin E. Gun, will be published by Fleet on April 29.
The election of George P. Egbert as vice president in the investment research department of the First National City Bank was announced here yesterday.

Eduardo Frei, the Christian Democratic President of Chile, is on the verge of winning a long and hard-fought victory for his copper program. In the excitement over other big world events this triumph, which should mean much to Chile and to Christian Democracy in Latin America, has gone largely unnoticed.

The Welfare Department said yesterday that it would not make a claim for any part of a fund being raised for the widow and 10 children of a man who was beaten to death in Brooklyn on March 28. About $17,000 has been cellected.
ALBANY, April 13 The State Council of Churches called on legislative leaders today to reach "a workable compromise" on their bill to revise New York's 179-year-old divorce law.
WASHINGTON, April 13 United States officials denied today that there was any political significance to the use for the first time, of B-52 bombers against North Vietnam.
SANTE FE, N.M., April 13 Indians were turned away today from a meeting of the Bureau of Indian Affairs designed to reshape bureau activities to be of greater help to Indians.

PARIS, April 13 The French Government cautioned the United States and other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today against requesting excessive delays for the completion of the evacuation of foreign military installations from France.
GROSSINGER, N.Y., April 13 "I'm going to win. I always feel that way before a fight. But I feel even stronger about it this time. This is my championship and I am going to keep it."

Only a relatively few hours remain before tomorrow evening's midnight deadline for the filing of Federal and state income-tax returns. Those who have filed their returns and perhaps even received a refund can take it easy.

TRENTON, April 13 Lieut. Col. Howard and K. Shaw, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Shaw have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Marilla Shaw, to David Julian Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian J. Smith of Cambridge, Mass.
LONDON, April 13 British Government sources acknowledged today that the effect of economic sanctions on Rhodesia was considerably slower than had been hoped last winter.
A rise in Government bonds provided the main interest yesterday in an otherwise quiet London Stock Exchange.
NEW DELHI, April 13 The India Government has moved to simplify sharply the procedures for the import of raw materials, spare parts and components needed to get Indian industry out of the doldrums.
LUCIUS BEEBE was a combat correspondent at cafe society's battles. His last and best book, "The Big Spenders," is a gaudy cyclorama in his finest pottedpalm style.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday the promotion of Charles Block, William P. Dubendorfer and Adam L. Gowans as vice presidents.

SAIGON, April 13 As South Vietnam's political crisis has deepened over the last month, attention has again focused on the headquarters of the Unified Buddhist Church, the sanctuary from which leading monks stage their attacks on the military Government.

Earl S. Baird, 61-year-old partner of Baird Co., a stock brokerage concern at 67 Broad Street, was charged yesterday in Federal Court with failure to file his income-tax returns for the years 1959 through 1963.

BUCKY HARRIS was properly cynical about the situation. "Don't ever believe it," he used to say, "when you are told that a manager has resigned. There are too few such jobs in baseball and they pay too well. A manager never resigns. He always is fired." Bucky should know because he touched a lot of bases in his day with managerial stopovers with the Senators (three times), Tigers, Red Sox, Phillies and Yankees.

WAYNE, N.J., April 13 (AP) Sunnybank, the home of the late Albert Payson Terhune made famous in his book, "Lad: A Dog," and other books, is unoccupied. Huge wisteria vines clutch the wide veranda, the roof and the chimney.

Howard J. Samuels charged yesterday that if the State Constitutional Convention next spring is approached with "a politics-as-usual attitude," the blame would lie "squarely, totally and unequivocally with Governor Rockefeller."
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) A special office to offer advice and possible loans to small businessmen in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn will be opened next week.

With the help of court back-to-work orders in New York and New Jersey, the leadership of the International Longshoremen's Association has ended most of the quickie strikes that marked introduction of the port's new manpower rules.
The Monsanto Company increased prices yesterday of two chemicals used in detergents and cleaning compounds by 50 cents per 100 pounds, following earlier action by the Stauffer Chemical Company.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., yesterday ordered $525-million worth of huge new jet airliners, each with a carrying capacity of 490 persons. This is about 2 times the number that can be accommodated in today's standard jet airplane.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson conducted a 2 -hour bus tour today of beauty spots and eyesores of this city, which she called "America's home town."

A former candidate for justice of the peace on Long Island and the operator of a flower shop in Manhattan's "Little Italy" were questioned by a Brooklyn grand jury yesterday about a January shooting fray in the former Mafia family of Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) The Washington Senators sold Steve Ridzik a righthanded pitcher, to the Philadelphia Phillies for "above the waiver price" of $20,000 today.

NAHA, Okinawa, April 13 The United States Army reported today that it was delaying a decision on whether to try two former prisoners of the Vietcong so that an exhaustive and impartial investigation of their case could be completed.

John (Sonny) Franzese, a figure in the Long Island underworld who is charged with directing a band of bank robbers, raised $150,000 in bail yesterday and walked out of Federal court, Brooklyn, surrounded by happy relatives and admiring henchmen.

Five works by as many composers were given first performances on the program of the Music in Our Times Series at the Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Street "Y" Last night. And wonder of wonders, in this day of closely drawn contemporary music camps, none of the five resembled one another.

WASHINGTON, April 13 As a job, the Presidency of the United States has never seemed particularly attractive. The work is sedentary. The hours are long. There is altogether too much speechmaking required and you have to spend a, great deal of time being pleasant to dull or disagreeable people.
Luna 10, the Soviet vehicle in orbit around the moon, has ob-. tained a gamma ray spectrum of the lunar surface indicating that the moon has a crust and that this crust is somewhat like the earth's.
TRENTON, April 13 The Republican party in New Jersey told its members in the Legislature today to vote as they pleased on a proposed state sales tax.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 13 Dr. Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., a former special assistant to President Kennedy, criticized the Johnson Administration's policy in Vietnam tonight.
The election of William L. Kauffman as a vice president was announced here yesterday by the Flintkote Company, a producer of building materials.
Mrs. Beverly Moss Spatt, a member of the City Planning Commission, last night became the first woman member of Mayor Lindsay's administration to perform the night owl trick.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, April 14 The Baghdad radio announced today that President Abdel Salam Arif of Iraq had been killed in an air crash near the Persian Gulf port of Basra.

WASHINGTON, April 13 President Johnson is reported to have rejected as too harsh the State Department's original reply to President de Gaulle's one-year deadline for the evacuation of American troops and bases from France.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Officials from the four northern New England states have endorsed the plea of Northeast Airlines for a permanent New York-to-Florida route.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 13 (AP) Three East German literary figures have said their government will not let them attend a Princeton University meeting of Group 47, a postwar organization of German writers and critics, a Princeton spokesman said today.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 13 Dr. Walter Adams, prin cipal of the University College of Rhodesia, resigned tonight after having defied police attempts to recapture an African student who had returned to classes after escaping from a restriction camp on the Rhodesia-Mozambique border.

The three New York newspapers planning to merge told staff members yesterday that the proposed consolidation was the only way to create a publishing force that would endure in New York and employ the largest number possible of people now working on the papers.
The United States Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the election of William C. Batchelder to the new post of financial vice president.
ST. LOUIS, April 13 (AP) A pinch-hitter, John Herrnstein, drove in a run with a two-out single in the 12th inning, giving the Philadelphia Phillies a 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.
SAN ANTONIO, April 13 President Johnson is acting as if he would like to escape momentarily from the cares of office, particularly those imposed by the political crisis in South Vietnam.
An East Harlem antipoverty agency announced yesterday that it had applied for funds directly from Washington in an attempt to bypass the city antipoverty organization.
WASHINGTON, April 13--"There were really only two innovations on the New Frontier," James Joseph Saxon said with casual selfassurance a few days ago "the Peace Corps and this office."

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 13 Army registered its fifth straight baseball victory with a 12-2 decision over previously unbeaten New York University today. Three-run outbursts in the first two innings put the game on ice early for the undefeated Cadets.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 13 (AP) Former Gov. William S. Flynn, one of the youngest men ever to serve as Rhode Island's governor, died today of a heart ailment at the New England Medical Center hospital in Boston. He was 80 years old.
Martin Lefcort, president and chairman of the board of the Chateau Martin Wines, died of a heart attack yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 63 years old.
HOUSTON, April 13 (AP) The Gulf Sulphur Corporation said exploratory drilling was expected to begin next year on new sulphur concessions in Mexico by a new affiliated company.

A speech by President Johnson in Mexico City will be broadcast live by the television and radio networks of the National Broadcasting Company, beginning about noon tomorrow. Mr. Johnson will participate in ceremonies unveiling a statue of Lincoln given by the United States to the Mexican people.
Wildcat striking by dissident longshoremen broke out again yesterday after a day of peace.

MILWAUKEE, April 13 A Wisconsin Circuit Court judge ruled tonight that the Braves must play their home baseball games here this season after May 17 unless the National League agreed to sanction a Milwaukee franchise in 1967.
Charges of disorderly conduct against six youths arrested in a near-riot outside a W.E.B. DuBois Club in Brooklyn last month were dismissed yesterday.

A Federal District Court judge in Grand Rapids, Mich., rejected yesterday an attempt to dismiss a Studebaker Corporation suit to block a takeover bid by insurgents. Hearings were ordered for April 19 on the company's request for an injunction that would stop the take-over move.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 13 Khalid Bakdash, Secretary General of the Central Committee of the Syrian Communist party, is back in Damascus after eight years of self-exile in Eastern Europe.
The Warner Brothers Company has appointed Henry P. Coogan to the new position of senior vice president in charge of the company's women'sapparel division.

ROME, April 13 Pope Paul VI said tonight in a television colloquy with Anglican, Orthodox and Protestant leaders that the Roman Catholic Church felt a profound obligation to seek Christian unity but could not make the "doctrinal or constitutional sacrifices" asked by some.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) The Social Security Administration said today that failure to fill out the loyalty oath section on the Medicare application woud not by itself disqualify elderly persons from benefits under the new program.

WASHINGTON, April 13 Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that President Johnson had made a "mistake" in not asking Congress for more money for the poverty program.
WASHINGTON, April 13 Michigan State University was disclosed today to have provided the support and cover for operations of the Central Intelligence Agency in South Vietnam from 1955 to 1959.
Senators Robert F. and Edward M. Kennedy treated students and faculty at New York University yesterday to an example of senatorial procedure during a hearing on Cuban refugees.
EL PASO, April 13 A prosecutor in the 1963 fraud trial of Billie Sol Estes testified today that doubt had been raised this week about key testimony against Estes.
The known death toll from Tuesday's Atlantic storm reached eight yesterday.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday he was ready to waive immunity and appear before a grand jury to dispute allegations that political kickback payments were made during his tenure as Queens District Attorney.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 When the world champion Ratzeburg crew came to the United States in 1963 no one endorsed its coach, Karl Adam, and his theories on rowing technique and training methods more wholeheartedly than did Joe Burk of Pennsylvania.
Stocks closed mixed on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, as continued heavy volume delayed the ticker as much as 16 minutes.
STOCKHOLM, April 13 (Reutprs) Count Felix von Luckner, the German naval hero of World War I, died today in Malmo at the age of 85.
A group of physicians picketed the International Automobile Show at the Coliseum yesterday to underscore demands for safer cars.

MEMPHIS Although he is not untowardly tall or uncommonly small, J. Tunkie Saunders looms larger than life. He is a master of the ducal gesture and the grand manner, and when guests dine in his home the meal frequently begins with vintage champagne with fresh caviar and a whole smoked salmon flown in from Iron Gate Products in New York.
A Federal Appeals Court upheld yesterday a lower court verdict allowing an Alleghany corporation tender offer ending next Monday to proceed.

LAUREL HOLLOW, L.I., April 13 Dr. Milislav Demerec, a geneticist and a former director of the department of genetics of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, died yesterday at his home in Stewart Lane here. He was 71 years old.
A one-day educational and sales conference for members of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards will be held April 28 at the Berkeley Carteret Hotel, Asbury Park.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 13 Ambassador William Tapley Bennett Jr. ended his tour here today and returned with his family to the United States.
The nation's electric power production rose 7.4 per cent in the week ended April 9 from the level in the corresponding week of 1965, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
The City Council flexed its muscles yesterday in what same members described as a "declaration of independence from Mayor Lindsay." Others called it "an exercise in futility."
PITTSBURGH, April 13 (AP) Many miners appeared today to be uncertain why they are striking. Orval Stone, a shift supervisor in Johnson City, Ill., summed up the confusion when he said:
PARIS, April 13 A syndicafe in which the French Government and the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) are partners announced today France's first offshore oil discovery.

PARIS, April 13 A private ceremony honoring the first American casualty in the liberation of Paris will be held at the American cemetery in Suresnes instead of the Invalides, the French military shrine, as in the past.

Wilt Chamberlain still doesn't convince anyone that basketball championship style is a oneman sport. But the Boston Celtics continue to prove that in championship play basketball is basically a five-man team sport.
Juan Ramirez, Louis Chu and Charles O. Washington may be names not easy to recognize yet.

In an apparent attempt to recoup from the 1965 fiscal year loss of $1,051,714, which was blamed on the collapse of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Commodore Business Machines (Canada), Ltd., is selling one of its subsidiaries to Litton Industries, Inc.; of Beverly Hills, Calif.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 13 A 44-year-old importer who was once ruled legally insane and later was found to be sane, was convicted today of the murder of his wife.

The engagement of Miss Linda Folsom Haight to Ferdinand Leopold de May has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Winthrop Haight of 155 East 82d Street. Mr. de May is the son of Mrs. Robert de May of London and the late Mr. de May.
WASHINGTON, April 13 The Senate Investigations subcommittee charged today that "unscrupulous and corrupt persons" had gained control of certain banks in the last few years.

A 33-year-old artist identified by the police as Robert J. Whitfield was questioned at Baltimore police headquarters last night in connection with a murder March 2 in a West Side apartment in New York City.
The fourth International Photography Fair opened at the New York Coliseum yesterday.
WHITAKERS, N.C., April 13 Night and day on the highways through this village of 1,000 people and others like it there is a flow of trucks and cars loaded with tens of thousands of cigarettes.

The National Gallery of Art in Washington revealed yesterday that it was the anonymous buyer of a postcard-size painting sold for $616,000 in London last month. And it attributed the work to Rogier van der Weyden, a 15th-century Flemish painter.

NEW DELHI, April 13 Purshottam Kakodkar, leader of Goa's Congress party, who disappeared from a Bombay hotel last Nov. 28, has turned up in Rishikesh, a spiritual retreat on the banks of the holy Ganges River.

FRANKFURT, Germany, April 13 (AP) Frankfurt's Police Commissioner, impressed by United States efforts to reduce deaths on the highways, wants to apply American methods to combat West Germany's highway-death rate.

Max Schuster, father of the late Arnold Schuster, who was shot and killed in 1952 after telling the police of the whereabouts of Willie Sutton, the bank robber, died yesterday at Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. His age was 59.

The proposed merger of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., into the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation became an issue at yesterday's annual meeting of the Western Union Telegraph Company.
ALTHOUGH the weather at the moment is less than ideal for salt-water fishing, any clearing trend should see resumption of excellent flounder fishing along the coast.

James D'Angelo, a young pianist who has studied both classical music and jazz, made his concert debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall with a program that might have developed into fun and games if the cards had not been so firmly stacked against the listener.
ATLANTA, April 13 (AP) Willie Stargell, who ruined the Braves' Dixie debut, spoiled Atlanta's second game in the South with a home run and a single that powered Pittsburgh to a 6-0 victory tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 Just as modern weapons have changed the battlefields of war, so have modern pressures changed the battlefield of man's unconscious mind, Dr. Erich Fromm, the psychoanalyst, said today.

SAIGON, April 13 A United States military spokesman said today that pilots had reported that the strategic Route 15 in North Vietnam was completely blocked at Mugia Pass as a result of a landslide caused by yesterday's massive raid by B-52 bombers.
ATHENS, April 13 Premier Stefanos Stefanopoulos assumed the portfolio of Foreign Minister today from Elias Tsirimokos, who with Minister of Welfare Mimis Galinos had resigned from the Government.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) A Constitutional amendment to modify the population guideline for apportioning state legislatures was brought up in the Senate today, and opposing sides quickly began debating the issue.
LOS ANGELES, April 13 (AP) The Houston Astros drove Sandy Koufax from the mound in the fourth inning, then went on to defeat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7-6, tonight.
BECAUSE the weather was bad yesterday, Roy White will finally get his chance to start in center field for the New York Yankees today provided the weather is not bad again.
PARIS, April 13 Georges Duhamel, a novelist, poet, essayist, surgeon and member of the Academie Francaise, died today at his home in Valmondois after a long illness. He was 81 years old.
A dozen Welfare Department employes demonstrated yesterday in front of the department's headquarters, 250 Church Street, demanding more special officers at the Men's Shelter.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 13 Senator Jacob K. Javits's name is probably going to be on the New York ballot next November, whether or not he decides to challenge Governor Rockefeller for the Republican nomination for Governor.
Time is rapidly running out on the ability of the United States to help feed the underprivileged nations of the world, Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said yesterday.

GENEVA, April 13 South Africa's economic boom is blurring the ultimate goal of its Government's apartheid policy of racial separation, according to a study published today by the International Labor Organization.
Sales and earnings of the National Biscuit Company during the first quarter of 1966 reached record proportions, stockholders were told yesterday at their annual meeting here.
A man on trial for assault said he had been asked by Federal agents to "set up" the poet Allen Ginsberg for a narcotics arrest, according to three witnesses who testified in Federal court yesterday.
Stock prices showed sharply divergent trend in heavy trading yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 13 (AP) Charles B. Shuman, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, said tonight that the Johnson Administration was making the farmer a whipping boy for inflation generated by the Government's own spending policies.
A bronze bust of the latet Chief Justice Harlan Fiske Stone was unveiled yesterday at the Columbia University School of Law.
The Liberal party will support Edward I. Koch, the Greenwich Village Reform Democratic leader, in his bid for Representative Theodore R. Kupferman's old seat on the City Council.
ROME, April 13 (AP) Carlo Carra, Italian painter and art critic, died in Milan today. He was 85 years old.
Miami Beach Gordon Lott, 158 pounds, Savannah, outpointed Gene Wells, 158, Mobile, 10 rounds.

With his political future at stake, Senator Jacob K. Javits must determine and quickly whether he can take the Republican nomination away from Governor Rockefeller, a declared candidate for a third term.
The belief that highly educated women feel frustrated in a man's world is a myth, a manpower expert said yesterday.

"VIOLENCE! Violence! Had scarcely left the Bureau when I saw a man struck by a taxi--no accident. The driver noticed him start across the street, I'm sure of it, and am sure there was time enough to stop the cab.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary will appoint Deputy Commissioner Theresa Maria Melchionne to handle minority group problems, the department said yesterday. She now heads the department's youth program.
WASHINGTON, April 14-- United States officials think that France is rushing preparations for atomic tests in the Pacific to coincide with President de Gaulle's visit to the Soviet Union this summer.
Baseball began forming its plan of battle yesterday for what is regarded as its toughest legal fight in history.

Many passengers who stopped using the city's subways and buses during the 12-day strike in January have not returned to the transit system, but they're coming back slowly, according to Commissioner John J. Gilhooley of the Transit Authority.
Financial district workers and antiwar demonstrators traded punches and insults yesterday during a hectic 45-minute protest march outside the New York Stock Exchange.

TOKYO, April 14--For two flower-scented hours this morning, 4,200 selected Tokyo residents became part of another Japan--the leisurely, beauty-loving Japan of older times that coexists today with an industrialized society.
WASHINGTON, April 14-- Assistant Attorney General Donald F. Turner said today that he hoped to have at least part of the long-awaited merger guidelines for business ready by fall.

ROCHESTER, April 14--Students and faculty at the University of Rochester have begun a drive to prevent former Vice President Richard M. Nixon from receiving an honorary degree when he delivers the university's commencement address.

The Bank of America, San Francisco, the nation's largest bank, reported yesterday that its net operating earnings for the first quarter were $24,481,000, or 86 cents a share, up 12.5 per cent fro mthe $21,755,000, or 76 cents a share, reported in the corresponding period of 1965.
HACKENSACK, N.J., April 14--Herbert F. Myers Jr., former State Assemblyman and a lawyer specializing in criminal cases, died of heart failure at his home last night. He was 57 years old.

Mayor Lindsay is reported to have "penciled in" an increase of $84.3 million in transit subsidy as he prepared the executive budget for 1966-67 that will be made public later today. He has thus decided, apparently, to try to keep the subway and bus fare at 15 cents, a serious mistake fiscally and politically.

The country's only legal distributor of LSD is recalling all of the hallucinatory drug that it sent to scientists for research. The move, which follows the company's decision to cut off all new supplies to the accredited researchers, will halt most scientific experiments with LSD on people.

An effort to revive the Metropolitan Regional Council has been begun under suburban initiative, with encouragement of Mayor Lindsay. The Tri-State Transportation Commission has won legal status as the official regional planning agency, but the Council could serve as a useful link between the 1,467 political entities of the metropolitan area and the commission.
BEIRA, Mozambique, April 14--The Portuguese authorities in this port today seized control of the tanker Ioanna V and her cargo of crude oil, believed intended for Rhodesia.
MEXICO CITY, April 14-- President Johnson entered this capital in triumph today.

WASHINGTON, April 14-- Some 350 persons who disapprove of the war in Vietnam announced today that they would not voluntarily pay their Federal income taxes, due tomorrow. They urged others to join them in this protest.

DUBLIN, April 14 (UPI)-- Irish extremists struck today with bombs and guns in the southeastern village of Kilmacow. They warned that they would continue their terrorist campaign until their jailed comrades were released and pardoned.
WASHINGTON, April 14-- The United States Court of Appeals indicated its belief today that the nearness of one embassy to another should not be used to frustrate the right of political protest.

It was a spring day, an Easter vacation day, a day to drag along at the end of mommy's arm, or have lunch with her in the Palm Court of the Plaza, or explore the big city, or go to museums, or throw rocks in the East River.
The removal of their favorite haunts on the Bowery would not solve the basic problems of the derelicts, social psychologists reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 14-- Industrial production and personal income continued to rise strongly in March, Government agencies reported today.
With a fine sense of history, the Metropolitan Opera will end 83 years in its home at Broadway and 39th Street tomorrow night with the closing scene from Gounod's "Faust."
WASHINGTON, April 14-- At the insistence of the Central Intelligence Agency, the State Department's Biographic Register is going to acquire an air of secrecy.
Three men were convicted last night by a Federal District jury here of assaulting agents of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics and of impeding an arrest by the agents.

ODESSA, Tex., April 14--In 1948 a young teacher stood in her English class in this oil town on the interminable flatness of West Texas and admired a crude miniature of Shakespeare's Globe Theater that had been brought in by one of her students.

Robert H. O'Brien, president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc., announced yesterday that the company's net earnings for the second quarter, ended March 17, of the current fiscal year rose to $2,633,000, or $1.04 a share, from $2,045,000, or 78 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year.
New York's apparel industry has endorsed Mayor Lindsay's direct 5 per cent tax on business net income, the first major industry to do so.

Tennessee Williams said yesterday that two short plays of his authorship, "I Can't Imagine Tomorrow" and "Confessional," would be presented on Broadway next season under the collective title of "Dragon Country."
What commodities have offered the best trading opportunities this year?
An air-pollution-control bill that incorporates the toughest proposals made to the City Council in 14 months of investigation and public hearings won unanimous committee approval yesterday.

Twenty Egyptian army officers have been secretly arrested on charges of plotting against President Gamal Abdel Nasser because of disaffection over his policy in Yemen, according to reports from diplomatic sources reaching The New York Times.
SAIGON, April 14--The generals who rule South Vietnam were in full retreat today.
LONDON, April 14--Spring --or what passes for it in England--was put to rout today by a mid-April blizzard that swept across much of the southern half of the country.

A long, cold afternoon at the Stadium proved profitless for the Yankee baseball team yesterday, although management collected the receipts from 13,195 customers attending one of the earliest double-headers in the annals of the franchise.

WASHINGTON, April 14-- The State Department disclosed today that several American universities had been notified that scientists and scholars from Communist China would be permitted to visit the United States.

He arrived from Paris April 5.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 14 --Aspirin seems to have-anxiety relieving effects in addition to its pain killing qualities, a scientist reported here today.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported this week changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

KENSINGTON, Md., April 14 --Joseph L. Ray, retired New York City industrialist, died yesterday of pneumonia at the Kensington Gardens Nursing Home here, where he had resided since 1961. He was 81 years old.

Firm or increased prices for many of its products enabled the Weyerhaeuser Company to set records in sales and earnings in the first quarter, its president announced yesterday at the annual meeting in Tacoma, Wash.

Last night the current guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic led the orchestra in Philharmonic Hall in a mixture of familiar and unfamiliar music, but even the familiar works were presented in such a way as to make them provocative.

In 1908 Otto Kahn promised Giulio Gatti-Casazza a new Metropolitan Opera House within two or three years. The financier, intimately involved in the opera company's affairs, had listened sympathetically to the new co-manager's complaints about the wretched stage facilities at the Met.
The Board of Estimate declined yesterday to take any action to override Mayor Lindsay's vetoes of items in the 1966-67 capital budget.
TOKYO, April 14--A high official of the Japanese Foreign Ministry denied today that Americans had attempted to kidnap a Soviet diplomat here last month.
Support already pledged to Governor Rockefeller and additional backing that will be announced within a week or so appear to assure him of renomination at the Republican convention in September.
THE message from Seventh Avenue designers working on fall fashion collections is: Keep up the knee exercises and keep on good terms with the tailor.

ALMOST 20 years ago, London's fashion world was set agog by Sharman Douglas, the blond, blue-eyed, 18-year-old daughter of Lewis W. Douglas, the newly appointed United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's. She wore a white straw hat, adorned with navy ribbon and veiling and a red rose, that was described at the time as looking like "an omelet with ketchup on it."
The Federal Reserve is keeping the nation's credit markets on a tight rein, figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.
The $150-million of Allied Chemical Corporation debentures put on the market yesterday at a yield of 5.20 per cent appeared almost sold by late afternoon.
WASHINGTON, April 14-- Democratic party officials are considering using funds from corporate advertising in a party-sponsored publication to assist Negro voting registration efforts in the South.

ALBANY, April 14--Starting next September, health classes in a selected number of schools over the state will receive intensified instruction about the dangers of using narcotics and smoking cigarettes.

The Bureau of Enforcement of the Interstate Commerce Commission has recommended to the commission a procedure by which it believes the Norfolk Western Railway should include three smaller lines in its system.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 --In a benevolent, scientific disguise, the age of big-brotherism is fast approaching with possibly disastrous consequences only dimly recognized by researchers and the public, a mental health meeting here was told today.
Sharp rises in copper shares were the main feature yesterday in an otherwise quiet London stock market.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 (UPI)--The Chicago Cubs, held to seven hits and one unearned run in two straight losses to San Francisco, rapped three Giants' pitchers for 16 hits today en route to a 9-4 victory-- their first of the season under manager Leo Durocher.

Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach said last night that despite fair-housing laws and organizations devoted to these statutes "we are not only failing to reduce racial ghettos, we are failing to keep them from expanding still further."

MEET the latest Russian musician. She is Valen tina Levko, a mezzo-soprano from the Bolshoi Opera, and she made her American debut last night in Carnegie Hall. She is a woman of great dignity and ample voice.

WASHINGTON, April 14-- The United Mine Workers of America was moving closer tonight to an accord with big Eastern and Southern soft coal producers on a new labor contract to end a strike by 50,000 miners in eight states.

Under the pressure of tightened military draft procedures, fewer Ivy League upperclassmen are leaving college. As a result, there are fewer places for next fall's freshmen at schools where five or six applicants vie for each seat.

In a heavily guarded, locked courtroom that was opened only to permit the widow of Malcolm X to enter, the three men convicted of killing the black nationalist leader were sentenced to life in prison yesterday.

On Wednesday, the stock price of Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., jumped nine points on rumors of a stock split. When the rumors actually materialized yesterday--directors voted a two-for-one split-- the stock closed 1 points off, at 70.

State Senator Thomas J. Mackell was endorsed for District Attorney last night by the executive committee of the Queens County Democratic organization. However, he was promised a fight in the June 28 primary by another Democrat, who refused to withdraw.

Christian W. Korell, president and chairman of the Underwriters Trust Company, a bank at 50 Broadway with several branches in the city, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 28 Sunnybrook Road, Lawrence Park West, Bronxville, N.Y.
THAT recently embattled American heroine--the housewife who longs for an identity beyond domesticity--is about to receive a pat of encouragement.

GNIEZNO, Poland, April 14-- The smoldering conflict between Poland's Communist Government and her Roman Catholic Church moved today toward an open confrontation in this provincial city and in the regional capital of Poznan nearby.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 14 (AP)--Firing broke out in a northern suburb of divided Nicosia tonight, the first outbreak in more than a year of strict observance of the United Nations cease-fire.

Some time tonight a multitude of last-minute New York taxpayers will write, with pens dipped in tears and gall, sizable checks to the order of the Internal Revenue Service, and then turn wearily to the job of filling out their state returns.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 --Whatever happened to beer and peanuts? Such standard baseball fare may have sustained fans in other cities where the major league season opened this week, but the scene at Candlestick Park on Tuesday was one vast elegant picnic.

WASHINGTON, April 14--Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara disclosed today that the United States had a conventional bomb inventory totaling 331,000 tons, of which 102,000 tons were based in the United States.

Secret fee-splitting in the development of Mitchell--Lama housing projects has been officially banned by directives issued by the City Housing and Redevelopment Board and the State Division of Housing.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 14 --Governor George C. Wallace momentarily disappointed an audience in Gadsden this week by declaring that he did not believe recent reports of unidentified flying objects.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., April 14 --This comfortable residen tial community, one stop up the tracks from Scarsdale, is voting again on a 13-year-old school question that has brought racial turmoil into its affluent, allwhite neighborhoods.

A secondary offering of 268,000 shares of class-A common stock and 75,000 shares of classB common stock of Shulton, Inc., was oversubscribed yesterday. It was placed on the market by a syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co., Inc., and Hornblower Weeks, Hemphill, Noyes.
Robert Goulet will star in a 90-minute television version of "Brigadoon" to be presented in color by the American Broadcasting Company on Oct. 15. The hour has not been set.

WASHINGTON, April 14-- Officials at Michigan State University described today their ties to the Central Intelligence Agency in South Vietnam as innocent, though embarrassing, but gave contradictory accounts of when they had learned of the link.
LOS ANGELES, April 14 (AP)--Perry Fowler, a photographer whose World War II exploits read like a spy "thriller," died last night of cancer. He was 58 years old.
With a swirl of colors and the skirl of bagpipes, the Carnegie Tech Kiltie Symphony Band made its New York debut last night at Town Hall.
Residents of Short Hills, N.J., will soon have a Bloomingdale's store close at hand, thanks to the success of Bloomingdale's venture into the Hackensack area to the north.

American business is planning to spend $61.64-billion for new plant and equipment this year, a rise of 19 per cent above such expenditures in 1965.

Major domestic and international airlines yesterday were weighing their next moves following Pan American World Airways' decision to lay out $525-million for 25 huge, new Boeing 747 jets--each of which will seat up to 490 passengers.

The waterfront of the Port of New York is operating under "powder keg" conditions, according to several responsible industry leaders and labor union officials.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 14 --The Premier and acting President of Iraq tonight relaxed the total curfew he imposed immediately on learning of the death of President Abdel Salam Arif in a helicopter crash last night.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 14 (AP)--The Chilean Government announced today a 20-cent rise in the price of export copper to 62 cents a pound. The price increase was the second this year and the third in the last six months.

The New York Mets saw their first sunshine in almost a week yesterday, and they were promised more for today, when they hope to open the season finally at 2 o'clock at Shea Stadium against the Braves of Atlanta --or, would you believe Milwaukee?

Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving said yesterday that the Children's Zoo in Central Park and Carl Schurz Park would be among the first facilities to close if his department's share of the city expense budget was not increased.

A certified public accountant, described by the Government as the biggest check casher in the city for bookmakers and loansharks, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of perjury and of evading $33,000 in personal-income taxes between 1959 and 1962.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange were forbidden yesterday to accept stop orders for the common stock of Calumet Hecla, Inc., which failed for the fifth straight trading session to open on the exchange. BALTIMORE, April 14--Organized crime syndicates are apparently taking over the bootleg cigarette business, tax authorities said here today.

GOOD bridge partnerships, like vintage wines, ma ture and improve with age. Yet the strains of playing serious tournament bridge are such that divorces occur with distressing regularity.

WASHINGTON, April 14-- Ralph Nader coupled new criticism of American automobiles today with a charge that the German-made Volkswagen was unsafe.
Jackie Halstead, a slim, freckle-faced teen-ager from Nitra, a small West Virginia town, looks forward to making seafaring his career.

The 21-story Regency Hotel, under construction in Atlanta, which will have 800 rooms on tiers around a central air-conditioned court, was sold yesterday for $16.5-million to the Hyatt Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)--The Securities and Exchange Commission lifted today a suspension on stock trading in Great American Industries, Inc. The order is effective at the opening of business tomorrow.

The city will tell the banks today that it wants to borrow $241,755,000.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a zoning change that cleared the way for construction of a huge warehouse over the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks on Manhattan's West Side.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 14--The Government is not going to permit the Greek tanker Manuela, now docked at Durban, to discharge 15,000 tons of crude oil intended for Rhodesia, according to reports here today.
OFFICIALS of the Hudson River Marathon have decided that inboard-outboards and outboards, like oil and water, don't mix.

BANGKOK, Thailand--Quite unofficially and without contributing any battlefield forces, Thailand is one of our most helpful allies in the Indochina war. Forty-five per cent of all bombing attacks against North Vietnam and many counterinsurgency and interdiction operations in Laos originate from bases here made available to U.S. aircraft.

Verdi's "Aida" was given at the Metropolitan Opera for the 511th and final time in the history of the house at 39th Street and Broadway. It is the mostperformed opera in the Met repertory, some 67 repeats ...

GENEVA, April 14--The United States outlined today at the disarmament conference what it called "simple, practical and unobtrusive" measures for verifying the observance of projected agreements to halt the nuclear arms race.

TORONTO, April 14, (AP)-- Gilles Tremblay scored two goals for Montreal after one of the wildest brawls in National Hockey League history tonight, pacing the Canadiens to a 4-1 victory that completed a fourgame sweep over the Toronto Maple Leafs in their Stanley Cup semi-final playoff series.

Members of the American Stock Exchange heard the chairman of their board of governors report yesterday that a yardstick study was under way to develop "a realistic and objective means of assessing the problems of trading in our issues."
WASHINGTON, April 14-- In the sprawling complex of Boeing Company buildings around Seattle, more than 50,000 workers are constructing jet planes for the world's airlines.
WASHINGTON, April 14-- A series of proposed procedures to insure quick investigation of power failures was issued today by the Federal Power Commission.
The city has accepted an offer of the Atomic Energy Commission to equip a nuclear museum adjacent to the Hall of Science at the former World's Fair grounds in Queens.

The Monsanto Company announced yesterday in St. Louis that it achieved record sales and earnings in the first quarter of 1966, and that volume in the quarter was the highest for any three-month period.

YONKERS, April 14--Stanley Dancer, a top-flight harness racing chauffeur who has driven in more than 6,000 events, couldn't recall a single outing in which he enjoyed a smoother or easier trip than the one he took behind Cardigan Bay in the $100,000 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Six molecular biologists have resigned from the Dartmouth Medical School after a longstanding dispute over the nature of medical education.
SAIGON, April 14--For the first time in the Vietnamese war, more Americans than South Vietnamese were killed last week, a United States military spokesman reported today.
