A Larchmont bartender and his four young sons took the day off, yesterday, as did a youthful student of hotel management. They, along with eight others, played hooky to go clowning.
WASHINGTON, April 14-- The three-man panel assigned to settle the manning scale dispute aboard new automated American merchant ships will start work shortly, a Labor Department spokesman said today.
LONDON, April 14--British sensitivity to miniature "bugging" devices has caused some embarrassment to the United States Embassy here.

LAS VEGAS, April 14--Gay Brewer, who lost in a three-way playoff for the Masters golf title on Monday, found himself in another tie today with a 70 in the $100,000 Tournament of Champions. Brewer's two-underpar round shared the openingday lead with Billy Casper.

HIGH POINT, N.C., April 14 (AP)--Richard Pettigrew, the all-Service heavyweight boxing champion, outpointed Earl Averette of Cleveland tonight in the first round of the Amateur Athletic Union's 77th boxing tournament.
George D. Widener's What A Treat, the 3-year-od filly champein of 1965, made her first Aqueduct apearance of the season yesterday and impressed with her performance.
NEW HAVEN, April 14--Dr. Fred Rogers Fairchild, Knox Professor Emeritus of Economics at Yale University, died yesterday in Bridgeport. He was 88 years old and lived on Mill Plain Road in Fairfield.

BASEBALL has landed in a legal snake pit through the ruling of Judge Elmer W. Roller of Wisconsin and the only escape ladder--if such an escape ladder even exists--extends shakily upward toward the Supreme Court in Washington. The sport has got itself into a frightful mess through its greed and arrogance, precipitating the thing it has made frantic efforts to avoid over the years, judicial scrutiny.
The Publishers Association of New York City voted unanimously last night to accept The World Journal Tribune, Inc., as a member.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)--The Navy has ordered six rescue submersibles that could be carried by plane to a disaster site and then attach themselves like leeches to a sunken submarine and take out crewmen.

WASHINGTON, April 14-- Ralph Ginzburg told the Supreme Court today it had trapped him into violating the obscenity laws by announcing lax standards for obscenity and then tightening them in deciding his case.
Gulf Western Industries, Inc., and Universal American Corporation announced yesterday that they had agreed in principle to merge, with Gulf Western to be the surviving company.
The American Stock Exchange had its second-busiest day in history yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15--Three psychiatrists reported today that the mental health of young civil rights and peace workers was equal to that of their more conventional contemporaries and that their maturity was often greater.
WASHINGTON, April 15 The prospects for an early settlement of the soft-coal strike appeared to dim today as labor negotiators recessed their bargaining efforts until Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) Sargent Shriver, director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, received apologies today from officials of an antipoverty group because his audience heckled during a speech yesterday.
CHARLES CITY, Va., April 15 (AP) A whale that lived briefly in the James River 70 miles from its native Atlantic Ocean died today in the hostile inland waters.
WASHINGTON, April 15--The National Mediation Board considered today asking President Johnson to impanel an emergency board to head off a major airline strike threatened for April 23.

District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Brooklyn called upon the State Legislature yesterday to make the distribution of LSD, or any other hallucinatory drug, a felony punishable by a jail sentence of between 7 and 20 years.
The starting gate rather than the finish line occupied the starring role yesterday in films viewed by the stewards after inquiries had been posted in two of the nine races at Aqueduct.
The board of directors of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., at a special meeting here yesterday, approved three proposals which will strengthen management's position in a possible fight for company control.

The war veteran rehabilitation program of the Mary Baruch Society at 240 West End Avenue will benefit from a luncheon to be held at the Pierre on April 26.
ALBANY, Calif., April 15 (UPI) A power failure at Golden Gate Fields today forced track officials to cancel the thoroughbred track's program shortly before the start of the fifth race.
To John C. Wood, president of 149-year-old men's clothing concern of Brooks Brothers, his job is a "fun" job.

JAKARTA, April 15 The rally preceding the attack on the embassy was originally intended as a show of support for the Indonesian Government by Indonesians of Chinese descent, but thousands of other young people also attended.

WASHINGTON, April 15 The index of primary market prices remained unchanged at 105.2 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended April 12, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products increased in price while processed foods declined. Industrial commodities averaged unchanged.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 15 (AP) Winston Chandler, 46 years old, of Little Rock, today became the fourth Democratic candidate for Governor of Arkansas.

Rayette-Faberge, Inc., a producer of perfume, cosmetics and toiletries, has announced the appointment of Philip Brass to the new post of executive vice president. Mr. Brass, 53 years old, will supervise operations of all divisions, including branches in London, Paris and Toronto.

FRANKLIN, Ind., April 15 (UPI) A stubborn sheriff won a test of nerves today against three prisoners who threatened to hang two fellow inmates in the Johnson County Jail unless they were given guns and freedom.
ALBANY, April 15 Mayor Lindsay's proposed New York City personal income tax, as it now stands, was pronounced dead today by the Legislature's leading Republican.
DETROIT, April 15 Henry Ford 2d said today that the automobile industry was "in trouble" over traffic safety, but he cautioned Congress not to do anything "irrational" about the problem.

MEXICO CITY, April 15 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson gave a speech in Spanish today at the dedication of a statue of Lincoln in a park although helicopters and jet planes roaring overhead interrupted her.

Mayor Lindsay assigned a former city mediator, Morris Tarshis, yesterday to sit in as an observer at negotiations between the newspaper unions and representatives of the dailies planning to merge on April 25.

One hundred and forty professional nurses submitted their designations yesterday to officials at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center in a dispute over salaries and working conditions, hospital spokesmen said. The resignations do not take effect until May 23. The center has about 300 registered nurses.
The spot rate on the British pound declined in moderate trading yesterday on foreignexchange markets here. The rate closed at $2,7938, down 10 points from the preceding day's level.
Toshihide Watanabe, chairman of the Nippon Electric Company, Ltd., died Sunday of a heart attack in his home in Tokyo. His age was 70.
Four major lumber associations reported an increase of 9 per cent in production in the week ended April 9 compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.

RUMSON, N.J., April 15 Miss Laura Runyon Heller daughter of Mrs. Edgar W. Heller of Fair Haven and the late Mr. Heller, was married today to Kenneth Berton Pierce, son of Mrs. Lois L. Windham of Lake Park, Fla., and Berton F. Pierce of Alpine.
Two bondholders of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad brought suit yesterday in Federal Court here, claiming the railroad had not met certain obligations on its 4 per cent bonds due in 2010.

An air pilot association which six years ago drew a tonguein-cheek picture as to what the automotive industry would be like if the Federal Government regulated it as closely as it did aviation now sees its forecast as "more prophetic than facetious."
Copper issues again dominated trading in a confused stock market yesterday.
NEWARK, April 15 New Jersey officials and welfare leaders portrayed the Cuban refugees today as assets to their communities.
A United States District judge ruled here yesterday that the State Department had no right to restrict the travel of an American citizen holding a valid passport.

WASHINGTON, April 15--The Army agreed today to turn over its heavy transport planes to the Air Force, ending a long dispute as to which fighting service should carry troops and supplies in forward combat areas.

The most significant fact about Mayor Lindsay's first executive budget is that it restores integrity to city finance. It stops the deficit financing. It provides in advance for unforeseeable contingencies, which occur every year with clocklike regularity. It may underestimate revenues instead of overestimating them as in the past. It begins the restoration of exhausted reserves.

The American Stock Exchange ended the most active week in its history on a bearish price note yesterday as most stocks declined on profit taking. Most stocks made forward progress during the first three hours of trading, but profit taking later clipped the earlier gains.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 (UPI) Tom Haller crashed a three-run homer tonight and Frank Linzy bailed Bob Shaw out of a sixth-inning jam to give the San Francisco Giants a 6-2 victory over the Houston Astros.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 15 (AP) An agreement on salvage rights to the Viking Princess was announced today, one week after the luxury cruise ship was wrecked by a fire on a Caribbean cruise. No details of the agreement were disclosed by attorneys in the case.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 113.5 on Thursday from 113 on Wednesday.

SAIGON, April 15 South Vietnam's Buddhist leaders announced today that they would suspend their campaign against the military Government provided the Government honored its pledge to hold an election for an assembly in three to five months.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 15 (AP) A Negro principal will be assigned next September to what is now an all-white elementary school. The move is a result of Federal desegregation guidelines.
A wistful Robert F. Wagner and a buoyant John V. Lindsay were among the 52,812 fans at Shea Stadium yesterday.
A new British device aimed at curbing the rising number of car thefts in this country is being demonstrated at the International Automobile Show.
It is much too early to breathe easily about the political situation in South Vietnam, but there is still a government in that unhappy land--and that is cause for gratification.

EPSOM, England, April 15 (UPI) Jack Crump, the sports official who put British amateur track and field back on the international map after World War II, died after a short illness in Epsom Hospital late last night. He was 60 years old.
Newbold Morris, former City Council President and Parks Commissioner, left an estate of more than $1-million, according to an application for probate of his will filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

RADFORD, Va., April 15 (AP) Rear Adm. George Clough Bullard, commander of the 18th Carrier Division at the Quonset Point Naval Station, R.I., died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his summer home on Claytor Lake near here. He was 50 years old.

The police were searching last night for a holdup man who took about $2,000 about at gunpoint from the Beneficial Finance Loan Co., 120-09 Liberty Avenue in the Richmond Hill section of Queens. They also were seeking an unidentified man who entered the loan company just before the holdup and left with the robber.

Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, the defending champion, obtained a dangerous edge over the challenger, his compatriot Boris Spassky, after the adjournment of the third game of their 24-game world title chess match, played at the Variety theatre in Moscow last night.
DUBLIN, April 11 In spite of the divisive effect of the ceremonies for the 50th anniversary of the Easter rebellion, the spirit in the damp Irish air this spring is one of conciliation.
Helen Menken, the actress, left an estate of more than $100,000, according to an application for probate of her will filed yesterday in Surrogate Court.

Price changes were announced yesterday in several industries. E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., raised prices of some of its packaging films and cut others. It added 2 cents a pound to its two-in-one polyethylene packaging film.
The stock of Calumet Hecla, Inc., traded for 21 minutes yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and in that time accounted for a gain of more than $47-million in paper values.
BALTIMORE, April 15 Cigarette smuggling can be halted completely only if North Carolina institutes a cigarette tax, state tobacco tax administrators agreed today.

The executive budget for the fiscal year, highest in the city's 300-year history and the first full-year budget of the new Lindsay administration, totals $4,615,286,712. It represents a gap between existing revenues and projected expenditures that must be filled by $520-million in new and increased taxes.

The St. Nicholas Society held its Paas (Easter) Festival Ball last evening in the WaldorfAstoria's Grand Ballroom. Orange candles on blue tablecloths and the white of the gowns of five debutantes presented there carried out the society's colors.

Dr. Linus C. Pauling, twice a winner of the Nobel Prize and an outspoken political activist, concluded presentation of his $1-million libel suit in court here yesterday, in which he contends that William F. Buckley Jr., maliciously called him a Communist fellow traveler.

PITTSBURGH, April 15 (UPI) Alex Johnson and Lou Brock slammed two-run homers to back up Bob Gibson's six-hit pitching and give the St. Louis Cardinals their 18th straight victory at Pittsburgh today, a 9-2 triumph over the Pirates.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 15 (UPI) Sandra Haynie of Fort Worth trimmed five strokes off par on the front nine and finished with a four-under-par 68 to take the first-round lead today in the Raleigh invitation golf tournament.

Gerald Hamilton, a bassbaritone who sang his first New York recital three years ago, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall last night to perform songs and arias by Handel, Haydn, Schubert, Schumann and others. He was accompanied by Stephen Whitford.

ST. PHILIBERT, France, April 15 (Reuters) Eric Tabarly of France, who won the 1964 single-handed transAtlantic sailing race, returned to port for repairs today, two days after setting out on another lone Atlantic crossing. He planned to try again tomorrow if weather permits.

Thomas J. Deegan Sr., for many years a Brooklyn realestate broker, died yesterday at the Doctors Hospital in Washington. He was 89 years old and had lived in Brooklyn and Manhattan before moving to the capital four years ago.
A Theater Masque Ball at the Overseas Press Club on the evening of April 24 will benefit the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theater.

The Fifth Avenue Association's Board has adopted a resolution endorsing some features of Mayor John V. Lindsay's tax proposals, but opposing a state constitutional amendment to increase the real estate tax limit from 2 per cent to 3 per cent.
WILMINGTON, N.C., April 15 (UPI) Larry Beck carded a 67 today for a six-under-par total of 138 to take a twostroke lead at the halfway point of the Azalea open golf tournament.
BOSTON, Apri1 15, (AP) Willie Naulls, a 31-year-old forward for the Boston Celtics, said today he woud retire after the National Basketball Association playoff finals.
Most Government bonds and some corporate issues declined yesterday in light trading.

In the engineers' Elysian Fields, Dr. T. Kennard Thomson must be faintly amused. The New York City Planning Commission recently announced a project to add 200 acres to the southern tip of Manhattan for parks and garages. How paltry is this idea in comparison with the visions of the late Dr. Thomson, a dreamer of constructive dreams on a far grander scale. He envisioned an extension on Manhattan measuring a full six miles.
LONDON, April 15 The late Somerset Maugham's villa on the French Riviera, La Mauresque, is up for sale through the London real-estate agency that the novelist once called "my favorite authors."
Neither Cincinnati rain nor Wisconsin justice nor anything else could stop the New York Mets from opening the baseball season four days late yesterday against the Atlanta Braves.

HIGH POINT, N.C., April 15 (AP) Richard Pettigrew, the all-Service champion, outpointed Roger Lewis of the United States Air Force, London, tonight to gain the heavyweight semi-finals in the 77th annual Amateur Athletic Union boxing tournament.
MESSINA, Sicily, April 15 (UPI) Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., and his Australian partner, Helen, Gourley, advanced today to the mixed doubles final of the Messina international tennis tournament.
Within an hour after it was released yesterday, Mayor Lindsay's record $4.6-billion expense budget drew sharp criticism from the two top Democrats in the city government.
The Westchester town of Briarcliff, which gets half its water from the New York City system, has decided to lift water restrictions that had been imposed because of the drought.

GENEVA, April 15 A lack of trained workers is the "greatest single reason" for the failure of health standards to rise throughout the world, according to Dr. Marcolino G. Candau, director general of the World Health Organization.
"WHO'S afraid of Mark Cross?" the advertise- ment asks, and answers: "You are."
BONN, April 15 The Volkswagen Company, West Germany's biggest automobile manufacturer, rejected as "absurd" today the charges that its cars were unsafe.

SALEM, N.J., April 15--A New Jersey Young Republicans investigating committee concluded today that at least 10 Rat Finks were guilty of having taken part in or encouraged racist and anti-Semitic songfests.
SYDNEY, Australia, April 15 The Interparliamentary Union meeting in Canberra, voted overwhelmingly today in favor of immediate talks among all parties in Vietnam to end the war.

The New York City Mission Society, one of the nation's oldest religious and social service agencies, will dedicate tomorrow at 3 P.M. its new resource and training center at Lenox Avenue and 142d Street, in Harlem.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (AP)--John Briggs's run-producing single in the ninth inning capped a two-run uprising against a former teammate, Jack Baldschun, that carried Philadelphia to a 4-3 victory over Cincinnati tonight.
A cut of $100,000 from last year's allotment to the New York Shakespeare Festival was called for yesterday in Mayor Lindsay's expense budget.

VIENNA, April 15 Austria tonight faced the end of the conservative-socialist partnership that has given her a stable Government for 21 years. For the first time the powerful Socialists are likely to go into opposition.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 14 Gay Brewer assumed the lead by two strokes today with a 36-hole aggregate of 139 in the $100,000 Tournament of Champions.
Soybean futures rallied yesterday, partly in response to a surge in soybean-oil trading.

ROME, April 15 A Soviet trade mission arrived in Rome today to complete an agreement for the manufacture of Fiat automobiles in the Soviet Union and, it is hoped here, in general to increase Russian purchases from Italy.

CLEVELAND, April 15 (UPI) The Cleveland Indians came from behind twice with the help of five Boston errors today and finally beat the Red Sox, 8-7, in 12 innings. Max Alvis's twoout single scored Chuck Hinton from second with the winning run.
A Coast Guard helicopter removed an injured crew member from the Italian liner Michelangelo at sea yesterday afternoon and took him to a hospital in Boston.

MADRID, April 15 (Reuters) The Spanish fisherman credited with leading United States searchers to the area where a hydrogen bomb fell into the Mediterranean Sea was honored today at the United States Embassy here.
LONDON, April 15 (AP) A Soviet geographer says the "Vinland Map of 1440," supposedly showing America 52 years before Columbus discov- ered it, is a clever fake.

From the morass of numerals in the Lindsay budget emerges a determination, in the words of the Mayor's message, to uplift the "dismaying areas of poverty" that persist in "one of the richest and most affluent cities in the world."

SALISBURY, Conn., April 15 Miss Rosina Rand, daughter of Mrs. Harrison E. Salisbury of New York and Roxbury and John A. Rand of Salisbury, was married this afternoon to Scott Warner, son of Mrs. Frank Hurlbutt of Falls Village and Harry R. Warner Jr. of Amityville, L.I.

On the brick and cement plaza in front of Columbia University's Low Library yesterday across the wide yard from a blaring rock 'n' roll band and dancers taking advantage of the spring air were four manned tables.
Mrs. Pierre Reynaud of Paris has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joelle Denize, to Philip Hone Auerbach, son of Mrs. Philippe Berard of Paris and the late John Hone Auerbach.
The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the largest domestic manufacturer of farm equipment, reported yesterday in Peoria, Ill., a decline in first-quarter profits, despite an increase in sales.

The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development no longer fears that world trade will decline this year. Its pulse-taking suggests that the pace of business activity, already strong in the United States and Canada, will rise in Europe, and boost trade for both developed and developing countries.

SOME of the most interesting bridge deals remind one of a fencing bout, with thrust, parry and riposte. The diagramed deal, noted by the leading French player-writer Bertrand Romanet, is a case in point. The reader may care to study the diagram and make up his mind whether six diamonds doubled should succeed if both sides play their best.
BERLIN, April 6 Peter Lors, chief foreign editor of Neues Deutschland, East Germany's biggest newspaper, wore a pleased smile.
A new speculative interest in Cuban securities seems to be under way in Wall Street.

Forty-eight products of the Terminal Iron Works, the prolific one-man sculpture factory that closed last year with the death of its proprietor, David Smith, are on their way to Europe for a long-term museum tour.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 15 Burdette Gibson Lewis, formerly of this community, who served in several New York City posts before World War I and later was a special agent of the United States State Department in Washington, died today in a Trenton hospital. He was 85 years old.
Simpson-Sears, Ltd., announced yesterday in Toronto the election of J.C. Barrow as chairman and chief executive officer and Douglas J. Peacher as president. Both men were elected directors.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 15 (AP) Seven members of Ohio State University's journalism faculty rejected today a plea for unity from the school's new director.

The New York Civil Liberties Union said yesterday it was "unfortunate" that the impending appointment of Police Deputy Commissioner Theresa M. Melchionne to handle minority group problems had been attacked by some civil rights leaders.
Robert Friede was sentenced yesterday to serve two and a half to five years in prison in connection with the death of a young woman from a narcotics injection he had given her.

TORONTO, April 15 Interest at the National Ballet of Canada's disappointing performance at the O'Keefe Center tonight was spread all too thinly over a revival of George Balanchine's "Serenade," and three specially created works new to Toronto, Heinz Poll's "Adagio Cantabile," Daniel Seiller's "Rivalite" and, most ambitious of all, Grant Strate's new staging of "Pulcinella."

A dispute over the presentation of summer music events at the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium was resolved yesterday when Justice Vincent A. Lupiano of the New York State Supreme Court ruled that Leonard Ruskin's lease on the stadium was valid.
Stevedoring companies in the port are beginning to wonder if they made a mistake in pressing for a closing of the longshore register or work list.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) Eleanor Adele Geraghty, 20-year-old sophomore at the University of Chattanooga, was chosen tonight as queen of Washington's annual Cherry Blossom Festival.
Chile's 20-cent-a pound increase in her copper price has aggravated an already chaotic market for the scarce metal.
NEWARK, April 15 (AP) Two former partners of Anthony DeAngelis, the key figure in the multimillion-dollar food-oil swindle, were given Federal prison sentences today.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., April 15 (AP) Elaine Tanner, a 15year-old from North Vancouver, B.C., shattered the American women's 100-yard backstroke record tonight as she upset the defending champion and Olympic gold medal winner, Cathy Ferguson, in the senior national Amateur Athletic Union swimming championships.

EAST LANSING, Mich., April 15 (UPI) The president of Michigan State University will be called before the State Legislature to explain his school's role in a Vietnamese aid mission that employed operators of the Central Intelligence Agency, a lawmaker said today.
The Mets presented "New Faces of 1966" when the curtain went up at Shea Stadium yesterday.
SAIGON, April 15 More United States servicemen were killed in the Vietnamese war in the first 99 days of this year than in all of 1965, a United States military spokesman reported today.

The International Automobile Show, nearing the end of its nine-day stand at the Coliseum on Columbus Circle, is setting records in car sales, attendance and vandalism, exhibitors and exposition directors reported yesterday.
A memento of the Metropolitan Opera House's opening night will be onstage at this evening's Gala Farewell.

About 200 members of eight labor unions picketed in City Hall Park for an hour yesterday demanding reinstatement of 17 State Island ferryboat officers who were not returned to their jobs after a walkout 10 months ago.
DAYTON, Ohio, April 15 (UPI) Daniel E. Armel, president of the bankrupt Certified Credit Corporation of Columbus, was sentenced today to 15 years in prison for fraud.

Even allowing for such other writers as Aldous Huxley and Ronald Firbank, no one in the decades before the war had precisely the satirical tone or cutting edge of Evelyn Waugh. Wild invention and deadpan incoherence were combined with a cool, precise prose to make his books both outrageous and delightful to read.
It was Birchers in the morning, antiwar demonstrators in the afternoon and a parade of puzzled taxpayers all day long at the Internal Revenue Service district office at 120 Church Street yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, April 15 (UPI) Bishop Ivan Lee Holt, a president of the World Methodist Conference, and Mrs. Modena McPherson Rudisell of Deluth, Ga., were married today.

CHICAGO, April 15--With broad strokes, a panel of lawyers and art-world figures today painted a picture of an art market without ethics in an affluent art-hungry society that "seems to be doing its best to strangle the creative artist in a bed of roses."
John T. Robertson, vice president for sales and marketing of I.T.T. Telecommunications, died Thursday of a heart attack in his office. He was 47 years old.
HOUSTON, April 15 (AP) Marty Mulligan of Australia upset top-seeded Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., 6-2, 6-2, today to advance to the semifinals of the River Oaks tennis tournament.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes was reported in critical condition last night at St. Vincent's Hospital with acute coronary thrombosis.

In this age where synthetics are rapidly taking over from natural materials, traditionalists will be happy to learn that leather one of man's oldest materials is making a comeback in the automotive field.
The Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation announced yesterday a decline in first-quarter sales and earnings from the 1965 level.

The projected reorganization on May 1 of the bureau system of the Navy Department has stirred up many ghosts from the past and may result eventually in even greater centralization of the Defense Department. Vincent F. Albano, former chief inspector of the safety division of the Harris Structural Steel Company, died Thursday of a heart attack in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at the Seville Hotel.

Alvin Handmacher, president of Handmacher-Vogel, Inc., 1407 Broadway, one of the country's largest producers of women's suits, coats and dresses, died yesterday in his home, 860 Fifth Avenue. He was 60 years old.
Dr. Philip Oberman, a dentist and a Zionist leader, died yesterday morning at Montefiore Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 41. He lived at 2126 Muliner Avenue, the Bronx.

MEXICO CITY, April 15--President Johnson urged the Western Hemisphere nations today to renew their efforts to achieve economic progress and social justice. He called this "a test of whether freedom can work."

YONKERS, April 15 Adios Vic, who beat Bret Hanover three times last year, wound up fifth tonight in a seven-horse race won by Chapel Chief at Yonkers Raceway. The oddity was that the beaten odds-on favorite is being primed for next week's 1 -mile $50,000 Good Time Pace, while the victor appears to be allergic to distance races.
Dr. Myron Skraly of 375 East Mosholu Parkway North, the Bronx, a retired dentist, who formerly practiced in Manhattan, died Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 60.
Harold M. Sherman Jr., an executive vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
The Hertz Corporation and the United Exposition Service Company announced here yesterday an agreement to merge.

HONG KONG, April 15 The Chinese Communist party complained today about its members who ignore politics and pay heed only to the technical as- pects of their jobs in key fields.
DENVER, April 15 (UPI) Gov. John A. Love today announced that Colorado would refuse to do business with any company that practiced discrimination.

PATERSON, N.J., April 15 Irving S. Baxter, chairman of the Baxter Corporation of Paterson and Shelby, N.C., card cutters of textile designs and sellers of textile machinery, died in Livingston. He was 76 years old and lived in Short Hills.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI) The number of workers drawing unemployment benefits fell by 71,200 to 1,152,700 during the week that ended April 2, the Labor Department reported today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 15 Maj. Gen. Abdel Aziz Uqeili, Iraq's Defense Minister, is being mentioned increasingly in Baghdad as the possible successor to President Abdel Salam Arif, who was killed in a helicopter crash Wednesday near Basra.

BALTIMORE, April 15 Where the vintage pitchers like Whitey Ford, Pedro Ramos and Bob Friend had failed, Frederick (Fritz) Peterson succeeded yesterday for the New York Yankees. In his first major league game, the 24-year-old left-hander beat the Baltimore Orioles, 3-2, and drew an accolade from his manager, John Keane.
Two dissident directors called off their proxy fight against the Paramount Pictures Corporation yesterday and sold all of their holdings in the company 143,100 shares to Gulf and Western Industries.

Incredible as it may seem, at least 10,000 American children are willfully injured or killed every year by their parents. Students of the problem have increasingly accepted the conclusion that such parents are too emotionally disturbed to be deterred by the possibility of punishment. The United States Children's Bureau recommends that states adopt reporting systems that would identify such parents so that they can be treated and if possible restored to emotional health.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Saturday, April 16 (AP) Prime Minister Ian Smith said today that Rhodesia would not use oil from the tanker Ioanna V because his Government did not want to aggravate the difficulties of Portugal or the ship's Greek crew.
BUFFALO, April 13--At the age of 89, an impatient but buoyant Pablo Casals is beginning a spring and summer schedule that would stagger many a younger man.

Automobiles ride in as much comfort as first-class cruise travelers aboard the four new Grace Line passenger cargo vessels of the Santa Magdalena class thanks to a modern and highly efficient method of handling the vehicles.
WITH modern processing and distribution methods many fresh fruits and vegetables are in season all year. Spinach and green beans, parsley and strawberries, for example, are almost always available.
WASHINGTON, April 15 The Office of Education today gave recalcitrant school districts an additional 21 days to pledge compliance with new school desegregation guidelines.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 15--Just over a year ago the Israeli Government warned seven foreign companies that if they wanted to do business here they would have to do it openly. Each had been dealing through third parties to avoid conflict with the Arab boycott of Israel.

The Greater New York Safety Council said yesterday that it was renewing its campaign to induce motorists to drive at less than the posted speed limits when weather, heavy traffic or other less-than-optimum conditions make such speeds hazardous.

The new budget to run the city's schools will exceed the billion-dollar mark for the first time. But despite the record total, the city's education leadership considers it an austerity budget which will require a drastic trimming of plans.
Among the thousands admiring the glistening new cars at the International Automobile Show at the Coliseum, there are many commenting, "Well, they don't make them as they used to."

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will observe an "extraordinary jubilee" beginning tomorrow as a gesture of respect and admiration for the achievements of the Ecumenical Council, Vatican II.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Anne Buck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Buck of West Hartford, Conn., to Dr. Carlton A. MacDonald Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. MacDonald of Baldwin, L.I., and Winsted, Conn., took place yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 High officials of the State Department overruled their subordinates and the Central Intelligence Agency today and ordered that the Biographic Register, a listing of diplomatic employes and some from intelligence, be published as a public document.
Danny Thomas has formed a new production company in association with Aaron Spelling to produce shows for the 1967 68 television season.

MADISON, Wis., April 15 (UPI) A research assistant at the University of Wisconsin burned a check made out to the Internal Revenue Service today to protest the use of tax dollars to finance the war in Vietnam.

LAST night's program called "The Big Guy" was an other reason for outlawing boxing. The turgid documentary over the network of the American Broadcasting Company concerned itself with the bout 18 months ago be tween Jim Beattie, who stands 6 feet 9 inches, and Dick Wipperman.
STONY BROOK, L.I., April 15 Dr. Martin Meyerson of the University of California was appointed president of the Buffalo Campus of the State University of New York today.
LOS ANGELES, April 15 (AP) Jim Lefebvre hit a threerun homer in the eighth inning, his fourth homer in three games, and carried the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 4-2 victory tonight over the Chicago Cubs.

The Coca-Cola Company yesterday granted a franchise for a bottling plant in Israel to a New York banker. BONN, April 15--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard appealed tonight to all West German parties to maintain unity and solidarity, "in present circumstances," on the question of reunification.

Five Mississippi Negroes and a white civil rights worker have filed separate damage suits seeking $3.5-million against the U.S. Fidelity and Guaranty Trust Company, an insurance concern that bonds Mississippi law enforcement officers some of whom have been charged with brutality.
DANANG, South Vietnam, April 15 After several days of disorder, a semblance of calm appeared to be returning to Danang today.
The National Association of Securities Dealers released yesterday its 1965 annual report detailing a list of self-regulatory activities initiated during the year.

CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP) Ronald E. Bush, 28 years old, a former engineer of B.F. Goodrich Company, who was accused of trying to sell a half-million dollar trade secret to another company for $42,500, was fined $1,000 today in United States District Court here.
WASHINGTON, April 15 Wholesale prices held steady for the eighth consecutive week in the period ending last Tuesday, the Labor Department reported today.

JERSEY CITY, April 15 Carol Abby of New York University swept through 19 matches without a defeat today at Jersey City State College to take the lead after five rounds of competition in the women's intercollegiate fencing championships.
Mayor Lindsay announced last night that an experimental bus run between Manhattan's East Side and the Long Island Rail Road station at Hunters Point, Queens, would be continued for three more months.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 15 Any interest white South Africans may once have had in the question whether black prisoners have been subjected to electric shock tortures in prisons here has apparently been exhausted by a process that could be called trial by boredom.
The Mafia has broken into the cigarette bootlegging racket as easily as a chain-smoker cracks the cellophane on a fresh pack.
Marvin J. Miller, assistant to the president of the United Steelworkers of America, was named executive director of the Major League Players Association yesterday.

From his desk in the Port Authority's bus terminal on the West Side, Sgt. Vincent Futia watched television yesterday with the special gusto of a man who does not let his children choose the TV programs he sees at home.
Hearing was not believing at a meeting between Puerto Rican leaders and the chairman of the police review board yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay handed to the Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday a plan for the management of the city's fiscal affairs for the next year that he described as "large," "frugal" and "ambitious."

INDIANAPOLIS, April 15 (UPI) A federal district judge sentenced a 17-year-old boy today to four years in a school for delinquents, which he said would provide a "better atmosphere" than the Job Corps center at Camp Atterbury, Ind.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn. April 15 (AP) The California Angels rapped Dave Boswell, the Minnesota starter today for two home runs, a triple and double in the first six innings and went on to a 9-4 victory over the Twins.
BUENOS AIRES, April 15 More businessmen here are starting a countdown on the next devaluation of the Argentine peso.

MESA, Ariz., April 15 (AP)--Mrs. Joel Lenzi O'Connell of Sunnyvale, Calif., successfully defended her one-meter springboard title today in the national Amateur Athletic Union women's indoor diving championships.
The new head of the United States Food and Drug Administration urged the nation's physicians yesterday to rally behind his agency in its task of screening 4,000 drugs now in general use.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 15 Animals have been protected from the aftereffects of severe radiation, it was reported here today, by a new method based on immunization.
WASHINGTON, April 15 Two American soldiers held by the Vietcong for two years have been cleared of charges of aiding the enemy and were released from the Army today, the Pentagon announced tonight.

MANILA, April 15 Adm. U.S. Grant Sharp Jr., commander in chief of United States Forces in the Pacific, said today that civil disturbances in South Vietnam had not interfered with military operations there.
LONDON, April 15 (AP)--The Soviet Union is planning to build the world's largest civil airplane--a double-decked 724-passenger giant--the magazine Flying Review International said today.
SAIGON, Saturday, April 16 The editor of a Vietnameselanguage daily that has vigorously opposed Buddhist agitation was shot and seriously wounded this morning as he left his home for work.

BONN, April 15 The United States, Britain and West Germany opened discussions today on the policy they will follow regarding President de Gaulle's decision to withdraw French forces in West Germany from allied command.
Richard M. Nixon said yesterday that the controversy over whether he would receive an honorary degree from the University of Rochester was "based on a mistaken premise."
Lucky Debonair, the winner of the 1965 Kentucky Derby, will race for the richest purse tomorrow, but Graustark, hopeful of winning the 1966 Derby, will attract more interest.

DETROIT, April 15 (UPI) Dick McAuliffe hit a grandslam homer and Al Kaline added a home run and a double today to lead the fast-starting Detroit Tigers to an 8-3 victory over the Washington Senators. It was the Tigers' fourth straight victory of the season.
Bishop James A. Pike bitterly denounced Christian-Judeo churches in general and the Episcopal Church in particular yesterday for passing judgment on the alcoholic.
SALT LAKE CITY, April 15 (AP) An expert in medical care of the aged said today that polygamy should be made legal after the age of 60.

A three-day conference of the Central Opera Service will end this morning when about l50 participants are taken on a tour of the new Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center by Herman E. Krawitz, an assistant manager of the company.

Genesco, Inc., has not at any time used its employe stockpurchase plan to influence market prices and "a careful study of price trends has confirmed this in our opinion." W. Maxey Jarman, chairman of Genesco, asserted yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, April 15 (UPI) The Los Angeles Lakers, extended to the limit by the St. Louis Hawks, finally broke loose in the closing minutes to record a 130-121 victory tonight and win the National Basketball Association's Western Division championship.
Many Negro students at such liberal institutions as City College and Brooklyn College are still on the outside looking in, a social psychologist reported yesterday.
SANTA FE, N.M., April 15 Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall outlined today "new approaches" to Indian affairs designed to end the grinding poverty on reservations.

Mrs. Henry H. Brewster of Stockton, Calif., and Henry M. Cathles of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheridan Elizabeth Cathles, to Steve Patton Lester, son of Mrs. Thomas C. Leighton of San Francisco and the late Clyde Lester.

Miss Marcia Panesis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Panesis of Miami, Fla., was married here yesterday to George G. Shackleford Jr., son of Mrs. Nora Shackleford of Rochester, and the late Mr. Shackleford.
MADISON, Wis., April 15 (AP) Dr. Julian Mack, a University of Wisconsin physicist who took part in the development of the atomic bomb, died yesterday in a Madison hospital. He was 62 years old.
THE penthouse apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Schroe- der Boulton has been under student siege since March 17.
Stock prices generally strengthened yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, with copper shares again in heavy demand.
THE word came down from Mayor Lindsay's office: "Work around the clock boys, if you have to, but get that budget out on April 15."

LONDON, April 15 A leading London pathologist cast doubt today on the popular but never proved theory that Jack the Ripper, the notorious East End murderer of the late eighteen-eighties, was a doctor or medical student.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 16 Business, banking and education leaders announced this week a campaign to "assure selection" of the Brookhaven National Laboratory as the site for a proposed $375-million atom smasher.
Cornell's varsity tennis team retained possession of the Allison Danzig Cup yesterday by defeating Columbia, 7-2, at Baker Field.
A typical large tanker or dry-cargo bulk carrier will be able to carry close to 2,000 tons more cargo under the International Convention on Load Lines, 1966.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 15 A Negro chauffeur for John D. Rockefeller 3d sought to invoke criminal prosecution under the Federal Civil Rights Law of 1964 today on charges that he has been blackballed from membership in the Tarrytown Volunteer Fire Department.

CAIRO, April 15 The death of President Arif, President Gamal Abdel Nasser's closest political ally in the Arab world, came as a shock to Cairo and left the United Arab Republic uncertain about future relations with Baghdad.
The drive to raise $80,000 from show business to help the New Dramatists Committee continue its five-point program for talented young playwrights got off to a jingling start yester- day.
MEXICO CITY, April 15 President Johnson who came to Mexico yesterday feeling restless and a bit disgrunted, returned exhilarated today to his ranch in Texas.

The Maritime Administration announced yesterday the appointment of Norman C. Nilsen as property and supply officer for the Atlantic Coast District, which extends from Maine to Florida. The appointment was announced by Capt. Thomas A. King, director of the district.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 15 (AP) A mob of 2,000 Indo- nesians of Chinese descent smashed into Communist China's embassy today, routed 30 screaming employes and ransacked the building.

Net income of Holiday Inns of America, Inc., rose 74 per cent to $4,181,450, equal to $1.13 a share, in the nine months ended March 31 from $2,406,453, or 69 cents a share in the corresponding 1965 period, it was announced yesterday. Revenues of the motel chain advanced 40 per cent to $67,622,336 from $48,325,279 a year earlier.

WEEHAWKEN, N.J., April 15 Jacob Levine, former president of the Board of Governors of North Hudson Hospital here, died yesterday in the hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 521 High Ridge Avenue, Cliffside Park.

CORAOPOLIS, Pa., April 15 Mrs. William Kennedy Graham has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Kennedy Graham, to William H. Uffelman Jr., son of Mrs. Uffelman of Wilmington, Del., and the late Mr. Uffelman.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) The Veterans Administration is again being deluged with letters from veterans who have been led to hope they can get an insurance dividend that was paid 15 years ago, officials said today.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 16 (AP) Jack Warner, a rookie, slammed a two-run homer in the seventh inning today as the California Angeles rallied behind Dean Chance and downed the Minnesota Twins, 3-2.

POLAROID LAND'S Polacolor photography made its exhibition debut as an art form last week in the Edward Steichen Photography Center at the Museum of Modern Art. Before the Revolution, while still is her twenties, she charmed a whole generation with the emotional force of her short, epigrammatic poems on love, repentance and religious aspiration.

In this helter-skelter age, who would stop to think broadcasting is that old?
The issuing of convertible preferred stock to effect mergers is gaining popularity in the corporate world. "It's the current vogue," one Wall Streeter remarked last week.

DOVER, Del., April 16 Greatly increased state spending on library services and the establishment of new "resource centers" in Delaware's three counties were recommended here today at a library conference called by Gov. Charles L. Terry Jr.

WASHINGTON, April 16 The President has promised additional proposals to enforce the civil rights which the Constitution guarantees to all citizens, and the Department of Justice is preparing the bill to be submitted to Congress. One of the few empty seats was that of the Foreign Minister.

The fastest-growing of all America's "growth industries" is local government. The number of workers in state, county and municipal agencies has doubled since 1950, and the present total of eight million is expected to pass the 12-million-mark by 1975. One result is budget and tax troubles of the kind that are making Mayor Lindsay a political orphan. Another is that the unionization of public employes has become organized labor's chief concentration point.

To see or not to see Batman on television has become a serious question, according to Mrs. Frances B. Marsh, director of the Norwood Parish School, in Chevy Chase, Md. Mrs. Marsh has sent a letter to the parents of the school's 125 pupils telling them that the children arrive in school with a TV-hangover on the morning after Batman.

AQUIET but crucial debate is under way among scientists about the true nature of the child. For years many parents have thought of their baby as a soft, receptive creature who must be molded into a person. This notion was inspired by John B. Watson, a popular child-raising authority of the 1930's, who held that the newborn was merely a bundle of unorganized reflexes and that all infants were "created equal."

PHILIP RAHV once made the amusing and useful distinction between the "paleface" and the "redskin" in American letters. Due to a dissociation between experience and consciousness, our writers tend to orient themselves around "fatal antipodes" the "redskin," celebrating the world of sensual experience, the lowlife on the frontier, while the "paleface," with patrician disdain, prefers the refinements of an urban aristocratic civilization to the life in the open air: Whitman versus Henry James.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) The Aerospace Industries Association reports manufacturers of light airplanes delivered more than $100-million worth of aircraft in the first three months of 1966, 42 percent more than in the 1965 period.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 16 Warren Dempsey scored three goals and made an assist to lead Army to a 12-7 lacrosse victory over Princeton.
WASHINGTON, April 16--Many thousands of visitors filed past the grave of President Kennedy today as the big Easter tourist week drew to a close.

JACKSON, Miss., April 16 The director of the Mississippi Council on Human Relations said here today that a survey of Negro parents and students in desegregated schools in the state had shown them to be victims of "a conspiracy to violate their civil rights and natural rights."
LOS ANGELES, April 16 Maybe there is something to be said for spring training.
Mrs. Melvin Block of 778 Park Avenue and Deal, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Susan Block, to Gordon Stearns, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Stearns of 80 East End Avenue.

MEXICAN HAT, Utah Most motorists en route through this tiny southeastern Utah hamlet, 375 miles below Salt Lake City, are in an understandable hurry. They have already been exposed to such a lot of remarkable sightseeing.
Any notion that life beneath the sea is a quiet one was loudly dispelled last week by some of the world's leading marine biologists.
Mr. and Mrs. Chester R. Olsen of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maryann Randall Olsen, to Michael John Oslac, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Oslac of Chicago.

Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel J. Freiberg of New York and Shreveport, La., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Hope Freiberg, to State Assemblyman S. William Green. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Green of New York.

NORTH WOODMERE, L.I., April 16 Miss Susan Carol Dresdner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Dresdner of Forest Hills, was married tonight to Ralph S. Behar, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Behar of Woodhaven. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel.

Mrs. Ruth Nelson Quinche, widow of Othon Quinche of Jamaica, Queens, was married yesterday to Francis Dodd McHugh of Douglaston, Queens. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas G. Ryan in St. Anastasia Roman Catholic Church in Douglaston.

DALLAS, April 16 In the Highland Park Presbyterian Church here this evening, Miss F. Ann Cook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey W. Cook of Larchmont, N.Y., became the bride of John Albert Cole, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl E. Cole of Oklahoma City.
The International Automobile Show is leaving New York today, but the exhaust fumes from the hot rods will linger on.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 16 White and Negro parents here are looking anxiously to Albany, where a decision is expected soon on Mount Vernon's novel plan for a "children's academy" to reduce the racial imbalance in the public elementary schools.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 16 (UPI) State Attorney General Harvel Dickerson said today that women blackjack dealers dressed in skimpy blouses would increase the gambling odds for a casino and he will not stand for it.

SAIGON, April 16--United States Air Force fighter-bombers hammered a Vietcong camp 10 miles west of Saigon and destroyed more than 40 trucks on the roads in North Vietnam yesterday, a military spokesman said tonight.
This morning at eleven o'clock a special service in honor of the memory of Anne Sullivan will be held at Washington National Cathedral.
HARTFORD, April 16 Amherst College's varsity crew pulled past the Trinity College boat in the final 500 meters of a 2,000-meter race on the Connecticut River today and won in 5 minutes 24 seconds.

FAIRFIELD, Conn. It is difficult to imagine a more pleasant way for both children and adults to increase their knowledge of nature than by a visit to the Birdcraft Museum and Larsen Sanctuary here in Fairfield. Both are operated by the Connecticut Audubon Society.
A six-room house with an atrium is a feature of the 20th annual Westchester County Home, Garden and Decorating Show this weekend.
The restaurant is dim, the chatter subdued and the cuisine is, well, Yin and Yang.

THE Metropolitan New York Numismatic Con vention, the year's biggest event in the East and one of the biggest annual coin shows in the country, opens to the public next Thursday at 1 P.M. in the Park Sheraton Hotel Seventh Avenue and 56th Street. The convention will run for four days.
Boston's four-week newspaper strike brought an economic loss to the metropolitan area of better than $33-million, according to final estimates of the Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce.

ALBERT CAMUS in moral agony over the use of terror by the Algerian rebels. Milovan Djilas languishing in a Yugoslav jail because of a book no more seditious than Emmett Hughes's memoir on the Eisenhower years. Harold Wilson unable to nationalize the steel industry but an accomplice to a semicolonial war in Vietnam. Such men embody the tragic fate of modern democratic socialism.

CARACAS The United States Government's recent decision to eliminate Federal control over residual petroleum imports may have been considered in Washington a victory for the Venezuelan petroleum industry, but, here, Government and industry alike have adopted a wait-and-see attitude.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 The paradox of dealing with delinquency is that "the more we publicize it, the more we fear it, the more we associate it with evil, the more dramatic and heroic a model it becomes for certain of our youth," a New York psychologist said here today.
WHITE PLAINS, April 16 Miss Elizabeth Lorraine Courtade, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerard Louis Courtade, was married today to Alfred Henry Hoddinott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoddinott.
Dr. and Mrs. Anthony Domonkos have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dita Domonkos, to Eugene W. Altman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Altman of Highland Park, Ill.

THE work of the Lincoln Center Repertory Thea- ter, in its first season under Herbert Blau and Jules Irving, is related to the subject of resident theaters as discussed here recently. (Technically the Lincoln Center company is also a resident theater, but here I use the term in the usual way to mean a theater outside New York.)
Governor Rockefeller is expected to appoint the first Puerto Rican to the State Parole Board next month, a source close to the Governor said last week.

A bitter quarrel between two old rivals about who shall control the National Guard of Cyprus has provoked a crisis within the seven-month-old Stefanopoulos Government in Greece. The episode is likely to affect the chances for fruitful Greek-Turkish negotiation on the Cyprus problem and it has revived all the old questions about the character and intentions of President Makarios.

Dr. Eli Ginzberg, Columbia University professor, in a report on "Life Styles of Educated Women": There is little in our analysis to support the widespread belief that most educated women are trapped in situations which create frustration and disappointment and that it is the rare woman indeed who is able to fulfill her potentiality. The opposite is much closer to the truth.

Park Slope, a middle-class neighborhood in Brooklyn whose worried residents have been watching the slow decay of once-fine old brownstone houses, has been offered hope by agencies that are now conducting a rehabilitation experiment on Harlem's 114th Street.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., April 16 Dr. and Mrs. John Daniel O'Connell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Mason O'Connell, to George Philip Nowak, son of Mr. and Mrs. George John Nowak of North Haven.

VISITORS to Arbor Lodge State Park near Nebraska City, Neb., will see inscribed on a monument to Julius Sterling Morton, United States Secretary of Agriculture from 1893 to 1897 and founder of Arbor Day, these words: "...Other Holidays Repose upon the Past; Arbor Day Proposes for the Future." The inscription, taken from Morton's writings, is a reminder of the days each year when all America, and other countries as well, plant trees.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 16 Miss Barbara Jane Knapp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Warren Knapp, was married here today in St. George's Episcopal Church to Charles Henry Herz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Herz of Bethesda, Md. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Darwin Kirby Jr., the rector. He was assisted by the Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., chaplain of Yale University.
LAS VEGAS, Nev. April 16 Gay Brewer, who finished third in the three-way Masters golf playoff on Monday, remained in the No. 1 spot in the Tournament of Champions today with a 54-hole score of 209.
Customs collections in the Port of New York last month rose to a record of more than $83-million, it was reported last week by Joseph P. Kelly, Collector of Customs.

NEW DELHI, April 16 India will seek a sharp increase in foreign aid during her current five-year plan. If she gets the money. she feels necessary, the Government is prepared to lift controls on many imports and on some other areas of the economy.

WASHINGTON, April 16 Fifty-four weeks after taking over as Republican National Chairman and 29 weeks before the first national election with him in command, Ray C. Bliss is adherring to his lifelong habit of making haste slowly.

OTTAWA, April 16 The first open session scheduled for Monday in the much-publicized Gerda Munsinger inquiry is expected to deal more with lawyers' technical arguments than with alleged scandal and security risks.

The engagement of Miss Linda Maria Halperin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Barnet Halperin of Brooklyn, to James William Matthews, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Willard Matthews of Clarks Green, Pa., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

PAU, France, April 16 (UPI) The two top drivers in the Goodwood, England. Formula Two race last weekend, won the first and second positions today for tomorrow's running of the Pau Formula Two Grand Prix.

BOSTON A historic house on Beacon Hill is now playing twin roles with exquisite charm. AS the Nichols House Museum, it is the only home on The Hill that is open to the public. As headquarters for the Boston Council for International Visitors, it welcomes many world travelers, who, stopping here, can glimpse a bygone era of gracious Boston living.
The condition of Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes remained critical yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, where he was taken Friday after suffering his fourth heart attack in three years.

WASHINGTON, April 16 A physician's syringe may be a far cry from the torture rack of medieval England, but a Los Angeles man will try to convince the Supreme Court next week that the principle is the same.

The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the scene yesterday of the marriage of Miss Katherine Jane Sughrue, daughter of Mrs. John Joseph Sughrue of Forest Hills, Queens, and Kennebunkport, Me., and the late Mr. Sughrue, to Ulises Giberga. He is the son of Mrs. Ulises Giberga of Havana and the late Dr. Giberga.

SAIGON, April 16 No matter which faction comes out on top in South Vietnam's current political conflict between the military regime and Buddhist leaders, it will have to deal with another thorny political problem. This is the "Montagnard problem," one of the most persistent, difficult and critical facing the Vietnamese and their American allies.

ASHFORD, Wash. Much of the newest day-use facility in Mount Rainier National Park, the Paradise Visitor Center, will be available to park explorers this summer. The structure stands near the old Parardise Inn; it can be reached by using either the Nisqually River entrance from the west, or Stevens Canyon Road from the east.
The work week in Cleveland, with business activity continuing its surge, is averaging out at one of the highest levels in 13 years.
CAIRO, April 16 The first deadening heat of summer enveloped Cairo this week and caught the capital of pan-Arab revolution in a drifting and uncertain mood.

THE Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., was established in 1859 and incorporated in 1869, making it the most venerable of the art museums in the nation's capital. Last week the Corcoran, apparently taking a look at itself in context with the severe competition now surrounding it, returned decisively to a restatement of its original purpose. It was founded primarily for the encouragement of American art.

"MORGAN!"? Pluck the exclamation point from the title of the new British comedy. Stretch it to six feet two and crown it with a long, stringy droop of orange hair. Give this pencil-thin apparition a pair of horn-rimmed glasses and quizzical, probing eyes. And that's Warner--David Warner--aged 24 with plenty going on inside.

St. Paul's Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Parish was the scene yesterday of the marriage of Miss. Elizabeth Shelby Elliott, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Shelby Elliott of Richmond, Ky., and New York, to Richard Waters Roberts. He is the son of Ernest W. Roberts of Denver and the late Mrs. Roberts.

MAMMOTH LAKE, Calif. Just west of this Mono County com- munity in eastern California lies a national monument that is spectacular evidence of Nature's frequently implausible architecture. The monument is the Devils Postpile, a cliff of basaltic columns formed by centuries of erosion, volcanic upheaval and glacial movement.

The last performance at the Metropolitan Opera was an occasion for tears from many, sorrow from all. It was a sorrow somewhat alleviated by the knowledge that the Metropolitan is moving into a new, efficient plant at Lincoln Center.
JERSEY CITY, April 16 Miss Maureen Ellin Cusack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael James Cusack, was married here today to Angelo Albert Vigna, son of Angelo Vigna and the late Mrs. Vigna.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 16 The Reformed Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Anne Holliss Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Robinson Young, to Gerald Strasser Hirsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Hirsch of New York.

HANOVER, N.H., April 16 Brown's varsity heavyweight crew opened up a three-quarterlength lead at the mile marker and steadily increased its margin to defeat Dartmouth and win the Atlanta Trophy today.

THIS short book, prepared by a working-group from the American Friends Service Committee, examines the United States' role in Vietnam, and finds it politically disastrous and morally outrageous. The book is tightly written, compelling and usually onesided. It has a breath-taking moral certitude that makes it especially trenchant as criticism. This makes it rather less convincing as an advocate of alternative policies.
It's annual report time again the time of year that drives businessmen and financial printers up the wall.

LONDON, April 16 Here, as in the United States, there is a growing concern over the widespread peddling of narcotics. The British are wondering whether their somewhat permissive laws are adequate to deal with the problem.
In every bull-market period there are always a few stragglers, and the first quarter of 1966 was no exception.

BALTIMORE, April 16 (AP) At least one person was hospitalized tonight and a number of people were shaken up when two cars of the Silver Meteor passenger train, traveling from New York to Miami, derailed and hit an underpass abutmen, a railroad spokesman said.

LOS ANGELES, April 16 (UPI) Claude Osteen, ranked as the Dodgers' third pitcher before the season started, moved to the head of the list tonight when he hurled Los Angeles to a 4-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs for his second straight complete-game triumph.

WASHINGTON, April 16 Senator Jacob K. Javits devoted two days of the Congressional Easter recess last week to taking political soundings in his home state of New York. There were a few problems: He talked to people in the wrong parts of the state and got the wrong answers.
BRITAIN, which several years ago began to intersperse her prim, line-engraved stamps with more colorful ones, as well as with some of rather unusual size, has once again departed from the normal.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 16 Arthur J. Goldberg has indicated that he plans to follow President Johnson's lead in working intensively for closer understanding with Latin-American countries.

WITH spring in the air and hospitality burgeoning in the Midsouth, increasing numbers of open house and garden tours are being offered this month and next. Virginia's 33d annual Historic Garden Week will begin on Friday and continue through April 30. More than 200 private homes will be opened to the public, among them Boxwood, the former home of the World War I advocate of military air power, Gen. William Mitchell.
NEWTON, Mass., March 16 (AP) The Manhattan College track and field team won the Boston College Relays today as the host Eagles and Northeastern finished in a tie for second.

Philadelphia Inquirer: We hope the planned elections can be carried out within the promised time and that for once the electorate will abide by the results. If the disorders resume, if supplies are left unloaded at the docks, if vital Vietnamese guard forces are withdrawn from U.S. installations for local political backing and filling, only Hanoi and Peking can profit and will.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 16 Miss Ellen Lansburgh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Lansburgh, was married here this evening to Howard J. Feinberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Feinberg. Rabbi Joseph R. Narot performed the ceremony at the Deauville Hotel.
J. William Craig, a sugar broker, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 182 Brewster Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 16 For the first time in years Mrs. Halimah Lubis can afford to laugh easily. In a few weeks maybe even in a few days she hopes that her husband, Mochtar, will be coming home.

"For forty years the movies have drummed away on the American character. They have fed it naivete and buncombe in doses never before administered to any people. They have slapped into the American mind more human misinformation in one evening than the Dark Ages could muster in a decade. One basic plot only has appeared daily in their fifteen thousand theaters the triumph of virtue and the overthrow of wickedness." Ben Hecht.

PARIS, April 16 A bestselling book about a Nazi extermination camp in Poland by a young Jewish author here has touched off a controversy on the role of the millions of Jews who went to their deaths in these camps.
Philadelphia is preparing to centralize its garment and wholesale shoe industries, with separate centers for each.
One-story and two-story houses with four bedrooms and two and a half baths are being offered at Rolling Hills, a new community in Huntington, L.I.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 16 Foreign Minister Malik today rebuked a group of Indonesian students who ransacked the Communist Chinese Embassy yesterday.

Mexico, supported by several smaller hemisphere nations, will propose this week a treaty to keep Latin America free of nuclear weapons and calling for the establishment of an international agency to enforce the agreement.

KURASHIKI, Japan -- Just a short distance off the well-traveled Tokyo-Kyoto-Osaka- Kobe circuit is a little-known, thoroughly delightful town that is waiting to be discovered by those looking for Old Japan.

The appointment of Andrew Goodman, president of Bergdorf Goodman, as general chairman of the American Jewish Committee's Appeal for Human Relations was announced last night by Morris B. Abram, president of the committee.

SAIGON, April 16 In the course of bringing down three Saigon Governments in two and a half years, South Vietnam's Buddhist leaders have slowly and carefully built an effective political organization. The key element the men responsible for executing the orders of the senior monks are Buddhist student leaders like Pham Ngoc Thach.
Milton Deutsch, head of the Milton Deutsch Plate Glass Company, 20 East Second Street, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital. His age was 59 and he lived at 750 Grand Concource, the Bronx.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 16 The First Presbyterian Church was the setting here today for the marriage of Miss Mary Gibson Winfield; daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hood Winfield of Riverside, to Benjamin Ashworth Wilson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson of Winston-Salem, N.C. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George Pera, assisted by the Rev. Jack Carter.

MANHASSET, L.I., April 16 Mr. and Mrs. William Eugene Kane have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Ellen Kane, to John Patrick Sullivan Jr. He is the son of Mr. Sullivan of Winnetka, Ill., and the late Mrs. Sullivan.

NO one will deny that Peter Weiss's play, Marat/Sade provides one of the most pow- erful and satisfying evenings in living memory. Long after, he leaves the theater, the spectator carries away with him the aura of the stark asylum in which the play takes place. But the production is so spectacular, so full of visual and technical effects that one wondered how such a vehicle could be transposed to disks.

WILMINGTON, N.C., April 16 (AP) Larry Beck sank a 12-foot putt on the last green today for a par 72 to gain a tie for the lead with Bert Yancey and Tom Weiskopf in the $22,800 Azalea open golf tournament.

The late Somerset Maugham's home on the French Riviera, Villa La Mauresque, is for sale for $1,175,000 and is being offered through the London real estate concern of Knight, Frank Rutley. The world-famous novelist and playwright died last December at the age of 91.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 16 (AP) Walnut Hill Farm's Pillanlelbun led all the way in the $60,600 Pan American Handicap at Gulfstream Park today and finished two lengths in front of Jerry Basta's Cedar Key.
PITTSBURGH, April 16 Miss Carol Louise Scharfe and C. Jon Widing plan to marry on July 2 at the Shadyside Presbyterian Church.
HOLLYWOOD, April 16 (UPI) Lynda Bird Johnson flew here today from Mexico City to join George Hamilton, the actor.

Travelers planning trans-Atlantic jet trips this summer may face delays, bumpier flights, spilled champagne with their filet mignon and some of those old-fashioned refueling stops at Gander and Shannon.

ONE of the fascinating puzzles of the commerce of cinema is the fact that Japanese movies, which flourished in their homeland from the time of World War I, did not dent the market in this country until after World War II.
FARMINGTON, Conn., April 16 Miss Lydia Coolidge, granddaughter of President Calvin Coolidge, will be married in the fall to Jeremy Whitman Sayles.
The curtain has dropped on the one-month drama involving the attempt by Genesco, Inc., to take over control of Julius Garfinckel Co.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 16 A fine-looking Great Dane named Ch. Reggen's Madas-L, of Marydane gained a fourth best-in-show award at the 19th annual event of the Twin Brooks Kennel Club today. The statuesque fawn-colored 135pound dog, owned by Mrs. Mary K. Johnston of Wilton, Conn., was put up by Mrs. L.W. Bonney of Oyster Bay, L.I.
WALTHAM, Mass., April 16 Bentley College has been assured of more than $2-million in its efforts to build a new $13,379,000 campus here, college officials said today.
A present was delivered to Charlie Dressen's hotel room this week a hot water bottle.

OF all the flowers called "poor man's orchid," western iris merit the title most. Their open, flat shape, wide petals, delicate marking and texture are all reminiscent of tropical orchids. However, they are perfectly hardy and create a soft band of pastel color at the front of the hardy border, in a large rock garden or near pine trees.

LYNDONVILLE, N.Y., April 16 Mayor and Mrs. Harry E. Maines Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Bette Maines, to William Clay Shrout 3d, son of Mrs. Sylvia Todd Shrout of Flushing, Queens, New York, and Mr. Shrout Jr. of Mobile, Ala.
Most over-the-counter stocks continued to advance last week in active trading.
The great white liner Michelangelo, battered by giant waves that killed three persons and injured 10 last week, sailed into New York yesterday.
Moscow, April 16 The Soviet Union's Luna 10 space station will remain in orbit around the moon for several years, the country's top scientist said today at a news conference.

NINETY-FOUR years ago this month, the first Arbor Day was proclaimed in the prairie state of Nebraska. The observance has spread through most of the country, with emphasis on conservation and the planting of young trees. Education has been part of the program, too. Many notable tree species are collected in "outdoor museums" or arboretums where they may be observed and studied.

SANDWICHED between the basketball and base- ball seasons, when midwinter exams are out of the way and before the long haul to the finals, comes the college jazz festival season. This is a new "season," a phenomenon of the nineteen-sixties, and it draws on resources that are still going through an adventurous stage of development.

THREE well-known chess players Grand Master Arthur Bisguier of Yonkers, master Ivan Theodorovich of Toronto and master Bernard Zuckerman of New York tied for first place in the recent Greater New York Open, each scoring 5 - . A total of 180 players participated in the six-round, Swiss system event, which was held at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

YONKERS, April 16 Among the disgruntled losers in the crowd of 31,626 after the feature race at Yonkers Raceway tonight was George Sholty. He looked back in anger at Vernon Dancer after the contest, shouting at the rival driver.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 16 Princeton oars flashed in victory over Navy on the Severn today in one of the biggest triumphs on the water for the Orange and Black in recent years.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., April 16 Prof. and Mrs. Arnold Corbin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Sue Corbin, to Kenneth Michael Rifkind, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Rifkind of Forest Hills, Queens.
A Brooklyn civil rights group picketed an American Legion hall in the Manhattan Beach section yesterday, charging that the Legion post had refused to rent its hall to a Negro sorority.

A collaborative architectural effort that turned a cen- tury-old chocolate factory, a San Francisco landmark, into a shopping center where cus- tomers and passersby may also dine on terraces, has won an award from the American Institute of Architecture.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 17 (AP)--Communist China rejected in effect today a United States proposal to invite Communist Chinese scientists and scholars to visit American universities. Peking called the American offer "nothing but a fraud."
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 16 (UPI) A South Vietnamese Air Force pilot has defected to Cambodia, with his helicopter and asked for political asylum, official sources said today.
A total of 1,126 ocean-going vessels arrived in the Port of New York last month, an in- crease of 199 over the number of inbound ships in February and 71 more than arrived in March last year.
Dudley Alan Voorhees Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Ann Christie Voorhees, to James William Anderson Jr.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 14 Former Gov. Elmer L. Andersen is edging toward a comeback this year. He is hinting broadly that he wants his party's endorsement for the governorship, by way of a "draft."

WORCESTER, Mass., April 16 The marriage of Miss Lynne Campbell Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Smith of Worcester and Chatham, to William David Crow took place this afternoon. He is the son of Mrs. William H. Crow of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Mr. Crow.
Neptune developers have opened a 150-house colony called Kensington Park, off Dutch Neck Road about a half-mile west of Route 130, in East Windsor Township, N.J.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 16 President Johnson announced today his intention to nominate John W. Tuthill as United States Ambassador to Brazil.

THIS is quintessentially a novel about Italians, and not only about Italians, but about Neapolitans, who at any rate in the author's eyes are the quintessential Italians. Any one who is not drawn to Italy and its inhabitants had probably better leave this book alone, although a reader who particularly disliked Italians might well enjoy a good many of the scenes.

GROSSE POINTE, Mich., April 16 The marriage of Miss. Catherine Renee Scripps to Brewster Montgomery Loud took place here this afternoon in the Grosse Pointe Memorial Church (Presbyterian). The Rev. Dr. Allan Zaun performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Bertram Atwood, minister of the church. A reception was held at the Grosse Pointe Club.

THE European monopoly on world bridge titles, which has prevailed since 1955, seems about to come to an end. The American team is given an excellent chance of getting the better of the Italians in the forthcoming world championship in St. Vincent, Italy; but even if it does not do so, one can reasonably look for an American victory in the World Pair Olympiad, which follows immediately in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

BONN, April 16 The United States and Britain gave their full support today to Bonn's stand that French forces in West Germany must continue to form part of the common defense after they are withdrawn from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's command July 1.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 16 Cornell's lightweight crews swept five races against Penn today.
VALLEY STREAM, L.I., April 16 Mr. and Mrs. James Rinaldi have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Rinaldi, to David Hearn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell E. Hearn of Tucson, Ariz.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 16 The engagement of Miss Victoria Mell Laird to Lieut. Henry Sweets Ackerman, U.S.A.R., son of Mrs. Douschka Sweets Ackerman of Louisville, Ky., and the late Robert Vanderhoof Ackerman of Columbia, S.C., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Angus McKenzie Laird.
Gateway Park, a 167-unit condominium on DeHaven Drive off Gateway Road in Yonkers, N.Y., will be ready for initial occupancy in June.
