BOWIE, Md., April 16 Briardale Farm's Tosmah, the first mare to race in the $114,600 Campbell Handicap, won the 13th running today at Bowie by a nose. She beat nine male rivals with a tremendous stretch drive. Lucky Debonair, the 3-5 favorite, finished last.

SWEET Charity is a girl who, like Ado Annie, caint say no. True, it's not getting her any- where in the musical hit named for her at the Palace. But, she's sure getting places in the world. Putting it another way, "Sweet Charity," now settled in as a long, longterm tenant at the converted vaudeville mecca, will be following the pattern of other major musical hits on Broadway. It's about to become big business.

The military service academies get public attention largely in the wake of trouble. The United States Military Academy at West Point, as well as its youthful offspring, the Air Force Academy at Colorado Springs, have had bouts with cadet cheating. Now, the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis has admitted that it has been flunking only a fixed "quota" of midshipmen letting others, who normally might be dropped as failures, graduate.
The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced yesterday that it was trying to force Consolidated Edison to reduce the toxic sulphur dioxide emitted by its Manhattan generating plants.

THE small, medieval town of Cuenca, Spain (pop. 20,000) will soon boast Spain's first museum of contemporary Spanish art. And how come? Mazza performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church.

Former City Council President Paul R. Screvane, who spent 22 years in the Department of Sanitation, took a job yesterday as vice president of an industrial cleaning and maintenance company.

One of the busiest places in troubled South Vietnam, last week was a dirt compound housing several low, tin-roofed buildings on the outskirts of Saigon. There, surrounded by barbed wire, Buddhist leaders met in strategy sessions and followers painted slogans on banners and made other preparations for street demonstrations.

NEW HAVEN, April 17-- William P. Hunt, an old China hand who once controlled all the tea in China and at another time took over China's entire merchant fleet, died yesterday after emergency surgery in St. Raphael's Hospital here. He was 60 years old.

LEESBURG, Va., April 17 (AP)--Ben O'Meara, internationally known horse dealer, showman and rider, was killed today when his refurbished World War II fighter plane crashed into a creek near here. He was 30 years old.

The use of college grades to determine which students will be drafted from the campus into military service is vigorously attacked, by Norman Cousins, editor of The Saturday Review, in the forthcoming, issue of the magazine.

Maria Carreras, Italian pianist, who performed under the baton of the late Arturo Toscanini here and abroad, died Friday of a heart ailment in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 89 years old and lived at 169 East 78th Street.

VALDIVIA, Chile, April 17 (UPI)--Hal Sergent of Morehead State sank three consecutive lay-ups midway in the second half to lead the United States to a 68-60 victory over Bulgaria tonight in the world amateur basketball championship.
Joel Thome and Alvin Brehm were the composers represented Saturday night at the Composers' Forum. The final program in this season's series was presented at the Donnell Library.

The container shipping division of American Export Isbrandtsen Lines has selected Stapleton, S.I., as the East Coast terminal site for its North Atlantic containership operation that is scheduled to get under way by mid-summer.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (AP)--Roger Dearborn Lapham, Mayor of San Francisco during World War II and a retired shipping executive, died last night after a fall from a staircase in his home. He was 82 years old.

HADDAM, Conn., April 17-- The body of Peter Guertin Tuttle, 37-year-old Yale University researcher who helped to assemble the White House library during President Kennedy's administration, was found this afternoon in the Connecticut River.

BURBANK, Calif., April 17 (UPI)--Cicero Murphy of Brooklyn, the defending champion, pinned a 150-89 defeat on Willie Mosconi of Haddon Heights, N.J., today in the world pocket billiards invitation tournament. The loss was the first in the tournament for Mosconi, who has been world champion 15 times.
ROME, April 17 (AP)--An l8th-century Capuchin monk was beatified today in St. Peter's Basilica.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 17-- Mr. and Mrs. William E. Kovacovich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Lena Kovacovich, to Earl Wylie Potter, son of Mr, and Mrs. Henry C. Potter of New York and Southampton, L.I.
RAVENNA, Ohio, April 17 (UPI)--Two deputy sheriffs followed a "bright circular" unidentified flying object early today from Atwater, Ohio to Freedom, Pa., a distance of 85 miles.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17 (AP)--The Center for International Studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology receives funds from the Central Intelligence Agency, but not for the type of work Michigan State University has done in Vietnam, the center's director said today.
CHICAGO, April 17 (AP)-- The Detroit Red Wings gained a three-goal lead today, then fought off a Chicago comeback before scoring a 5-3 victory in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

TOKYO, April 17 (AP)-- A photograph sent by the United States weather satellite Essa II is providing an important clue in the investigation of the crash of a British Overseas Airways Corporation jetliner on Mount Fuji, officials disclosed today.

Irving Klein, who retired in 1954 as president of the United Metal Box Company, formerly of Brooklyn, died Saturday of a heart attack in his home at 125-10 Queens Boulevard, Kew Gardens, Queens. He was 74 years old.

A four-story, 20,000-square- foot office building has been built in Rutherford, N.J., giving the Bergen County community its first modern commercial facility and one that is unusual for an older suburb such as Rutherford.

SAIGON, Monday, April 18-- United States Air Force planes attacked two missile sites under 20 miles from Hanoi in two raids today, a United States military spokesman said. The raids were the closest to the North Vietnamese capital so far.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he hoped to have a report on the reorganization of the city's welfare and antipoverty agencies within two months.

Last month in Vietnam, Warrant Officer Larry Bemme, a copilot in a helicopter attacking three automatic-weapons positions of the Vietcong, received a direct hit from a 50-caliber machine gun bullet. The bullet came through the nose bubble and hit him in the lower right side at the belt line.
MESSINA, Sicily, April 17 (UPI)--Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., beat Ion Tiriac of Rumania, 6-4, 6-8, 6-2, 6-4, today in the singles final of an international tennis tournament.
SKILLMAN, N.J., April 17-- The Association of the New Jersey Neuro-Psychiatric Institute is sponsoring the 12th "April Annual," to be held on the grounds of the institute here on April 26.
A program to aid the expansion of United States exports by attracting more foreign commercial buyers to trade shows in New York is getting under way with wide support of the local business community.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)--Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, said today it was a "shocking thing" that "we have done so little and have been so slow to react to the necessity of doing something about this carnage and killing" on the highways.
HAVANA, April 17 (AP)-- Premier Fidel Castro showed his military power today, consisting largely of Soviet warplanes and tanks and other Communist-made equipment.
LOS ANGELES, April 17 (UPI)--Sandy Koufax hurled six innings and was the winning pitcher as the Los Angeles Dodgers posted a 5-0 victory today over the Chicago Cubs.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17-- Maj. Gen. Abdel Rahman Arif, who was elected President of Iraq last night, told a group of army officers today that he would adhere to the policies of his brother and predecessor, Col. Abdel Salam Arif.

A speech hailing progress on civil rights won ringing applause and a standing ovation yesterday from 2,500 policemen and detectives at a communion breakfast of the Police Department Holy Name Society of Brooklyn and Queens in the St. George Hotel.

George A. Schlining of Bedford Village, N.Y., an art directof and commercial artist, died of a heart ailment Saturday in a New York Hospital. He was 63 years old.

TORONTO, April 17--The National Ballet of Canada completed today the first week of its two-week 15th anniversary season at the O'Keefe Center. Apart from a new staging of Antony Tudor's "Lilac Garden," scheduled for Tuesday, the season's varied repertory has now all been displayed.

LANGHORNE, Pa., April 17 (AP)--Norm Nelson of Racine, Wis., won the United States Auto Club's 150-mile national championship classic today and set a record on the mile-long track at Langhorne Speedway.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 17 --Arnold Palmer erased a fivestroke deficit today, went ahead and then ended in a tie with Gay Brewer in the Tournament of Champions golf competition. Palmer's fourth round of 69 and a 74 by Brewer gave them 72hole totals of 283.
Dr. Joachim Prinz, the president of the American Jewish Congress for the last eight years, announced last night that he would not be a candidate for re-election.

A woman who was seized by a holdup man and robbed in an elevator on the West Side yesterday fought him off and ran down eight flights of stairs pursued by her attacker. Her assailant seized her again in the lobby.
American Airlines announced over the weekend the reassignment of William T. Seawell to operations vice president, from vice president in charge of flight.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- Antipoverty officials are seeking ways to halt or reverse a rapidly accelerating trend toward an all-Negro Job Corps.

Income tax returns, due last Friday, took a bigger bite than many persons expected. For a lot of families, this is a good time to trim the budget. sonal loans at tax time will show up in banking figures this week.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- The United States has decided to reply favorably, though cautiously, to feelers from Indonesia's new leaders for emergency food assistance.

VOLTA REDONDA, Brazil, April 17--President Humberto Castelo Branco has urged Brazil's pioneering state steel company to seek private, as well as governmental, financing for its $216-million expansion program.

Oginga Odinga was right in at least one of his statements at the press conference in which he announced he was quitting the Government of Kenya: The former Vice President had, indeed, become "an unwanted person"; there was "pressure and desire" that he get out.
DUNEDIN, New Zealand, April 17 (Reuters)--Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain arrived here by yacht today and attended church. She began an 18-day tour of New Zealand yesterday.

Two scientists at General Telephone and Electronics Laboratories, Inc., at Bayside, Queens, have received a patent for a color television picture tube that uses a new combination of phos- phors on its picture screen.
HOLLYWOOD, April 17 (AP)--George Peppard and Elizabeth Ashley were married today at the Bel Air Hotel by Dr. Robert Shaffer of the Church of Divine Truth in Los Angeles.

The Italian superliner Michelangelo computed successfully yesterday with Central Park, the Bronx Zoo and the sight-seeing boats for New Yorkers trying to solve the problem of what to do in town on a nice spring Sunday.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- Fresh evidence pointing to an environment on the planet Venus suitable to sustaining life has been published by two Johns Hopkins University astrophysicists in the April issue of The Astrophysical Journal.

The Singer Company announced over the weekend that it would acquire for $17.3-million in cash a note of the Packard-Bell Electronics Corporation, held by Marathon Securities Corporation.

The Rev. Charles J. Deane, secretary general and a vice president of Fordham University, died Saturday in the University Infirmary after a short illness. He was 85 years old April 2.

DRESDEN, Germany, April 5--A great red banner strung along a drab street in this East German city proclaims in white letters, "The German Democratic Republic--20 Years of Building Socialism."

PRESUMABLY we can now look forward to an annual recital by Vladimir Horowitz in Carnegie Hall. The emivent pianist played there yesterday afternoon, almost a year after the famous appearance last May in which he returned to the concert stage after l2 years.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP)-- John Buzhardt pitched a threehitter as the Chicago White Sox handed Kansas City its fifth defeat without a victory, 5-0, today. The second game of the scheduled doubler-header was postponed by rain.

LAFAYETTE HILLS, Pa., April 17--The engagement of Miss Rebecca Jane Serviss, daughter of Mrs. Eikenberry Serviss of Lafayette Hills and O. Franklin Serviss of Atlanta, to Peter Gottlieb of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Gottlieb of Bala Cynwyd, has been announced by the future bride's parents.
POZNAN, Poland, April 17 --The two most powerful men in Poland--Wladyslaw Gomulka and Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski--staged imposing shows of strength today in the same town at the same time.

NINE table settings for brides go on display to- day at Tiffany's. Each setting is designed, around a different menu prepared by Gertrude Crum, who runs a seasonal menu-planning service called Menus by Mail.

NORTH WOODMERE, L.I., April 17--Miss Brenda Carole Spilton, daughter of Mrs. Sol Spilton of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Spilton, was married this evening to Dr. Robert Munies, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Munies, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Munies of the Bronx.

Mayor Lindsay suggested yesterday that Governor Rockefel- ler's silence was hurting the chances for his $520-million tax proposal. The Mayor renewed his appeal for a "clear statement of support" from his fellow Republican.

VADUZ, Liechtenstein, April 17 (Reuters)--Crown Prince Hans Adam of Liechtenstein became engaged to marry Countess Maria von Kinsky in church ceremonies here today.

Cardinal Spellman, who will be 77 years old on May 4, said yesterday he felt "a bit worn out" but promised to "keep going as long as I can." He will celebrate his fiftieth anniversary as a priest on May 14.

DETROIT, April 17--In St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church here today, Miss Cynthia Mary Karay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmanuel N. Nicholas Harbatis, who was assisted by the Rev. George Dovas.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 17-- Harry A. Livermore, a financial specialist and retired assistant vice president of the American Telephone Telegraph Company, died today at his home at 66 New England Avenue here. He was 84 years old.

Among the many extraordinary musical artists who made this past weekend a whirl of first-class concert activity, Shirley Verrett ranks as one of the finest. She gave her third New York recital at Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon. It was not only the best she has sung so far but an impressive achievement by anybody's vocalrecital standards anywhere.

Before the end of this month New York State will begin the selection of delegates to its ninth Constitutional Convention, which will convene in Albany a year from now. Under the amended political timetable made necessary by the delay on reapportionment, April 30 is the first day for circulating designating petitions for candidates. It is not too soon, therefore, to urge both major parties to canvass their ranks for their ablest political thinkers.

The municipal bond market faces the largest volume of new issues this week since tax-exempt yields reached their peak early in March.

The New York Mets scored two runs in the eighth inning and one in the ninth yesterday to defeat the Atlanta Braves, 5-4, and scale mathematical heights that no other Met team in history had ever reached.
HOUSTON, April 17 (UPI) --Marty Mulligan won the final of the River Oaks invitation tennis tournament today when Nicola Pilic, leading in the fifth set, had to catch a plane.
For signs of spring most New Yorkers depend on other New Yorkers--spring fashions, as indoor flower show, the baseball season or ice cream carts.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 --A Congressional investigation of the role of American universities in carrying out the nation's foreign policies was urged today by the editors of Ramparts magazine.
LONDON, April 17--The Washington Cathedral Choir sang in Westminster Abbey today at a service opening a three-month festival of American arts and humanities.

Van Cliburn played his first New York recital since 1963 Saturday night at Hunter College. In that time many concertos have gone under the bridge. Mr. Cliburn has coveted the conductor's baton and has conducted several orchestras. But any doubts over whether success would spoil this tall Texas-sized talent can be put to rest.

The Late Late Concerts continued their agreeable way at Philharmonic Hall over the weekend. A large crowd arrived at 11:30 P.M. Saturday to hear Handel's Concerto for Two Horns and Two Oboes (Op. 24).

WASHINGTON, April 17-- The slow process of negotiating improvement in the international monetary system resumes here this week as top officials of the ten leading financial nations begin the process or drafting a report to their finance ministers.
VINELAND, N.J., April 17-- Oscar Koveleski of Scranton, Pa., drove a Cooper Chevrolet to first place today in the Delaware Cup race.

When the Medicare bill was passed last year its widely publicized provisions for medical care to the aged were coupled with an almost unnoticed companion program that may in the end have an even greater effect on the nation's health. This program, known as Title XIX of the Social Security Act, authorizes Federal payments to the states to cover medical assistance to families with too little money to pay their own medical bills.

KINGS POINT, L.I., April 17--Massachusetts Institute of Technology retained the Owens Trophy in the Old Guard intercollegiate sailing regatta on Long Island Sound today, defending a lead built up in yesterday's opening program.

The results of an 11-year inquiry into the physiology of sex were disclosed today with the publication of "Human Sexual Response." The inquiry involved the direct observation of 382 women and 312 men as they engaged in coitus and masturbation.
Calvin Murphy, who averaged 40.3 points for his Norwalk, Conn., team, led the list of 40 players named to Scholastic Magazine's 1966 all-star basketball squad yesterday.

BOSTON, April 17--It looked as if it would be so easy for the Boston Celtics today. They got the first 10 points and they built 18-point leads twice in the first game of the National Basketball Association championship playoff with the Los Angeles Lakers.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., April 17--Shaul Ladany, an Israeli graduate student at Columbia University, broke the oldest United States track record today in winning a 50-mile walk. He covered the 200 laps of Point Pleasant High School's quarter-mile track in 8 hours 35 minutes 35 seconds.
MOSCOW, April 17 (AP)-- Col. Rudolph I. Abel gave the Soviet people tonight what was perhaps their first radio lecture from a proved expert in spying.

MILLBROOK, N.Y., April 17 --Dr. Timothy F. Leary, the psychologist who was dismissed from the Harvard University faculty after experimenting with the drug LSD, was arrested on a narcotics charge in a raid on his rented mansion here early today.
PITTSBURGH, April 17 (AP) --Bill Mazeroski hit a sacrifice fly with the bases loaded in the ninth inning today to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 6-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (AP)--Bob Bolin singled in the tie-breaking run in the seventh inning as the San Francisco Giants whipped the Houston Astros, 3-1, today for their fifth victory in six games.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 17--Ten thousand Irish republicans paraded in Belfast today to commemorate the 1916 Easter uprising in Dublin, and 4,000 Ulster Protestants demonstrated against it.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April --17--Indonesia is in the process of reorganizing her entire Foreign Miniistry to rid it of Communist influence, informed sources said here today.
A man who contends he was made a female by a recent operation asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to order a change in the sex listing on his birth certificate.

The spreading movement among nurses in city hospitals to resign, effective May 23, creates a new crisis in municipal labor relations. The city hospitals are desperately short of nurses now; any large-scale exodus will create a drastic health emergency, even without the new burdens that will be thrust upon all hospitals when Medicare begins operating July 1.
HOUSTON, April 18 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers shelled Robin Roberts with a barrage of singles tonight and defeated the Houston Astros, 6-3.

LONDON, April 18 The British trade gap, the excess of her imports over exports, widened last month, intensifying the pressure on the Chancellor of the Exchequer, James Callaghan, for a tough May budget.

ALBANY, April 18--Legislative leaders have agreed to soften the controversial separation provision of their divorce-reform bill that would have required a separated couple to wait five years before obtaining a divorce. It now appears that the time may be reduced to two or three years.
Mayor Lindsay defended his program for neighborhood city halls yesterday and said he would seek to retain them even if he was forced to cut his expense budget "to the marrow."
"Disease" that results from the treatment of other ailments is on the rise, a panel of medical experts noted yesterday.
CAIRO, April 18 (Reuters)-- Iraq will grant autonomy to the Kurds, President Abdel Rahman Arif said in an interview reported from Baghdad today by the Middle East News Agency.

AMHERST, Mass., April 18 Charles R. Longsworth has been appointed vice president of Hampshire College, a co-educational school being formed here with the support of neighboring Amherst, Mount Holyoke and Smith Colleges and the University of Massachusetts.

OTTAWA, April 18 Most of the hearings in Canada's sex and security case will be held behind closed doors in the interest of national security, Justice Wishart F. Spence said today at the first open session of the inquiry.
TUCSON, Ariz., April 18 (AP) The United States Supreme Court ruling today that struck down Arizona's loyalty oath puts an end to years of sacrifice for a Tucson schoolteaching couple.

The Last of the Middle West," by J.B. Humphreys, will be issued by Doubleday on May 6. The author, director of writing programs at Columbia University, recently traveled with his wife on several automobile journeys through the Middle West. These were trips through the past of the region and of the travelers, for Mr. Humphreys was born in Michigan and his wife in Iowa.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The United States Supreme Court ordered today the dismissal of the appeals made by two minority stockholders of the Allegheny Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Senator Walter F. Mondale said today vehicle inspection in the District of Columbia and the state of New Jersey indicates many new cars are sold to customers in unsafe condition.

BURBANK, Calif., April 18 (AP) Willie Mosconi of Hadden Heights, N.J., started with a run of 71 and went on to defeat Jack Breit of Houston, 150113, yesterday in the 1966 Billiard Congress of America invitation championships.
DETROIT, April 18 The Ford Motor Company said today it was recalling about 30,000 of its 1966 models because of a production defect that could cause brake failure.
TRENTON, April 18 A bipartisan bill for a 3 per cent state sales tax was introduced in the Assembly tonight after Democratic and Republican leaders offered wary assurances of its passage next week.

Traders have been arguing for months about $3-a-bushel soybeans. Would this year bring that price level? The bulls have insisted "yes;" the bears have said "no." Both have watched the same statistics record supplies, record demand, with only a small carryover.
Dr. Prosser Gifford, assistant professor of history and director of the five-year bachelor's program at Yale, today was named dean of the faculty at Amherst College.
RED AUERBACH interrupted a conversation with a visiting reporter as Bill Russell ambled past in the Boston Celtic dressing room the winter before last.

Mr. and Mrs. William H. Kane of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Ruth Kane, to Rabbi Abraham J. Bayer, son of Cantor and Mrs. Max Bayer of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for next month.
WASHINGTON, April 18 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
CHICAGO, April 18 A Federal appeals court has ruled that an automobile manufacturer is not under a duty to make cars accident-proof or fool-proof.

Marshall Snyder, who recently retired as counsel for the Greater New York Savings Bank of Brooklyn, died Sunday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 78 years old and lived at 440 East 57th Street.

WASHINGTON, April 18 Senator J.W. Fulbright said today he would oppose the Administration's $3.4-billion foreign-aid request unless the program was put under "im- personal" direction of international agencies.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 18 (AP) Striking members of the International Union of Electrical Workers picketed all five gates to this space center today and about 500 construction workers refused to cross the lines.
Two former fashion models have pooled their talents to develop new careers.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor announced the formation yesterday of a Foreign Trade Advisory Committee.

Directors of the Paramount Pictures Corporation elected two more executives of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., to the Paramount board yesterday and voted to abandon an attempt to scrap cumulative voting.

Miss Adrienne Gray and Raymond Spencer Hines Jr. plan to marry in June. Their engagement has been announced by Mrs. Ann Gray of New York and Stewart S. Gray of Kansas City, Mo., parents of the brideto-be, whose fiance is the son of Mr. Hines of Rocky Mount, N.C,. and the late Mrs. Hines.
If the doctor is busy, just have a seat and let the chair examine your pulse, breathing, heartbeat and emotional responses. It's simple, painless, accurate and it takes only a few seconds.
"ALBANY, April 18 Democratic and Republican legislators proposed separate bills today to control the distribution of LSD and other hallucinogenic drugs.

ALBANY, April 18 The Assembly voted today to forgive the 18 New York City ferryboat officers who were dismissed last June 8 for walking off their jobs in defiance of the ban against strikes by public employes.

William Chodorcoff, the executive vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, collapsed and died of a heart attack in New Orleans after he had finished addressing delegates to Prudential's Canadian National Business Conference in the Jung Hotel yesterday. He was 56 years old and lived at 89 Westview, Short Hills, N.J.

BOSTON, April 18 Sometime between 2:10 and 2:20 P.M. tomorrow, the 70th annual Boston Marathon is almost sure to produce a winner. Sometime between 2:45 and 3:15 P.M., 58year-old John A. Kelley is almost sure to cross the finish line to cheers the winner never heard.

WASHINGTON, April 18 Senator Frank Church has declined a State Department offer to provide a high-ranking officer as escort and adviser on his trip to sound out the views of European leaders on problems of the Atlantic community.

LUSAKA, Zambia, April 18 A strike by drivers halted production today at Mchanga, the world's biggest open copper pit. The walkout came only a week after the end of a twoweek nationwide strike that halted Zambia's copper production.
WASHINGTON, April 18 The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional today Arizona's loyalty oath for state employes.
WASHINGTON, April 18 Press Conference:
The closed-circuit television system of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn beamed its first programs yesterday to 240 parochial schools, in Brooklyn and Queens.

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer reserved decision yesterday on a motion by the three men who stole 24 gems from the American Museum of Natural History in 1964 to suspend sentence on the third year of their three-year jail terms.
MEXICO CITY, April 18 (AP) United States track stars competed for the first time in Mexico City's thin air yesterday with Ralph Boston and John Pennel performing well.

WASHINGTON, April 18 Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana proposed today that Japan or Burma take the lead in bringing about a "direct confrontation across a peace table" of the United States, China, North Vietnam and "essential" elements from South Vietnam.

Residents of the Cooper Square neighborhood on the Lower East Side picketed a housing rehabilitation office yesterday to protest what they described as a plan to bulldoze and replace with middle-income housing 1,000 old buildings in the area. They demanded that the city rehabilitate the existing buildings in stages so that residents would not have to move away.
BONN, April 18 Fourteen former Nazi policemen, charged with complicity in the wartime murder of at least 80,000 Polish Jews and members of the Polish intelligentsia, went on trial at Munster today.
An analysis of air cargoes being exported from the United States shows that based on dollar value, the principal Component is machinery of all kinds.
Benton Bowles, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Bern Kanner as a senior vice president and director of media management, the agency's top television programing and media position.

Roy Innis, chairman of the Harlem chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality, was cleared yesterday in Criminal Court of charges that he unlawfully possessed two hypodermic syringes and 44 pills last month while with a group picketing the West 135th Street police station.

The Detroit Edison Company announced yesterday the election of James Boyd as a director. Walker L. Cisler, chairman, also reported that net income of the company in the 12 months ended March 31 rose to $58,006,868, or $2.01 a share, from $54,453,346, or $1.89 a share, a year earlier.
Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., announced yesterday that it was offering the holders of its common stock rights to subscribe for 159,669 shares of $1.52 cumulative preference stock.
The Crucible Steel Company of America, whose management is fighting a proxy contest with dissidents, reported yesterday an increase in firstquarter net income despite a decline in sales.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 18 (AP) Secretary of State Dean Rusk's hope for an eventual improvement in relations with Communist China has aroused criticism from Nationalist Chinese officials and newspapers.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) The Daughters of the American Revolution was praised tonight by President Johnson for "three-quarters of a century of dedication to the great American past. "

BOSTON, April 18 Bill Russell became the first Negro to direct a major professional sports team today when he was named to succeed Arnold (Red) Auerbach as coach of the Boston Celtics, eight-time champions of the National Basketball Association.
A neighborhood art show of a kind that few neighborhoods can boast opens today at the Goddard-Riverside Community Center, 647 Columbus Avenue.

Passage of legislation pending in Albany to extend the State Labor Relations Act to cover employes of charitable, educational and religious groups was urged yesterday by City Council President Frank D. O'Connor.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 18 Arnold Palmer played through a cold, 50-mile an hour gale today to win the playoff of the Tournament of Champions golf competition by four strokes. Despite the unfavorable conditions, Palmer scored a threeunder-par 69 against Gay Brewer, with whom he tied at 283 yesterday following the regulation 72 holes.

CATANIA, Sicily, April 18 (AP) Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., completed a sweep today when he teamed with Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., for the men's doubles title in the Catania tennis tournament.

The members of Congress, now sluggishly returning to work after the Easter recess, have approximately eleven weeks before the July Fourth holiday begins the usual summer scramble to adjourn. These are the critical weeks for Congress. If the members do not achieve a positive record in the period just ahead, they are unlikely to do so later when election-year pressures intensify and tempers fray.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18 In Congress Hall, where the Bill of Rights was proclaimed in 1791, American Jewish leaders adopted today a six-point "declaratian of rights for Russian Jewry."

An artists and writers committee, led by Allen Ginsberg, the poet, charged yesterday that "petty officials" in the Lindsay administration were conducting a campaign of harassment to drive avant garde artistic endeavors out of the city.
Using an atom-smasher, Midwestern physicists have gener- ated a short-lived "particle" of matter heavier than any observed to date.
The stock market turned downward yesterday as profit takers moved in on same of last week's big gainers.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 18 A major Baghdad newspaper urged President Abdel Rahman Arif today to "complete steps for the fulfillment of union between Iraq and the United Arab Republic" and urged nationalist elements in the country to rally behind the new leader.

WASHINGTON, April 18 A navigator official suggested today that the solution to the current dispute over the safety of narrower trans-Atlantic air corridors was to segregate airlines with poor records of navigating accuracy.
The Cambodian Government has denied a report from South Vietnam that North Vietnamese soldiers retreated into Cambodia after a battle near Chuprong on March 30.

Leaders of the New York City Central Labor Council pledged yesterday to provide pickets and financial support for striking teachers at St. John's University until 21 dismissed faculty members were reinstated.

VIENNA, April 18 Chancellor Josef Klaus decided tonight to form a one-party, conservative Government. His action brought to a close the era of coalition with the Socialists, which had lasted 21 years.

Norman, Craig Kummel, Inc., is losing its top creative executive. Richard Bowman, senior vice president in charge of creative operations, chairman of the executive committee and a director of the agency, has submitted his resignation, to be effective at the convenience of Norman, Craig Kummel.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The Supreme Court cleared the way today for trial of a Chicago police captain's $350,000 libel suit against Time, Inc.
WASHINGTON, April 18 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal Government may punish persons who travel to prohibited Communist countries without the State Department's permission.
WASHINGTON, April 18 The United States announced today that it had agreed to furnish Indonesia with a fiveyear credit to purchase 50,000 tons of rice.

NEWARK, April 18 Commuters who use bus facilities of the Public Service Coordinated Transport System can expect to pay higher fares soon. The system operates between points in New Jersey and New York City.

Mrs. Elsie May Gross of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Albert P. Gross of 7 East 86th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy May Gross of Los Angeles, to Barrie Wayne Blase of Urbana, Ill. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Blase of Maywood, Ill.

In the first case ever prosecuted by the Government, Bert Rose, a Long Island musician, was convicted yesterday in Federal Court on 60 counts of criminally infringing the copyrights of popular songs for profit.

Acting City Personnel Director Solomon Hoberman said yesterday that he had asked the Corporation Counsel for a ruling on the legality of Mayor Lindsay's appointment of a 31year-old Israeli as a deputy city administrator.
Alexander's Department Stores has started construction of a three-floor, 165,000 square-foot addition to its Rego Park store in Queens.
JACKSON, Miss., April 18 A special task force set up in February by the Administration to supply inreased economic assistance to Mississippi has found the state a paradox.

MADISON, N.J., April 18 The Rev. George Weston Briggs, emeritus professor of the History of Religion at Drew University's Theological School, died this morning at Morristown Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 92 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- Following is the text of a statement read in the Senate today by Mike Mansfield, the majority leader, calling for a Vietnam peace conference:

THE enduring poetry of World War I, the work of Owen and Sassoon, of Graves and Rosenberg, finds its prose equiva- lent in Guy Chapman's "A Passionate Prodigality" his autobiographical account of the fighting in France from 1915 to 1918. It is not only a singularly concrete picture of the war, but also one that captures the mixture of exaltation and despair, of comrade-...

GREENWICH, Conn., April 18 Mr. and Mrs. David Chrystal Thomas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Chrystal Thomas, to John Francis Schivell. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Schivell of Twinsburg, Ohio.
Senator J.W. Fulbright believes the Vietnam struggle would have been settled long ago if the United States had kept out of it.
MOSCOW April 18 (Reuters) Nikita Khrushchev lit a bonfire last night to celebrate his 72d birthday but the blaze was extinguished by rain after only a few minutes, Soviet sources said today.

IF you're Leopold Stokowski and you've just reached the age of 84, you celebrate your birthday by making music. That is what the distinguished conductor did last night in Carnegie Hall, leading his American Symphony Orches- tra in its next-to-the-last program of the season.
WHITE PLAINS, April 18 A Westchester County law reapportioning the Board of Supervisors for the first time since 1703 was adopted by the board. today.

The Frank G. Shattuck Company said yesterday that the earnings of its W.F. Schrafft Sons subsidiary had been overstated by a total of "approximately" $600,000 in 1964 and 1965 because of the "collusive fabrication of fictitious invoices and other accounting records."
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 18 Joaquin Balaguer will run for President on the Reformist party ticket on June 1.

The Supreme Court agreed today to rule whether the Interstate Commerce Commission had authority to require railroads to haul truck trailers tendered by motor carriers for piggybacking on the same terms under which the rails transport trailers tendered by shippers.
HOLLYWOOD, April 18 "The Sound of Music" won an Academy Award tonight as the best picture of 1965. Julie Christie and Lee Marvin won the top acting awards.

Roberto Lebron, the president of the Puerto Rican Bar Association of New York, charged yesterday that the police did more to please Negroes than Puerto Ricans because "the wheel that squeaks the loudest gets the most grease."
THE HAGUE, April 18 Prince Karl von Hessen married Countess Yvonne Margit Valier Szapary von Muraszombat in a Protestant church in The Hague today.

CALDWELL, N.J., April 18 Sister M. Aloysius, former professor of philosophy at Seton Hall University and at Caldwell College for Women, died Saturday at St. Catherine's Convent infirmary here. She was 88 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The Defense Department today made public the names of 20 United States military personnel who have died in Vietnam. Among them were the following men from the New York area:

The junior committee of the South Brooklyn Neighborhood Houses has arranged its 12th annual art show in the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims at 75 Hicks Street for this weekend, starting Friday, and next weekend, starting April 29.

A stubborn fire in the library stack tower of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America yesterday caused heavy damage to a collection of 200,000 volumes dealing with the history, theology and philosophy of the Hebraic and Judaic cultures. 12 stacks of books in the library, two were burned and 10 more were damaged by water, However, spokesmen...
One child was killed and three were critically injured in a fire that broke out in a Brooklyn apartment. The four children had been left alone while their mother went to buy groceries.
A Federal court jury of 12 men, eight of whom are members of unions, yesterday convicted a union official of charges of violating the TaftHartley Act.

The 1965-66 Young Artists Series ended last night with a program played at Carnegie Recital Hall by Ko Iwasaki, a 22year-old Japanese cellist who has studied with Leonard Rose at the Juilliard School. The assisting pianist was Mr. Iwasaki's sister, Shuku, who has studied with Jacob Lateiner at Hartt College and is now working with Irwin Freundlich at Juilliard.
WASHINGTON, April 18 Several thousand striking soft coal miners returned to work today but about 35,000 others remained off the job as efforts resumed to end the eight-day walkout.

The St. Lawrence Seaway Corporation will open public hearings in Chicago on June 1 on the controversial proposal of an increase of about 10 per cent in Seaway tolls, it was announced yesterday by Joseph H. McCann, administrator.

HARTFORD, April 18 E. Clayton Gengras, a prominent 57-year-old businessman from West Hartford, received the endorsement of the Connecticut Republican State Chairman, A. Searle Pinney, today, as the party's candidate for Governor. The selection of Mr. Gengras by Mr. Pinney, a powerful figure in the state party, will most likely bring him the support...
Andre Watts, pianist, will open the second season of the "Great Performers at Philharmonic Hall" series on Oct. 26.

CHESTER, England, April 18 The Pennine Moors murder trial, a notorious case allegedly involving the torture and molestation of children, will open here tomorrow with the Attorney General serving as crown prosecutor.
WHITE PLAINS, April 18 Governor Rockefeller was unanimously endorsed for renomination tonight by the executive committee of the Westchester Republican County Committee.
LOS ANGELES, April 18 (AP) Lenny Bruce, the comedian, was given a suspended one-year jail term, fined $250 and put on two years' probation today for a 1963 conviction of possession of heroin.

KANSAS CITY, April 18 The professional people who are most concerned with problems of marriage and family life met here today. Some of them discussed the book "Human Sexual Response," and almost all of them liked it.
R.C.A. Communications, Inc., announced yesterday a new international service for electronic switching or airline operations and reservation messages.
DAKAR, Senegal, April 18 A gentle cold-war wind has blown through Dakar's first World Festival of the Negro Arts, but it has permeated the atmosphere with more whimsy than chill.
ROME, April 18 A majority of the nation's 80,000 physicians went on a 24-hour strke today against medical insurance organizations to support demands for new contracts with higher fees.
Zenon Fisbein, in his recital last night at Town Hall, sometimes played with assurance, flexibility of nuance and strong technique. At those moments he was a fine pianist indeed.

VILLANOVA, Pa., April 18 Mr. and Mrs. George I. MacLeod have announced he engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Torbert MacLeod, to Dr. William L. Elkins. He is the son of Mrs. Arthur O. Choate Jr. of New York and the late William L. Elkins of Philadelphia.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 18 The blockade-running adventures of the Ioanna V and the Manuela provided all of southern Africa with several days of stimulating diversion.
LONDON, April 18 (UPI) Barbra Streisand announced today that she was expecting her first child in mid-December. It appears that the baby is going to cost her about $1-million.
The Continental Can Company outpointed its chief rival the American Can Company, in total sales and earnings in the first quarter of 1966, their reports showed yesterday.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 18--President Johnson ended tonight an 11-day working vacation at his Texas ranch.
A foreclosure action has been brought against the New Yorker Hotel, which is now being operated by court-appointed receivers.

Bertram A. Powers, leader of the typographical union here, expressed optimism last night about the prospects for an agreement with the publishers of the three newspapers that plan to merge next Monday.
The logjam of proposed banking laws in the New York State Legislature was apparently broken yesterday.

Unrest over controversial work rules, ordered into effect on April 1 under the terms of an agreement between the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association, flared up briefly again yesterday.

Bell Telephone Laboratories confirmed yesterday that it was closing its former headquarters on the lower West Side and would move most of its 1,400 employes to three New Jersey research centers. The city indicated it would try to prevent the job outflow.
BUENOS AIRES, April 18 Juan D. Peron, the former Argentine dictator, reached out from exile in Madrid yesterday and scored a moral victory in the Mendoza provincial elections.
The spot rate on the British pound dipped yesterday in fairly active trading on foreignexchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7936, down 2 points from its level of last Friday.

United Air Lines has joined Delta Air Lines in asking the Civil Aeronautics Board to amend the new program of cut-rate fares for young people. Changes are necesary, they say, to remove abuses that have arisen.
Because Ruben Amaro will need a knee operation that will keep him out of action for three months or more, the New York Yankees will shift Clete Boyer to shortstop and Tom Tresh to third base.
WASHINGTON, April 18 A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee will begin hearings tomorrow that may arouse strong emotions inside the State Department.

NEW HAVEN, April 18 Miss Felicia Catherine O'Keefe, daughter of William John O'Keefe of Hamden and the late Mrs. Felicia Roman O'Keefe, was married this noon to Charles Martin Pleuthner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pleuthner of Garden City, L.I.
The Susquehanna Corporation won dismissal yesterday of part of a stockholder suit charging several present and past officers with fraud in connection with the merger with the American Gypsum Company.

WASHINGTON, April 18 Solicitor General Thurgood Marshall said today that since Congress had allowed Puerto Ricans to be educated in Spanish, it therefore must be allowed to protect their right to vote if they are literate in Spanish.

IF his book were called "Small Expectations" in- stead of "Go Up for Glory," the title might better describe the roots of William Felton Russell. He never expected to be most of the things he has become, and that's only fair, because he has not become most of the...
It was a day of divergent price trends yesterday in the bond market.

THE New York Television Theater wound up its first season on Channel 13 last night with an avant-garde double bill: Eugene Ionesco's "Bedlam Galore, For Two or More" and Samuel Beckett's "Eh, Joe?" To expect to be able to divine with complete precision what the authors had in mind would be like complaining about tennis played without a ball. If the strokes are intriguing, the spectator can put in his own bounces.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The creation of a unified national veterans cemetery system within the Veterans Administration was proposed today.
CHICAGO, April 18 (UPI) The Chicago White Sox said today they had stopped playing "The Star-Spangled Banner" before their games at Comiskey Park because it was too difficult to sing.
Steel production continued steady last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The New York Mets and St. Louis Cardinals worked out at Shea Stadium yesterday, preparing for a "big" two-game series scheduled to begin this afternoon. The series deserves the adjective since the Mets, having won two of their first three games are "big" whenever they show up.

Richmond M. Flowers, Attorney General of Alabama, has charged that the Justice Department backed down on a promise to help him investigate the Ku Klux Klan after the murder of a civil rights worker, Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo, last spring.

FORT LAMY, Chad, April 18 The Chad Republic is a good example of the adolescent African state torn between the culture that gave it birth, in this case the French, and the hope for United States help.

PARIS, April 18 (Reuters) The frozen body of a man believed to have stowed away on a plane he thought was bound for Spain was found early today in the undercarriage housing of an airliner just back from Moscow. There was unclear and conflicting evidence on his nationality.
The American Cyanamid Company showed record sales and earnings in the first quarter and expects to maintain the pace through the remaining quarters of 1966, W.G. Malcolm, chairman, said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 Mayor James H.J. Tate unveiled today a master plan for a new $75-million Philadelphia international airport complex that would quadruple the passenger capacity of the terminal by 1973.
TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., April 18 (AP) Dr. Joseph E. Maddy, the founder and president of the National Music Camp and Arts Academy at Interlochen, died today of a heart attack. He was 74 years old.
MILLBROOK, N.Y., April 18 Dr. Timothy F. Leary today accused the Dutchess County Sheriff of "intolerable violations of my rights" in a predawn raid on his rented mansion here yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, April 18 Frenchy the Batboy has become the premier Batman of the Los Angeles Dodgers.
WASHINGTON, April 18 State Department officials were skeptical today that President Arif would order such a drastic revision of past Government policy as offering autonomy to the Kurds.

LONDON, April 18 The Lord Chancellor summoned members of the House of Commons to the House of Lords today and announced that Queen Elizabeth II had "ordered a Parliament to be holden at our City of Westminster."

Stage and educational facilities of the new Fine Arts Auditorium at the Montgomery Junior College in Rockville, Md., will be opened tonight with Archibald MacLeish's Pulitzer Prize drama, "J.B.," as part of the current Rockville Arts Festival.
A group of neglected teen-age boys reared in rural surroundings will complete their high school education in the city to ease their transition to urban life.
A professional round-robin tennis tournament for $30,000 in prize money will be held under the VASSS scoring system on grass at the West Side Club's stadium at Forest Hills from June 8 to 12.
LISBON, April 18 Pianists from 18 countries are competing in the third international Vianna da Motta contest, which opened here today.

MANCHESTER, England, April 18 (AP) Thad Spencer of San Francisco, a heavyweight contender, stopped Jack Bodell, Britain's best young prospect, in two rounds of a 10round bout at Belle Vue Stadium tonight.

MODERN dance covers a multitude of things. Last night the Edith Stephen Dance Theater, which I missed through pressure of other duties when it appeared earlier this season at the 92d Street Young Men's and Women's Hebrew Association, came to the Loeb Student Center of New York University.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 18 The president of two construction companies pleaded guilty today to charges that his concerns stole topsoil from a building site for the Long Island Expressway and used them on other projects.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 (AP) The Pittsburgh Pirates, sparked by Jose Pagan's pinchhit, two-run double in the sixth inning and a triple play in the seventh, beat the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3, tonight for their fifth victory in six games.
"She's kinda light on her feet, but I think we could use some more distance in the race," said Gary Mineau before the $27,850 Distaff Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
Success or failure of the Kennedy-round of tariff negotiations will be told in the coming weeks rather than months, a United States trade official warned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The Defense Department explained today why it paid $21 each for bombs originally sold to a German company for $1.70 each.

Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy ruled yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had made a strong, "although far from conclusive" prima-facie case that David M. Milton controlled S P National Corporation and several related companies.
Prices on the London stock market generally drifted downward in listless trading yesterday.
Up in the morning and down in the afternoon that was the price trend on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the market showed losses at the close in continued heavy trading.

Fred w. Friendly, former president of C.B.S. News, told a group of radio and television news workers last night that they, as professionals, were the key to whether electronic journalism becomes a force of integrity.

Donald L. Fuchs of Goldman, Sachs Co., Edmund J. McRichard of Brooks, Harvey Co. and Phillip C. O'Connell of Huntoon, Paige Co. will speak on interest rates and yields at the monthly dinner meeting of the Mortgage Bankers Association of New York tomorrow at 6 P.M. at the Biltmore Hotel.

MOSCOW, April 18 Dr. Yussef Zayen, Premier of the new Baathist Government in Syria, arrived in Moscow today for an official visit. He was warmly welcomed at Vunkovo Airport by Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and other Soviet officials.
PORTLAND, Ore., April 18 (AP) The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today it was discussing the possibility of acquiring the Kalamazoo Paper Company of Kalamazoo, Mich.
Plywood has been drafted into the war in Vietnam.

The State Supreme Court justice who has presided at a sixweek-long libel trial unexpectedly announced yesterday that he would rule this afternoon on whether to dismiss charges brought by Dr. Linus C. Pauling against William F. Buckley Jr.
The General Dynamics Corporation has received a $36.4 million Navy contract for construction of a submarine tender.

In a $2.5-million transaction. Jack Resneck, investor and builder, has purchased the 14story industrial building at 250 Hudson Street, occupying the entire east blockfront between Broome and Dominick Streets.

Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the challenger for the world chess championship, had a theoretical edge over his compatriot, Tigran Petrosian, when they adjourned the fourth game of their title match last night at the Variety Theatre in Moscow.
Four foreign-language feature movies will have their American premieres at the New Yorker Theater, Broadway and 88th Street, in a series starting May 12.

WASHINGTON, April 18 The annual rate of the nation's total output of goods and services the gross national product soared by $16.9-billion in the first quarter of this year, but more than one-third of the increase in the dollar total represented higher prices, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) The Supreme, Court today settled a river boundary dispute between Louisiana and Mississippi.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 18 (AP) The owners of 78 cars have each paid the $1,000 entry fee for the 500-mile race May 30. Indianapolis Motor Speedway officials announced today.

John F. White, president of the National Educational Television network, yesterday denied assertions by some affiliated stations that N.E.T. programs emphasized liberal ideology at the expense of conservative viewpoints.

WASHINGTON, April 18 Sargent Shriver said today that "the people involved in the yelling business" that drove him from a poverty convention here last Thursday were determined beforehand to break up the meeting "as an end in itself."
The latest readings of the economic indicators confirm that the Johnson Administration's forecasts, which were the basis for its economic policy, are sadly out of date.

WASHINGTON, April 18 The common report of some members of Congress, after sampling the sentiments of their constituents during the Easter recess, is that the Administration's conduct of the war in Vietnam has spread confusion and discontent among the American people. The discontent derives from a widely voiced judgment that our deep...

Emperor Haile Selassie has now carried out the governmental reform he promised last month. He has allowed Premier Aklilou Abte Wold to appoint his own Cabinet. This might seem a mild reform in many countries, but in Ethiopia it represents a substantial change in a system in which the Emperor's control has been direct and absolute.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Federal and state health pro- grams are being hampered by such things as grantsmanship, multiple convergence and squeeze bemused Congressmen were told today.

SEVILLE, Spain, April 18 Mrs. John F. Kennedy flashed an encouraging grin to many of the 58 debutantes during their procession at the annual Charity Spring Ball given last night in the Casa de Pilatos Palace here. But others near her found it hard to look cheerful for very long.
Walston Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, announced here yesterday the appointment of W.T.S. Quicke as vice president in charge of its investment advisory department.
Federated Department Stores, Inc., has appointed Lee Champion as head of its New York real estate office to guide the expansion of Abraham Straus and Bloomingdale's, Federated's major stores here.

This year, for the first time since it was begun in 1962, the Critics' Week of the Cannes Film Festival, a competition of films by new directors, will not include entries from American filmmakers. The obvious implication is that young American directors are simply not turning out films of more than routine interest.

The Cities Service Company and the Gulf Oil Corporation took much of the oil industry by surprise yesterday by announcing the signing of a letter of intent for the sale of major Cities Service Midwestern marketing and refining properties to Gulf.

FLOATING tournaments sponsored by local bridge associations are well-known these days, but for a small club to organize a tournament over a thousand miles from home is perhaps unique. The club is the Bridge Masters of Washington, D.C., one of the oldest in the country, and their venture planned for San Juan, Puerto Rico, on July 2-4.

HENRIK Ibsen's "When We Dead Awaken" is extremely difficult to perform, almost forbiddingly so. There is probably a way to realize it on the stage, but the way has not been found on West 42d Street. The production that opened last night at the Masque, and which I saw at its last preview, has nothing at all to recommend it.
NASHVILLE, April 18 Miss Meredith Gayle Keras and Philip Sheridan Joseph Moriarty plan to marry Aug. 20.

The city's Buildings Commissioner, Charles G. Moerdler, seems somewhat startled at discovering through his inspectors that a great many public school buildings are in a state of disrepair. He would be less surprised, perhaps, if he had studied the long history of inadequate budget provision for school maintenance.
Mayor Lindsay and Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Superintendent of Schools, heard some education complaints last night at a monthly meeting of an East Harlem school board.

The city's building trades unions have made strides in the last two years in eliminating discrimination and opening their doors to Negroes and other members of minority groups, according to Peter J. Brennan, the president of the New York Building Trades Council.
The board of directors of the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York has elected Reese H. Harris Jr. president to succeed Alfred H. Howell.
The late-winter rise in pneumonia and influenza appears to have subsided, according to figures from city and Federal health agencies.

WASHINGTON, April 18 Sylvia Symington, whose understated sophistication rests on the foundations of a comfortable childhood, a master's degree in music composition and an ability to entertain, is just three weeks into one of the toughest and most demanding jobs in Washington. But there she was the other day, as unruffled as if her only thought were carpooling her two children to school.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Tne Securities and Exchange Commission said today a proposed plan for reorganization of the F.L. Jacobs Company is fair and equitable, but should be amended to eliminate a proposed restriction on common stock dividends.

MEXICO CITY, April 18 Mexico is making the question of cotton prices the major touchstone for judging the Johnson Administration's reaffirmation of its intention to cooperate with Latin America toward its economic progress.

SAIGON, April 18 Thich Tri Quang, the Buddhist monk who is regarded as the main figure behind the opposition to the Ky regime, toured the northern area of South Vietnam today and asked that rebellious section to accept the military junta's promise of elections in three to five months.

MOSCOW, April 18 David Carver, secretary of P.E.N. International, returned to London tonight after being rebuffed in a three-day effort to obtain clemency for Andrel D. Sinyavsky and Yuli M. Daniel, writers imprisoned on charges of having slandered the Soviet Union in works smuggled to the West.

HOUSTON, April 18 (UPI) The Gemini 9 guided by two astronauts, Lieut Col. Thomas P. Stafford of the Air Force and Lieut Comdr. Eugene A. Cernan of the Navy, will be orbited on May 17 on a mission that will include a chase with another satellite, a space float by a pilot and a simulated rescue of a pilot stranded in orbit.

INDIANA, Pa., April 18 Mr. and Mrs. Donald Samuel Brody have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Anne Brody, to Jay Muchnick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Muchnick of Melrose Park.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reported yesterday a first-quarter net profit of $102million, or $2.17 a common share.
YONKERS, April 18 There were more eyes focused at the five-eighths pole than at the finish line tonight for the fourth race at Yorkers Raceway.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 18 Emphasis on continuity of government and policy in Iraq despite the death of President Abdel Salam Arif was maintained today with formation of a new Cabinet by Premier Abdel Rahman al-Bazzaz.
The storm-battered Italian liner Michelangelo suffered additional but minor damage yesterday afternoon from fire.
The city's public health nurses have rejected a contract approved by Mayor Lindsay and will meet today to consider mass resignations.
DETROIT, April 18 (UPI) The Chicago Black Hawks and Detroit Red Wings spent a leisurely day off the ice today, awaiting the sixth game of their Stanley Cup semi-final playoffs here tomorrow night.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 18 (UPI) Debbie Austin, an 18year-old high school senior from Oneida, N.Y., shot a three-over-par 75 today to lead qualifiers in the 64th North and South women's golf championship at Pinehurst Country Club.
"I love Harlem," the woman said. "I've lived here all my life, I raised my children here I will not be forced out."
The New York Democratic executive committee has declined to designate an organization candidate for Congress in Manhattan's 19th District.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Retired Supreme Court Justice Charles Evans Whittaker will serve as a consultant to the Senate Committee on Standards and Conduct.

BONN, April 18 The West German and French Foreign Ministers began today their discussions of what has to be done to permit French forces to remain in West Germany after July 1, when they are to be withdrawn from allied command.

WASHINGTON, April 18 Senator Leverett Saltonstall said today that there was nothing "clandestine" about the Central Intelligence Agency's participation in a Michigan State University program to train security police in South Vietnam from 1955 to 1959.
The appointment of Richard Craw as director of trade development for the Grace Line was announced yesterday by Ernest R. Senn, senior vice president of the steamship company.

Philip Robert Benjamin, a reporter for The New York Times for 12 years, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after a short illness. Mr. Benjamin, who was also a novelist and a poet, underwent abdominal surgery on April 4. He was 43 years old and lived at 501 East 79th Street.
LONDON, April 18 Prime Minister Wilson answered a warning from Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd of South Africa with a gentle warning of his own today.

BEREA, Ky. "Why don't you sniffle over and snitch one?" Floyd Baker suggested as an approach to his contribution to the pot-luck supper, "Old-fashioned ginger cookies like my mother used to make when I was a kid."

SAIGON, April 18 A United States Air Force spokesman said today that American fighter-bombers had left two missile sites near Hanoi engulfed in flames after raids yesterday. The spokesman said that the radar equipment that guided the missiles had apparently been destroyed.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 18 (UPI) Dr. John Harry Williams, a nuclear physicist who left the academic world to help build the first atomic bomb, died today at the University of Minnesota, Hospital. He was 57 years old.
The national secretary of Students for a Democratic Society asserted yesterday that there "seems to be a national investigation" of his group by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The Celanese Corporation announced here yesterday the appointments of Alexander R. Cochran and Dr. Robert T. Armstrong as senior vice presidents and Frank J. Pizzitola as a group vice president. All are new posts.
WASHINGTON, April 18 In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceedings were had:
SCHWEDT, Germany, April 12 East Germans consider this little city on the Oder River one of the wonders of their 20-year-old "workers' and farmers' republic."

The father General of the Society of Jesus told Protestant and Jewish leaders here yester- day that Jesults contritely ac- knowledge the part society members have played in history in escalating religious tensions to "formidable proportions."
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 18 (AP) Prime Minister Terence O'Neill rejected tonight a proposal by President Eamon de Valera of the Irish Republic for an all-Ireland Parliament.

LOS ANGELES, April 18 The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, the nation's largest municipal utility agency, signed contracts today covering an $86.6-million project to bring electricity nearly 900 miles to the city from the Federal Government's Bonneville power development on the Columbia River in Oregon.
Mrs. Maginel Wright Barney, illustrator and craftsman, sister of the late Frank Lloyd Wright, the architect, died yesterday in the Huntting Lane Rest Home in East Hampton, L.I. She was 84 years old.

ALBANY, April 18 Because of the unusual length of this year's session, the leaders of the Legislature have decided to grant every member an extra "lulu" of at. least $1,000 the same reward they got during last-year's long session.

Litton Industries continued to roar down the merger trail with the announcement yesterday of a preliminary understanding on the acquisition of Diebold, Inc., a major manufacturer of bank security equipment.

DETROIT, April 18 (AP) Automobile production lines moved actively this week, with the three-millionth car of calendar 1966 due to roll off a United States assembly line Wednesday, five days behind the record of April 15 set last year.
NEWARK, April 18 (UPI) The Christian Brothers of Ireland announced today the election of the Rev. Brother Arthur A. Loftus of Newark as the first American to head the 4,000-member teaching order.

Miss Pilar Guerrero, daughter of Mrs. Albirto Guerrero of La Serena, Chile, and the late Mr. Guerrero, was married last Wednesday to George K. Bissell of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl H. Bissell of Bellport, L.I.
George F. Kennan, president of the National Institute of Arts and Letters and the Academy, announced yesterday the award of eight grants and one fellowship in literature totaling $25,000.
CLEVELAND, April 19 Additional disturbing evidence appeared tonight that this year would be discouragingly like last year for the New York Yankees.
Stock prices went down in the morning yesterday, up in the afternoon and finished on the fence.

Events tonight: Brooklyn Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Marcelita Lopez Kabayao, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Robert Sylvester, cellist, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 8; Columbia Composers Group, McMillin Theater, Columbia University, 8:30.

ROCHESTER, April, 19--Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Schleber have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Jane Schleber, to Richard Clark Lowry. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Leo E. Lowry of Caracas, Venezuela, and New York.
Mayor Lindsay took the podium yesterday to lead the Department of Sanitation Band.

RAHWAY, N.J., April 19 Merck said in a statement here today that the commission "has ignored the findings of their own hearing examiner, based on months of sifting the medical testimony brought out at the hearings before him."
Mechanical failure of automobiles may be responsible for as many as one-half of the 50,000 motor vehicle deaths that occur in this country each year, a study reported yesterday indicates.
Abner A. Raeburn, chairman of the board of directors of N.S. Meyer, Inc., manufacturers of military insignia, died here Sunday night at the Rusk Centre of University Hospital. He was 64 years old.
The City Council moved yesterday into the bitter controversy surrounding the proposed construction of the $525-million World Trade Center in downtown Manhattan.

The Citizens Committee for an Effective Constitution urged Manhattan political leaders yesterday to select delegates to next spring's State Constitutional Convention from its list of 24 "highly qualified citizens."

ALBANY, April 19 A broad liberalizing of the state's 179-year-old divorce law was all but assured today when leaders of the Legislature formally announced they had agreed to modify some of the stiffer require ments in their bill. As a result, the measure, in substantially the form in which it emerged today, is expected to win approval in both houses...

MIAMI, April 19 (UPI) Premier Fidel Castro said tonight that he hoped the late Adlai Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations at the time of the 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion, was in hell.

LEFTY GOMEZ was a flippant operative who could buzz in a fast ball or break off a quip with equal facility. The ace of the Yankee pitching staff in his prime, the singular southpaw fell just a fraction short of immortality as a pitcher. But baseball historians found themselves so fascinated by so many of his off-hand remarks that they have been immortalizing them ever since.

DETROIT, April 19 (UPI) Dean Prentice scored two goals, just 63 seconds apart, in the closing minutes of play tonight to send the Detroit Red Wings into the Stanley Cup finals with a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

TOKYO, April 19 Japan would welcome an international peace conference here on Vietnam, as suggested by Senator Mike Mansfield in the United States Senate yesterday, but high officials in Tokyo doubt that now is the time for it.

The 15 largest mutual savings banks in New York City, whose combined assets total about $17billion, showed a net deposit loss of approximately $280-million during the 14 business days from March 29 through April 15.
It was a day of happy tidings in the oil industry yesterday. Texaco, Inc., and the Sun Oil Company reported sharply higher earnings for the first quarter of 1966.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., April 19 Mr. and Mrs. E. Stephen Brekstone have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Brekstone, to Celestino Iginio Carmenini, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Carmenini of White Plains and Abbruzzi, Italy.
WASHINGTON, April 19 The Pentagon termed "misleading" today reports that United States air sorties against the Vietcong in South Vietnam had been sharply reduced by shortages of bomb parts.

PARIS, April 19 France confirmed today that the United States had ignored her request for nuclear fuel under a 1959 agreement for more than a year and a half. The French Government denied it had in any way violated the agreement.

TRENTON, April 19 The Republican State Committee upheld today a finding by the New Jersey Young Republicans that at least 10 members of the conservative Rat Fink faction were guilty of displaying or encouraging racism and antiSemitism.
There is a great deal of serendipity waiting for venturesome industry in the oceans of the world if industry will just venture, a retired Navy admiral said yesterday.

The East Harlem Block Development Project announced new staff members yesterday to replace those who had resigned en masse to avoid a feud over who will control the area's antipoverty efforts.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) President and Mrs. Johnson were shoved and jostled by thousands of female admirers at a White House reception today.
WASHINGTON, April 19 The Supreme Court unanimously upheld today a 1964 New York State law designed to reduce the price of liquor in the state.
Mildred Howells, last surviving child of William Dean Howells, the author, died Monday, in Boston. She was 93 years old.

Dr. Leon Golden, a physician and Hebrew and Yiddish writer, who did much to provide up-todate etymology for modern Hebrew medical books, died Monday in his home at 739 Mace Avenue, the Bronx. He was 83 years old.

ODESSA, Tex., April 19 Now that the Globe of the Great Southwest has proved to be eminently stageworthy, what is to be done with it? This attractive and authentic reincarnation of an Elizabethan theater, which stands improbably on the edge of this West Texas town, has no compelling reason...

Top-level bargaining between the printers and the publishers of the three newspapers planning to merge here was resumed last night in an effort to settle the key question of extra severance pay for those facing dismissal.
An electronic device that simplifies the task of rowing coaches in determining the oarsmen who are pulling the greatest weight in the boat is being used by the University of Pennsylvania.

German authors, critics and publishers who form an important segment of their nation's literary community are arriving in the United States for a meeting Friday at Princeton University of the so-called Gruppe '47. The group will meet in private for three days and then on Monday join a university conference on "The Writer in the Affluent Society."
Stockholders of the United States Rubber Company voted yesterday to change the name of the company to Uniroyal, Inc.

The negotiations that have just begun over French forces in Germany are essentially an effort to integrate France not Germany this time into the West. With the Atlantic Alliance on notice that General de Gaulle intends to remove his staff officers from NATO headquarters and his troops from NATO command on July 1, the problem is to work out a new French relationship with Germany and the NATO military structure.
WASHINGTON, April 19 The Army Surgeon General's office denied tonight that there had been negligence in the case of Donald Dilworth, a newly inducted Army private from New Milford, N.J.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 19 New Jersey membership in the John Birch Society was reported here today to have quadrupled in the last 12 months, with the state now ranking second only to California in membership growth.

ROME, April 19 A Roman Catholic bishop has asserted, despite a declaration by the recent Vatican Ecumenical Council intended to end anti-Jewish theology, that Judaism, as a religion, carries, "by its very nature," the "judgment of condemnation by God."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 19--Representatives of 36 African states have formed a committee to plan a new move in the security council demanding more forceful action against the white minority Government of Rhodesia.

Long Island University gained its first Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference victory yesterday by defeating the defending conference champion, New York University, 17-4, at Ohio Field in the Bronx.

KIEV, April 19 (UPI) The Kremlin opened a campaign today against anti-Soviet nationalist organizations that were said to have been infiltrating the Soviet Union since the end of World War I. The United States was accused of giving the groups financial support.

SAIGON Communist underground, which takes great pains not to surface, is now secretly preparing a take-over bid in the South Vietnamese region of Annam with the unwitting help of Buddhist nationalists. Two Annamite cities are the principal targets Hue, former imperial capital, and Danang, a U.S. Marine citadel and military airport.

LODZ, Poland, April 19 Tough-looking Polish and Moroccan "cowboys" broke into Indian war whoops and fired their popgun Colts into the air this morning as the visitor from Hollywood stepped from his car. The Lodz Jazz Stompers tore into the "Hesitation Rag."
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 19 "I'm planning to knock Tiger out sometime after the 10th round," said Emile Griffith after a spirited workout today at the Concord Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission said tonight BroadwayHale Stores, Inc., of Los Angeles had agreed to an order forbidding it to acquire any department, general merchandise, apparel or furniture stores for five years without commission approval.

BONN, April 19 Representatives of the United States, Britain and West Germany started work today on arrangements to be proposed to France regarding the stationing of French troops in West Germany after they leave NATO command on July 1.

Roy Innis, chairman of the Harlem chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality, who was cleared in Criminal Court on Monday of charges that he unlawfully possessed two hypodermic syringes and 44 pills last month, said yesterday the pills were "tranquilizers" for his wife and that he used the syringes in his research work.
The spot rate on the British pound again declined in moderate trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7931, down 5 points from its level of the preceding day.

The 500-room Park Crescent Hotel at the northeast corner of Riverside Drive and 87th Street has been sold by Park Crescent Arms, Inc., to the Riverside 87th Street Corporation, subject to a first mortgage of $1.3-million.

The City Council opens its public hearings today on the new taxes that Mayor Lindsay asks to balance his $4.6 billion expense budget. This is a turning point in city finance. If New York does not now begin to supply essential services with the funds they need, if it does not call a halt to borrowing for current expenses and to playing fast and loose with reserves, it faces a downhill future.

THE dress of the future may be schussing down the ski slopes next winter over heavy knitted tights or extra-sleek ski pants. It has a stand-up collar, modestly flaring skirt and is one of the most arresting of next winter's fashions presented this week by ski manufacturers in their own showrooms, in hotel suites or under the auspices of two trade organizations, Ski Industries America or the Ski Council of America.
District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Brooklyn said yesterday that his office had received information that school facilities were being used to make the hallucinogenic drug LSD.
PITTSBURGH, April 19 (UPI) Representatives of 10,000 miners in eastern Kentucky defied union leaders today by voting to stay off the job until a new contract was signed with the soft coal industry.
Mayor Lindsay said last night that neglect of the elderly was "one of the great and growing problems of our society."
