Mr. and Mrs. Vladimir Horowitz and Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey have added their support to the campaign to save the old Metropolitan Opera House.
Beatrice Lillie, who has made infrequent guest appearances on television, will star in a pilot film for a proposed half-hour weekly situation comedy series. Artie Shaw will be the executive producer.
Two well-known watchdog groups on public spending called on the Lindsay administration last night to trim its $4.6-million budget by $185-million and scale down new taxes to meet the reduced need.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 19 Relations between Malaysia and Singapore became more strained today when the Malaysian Government announced that immigration controls were being imposed on all Singapore citizens.
ALBANY, April 19 The State Senate voted overwhelmingly tonight to prohibit the Education Commissioner from ordering the busing of public school pupils to achieve racial

Ernest Hemingway lost out on a 1941 Pulitzer prize for his novel "For Whom the Bell Tolls," because of a veto by the president of Columbia. University, according to an article in the current issue of McCall's magazine.

Edwin D. Etherington, president of the American Stock Exchange, said yesterday that "current turnover figures" and "wide price swings" indicated an "unusual degree of speculation" had swirled into the market place.

RUNAWAY BAY, Jamaica, April 19 (Reuters) Leading Latin-American bankers have arrived here for two international conferences, which may have great effect on future economic integration of the hemisphere.
TEL AVIV, April 19 (AP) Fighting broke out on the Israeli-Jordanian border today, and each side accused the other of having violated the border truce.

WINDSOR, Conn., April 19 Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Sullivan have anounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maureen Thrall Sullivan, to Robert Warren Crandall, son of Mr. and Mrs. C.L. Crandall of Salinas, Calif.

A BEATING of wing-like arms, an immortal shiver- ing glide to the center of the stage, an onrush of white feathers, a wildly held poetic pose and Maya Plisetskaya was back in New York. So, or rather a little earlier, was Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet, dancing "Swan Lake."

BOSTON, April 19 The Boston Celtics didn't squander the wealth of an early lead tonight as they did Sunday afternoon. Instead, the defending champions, seeking their eighth straight National Basketball Association title, kept a big advantage, built in the first half, to beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 129-109, and even the N.B.A. final playoff series at one game apiece.
WASHINGTON, April 19 Mrs. John F. Kennedy has asked Congress to reduce her annual Federal allowance of $50,000 to $30,000.
HARTFORD, April 19 (AP) The Hilton Hotels Corporation announced today that it had bought the Statler Hilton Hotel here, which it had operated under a lease since it opened in 1954.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 112.5 on Monday from 112.9 on Friday.
ANAHEIM, Calif., April 19 (AP) The Chicago White Sox defeated the California Angels tonight, 3-1, in the Angels' debut in Anaheim Stadium.
EL PASO, Tex., April 19 Federal District Judge Leo Brewster today extended from today until noon Friday the deadline for receiving new evidence on a motion for a new trial for Billie Sol Estes.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) Government agents today began rounding up 18 men accused of hijacking more than a $1-million worth of silver and camera equipment from interstate shipments over the last two years.

BONN, April 19 (AP) The magazine Stern charged today that American intelligence agents had intercepted one of its couriers and taken from him notes and a tape recording of an interview with a Soviet general.
The election of A. Carleton Dukess and William F. Purcell as directors of C. F. Childs Co., the financing concern, was announced here yesterday.

DAKAR, Senegal, April 19 He chomps on American chlorophyll chewing gum, chainsmokes American cigarettes and wears tailor-made European pin-striped suits. His opinions on everything from politics to women seem as limitless as his capacity to down Scotch on the rocks and stay sober.
WASHINGTON, April 19 President Johnson appealed to other nations today to respond with "compassion and responsibility" in meeting the emergency food needs of droughtstricken India.

ARROZ con pollo Castillane is a variation of the traditional rice with chicken dish using more delicate seasonings than the familiar Mexican version. An easy-tofix, all-in-one main dish, it is ideal for a buffet dinner. Except for the last step, it can be prepared an hour or two ahead.

The Molybdenum Corporation of America announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering an offering of convertible preferred stock for subscription by common stockholders.
LIVERPOOL, England, April 19 (UPI)--More than 100 persons were injured tonight in a riot that forced an early ending to a soccer match between Liverpool and Celtic of Scotland.
The bond market continued yesterday to exhibit inconsis tency.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, April 20 (AP) Students rampaged through the empty Chinese consulate here yesterday, burning furniture and painting anti-Communist slogans on the walls.
ACCORD, N. Y., April 19 Senator Robert F. Kennedy accused the Johnson Administration tonight of making domestic budget cuts that will hurt the poor the most.
Robert V. Lindsay, brother of Mayor Lindsay, and Mrs. Hampton C. Lynch have been elected to the board of directors of the New York Philharmonic.

MANY tournament players complain about the pro- liferation of conventions, and it is quite true that a number of artificial devices have been introduced into expert play in recent years. There is, however, a simple way of keeping up with the experts in this area.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., April 18 (AP) Campus policemen broke up an anti-Wallace demonstration during Governor's Day ceremonies today at the University of Alabama.

WHITE PLAINS, April 19 The state asked for bids today on parkway reconstruction that will detour thousands of motorists on the Cross County and Hutchinson River Parkways for two years. It will ultimately permit the development of a new scenic lakefront park just to the north of the intersection.

READ any good sweatshirts lately? The new popularity of the heavy cotton, long-sleeved pullover is not based on a change in the sweatshirt itself but on what has been written, flocked or stenciled on it.
Maryland sold $30.25-million of bonds yesterday to finance port authority, education and nursing home facilities.

WASHINGTON, April 19 ? Airline pilots opposing the recent narrowing of air lanes over the Atlantic today produced two experts on statistics who sharply criticized a basic Government study on the safety involved.
Mrs. Elisabeth Bevier Hamilton, former children's book editor of William Morrow Co., publishers, died Sunday in her home at 235 East 22d Street. Her age was 73.
David A. Gearey, a 23-yearold English teacher at Bishop Ford High School in Brokolyn, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy to two years in prison for draft evasion.
HOUSTON, April 19 (AP) The Houston Astros routed Don Drysdale during a four-run fifth inning tonight and defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 8-5.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) Robert C. Weaver, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today the Administration's new demonstration cities program was designed to help people, not improve business areas.

WASHINGTON, April 19 Vivien Leigh slid into an armchair in the living room of her Jefferson Hotel suite here, crossed her slim legs and tucked the skirt of her two-year-old, coral-colored Dior suit neatly around her knees.
The Allegheny Airlines announced yesterday in Washington, D.C., the appointment of Eugene C. Taylor as senior vice president for operations and as a member of its senior executive committee.
HONG KONG, April 19 (Reuters) President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam was reported today to have rejected a Japanese effort to find a peaceful solution to the Vietnam problem.

WASHINGTON, April 19--Hairline cracks have been found around bolt holes in the tail assemblies of 22 older Boeing 707 and 720 jetliners in precautionary inspections, the Federal Aviation Agency said today.
ROME, April 19 (AP) A Yugoslav Government delegation has been meeting with Vatican officials to discuss a possible accord, Vatican sources disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 Everett McKinley Dirksen, the Senate Republican leader, refused today to associate himself with the charge by Gerald R. Ford, the House Republican leader, that there had been "shocking mismanagement" of the Vietnam war.

HELSINKI, Finland, April 19 (Reuters) Vaino Tanner, the former Social Democratic leader and Cabinet minister long known as the Finn Moscow hated the most, died early today in a Helsinki hospital. He was 85 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)--The House Merchant Marine Committee urged today that all foreign passenger ships not meeting United States safety standards be barred from American ports.

Except for Mrs. James Biddle, a du Pont Copeland whose new baby gave her a legitimate reason for staying home, nearly everybody who is anybody so- cially was out on the town last night whooping it up in what was widely held to be the most hopelessly overscheduled evenings since the World's Fair opened two years ago.
PITTSBURGH, April 19 (AP) The Pittsburgh Pirates supported Steve Blass with a 17hit attack tonight and beat the Cincinnati Reds, 7-3.
WASHINGTON, April 19 In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceedings were had:

Elizabeth Vernay, contralto, gave what amounted to a lecture with musical examples rather than a recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Her subject was sacred music of the Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque eras.
The City Council stood by its long-standing policy yesterday and denied a request by WCBS-TV to film today's and tomorrow's public hearings on Mayor Lindsay's tax proposals.

They could have used a few of Whitey Ford's hot-water bottles at Shea Stadium yesterday. It was so cold that only 6,371 customers showed up, people in the grandstand couldn't hold on to foul balls with their usual tenacity and, worst of all, even the mighty Mets cooled off.

EISENHUTTENSTADT, Germany, April 13 It was Pioneer Day for the second grade in one of Eisenhuttenstadt's attractive modern elementary schools. On Pioneer Days East German children learn about their heritage.
Mitsui, the major Japanese trading company, announced yesterday the formation of an American corporation to increase United States trade with countries other than Japan.

THE problem for aristocratic girls and young women in Rome today, according to Federico Forquet, the fashion designer, is to keep up with the dernier cri in other capitals skirts 'way above the knee, pants for dress-up wear while maintaining the decorum that has always characterized the appearance of the well-born in the Eternal City.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., April 19 (AP) Arnold Palmer, who beat Gay Brewer in the Tournament of Champions playoff yesterday, took over Brewer's No. 2 spot today in the top 10 money-winning list of the Professional Golfers' Association.

BOL, Chad, April 19 Here on the edge of the Sahara, amid sand, scrub and thorn bush, the waters of Lake Chad are being pushed back to recover land where wheat can be grown for the hungry African Continent.
Everybody's doing it. Amateur public investors are obviously contributing to the surge in speculative activity in the stock market. But many professional institutional in-

SAIGON, Wednesday, April 20 The South Vietnamese police today prevented a group of American pacifists from holding a news conference in the Caravelle Hotel and a demonstration outside the United States Em- bassy.
The American Jewish Congress, a tax-exempt association, said it was "tithing in reverse" yesterday as it gave New York City a check for $1,200 as a token toward taxes.

The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a new high of $22,681,000 in first-quarter net income. This was 8.2 per cent higher than the $20,959,000 earned in the 1965 quarter.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 James J. Saxon, Controller of the Currency, underwent intensive and sometimes sarcastic cross-examination today in the reopening of the antitrust trial in the $3.75-billion merger of the Crocker-Citizens National Bank.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 19 Mrs. Virginia D. Draper of Scarsdale and Thayer P. Draper of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Sheldon Draper, to Manuel Roberto de Vengoechea-Fleury. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel de Vengoechea-Mier of Bogota, Colombia.

Randolph Guthrie, chairman of the Studebaker Corporation, testified in Federal District Court yesterday in Grand Rapids, Mich., that he looked with disfavor on a suggestion that Studebaker merge with the Allied Products Corporation.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell obtained an order yesterday that seeks to recall a contempt citation for failure to appear for examination in a $575,000 judgment against the New York Democrat.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 19 (UPI) A tornado ripped suburban Overland Park, Kan., today, destroying or damaging at least 25 houses and injuring two persons. The twister narrowly missed an elementary school where 450 children huddled against a wall.

A 15-year-old boy died yesterday in the Bronx Youth House, 1221 Spotfford Avenue, where he had been confined as a juvenile delinquency suspect after a robbery investigation. Ralph Green, of 110 W. 133d Street, was pronounced dead, apparently of a heart attack, in the institution's infirmary at 9:15 A.M.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 19 Rutgers celebrated the 100th anniversary of its first baseball game with Princeton today by downing the Tigers, 9-2. The game was stopped after six innings because of cold and darkness.
The city was promised $50,000 yesterday to pay for a small outdoor restaurant in Central Park that will be "elegant" but "popularly priced."
BALTIMORE, April 19 One of the Government's most outspoken defenders of the Federal antipoverty drive and one of its most abrasive critics clashed in debate here today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) The Boeing Company and the International Association of Machinists settled a contract dispute early today and ended the threat of a second strike at Cape Kennedy's space complex. A strike by electricians is already underway.

H. Richard Heilman was elected president and chief underwriting officer of the Insurance Company of North America and Edmund L. Zalinski was named president of the Life Insurance Company of America, its affiliate, at a meeting yesterday in Philadelphia.

A $1-million libel suit brought by Dr. Linus C. Pauling against William F. Buckley Jr. was dis- missed yesterday by State Supreme Curt Justice Samuel J. Silverman after the case had been before a jury for six weeks.

THE 1965-66 concert season is approaching its end, and last night in Carnegie Hall the National Orchestral Association gave the fourth and last program in its series. Two interesting works occupied the first half of the evening Franz Berwald's Symphony No. 5 in C (the "Singuliere"), and a new Piano Concerto by the Mexican composer, Blas Galindo.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The Office of Education told five Southern colleges today that they might lose their Federal aid for failing to comply with the 1964 Civil Rights Act. It was the first time the Government had threatened to move against colleges.
A mild-mannered former male nurse admitted yesterday that he had obtained a New York State certificate to teach by forging a college transcript and the names of registrars.
WASHINGTON, April 19 Representative Leonard Farb stein said today that most of the elected Democratic leaders of his Manhattan Congressional District favored his renomination.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 19 Dr. Mohammed Hatta, who resigned as Vice President in a dispute with President Sukarno nine years ago, charged today that the Government had been despotic and had "deviated from the right course."
SALT LAKE CITY, April 19 (AP) The three top-seeded players won first-round matches as the national handball tournament began yesterday at the Phoenix Y.M.C.A.

The American Conservatory Theater, the nonprofit group that was founded last spring by William Ball, artistic director, will demonstrate its progress at a special season from May 16 through June 11 at the Westport (Conn.) Country Playhouse.

The Boeing Company, which next Monday is asking its shareholders to approve a two-forone stock split, announced yesterday it planned to market 2,165,000 split shares through a rights offering to its shareholders.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)--The House Judiciary Committee today approved legislation that would permit narcotics addicts charged with Federal crimes to request commitment for medical treatment and rehabilitation instead of standing trial.
CENTER LINE, Mich., April 19 The Chrysler Corporation reported today a first-quarter net profit of $62.5-million, a record for the period.
GENEVA, April 19 The United States proposed to the nonnuclear nations today a sixpoint formula to speed their economic and social development by avoiding the wasting of their resources on arms races.
Julian Koenig, president of Papert, Koenig, Lois, Inc., was inducted into the Copywriters Hall of Fame last night but not without an argument.
AMERICAN officials, like the French before them, have watched with concern as Thich Tri Quang has again demonstrated that he is one of South Vietnam's most powerful leaders.
TOKYO, April 19 Japan's shipyards set a new record in orders received during fiscal 1965, which ended March 31, the Transport Ministry announced today.

MANHASSET, L.I., April 19 The engagement of Miss Nancy Jane Carnese to Robert A. Ferraro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ferraro, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Carnese.
NAPLES, April 19, (AP) Owen Davidson, a member of the Australian touring team, ousted Bill Tym of Peoria, Ill., 6-1, 6-0, today in the first round of the Naples international tennis tournament.
Don Brumfield could have stayed at Garden State Park yesterday and "ridden they card," meaning all nine races.

Max Rabinoff, an impresario who pioneered in presenting popular-priced opera in this country more than 30 years ago, died yesterday. He was pronounced dead at Roosevelt Hospital after collapsing from a heart attack near Broadway and 72d Street. He was 87 years old and lived at the Commander Hotel, 240 West 73d Street.
CHICAGO, April 19 A fan of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra is giving $2-million to renovate its 62-year-old home base, Orchestra Hall.
PARIS, April 19 A major new European industrial-financial complex is being formed under a share-exchange agreement signed today by two French and Belgian business empires and an important Paris bank.

BONN, April 19 The owner of the West German company that sold 5,570 bombs back to the United States at nearly 13 times the original purchase price emphatically denied today that he had engaged in sharp business practices.
The London stock market closed steady yesterday with mostly small net gains.
Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., announced yesterday in Fullerton, Calif., that its sales and earnings in the third fiscal quarter and first nine months rose sharply from 1965 levels.
The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the largest cigarette producer, announced here yesterday a strong increase in firstquarter sales, accompanied by a slight increase in profits.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 19 (AP) Twenty-eight rebel leftist legislators pushed their political revolt against President Jomo Kenyatta tonight and named former Vice President Oginga Odinga to lead them.

HOUSTON, April 19 (UPI) With the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion Ernie Terrell, and his expected challenger, Doug Jones, looking on, Cleveland Williams of Houston punched his way to a close but unanimous 10-round decision over Sonny Moore of Dallas tonight. Williams weighed 212 pounds to Moore's 210.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) Striking electricians agreed today to limit "temporarily" their pickets at the Cape Kennedy, Fla., space center to one entrance while the Government seeks to mediate their dispute.

Carl Rosen, president of the Puritan Fashions Corporation, was named president of the Educational Foundation for the Apparel Industries, and Melvin E. Dawley, president of Lord Taylor, was elected chairman at a meeting yesterday of the Fashion Institute of Technology.

With ashes still smoldering in their library, administrators and students at the Jewish Theological Seminary began yesterday a wet and tiring salvage job among the shelves where a fire had raged for six hours on Monday.
BOSTON, April 19 (AP) The Boston Red Sox beat the Detroit Tigers, 7-0, in the Patrots Day morning game for their first victory of the season today.

Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel conceded yesterday that he had "no evidence to submit to a grand jury" of political kickback payments under his predecessor, Frank D. O'Connor, now City Council President.

WASHINGTON, April 19 With his flair for low comedy and his gift for oratorical camouflage, Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois was at his ineffable best today, but all his art could not mask his differences with the House Republican leader, Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, on the...

OTTAWA, April 19 The Canadian Government announced today that it would review the conviction of Steven Truscott, who was sentenced to death in a rape-murder case seven years ago, when he was 14 years old.

The coldest measure of poverty in the richest city in America in the most prosperous year in our history is provided by the Welfare Department allocation in Mayor Lindsay's budget. He is asking for a total outlay of nearly two-thirds of a billion dollars, an increase of $129 million over the expenditure for this fiscal year.
MILLBROOK, N.Y., April 18 "Wow," breathed a bearded youth sprawled on a mattress as he viewed what was called a psychedelic film at Dr. Timothy F. Leary's neo-Bavarian retreat here last night.
The United States and Indonesia have agreed to begin a cultural exchange program as part of a broad effort to restore friendly relations.

DARIEN, Conn., April 19 Mr. and Mrs. Brainerd Richardson Taylor have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elia Vesta Taylor, to William Cameron Agee of New York. He is the son of Mrs. William Herman Agee of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Agee.
The duties of chief executive officer of the Ceco Corporation have been transferred to Elmer T. Gustafson, president, from Ned A. Ochiltree, chairman of the board and of the executive committee.
Sheila Copelan, actress, was found dead Monday in her apartment at 412 West End Avenue. Apparently she was the victim of a heart attack. She was 30 years old.
The country's major distillers were undecided yesterday whether to reduce liquor prices in the state or increase them in some other states to match current New York prices.

WASHINGTON, April 19 A large Soviet trawler fitted with electronic equipment spent at least two weeks observing United States naval efforts to recover the hydrogen bomb that was lost off the Spanish coast on Jan. 17.
Operating revenues of the Port of New York Authority during 1965 showed a net gain of 2.1 per cent over the previous year, it was reported yesterday.
BALTIMORE, April 19 (AP) Frank and Brooks Robinson helped Baltimore score nine runs in the first four innings, and the Orioles held on for a 14-8 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

For nearly a decade Bill Russell of the Boston Celtics has been recognized as one of the greatest players in professional basketball. His brilliant defensive play and his gifts as a natural team leader have helped the Celtics to win eight straight championships.
SEVILLE, Spain, April 19 (UPI) Mrs. John F. Kennedy emphatically denied reports today that she planned to marry Antonio Garrigues, Spanish Ambassador to the Vatican.

YONKERS, April 19 Wagering on Cardigan Bay in Thursday night's $50,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway was barred today. In last week's $100,000 International Pace, Cardigan Bay won easily and caused a record minus showpool of $32,896.20.

Dr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Patterson Jr. of 148 East 65th Street and Mount Kisco, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Patterson, to Ihor Sevcenko, son of Mrs. Ivan Sevcenko of London and the late Mr. Sevcenko.
WASHINGTON, April 19 New orders for durable goods rose sharply in March, indicating a continuation of boom forces in the economy.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) A Commerce Department official rejected today suggestions that the Federal highway program be slowed as an anti-inflation step.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 19 Left-wing students of the Middle East Technical University and Ankara University demonstrated against the United States today on the arrival of Secretary of State Dean Rusk. He is here to attend a meeting of the Central Treaty Organization's Council of Ministers.

WASHINGTON, April 19 The head of the American Geophysical Union described today new evidence that surface features of the earth, such as the Rocky Mountains and Great Plains, are related to peculiar- ties of the earth's interior that reach down hundreds of miles.
The General Electric Company and Time, Inc., named yesterday the officials who will head the jointly owned educational enterprise the concerns announced last November.
A trailer truck carrying photographic equipment belonging to the Federal Government was stolen in Brooklyn last night. The police described the cargo as "very important."
WASHINGTON, April 19 An Administration advocate of measures designed to expand the Foreign Service conceded at a Senate hearing today that they were unpopular among most United States diplomats.

WHITE PLAINS, April 19 Miss Diane F. Hecht, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Hecht of the Bronx, was married this evening to Joel Steven Feigenson, son of Mrs. Abraham Feigenson of White Plains and the late Mr. Feigenson.
OTTAWA, April 19 The Roman Catholic bishops of Canada announced plans today for an international interfaith congress in Toronto next year.
MEXICO CITY, April 19 Mexico urged Latin America today to complete a treaty this year to ban nuclear arms from Latin America.
The city's water pumping station at Chelsea will resume operations a week from today, Edward C. Maguire, the president of the Board of Water Supply, said yesterday.

LONDON, April 19 Realigning his forces for what is expected to be a long period in opposition, Edward Heath, the Conservative party leader, today cut the size of his shadow cabinet and dropped five former Ministers.
Iona, led by Dave DeWitt and Joe Mitchell, scored its first Metropolitan Baseball Conference victory yesterday by downing City College, 4-1, at McCombs Dam Park.

"FOR me, politics has a fascination and excitement which make it simultaneously addictive and nourishing. I believe it is good for the people in it and, despite all those who criticize politics and politicians, for the country."

SAIGON, April 19 The United States Air Force has drastically reduced the number and intensity of its bombing raids against Communist forces in South Vietnam over the last 13 days because of a shortage of parts for bombs and other explosive ordnance, informed sources said today.
France's objections to the workings of the present international monetary system based on the gold-exchange standard have been restated by Michel Debre, the French Minister of Economy and Finance.

A proposal for shifting most of the sidewalks of the crosstown streets in the heart of Manhattan's garment center to the ground floor space of buildings along those streets was put before Mayor Lindsay yesterday by Mrs. Constance Baker Motley.

WASHINGTON, April 19 The Johnson Administration welcomed today Senator Mike Mansfield's call for a Vietnam peace conference in Asia, but it hedged the endorsement by insisting that the Saigon Government would have to represent South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 19 High-ranking Administration officials told women Democrat- ic campaign workers today there was a "very good chance" of avoiding a tax increase this year and no reason to fear a "swing toward Communism" or neutralism in South Vietnam.
My Fair Lady" at the Criterion Theater.
The Government-imposed ceiling on the domestic-producer copper price may soon be pierced.

ALBANY, April 19--The Legislature's top Democrat made it clear today that Mayor Lindsay's transportation unity plan may be scuttled if he insists on veto power over operations of the transit body it would create.
Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, the defending world chess champion, and his compatriot, Boris Spassky, drew their adjourned fourth match game in Moscow yesterday.

The Senate is expected to vote today on the constitutional amendment offered by Senator Everett Dirksen which would overturn the Supreme Court's reapportionment decision. The amendment would permit a state to apportion one house of its legislature on a basis other than population.
The "death of God" controversy has been a good thing because "it has required people to define their terms about God," according to Erwin D. Canham, editor-in-chief of The Christian Science Monitor.
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., reported yesterday a 22.1 per cent gain in earnings on a 4.7 per cent advance in sales in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31.

CHICAGO, April 19 (UPI) Willie Mays had four hits in five trips to the plate and batted in four runs to lead the San Francisco Giants to an 11-10 victory over Chicago in the Cubs' home opener before 15,396 today. It was the Giants' fourth straight victory and the Cubs' fourth straight defeat.
When Roosevelt Raceway opens May 25, patrons will find a new tote board in the infield for the second time in two years.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 19 Maj. Gen. Abdel Aziz Uqeili, once considered a possible candidate for the Presidency, has been eliminated from the Iraqi Cabinet and replaced as Defense Minister by Maj. Gen. Shaker Mahmoud Shukri, Iraqi Ambassador in Lon.
WASHINGTON, April 19 The political crisis in Saigon has clearly changed the tone of the American Government's statements on the war in that country.
There was both good news and bad news yesterday for the Alleghany Corporation's shareholders.

KANSAS CITY, April 19 (UPI) Tony Oliva dropped two fly balls in right field in each of the first two innings to hand Kansas City two unearned runs and enable the Athletics to record their first victory of the season tonight, a 3-2 home-opening triumph over the Minnesota Twins. The Athletics, who had lost five straight, sent the Twins to their third straight loss.

Democrats gathering here for a $100-a-plate fund-raising dinner of the State Democratic Committee tonight are expected to lard their public speechs with expressions of confidence about the chances of unseating Governor Rockefeller in the fall. But in private talks, party...
John H.F. Cordes, the only man in the New York Police Department's history to win its Medal of Honor twice, died yesterday afternoon in the Hollywood (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old.
SELMA, Ala., April 19--The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee is urging Negroes to boycott the Democratic primary on May 3 in several of Alabama's predominantly Negro counties.
BOSTON, April 19 Kenji Kimihara, a Japanese clerk, won the Boston Marathon, the world's most famous foot race, leading his countrymen to a sweep of the first four places today.
BALTIMORE, April 19 (UPI) Six Johns Hopkins students were sentenced to 60 days in jail and fined $50 each today for protesting the war in Vietnam in a demonstration March 28.
The American Stock Exchange marked time yesterday on which way to move as volume fell to its lowest level in almost two weeks.
CHESTER, England, April 19--The gruesome Pennine Moors murder trial opened today in a hushed courtroom before a bewigged judge in red Tobes and packed galleries.

THE first Championship races of the season for the New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America will be run Saturday on the Lime Rock, Conn., course. A large entry has been filed and the action starts at 10 A.M. Registration and practice are scheduled for Friday. The
The bulls won an apparent victory in soybean trading yesterday as soybeans reached the $3-a-bushel level in futures trad ing for the first time this season.

Frederic R. Pratt, president of the Boys' Club of New York and a partner in Charles Pratt Co., a family estate management concern, died yesterday of a heart attack in his office at 45 Wall Street. He was 58 years old and lived on Skunks Misery Road, Locust Valley, L.I.
LONDON, April 19 (AP)--Sophia Loren revealed today that she and Carlo Ponti were secretly married 10 days ago at Sevres, France.
Two top-level executive changes and record first-quarter sales and earnings were announced yesterday at the annual stockholders meeting at the Biltmore Hotel of the Interchemical Corporation.

The 40th anniversary of the founding of the Westminster Choir College by the late John Finley Williamson was observed at Town Hall last night with a concert sung by the Westminster Choir. The 40-voice ensemble was directed by George Lynn.
SAIGON, April 19 The Buddhist leader Thich Tri Quang has told his followers that Vietnam is "oppressed by two pressures the Communists and the Americans."

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission ordered Merck Co., Inc., of Rahway, N.J., tonight to discontinue what the commission called false claims of germ-killing and pain-relieving properties for its Sucrets and Children's Sucrets throat lozenges.
DETROIT, April 19 Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh, waging an uphill fight for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, advocated today "the building of a neutral buffer state" in Vietnam.

THE Long Island Rail Road will once again help the metropolitan area rod and reel set get to the scene of the angling action when the Captree State Park fishermen's special begins its daily run on Saturday.

SAIGON, April 19 Two United States Navy jet fighterbombers hit the 24,000-kilowatt Uongbi power plant near Haiphong, North Vietnam's principal port, with 1,000-pound bombs in a surprise attack late yesterday.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 19 (Reuters) A two-week-old strike that virtually paralyzed Jamaica's mail services appeared to be ending today following an order to the island's postal workers to return to work.

WHITE PLAINS, April 20 A judgment for $10,527,763 was granted here today to the Carvel Corporation and affiliated concerns because of charges of fraud made against them in antitrust suits from 1959 through last year.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., April 20 (UPI) A national organization of physicians charged Henry Ford 2d today with "patent deception" and overlooking "common sense" in his defense of the industry's safety accomplishments.
Three errors by New York University's baseball team in the third inning allowed Queens College to score four runs and defeat the Violets, 5 2, yesterday at Ohio Field, the Bronx.
GROSSINGER, N.Y., April 20 Former boxing champions often are employed by promoters to act as shills for an approaching championship fight. Thus, their comments are to be regarded in that light.

YONKERS, April 20 Cardigan Bay and Bret Hanover in the same race, the dream of all harness racing breed improvers, especially those connected with track management, will become a reality at Yonkers Raceway on May 20.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.9 per cent in the week ended April 16, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

SINGAPORE, Thursday, April 21 (Reuters) A special military court in Jakarta last night sentenced an army lieutenant, Ngadimo, to death for his part in the abortive coup last October, the Jakarta Radio reported today.
The New York Mets were spared the hazards of batting against Bob Gibson yesterday, when their game with the St. Louis Cardinals was postponed until this afternoon because of cold and drizzle.
WASHINGTON, April 20 President Johnson was defended today against criticism by Senator Robert F. Kennedy of the Administration's proposed cutbacks in domestic spending.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) President Johnson announced today that he would award the Medal of Honor posthumously tomorrow to Pfc. Milton L. Olive 3d, a 19-yearold Chicago Negro who was killed in action in Vietnam.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20 The Curtis Publishing Company is about to begin a corporate expansion program and talent search, stockholders were told here today.

HOLLYWOOD, April 20 The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., has completed its strongest first quarter on record and expects record sales and earnings for the year, William S. Paley, chairman, told the company's annual meeting today.
Ignoring pleas from parents, the Board of Education voted last night to discontinue Public School 69, a small, antiquated school in mid-Manhattan that has long been the pride of its community.

The short-interest position of issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 11,096,067 shares on April 15, from a total of 10,642,174 shares in mid-March acording to figures released by the exchange yesterday.
BOSTON, April 20 The Right Rev. Lawrence J. Riley resigned today as rector at St. John's Seminary where eight students were expelled last month after demonstrating for academic freedom.

Jack A. Tishman, a realestate man who helped develop the Northern Boulevard area of Queens in the 1930's, died last night at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 21 East 87th Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 Premier Jens Otto Krag of Denmark asked Secretary General Thant today to take a new initiative for peace in Vietnam.

LOS ANGELES, April 20 Donald Douglas Jr., president of the Douglas Aircraft Company, discounted today the significance of the record $525million contract awarded by Pan American World Airways to the rival Boeing Company of Seattle for 25 of the projected 490-passenger 747 transport planes.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Tuesday the level it reached on Monday which was 112.5.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) President Johnson, who has campaigned to cut the number of Government publications, gave his blessing today to a new one.
COMMACK, L.I., April 20 A court battle portrayed as a round in man's struggle with machines was won by a man here today.
SAIGON, April 20 For the third day in a row, United States fighter-bombers penetrated North Vietnamese defenses yesterday to strike near the Hanoi-Haiphong region.

Sales and earnings of the United Fruit Company during the next five years are expected to increase at the rate of about 10 per cent a year, John M. Fox, president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Boston.

Theodore Mann, operator of the Circle in the Square, 159 Bleecker Street, said yesterday that he would rent the theater to an independent attraction for the first time in 16 years. A double bill, consisting of "Fitz" and "Biscuit," will open there the week of May 16.
TORONTO, April 20 The possibility of an increase in the price of nickel was raised today by the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., at its annual meeting.

MOSCOW, April 20 Enthusiastic cheering and applause in the Theater of Satire Monday night suggested one reason that Aleksandr Tvardovsky remains in his post as editor of the liberal literary journal Novy Mir strong support from Soviet intellectuals against criticism by hard-line ideologists.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 20 Squads of Salisbury riot police were called out last night to deal with disturbances in a number of African townships surrounding the capital.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 20 In the first decision of its kind in the state, a Superior Court judge restricted today the operations of a factory until it stopped violating air-pollution laws.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company reported yesterday record firstquarter net income of $29.9million, or 56 cents a share, compared with $22,991,000, or 43 cents a share, in the initial three months last year. Sales rose 15.9 per cent to a new nigh of $263.5-million from the $227.4-million a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) President Johnson's future son-in-law, Airman Patrick J. Nugent, may go to work for the LBJ radio-television interests in Texas after his wedding, informed sources said today.

SEVILLE, Spain, April 20 Mrs. John F. Kennedy saw this week some of the sights that most tourists in this country seek including bullfights and flamenco dances but her first visit to Spain could not be called a typical one.

WASHINGTON, April 20 President Johnson asked Congress today to vote legislation that would give the Government permanent authority to sell to private investors billions of dollars worth of mortgages and other loans held by the Government.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 20 Juan Bosch, presidential candidate of the Dominican Revolutionary party, rejected yesterday the unsolicited support of a Castroite movement. His action caused what appeared to be the first serious split in the ranks of the socalled constitutionalist rebels.
ALBANY, April 20 State Senator John H. Hughes, who suggested last year that Governor Rockefeller be replaced by Senator Jacob K. Javits believes that it is "too late" now to attempt such a move.
Governor Rockefeller's staff has brought together experts on organized crime from all over the country for secret meetings officially described as "'Apalachin Conferences' of their own."

The Trianon Ballroom at the New York Hilton was decorated with ostrich plumes of red, black and white last night for the fourth Bal Rouge et Noir. The ball is expected to raise about $40,000 for Irvington House, a privately supported agency for treatment and research in rheumatic fever and allied diseases in children.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) The Daughters of the American Revolution expressed fear today that United States military forces were being weakened by "crucial shortages," armament cutbacks and allied trading with the enemy.

WASHINGTON, April 20 Here are the winners of this year's Academy (East) Awards as announced last night amid appropriate weeping, cries of exultation and expressions of gratitude at the Academy (East's) regular Award banquet: Best song used in 1965-66 political production "La Marseillaise" from "The Guy Who Threw the Americans Out in the Cold," produced by Charles de Gaulle for Yankee Va t'en Cie. of Paris.

Senator Mansfield's proposal for Vietnam peace negotiations in Japan or Burma seems destined for as negative a Communist response as previous efforts. Still, the proposal was worth making and it was important for the Administration to welcome it.

A Federal grand jury investigating racketeering and violence in the private garbage collection industry in the metropolitan area indicted two owners of major refuse companies yesterday on charges of perjury.
The most accomplished and best-matched group of oarsmen probably ever assembled in a college crew has been broken up by the graduation of six of its eight members.

Mayor Lindsay told the City Council yesterday at the opening of hearings on his controversial $520-million tax program that "no more destructive effect can be imagined" than exempting commuters from his proposed city income tax.

Both sides in the complex newspaper merger dispute agreed yesterday that a strike appeared inevitable, and that it would prevent the new publishing company the World Journal Tribune, Inc. from beginning operations next Monday as it had planned.

WASHINGTON, April 20 The Peace Corps, in line with President Johnson's policy of emphasizing food production in the United States assistance program in India, plans to increase its contingent there from the current total of 700 volunteers to 1,600 by the end of this year.
A Federal judge criticized the Government yesterday for what he called "arbitrary, capricious and unconscionable" actions in the seizure of $247,500 from a French citizen.
The Barnard College faculty adopted yesterday several changes in curriculum, including a reduction from five to four in the number of courses usually taken each semester.

The Bronx County District Attorney's office has agreed to drop charges of extortion and bribery against three patrolmen provided they resign from the force. A fourth man, a former patrolman, has agreed to plead guilty next Thursday to an extortion charge, as a misdemeanor.

A study of the many issues involved in automobile safety standards will be presented on a special hour-long news program over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network. "Crash Project the Search for Auto Safety" will be televised in color at 10 P.M. Friday, May 13.

BOSTON, April 20 (UPI) Tony Conigliaro, last year's American League home run champion, hit his first of the season today to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers in a game played in a steady drizzle.

WITHIN a week or two the Lafayette College baseball team is expected to post its 300th victory under the coaching guidance of Charlie Gelbert, who was once a World Series hero and a star with the St. Louis Cardinals and other major league teams.
NEW HAVEN, April 20 Mr. and Mrs. Anthony DeLaurentis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janett DeLaurentis, to Paul Winston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney C. Winston of New York.
WASHINGTON, April 20 The United States informed Israel this week that it was prepared to resume food and economic aid.
SIGN OF THE PRAYING TIGER, by Ben Lucien Burman, drawings by Alice Caddy (New American Library, $4.95). A novel about a Kentucky mountaineer on a Malayan island.
Diversification and expansion developments are enhancing the sales and earnings of a number of chemical companies, according to the first-quarter reports released yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP) Striking soft coal miners returned to the pits in Illinois today, but 48,000 in five other states stayed out.

The governing principle of our military assistance program has been and is that the vital interests of this country in the defense of the free world are dependent upon the strength of the entire free world, and not merely upon the strength of the United States.
Mayor Lindsay proposed the establishment of a city foundation for the arts and humanities yesterday.
Attendance in the Broadway theaters during this year's Easter period was better than it was last year, showmen reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) Senator Mondale accused the Ford Motor Company yesterday of deliberately camouflaging possible safety hazards involved in the recall of 30,000 of its 1966 models.
The election of Donald C. Frisbee as president of the Pacific Power and Light Company was announced yesterday at the annual stockholder meeting in Portland, Ore.

Warren Miller, an author who won from James Baldwin the tribute that he had written "one of the finest novels about Harlem that had ever come my way" died of lung cancer yesterday at his home at 515 East 85th Street. He was 44 years old and, until recently, was literary editor of The Nation.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., April 20 School officials here began searching for a high school today because of the disapproval in a referendum last night of a state plan for merging two school districts.

MEXICO CITY, April 20 (Reuters) Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela made it clear today that they would sign a treaty to prohibit nuclear weapons in Latin America only if Cuba took part and if the nu clear powers guaranteed the region.
Gains by copper shares were the feature in an otherwise dull and narrowly mired session on the London stock market yesterday.

Miss Penelope Le Fanu, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. G.E.H. Lee Fanu of South Brent, England, was married yesterday to Benjamin Maugham of London, vice president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency.

MASTER BERNARD ZUCKERMAN of New York, the opening specialist, obtained a solid lead over Jan Pamiljens of Brooklyn when Pamiljens dubiously captured a pawn in their game in the recent New York Open. This led to a triple first-place tie, with Zuckerman sharing the honors with Arthur Bisguier of Yonkers and Ivan Theodorovich of Toronto.
Miss Marjorie Lewin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Lewin of New York, was married yesterday evening to Mervin Ross, son of Mrs. Sam Ross of New York and the late Mr. Ross.

WASHINGTON, April 20 A bipartisan band of liberals thwarted for the second time today the efforts of Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois to nullify by constitutional amendment the oneman, one-vote ruling of the Supreme Court on state legislative apportionment.
PORTLAND, Ore., April 20 The American Association of Colleges has chosen Richard Howard Sullivan, president of Reed College since 1956, as its new president.
The beleaguered blue chips finally came to life yesterday as the stock market rallied sharply in active trading.

THE Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club, which has ex isted for eight years without members, officers, dues or bylaws and only the attraction of many specialists talking on canine affairs to hold the group together, yesterday took a step to acquire all those things at Luchow's Restaurant.

BONN, April 20 Several foreign companies, including the Continental Oil Company of the United States, are trying to take control of Deutsche Erdol, A.G., the West German oil and coal mining company, according to reports making the rounds in financial circle here.

Now that the stock market is booming and prices have risen sharply for growth-type stocks, this is a good time for a parent to consider avoiding some high capital-gains taxes and cutting dividend income by giving stocks to his children.

WASHINGTON, April 21 The Justice Department announced today that it would make no attempt, under the antitrust laws, to block the proposed merger of The New York Journal-American, The World Telegram and The Sun and The Herald Tribune.

A new seven-week sewing series will be given free by Gimbels starting at 2:30 P.M. Monday. Those who prefer may take morning lessons that start at 10 A.M. Wednesday or evening lessons at 5 or 7 P.M. on Thursday.
The 72-year-old owner of the Hickory House restaurant was accused last night of having hired a muscle man to squeeze $3,000 from a slow-paying bookie.
Prices advanced yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as trading resumed the pattern of high turnover that has prevailed in recent weeks.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 20 The Rev. Dr. Fred Hoskins, minister of the Garden City Community Church and former co-president of the United Church of Christ, died today at Nassau Hospital, Mineola. Dr. Hoskins, who was 60 years old, suffered a heart attack at a church staff meeting yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, April 20 The John Birch Society has attacked Representative Ogden R. Reid in letters sent to Westchester County Republican committee men who will meet here tomorrow night to designate candidates.
Czechoslovakia has "officially" emerged as a recognized film-maker with the awarding of an Oscar for last year's best foreign-language picture, "The Shop on Main Street."

A bird in shining bronze stood briefly in the spotlight last night and when it left amid a spatter of applause after a winning bid of $140,000, an auction record for a piece of sculpture had been set.

THE woman who once said that she never went to the West Side except to take the boat to Europe might be lured there these days. Word is getting around about an attractive shop and a promising two-girl fashion "industry" in the neighborhood of West End Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) The Justice Department said today that the Chicago Title and Trust Company had agreed to dispose of more than $8-million in assets as a result of the first Government case in which the Clayton Antitrust Act was applied to mergers in the insurance field.

Puccini's "La Boheme," Bizet's "Carmen," Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" and Verdi's "Aida" will be the four operas given by the Metropolitan Opera at the first Newport (R.I.) Opera Festival July 12 to 16.

DETROIT, April 20 (UPI) More than 2,100 students boycotted a predominantly Negro high school today protesting "substandard education." They set up a picket line and vowed not to return until the principal was ousted.

WASHINGTON, April 20 Shock waves from a nuclear explosion fired almost a half mile below an Aleutian island last year threw lakes and ponds into the air, according to a moving picture record shown here today.

The annual spring Polonaise cocktail dance for the benefit of Polish Mutual Assistance, a nonprofit organization aiding Polish refugees in this country, will take place Sunday afternoon at El Morocco.

Meeting on the "Latest Techniques in National and International Use of Computers in Police Work," New York Metropolitan chapter, American Society for Industrial Security, Top of the Sixes, 666 Fitth Avenue, noon. Speaker: Deputy Inspector John J. O'Neill, New York City Police Department.
OTTAWA, April 20 Canada announced today a wildlife series of six coins to commemorate the 100th anniversary of Canadian Confederation next year. They will be issued at the start of 1967.

LOS ANGELES, April 20 (UPI) The Boston Celtics broke open a close game with a third quarter onslaught and continued to a 120-106 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight to take a 2-1 lead in the National Basketball Association final playoffs.

Helen M. Harris resigned yesterday as chairman of the city's screening board for antipoverty proposals, charging that "the situation has deteriorated well past the point where I can hope to retrieve it, and my usefulness is at an end."

LIFE has often been something of an afterthought to Ralph Craig, a kindly and gentle sportsman who gained enduring fame at the age of 23 and is now seeking a less measurable distinction at the age of 76. Destiny, it would seem, pushes him into these things.

HOUSTON, April 20 (AP) Al Ferrara drove in two runs with a homer and a single and Claude Osteen pitched his third straight complete game victory tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers downed Houston, 3-2.

At 1:10 P.M. yesterday there were three customers in a branch of the First National City Bank on Broadway at 111th Street. Three minutes later the bank was jammed with people bent on closing their accounts. In a line outside were 250 supporters.
Into the Waterfront Commission's hiring hall on Hicks Street in Brooklyn yesterday tramped 370 dockworkers for the traditional early-morning shape-up.
WASHINGTON, April 20 Robert H. Fleming, the new deputy press secretary at the White House, has complained that some Washington reporters are not doing their jobs "very well."

Gerardo A. Re and his son, Gerard F. Re, former American Stock Exchange specialists who are seeking a new trial, moved yesterday to disqualify United States District Judge Dudley B. Bonsal from further participation in the court proceeding.
COLORADO SPRINGS, April 20 (AP) The nerve center of the North American continent's air defense system was moved today to a new underground location deep inside a mountain.

CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) Advisers for a group of dissident shareholders of the Crucible Steel Company of America contended today that the present management enlisted outside help to prevent a possible take-over by dissatisfied stockholders.

STONINGTON, Conn., April 20 Mr. and Mrs. Francis Hallowell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adele Livingston Hallowell, to Peter Jacob Maria de Vries, son of Mig. and Mrs. Piet de Vries-Brenninkmeyer of Sneek, the Netherlands.

Marcelita Lopez Kabayao, a pianist from the Philippines who made her debut here in 1948 at the age of 14 and played here again in 1950, returned last night to Carnegie Hall with a long taxing program.

The long-rumored move of the New York Cotton Exchange to introduce a new and decidedly different futures contract will soon become a reality. The exchange said yesterday its membership had approved a plan to begin trading in futures for frozen orange concentrate.

WASHINGTON, April 20 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff disclosed today that he would ask United States distributors of foreign-made automobiles for reports of mechanical defects in cars sold in this country.
LAST night at the old Metropolitan Opera House, the Russian ballerina Maya Plisetskaya danced Kitri in the New York premiere of the Petipa and Gorsky ballet "Don Quixote."
A new weekly subscription theater called Children's Cinema, Inc., will start at 11 A.M. April 30 with "White Mane" and "The Owl and the Pussycat" at the Bleecker Street Cinema, 170 Bleecker Street.
Four men, including a father and son, have been arrested in Brooklyn and Massapequa, L.I., in an alleged loan-shark racket.
Where and how to build adequate housing for the city's poor ignited a debate yesterday before the City Planning Commission.

The President of the American Jewish Committee yesterday denounced as an "antiSemitic attack" the recently published opinion of Bishop Luigi Carli of Segni, Italy, that Judaism, as a religion, carried the "judgment of condemnation by God."

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) A close associate of Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that money raised for the Senator at two testimonial dinners represented tax-free gifts to help him meet the expenses of public office.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 20 (UPI) Three former champions and Mrs. Harton S. Semple survived two rounds today to gain the semi-finals of the 64th North-South women's amateur golf tournament at the Pinehurst Country Club.

SIX of North America's greatest bridge players will fly this morning from New York to London to begin a European tour during which they will play in two world championships teams and pairs and a high-level invitation tournament.
PITTSBURGH, April 20 Officials of the Consolidation Coal Company are concerned by the bituminous coal strike, they indicated at the annual meeting today.
VIENNA, April 20 An economic agreement with the Common Market is Austria's "most urgent" task, Chancellor Josef Klaus told the country's new Parliament today.
Forty policemen made a doorto-door search today in a Brooklyn neighborhood for a 7-monthold girl reported to have been kidnapped from her crib.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., April 20 Brooklyn College won its third straight baseball game today, beating the New York Aggies; 7-3, in a Knickerbocker League contest called after seven innings because of darkness.
HAVANA, April 20 (AP) Premier Fidel Castro asserted today that the United States had failed to make the Alliance for Progress work but that Cuba was making economic strides without United States aid.
BURBANK, Calif., April 20 (AP) Willie Mosconi, who has been world billiards champion 15 times, still held the lead today in the 1966 world invitation pocket billiards tourney.

Extremist elements in Alabama's civil rights movement have adopted a rule-or-ruin attitude toward the forthcoming Democratic primary there that can only produce frustration and defeat for the state's Negroes.

DETROIT, April 20 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has cut back its 1966 expansion program by "about $200-million," Frederick R. Kappel, chairman, told a news conference here today prior to the company's annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 20 Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen denied today there was any split between him and the House minority leader, Gerald R. Ford, on whether there had been "shocking mismanagement" of the Vietnam war.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 20--Sam J. Harris, a leader in community affairs for more than 40 years and a former performer in vaudeville and minstrel shows, died today in Greenwich Hospital. He was 82 years old.

Textron, Inc., cleared $8,751,000, equivalent to 78 cents a share on sales of $247,038,000 in the first quarter, Rupert C. Thompson, chairman, announced yesterday at the annual meeting in Providence, R.I.
Roy M. Cohn announced yesterday that he had agreed "to satisfy" a $700,000 judgment he owes two brothers for breaching a contract in 1961 when he controlled the Lionel Corporation.

Dr. D. Vincent Manson, assistant curator of mineralogy at the American Museum of Natural History, studied the twopound piece of blackened, micaflecked rock, and the Sanitation Department men who had found it held their breath.

A total of 23,500 square feet in the two buildings that occupy the west blockfront of Park Avenue South, between 31st and 32d Streets; has been leased by the Symphonic Radio and Electronic Corporation.
An Assistant State Attorney General, whose duties included investigating frauds, and two Long Island lawyers were accused here yesterday of trying to shake down the owners of a book club for $15,000.

The University Settlement will celebrate its 80th anniversary at a dinner dance on Sunday at the New York Hilton. Mayor Lindsay will then present the settlement's diplomate of humanities award to Representative Emanuel Celler.
Dr. James Hans Licht, an internist at 500A Grand Street, where he also had his home, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. His age was 65.
William M. White Jr., a 26-year-old executive, was elected yesterday by the Colorado Milling and Elevator Company to the new posts of chairman of the board and of the executive committee.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 20 A Ghanaian businessman who was sentenced to hard labor before the fall of President Kwame Nkrumah, testified at a public inquiry today that he had given Mr. Nkrumah $280,000, a bulletproof automobile valued at more than $30,000 and another car that cost more than $3,000.
PARIS, April 20 Utility workers blacked out most of France today for the second time this year. Railroad workers plan to walk out tomorrow for the fourth time.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 20 Two members of the opposition in the Transkei South Africa's only Bantustan or all-black homeland appeared in court today on charges of having plotted to kill Chief Kaiser Mantanzima, chief minister of the Transkei.

Paperboard production rose 1 per cent to 420,900 tons in the week ended April 16, from 413,324 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay's plan to consolidate and unify the city's transportation agencies is so strongly in the public interest that differences of opinion about some of its details should not be permitted to balk its basic objective. The need to bring order and rational planning into a field where in the past a half-dozen different agencies have functioned independently and often at cross-purposes is imperative.

WASHINGTON, April 20 Arthur B. Krim of New York, president of United Artists Corporation and a close friend of President Johnson, was put in charge of the Democratic party's financial operations today.

The liquor industry suffered a defeat when the Supreme Court upheld the New York State liquor law designed to bring about price reductions for liquor. Yet the Court's decision does not automatically bring consumers a victory in the form of lower liquor prices.
Seventeen persons were injured, one seriously, in a twobus accident yesterday morning at 113th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

KINGS POINT, L.I., April 20 Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clements have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Lynn Clements, to Paul David Finkelstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Finkelstein of Great Neck.
BUCHENWALD, Germany, April 13 The rubble here has simply been leveled with a bulldozer. Plaques mark the various barracks. The original crematory still stands.

THE Brooklyn Philharmonia, now 11 years old, has be come a musical adornment of New York City as well as of its home borough. It is only right that it should show itself off regularly on the Manhattan side of the East River, and it did so again last night for the third year in a row, appearing in Philharmonic Hall.
GREAT NECK, L.I., April 20 Frederick G. Weisser, a lawyer in New York City and Manhasset since 1918, died Monday in his home at 85 Maple Drive, Great Neck Estates. His age was 71.
ROME, April 20 (UPI) A commission of national Olympic organizations voted 6-5 today to set up a new body that might be a challenge to the International Olympic Committee.

Gannett Herwig, a partner in the architectural concern of LaPierre, Litchfield Partners, 8 West 40th Street, died of a heart attack Monday at his home at 11 Garden Place, Brooklyn. He was 69 years old.
A new service has been set up to help advertisers measure their potential audiences in trade shows, direct mailing and interview surveys and so to spend their dollars more wisely.
Once again, the bond market yesterday went off in several directions at once.

"Fodor Shell Travel Guides USA," a series of eight regional guidebooks to the United States, will be issued on May 16 by Fodor's Modern Guides, and the Shell Oil Company. Eugene Fodor, who is known for 24 books on foreign countries, is the general editor of the new guide. McKay is the distributor.
Applying a law that he said had not been used since 1883, a New York judge ordered a landlord yesterday to post a $1,000 peace bond.

CLEVELAND, April 20 Misery piled upon misery for the New York Yankees tonight as they took possession of last place in the American League by losing, 4-2, to the Cleveland Indians, who are undefeated in six games.
WASHINGTON, April 20 Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor ordered a formal investigation today into the death of a 21-year-old Army inductee, Donald D. Dilworth Jr., at Fort Dix, N.J.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 20 (AP) Joseph E. Ridder, chairman of the board of Ridder Publications, Inc., of New York City, died today at Good Samaritan Hospital after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

PARIS, April 20 Premier Georges Pompidou charged today that United States nuclear strategy "condemned Europe to destruction" and was adopted in violation of a unanimous decision by the 15 members of the North Atlantic alliance.

SINCE camp threatens to give cartooning a bad name, it's a pleasure to welcome back to New York "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying." This Frank Loesser-Abe Burrows collaboration, which was revived at the City Center last night, reminds us that it's possible to laugh with comic strips, and not just at them.

WASHINGTON, April 20 The House sustained President Johnson on a civil rights issue today, by approving his proposal for transfer of the Community Relations Service from the Department of Commerce to the Department of Justice.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 20 Protestant and Eastern Ortodox leaders took a "hard look" here today at the ecumenical movement and came up with a disquieting problem.

MILAN, Italy, April 20 (AP) A Milan court today convicted 36 defendants and acquitted 21 others in a mass trial of Austrians, Germans and Italians accused of terrorism in the Alto Adige (South Tyrol) region, which belonged to Austria before World War I.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 20 If he could use ordinary political arithmetic in computing his chances, Lucius D. Amerson would be a heavy favorite to become one of Alabama's first Negro sheriffs since Reconstruction.

A LITTLE more care, thought and precision might have made "The Pleasure Girls" a fairly meritorious low-budget bundle from Britain. The film skidded into the World Theater yesterday and kept skidding! That's the real trouble. Pity.
The spot rate on the British pound was unchanged at $2.7931 in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 20 Spokesmen for the scheduled airlines defended today the recent narrowing of air lanes over the Atlantic that airline pilots have called unsafe.
CHESTER, England, April 20 The prosecution introduced evidence today of alleged torture and sexual perversion in the Pennine Moors murder trial.
BALTIMORE, April 20 (AP) Andy Etchebarren and Luis Aparicio helped the Baltimore Orioles gain a 6-3 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.
DACCA, Pakistan, April 19 Growing pressure for full autonomy in isolated East Pakistan has confronted the Government of Field Marshal Mohammad Ayub Khan with a grave political crisis.
One explanation why sane men continue to be drawn into the always risky motion picture industry is contained in the notice, sent out this week, of the 20th Century-Fox annual stockholders' meeting.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 Albert F. Bender Jr. of the United States mission to the United Nations has been appointed Deputy High Commissioner for Refugees.
Merger talks are being held by the Riegel Paper Corporation and the Oxford Paper Company, officials of the two companies announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 Four reasons account in varying degree for the refusal of the Senate once again to submit a constitutional amendment to the states removing from the Supreme Court its asserted power to require that the districts which elect members of each branch of the state legislatures contain an approximately equal number of eligible voters.
"I can't believe it!," 16-yearold Twila Perry squealed over the telephone yesterday afternoon.

Mayor Lindsay, who has created a great stir on Wall Street with his plan for raising the stock-transfer tax levied by New York State, will wear a new hat on the night of June 16 at the Americana Hotel.
City Hall, that popular gathering spot for New York's outraged citizenry, was in a state of virtual siege yesterday.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy has quietly invited half a dozen Democratic contenders for Governor to a breakfast meeting today to try to work out a unified action program on major legislation still to be disposed of in Albany.

MIAMI, April 20--After a numbers racket investigation, the Dade County grand jury has indicted Sheriff T.A. Buchanan on charges of perjury and failure to report a $25,000 campaign contribution. Gov. Haydon Burns suspended Mr. Buchanan, as Florida law requires, pending disposition of the charges.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., April 20 Victor J. Cevasco, senior vice president and a former director of Albert Frank-Guenther Law, Inc., New York advertising and public relations agency, died today in his home at 400 Heights Road here after a long illness. He was 80 years old.
RICHMOND, April 20 The Reynolds Metals Company at its annual meeting here today reported record first-quarter net profits of $14,454,000 on sales of $195,616,000, also a record.

LONDON, April 20 NonCommunist diplomats, and especially those of the United States, were taken to task today for failure to keep up with their Communist colleagues in wining and dining the politically uncommitted diplomats of Asia and Africa.

The Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund announced yesterday that it would go through with its annual plan to give underprivileged youngsters from the metropolitan area summer vacations in the country despite the outcome of the merger negotiations.

Trainers of leading candidates for the $100,000 added Wood Memorial for 3-year-olds adjusted their sights at Aqueduct yesterday for Saturday's fixture, the east's traditional prelude to the Kentucky Derby.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 20 Kurdish insurgent leaders have sent to President Abdel Rahman Arif of Iraq their conditions for negotiating with the Government on settlement of the Kurdish question, informed sources said today.
RALEIGH, Tenn. When Shelby Foote, the Civil War historian, discusses French cooking or the victuals of the War Between the States it is with approximately the same degree of enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) "People who dirty the water should pay to clean it up," Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today in defending the Administration's plan for combating water pollution.

NEW HAVEN, April 20?Ed Goldstone's triple with the bases filled broke a 6-6 tie and capped a six-run eighth-inning rally that enabled Yale to defeat Pennsylvania, 10-6, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game today.
"IN my beginning is my end," T.S. Eliot said in "East Coker." The beginnings embody the ends of Spain's vast sea borne empire as J.H. Parry presents them in this solid, salty book.
WASHINGTON, April 20 Recent fires aboard cruise ships carrying passengers out of United States ports were cited today as dictating the need for a "realistic insistence upon a measure of control."

TOKYO, Thursday, April 21 (AP) Communist China today branded as another "peace talks hoax" the latest United States proposals on Vietnam and re iterated that there could be no negotiations without American military withdrawal from South Vietnam and recognition of the Vietcong.
NAPLES, April 20 (AP) Marty Riessen and three other Americans won matches today in the Naples international tennis tournament.

MADRID, April 20 With direct Government censorship abolished by a 10-day-old law, leading newspapers in Madrid and Barcelona today provided extended coverage of disturbances at Barcelona University. Riot policemen were twice ordered to the campus yesterday.

For the first time in the history of the State Senate its proceedings will be televised live next week when it debates reform of New York's antiquated divorce law. We hope the telecast will prove the precursor of many future efforts to give New Yorkers as intimate a view of the lawmaking process as they would get if they had seats in the State Capitol at Albany.

Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate, 55 to 38, failed today to approve a proposed constitutional amendment to let the people of each state decide whether factors' other that population could be used in apportioning one branch of their legislature (a two-thirds majority was required for approval):

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 The United States and Britain protested vigorously today when a cablegram from the Foreign Minister of East Germany was incorporated in the record of the committee of 24 on colonialism.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., April 20 The biggest crowd in Garden State Park's 25year history is expected to attend the races tomorrow, but there won't be much money in the till from admissions.

Mr. and Mrs. T. Suffern Tailer of New York have announced the engagement of Mr. Tailer's daughter, Miss Toni Suffern Tailer, to Laird Kenneth Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Kenneth Smith of Oceanside, L.I.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP) Hank Aaron became the 12th player in major league history to reach the 400-homer mark when he hit two in the Atlanta Braves' 8-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

HAUTE couture in miniature from France, ap pliques from Spain, bright cottons and terry shifts from Denmark, poplin raincoats from Belgium and playclothes from Israel were among the 80 designs unpacked yesterday from orange, pink and yellow trunks as Ohrbach's introduced its collection of young imports from 10 countries.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) The Commerce Department reported today an 11 per cent rise in United States exports during March, raising the total for the first quarter of this year to $7.2-billion.

Two more Boeing 707 jetliners operated by the British Overseas Airways Corporation were grounded yesterday after inspections showed hairline cracks in their tail assemblies. The groundings brought to six the number of B.O.A.C. 707's taken out of service and forced the cancellation of at least seven flights between London and New York and the Far East, the company said.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., April 20 Dr. E. Clarence Kern, a retired physician and former president of the medical staff of Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, died at that hospital yesterday. He was 70 years old and lived at 186 Devon Road here.

BRUSSELS, April 20 Walter Hallstein, president of the European Economic Community Commission, and Sicco L. Mansholt, a vice president, are both sidelined by ill health just as the trade bloc's six member nations begin a series of important negotiations. Seventeen days of ministerial meetings are scheduled between today and July 1.

MOST people think of international cooperation as involving only political and cultural projects. Yet there are other areas, such as wild fish and animals, in which diverse interests are working together to some degree. If expanded and intensified, these efforts couldonly be beneficial for all.
Gulf Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it would acquire three companies with combined annual sales of more than $17-million.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) Braniff Airways and Delta Air Lines bid today to replace Northeast Airlines on the much-sought New York-toFlorida route, one of the richest in the nation.
Two suspects were arrested yesterday and charged with taking $10,460 from the Elmhurst branch of the Jamaica Savings Bank at 87-10 Queens Boulevard in an armed robbery last June 18.

CHICAGO, April 20 Mayor Richard J. Daley presented to the City Council today a record $195-million bond issue for sweeping civic improvements, a political gamble in an election year but one he carefully calculated.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP) Jose Pagan pinch-hit a basesfilled sacrifice fly in the ninth inning tonight, scoring Donn Clendenon with the winning run as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2.

WASHINGTON, April 20 Administration sources reported today that the United States had altered the pattern of bombings in North Vietnam in recent months to make the raids less predictable but not more menacing to civilian centers.
The number of nurses in city hospitals threatening to resign May 23 has risen to 575, according to the New York State Nurses Association.

The North American headquarters of Olympic Airways, the Greek national airline founded by Aristotle Onassis in 1957, was consecrated yesterday by Archbishop Iakovos, Greek Othodox Primate of North and South America.
HONG KONG, April 20 Liu Shao-chi, Communist China's head of state, failed to budge Burma from her neutrality on the Vietnam issue during a three-day visit to the Southeast Asian nation.
James Mullen named vice president of Bolte Advertising-Suburban New York, Inc.
Justice may be blind but not a juror, according to a Supreme Court ruling here yesterday.
SAIGON, April 20 Some American officials hope to persuade Premier Nguyen Cao Ky to bring his rival Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi back into the South Vietnamese Government in a high post.

WASHINGTON, April 20 More political discord in South Vietnam, along with a resumption of heavy fighting, was forecast today by Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara in testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the challenger, remained a pawn up against the world champion, his compatriot Tigran Petrosian, at the adjournment of their fifth match game at the Variety Theater in Moscow last night.
The Beaunit Corporation, a producer of chemical fibers and fabrics, announced here yesterday the appointment of Richard F. Heitmiller as vice president and technical director of its fibers division.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 20 General of the Army Artur Costa e Silva's transformation from War Minister to President of Brazil is now considered a virtual certainty by political observers.

TRENTON, April 20 The Delaware River Basin Commission in its first appraisal this year of the metropolitan region's water supply, described New York's watershed today as a healthy oasis in the middle of a desert.
