Raymond Willett Marshall, president of the railroad equipment company bearing his name, of 60 East 42d Street, New York, died Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at Meads Point, Greenwich, Conn.

The Eastern Tennis Patrons will give a party on Monday in the New York Hilton's Trianon Ballroom to raise funds for its program of widening interest in tennis among boys and girls in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Equipment that is expected to help major blood centers automate the routine typing of blood was shown here yesterday by the Red Cross.

MARION, Ohio, April 20 Good news and a changing of the guard were highlights today of the annual stockholders' meeting of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation in the Marion County Coliseum.

ALBANY, April 20 The Assembly passed a bill today designed to keep a closer watch on political campaign expenditures. It would have the effect of cutting the amount that could legally be spent for a candidate in the state.
SAIGON, Thursday, April 21 Six American pacifists were carried, Kicking and flailing their arms, onto a Pan American World Airways jetliner bound for San Francisco today.
MASSENA, N.Y., April 20 Governor Rockefeller suggested today that Mayor Lindsay would be wise to compromise if he expected to get his New York City tax package through the Legislature.

ALBANY, April 20 Governor Rockefeller will introduce legislation in a week or so under which the state would compensate innocent victims for physical injuries inflicted on them in the commission of a crime.

Robert Kurzweil, industrial engineer and head of Robert Kurzweil Associates at 103 Park Avenue, died yesterday of cancer at Parkway Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 54 years old and lived at 170 West End Avenue.
A big man with the far-seeing eyes of the master mariner stood on the bridge of his ship yesterday and watched the Sandy Hook pilot take her out to sea for the voyage home.
The Lindsay administration is exploring the feasibility of a 25-cent toll on the city's four major bridges across the East River.
LAKE FOREST, Ill., April 21 Graham Aldis, president of Aldis Co., one of Chicago's early real estate firms, died here at the age of 70.

WASHINGTON, April 21 Chief Justice Earl Warren suggested today that members of the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities might be operating unlawfully when they "roam the country at large" investigating suspected subversives.

HONG KONG, April 21 (UPI) Six American pacifists who had been expelled from South Vietnam arrived in Hong Kong today. They complained that the United States Embassy in Saigon had done nothing to prevent their arrest and deportation for having demonstrated against the war.
ROME, April 21 Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko arrived today from Moscow for six days of talks, some sightseeing and probably a call on Pope Paul VI.

Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, moved into the men's singles quarter-finals of the Naples international tennis tournament today, but Kathleen Harter of Seal Beach, Calif., and Julie Heldman of New York were defeated in women's singles.
MOSCOW, April 21 A Soviet art jury has rejected all 57 entries in a competition for the construction of a giant monument to Lenin inside the Kremlin.
PASSAIC, N.J., Friday, April 22 (AP) The Board of Education agreed to raise teachers' salaries for the next two years early today, and members of the Passaic Teachers Association.

Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson received a George Foster Peabody Award here yesterday for a television program on which she guided viewers around Washington and campaigned for national beautification. Accompanied by a secretary and three Secret Service men, she flew here from Washington on a shuttle service to attend the awards luncheon in the Pierre Hotel.

NINETEENTH-CENTURY Russia is where the soul was discovered--at least as the territory of richly introspective literature. There are glimpses of that territory now and then in the play that opened last night at the Off Broadway American Place...
Democratic contenders for Governor and legislative leaders held the first of a series of strategy meetings over breakfast yesterday at Senator Robert F. Kennedy's East River apartment.

Adequate financing will continue to be available for business property owned by prime risks, but others seeking funds for business-property purchases face a monetary squeeze, according to a quarterly study of the mortgage market by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
DALLAS, April 21 (AP) Dennis Ralston, the United States' No. 1 ranked player, rallied twice today to defeat Chris Bovett of Australia in the Dallas invitation tennis championship, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) A new reduction in the mental standards for draft inductees has been approved by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara, effective April 1, the Selective Service System announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 21--Following is the transcript of President Johnson's remarks as he awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously to Pfc. Milton L. Olive 3d in the White House Rose Garden today:

ANAHEIM, Calif., April 21 (UPI) Joe Adcock hit a tiebreaking pinch-hit single in the bottom of the 11th inning last night to score Bob Rodgers and give the California Angels a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox.
BOSTON, April 21 (AP) The Boston Globe has won the eighth annual Sevellon Brown Memorial award "for disinterested and meritorious public service" among New England newspapers.

The front-page headlines and the radio bulletins that yesterday told millions about an "artificial heart" being implanted into a human being undoubtedly represented a public relations man's dream. But others will wonder about the propriety and ethics of publicizing a highly experimental procedure, with its concomitant raising of possibly unjustified hopes among thousands suffering from heart ailments.

Former Postmaster Emil Luc of Williston Park, L.I., pleaded guilty in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday to charges of embezzlement from the mail. Judge Leo F. Rayfiel deferred sentencing until May 26.
Gary Player of South Africa, the defender, and three other winners of the last five years have filed entries for the United States Open golf championship June 16 through 19 at San Francisco.
A successful artificial heart could extend the lives of thousands of otherwise doomed persons and usher in a new era in the treatment of serious heart disease.
HOUSTON, April 21 Surgeons successfully implanted what they called an "artificial heart" in a 65-year-old man here today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 21 The Harvard Divinity School ended today a convocation in observance of 150 years as a nondenominational center of theological culture in a pluralistic society.

Production of newsprint in North America rose to 940,633 tons in March the largest output in any month to date, the Newsprint Service Bureau said yesterday. The figure was 12.7 per cent above the total for March, 1965.

THE fashionable luncheon circuit that includes Le Pavilion, La Cote Basque and La Caravelle seems to have expanded to Orsini's. The coffeehouse-turned-restaurant at 41 West 56th Street sparkled yesterday with social figures in brilliant suits and even brighter diamonds.
CHESTER, England, April 21 The key witness for the prosecution in the Pennine Moors murder trial gave a lurid description in court today of the slaying of one of the victims last October.
PICASSO has always carried his Blue Period with him, rather as, perhaps, an insignia. Even in his most advanced sketches you can fugitively and, for that matter, comfortingly catch...
Mayor Lindsay's tax program won the support of the Temporary Commission on City Finances yesterday at the City Council hearings on the program.

A RECENT column here described an opossum that had set up residence in the suburbs. Robert Ackerly of the Marine Testing Laboratory in East Rockaway, L.I., was kind enough to pass along a story told by his father and grandfather concerning the possible origin of opossums on Long Island.
Alexander's Department Stores is close to signing papers for its first Nassau County branch.

The City Council hearings on the Lindsay tax program have produced a beneficially broad cross-section of public opinion, but certainly no consensus. The most respected civic organizations were heard. The lobbyists for special interests were heard. Substitute courses of action were proposed. But after all the speech-making and all the demonstrating, the Mayor's program stands up well to the test of informed debate.
Mrs. Dora Hackman Cohen, a retired public school teacher who was active in Jewish organizations, died yesterday in the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals after a long illness. Her age was 68.

WHITE PLAINS, April 21 An attempt to block Republican renomination of Representative Odgen R. Reid of Purchase in the 26th Congressional District of eastern Westchester County was defeated tonight at a convention of the Republican County Committee.
A pair of two-run homers, one the 509th of Willie Mays's career, and the pitching of Juan Marichal gave the San Francisco Giants a 5-2 victory today over the Chicago Cubs.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

WASHINGTON, April 20 The International Air Transport Association, with the approval of the United States, is making a last-hour effort to save a treaty limiting international airlines' liability for deaths and injuries in accidents.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 21 Dr. Harry Houser Love, a former Cornell University professor and experimenter in plant breeding, died yesterday at the Tompkins County Hospital. He was 86 years old.

Beneath the crystal chandeliers of the St. Regis Roof, where debutantes have danced and society matrons have mingled with nobility, a rather prosaic annual meeting was held yesterday morning by the Lionel Corporation.

NEW DELHI, April 21 Pressure is growing in the press and Parliament for lifting of the state of emergency under which India has been governed for the last three and a half years. The Defense of India rules, have enabled the Government to detain thousands of persons indefinitely without trial.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15 P.M.; Gilbert Becaud, French singer and composer, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Vivian Rivkin, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Francisco Aybar, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Eastman Brass Ensemble, Concert-party, Bowman Room, Biltmore Hotel, 8.
WASHINGTON, April 21 The Government moved today to increase the involvement of the poor in the poverty program.
YONKERS, April 21 Cardi gan Bay, as expected, was the winner of the $50,000 Good Time Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway, but only the true breed-improvers among the 21, 564 fans made capital of it,...
ALBANY, April 21 Governor Rockefeller sent his bill to compensate innocent victims of violent crime to the Legislature today but the fate of the proposal is doubtful.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 21 (UPI) British women eliminated the last of the overseas opposition today in the British hard court championships.

The fresh jump in the cost of living index for March is another indication that inflationary pressures have gathered strength. The Johnson Administration had hoped that lower food prices would halt or limit the rise. Instead, food prices continued to advance along with other items, including consumer services. Administration spokesmen report that farm prices declined this month, but they admit that the drop may not influence retail food prices or the April index.
In increasing numbers, hogs and cattle are coming to market and that is being reflected in futures prices of pork bellies and hides, as well as prices paid for live hogs. All dropped yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 21 The Government of South Africa today informed Joseph Lelyveld, a correspondent of The New York Times, that his visa would not be renewed and that his permit to remain in the country would expire on April 28.
BONN, April 21 (AP) The West German Government says it will build with Britain and France a 300-seat short and medium-range commercial plane.
John E. Blomquist, vice president and general sales manager of the Reynolds Metals Company, has been elected to the board of directors.

The country's large chain stores and mail-order houses houses completed the first quarter of 1966 with a 13.7 per cent sales gain over the corresponding 1965 period, a survey made by The New York Times disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, April 21 Queen Elizabeth II, marking her 40th birthday, today opened the fourth new Parliament of her reign, and within hours the House of Commons was embroiled in heated debate.
Two ticket brokers were arrested here yesterday on charges of reselling theater tickets without a city license, and overcharging on the resales.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (UPI) Rico Carty tripled home the tying run in the eighth inning and scored the winning run on Chris Short's wild pitch to give the Atlanta Braves a 5-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight and a sweep of their three-game series.
The Lindsay administration plans to have civilians, not policemen, conduct hearings into charges of police brutality.
Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery inspected Gracie Mansion in person in early February and told its new occupant that the 167-year-old home was a "firetrap."
PARIS, April 21 A hotel opened today in Paris, and the event told a good deal about the cultural and social differences between the United States and France.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., April 21 Mr. and Mrs. Morris J. Sommer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Ann Sommer, to Gordon M. Berger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Julius Berger of Passaic, N.J.

PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP) A triple by Matty Alou and Gene Alley's squeeze bunt in the sixth inning produced the winning run as the Pittsburgh Pirates edged the Cincinnati Reds, 2-1, tonight and ruined Milt Pappas's National League pitching debut.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 21 (UPI) Michael Moretti, a policeman, whose conviction in the slaying of two youths rocked Chicago in the early 1950's, won a parole from a life term in prison today.
The Federal Reserve continued to keep a tight rein on the credit markets during the week ended last Wednesday.

THE current "death of God" controversy is a legitimate one in theological circles despite the fact that the phrase has all the earmarks of a successful slogan. The three words, "death of God," make a point, have punch and sales appeal, and, best of all, fit neatly on the cover of Time magazine. Unfortunately, like the successful slogan, they also oversimplify.
How do you win $27,200 in three easy trips to the mutuel windows?

LOS ANGELES, April 21 (UPI) Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina, five-time world champion racing driver, testified today that he drove a 1960 Chevrolet Corvair in 1961, found it "very easy handling" and "liked driving" it.

WASHINGTON, April 21 George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, sought today to spur the House to speed up action on legislation to ease restrictions on picketing at construction sites.

WHITE PLAINS, April 21 Mr. and Mrs. Myron S. Isaacs have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane L. Isaacs of San Francisco, to Tim Aaron Doyle, son of Prof. and Mrs. Leonard A. Doyle of Walnut Creek, Calif.
LONDON, April 21 (AP) British Overseas Airways Corporation suspended four more of its long-distance flights today because of suspected hairline cracks in its fleet of Boeing 707 jetliners.
Earnings of American Airlines, Inc., in the first quarter advanced to $3,661,000, equal to 41 cents a share, from $2,314,000, or 27 cents a share on fewer outstanding shares...

VILLANOVA, Pa., April 21 Mr. and Mrs. George I. MacLeod have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maris Inglis MacLeod, to James Langley Van Alen, son of Mrs. Walter D. Fletcher of New York and Charlottesville, Va., and James H. Van Alen of New York and Newport, R.I. A summer wedding is planned.
A Cambodian Government representative has taken issue with published accounts of a naval engagement between Thai and Cambodian vessels.
The World Journal Tribune, Inc., warned the nine newspaper craft unions last night that a strike against the merged newspaper corporation would violate their present contracts and that "appropriate

I.D. Robbins, who is reportedly under consideration for appointment as chairman of the City Housing Authority, was sued for $5-million yesterday by lawyers engaged by residents of a Mitchell-Lama cooperative he developed. UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 21 Arthur J. Goldberg has assured United States employes of the United Nations that he will give "sympathetic" attention to their complaints ...

Mrs. Helen Flynn Conway, widow of Carle C. Conway, president and chairman of the board of the Continental. Can Company until his death in 1959, died at her home at 1 Sutton Place South early yesterday morning.

Sales and earnings of the National Dairy Products Corporation, the nation's largest food processor, during the first three months of this year were the highest for any first quarter in the company's 43-year history.
The New York Stock Exchange reported this week changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

A new phase in air transportation will be opened up when the giant planes ordered by Pan American World Airways from Boeing begin operations. Capable of carrying nearly 500 passengers or 214,000 pounds of freight, these huge aircraft will fly higher, faster and longer than the present generation of jets.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., April 21 A group of eight spectators from Scotland walked through the Garden State Park gates today without digging into their wallets and promptly decided that this sort of thing should go on back home.
DOUALA, Cameroon, April 19 "They are happy, are they not?" a French official asked as he watched village dancers. "So why should we teach them to want things they will never get?"

TRENTON, April 21 Gov. Richard J. Hughes was reported tonight to be ready to eliminate a proposed $33-million turnover tax on business inventories, in a final effort to insure Republican support of a 3 per cent sales tax.
WASHINGTON, April 21 The Daughters of the American Revolution have found a new target for indignation "the socalled peace movement."
MIAMI, April 21 (UPI) The 160-mile Miami-to-Nassau ocean powerboat race was postponed a second time today because of rainy, windy weather that kicked up seven-foot seas in the Gulf Stream.

ONE of the strongest pair championships in the international bridge calendar begins tonight in London. It is the annual invitation event sponsored by the London Sunday Times, and is comparable in strength and procedure--...

HARTSDALE, N.Y., April 21 School officials here said today that residents of this Westchester County community would ultimately realize that they have no alternative but to merge their white school district with the heavily Negro Woodlands District.
Eager bidders with a special penchant for African art filled the sales room last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, to compete for the collection amassed by Helena Rubenstein.

The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange announced yesterday tighter rules for buying securities on credit in an effort to reduce a speculative wave that has swept the stock market.
Federal grants of $230,000 to develop an automatic system to read license plates and to set up regional police training centers were announced by Governor Rockefeller yesterday.

Jeanne Hepple, of "Serjeant Musgrave's Dance," Christopher Walken, of "The Lion in Winter," were chosen yesterday as this season's winners of the American Clarence Derwent acting prizes for performances in nonfeatured roles. Miss Hepple also won last year's British Derwent award for her appearance with the National Theater in "The Crucible."
SYDNEY, Australia, April 21 The Australian Army's first task force of 4,500 men is on its way to serve in Vietnam.
SAIGON, April 21--Government troops fought a bloody street batttle with youthful rioters today in the highland resort of Dalat, 145 miles northeast of Saigon.

THERE comes a day in the life of a big company when it takes a good look at its customers and realizes that they're not as young as they used to be. Convincing daughters that what is good for mother is also right for them is a lot harder than starting fresh. So a new division with younger merchandise is born.

The New York Mets have done some amazing things this season. They made it to the first division. They got Casey Stengel into the Hall of Fame. They even were "reviewed" by a dance critic and survived.
Paramount Pictures' "Seconds," a melodrama starring Rock Hudson, has been picked to represent the United States in competition at the Cannes Film Festivay, May 5 to 20.
The $7-million offshore drilling rig Ocean Traveler starts an 8,200-mile trip across the Atlantic April 30 when it leaves Grand Isle, La., under tow to Stavanger, Norway.
Mayor Lindsay made official yesterday the Mayor's "interneship" program under which college students work in the city government six to eight hours a week.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 22--The Council of Ministers of the Central Treaty Organization ended here today with a resolution to maintain the defensive strength of the alliance.
Louis Cohen, who founded the Metal Purchasing Company, Inc., of 501 West 30th Street, died Wednesday at the Mount Sinal Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 88 years old and lived at 880 Fifth Avenue.
The spot rate on the British pound improved moderately yesterday in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2,7939, up 8 points from the previous day.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 21 (Reuters) Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia was mobbed by thousands of adherents of a cult that worships him as a living god when he arrived here today for an official three-day visit to Jamaica on his tour of the Caribbean.

Warren C. Giles, the National League president, rejected today a protest of a new rule by Red Schoendienst, manager of the Cardinals, during the St. Louis-Pittsburgh game April 16. The Pirates won, 5-3.
The New York Amsterdam News, the city's largest Negro weekly, published yesterday a 232-page Special Progress Edition detailing Negro progress in the United States during the last 300 years.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 21 (AP) Railroads should be permitted to merge and allowed to set their own rates on a competitive basis, a railroad official said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, April 21 The Hollywood studios, alarmed by the mounting failure rate among major productions, are turning increasingly to remakes of old pictures, sequels, movies based on TV series and similar projects.
Christian teachings continue to "reinforce and foster" anti-Jewish prejudice in this country, two prominent sociologists declared yesterday in a special study.
Two State Supreme Court Justices made their movie debut here yesterday before an appreciative audience of 35 of their colleagues and about 200 prospective jurors.

The defending world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, managed to draw his fifth game last night against the challenger, his compatriot Boris Spassky. Petrosian used a tortuous precision ...

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 21 A suggestion by a leading Lutheran churchman that the United States get out of South Vietnam it asked to do so opened the door today to a warm debate on the right of churches to speak out on social and political issues.

SAIGON, Friday, April 22--United States marines and South Vietnamese troops battled last night against a force thought to be of regimental strength in the coastal lowlands 340 miles northeast of Saigon.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 21 Foreign Minister Abba Eban will travel to Poland next month, the First Israeli Cabinet Minister to visit an East European country.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) The House Banking Committee approved today President Johnson's plan for refinancing Government-held loans. It is estimated that the plan will yield $4.2-billion in the coming year's budget.
WASHINGTON, April 21 An airline industry spokesman defended today a vote of 18 Governments last Dec. 17 that established narrower air corridors for jets across the Atlantic.
THE April 15 tax deadline passed last Friday, and for the 19th time the Rev. A.J. Muste's tax return was among the missing.

Dr. Rufus Cole, the first director of the Hospital of the Rockefeller Institute in New York died of pneumonia on Wednesday night in a Washington hospital He was 93 years old and lived in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

For the first time since World War II Austria is to have one-party Government and a genuine parliamentary opposition. After winning an absolute majority in the National Assembly in last month's election, the conservative People's party set so high a price for continuation of the 21-year-old coalition that the Socialists refused to pay it.
A manufacturer and philanthropist was sentenced to a year in prison and fined $10,000 on income tax evasion charges in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday.
ESSEX FELLS, N.J., April 21 Mrs. David Johnstone of Montclair won the Garden State Women's Golf Association's opening tournament today at the Essex Fells Country Club.
Nearly 4,000 experienced teachers now on special assignment will be returned to regular classroom duty next fall as part of a new effort to improve staffing in the city schools.
WASHINGTON, April 21 The Johnson Administration was accused today of a delay in submitting civil rights legislation to Congress.

Dr. Irving S. Wright, clinical professor of medicine at Cornell University Medical College, was installed yesterday as president of The American College of Physicians at the group's 47th annual meeting at the New York Hilton.

ALWAYS on the search for new repertory (and in this he is almost unique among the big violinists), Isaac Stern came up with some unusual items for his Carnegie Hall recital last night. There was the Sonatensatz by Brahms; there was ...

WASHINGTON, April 21 Intercity truck tonnage and rail freight ton-mileage for the latest week ended April 16 were both considerably above that of the corresponding period of the preceding year. Some of the sharp year to year increases can be attributed, in part, to religious holidays observed during the comparable 1965 week.

WASHINGTON, April 21 The Senate Armed Services Committee added $167.9-million to a defense authorization bill today in a move to nudge the Administration into faster development and deployment of the Nike X antimissile system.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 21--The query was addressed to Emile Griffith, the welterweight champion of the world: What did you think when Rubin Carter knocked you to the floor?

LONDON, April 21--Prime Minister Wilson disclosed today in the House of Commons that the Government had twice sent representatives to Rhodesia empowered to open negotiations. But Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, he said, would not talk.
Texaco, Inc., announced here yesterday the election of two new vice presidents and the reassignment of two other vice presidents.

Calvin Siegel, president of Calvin Clothing Corporation, has been elected president of the Boys' Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association. Mr. Siegel succeeds Allen L. Boorstein, president of Rob Roy Company, Inc., who has been named chairman of the association.
Peter Frankl, a Hungarian pianist who lives in London, will make his debut here next March 4 in the 1966-67 Hunter College Saturday Evening Subscription Series.
CHICAGO April 21 (UPI) The Chicago Cubs traded two starting pitchers today to give Manager Leo Durocher a "set outfield" in a bid to climb out of the National League basement.

Job calls on the waterfront were up 19 per cent last month over the February total of 391,107. The calls for 465,639 dock workers ran about 8 per cent behind the record total of 508,450 for March, 1965.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 21 The Special Committee of 24 on Colonialism adopted a resolution today calling on Britain to use military force to depose the white minority government of Rhodesia.
St. John's retained first place in the Metropolitan Baseball Conference yesterday as Tom Sowinski shut out Fordham, 2-0, on the Redmen's field in Jamaica, Queens.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) A tentative agreement to end an eight-week-old strike involving Colgate-Palmolive plants in three states was announced tonight.
Johnny Dio, the labor racketeer, and his 24-year-old son were indicted yesterday along with two other men and a corporation on bankruptcy fraud charges by a Federal grand jury.
MOSCOW, April 21 The Soviet Union's Lenin Prize Committee, announcing its annual awards tonight, omitted recognition for literature and drama.

PARIS When Beatrice de Baritault du Carpia saunters across some of the 618 acres around the 14th-century Chateau Roquetaillade, which is near the village of Mazeres in the Bordeaux region, she has an odd dream for a girl with her address.

DALLAS, April 21 (AP) Doug Sanders carded a fourunder-par 67 today and took a two-stroke lead in the first round of the $85,000 Dallas open. The tournament is being played over the 6,923-yard Oak Cliff Country Club course.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 112.6 on Wednesday from 112.5 on Tuesday.

GREAT NECK, L.I., April 21 Ruel E. Tucker, principal of the Great Neck South Senior High School, died last night in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, after a heart attack. He was 64 years old and lived at 6 Fourth Road here.
MADRID, April 21 Spaniards are discovering that it pays to read their newspapers these days.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) Senator J.W. Fulbright warned today that the United States was "succumbing to the arrogance of power." He said that those protesting the Vietnam war "deserve our sympathy and respect."
The United States Customs Service, faced with a bigger rush of travelers than ever this year, is grateful for summer vacations at schools and colleges.

Prince Albert of Liege, younger brother of King Baudouin of the Belgians, performed his first official ceremony at the age of 5. He sat on a red velvet chair before a microphone and, distinctly and unhesitantly, declared the Hydraulic Exposition of Liege open. His duties have increased considerably since that time.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 21 (AP)--Phyllis (Tish) Preuss chipped in for a birdie from 65 feet on the 20th hole to beat Mrs. Marlene Stewart Streit and gain the final of the North-and-South amateur golf tournament today.

PARIS, April 21 Jean Genet's sprawling, strong-spoken, symbolic drama, "Les Paravents" (The Screens), which has the Algerian War as its setting, received its Parisian premiere tonight at Jean-Louis Barrault's state-subsidized Theatre de France.

SAIGON, Friday, April 22 (Reuters) South Vietnam's national police chief has been removed from his post and replaced by the director of military security, the Government announced today. No reason was given for the change.

The Bancroft Prizes for books, judged the best in American history were presented last night to Richard B. Morris and Theodore W. Friend 3d, Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, made the presentations at a dinner in the Low Memorial Library. Each award is for $4,000.

The resignation of Helen M. Harris as chairman of New York's planning and coordinating board for antipoverty projects is a sign of deep trouble in the organization set up to map strategy for the fight against want in this largest of American cities. Miss Harris, executive director of United Neighborhood Houses, has earned universal respect in her halfcentury as a battler against deprivation and disease in slum areas.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 21 Seton Hall University, scoring its first four runs without a hit, went on to defeat Upsala College, 7-2, today. The Pirates have an 8-3 won-lost record.

DALLAS, Tex., April 21 (AP) Robert E. Moore, an engineer and co-founder and retired president of Fischbach Moore of Texas and vice president of, Fischbach Moore, Inc., electrical contractors, of New York, died here yesterday. He was 73 years old.
DETROIT, April 21 Dissident students defied school board orders to end their boycott of Northern High School today and went instead to a freedom school.

THE honky-tonk nightclub of Fred and Mickie Finn in San Diego, Calif., was brought in last night by the National Broadcasting Company as a replacement for "Mona MeCluskey." Under those specific circumstances, the show represented progress.
MONTREAT, N.C., April 21 The Southern Presbyterian Church began its annual meeting in the mountains here today amid growing concern over unrest and instability in the influential denomination.
Lukas Foss enlivened the New York Philharmonic program last night at Philharmonic Hall with a first-half devoted to two pivotal 20th-century composers, Anton Webern and Alban Berg.
Sidney J. Ungar, the lawyer and real estate promoter whose association with Hulan E. Jack led to the downfall of the former Manhattan Borough President, was disbarred yesterday.
Following is a statement on the newspaper merger by John Hay Whitney, editor in chief and publisher of The Herald Tribune, that appeared in his paper this morning:

Three homosexuals, intent upon challenging State Liquor Authority regulations cited by some bartenders in refusing to sell liquor to sexual deviates, met with some difficulty yesterday in finding a bar that would deny them service.

Hazel Bishop, Inc., the cosmetics producer, announced yesterday in Union, N.J., the promotion of David Edell to executive vice president from vice president, a post he has held since joining the company last July.

WASHINGTON, April 21 Secretary of Defense McNamara is a puzzle. He is probably the most energetic, efficient and dominant Secretary of Defense since Forrestal, but he is energetic, efficient and dominant in a very special way.
CONCERNING the New York Yankees, the ques tion that comes to mind is: What in the world is going on here?

SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 (AP) A man who confessed he had thrown a 7-year-old girl to her death from a roof in New York City in 1958 was arrested today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges of violating parole.
Stocks closed mixed on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Advances and declines were just about evenly matched and trading was the slowest since March 23.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today . It would continue an exemption from registration for foreign securities until Nov. 30, 1966.

Broadway audiences who have sat through an evening of startling stagecraft with the Royal Shakespeare Theater's production of "Marat/Sade" by Peter Weiss will be able to see the author in a completely different tempo in October, when his play "The Investigation" opens here.

The men who run Georges Carpentier's Bar and Restaurant, 8 Boulevard de Madeliene, Paris, and Jack Dempsey's Broadway Restaurant and Bar, 1619 Broadway, met yesterday for the first time in nine years.
The city's water supply showed an increase yesterday over both Wednesday and the previous Thursday.
Stock prices continued to advance yesterday with low-priced issues receiving the bulk of trading interest.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 The Washington Post, a morning newspaper with a daily circulation of 444,396, was named today the winner of the 36th F. Wayland Ayer Cup for excellence in typography, makeup and printing.
GLEN RIDGE, N.J., April 21 Mrs. Margaret Connelly Lazarus, former owner and publisher of The Bayonne Times, died today at her home, 400 Ridgewood Avenue. She was 96 years old.
Four new trains, including a week-night theater special and a Saturday evening shoppers' special, will be added to the New York Central Railroad's Harlem Division on Monday.
Miss Susan Scholl Connelly and James D. Sparkman Jr. of New York, son of Mr. Sparkman of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Dr. Kathleen Palmer Sparkman, plan to be married in June.

LONDON, April 21 (AP) Scotland Yard detectives today seized James Edward White, suspected mastermind of the $7.2-million train robbery of 1963. White, who had eluded the police since 1963, was picked up in a remote little seaside resort 70 miles from London.
WASHINGTON, April 21 Espionage precedents are continuing to crumble at the Central Intelligence Agency.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 21 Mr. and Mrs. John H. Finley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Corinna Finley, to Lincoln Davis Hammond, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Hammond of Marblehead. A June wedding is planned.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 21 (UPI) Paul Haber of San Jose, Calif., beat top-seeded Dave Graybill of Phoenix, Ariz., 21-13, 21-15, today to advance to the semi-finals of the United States handball championship.
Dr. Joseph D. Eby, orthodontist, died of a cardiac arrest Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at the Alrae Hotel, Madison Avenue and 64th Street.
Mordecai Bernstein, the editor of Der Wecker, a publication of the Jewish Socialist Farband, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 61 years old.
AUSTIN, Tex., April 21 The Communications Workers of America has won a representation election at the Capital Cable Company, part of the Lyndon B. Johnson family's business holdings.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm in quiet trading yesterday.
DAKHLA, United Arab Republic, April 15 This oasis is one of the new frontiers in the United Arab Republic.

A strong likelihood exists that Julius Garfinckel Co. will discontinue its efforts to appeal a recent ruling by the Fairfax County Circuit Court, in Fairfax, Va., giving Genesco, Inc., the right to Garfinckel's shareholder list.
ALBANY, April 21 Legislative leaders moved today to smooth the way for passage of their drastically amended divorce-reform bill by signing up former critics as sponsors.

WASHINGTON, April 21 In the shadow of the White House, a warehouseman from Chicago and a President from Texas philosophized today over the lessons to be drawn from the heroism of a young Negro soldier who gave his life on a jungle trail in Vietnam.

SAIGON When political action branches of South Vietnam's Buddhist movement exploited a split in the governing junta and took virtual control of Danang and Hue, the Vietcong moved to capitalize on this unexpected bonanza. Agents were intruded into the two Annamite cities, radio stations were infiltrated and precise directives were issued to Communist underground cadres.
The Mets put Dick Stuart on the 15-day disabled list because of the torn rib muscle he suffered while batting Monday and again Tuesday.

NEW HAVEN, April 21 Two youths from Darien who were sentenced to four months in Fairfield County Jail in February for possession of marijuana for their own use were released yesterday after a Circuit Court judge reduced their sentences.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 21 President Sukarno admonished his ministers today not "to view me as a puppet."

GROSSINGER, N.Y., April 21 Because it does not qualify as a revolutionary relic, the ancient cottage has no memo rial plaque to George Washington, the itinerant snoozer. But it could proclaim, "Rocky Marciano slept here." On the fringe of the mountain-top airport in the heart of the Borscht Belt the abandoned cottage that the Brockton Blockbuster, used as training headquarters has been taken over by another fighter.

GUATEMALA, April 21 The Guatemalan Transportation Association, to which all local trucking concerns belong, held an emergency session today to discuss guerrilla attacks on the highway from Puerto Barrios on the Caribbean to Guatemala City. Thus far 20 vehicles have been disabled and a number of cargoes destroyed.
Government bond prices advanced yesterday in a move attributed to Federal Reserve buying and news of a rise in the consumer price index.
THE new show at the downtown Square East cafe, which I saw at its last preview but one, is billed as The Return of Second City in "20,000 Frozen Grenadiers."
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) Representative Gerald R. Ford said today he had new but admittedly unconfirmed information suggesting "quite shocking mismanagement" of the Vietnam War.
The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association completed yesterday a reorganization of its top management.

Tenants of two five-story brownstone buildings at 30 and 32 West 116th Street were ordered out of their apartments early today by Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler. He said the structures were in danger of imminent collapse.

PARIS, April 21 If United States policy-makers ever hoped that the French withdrawal from the integrated Western defense system could be slowed or reversed by appealing to the French electorate over the head of President de Gaulle, the last few days of sharp parliamentary debate should have dis abused them.

GENEVA, April 21 The disarmament conference formally agreed today to a recess for stocktaking next month after the Soviet Union and the United States had both warned that the four-year-old talks could become a "dialogue of the deaf."
Directors of the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation approved yesterday a proposal to offer additional common shares to stockholders.
AROUND the race track, it's considered bad form to use the term "boat race"

If Funds Were Gift to Senator They Are Tax Exempt WASHINGTON, April 21 When several hundred people paid $25 or $100 a plate at fund-raising dinners for Senator Thomas J. Dodd in 1961 and 1963, what did they think they were doing?
WASHINGTON, April 21 President Johnson today blocked a major airline strike for 60 days while further efforts are made to solve the labor dispute.

A young poet, Jay Wright, strode casually about the library of Harlem's Junior High School 164 yesterday reading aloud a poem by Thomas Merton in a soft, clear voice. His audience was a group of 45 11-and 12year-olds from the school's "S.P." (special progress) classes.
BALTIMORE, April 21 The American spiritual heirs of John Wesley held a 200th birthday party today and honored 12 saddle-sore but happy circuit riders.

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) Joel Hunter, chairman of the Crucible Steel Company of America, denied today that he agreed to turn over control of Crucible to a group headed by Norton Simon, a California industrialist.
Edward A. Merkle, president of the Madison Fund, Inc., told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday that "inflation as such is not necessarily bullish on common stocks."
Philip Frederick Chew, a retired stockbroker, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital at the age of 80. He lived at the Union Club, Park Avenue and 69th Street.

MILWAUKEE, April 21 (AP) Two small boys who confessed that "we aren't even supposed to play together because we get into trouble" were found safe today in a sealed box car 13 days and 1,000 miles from the start of their trip in Fayetteville, N.C.
BONN, April 21 The major West German parties agreed today to follow a unified policy regarding the reunification of Germany and expressed the hope that West Germany's allies would do the same.

WASHINGTON, April 21 The increase in Social Security taxes at the beginning of this year did not restrain consumer spending in the first quarter because, consumers simply saved less, new Government figures indicated today.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 A retirement and a prospective merger have brought shifts in the top command of two shipping lines here.
The State Liquor Authority has told wine and liquor wholesalers that they may not retaliate against pricecutting package stores by withholding any brands from them.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 21, Charles Coudert Brennig, a real-estate broker here for the last 20 years who had been living in semi-retirement, died...
The Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc., has bought Frederick A. Praeger, Inc., publishers of books about international relations, foreign-area studies, military affairs and Communism.

BOSTON, April 21 (UPI) The 652,201 fans who saw the Boston Red Sox finish in the American League cellar last season spent more money outside Fenway Park than they did inside, the Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce said today.
WASHINGTON, April 21 Consumer prices rose sharply in March for the second consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today.
CHICAGO, April 21 Officers of Time, Inc., reported today record first-quarter earnings of $2,893,000, or 42 cents a share, compared with $1,988,000, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier.
Theodore C. Sorensen, former special counsel to President Kennedy, advised businessmen yesterday to become accustomed to dealing with Democratic Congresses.
The children in the fifth-floor room at Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital had been waiting 35 minutes for their guest and when he came in, they burst into applause and giggles.

BELMONT, Mass., April 21 Announcement has been made by Prof. and Mrs. Elkan Rogers Blout of Belmont and Cuttyhunk Island of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan L. Blout, to Glenn Woodruff Merry, son of Mrs. Kay Bingold Merry and Prof. Robert Watson Merry, both of Lexington.

ROME, April 21 (UPI) A group of North American ski resort areas, many in Oregon, Washington and Idaho have asked the United States to support the Canadian city of Banff, rather than Salt Lake City, as the site of the 1972 Winter Olympics, it was learned today.
The Port of New York Authority promised Mayor Lindsay yesterday that it would submit to him in August a plan for improved passenger ship terminal facilities on Manhattan's West Side.

BERLIN, April 21 Walter Ulbricht called on West Germany today to follow the example of President de Gaulle, relinquish the "dangerous and suicidal" alliance with the United States and conduct "German policy, not American policy."
"The cube" LSD has emerged from the shadows, fascinating college students, alarming parents and arousing the police and Federal officials.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) Senator Fulbright cautioned in his talk tonight, "It is by no means certain that the relatively healthy atmosphere in which the [Vietnam] debate is now taking place will not give way to a new era of McCarthyism."

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) A narrowing of the expected budget deficit by $1-billion to $2-billion for the current fiscal year appeared to be developing today as tax collections, spurted by growing prosperity, continued to run higher than expected.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Thursday the level it reached on Wednesday, which was 112.5.

New measures by the Belgian Government to encourage needed industrial investment by paying most of the interest charges on capital loans were announced here yesterday by... Jacques van Offelen, Belgium's new Minister of Economic Affairs.
Conrad Aiken, the poet, has converted his poem "The Kid" into a children's play with music.

LOS ANGELES, April 22 (UPI) The Boston Celtics overcame a 45-point effort by Jerry West tonight and moved just one step from their eighth consecutive National Basketball Association title as they downed the Los Angeles Lakers, 122-117, before 15,251 fans at the Sports Arena.
Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Wangeman of the Waldorf Towers will give a reception at home Monday afternoon for Mrs. John V. Lindsay for her work as a committee member of the Friends of City Center.
WASHINGTON, April 22 New radar observations seem to show that Venus always turns the same face toward the earth as it passes this planet.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) The Soviet Embassy has rented a Virginia estate for use as a children's camp and summer recreation area, State Department officials said today.

HONOLULU, April 22 (AP) Rear Adm. George W. Pressey, a key member of the staff of the United Stats Pacific Military Command, died yesterday after a series of strokes that began Monday. Admiral Pressey, who was 55 years old, was deputy chief for military assistance, logistics and administration on the staff of Adm. U.S. Grant Sharp.
Francisco Aybar turned to his Town Hall audience after having completed his printed debut program and one encore and announced his second encore; a "little" Etude by Benjamin Godard.
Stock prices declined yesterday as volume slackened in the wake of new measures designed to slow down the pace of speculative trading.

LOS ANGELES, April 22 (UPI) Hedy Lamarr, the 52year-old actress who has been accused of shoplifting, was described today by her teen-age son as a troubled woman "because she wasn't as beautiful as she once had been."
ST. LOUIS, April 22 (UPI) Tim McCarver, the St. Louis Cardinals catcher, suffered a small chip fracture on the tip of the finger, X-rays showed today.

ANAHEIM, Calif., April 22 (UPI) Jim McGlothlin, a rookie who worked seven scoreless innings, hurled the California Angels to a 2-1 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight for his first major league victory.
In another attempt to leave the Yankees "margin for error," Manager Johnny Keane yesterday put together a new lineup, which he said would be permanent.
WASHINGTON, April 22 President Johnson urged the nation today to be patient and steadfast in support of his policies in Vietnam through the "period of testing" ahead.
TORONTO, April 22 (AP) The brokerage concern of Waite, Reid Co., Ltd., has been suspended from trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange for two weeks and fined $5,000, the exchange announced today.
Cristobal Real, a historian and poet, who, wrote on the discovery of the Americas, died Sunday in Seville, Spain. His age was 93.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) A Circuit Court judge took under advisement today the plea of a dissident group of shareholders to postpone the annual meeting of the Crucible Steel Company of America scheduled for Wednesday.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP)-Commuter airline service between downtown Chicago and downtown Detroit was introduced today with ceremonies at Meigs Field, Chicago's lakefront airport.

WASHINGTON, April 22 Reductions proposed by President Johnson in outlays for school lunch and milk subsidies, soil and water conservation and other politically appealing programs were rejected today by the House Appropriations Committee.

Directors of Eaton Yale Towne, Inc., proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the company's common stock and voted an increased quarterly dividend of 62 cents a share on the present stock, compared with 55 cents paid previously.
Industrial issues, led by oil shares, paced a brisk advance on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

Tokyo Johnny Jamito, 126 pounds, Philippines, outpointed Rokuro Ishiyama, 126, Japan, 10 rounds.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 22 Dr. Thomas Jefferson Wertenbaker, professor emeritus of American history at Princeton University, died today at Princeton Hospital followings a stroke suffered Thursday. He was 87 years old.
Following is the transcript of an interview with Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge conducted in Saigon by the Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent Peter Kalischer, as broadcast yesterday:

A national group of lawyers who specialize in accident claims have protested a Johnson Administration plan to revive this country's participation in the Warsaw Convention, which limits airline liability in international air travel.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) Gen. Bernard A. Schriever, who directed the development of the United States Missiles virtually from the beginning, will retire this summer, the White House announced today.

The restoration or replacement of losses resulting from the fire in the library of the Jewish Theological Seminary last Monday will take 18 months and cost about $2-million, Dr. Louis Finkelstein, the chancellor, said yesterday.

Breakfast, Brooklyn Catholic Teachers Association, St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, 10 A.M. "The Catholic Teacher and the PostConciliar World," Msgr. George A. Kelly.
PENDLETON, Ind., April 22 (AP) Prisoners collected $500 at the Indiana Reformatory to send a fellow inmate back to his native Alaska.

CHICAGO, April 22 Federal District Court Judge Julius J. Hoffman rejected today an attempt to test the constitutionality of the House Committee on Un-American Activities when he dismissed a set of motions that included an injunction against the committee.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 Tom Vandetta reached the final of the United States professional handicap court tennis championship today by scoring a 6-3, 3-6, 12-10 victory over Jimmy Dunn at the Racquet Club.
PANAMA, April 22 President Marco A. Robies announced three Cabinet changes today in a move said to be designed to bring a wider base of political support into his administration.
Vienna's Jewish community was uneasy when Paddy Chayefsky's "The 10th Man" opened at the Theater in der Josefstadt on March 4.
Longshoremen in New Jersey were ordered by the Superior Court yesterday to stay on the job or face court action.

Mrs. Aileen B. Ryan, Bronx Councilwoman at Large, has been designated by the Democratic leaders in the county's 24th Congressional District to oppose Representative Paul A. Fino, the Republican incumbent, in the November election.

STUTTGART, Germany, April 22 (UPI) Sepp Dietrich, chief of Adolf Hitler's bodyguard and commander of the troops who massacred more than 100 American prisoners at Malmedy, Belgium, in 1944, died of a heart attack today at his home in Ludwigsburg. He was 74 years old.

NEWARK, April 22 Maurice Eisenberg, cellist, has been selected for the New Jersey Symphony's 1966 Arts Award. The presentation will be made at Symphony Hall here next Friday during the Symphony Ball. It will include a citation from Gov. Richard J. Hughes.

WASHINGTON, April 22 Following is a partial transcript, released by the White House, of President Johnson's impromptu news conference this afternoon. The transcript begins with an answer because the official stenographer was not present for the first few minutes.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 22 (Reuters) The Johannesburg Star criticized the South African Government today for refusing to renew the resident's permit of Joseph Lelyveld, correspondent of The New York Times.
Senator Birch E. Bayh, Demcrat of Indiana, has released an independent study that he says supports his charge that steel purchased by Vietnam with aid funds from the United States was inferior.

NEWARK, Del., April 22-Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner of New York City predicted tonight that a "super-gap" between expected income and spending for essential needs would develop in the city's operating budget for the next fiscal year, 1967-68.
HOUSTON, April 22 A 65year-old patient who was given a booster pump for his heart yesterday continued in a coma tonight. Methodist Hospital spokesmen declined to assess his chances of survival.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 22 (UPI) John Lawson supplied a torrid finishing kick today in anchoring Kansas to a record time of 16 minutes 36.8 seconds in the university four-mile relay of the 41st annual Kansas Relays.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) G.I.-home-loan activity grew considerably during March as a result of the recent increases in maximum interest rates and the new G.I. bill, the Veterans Administration said today.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 22 There is a growing hope among Government officials here that the United States will attempt to persuade Greece to negotiate a settlement with Turkey on the Cyprus problem.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 22 (AP) The United States took possession of first place in the final round of the world amateur basketball championships tonight by trouncing Chile, 73-48.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., April 22 Mrs. Ella Baker Deshon, an artist and former fashion editor, died yesterday in her home at 200 West Palisades Avenue at the age of 66.

It was the day of the shopping bags on Barclay Street. Almost every newsman who left The World-Telegram and The Sun yesterday carried his little burden of sadness and memories. None of them knew which of them would be back.
WASHINGTON, April 22 Vice President Humphrey called on a group of New York State mayors today to provide summer jobs in government for young people.
WASHINGTON, (AP) The Daughters of the American Revolution urged today that the post of the Federal Bureau of Investigation be made a Presidential appointment subject to confirmation by the Senate.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) President Johnson took time today for a farewell to a White House sercetary who is retiring after serving under every President since Franklin D. Roosevelt.
BERLIN, April 22 (Reuters) East and West German border guards exchanged fire across the Berlin wall tonight as two East German guards dashed over to the West.

ALBANY, Calif., April 22 (UPI) Fleet Shoe, one of the four Kentucky Derby-eligibles entered in the race, was listed as a 5-2 favorite today in the morning line for tomorrow's 51st running of the $95,000 California Derby at Golden Gate Fields.
Eastern Air Lines will begin using three-engined Boeing 727 jets on its shuttle flights between New York and Washington tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.

The numerous and eclectic furnishings that decorated the late Helena, Rubinstein's homes here, in Greenwich, Conn., in Paris and London, came up in part at auction yesterday, realizing $73,437 in two sessions.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 22 (AP) Mrs. Nancy Roth Syms won four of the last six holes, three with birdles, for 1-up victory today over Phyllis (Tish) Preuss in the 18-hole final of the North-and-South amateur golf tournament.
The city increased its salary offer to registered nurses at a mediation session late Thursday evening, the first movement in the hitherto deadlocked sessions.

The president of Lenox Hill Hospital, Theodore F. Childs, was elected president of the Greater New York Hospital Association yesterday at the association's annual meeting at the New York Red Cross Chapter House, 150 Amsterdam Avenue.

A sharp cutback in admissions for next fall was announced yesterday by the City University. Chancellor Albert H. Bowker said that the university would take in 2,278 fewer freshmen than last September because of "problems of space" and "the uncertainty of financing."
HELSINKI, Finland, Saturday, April 23 (Reuters) Twenty-nine patients were burned to death in a blaze at a mental hospital in Lapinlahti in central Finland, early today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) Northeast Airlines completed presentation before a Civil Aeronautic Board examiners today of the bulk of technical testimony in justification of its application to retain its New York to Florida routes.

ATLANTA, April 22 The New York Mets made their first official foray into the Deep South tonight, playing in the new Atlanta Stadium in chilly, rainy weather that would have made the Braves blush even back in Milwaukee.

A former state banking official and three former Internal Revenue Service employes were among seven persons convicted yesterday in schemes to defraud the Government of thousands of dollars in tax revenue.
WASHINGTON, April 22 The International Busi ness Machine Corporation has further reduced the size of the transistor, which was already miniature.

A National Broadcasting Corporation reporter quoted a Soviet informant yesterday as having said that North Vietnam would be willing to enter peace negotiations with the United States "if all bombing of North Vietnam is ended."
It has been a long time since a Wood Memorial winner went on to capture the Triple Crown.
ROME, April 22 (Reuters) The international federations of the 21 Olympic sports today voted on which site should be awarded the 1972 Olympic Games.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 22 (AP) Three defending champions advanced through two rounds tonight, but a fourth bowed out with an injury in the opening of the 14th annual national senior Amateur Athletic Union championships.
The Lindsay administration emphasized yesterday that it and not the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority would determine basic policy on construction of major expressways, highways and parkways.
HONG KONG Communist China, afflicted by a chronic shortage of grain and now threatened by drought, is encountering difficulties in its efforts to buy wheat on the world market.
ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP) Curt Flood's three-run homer off Pete Mikkelsen in the fifth inning tonight snapped a tie and gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 7-5 victory over Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) The Agriculture Department said today that Russian farming, after years of failure and stagnation, now had a chance to progress because the Soviet Government was showing a willingness to pay the price necessary to raise production.

BALTIMORE, April 22 President Johnson told a Methodist gathering here tonight that Americans of all faiths "have come to believe that the works of compassion are the legitimate and the necessary concern of the entire nation."
Miss Elizabeth Singer and John de Sola Mosely of Fribourg, Switzerland, were marmied in London Thursday.

HOUSTON, April 22 (UPI) Joe Morgan and Jim Gentile hit home runs and Dave Giusti held the Giants to eight hits tonight as the Houston, Astros scored a 2-0 victory that snapped San Francisco's winning streak at five games.
Odetta, the folk singer, was in excellent voice last night for her recital at Hunter College.
MONTREAT, N.C., April 22 In 1924, a young semi nary student from a rural Mississippi background attended an integrated Student Volunteer Movement meeting in Indianapolis.

Fire losses in March were estimated yesterday by the American Insurance Association at $133,358,000. This was 3.8 per cent less than the $138,631,000 reported for March, 1965, and 1.7 per cent more than the $131,095,000 for February, 1966.
MIAMI, April 22 (AP) Cuba has signed 500 athletes to compete in the 10th Central American and Caribbean Games, but a wrangle over United States visas makes it doubtful that any will attend.
RECIFE, Brazil, April 22 Secretary of Agriculture Orville Freeman offered United States support today for major economic and social reform of Brazil's depressed Northeast sugar industry.

PARIS, April 22 France delivered to the United States today a new note that is understood to have reiterated French determination to see the extraterritoriality of all American and other foreign military installations in France ended by April 1, 1967.
MIAMI, April 22 (UPI) The Miami-to-Nassau ocean powerboat race was postponed a third time today because 25knot winds were kicking up eight-foot swells in the Gulf Stream.
I. John Billera, president of U.S. Industries, Inc., was named yesterday to the additional post of chairman, a position that has been vacant since the death of John I. Snyder Jr. last year.
EAST LANSING, Mich., April 22 Dr. John A. Hannah, president of Michigan State University, issued an elaborate defense today of the school's role in a South Vietnam aid program.

MOSCOW, April 22 The Soviet Union announced, today that a new edition of the Great Soviet Encyclopedia was being prepared that would eliminate "the sharply critical tone of a number of articles" in the old encyclopedia.

A concentrated study and evaluation of Ernest Bloch's compositions will be undertaken in "An Ernest Bloch Weekend School" to be held tonight and all day tomorrow at the Theodor Herzl Institute, 515 Park Avenue.
