MINEOLA, L. I., April 22 (UPI) A Long Island housewife was sentenced to life imprisonment today for drugging her husband's butterscotch pudding, then stabbing him 34 times with a steak knife as he slept.
Owens-Illinois, Inc., a producer of glass containers, announced management changes here yesterday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia April 22 (UPI) Militant anti-Communist students demanded today that Indonesia's military leaders "invalidate" President Sukarno's claim that he holds his post for life.

SAIGON, April 22 The United States Embassy made public today the text of an interview in which Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge voiced uneasiness over the outcome of the South Vietnamese national election scheduled for Aug. 15.
Chief Inspector Sanford D. Garelik has forbidden policemen to transport women in squad cars unless they notify their headquarters first.

WASHINGTON, April 22 Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, said today there was no reason to believe that home mortgage interest rates would rise if the Government went through with its plan to sell to private investors some $8-billion worth of loans it now holds.

DALLAS, April 22 (UPI) The nation's top-ranked amateur player, Dennis Ralston, beat Frank Froehling, 6-3, 3-6, 8-6, today as rain forced the Dallas invitation tournament to move indoors to the Samuel Grand Tennis Center.
YONKERS, April 22 With Cardigan Bay resting, a treat he enjoys at Philadelphia's Liberty Park, the lesser lights of the pacing fraternity stepped front and center at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) The antipoverty agency is maintaining a "comic book stockpile," two Republican critics said today.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 22 Dr. and Mrs. Elvin Gottdiener have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Donna Gottdiener, to David Duane Oakes, son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Oakes of La Porte, Ind.
WASHINGTON, April 22 President Johnson cautioned today against trying to go "too far, too fast" in laying the social welfare and educational planks of the Great Society.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) There are indications that the Soviet Union exploded a lowyield nuclear device Wednesday, the Atomic Energy Commission reported today.
Jim Jackson of Boys High proved once again yesterday why he is one of the most sought-after schoolboy runners in the country even though he has a year of high school remaining.

BOWIE, Md., April 22 (AP) Three colts whose handlers plan to enter them in the Kentucky Derby are in the field of 12 for Bowie Race Track's $100,000 added Governor's Gold Cup tomorrow but none is expected to be the favorite of the bettors.
The Federal Government will supply LSD to a limited number of physicians for experiments that it approves, a Federal official reported yesterday.
DENVER, April 22 Miss Linda Downer Hough and Richard Selig Grossinger will be married June 21.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) President Johnson said today that his blood pressure was taken by his doctor every morning before he got out of bed.

The National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday the election as directors of 12 executives of companies based here and of 12 other men who are executives of companies situated outside of New York.

PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., April 22 (UPI) A court-martial board convicted a young Marine Corps drill instructor today of mistreating recruits. It sentenced him to two years at hard labor and ordered him dishonorably discharged.
WASHINGTON, April 22 President Johnson said today that he was "not approaching at this time" a decision on major new anti-inflation moves such as a tax increase.
WASHINGTON, April 22 A free concert series called Music for Young America began here tonight in the Commerce Department auditorium.
The ballroom of the Astor wore a lovely look for the Spring Carnival of Fragrance last night even though the chairman's gown and the table napery didn't match.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., April 22 Dick Tiger of Nigeria, the world middleweight champion, and Emile Griffith of New York, the welterweight titleholder, laced on 16-ounce training gloves for the last time today.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 22 (UPI) Top-seeded Ken Fletcher of Australia needed only 35 minutes today to whip Bobby Wilson of England, 6-1, 6-1, and gain the final in the British hard-court tennis championships.

Two competitions for home sewers are to be held this year at the New York State Exposition, Aug. 30 through Sept. 5, at Syracuse. Cash prizes totalling $1,563 will be given for home arts entries and $1,420 for crafts.
At a downtown luncheon club, a brokerage house partner took a bite of cold salmon yesterday and said reflectively: "Frankly, this speculation scares the hell out of me."
Filmways, which last October announced it had acquired the film rights to "The Royal Hunt of the Sun," has quietly abandoned the project for reasons that are as unclear as they are complex.

WASHINGTON, April 22 Senator Robert F. Kennedy called today for creation of a 16,000-acre Federal conservation and recreation sanctuary in the tidal wetlands that lie off the South Shore of Long Island.

FORT-LAMY, Chad, April 18 The Soviet Ambassador did not place a bet, although someone told him that he had nothing to lose but his change, but everyone else in the presidential stand did bet when the town went to the races.

TOKYO, April 22 (UPI) A tired band of pacifists arrived here today minus one of their colleagues, who is trying to get into Cambodia. They promised "bigger and better" antiwar demonstrations on their return to the United States.

The index primary market prices edged off one-tenth of 1 per cent to 105.1 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended April 19, the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods moved lower in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

Chester, Blackburn Roder, Inc., steamship agents and operators, announced yesterday the appointment of John F. Cloarec as assistant to Alvin P. Chester, the president. He will assist in coordinating liner operations.
OTTAWA, April 22 Yvon Dupuis, a former Liberal Cabinet Minister, was convicted on charges of bribery in a Quebec court today and fined $5,000.
A power failure, which halted trading for 40 minutes, did not put much of a dent in yesterday's activity on the American Stock Exchange.

QUANGNGAI, South Vietnam, April 22 Five battalions of United States marines and South Vietnamese soldiers swept toward the South China Sea today in the cleanup phase of an operation in which 322 Vietcong regulars have been been killed.
PARIS, April 22 The French Government-owned Renault and the privately owned Peugeot are pooling their efforts to assure survival against American competition in the world market for automobiles.
CHESTER, England, April 22 The defense failed today to shake the testimony of David Smith, the prosecution's chief witness in the Pennine Moors murder trial.
NAPLES, Italy, April 22 (UPI) Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., advanced to the semi-finals of the Naples tennis tournament today, but Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, lost.

CINCINNATI, April 22 (UPI) Johnny Callison, Richie Allen and Cookie Rojas each collected three hits tonight to lead the Philadelphia Phils to a 9-7 triumph over Cincinnati and spoil the Reds' delayed home opener.

WASHINGTON, April 22 Members of the Senate Ethics committee said today that Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat Connecticut, had not told the committee that he regarded the proceeds from several testi monial dinners as tax-free gifts.
LONDON, April 22 Britain is coming under renewed diplomatic and commercial pressure to get rid of a "temporary" tariff surcharge imposed in October, 1964.
THE LONG LONG WAR. By Brigadier Richard L. Clutterbuck. 206 pages. Praeger. $5.95. This book, a narrative analysis of Britain's 15-year struggle against Malayan Communist...

DARIEN, Conn., April 22 John J. Farrell, chairman of the executive committee of the Farrell Lines, Inc., a New York steamship line with sailings to Africa, died today in his home on Cross Road, Tokeneke. He was 75 years old.

Four major lumber associations reported an 11.1 per cent increase in production for the week ended April 16, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week. Output rose 1 per cent from the preceding week.

A television correspondent who described the burning of a South Vietnamese village by United States marines received the highest award of the Overseas Press Club of America last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The bond market closed the week with a moderate gain yesterday.

THE caprice of fashion; which has dictated more cutouts, nudity and general exposure for day and evening clothes, has reversed gear for current beachwear. The covered-up look has never been more popular.
"Here Is Your Enemy," by James Cameron, will be published by Holt, Rinehart Winston on May 24.
SEVILLE, Spain, April 22 (UPI) Mrs. John F. Kennedy ended her visit to the colorful fair of Seville today after displaying her skill on a spirited horse trained for the bullfight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 22 The United States filed a letter today formally dissenting from the procedure followed by Moussa L. Keita of Mali, who, as President of the Security Council, waited two days before calling a meeting that Britain had urgently requested.

Britain's Labor Government is now unquestionably moving toward the European Common Market. The question is whether it is moving as rapidly as circumstances in the Community and the Atlantic alliance demand.

WASHINGTON, April 22 President Johnson said today that the time had come to establish "strict safety standards" for automobiles. He appealed to industry to stop raising "picayunish" objections to Federal safety controls.
DETROIT, April 22 (AP) Spokesmen for foreign car makers indicated today that they would comply with a request from Senator Ribicoff.
The automobile industry's daily selling rate for new cars in the mid-April period fell almost 11 per cent from the pace a year ago, according to preliminary reports received from Detroit yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 The State Supreme Court today threw out a taxpayer's suit that sought to block the city of Pittsburgh from constructing a new sports stadium for use by the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Pittsburgh Steelers.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., April 22 Three teams tied for first place today in the season's first state Professional Golfers' Association pro-amateur golf tournament at the Homestead Country Club.
The American Stock Exchange took steps yesterday to strengthen its rule relating to rumors.

Net income of the New York Telephone Company in the first quarter rose to $49,436,000, or 56 cents a share, from $41,330,000, or 47 cents a share, in last year's comparable period, the utility reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 Federal District Judge Alexander Holtzoff dismissed today a request from the firemen's union that he turn the railway labor case over to another judge on the ground that he was biased against the union.

A chartered airliner carrying 92 servicemen and a crew of six slammed into a wooded hillside in a remote area in southern Oklahoma last night. By 3 A.M. today the police could report only 17 survivors.
To the firemen in six Brooklyn companies the Morse bell tapping out the signal 1-6-8-6 means drop everything and move. Out of your shoes and

NOT the least of the charms of Manhattan is the extraodinary availability of unexpected foods. There are exotic Puerto Rican vegetables with names like chayote and yautia on the supper reaches of Park Avenue, candied flowers in many local specialty shops, and there is almost no part of the lamb or pig that can't be purchased on Ninth Avenue.
LONDON, April 22 Fourteen top-ranked pairs, in cluding three from North America, began play in the London Sunday Times tournament here tonight.

Volume of trade for the first quarter on the Chicago Board of Trade was about the same as the record number of transactions in the similar period of 1965, Warren W. Lebeck, executive vice president, announced yesterday.
EL PASO, Tex., April 22 (UPI) United States District Judge Leo Brewster rejected today a motion for a new trial for Billie Sol Estes.
Thomas P.F. Hoving, Commissioner of Parks, yesterday stood on a flagged terrace outside the Brooklyn Museum, surveyed a transformed bit of park wasteland and pronounced it, "charming, witty."

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 22 In the library here at The Inn, a bronze plaque proclaims the fact that on April 22, 1947, the first meeting in this country of the founding fathers of the World Council of Churches was called to order.
The spot rate on the British pound eased further yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7930, down 9 points from the previous day's level.
Most Americans will find themselves on Daylight Saving Time tomorrow if they don't forget to set their clocks ahead one hour before they go to bed tonight.
Three children died and seven other persons were injured last night when a fire flashed through, a three-story building in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn.

THE dual roles in "Swan Lake" of Odette, the Swan Queen, and Odile, the Magician's daughter, are customarily danced by one ballerina. But through a sad accident to the young ballerina Natalia Bessmertnova, who sprained her right ankle and was unable to continue after the second act, the Bolshoi Ballet perforce gave a different Odile, Rimma Karelskaya, at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.

WASHINGTON, April 22 A well-known Washington lawyer working with the Central Intelligence Agency to defend one of its agents in a $110,000 slander suit attempted to "pay off" the complainant to drop the case, according to statements filed in the Federal District Court here.
The Police Department here is handling such a heavy volume of radio calls that it has asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to use 10 additional frequencies.

Vivian Rivkin, a pianist who has played here many times since she made her New York debut 25 years ago, came to Carnegie Hall last night with the New York Orchestral Society to play three Mozart concertos. They were No. 3 in D (K. 40), No. 18 in B flat (K. 456) and No. 26 in D (K. 537).
In France, Gilbert Becaud is known as "Mr. 100,000 Volts," which Sounds like an awkward attempt at a typically American promotional gimmick.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) United States District Judge Edward Curran postponed today the trial of Clifford Jones, former Nevada Lieutenant Governor, on a perjury charge in the Robert G. Baker conspiracy case.
The battle for the savings dollar in New York is getting rougher, and the in-fighting is getting sharper.

GROSSE POINTE FARMS, Mich., April 22 Miss Krystn Alfred Glancy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred R. Glancy Jr., was married this evening to Dr. Michael Edwin Rollins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin O. Rollins of Algonac.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 22 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. McBride have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Neals McBride, to James Henry Brooks, son of Mrs. Henry Vail Brooks of Torrington, Conn., and Woodstock, Vt., and stepson of the late Mr. Brooks.

DALLAS, April 22 (UPI) Heavy thunderstorms, accompanied by lightning, washed out the second round of the $85,000 Greater Dallas open golf tournament today after Gene Littler and Dow Finsterwald had taken a temporary lead with 138's.
WASHINGTON, April 22 The United States' concern over the possibility of imminent violent political upheaval in Haiti has diminished, according to official sources.
WASHINGTON, April 22 New York Republicans may be undecided on the political future of Senator Jacob K. Javits, but apparently his Democratic colleague, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, is not.

Bernard Botein, presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, said yesterday that a new, courtsponsored method of handling homeless men had virtually eliminated the imprisonment of chronic alcoholics on disorderly conduct charges.

AMERICAN sculpture in the first three decades of the 20th century does not constitute one of the most spectacular episodes in our native art history, but it nonetheless includes a number of important artists whose excellence is, even now, only fitfully acknowledged.

ANDERSON, Ind., April 22 Mr. and Mrs. James E. Turnquist have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Ann Turnquist, to Lee Richards Bradley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Bradley Jr. of Weston, Conn.
LONDON, April 22 Britain has asked West Germany and Japan to take stricter measures to enforce the United Nations embargo on trade with Rhodesia.

Ground was broken in Brooklyn yesterday for a Children's Mental Health Center to be erected by the League School for Seriously Disturbed Children, a voluntary agency that has achieved international fame in its 13-year career.
Three Teamsters Union locals yesterday won the right to renegotiate their contracts with metropolitan area milk companies that are selling milk below cost.
Truman Capote, author of "In Cold Blood," a best-selling book about the murder of four members of a Kansas family, will read from his works at Town Hall on May 5 at 8:30 P.M.
John Ball, a 54-year-old writer who invented a detective of such competence that the Pasadena, Calif., police force has enrolled him on its roster, won an Edgar last night.

The World Trade Center promises to transform the lower West Side of Manhattan at least as dramatically as Rockefeller Center did midtown, the United Nations enclave the East Side, and Lincoln Center the upper West Side.
MOSCOW, April 22 A weekly literary newspaper has disclosed that a controversial plan for radical spelling reform has been abandoned.

PARIS, April 22 The country house where Jean Francois Millet, Gustave Courbet and Theodore Rousseau gathered and painted more than 100 years ago was broken into today, and thousands of dollars worth of their paintings were stolen.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 22 (AP) George Bell Timmerman Sr., a retired Federal judge whose ruling in favor of school segregation was reversed in the historic Supreme Court decision of 1954, died in a hospital here today. He was 85 years old.

The normally subdued halls of the Metropolitan Museum of Art resounded yesterday after- noon with shouts, ringing alarms and quick footfalls as guards sought to capture a thief who had taken a small Gainsborough painting from a gallery.
ROME, April 22 Italy and the Soviet Union reached agreement today on economic, technical and scientific cooperation.

BONN, April 22 The West German states will intensify the search for Nazi murderers in the three and two-thirds years remaining for such prosecutions under the statute of limitations, it was announced today.

ROBOTS, rockets and radiation are conversation topics on the tips of children's tongues today. The following books, written to whet the science appetites of 6-to 16-year-olds, should answer many questions and stir their imaginations.
Slowly the truck backed to a stop along West Street, beneath the noisy West Side Highway.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 22 Raymond Rebsamen of Little Rock, a millionaire industrialist and philanthropist, became a Democratic candidate for Governor today.

VIENNA, April 22 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has brought into service a new long-range antimissile system and has designed a number of new rocket weapon types, Defense Minister Rodion Y. Malinovsky said today.

One hundred years ago a devout Congregationalist named Mary Baker Eddy slipped on the ice near her Lynn, Mass., home and severely injured herself. She experienced a "spiritual healing" and went on to found Christian Science.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 22 Henry A. Rudkin, a retired Wall Street broker who with his wife, Margaret, founded the Pepperidge Farm Company, died here today at his home, Pepperidge Farm. He was 81 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 Today's annual meeting of the General Refractories Company was adjourned until tomorrow to permit the election judges to count the ballots turned in after an intensive and expensive proxy fight.
LOS ANGELES, April 22 (AP) Navy scientists have taught porpoises to tell one metal from another. The creatures may be used some day to detect submarines, mines and underwater missile installations.

LONDON, April 22 (AP) Scotland Yard's hopes of wrapping up the case of the great train robbery in August, 1863, rose tonight as a captured member of the 14-man gang said he was ready to talk. The police also picked up a clue to another member of the gang still on the run.
If any New Yorkers have ever wondered about that strange structure over 33d Street that links Gimbels to the building that housed the old Saks-34th Street store, they need wonder no longer.
The president of American Broadcasting Company television yesterday suggested a new way to slice ratings.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., April 22 (AP) Kathy Whitworth and Mrs. Marlene Hagge managed one-under-par 71's in the rain today to share the first-round lead in the Betsy Rawls Peach Blossom invitation golf tournament.

Vladimir Horowitz will give his first out-of-town recital in 13 years May 8 in the 3,000seat gymnasium at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. The 61-year-old pianist will play virtually the same program as at Carnegie Hall last Sunday.
ROME, April 22 Pope Paul VI said today that he had been "saddened" at being unable to go to Poland for the celebration of 1,000 years of Christianity there.

The State Human Rights Commission charged yesterday that two airline companies had failed to submit "persuasive evidence" to counter claims by three stewardesses that they had been dismissed because of their age.
KIEV, U.S.S.R., April 22 (Reuters.) The vast Jewish ceremtery here, which was desecrated by the Nazis, is being cleared to make way for new building.
The Port of New York Authority has offered to pay the city more than $4-million a year in lieu of taxes in order to get clearance for its controversial $525-million World Trade Center.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), April 22?The Archbishop of Canterbury paid his first visit to Israel today. He was immediately asked to do what he could to help the Jews regain access to the holy places in Jordan.

GENEVA, April 22 The International Labor Organization announced today that they Government of Burundi had invited it to investigate charges that human rights were being violated in the African kingdom.
William Goldman, a plumbing and heating contractor and home builder, died at his home in Kew Gardens, Queens, Thursday afternoon. He was 64 years old and lived at 123-60 83d Avenue.
A group of residents in the Morningside Heights area yesterday charged the police of the 26th Precinct with failure to provide adequate protection against prowlers.

CHICAGO, April 22 (UPI) Sandy Koufax, the spring's, No. 1 holdout, today went the route for the first time this year. He hurled a six-hitter and struck out 11 men in pitching the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 2-1 triumph over the Chicago Cubs.
Miss Sharon Tang, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Y.F. Tang of Taipei, Taiwan, and Samuel Ho, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin L. Ho of New York, will be married today in Taipei.

Mayor Lindsay failed yesterday to block a strike threatened for tomorrow against three of the city's major daily newspapers. He was also unable to get the publishers to postpone their planned merger of the three papers.

HIALEAH, Fla., April 22 (UPI) Abort 100 head of cattle, led by a bull, broke from a slaughterhouse pen today and stampeded through Hialeah, snarling traffic and forcing pedestrians to climb trees.
Harvard will open its heavyweight crew season today, with only two oarsmen remaining from its record-breaking eight of last year.
A SECOND HOME, By Brian Glanville, 320 pages, Delacorte. $4.95. IN his new novel, Brian Glanville moves from London's middle class ("Diamond") to the theater's second class.
Secretary of Defense McNamara has met disturbing reports of bomb and other shortages overseas with a denial that is more emphatic than convincing.

WASHINGTON, April 22 A former Federal Aviation Agency employe who led a basic agency study of airliner navigation said today that the study had "cast doubt on the wisdom" of narrowing the air lanes across the Atlantic Ocean.

First-quarter earnings of the Borg-Warner Corporation rose 14 per cent to a record $11,334,000, or $1.20 a share, from $9,959,000, or $1.05 a share, a year earlier. Sales were up 15 per cent to a new high of $227,526,000 from $198,432,000 in 1965's first quarter.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad's chief executive officer said today that it expected to be authorized to discontinue its passenger service in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area by the end of the year.
The long-simmering feud within the New York State Bankers Association over banking legislation currently pending before the State Legislature flared into open and bitter controversy yesterday.
The B.V.D. Company, Inc., a diversified apparel manufacturer, is planning to enter the luggage business in a transaction involving about $8-million in stock.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., April 22 Mrs. Pat Cicl of the Cedar Brook Club posted a 40, 39 79 to win the low-gross prize in the season's first women's Cross-County Golf Association one-day tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today. Par for the 5,939-layout is 36, 36 72.
WASHINGTON, April 22 Discounting Vietnam as a political issue, President Johnson painted a bright picture today of Democratic prospects in the midterm elections.

BERLIN, April 22 East Germany's Supreme Court has sentenced a self-confessed spy for the United States Central Intelligence Agency and two other men who admitted having worked for West Germany to terms ranging from 12 years to life imprisonment. The sentences were imposed last Monday.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 23 --Russell R. Kramer, a lawyer who had represented the United Mine Workers Union and several large corporations, died today in a hospital at Maryville. He was 77 years old.

ON April 24, 1916, the Monday after Easter of that fateful year, Pedraig H. (Patrick Henry) Pearse stood outside the General Post Office in Dublin and read the "Proclamation of the Irish Republic." This symbolic act launched the bloody Easter Week Rising that moved Ireland decisively toward independence.

IN less than a month, the most important international stamp show of the year will open at the Shoreham Hotel in Washington. It will be SIPEX, the Sixth International Philatelic Exhibition, which begins May 21 and continues through May 30. The last previous international show in the United States was staged in 1956.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 23 (AP)--The New York State amateur golf championship will be played July 19 to 23 at the new Concord Hotel course here.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., April 23--Mr. and Mrs. Edward Chessman Jaehnig have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Jaehnig, to George Rumsey Gibson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gibson Jr. of New Vernon.

WHETHER a gardener cultivates on a Manhattan roof or fauns an acre in the suburbs, he can find a use for planters made of natural rocks. Grouped or displayed individually, the versatile containers give dependable and long-lasting performance in limited space, and will harmonize with every landscape design. Ideal for the porch, patio or poolside, they will also dress up steps, walls and drab corners.
NORMAN CLARKE, a Briton, on his first professional visit to the United States, follows an occupation rarely encountered here. He is a custom gun fitter and a shooting coach.

An upheaval has occurred in the relationship between the American Indians and their Government. Secretary of the Interior Udall has removed the Commissioner of Indian Affairs and appointed an Oneida, Robert L. Bennett, as his successor. Mr. Bennett is the first Indian to hold this post in almost a century.

TROY, N.Y., April 23--There are 10,000 fewer persons here than there were 20 years ago, but the city is taking better care than ever of its 65,000 residents who have resisted the flight to the suburbs.

BEN O'MEARA, the Brooklyn-born former blacksmith who was killed in the crash of his private plane last Sunday, was a controversial figure in the horse show world from the time he arrived on the scene.

KANSAS CITY, April 23 (AP)--Mike Hershberger tripled home the first run of the game in the seventh inning tonight, then scored on a single by Bert Campaneris as the Kansas City Athletics edged the Chicago White Sox, 2-1.
AMHERST, Mass., April 23-- The Boston University varsity crew scored a strong victory today over Amherst and St. Joseph's.

RYE, N.Y., April 23--Donald Bomann, former vice president and a director of J.H. Thorp Co., New York, suppliers of imported and domestic drapery and upholstery fabrics, died today in his home, 114 Highland Road. His age was 61.
SAIGON, Sunday, April 24-- Thousands of Roman Catholics demonstrated quietly against the Government of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky this morning in Saigon and outlying areas.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., April 23(UPI)--Point du Jour, a 10-1 shot, survived a gruelling stretch battle with Davis II today and captured the $29,000 Valley Forge Handicap by a neck at Garden State Park.
The Cerro Corporation announced last week that directors had approved construction of the Cobriza copper mine.

Nearly one-fourth of the increase in the nation's manufacturing employment since 1955 occured in the Fifth Federal Reserve District, an area with less than onetenth of the national population, according to the Richmond Federal Reserve Bank.

ATLANTA, April 23--While almost everybody else was preparing to move their clocks ahead today, the New York Mets continued to turn theirs back--back to the old days of the missed opportunity, the wild throw and the losing streak.

QUONDAM is what is called a great English country house, of the palatial Inigo Jones variety. Originally it was designed as a home for one of that race of aristocrats, which, perhaps more than any other, combined sublime assurance and common, common sense --the grandees of 18th-century England. Now empty and overgrown, it is bought "for a song" by Mr. Gervase, an elderly, modestly eccentric property speculator who can afford such whims.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)--A southeast Iowa and southwest Illinois conference beamed toward procurement of Government contracts will be held in Moline, Ill., May 26.

ASUNCION, Paraguay-- High school or even college Spanish will not do for eavesdropping on the sidewalks and in the cafes of this South American capital city. Chances are that the people will be speaking Guaranf, an ancient Indian language.

BALTIMORE, April 23-- Lawrence Cardinal Shehan, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Baltimore, told a Methodist audience today that concrete effects of recent ProtestantCatholic dialogues can already be seen in the Ecumenical Council's teachings on religious liberty and in an increased interest among some Protestant theologians in the Virgin Mary.
MOSCOW, April 23 (AP)-- The Soviet Union announced tonight that it would hold a series of new rocket tests in two areas in the Pacific starting Monday and lasting until July 31.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)--The Defense Department disclosed today that 18,000 bombs had been "reacquired" from several allies for the Vietnam war effort.
ROME, April 23--Pope Paul VI told an international group of scientists today that their work, divorced from the higher interests of man, could become "sterile, useless and, let us say it, harmful."

A rash of arson on Powell Street in Brooklyn's depressed Brownsville-East New York section has been drawing firemen to the scene week after week. "It seems they want to burn down the entire block," a Fire Department official remarked recently.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 23-- Edward E. Black, formerly of this city, assistant to the president of Church and Dwight Company, Inc., of 70 Pine Street, New York, which he served for 68 years, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital. His age was 83.
BERLIN, April 12--The young circuit assembler in the stateowned Radio Factory of Kopenick knew all about East Germany's New Economic System.

William E. Miller, who--as Barry Goldwater's running mate in the 1964 Presidential campaign--often outdid Mr. Goldwater in his searing attacks on liberals, has quietly offered to campaign for Governor Rockefeller's re-election.

BEFORE the Jewish Museum's new sculpture exhibition actually opens (Wednesday) it's being hailed as This Year's Landmark Show (last year's, if you remember, was the Museum of Modern Art's Optacular, "The Responsive Eye").

MADRID, April 23--In the Spanish monastery where the Grand Inquisitor, Tomas Torquemada, lies buried, a Jewish community leader stood up this month to tell assembled priests and friars about the Jewish faith.
SAIGON, Sunday, April 24-- United States Air Force pilots shot down two Soviet-built MIG-17 jets over North Vietnam yesterday afternoon.

The election of J. Marshall Gaffney, European vice president of United States Lines, to the first top executive office ever held by an American in the International Chamber of Shipping, was announced last week by Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

Capt. Bernt A. Jacobsen, the first master of the American liner Constitution, died Thursday in Richmond Memorial Hospital, Princes Bay, S.I. He was 75 years old and lived at 222 Guyon Avenue, S.I.

DAKAR, Senegal, April 23-- If any one idea has dominated the talk of Dakar's first World Festival of the Negro Arts, it is the controversy over "negri tude," a word that is said to signify that the creative process of Negro artist is unique.

The Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital in Denver will benefit from the Carnation Ball to be held in the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana Hotel on May 13. Robert W. Dowling is chairman of the event.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 23--The Provisional President and the police chief appealed today to the Dominican people to remain calm and avoid extremist agitation during the week marking the first anniversary of the revolution and United States intervention.

Four-year-old Nancy clings to her mother's hand and refuses to join in the blockbuilding at nursery school. Michael doesn't want to go away to camp this summer like most of his fourthgrade classmates.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)--Criticism was directed at Johnson Administration farm price policies today by a farm organization that long has been a stanch supporter of the Democratic party and its national officials.

SPRING heralds the arrival not only of new buds and blooms but also a new crop of spring garden books. The orchid, one of the most colorful plants found in the tropics, is more rugged than one would think. An accurate review of the plant's growing habits is told in precise language by Jeanne Garrard in "Growing Orchids for Pleasure" (A. S. Barnew, $7.50). This versatile volume includes chapters on lore and corsage making.

GUTTENBERG, N.J., April 23--The marriage of Miss Pamela Joan Schwab and Robert Edward Dalton took place today in the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Nepomucene, The Rev. Edward Matash performed the ceremony.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 23--Michael Brody has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Robin Clarke Brody, to Leighton R. Longhi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Longhi of Orange, Conn. The wedding is planned for next year.

BALTTMORE, April 23-- Maryland's governorship race began taking shape this week as the Baltimore County Executive, Spiro T. Agnew, filed for the Republican nomination after Attorney General Thomas B. Finan confirmed he would run in the Democratic primary.

The copper industry, which in historical teams has risen steadily ever since the metal was first smelted thousands of years before Christ, may seem indestructible. The industry calls copper the eternal metal.

OWNERS of truly beautiful lawns often spend less time on upkeep than owners of sparse, poor lawns. This is probably because the homeowner with the beautful greensward follows a systematic method of maintenance. In the long run, this saves time and money.

THOUGH fluorescent lamps will burn many times longer than conventional incandescent lamps (and at less cost for the same amount of illumination) sooner or later they do start to develop trouble. The lamps may fail to light entirely, or they may flicker and blink unpredictably when switched on.
MADRID, April 23 (AP)-- Mrs. John F. Kennedy capped a week's visit in Spain tonight with an ambassadorial dinner attended by princes, ministers, generals and counts.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla.-- At St. Marks, a half hour drive from this capital city, a monument of great significance in the history of Florida and the nation has been opened to the public. It is called San Marcos de Apalachee Historic Memorial, and it is named for the Spanish fort that was built there three centuries ago.
NORFOLK, Va., April 23 (AP)--Dr. Walter B. Martin, president of the American Medical Association in 1954-55, died at his home here today. He was 78 years old.
LONDON, April 23--Zambian copper producers announced today that they would begin selling copper at the market price on the London Metal Exchange.
OBERLIN, Ohio, April 23 (AP)--Dr. Walter Marshall Horton, theologian, who had taught at Oberlin College from 1925 to 1962, died yesterday in the Allen Memorial Hospital here. He was 71 years old.

HONG KONG, April 23--The children of Communist China now get their first political lectures at the age of 7. To facilitate an enormous expansion of Communist youth organizations, the eligible age for entry into the Young Pioneers has been lowered from 9 to 7.
LONDON, April 23--One of the most influential men in Prime Minister Wilson's "kitchen cabinet" is a former army colonel with jug-handle ears and a lugubrious mouth.

GROSSE POINTE, Mich., April 23--Miss Mary Waye MacArthur and Gary Thomas Walther plan to be married on July 2. Mr. and Mrs. Reginald MacArthur have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Walther Jr. of Bay City.
GERMAN shepherd admirers, who like to think their breed is the smartest, had reason for satisfaction in the figures for obedience degrees gained in 1965 issued last week by the American Kennel Club.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 22--The S.S. Fairland sails from Elizabeth, N.J., for Rotterdam Saturday carrying 226 containers. The bills of lading will specify such contents as safety razors, cameras, supplies for the United States Army, chemicals and components for prefabricated houses.

Three major United States court decisions in 1964 may hold the key to litigation that could arise in the dispute between the nine newspaper craft unions and the new World Journal Tribune, Inc., a merger of The Herald Tribune, The Journal-American and The WorldTelegram and The Sun.

KRISTIN HUNTER's first paragraph defines the allegorical dimensions of "The Landlord": "Elgar Enders patted the four new crisp rent books with tender satisfaction. At last he had a business: Real Estate. An occupational title: Landlord. A piece of property, described in a deed with fine legal exactness; Three stories, four units, so many square feet on a lot one hundred by fifty, valuation for tax purposes, twelve thousand dollars."
WASHINGTON, April 23-- George E. Reedy, the special assistant to President Johnson who has worked for him longer than any top staff man, will resign soon to enter private business.
EUREKA, Calif.--Agitation in Congress for a Redwood National Park has given businessmen here visions of increased tourist dollars from visitors pouring into the Redwood Empire this summer.

Newspaper owners from every section of the country are flocking into New York today for the annual celebration of Publishers Week, but they may discover they have arrived in a journalistic ghost town.

ARDMORE, Okla., April 23 (AP)--Federal investigators sifted wreckage today to determine what caused a charter airliner with 92 servicemen and a crew of 6 to crash near here last night. There were only 17 survivors.

One way to increase membership in a sailing club is to add more cocktail parties, brunches and cook-outs to the social calendar. Another is to add more boats to the club's fleet.

GLASGOW, Scotland, April 23--Three spectators collapsed and died and more than 40 others were injured in riots following a soccer match today between the Glasgow Celtics and the Glasgow Rangers at Hampden Park.

GROTON, Conn., April 23-- Edmund G. (Ned) Anderson, former secretary of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association and a founder of the Junior Yacht Racing Association, died today in Lawrence Memorial Hospital, New London. He was 82 years old.
After seven years as chef over a staff of 37 cooks and helpers at Le Pavillon, Clement Rene Grangier has quit to become the supervisory chef for the Campbell Soup Company.

WHERE are the young playwrights? The cry is as old as the theater, uttered in all ages in tones mingling muted hope with black despair. Now, as another unproductive Broadway season nears its final curtain, the cry--more like an anguished wail--has taken on an urgency the likes of which have not been heard in years.

Retail trade is on a high plateau and will climb higher. The nation's chain stores and mail-order houses completed the first quarter of the year with a sales gain of close to 14 per cent, compared with the level of the corresponding period last year. Volume at department stores went ahead by more than 11 per cent.

The appointment of the Rev. Frederick L. Canavan as dean of Fordham University's School of General Studies was announced yesterday. In September the school will begin evening courses open to men and women in liberal arts, business administration and education.

WASHINGTON, April 23-- An exodus of administrative, scientific and technical personnel, resulting from a governmental reorganization, is threatening to slow President Johnson's efforts to clean up the nation's water supplies.

BOWIE, Md., May 23--Michael J. Ford's Kauai King, who has demonstrated he is partial to off tracks, handled today's sloppy conditions at Bowie as if he reveled in them, winning the $118,500 Governor's Gold Cup impressively before a disappointing turnout of 15,030.

CATTLE brands are an integral and fascinating part of the folklore and tradition of the Southwest. The casual traveler, cruising along where the vast ranges extend to the highways' edges, is sure to encounter a variety of brands on the flanks of grazing cattle and horses. He may, as likely as not, come upon clusters of ranchers at work, with their branding tools over hot fires in pens full of bawling calves.

What they want, simply, is for these people (and themselves) to gain some control over the way they live their lives.

CROTCH ISLAND, Me., April 23--The noisy grind of pneumatic chisels drowns out the cries of the sea gulls these days as warming weather permits the speeding up of quarrying the granite for the permanent gravesite of President Kennedy in Arlington Cemetery.
Five hundred students at New York City Community College are being denied the status of degree candidates because of the insufficiency of city funds provided to the college.

SEOUL, Korea, April 23-- South Korea has attained an annual economic growth rate of 7.6 per cent during the first four years of its current fiveyear plan and expects to complete 83 per cent of the plan's projects on schedule this year.

The World Book Year Book is being printed in a 2.1-million volume press run while Britannica Book of the Year has a print order of about one-million. These figures show that the annuals are two of the leading best sellers among all American books and also indicate how important encyclopedias are in the publishing industry.
WASHINGTON, April 23-- The Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy urged Congress today to reverse Defense Department plans by authorizing the construction of two nuclear-powered destroyers.

LONDON, April 23--American hopes of victory dwindled to the vanishing point in the Sunday Times international invitation pair contest here tonight. With eight matches out of 13 completed, all three American pairs were virtually out of contention.
DALLAS, April 23 (AP)-- Torrential downpours of more than nine inches sent flood waters swirling in northeast Texas today in the wake of tornadoes that smashed through three small towns.

HERE'S a tip to fans and sympathizers of William Talman, the actor who plays Dis trict Attorney Hamilton Burger on "Perry Mason." In the farewell episode filmed last week in Hollywood, Mr. Talman went out in a great blaze of non-glory. He lost two cases, twice as many as he ever lost in some 250 other episodes.

OKLAHOMA CITY--Oklahoma, highways have improved markedly since the time when a cross-country motorist had but one thought--to traverse them quickly as possible and head onward. He wanted to sprint through the Sooner State, but the highways did not cooperate.

Two years ago Cle and Jean Kinney bought 50 acres of rundown farmland in New Milford, Conn., for $18,000. The site, once a tobacco farm, was swampy and overgrown with weeds and tangled underbrush.

STAPHORST, the Netherlands--A tourist click ing a camera in this village is asking for trouble. In Staphorst, picturetaking is against the law, and a sign in front of the City Hall makes this clear in four languages--Dutch, German, English and French. The pictures accompanying this article? They are contraband.

PARIS, April 23--Gen. Charles de Gaulle will withdraw all French officers and forces from the integrated military system of the North Atlantic alliance by July 1, and he insists that by April 1 next year all foreign military installations in France be removed or put under exclusive French control.

PARIS, April 23--The Government invited Citroen today to join Renault and Peugeot in a merger. Citroen was silent. The others replied that two's company and three's a crowd.

TOKYO, April 18--Shopowners along Tokyo's crowded, brightly-lighted Ginza, opened a drive today to keep the advance of staid-looking banks from giving an unwanted air of sobriety to the city's main shopping and entertainment center.

Brown's track team took the lead in the second event and went on to an easy victory over Columbia and Pennsylvania in a triangular meet yesterday afternoon at Baker Field. The Bruins finished with 92 points, Columbia 52 and Penn 47.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The specific subject of inquiry by the Senate Select Committee on Standards and Conduct is whether Senator Thomas J. Dodd of Connecticut violated the ethical code which should govern a public official in his uses of the more than $100,000 raised at "testimonial" dinners to defray personal expenses.

Sixteen men and women who operated a lucrative telephoneorder business in stolen merchandise and a side racket in false insurance claims, according to the police, were arrested in two raids in Brooklyn yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 23 (AP)--President Tito returned to Belgrade today after a five-day official visit to neighboring Rumania.

The marriage of Miss Patricia Ellen Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Godfrey Davis of 141 East 55th Street, to Thomas Duffy Zumbo, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Zumbo, took place yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Agnes.

THE City Gardens Club will conduct its 20th annual showing of Manhattan gardens and penthouse terraces on May 3 and 10. Six gardens will be on display each of the two days of the tour from 2:30 to 6 P.M. Proceeds from the tour will be used to finance scholarships for New York public school teachers at nature study camps conducted by the Audubon Society in Maine and Connecticut, and for other club projects.

KELSEY BAY, Vancouver Island, B.C.--A ship called the Queen of Prince Rupert will go into service here on May 20. She will have a dining room and a cafeteria, passenger elevators, spacious lounges and de luxe staterooms. With all that finery, how will anyone convince the Queen she is only a ferry?

In 1891, Claude William Dukinfield, age 11, ran away from his poor but miserable home in Philadelphia, determined to make a name for himself as a comic juggler. SEVENTY years ago America was enjoying its Golden Age of Philosophy. At Harvard, William James was expounding the new pragmatism and looking at the classical questions of man's place in the universe with an unparalleled freshness of perception. At Chicago, John Dewey was fashioning with the help of teachers at the Laboratory School a new answer to Pontius Pilate's query, "What is truth?" Truth, said Dewey, was an instrument for reforming and remaking the world.

WHEN lubricating hinges on doors that squeak the homeowner is often frustrated because the squeak continues even after oil is applied. In most cases this is due to the fact that the oil did not penetrate fully into the hinge pin--either because the pin fits too tightly, or because caked-on paint has sealed the crevices between the hinge leaves.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) --William J. Griffin will be Customs Commissioner for the new Region 1, covering Buffalo and Ogdensburg, N.Y., and the New England states, under a Treasury Department reorganization of the Customs Service.

The new trading restrictions announced by the New York and American Stock Exchanges represent a commendable exercise in self-regulation. These two major markets, which together account for well over 90 per cent of the trading in listed securities, have recognized the necessity of curbing the huge increase in speculative activity that has swept Wall Street.

L. Rohe Walter, special assistant to Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield during the Administrations of President Dwight D. Eisenhower, died yesterday in his home at 330 East 76th Street. His age was 67.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 23 --Mr. and Mrs. John Jermain Slocum of Newport and Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irene Marguerite Slocum, to John B. Trevor 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Trevor Jr. of Wyndover, Paul Smiths, N.Y., land of New York.

NEW HAVEN, April 23-- Yale's lacrosse team rallied for six goals in the second period and four more in the third to score a 12-8 victory over previously undefeated Army today in the Yale Bowl.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 23--In the Episcopal Church of the Holy Innocents here this afternoon, Miss Alicia Quigley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas T. MOSCOW, April 23--A painful dilemma confronts the Soviet Communist party as it prepares for nest year's 50th anniversary of the victory of the Bolsheviks in Russia. How can the party point with pride to 50 years of Soviet rule when nearly half that period was denounced as Stalinist despotism by Nikita S. Khrushchev in his famous secret speech of 1956?

FOR John Coltrane, 1965 was quite a year. The readers of Down Beat, the jazz magazine, voted him the best Jazz tenor saxophonist of the year, named him "Jazzman of the Year," elected him to the magazine's Hall of Fame, and chose his recording of "A Love Supreme" as the record of the year, a choice that was echoed in's poll conducted by Jazz magazine.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 23 --Jim Ryun, the 18-year-old Kansas freshman, ran the Glenn Cunningham Mile in 3 minutes 55.8 seconds today at the 41st Kansas Relays. His time was a half-second slower than his own American record. It is the best in the world this year.

On Friday, Aug. 20, 1937, in 100-degree heat at Baker Bowl in Philadelphia, Mel Ott hit a home run for the New York Giants in the ninth inning of a 13-6 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

Mrs. Gertrude D.H. Perlman, a lawyer for more than 50 years and an attorney with the New York State Mortgage Commission until her retirement in the early nineteen-fifties, died Saturday in her home at 160 East 89th Street. She was 81 years old and was the widow of Max Perlman.
LONDON, Monday, April 25 The Morning Star, a bigger and more readable Communist newspaper than The Daily Worker, which it replaces, made its debut today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 24 Leo H. Rich, a former president of L.H. Rich, Inc., industrial consultants in New York, died yesterday in his home at 34 Oxford Road. He was 69 years old.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) Don Kessinger's triple in the second inning scored two runs today and the Chicago Cubs made the tallies stand up for a 2-0 victory over Don Drysdale and the Los Angeles Dodgers.

DALLAS, April 24 (UPI) John Lotz celebrated his 25th birthday today by tying Harold Henning for the third-round lead in the Dallas open golf tournament. They posted eightunder-par scores of 205 for 54 holes.

PARIS, April 24 (AP) Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville denied today that France's withdrawal from the military structure of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was against the interests of the United States and her other allies.

Samuel J. Borowsky of New York, Zionist leader and a leading American Hebrew educator, died yesterday in a hospital in Israel. He was 71 years old and lived at 315 East 68th Street.

Cardinal Spellman presided yesterday at a pontifical mass that opened the 1966 Catholic Charities Appeal. About 1,500 persons attended the 10 A.M. service in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 24 The fathers came to Vassar College this weekend to get to know the school, its faculty and their daughters. "It's the first time in 19 years that we've really talked, and we're both getting to say a lot of good things we've left unsaid too long," Clinton Englander said yesterday afternoon as he and his daughter parked their bicycles outside the Vassar Gymnasium and went in for a swim.
Jack I. Wagenheim, a member of The New York Post advertising staff, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 325 East 79th Street. He was 58 years old.

Five hundred persons paid a total of about $20,000 to attend a benefit stage show last night for WNDT, the educational television station. The show, for which theatrical performers donated their services, was taped for broadcast over Channel 13 from 8:30 to 11 tonight and a repeat at the same time Wednesday.

Kings County District Attorney Aaron E. Koota said yesterday that his office was investigating complaints that hallucinatory drugs had been manufactured or compounded by students in three city colleges, 13 high schools and a grammar school in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 24 The upsurge of public and Congressional interest in auto safety has brought into the open a dispute within the engineering profession over the ethics and licensing of automotive engineers.
BATON ROUGE, La., April 24 John F. Kennedy and Huey P. Long are among the major influences in this year's Senate race in Louisiana.

MEXICO CITY, April 24 The Inter-American Development Bank announced today the approval of seven loans totaling $47.6-million to help finance economic and social development loans throughout its LatinAmerican member countries.

WASHINGTON, April 24 The Federal Aviation Agency pronounced the advent of the jet age at Washington National Airport an operational and an acoustical success today.

The president of Princeton Theological Seminary told worshipers in St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday that within a "splintered and fragmented" Protestantism there persists a "deep theological conviction" for unity.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 24-Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Gately Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Mavourneen Gately, to Edward John Shanaphy of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Shanaphy of Long Branch, N.J.
WASHINGTON, April 24 Hundreds of persuaders will flock to Capitol Hill this week to exert pressure on Congress for broad consumer legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 24 The United Mine Workers of America and big Eastern soft coal producers have reached an agreement on a new 30-month labor contract that should end a two-week-old strike by 50,000 miners this week.

The Maritime Administration has invited 10 subsidized steamship lines to join a cooperative venture to obtain maximum shipbuilding mileage from the $109-million available for ship construction in the fiscal year 1967.
More than 1,000 persons went to, or stayed on the campus of Princeton University on the weekend to examine "What's Happening: The Arts 1966."
A 22-year-old man was held in $15,000 bail yesterday on charges of having raped one woman and of having attempted to rape another on the Upper East Side early Saturday morning.

Silas Lloyd-Jones, a partner in the Lloyd-Jones Company, certified public accountants and management consultants, 420 Lexington Avenue, New York, died Friday at St. Mary's Hospital in Tucson, Ariz., after an illness of three weeks. He was 70 years old and lived at 430 West 116th Street, New York.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Norm Cash's triple and home run powered the Detroit Tigers to a 4-1 second-game victory over the Washington Senators today and a sweep of their double-header.

Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving announced yesterday that a contract had been awarded to a Negro architectural firm for designing an $850,000 swimming pool and bathhouse in Harlem's Mount Morris Park.

Bach's "Passion According to St. Matthew" is one of the most difficult of all large-scale choral works to perform well. This is not just because it requires a double chorus and additional soprano choir, a double orchestra, six major vocal soloists and some minor ones and several skilled instrumental soloists.

MICKEY WALKER made it eventually and went on to gain recognition as one of the better middleweight cham pions. In his first try, however, the famed Toy Bulldog, then the holder of the welterweight crown, was soundly thrashed by Harry Greb, the ruler of the bigger division.
The Zambian Government imposed an export tax on copper yesterday in a move designed to bring its revenues from the scarce metal into line with Chile's.
NEW DELHI, April 24 The death toll in last night's explosion of a passenger train in Assam State rose to 40 tonight. The explosion was the second there in four days.

Newspaper executives from major cities deplored the industry's labor troubles in New York City yesterday as distorting a picture of general newspaper advances. They described newspaper gains elsewhere as reflecting the nation's prosperity, and linked successes to strong news coverage and community effort.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 24 Dominicans celebrated today the first anniversary of the revolt that overthrew the junta of Dr. Donald Reid Cabral.

Louis A. Lotito, president of City Playhouses, which controls the Morosco and Helen Hayes Theaters, will reach his 50th year in show business today. The showman, who was born on Manhattan's East Side on July 24, 1900, began his career as an usher at the old Hippodrome when he was 16 years old.

TAOS, N.M., April 19 With freedom of religion long assured to most citizens, a remote tribe of the nation's first Americans is now urging Congress to apply the full force of the First Amendment to them.

WASHINGTON, April 24--A House Armed Services subcommittee has sharply challenged Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's plans to cut the United States' manned bomber force by approximately one-third over the next five years.
Council President Frank D. O'Connor predicted yesterday that the City Council would vote home rule messages for Mayor Lindsay's entire $520-million tax package, "but only because its hands are tied."

TRENTON, April 24 Rodger Ward of Indianapolis won a rain-shortened championship race on Trenton's one-mile speedway today. His victory, achieved in a Lola powered by a supercharged rear-mounted Offenhauser, owned by John Mecom Jr. of Houston, was the first in major competition for that power plant. It also was Mecom's first victory on the United States Automobile Club championship circuit.

BOSTON, April 24 (UPI) The officials in today's LakersCeltics National Basketball Association playoff game, Earl Strom and Norm Drucker, scuffled with several fans after the game.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 24 Mr. and Mrs. Howard P. Farwell Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Frances Farwell, to Stephen Arthur Patay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Patay of Pekin, Ill.

Following is the first of five articles on the Central Intelligence Agency. The articles are by a team of New York Times correspondents consisting of Tom Wicker, John W. Finney, Max Frankel, E.W. Kenworthy and other Times staff members.
ATLANTA, April 24 The Marines came to the rescue of the New York Mets today, just when all seemed lost and the club was sliding back toward last place in the National League.
Dr. Alonzo S. Yerby, the city's Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday that the city would have to pay its nurses more money to reach a contract settlement with them.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the first quarter of 1966 was the most active in its history.
KANSAS CITY, April 24 (UPI) Tom McCraw's fourth single, following Ken Berry's triple gave the Chicago White Sox a 4-3 victory over the Kansas City Athletics in 10 innings today.

MONZA, Italy, April 24 (UPI) Roger Mack, a British auto racer, broke a rib in a crash during a Formula-Three race today in which Italian De Sanctis cars vindicated their reputation against the powerful Brabhams.

VALPARAISO, Chile, April 24 (UPI) The Soviet Union took the lead in the world amateur basketball championship tonight by beating Chile, 69-59, for its third victory in the final round without a defeat. Earlier the Russians downed Spain, 89-50.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)--A physician who helped to develop the heart pump and put it into use for the first time on a human patient says the device will never be patented, but should be available for everyone.
Elizabeth Fairall, known as the dean of American fashion buyers, died yesterday at her home in Washington. She was 85 years old.

Stock prices wandered aimlessly yesterday, lacking leadership and direction.

The commander of Columbia University's unit of the Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps said yesterday that he had ordered the cancellation of the group's annual award ceremony, originally scheduled for May 6.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 24 This mountain-ringed, desert city where almost everyone hails from someplace else has plenty of Pucci pajamas, low-heeled Pilgrimbuckled shoes by Vivier, white mesh stockings and a Red Dog discotheque where lights flash on the black ceiling as the rock 'n' roll band plays the frug.

True to past performance, the Legislative has made a wretched beginning on two bills to strengthen the state's code of ethics. One bill is designed to create a State Commission on Ethics to give advisory opinions on difficult cases; the other would prohibit all state employes, including legislators, from representing private interests for compensation before state agencies.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- Import rose 4 per cent in March from February, less than exports Increased, the Commerce Department reported today.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 25 --A dozen German and American literary figures discussed "The Writer in the Affluent Society" at Princeton University today at a conference that itself reflected some aspects of its topic.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Central Intelligence Agency traces its beginnings to the intelligence failure that made the Japanese sneak attack on Pearl Harbor possible. The agency owes its phenomenal growth to the cold war with the Soviet Union.

Raymond H. Belknap, president of the United States Life Insurance Company, 125 Maiden Lane, died yesterday in California, where he had undergone an operation. He was 58 years old and lived at 200 East 68th Street.
Copper stocks moved up sharply on the London Stock Exchange yesterday following a decision by Zambia to sell copper at the free-market rate instead of the much lower controlled level.
The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service yesterday stepped into the deadlocked negotiations between the striking Newspaper Guild of New York and the newly merged World Journal Tribune, Inc.
Two restful open spaces in Midtown Manhattan won honors yesterday for excellence in architecture and urban design.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The United States has decided to end the exchange of diplomatic notes with President de Gaulle and turn to oral discussions.

A stinging criticism of the mass communications media-- especially television--was made yesterday by W.H. Ferry, a vice president of the Fund for the Republic's Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- A group of observers who spent last week in the Dominican Republic reported today that they had found strong distrust among Dominicans about the United States' willingness to support democracy there.

A play that was turned down by at least 15 Broadway producers and, when it did make a shaky start, was not given more than a few weeks to run, went on to win the Pulitzer, Critics Circle and Tony prizes. Now it is edging toward the end of a career.

ALBANY, April 25--Governor Rockefeller sent the Legislature today a package of three bills designed to protect the average wage-earner from the possible "tragedies" of borrowing money or buying on credit.
The Savannah, the world's only nuclear powered merchant ship, recently supplied some unusual assistance to the Manchester Merchant when a fire broke out in a hold while in the North Atlantic.

Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., announced yesterday the establishment of a special pharmaceutical division within the agency.

NAPLES, Italy, April 25 (UPI)--Nicola Pietrangeli, the Italian Davis Cup star, won the men's singles today in the Naples international tennis tournament, defeating Tony Roche of Australia, 8-6, 2-6, 6-2, 6-1, in the final round.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 25 --Eastern European and Western scholars are meeting at the University of Notre Dame to discuss the role of Karl Marx in the modern world.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 25 (AP)--The Florida East Coast Railway kept some trains running today despite a strike by trainmen, firemen and conductors who are protesting new pay and work rules.
The Society of the Silurians presented awards last night to nine journalists and a newspaper.
The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian, had a winning position against the challenger, Boris Spassky, at the adjournment of the seventh game of their title match last night.
ASPARAGUS from California and Mexico is appearing in many local markets, a delicacy of spring and a versatile Avegetable.
The City Corporation Counsel's office has ruled that Mayor Lindsay's appointment of Dr. Nachman Bench to a $20,000a-year post as deputy city administrator was illegal because he is an alien.
LONDON, April 25--Copper prices dropped sharply here today in the wake of last Saturday's decision by Zambian producers to base their selling ...
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)--A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that Olympic Airways be granted a route between Greece and New York City.
WASHINGTON, April 25 --President Johnson sent to Congress today a plan to reorganize the Public Health Service "to bring new strength to the administration of Federal health programs."

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (AP)--Harry T. Griffith, 62 years old, of Flourtown, Pa., who underwent an exchange of cancerous tissue a few weeks ago in an effort to save the lives of himself and his partner in the experiment, died here today.

BERLIN, April 25--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard said today that West Germany was seeking talks with the Soviet Union on the question of Germany's future and would welcome a visit by Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin in Bonn "any day."
The Board of Higher Education created the position of administrative vice chancellor or the City University last night and appointed Dr. Harry L. Levy to the post.
WASHINGTON, April 25 --Nine years ago, a Houston advertising man named Jack J. Valenti met a United States Senator named Lyndon B. Johnson.
The Astor Library, a landmark spared destruction recently when it was bought by the New York Shakespeare Festival, will be the setting for the Saved From the Wreckers Ball tomorrow night.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 25 --Public attitudes on Vietnam, Federal domination of land holdings in the West, and resentment over an economy request from Washington were discussed at the Western Governors Conference here today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, April 26 (Reuters)--President Sukarno has formed a new 66-member Supreme Advisory Council after dismissing the 70 members of the old body, the official Antara press agency said today.
LONDON, April 28 (Reuters) An explosion killed one of five Russians watching a laboratory experiment at an engineering factory in southwest London tonight.
LONDON, Apri1 26 The British Government is putting new emphasis on "joining Europe."

WASHINGTON, April 26 Robert G. Baker, former secretary to the Senate Democratic majority, who is under indictment for tax evasion, theft and conspiracy, accused the Government today of "massive wiretapping" and of indicting him in an atmosphere of "extensive publicity."
Leroy C. Griffith, who operates a number of burlesque houses, has added the Hudson Theater, 141 West 44th Street, and Coney Island's Shore Theater to his circuit.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The Treasury auctioned $1-billion of one-year bills today at an average discount rate of 4.773 per cent, up slightly from last month's issue but well below the peak reached in February.

A good looking 2-year-old colt named Al G. Specialist, who has fine conformation except for knees that protrude more than usual, was watched with particular interest by his trainer, John Rigione, at Aqueduct yesterday.
NEWINGTON, Conn., April 26 (AP) A Connecticut con tractor said today he had lent a new car to Senator Thomas J. Dodd. "on a personal basis having nothing to do with my business operations."
Tradition and innovation are blended in the opening exhibition today of the new Gallery of Chinese American Art at 399 East 72d Street.

WASHINGTON, April 26 Noting a general lag in desegregation of school districts under court order, the Depart ment of Justice petitioned tonight for a uniform decree that would have the effect of speeding integration in many Southern cities and counties next fall.
LOS ANGELES, April 26 (UPI) Hedy Lamarr, the actress, was acquitted today of stealing $86 worth of merchandise from a department store by a Municipal Court jury that deliberated about five hours.
DETROIT, April 26 The General Motors Corporation denied today that its push-button seat belts, offered as an extra-cost optional feature, were unsafe.
ROME, April 26 (Reuters) The International Olympic Com mittee awarded today the 1972 summer games to Munich and the winter games to Sapporo Japan.

There can be no doubt that Britain turned an important corner in its struggle to end the white rebellion in Rhodesia when the Royal Navy acted under United Nations sanction to divert the oil tanker Manuela from Beira in Portuguese Mozambique. What is still in doubt is whether this was the decisive corner and, if it was, how long the struggle may yet have to be waged.

DALLAS, April 26 (UPI) Roberto De Vicenzo of Argentina, who came to Dallas to see friends, also won a golf tournament here today. He took the Dallas open's $15,000 first prize with an eight under-par total of 276 for 72 holes.

New Yorkers who were not mixed up in last Tuesday night's marathon of gala benefit parties and hundreds who were found themselves artgallery hopping in evening clothes last night, mostly along Madison Avenue.

Testimony was presented at a Coast Guard hearing yesterday that the helmsman of the Grace Line passenger-cargo ship Santa Isabel turned the ship's wheel the wrong way before the vessel struck the Raritan River Drawbridge last March 3.

LONDON, April 26 Noel Coward performed last night at the Queen's Theatre in the two one-act plays that complete his trilogy "Suite in Three Keys." The trilogy opened 10 days ago with "A Song at Twilight."

GRAHAM HILL of England or Chris Amon of New Zealand may be in the driver's seat of a John Mecom Jr. car when practice starts next week for the 500-mile Memorial Day race at Indianapolis. Mecom already has Rodger Ward of Indianapolis and Jackie Stewart of Scotland...

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 26 State laboratory tests show that a Fairfield University basketball player who fell to his death behind a Fairfield motor inn last Feb. 15 "had been drinking heavily," a coroner's report said today.
SAIGON, April 26 Authoritative sources said today that none of the MIG jet fighters that had engaged in fights over North Vietnam had been identified as Chinese.

WASHINGTON, April 26 A panel of international economic experts established by the original charter of the Alliance for Progress has resigned. The group asserted that it had lost its independence. Its members believe there is too much dominance of the alliance by the United States.
The American Express Com pany plans to enter the municipal bond business in a substantial way as an underwriter, Howard L. Clark, president, told a quiet annual meeting yesterday.
Jacob Pat, secretary emeritus of the Jewish Labor Committee, died yesterday in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 573 Grand Street.
The Board of Education announced yesterday a drastic scaling down of its plans to strengthen and expand school services next fall.
MADRID, April 26 The Spanish Air Ministry said today that the prohibition on flights over Spain by bombers carrying nuclear weapons was being maintained.
Herbert Lee Massey, a bigvoiced baritone from San Angelo, Tex., made his local debut last night at Town Hall.

THERE was a long delay while Frank Morris of the boxing commission carefully checked the cards of the three officials. Most ringsiders wondered what the fuss was all about. They thought Dick Tiger had successfully defended his world middleweight title against Emile Griffith at Madison Square Garden Monday night.
Gerald Tsai Jr., whose new mutual fund has dazzled Wall Street with its spectacular sales, put more than one-quarter of a billion dollars in the stock market during the six weeks ended March 31.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The Center of International Studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology disclosed today that it would "reluctantly" sever connections with the Central Intelligence Agency at the end of June.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 26 Mrs. John McDonald Holtzinger has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Wanda Sue Holtzinger, to Prof. Robert Clifford Gunning. He is the son of Mrs. Clifford Henry Gunning of Longmont, Colo., and the late Mr. Gunning.
ST. VINCENT, Italy, April 26 North America, got off to a shaky start in its match against The Netherlands in the Bermuda Cup tournament here this afternoon . . .
DETROIT, April 26 The automobile industry opened a new phase in the safety war today with its reluctant endorsement of mandatory Government standards.
Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday that it had purchased $112-million of new jet airliners and reported that its first-quarter profits before taxes were 21 per cent higher than a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The Johnson Administration has decided to ask West Germany to forgo indefinitely even nominal ownership of part of an allied nuclear weapons system and to be content with improved consultation on nuclear strategy.
The aerial battles over North Vietnam since the weekend may be the start of a more intensive air war.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The National Academy of Sciences elected 42 new members today, bringing its membership to 745. Election to the academy is an acknowledgement of accomplishment in any of a wide range of scientific fields.
MOSCOW, April 26 A severe earthquake struck Tashkent, in Soviet Central Asia, early today, destroying many homes, several hospitals, schools and public buildings.
Soybeans staged one of their most spectacular rises in years yesterday in active trading.
CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP) The United Automobile Workers was defeated today in the first attempt in its national iorganizing drive among Ford Motor Company's 30,000 whitecollar workers.
