PITTSBURGH, April 26 The Gulf Oil Corporation has ordered construction of six huge oil tankers, each of which will be longer than the liner France and almost four times heavier than the Queen Elizabeth.

WASHINGTON, April 26 To the men most privy to the secrets of the Central Intelligence Agency, it sometimes seems that the human spies, the James Bonds and Mata Haris, are obsolete. Like humans everywhere, they are no match for the computers, cameras, radars and other gadgets by which nations can now gather the darkest secrets of both friends and foes.

BALTIMORE, April 26 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles hit four homers tonight and defeated the California Angels, 7-3, for their seventh straight victory. Brooks Robinson, Dave Johnson, Andy Etchebarren and Curt Blefary connected for the victors.

WHITE PLAINS, April 26 Yonkers police officials were accused in State Supreme Court here today of bullying a 17year-old youth into confessing falsely that he started a fire Dec. 20 at the Yonkers Jewish Community Center that killed 12 persons.
WASHINGTON, April 26 The automobile industry hedged its support of Federal safety standards for new cars today with testimony that "appropriate guidelines and procedures should be set by Congress.

CHICAGO, April 26 Leo Durocher probably thinks that the New York Mets are the nicest guys in the league because they always finish last. But today they encountered Leo for the first time since he replaced 10 coaches as manager of the Chicago Cubs, and this time the Mets finished on top.

Native Prince was one of six favorites to score. The program started and ended on a chalk note as Randolph Weinsier's favored Steve's Vow took the opening contest and Mrs. Walter Kelley's Hy-Nat won the finale.

MIAMI BEACH, April 26 The National Association of Tobacco Distributors adopted a resolution today condeming the "pernicious" bootlegging of cigarattes. The association caused for severe national and local laws to help eliminate the illegal tobacco traffic.
The stock of Ogilvy Mather International, Inc., made its debut in the financial market yesterday with the public offering of 349,883 common shares at $22 each.
Miss Diana Beal and Richard John Wadia plan to marry next month in Beirut, Lebanon, where he is with the Shell Oil Company.

CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP) The undefeated Cleveland Indians, led by Luis Tiant's threehit pitching, beat the Kansas City Athletics, 4-0, tonight for their ninth victory, tying an American League record for the most consecutive victories at the start of the season.

The executive director of the Port of New York Authority yesterday accused the head of the syndicate that owns the Empire State Building of opposing the authority's projected World Trade Center for "narrow and selfish" reasons.
MEXICO CITY, April 26 The president of the InterAmerican Development Bank today called on Latin Americans to move decisively toward establishing a common market for the entire region.
NEW DELHI, April 26 V.K. Krishna Menon, leader of the left wing in India's governing Congress party, delivered a subtle but stinging attack today on Government policies.

SAIGON The armed forces have little intention of relinquishing control of South Vietnam's Government without a struggle. They contemplate creating their own party to present candidates for next September's Constituent Assembly. By this device Premier Nguyen Cao Ky hopes to get himself voted back into power in national elections.
THE place to see the latest "moon baby" fashions is the friendly neighborhood discotheque, where mirror dresses flash, plastics rattle and vinyls glow in the dark.
BERLIN, April 26 The East German Communists named two high-ranking officials today to meet with representatives of West Germany's Social Democrats on the terms for meetings envisaged for next month.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to fall yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7926, down 3 points.

"Bob Hope, American," became yesterday the first person outside the ranks of journalism to receive the Silver Lady Award of the Banshees, communications executives' club sponsored by King Features Syndicate.

SAIGON, April 26 A United States Air Force Phantom jet pilot shot down a MIG-21 with missiles in a duel 65 miles northeast of Hanoi today, an American military spokesman announced. It was the first "kill" of a MIG-21, the enemy's most advanced fighter plane.

RICHMOND, April 26 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Gaunt 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Marie Gaunt, to Capt. Robert George Hufschmid, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Hufschmid of Hewlett, L.I.

MONTREAT, N.C., April 26 The General Assembly of the Southern Presbyterian Church voted today to join unity conversations with seven other Protestant denominations, including one from which it split in the Civil War.

John F. Finnell, a former Assistant Attorney General of New York State, has been appointed general counsel of New York City's Department of Relocation at an annual salary of $13,000. In his new position...

World ship construction rose to an all-time high during the first quarter of 1966, Lloyd's Register of Shipping reported yesterday.

SAIGON, Wednesday, April 27 (AP) Vietcong terrorists exploded a powerful mine at a bus stop crowded with South Korean and other workers early today, killing 11 people and wounding 23 others, the authorities announced.
Burlington Industries, Inc., reported yesterday a 15 per cent gain in net earnings for the quarter ended on April 2, on a sales increase of 12 per cent from the level of a year earlier.
The American Electric Power System announced here yesterday plans for transmitting larger "blocks" of electricity for more miles than has ever before been attempted on a commercial basis.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 26 First-quarter sales and earnings of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation declined from the year-earlier levels, Edmund F. Martin, chairman and chief executive officer, told the annual meeting here today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 President Johnson is planning no major policy shifts or new initiatives as a result of the recent political unrest in South Vietnam and a new upsurge of criticism in this country.
Generally fair skies and balmy weather brought out a good attendance of stockholders yesterday at the more than 110 annual meetings held here and in other cities.
LONDON, April 26 A hushed courtroom heard today a tape recording of a child's screams and pleas for help. The tape is being presented as evidence in the Pennine Moors murder trial.

STRAVINSKY could hardly have known in 1913 when he first composed "The Rite of Spring" that when he heard the awful stirrings and dealthy poundings of Unholy Russia he was in fact envisaging a revolutionary hero striking a blow against the iniquities of that old-time religion.

The nation's newspaper publishers were told yesterday that their labor field was tightening to the point of "near crisis" on many staffs and that "there seem to be two newspaper jobs for every available newspaperman."

"SEVEN DECADES" is a seven-part exhibition opening today at 10 New York galleries a sort of monster with seven necks, three of them double-headed. But "monster" is a word that should be applied only to this exhibition's size. It is a beautiful show of 371 paintings and sculptures, just as good as it promised to be in advance descriptions and a walloping finale to the art season.
The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that sales and earnings in the first quarter declined from a year earlier.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 26 (UPI). The Southeast Coal Company of Kentucky filed suit in Federal District Court here today for $9.3-million against the United Mine Workers and the Consolidation Coal Company of Pittsburgh.
ALBANY, April 26 Proposed changes in the state's 179-year-old divorce law drew new criticism today from the state's Roman Catholic Bishops. The criticism was expressed
Scientists differed yesterday on whether the bright meteor that startled the Northeast Monday night had "burned to dust" or had reached the earth.
Construction was started yesterday on the Greyhound Corporation's $ll-million maintenance center in midtown Manhattan.
Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson blamed Governor Rockefeller last night for the City University's current problems in finding enough space for qualified students.
PARIS, April 26 Representatives of seven countries met here today to decide on Europe's effort to compete with the United States and the Soviet Union in space.
Trustees of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation have elected Devereux C. Josephs as chairman of the board.
Frank Sheehan, an international vice president of the Transport Workers Union and its director of organization, died of cancer yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 55 years old.
LONDON, April 26 Prime Minister Smith's willingness to enter into unconditional negotiations with Britain is seen here as the first fruit of secret diplomacy between Britain and South Africa.

WASHINGTON, April 26 Harold F. Linder, president of the Export-Import Bank, disclosed today a number of liberalizations in the bank's program of export credit guarantees and insurance, all aimed at spurring the nation's exports.
R.H. Macy Co. is discontinuing today its practice of absorbing the city sales tax for New Yorkers who shop in its three Long Island department stores.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 27 (AP) North Vietnam said today that planes of its air force engaged American attacking aircraft northeast of Hanoi, the capital, yesterday. It reported that two United States jets had been shot down and several others damaged.
Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery believes the most important job his departmen faces is halting the mounting community hostility toward firemen.

Michael Roemer and Robert Young will be the guest lecturers for the 1966-1967 filmwriting program at the Yale University School of Drama. The program, underwritten by the American Broadcasting Company, had David Davidson, novelist and TV writer, as guest lecturer this, year.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 26 Gajo Petrovic, a Yugoslav Marxist philosopher, challenged today a Soviet Marxist concept that the transformation of private property into state-owned property could bring about an essential change in the situation of the working class.

MARGARET and Melvin Stein live in a tall, crooked house on a middle-class street in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn. The floors sag a bit and the stairs creak even when their pug dog, Giveret, pads up and down the retreads.

Pedestrians on West 57th Street stared in puzzlement yesterday at a man who shouted: "Susan B. Anthony would churn in her grave at this injustice!" He meant, of course, the noted fighter for women's rights.

STORRS, Conn., April 26 (AP) Charles E. Silberman, a Fortune magazine editor, and Ross Robertson, an Indiana University professor, won the University of Connecticut's annual G.M. Loeb awards for business and financial writing today.
DENVER, April 26 (AP) Dr. Carl G. Hartman, an 87year-old New York scientist and author, was given the first Margaret Sanger Award in Medicine tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26 Charles W. Yost, deputy chief of the United States delegation, has resigned, causing a major realignment of posts in the mission.
Changes in the City Charter that were meant to diminish the role of the borough president have actually increased his influence, according to Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, Manhattan Borough President.

Clarence J. Johnson, 53year-old vice president and corporate secretary of the American Machine and Foundry Company, was elected yesterday as a company director. He succeeds Dr. Roland P. Soule, who has retired.

WHITE PLAINS, April 26 Westchester County Democratic leaders announced today that no county committee convention for endorsements would be held this year. They also disclosed their candidates for the June primary.

Lord Avon (Anthony Eden) is completing a book on Vietnam which Houghton Mifflin will publish on Aug. 16. Eden and Molotov were the joint chairmen of the Geneva Conference on Far Eastern Affairs in 1954 which established a peace formula for the countries that had made up Indo-China, including Vietnam. The book is reported to give Lord Avon's estimate of the Vietnamese situation and to propose a road to peace.

LAKEWOOD, N.J. Down in the pine belt the Bespopovtzy are prospering and multiplying. Impressed by the sober industry of this priestless sect of Russian Old Believers, local employers pray they will increase.

WASHINGTON, April 26 A State Department spokesman restated today the United States' long-standing position that "there is no sanctuary" in Communist China or elsewhere for aircraft fighting over Vietnam.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 (UPI) The Los Angeles Lakers, after losing an early 16point lead, rallied in the fourth quarter tonight and defeated the Boston Celtics, 123-115, evening the National Basketball Asociation championship playoff at three games apiece. The final game of the four-of-seven series will be played Thursday night in Boston.
The election of Herbert E. Longenecker and Lewis P. Seiler as directors of the Corn Products Company was announced yesterday at the company's annual meeting here at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

WOLFSBURG, West Germany, April 26 (Reuters) Volkswagen and Daimler-Benz, West Germany's two largest car companies, will set up a joint committee to study automobile safety, the companies announced today.
The World Journal Tribune, Inc., went into Federal Court yesterday in an attempt to force arbitration of merger problems and the issue of work stoppages by newspaper craft unions.
CHICAG0, April 26 (AP) A dissident group of stockholders of the Crucible Steel Company of America won today a four-month delay in the company's annual meeting.
WASHINGTON, April 26 Livingston L. Blair, a former director of the Junior Red Cross, died Sunday night. He was 62 years old.
Prices were generally on the downside in the credit markets yesterday in trading that was described as "very quiet."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 26 (AP) Indonesians blockaded the Soviet Cultural Center in Jakarta today.

MONTREAL, April 26 Improbably, the Detroit Red Wings reeled off their second straight upset victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight and left only one question unanswered: How long can they keep it up?

If Erik Satie were still alive, he would celebrate his 100th birthday on May 17, and he could hardly have wished for a nicer advance birthday entertainment than the concert given at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. The event was not advertised, or even planned, as a Satie celebration, but it did include one of his works, and everything that happened (save, possibly, the performance of his own piece) should have delighted him.

Paperboard production in the week ended April 23 was 450,600 tons, a gain of 11.5 per cent from 391,173 tons produced in the corresponding week of 1965, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute re ported yesterday.
The 50-foot top section of a 200-foot crane collapsed yesterday afternoon, tying up traffic on upper Fifth Avenue for more than an hour. No injuries were reported.
Stock prices on the American Stock Exchange fell yesterday with declines outnumbering advances by about a four-to-three ratio.
LONDON, April 26 The Treasury clamped down today on a back-door method of hoarding gold.

WASHINGTON, April 26 Mrs. Edmond Howar, fashion adviser to Lynda, Luci and Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson, gave a "Batman" party on Sunday night for E. William Henry, who is resigning as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

The National Football Foundation inducted four players of the era before 1910 into the hall of fame last night and honored Paul Savidge, the captain of the 1965 Princeton team, with a scholar-athlete award. The ceremonies took place at the Union Club on Park Avenue and were followed by a football forum, conducted by Roger...

QUEBEC, Canada, April 26 The Soviet Union introduced its first trans-Atlantic liner service to the people of Canada today, with a reception for city and provincial authorities aboard the trim black-and-white liner Aleksandr Pushkin.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The official policy of the United States is that our bombers are now free to attack the bases of any planes that intercept our flyers in North Vietnam, even if those bases are inside Communist China.

ATLANTA, April 26 Senator Richard B. Russell, who has proposed withdrawal of American troops from South Vietnam if the people of its cities indicate they are anti-American, today again advocated wider bombing of North Vietnam by the United States.
A $1-million personal gift was announced yesterday in the campaign to salvage and rebuild two ancient Egyptian temples,now safe from Nile waters that will soon be raised by the Aswan Dam project.

The Senate is expected to vote today on restoring funds for the rent subsidy program. The Senate Appropriations Committee deleted $12,000,000 for this purpose from the pending money bill. It is imperative that the Senate put this item back in the bill and without the harmful restrictions added in the House.

HOLYOKE, Mass., April 26 Mr.and Mrs. Frederick Park Barrett of Holyoke and Annisquam have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Virginia Barrett, to Richard Gene Hoffman, son of Mr. and Mr. Samuel Robert Hoffman of East Walpole.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 26 (UPI) The defending champion, Tom Draper, bowed on the 20th hole, but three former title-ohlders, Dale Morey, Charlie Smith and Bill Campbell, advanced in the second round of the North and South men's amateur golf championship at the Pinehurst Country Club today.
PARIS, April 26 The French Government has quietly removed a fringe benefit for American servicemen and employes of the allied armed forces here.

WASHINGTON, April 26 United States intelligence outposts in northern Pakistan, near the borders with the Soviet Union and Communist China, have been closed by Pakistan in reprisal for the suspension of military aid.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 26 Mrs. Adele Alfke Thompson, wife of John Miles Thompson, a former investment banker, died today in the home of her son, John Miles Thompson Jr., 112 Union Street, after a long illness. She was 68 years old and lived at 81 Irving Place, Manhattan.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 (AP) Sandy Koufax allowed 13 hits tonight, but held on to gain his third victory of the season as the Los Angeles Dodgers snapped a three-game losing streak by beating the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-2.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 26 Prof. and Mrs. Charles Cladel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Louise Cladel, to Charles P. Scholes, son of Dr. and Mrs. John C. Scholes of Webster.

REVERE, Mass., April 26 (AP) Floyd V. Wilkins, a 51year-old New Jersey industrialist, died of a gunshot wound in the head, Dr. Michael A. Luongo, medical examiner, said today. He said the victim also had suffered a fractured skull as a result of having been struck several times.
Mayor Lindsay ruled outs yesterday any material relaxation of the stringent waterconservation measures ordered last year to carry New York City through its most severe water shortage.
Six British royal palaces, including Buckingham Palace, will be opened soon to motion picture cameras for the first time, in the filming of an hourlong color television program.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 26 President Jomo Kenyatta today summoned Kenya's Parliament to an extraordinary meeting Thursday to enact a law requiring members of Parliament who have quit his party to give up their seats as well.

Hugh Ross last night led his Schola Cantorum and the combined University of Maryland Chapel Choir and Shelton College Choir of Cape May, N.J., in a big Carnegie Hall program that looked fine on paper but did not pan out in sound.
ALBANY, April 26 A Lindsay administration measure to broaden New York City's borrowing power to build low-rent housing was defeated by upstate Republicans in the Assembly.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) A young medical student and his wife think they have an original Picasso, scaled to the size of their Small apartment and small income.
Ben Hogan has accepted a, special invitation from the United States Golf Association to compete in the 1966 Open championship.
Andrew T. Buglione, a deputy collector of customs for the Port of New York, died of a heart attack Saturday in his home, 2077 New York Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 51 years old.

The executives of the General Electric Company were in an effervescent mood at a news conference they held yesterday in Atlanta. Presumably, their ebullience sprang less from word that Mrs. Wilma Soss, a self-styled professional minority stockholder, would not be on hand at G.E.'s annual meeting in Atlanta today, than from a raft of other good news, including a 17 per cent profits gain in the first quarter.
Mrs. Edward Durell Stone, wife of the architect, was granted a separation yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam.

WASHINGTON, April 26 Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has expressed the hope that Congressional doubts about the foreign aid program will be resolved in favor of the Administration's $3.4-billion authorization request.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 The rate of church building and trends in religious architecture came under sharp criticism today.
A final accounting of the receipts of the 1965-66 Neediest Cases Fund was submitted yesterday to The New York Times Company by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the board.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 26 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith told Parliament today that he was prepared to reopen negotiations with Britain in an effort to resolve their differences.
Optimism was the keynote at the annual meetings yesterday of the nation's two largest can companies, the American Can Company and the Continental Can Company.
WASHINGTON, April 26 The Supreme Court Was urged today to prohibit state courts from trying Negroes who contend they cannot get a fair trial there.

The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, scored the first victory in the title match last night. He defeated his compatriot Boris Spassky in the playoff of their adjourned seventh game in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) The W. E. B. DuBois clubs asked the United States District Court here today to determine the constitutionality of law requiring certain groups to register as "Communist front" organizations.

A SINGULARLY useful documentary, "Mexico: A Lesson in Latin," was offered last night on "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2. With vigor and conviction the program cited the neighboring country to the south as one example where a revolution had contributed to hemispheric peace and stability.
Mayor Lindsay released yesterday a first-quarter report on the work of one of his most controversial commissioners Charles G. Moerdler of the Buildings Department.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 20 The South Koreans, now in the process of doubling their troop commitment in Vietnam, believe they have won the right to a larger voice in allied policy councils on Southeast Asia.

CHICAGO, April 26 A spokesman for the American Medical Association's Council on Mental Health today urged "all physicians to be on the alert in their communities" for LSD and other drugs that produce hallucinations.
OTTAWA, April 26 The discovery of a new antibiotic that is said to show promise of becoming a "major weapon" against disease was announced here today.
Copper shares fell yesterday on the London market on profit taking. Roan Selection Trust fell 84 cents to $14.07. Other Zambian producers registered smaller declines.

MEXICO CITY, April 26 (AP) The head of Mexico's; National University resigned tonight after striking law students fought past campus security guards and took over his office. Scores were reported in jured in the fighting.

David Ross, the City Council majority leader, took issue yesterday with City Council President Frank D. O'Connor's contention that Mayor Lindsay's $520-million tax program would be passed in its entirety by the Council.
Random House has charged Howard Hughes with establishing a corporation to suppress a biography of the industrialist planned for publication next month.
Hugo R. Lehrfeld, former president of Kastenhuber Lehrfeld, Inc., smelters and refiners of precious metals, died yesterday in his home at 830 Park Avenue. His age was 81.

At long last, the New York Yankees won a baseball game at Yankee Stadium yesterday. In fact, they won it twice. Apparently secure with a 4-2 lead and Whitey Ford pitching as the ninth inning began, they struggled through 45 minutes of the final inning before emerging with a 7-8 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 26 Mr. and Mrs. Lauriston Sharp have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susannah Burdick Sharp, to Colin John Starnes. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kenneth Starnes of Ottawa.
YONKERS, April 26 Yonkers Raceway will offer a purse of $65,000 for the one-mile pace in which Bret Hanover and Cardigan Bay will meet for the first time, on the night of May 20.
About $300,000 in stolen securities were recovered yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents when they arrested Larry Knohl, a onetime Washington "tax fixer," in another case.
Paul Miller, president of the Gannett Newspapers, of Rochester, N.Y., was re-elected president of The Associated Press yesterday at a meeting of thhe board of directors at 50 Rockefeller Plaza.
A $16,582,000 judgment for taxes was obtained by the Government yesterday against six corporations owned and controlled by Stavros Spiros Niarchos, the Greek shipping leader.

NEW HAVEN, April 26 There is no way of telling how many of about 600 boys and girls in the junior class of the Hillhouse High School here have ever seen actors in the flesh, but there was no trouble the other morning in checking on the pleasure they derived from the touring company of the Long Wharf Theater.
Mayor Lindsay asked the City Council yesterday for two home-rule messages to permit the State Legislature to approve his bills for consolidating transportation facilities here.
GREEN BAY, Wis., April 26 (AP) The Green Bay Packers of the National Football League traded today Tom Moore, a running back, to the Los Angeles Rams for two players and a high future draft choice.

WASHINGTON, April 26 A group of American writers urged today that the United States attempt to achieve a negotiated settlement of the Vietnamese war by ordering an immediate cessation in the bombing of North Vietnam.
Stock prices drifted lazily in relatively quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 26 A $735,000 study of a helicopterborne "skylounge" as a possible future airport-to-city transit system was announced today by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
The Phoenix Steel Corporation announced yesterday a $28-million modernization program to double production at its Claymont, Del., plant.

Maurice A. Smoler, founder and chairman of Smoler Brothers, Inc., a dress manufacturing concern at 64 West 36th Street and 1350 Broadway, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street.

The election of Alfred Brittain 3d, president-elect of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, to the board of Philip Morris, Inc., was announced yesterday at the cigarette company's annual meeting in Richmond, Va.
PARIS, April 26 An Argentine painter has brought suit against the Louvre for failure to identify as an original copy by him a famous painting attributed to Chaim Soutine, who died in 1943.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday a decline in net income for the first quarter. Operating revenues rose to $228,894,901 from $225,176,849 in the 1965 period. However, net income slipped to $32,750,018, equal to 72 cents a share, from $33,797,989, or 77 cents a share, one year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 26 Representative F. Edward Hebert, chairman of a House Armed Services subcommittee, accused Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today of seeing fit to "impugn the integrity" of the subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) The Navy is disbanding its airlift squadrons now under the Military Airlift Command and turning their work over to the Air Force, it was announced today.
Stock prices drifted lazily in relatively quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
PARIS, April 26 An Argentine painter has brought suit against the Louvre for failure to identify as an original copy by him a famous painting attributed to Chaim Soutine, who died in 1943.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday a decline in net income for the first quarter. Operating revenues rose to $228,894,901 from $225,176,849 in the 1965 period. However, net income slipped to $32,750,018, equal to 72 cents a share, from $33,797,989, or 77 cents a share, one year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 26 Representative F. Edward Hebert, chairman of a House Armed Services subcommittee, accused Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today of seeing fit to "impugn the integrity" of the subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) The Navy is disbanding its airlift squadrons now under the Military Airlift Command and turning their work over to the Air Force, it was announced today.
HONG KONG, April 26 Communist China, using economic and ideological pressures, is compelling its people to practice birth control. According to reports received here,
A new generation of spacecraft is being developed to enable astronauts to glide in from orbit to a smooth landing at any conventional jet airport.
WASHINGTON, April 26 Unequivocal opposition to the establishment of a Department of Transportation was expressed here today by a leading spokesman for the inland waterways industry.

WASHINGTON, April 26 If Robert LaFollette Bennet throws as many ringers as Indian commissioner as he did when he was horseshoe pitching champion of the Department of the Interior, the Bureau of Indian Affairs is in for an exciting time. Mr. Bennett, who will be sworn...

WASHINGTON, April 26 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach informed Alabama election officials today of a three-step plan Federal agents would put into effect during the Democratic primary May 3 to protect newly enfranchised Negroes from possible intimidation or violence.
Crank telephone calls some obscene, some threatening, all annoying have become so epidemic an evil that the New York Telephone Company has set up an Annoyance Call Bureau to shield the victims.

WASHINGTON, April 26 President Johnson's demands for sharp cuts in the milk and lunch programs for schools were ignored today as the House passed a $6.9-billion agriculture appropriation bill. The vote was 366 to 23.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., April 26 (AP) Leonard M. McCabe, an artist for The New York Journal-American for 45 years, died Saturday at the age of 73.
The Sperry Rand Corporation has received an $11,410,856 Army contract for production of ammunition.
MIAMI, April 26 (AP) Jacinto Vasquez won two races today to move within two victories of the jockey lead at Gulfsream Park.

Dr. John M. Schapiro, a dentist who was head of the Oceanic Chemical Company until it was recently sold, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was in his seventies and lived at 845 West End Avenue and in Yorktowh Heights, N.Y.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 26 Mrs. Margaret Edge Tirrell, senior psychologist at the Essex County Guidance Center, East Orange, died yesterday at Orange Memorial Hospital. She was the widow of Dr. Malcolm C. Tirrell and her home was at 101 Gates Avenue.

SOME well-intentioned adminers of Gunter Grass are doing him a disservice on lower Third Avenue. Selections from the German author's works have been woven into a program called "The World of Gunter Grass," which opened last night at the Pocket Theater (and which I saw at the last preview). It is a production full of teases, hints and dissatisfactions.

LONDON, April 26 For his 50th birthday concert in Festival Hall tonight Yehudi Menuhin appeared as soloist, conductor, patriarch of the remarkable Menuhin family, and in the words of Sir Adrian Boult "our hero" for a vast audience who gave him an affectionate ovation. The actual birthday was last Friday.
"You're a lucky boy, a lucky boy," Dick Tiger said to Emile Griffith yesterday.

TOKYO, April 26 A large proportion of Japan's working and school-population was drawn into the annual "spring labor struggle" in a token strike of major commuter transportation throughout the country today.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), April 26 The Archbishop of York, the secondranking prelate of the Church of England, said today that Christians in developing nations were often more eager for church unity than men in lands where Christianity has been established for centuries.
ALBANY, April 26 Governor Rockefeller has signed into law a bill requiring annual inspections for all motor vehicles.
The suspicion is growing among economists that the Johnson Administration has missed the boat on tax increases.

John P. Stanton, since 1964 director of European operations for the Canada Dry Corporation, manufacturers of carbonated drinks, died April 11 in Padua, Italy, of meningitis after a short illness. He was 51 years old, and made his headquarters in Offenbach, West Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 26 Science advisers to the Mohole geological project have decided to give their gigantic drill rig its first test by sinking four closely spaced holes into the floor of the Pacific to assess two of the most controversial theories concerning the earth.
WASHINGTON, April 27 Some "architects" have almost no brains, yet they build elaborate "cities" housing millions of their kind, cooled by complex air-conditioning systems.
Mrs. Mae A. Planagan Blaney, wife of H.Clay Blaney, theatrical producer; died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital of cancer after a long illness. She was 56 years old and lived at 310 West 56th Street.
Frederick J. Ziegler, a sculptor and director of Steinway Sons, piano manufacturers, died yesterday in his home at 770 Park Avenue. He was 79 years old.
ALBANY, April 27-Governor Rockefeller moved today to break a deadlock in the politically divided Legislature over how the state shall set up its program to take advantage of Federal Medicare funds.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and its worldwide affiliates had the most prosperous quarter in its 84-year-history in the first three months of this year.

The American Opera Society will celebrate its 15th season during 1966-67 with a revival of five of its earlier productions. Rossini's "Mose in Egitto" will open the season Oct. 28; Donizetti's "Anna Bolena" will be given Nov. 15; Cherubini's "Medea," Dec. 6; Handel's "Giulio Cesare." March 21, and Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice," April 4.

PARTICULAR talent is needed to rebuild a washed-out Nebraska railroad in five months, transform "two streaks of rust" with high mountains and low traffic into the money-making Denver Rio Grande and whittle the high costs of the New York Central System...

YORK, Pa., April 27 Mr. and Mrs. Walter Sechrist have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Melissa Barker Hammatt, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hallett B. Hammatt, to Lieut. Peter Perenyi, U.S.A. He is the son of Baroness Eleanor Perenyi of New York and Stonington, Conn., and the late Baron Zsigmond Perenyi of Orebro, Sweden.

As if exhausted by the prodigious effort required to win a game on Tuesday, the New York Yankees lapsed back into total ineffectiveness yesterday and were beaten by the Washington senators, 2-0, at Yankee Stadium.
WASHINGTON, April 27 Premier Jens Otto Krag of Denmark expressed to President Johnson today grave concern over the impact of the war in Vietnam on Soviet-United States relations.

MEXICO CITY, April 27 (AP) Striking law students today controlled the sprawling National University campus, one of Mexico City's showplaces, after forcing the resignation of the rector, Ignacio Chavez, at the climax of two days of violence.
ATLANTA, April 27 A decade of surging economic growth and social progress was predicted today by the executives of the General Electric Company at its annual meeting in Atlanta Municipal Auditorium.
Stockholders of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., wasted little time at their annual meeting yesterday in approving a merger agreement with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) Secretary of State Dean Rusk said tonight he believed Communist China's leaders were showing a prudence that would help prevent spread of the war in Southeast Asia. "The United States is not interested in war with mainland China," Mr. Rusk said in an American Broadcasting Company interview.
Mayor Lindsay is about to get new support in his efforts to keep industry in New York, and, appropriately enough, that support is being given by a foundations manufacturer.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Communist China may soon explode its third nuclear device, according to information received recently by United States intelligence.

Charles A.Siegfried, 57year-old executive vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, was elected a director yesterday. He joined the company in 1930 after being graduated from Franklin and Marshall College that year.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads today to effect the biggest merger in corporate history.
Profit taking trimmed prices of soybean contracts yesterday by of a cent to 1 cents a bushel. The selling developed after the sharp climb Tuesday.
The election of Ralph L. Hennebach as an executive vice president of the American Smelting and Refining Company was announced here yesterday.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Tuesday the level that it reached on Monday, which was 111.9.

BALTIMORE, April 27 It took 75 stockholders just 42 minutes, including time for about a dozen questions and comments from Lewis D. Gilbert, to approve International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's $400-million acquisition of the American Broadcasting Companies.
UTICA, N.Y., April 27 (AP)-A Federal District Court ordered the Aluminum Company of America today to divest itself of its Rome Cable Corporation plants within six months.

The auction of the late Helena Rubinstein's collections in its continuation yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, was a competition for "little art" in which foreign dealers joined and sometimes won.
John V. Lindsay and Robert Moses smiled at each other yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 Eerik Heine, the Estonian emigr now living in Canada whom the Central Intelligence Agency has formally labeled "a dispatched Soviet intelligence operative, a K.G.B. agent," arrived here today from Toronto. He was not arrested.
An experimental microwave system that can relay at least 12 color television programs from one transmitter has been developed by the Hughes Aircraft Company and will soon be tested here.

VERONA, N.J., April 27 Jonathan P. Glasby Jr., president of J.P. Glasby Manufacturing Company, Inc., of Belleville, died Monday in East Orange Veterans Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 29 Mountain Road here.
More than 1,300 city nurses cheered a proposal last night that they dismantle beds as they become empty in the overcrowded wards of the municipal hospitals.
PITTSBURGH, April 27 First-quarter sales and earnings of the National Steel Corporation fell sharply to $1.01 a share from $1.45 in the 1965 period, the annual shareholder's meeting was told today.
The Board of Education last night approved the city school system's participation in another controversial phase of the Federal aid-to-education program enacted last year.

Mrs. John Wilkie of New York and Katonah, N.Y., and Dwight W. Morrow Jr. of New Hope, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Faith Morrow, to Stephen Fain Williams. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. C. Dickerman Williams of New York and Norfolk, Conn.
CHICAGO, April 27 The Inland Steel Company reported today a decline in first-quarter earnings from the year-earlier level despite record sales of $259,073,000.

WASHINGTON, Apri1 27 (AP)-President Johnson hailed today the "brilliant and imaginative" achievement of two physicists who received the first Fannie and John Hertz Foundation Award as developers of the laser beam.

In a major policy move, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates the $130-billion savings and loan industry, has practically frozen lending for expansion by the 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks.
HOUSTON, April 27 (AP) Dave Guisti pitched a threehitter and Jim Wynn had a hand in every run as the Houston Astros defeated St. Louis, 3-1 tonight.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 27 The Darby Dan Farm's undefeated Graustark almost certainly will be in the Blue Grass Stakes tomorrow. Some apprehension about the colt's competing in the important 1 1/8mile test for 3-year-olds arose today when he took a few lame

Miss Susan Starr Fletcher and Dr. William E. Boyle Jr, plan to be married in July. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Fetcher of Plymouth, Montserrat, W.I., formerly of New Cancan, Conn, Dr. Boyle is the Son of Mr. and Mrs. Boyle of Cranston, R.I.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Three education bills that would cost nearly $3.8-billion over the next three years were approved today by the House Education and Labor Committee.
The Staten Island ferry brought in 5,524,868 fewer nickels last year, and the new Verrazano-Narrows Bridge looks like the culprit.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate rejected today the action of its Appropriations Committee in amending an appropriations bill to strike out 12-million for a rent supplement program:

PARIS, April 27 Millions of Frenchmen who had been caught parking illegally, insulting a gendarme, poaching, committing adultery or being absent without official leave were told by the Government today to go and sin no more.
LOS ANGELES, April 27 (AP) Gladys Parker, a former cartoonist who drew the comic strip "Mopsy" for 16 years, died today of lung cancer. She was 56 years old.
Buildings occupied by some of the city's leading clubs and hotels are among 31 additional structures proposed for landmark designation by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.
The Boeing Company awarded contracts yesterday to six aerospace concerns in connection with the Boeing 747 jet airliner.
Gasoline supplies in the United States fell 14,231,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday from the comparable levels of a year ago, the American Petroleum. Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 27 President Johnson said today that he was worried about Congressional actions that were enlarging his proposed $112.8-billion budget fcr the coming fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, April 27 Senator Robert F. Kennedy criticized today the Administration's policy of permitting "no sanctuary" in Communist China or elsewhere for planes attacking United States aircraft over North Vietnam.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 27 Leverett Saltonstall Jr., president of the Foundation Seed Corporation and son of Leverett Saltonstall, Republican Senator from Massachusetts, died of cancer today in Tompkins County Hospital. He was 48 years old.

Last Nov. 15 the State Department took a bold and overdue step in denouncing the Warsaw Convention, an international treaty limiting the liability of an airline involved in crashes in international flight to $8,300 per passenger. This is an insignificant figure for the death of an American breadwinner.

SAIGON, April 27 United States B-52 strategic bombers struck North Vietnam today for the second time, dropping bombs in a saturation pattern on the vital Mugia Pass leading from North Vietnam into Laos. The pass is a key link in the major infiltration route into South Vietnam.
Copper shares met with renewed profit taking on the London Stock Exchange yesterday in an otherwise quiet session.

LORD TAYLOR opened its storewide Mediterra nean Odyssey promotion last night with six room settings designed by ambassadors' wives and a reception in a weekend beach tent owned by the King of Morocco.

Plans for New York City's first fight in a ball park in six years were confirmed yesterday with the announcement of the Jose Torres-Wayne Thornton bout at Shea Stadium on May 21, a Saturday night. The world light-heavyweight championship, held by Torres since March 30, 1965, but never before defended by him, will be at stake.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (AP) The Cincinnati Reds blew a six-run lead and then pushed across two runs in the last two innings today to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 8-6.
WASHINGTON, April 27-Following is the text of a statement made today on the Senate floor by Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, on the bombing of North Vietnam:

GLADSTONE, N.J., April 27 Seven riders, headed by Bill Steinkraus, a four-time Olympian, were selected today for the United States Equestrian Team that will tour European horse shows in the summer. The team, with 16 horses still to be named, leaves May 20.
BONN, April 27 The city of Munich, selected yesterday as the site of the 1972 Olympic summer games, received today its first request for hotel reservations for the event.
Nicholas Downey Jr., circulation director of Golden Press books, died yesterday of cancer. He was 42 years old and lived at 279 East 44th Street.

WASHINGTON, April 27 Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon, in his first argument before the Supreme Court, accused Life magazine today of violating a family's privacy with "a reckless disregard of the facts."

WASHINGTON, April 27 Thomas C. Mann, the thirdranking official in the State Department, declined to comment tonight on a report that he had submitted his resignation as Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.
Meeting, Council of Higher Educational Institutions in New York City, at the College of Mount Saint Vincent, Riverdale Avenue and 263d Street, the Bronx, 9:30 A.M.
LISBON, April 27 This is a year of accounting for Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar and his regime.

Sir Ronald L.Prain, chairman of Roan Selection Trust, Ltd., was able to give American shareholders of the Zambia copper producer scant reassurance yesterday on the company's earnings outlook this year.
LONDON, April 27 The leading organization for West Indian immigrants accused the London police today of persecuting colored residents.
Carolyn Smith-Meyer, a young, slightly built soprano who made her New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last night, is said to have had only three years of professional training as a singer.

THE familiar story of Galileo's fight for truth against tradition and authority was told again last night in a television adaptation of the Barrie Stavis play, "Lamp at Midnight," The play, seen on the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" over Channel 4, was an abbreviated account of the scientist's ordeal, more akin to a simulated documentary than a drama of compelling depth and persuasion.
Before yesterday's action at Aqueduct, Hirsch Jacobs was wondering if he would ever saddle another stakes winner and Gary Mineau was debating whether to go back to bed.
DETROIT, April 27 (AP) The New York Knickerbockers won the flip of a coin today for first choice in the National Basketball Association player draft May 11.

WASHINGTON, April 27-Without explanation the Supreme Court let stand today an $85,739 judgment against the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People arising out of the picketing of a Savannah, Ga., store.

The National Football League's preseason schedule will begin earlier than usual this summer, with the first exhibition game listed for Atlanta on Aug.1, a Monday night. The league announced the full schedule yesterday.
CHEETAH, one of the fastest-moving of wild ani mals, proved both fast and wild last night even though rooted to the spot on Broadway at 53d Street.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The Senate handed President Johnson his slimmest victory of the year today by voting to restore funds for his rent-supplement program. The vote was 46 to 45.
ALBANY, April 27 There was nothing unusual about the afternoon of May 26, 1965, in the State Senate. The session had dragged on too long, the oratory was limp, the legislation forgettable.

IN the majestic surge of Willie Mays toward the uppermost echelons of the listings of home run kings, the first man he overhauled this season was Mel Ott. The return of Ottie's name to the sports pages, even though it came in a somewhat negative fashion, had to bring nostalgic gleams into the eyes of old Giant fans. But a new generation undoubtedly reacted with blank stares and the unspoken question: Who he?

WASHINGTON, April 27 James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, urged Congress today to require the establishment of minimum safety standards for trucks as well as passenger cars.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 27 President Abdel Rahman Arif of Iraq denied today that his Government was ready to negotiate with Kurdish insurgents in North Iraq, but he indicated that the rebels would be forgiven if they "repent."

HOLLYWOOD, April 27 Spry and alert at the age of 84, Samuel Goldwyn presented his annual creative writing awards today and noted that most of past recipients have gone on to fruitful careers as novelists, screen writers or playwrights.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 27 John H. Gage, former executive treasurer of Merck Co., manufacturing chemists of Rahway, died here yesterday at his home in Glen Avenue, Llewellyn Park, after a long illness. He was 58 years old.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 27 (Reuters) Leopoldville's city administration was put under military control today.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 27 (AP) A 17-year-old Maryland girl sneaked aboard a British submarine today and hid for four hours while the vessel headed back to Scotland.

LIMA, Peru, April 27 (UPI)-A Lansa Airlines Constellation with 49 persons aboard, including five Americans, disappeared today on a flight between Lima and Cuzco and was believed down in the rugged Andes Mountains.

Steven L. Osterweis, executive head of Gimbels, Pittsburgh, and a vice president and director of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., will join the Associated Merchandising Corporation, the nation's largest store-owned

The Alliance for Progress, which has been subject to criticism since its inception, is on the receiving end again. An eight-man economic advisory panel, responsible for reviewing national development plans for the Alliance, has resigned with the charge that there has been too much reliance on bilateral arrangements between the United States and individual countries in Latin America. In its view, Washington is the chief culprit in bilateralism over multilateralism.

The New York Conservative party charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary were "putting on an Edgar BergenCharlie McCarthy act" on the issue of the Police Department's civilian complaint review board.
ALBANY, April 27-The New York State Legislature drastically revamped tonight the state's rigid divorce statute, which since 1787 has allowed only one ground for dissolving a marriage-adultery.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 27 (AP) Joseph Lelyveld, a correspondent of The New York Times, flew to London tonight after the South African Government had refused to extend his resident's permit.

Fines totaling $100,000 were imposed in Federal Court yesterday against three major makers of book matches. They had pleaded no contest to antitrust charges of conspiring to fix prices in the sale of their products.
ROME, April 27 Pope Paul VI and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko talked of peace and other world problems for 45 minutes today during the first visit by a high Soviet official to a Roman Pontiff.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said in testimony made public today that he did not believe any "substantial numbers" of United States troops would be needed in Vietnam once American objectives had been met there.

The establishment of the Henry James Porfessorship of English and American Letters announced yesterday by James M. Heater, president of New York University. Dr. Leon Edel, who received a Pulitzer Prize for his biography of the 19th-century writer, was named to the new professorship.
SAIGON, April 27 Maj. Paul T. Gilmore is the first American pilot ever to "kill" a MIG-21 jet fighter, but he is rather ashamed because he killed it twice.

Mrs. Ethel Stever Epstein, widow of State Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein and a daughter of the late Max D. Steuer, the noted lawyer, died yesterday of a heart attack in her apartment at 880 Fifth Avenue. She was 66 years old.
Lawrence Schacht has been elected chairman of the executive committee of the Royal National Bank of New York.

A merger may take some of the bumps out of the operating problems of the New York Central and the Pennsylvania railroads, but it can't expunge history. There was a long period when the two rail lines were anything but good friends.
Randolph H. Brownell, 63 years old, chairman of the Union Square Savings Bank, was elected president of the Savings Banks Association of New York State yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The Securities and Exchange Commission formally accused the Georgia-Pacific Corporation and its top two officers today of using employe trust funds to manipulate the price of its stocks.

WASHINGTON, April 27 Senator John J. Williams accused the Johnson Administration today of trying to obscure a "perfectly clear" law governing tax liability on campaign contributions in order to help Senator Thomas J. Dodd.
Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner suggested yesterday that the war in Vietnam had begun to harm the nation's effort in science and technology.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 27-Hamengku Buwono, Sultan of Jogjakarta, who is Deputy Premier in charge of economic affairs, said today that Indonesia would send a mission to foreign capitals next month to discuss the rescheduling of her debts.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) Senator J.W. Fulbright suggested today that "American hostility" was prolonging "the extremist phase of the Chinese revolution."

WASHINGTON, April 27 The House of Representatives passed with surprising ease today a bill to give enforcement powers to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the agency established by the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

The International Air Transport Association notified the State Department yesterday that a "substantial" number of its members had agreed to meet the department's demands for radical changes in the Warsaw Convention. The agreement deals with airlines' liability.

Lieut. Gen. Maurice Arthur Preston, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Preston of Tokyo have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Paige Preston, to Jerome Frederick Peck 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peck Jr. of Mount Kisco, N.Y.
The Philip A. Hunt Chemical Corporation filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the proposed sale of 150,000 shares of its class A common stock.
Chesebrough-Pond's to Ciesa, Norman, Craig Kummel, which is Norman, Craig Kummel's partner agency in Lisbon, for Cutex and other products.
Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leader, urged Spanishspeaking college students last night to act as independent observers during elections set for June 1 in the Dominican Republic.

Rain is forecast today in the North and Middle Atlantic States changing to showers in the northeastern section of the Ohio Valley and in the lower Mississippi Valley. Some light snow will fall in the upper Mississippi Valley and will change to showers which will extend into the middle Mississippi Valley.

Walter Arm former Deputy Police Commissioner who was a newspaper reporter for 25 years, will soon be appointed city editor of the news division of station WCBS-TV. In the newly established post he will be in direct charge of local news coverage for Channel 2.
Milton Pollack, a courtappointed referee, has recommended judicial approval of a proposed $4.3-million settlement between the New York World's Fair Corporation and its noteholders.

The Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Virginia awarded yesterday $50million of 39-year debentures to a group led by the First Boston Corporation, Halsey, Stuart Co., and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered the New Haven Railroad today to keep most of its passenger service, including all commuter trains.

The engagement of Miss Gail Marie Andrews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Andrews of Chicago and Long Beach, Ind., to Richard Lawrence Walker has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. Mr. Walker is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Walker of Rye, N.Y.

The Government said yesterday that there was no tax claim personally against Stavro Spiros Niarchos in the $16,582,000 judgment obtained against five nonoperating corporations controlled and owned by the Greek shipping leader.

SYRACUSE, April 27 Loren Schoel started a rebuilding program last year and the outlook has brightened appreciably for the Syracuse crew that meets Navy and Cornell on Onondaga Lake here Saturday for the Goes Trophy.

A mother and her five young children were found stabbed to death in their Brooklyn apartment yesterday afternoon. All had been stabbed with a knife many times, the mother in the chest and back, the children all under 6 years old in the back.
WASHINGTON, April 27 In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceedings were had:

MADRID, April 27 Scores of students and a Roman Catholic priest who is a Professor of Theology were reported to have been severely beaten today by policemen in a melee in Barcelona. It was the worst clash in the disturbances at the university there.
TRENTON, April 27 Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed a 3 per cent state sales tax into law late today shortly after the Senate, in an 18-to-8 bipartisan vote, gave it final legislative approval.

The New York Institute of Technology has leased 26,000 square feet of space in the new Lincoln Towers office building at 170 Amsterdam Avenue. The office building is part of a new shopping plaza on the west side of Amsterdam Avenue between ...

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The House Government Operations Committee approved today a "freedom of information" bill to give greater access to the Government's official records. By unanimous vote, the committee approved the bill in the same form in which it passed the Senate last Oct. 13.
The gathering impatience in Albany to end the legislative session imperils plans for action this year to replace the worthless Condon-Wadlin Act with an enforceable law barring civil service strikes.

"Good night, David," said Chet Huntley, but this time he was not closing a news broadcast but a new piece of music by Morton Gould. And David was not David Brinkley, Mr. Huntley's partner in commentary, but his boss, David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America.
American Home Products, Inc., a producer of drugs, cosmetics and food, announced in Wilmington, Del., yesterday that it achieved record sales and earnings in the first quarter.
NEW DELHI, April 27 The Peace Corps will embark later this year on the first birthcontrol project it has undertaken anywhere.

Price rises in the Johns-Manville line of vinyl asbestos Terraflex and asphalt asbestos floor tiles were announced yesterday by A. Kenneth Higbee, vice president and general manager of the flooring division of JohnsManville, Inc.

BAY SHORE, L.I., April 27 A 16-year-old student critically wounded a teacher in Senior High School here this afternoon after racing through the corridors with a shotgun and angrily shouting for some boys he had argued with earlier in the day.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) The Studebaker Corporation paid $37.9-million to 7,481 employes under its company-financed pension plan with the United Auto Workers Local No. 5, C.M. MacMillan, company vice president, reported today.
Watchful waiting for the Treasury's announcement of its refunding plan, issued after the formal close of trading, caused the Government securities market to slow to a snail's pace yesterday.
The Advertising Council, Inc., and the Community Relations Service announced yesterday a nationwide campaign to promote better race relations through advertising materials prepared by the council.
A casualty of the highway age, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad has operated for years on little more than rails and a prayer.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 About a dozen shareholders of the Crucible Steel Company of America showed up at the Carlton House Hotel for the annual meeting today. It lasted just long enough for Joel Hunter, president, to adjourn the meeting for four months.
BOSTON, April 27 (AP) The Chicago White Sox scored three runs in the seventh inning today and registered an 8-6 victory over the Boston Red Sox before a crowd of only 1,578.

BETHPAGE, L.I, April 27 C.W. Post College won both the team and individual championships in the 12th annual Abraham Straus collegiate golf tournament today. The play was over the par-72 Bethpage State Park Blue Course of 6,288 yards.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 27 John J. Dillon, retired board chairman of George W. Millar Co., Inc., 284 Lafayette Street, Manhattan, converters and wholesalers of coarse and fine papers, died yesterday at Nassau Hospital here after a short illness. He was 90 years old and lived at 269 Stewart Avenue, Garden City.
The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and the challenger, his compatriot Boris Spassky, drew the eighth game of their title match in Moscow's Variety theater last night.
NEW MARKET, England, April 27 (AP)-Kashmir II won the Two Thousand Guineas today, the first classic of the British racing season.

The Paradise Ball, the 10th annual benefit for the Sheltering Arms Children's Service, will be held on May 6 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. Mrs. Ernest T. Greeff and Mrs. Caleb C. Whitaker are general chairmen for the dinner dance, and Mrs. William B. Kegg is vice chairman.
HARRISON, N.Y. April 27 A Westchester County plan for 263 miles of new superhighways was announced at a conference here today.

Grace Line and Moore-McCormack Lines-the two American subsidized steamship companies providing cargo ship service from the West Coast to South America and the Caribbean-have concluded that there is only room for one of them in this area.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 27 Yugoslavia scored the major upset in the world amateur basketball championships tonight by defeating the United States, 69-59.
LONDON, April 27 Prime Minister Wilson triumphantly announced to the House of Commons today that talks between the British and Rhodesian Governments would be resumed.

The General Motors Corporation, the world's Largest manufacturer and the nation's biggest profit maker, reported yesterday a firstquarter net income of $594-million. This represents a decline of 6.6 per cent from the previous record of $636-million.

The Witco Chemical Company announced yeserday the election of J. Bertram Fisher as a vice president and director. He continues as president of the Kendall Refining Company, which Witco acquired March 21.

IN his book "The Craft of Intelligence," Allen W. Dulles observes that serious fishermen are often the best intelligence officers. The former director of the Central Intelligence Agency seemed to suggest that a fisherman is endowed with patience to play out his lure or bait and has a certain native' guile and calmness that would be of help in spying.
At least $15 million would be needed to save the old Metropolitan Opera House, Anthony Bliss, Met president, has told a citizens committee now working to raise $8 million to save the building.

Gen. Harold K. Johnson, Army chief of staff, reaffirmed last night the United States' intention to remain in Vietnam. But he called public debate on policy alternatives "constructive" and "very necessary."

A group headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank submitted yesterday the best bid, subject to award today, for $5.65-million of Urbana and Champaign, Ill., Sanitary District bonds. The bid of 100.00402 for coupons of 4, 3 and 3.60 per cent resulted in an annual interest cost of 3.6237 per cent.
In addition to approving the biggest railroad merger in histerday, a merger that creates Commission also approved yesterday a merger that creates one of the largest trucking companies in the country.
DANANG, South Vietnam, April 27 (UPI) A Roman Catholic leader charged today that the Buddhists wanted to make peace in Vietnam "by shaking hands with the Communists."
Officials in Washington have tentatively identified three of the victims as Peace Corps volunteers, according to The Associated Press.
Four other games were postponed Wednesday in the major leagues because of rain.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (A.P) President Johnson danced the foxtrot tonight with the actress wife of Denmark's Premier. His daughter Luci danced the Watusi and Vice President Humphrey and Bob Hope exchanged jokes.

MONTREAL, April 27 The first trans-Atlantic liner flying the hammer and sickle on a regular North Atlantic service opened a new route from Leningrad to Montreal today. But she opened it without the aid of Soviet citizen customers. There were no Russian tourists aboard.
BEAUTIFUL LOSERS by Leonard Cohen (Viking, $5.75).
WASHINGTON, April 27-Leading House Democrats have agreed on amendments that will alter the face and character of the Great Society's campaign againts poverty. against poverty.
Stock prices declined on a broad front yesterday, with automobile, railroad and copper issues leading the way downward.
Luci Baines Johnson, the 18year-old younger daughter of the President, has an arithmetic equation by which she rebuts any notion that she is entering an "irresponsible teen-age marriage."

Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States representative at the United Nations, contended yesterday that "failure to resolve the Rhodesian crisis with justice to the African majority" would strengthen "extremism, violence and racism" in Africa.

GUILD LISTS WINNERS OF PAGE ONE AWARDS McCandlish Phillips and Peter Kihss of The New York Times were among winners of the 1966 Page One Awards in Journalism of the Newspaper Guild of New York announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 27 (UPI) The owner of an apartment building taken over by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as part of a civil rights drive was found dead today.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 27 Prof. Gaston Fessard, a leading French Jesuit philosopher, and Prof. James L. Adams of the Harvard University Divinity School agreed today that Karl Marx's thinking is relevant to Christians, but in their reasons for this view they differed sharply.

ROME, April 27 (AP). A brief Vatican announcement said the meeting between Pope Paul and Mr. Gromyko today was a "continuation of the talk" they had had at United Nations headquarters in New York during the papal visit last October.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., April 27 A small group of residents demonstrated briefly in front of the high school here today to protest what they called "a double set of political standards, censorship and thought control."

Many newsmen thrown out of work by the merger of three newspapers must leave New York if they want to stay in the business, according to the directors of job-placement agencies set up by journalism societies and the Newspaper Guild of New York.
The city was enjoined yesterday by the State Supreme Court from building a $1.19-million playground and community center in Riverside Park near 103d Street.
An action for divorce may be maintained by a husband or wife to procure a judgment divorcing the parties and dissolving the marriage on any of the following grounds;
The nation's electric power production rose 9.5 per cent in the week ended April 23, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

WHEN Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, faced Herman Pilnik of Chile in the recent 16-man international round-robin at Mar del Plata, Argentina, a clash of temperaments was foreshadowed.
WASHINGTON, April 27 Secretary of Labor W.Willard Wirtz clashed with a union leader at a labor convention today over the right of public employes to strike.
LOS ANGELES, April 27 (AP)-Wes Parker knocked in three runs and Don Sutton pitched a five-hitter as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated Atlanta, 4-1, tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 27 President Johnson today instructed his new Indian Commissioners to devise the most comprehensive, far-sighted and adventuresome program to help Indians in the nation's history.

ORANGE, N.J., April 27 Dr. Claudia G.Argent, a former assistant professor and chairman of the associate degree program in nursing at Rutgers University, died of a heart attack yesterday at her home at 380 Oakwood Avenue, She was 40 years old.

The printers' union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., held a negotiating session for almost four hours last night. There was disagreement over whether "a little progress" or "no progress" had been made and no time or date was set for a resumption of talks.
CHARLESTON, IND. April 27 (UPI) An explosion today rocked an Army ammunition plant that produces gunpowder used in the Vietnam war. Three persons were missing and at least 45 others were injured.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 27 Two Government scientists announced here today that they had developed what appears to be the first effective vaccine against German measles, a virus disease responsible for deforming thousands of babies.

WASHINGTON, April 27 High-ranking Administration officials concluded today that the MIG jets that fought American planes over Vietnam were piloted by North Vietnamese who had probably been trained in the Soviet Union.
Blind craftsmen have made for Lighthouse Industries a combined waxer and buffer with a wrist-action construction that permits it to get under and around appliances and low furniture.

MEXICO CITY, April 27 Secretary of the Treasury Henry H.Fowler declared here today that the voluntary guidelines on United States bank loans and corporate investments abroad would stay in effect until the hostilities in South Vietnam ceased or were reduced sharply.

While the Interstate Commerce Commission often is faulted for its deliberate procedures, on any substantial request by a carrier or shipper, it has acted on 33 railroad unification proposals in the last decade. It has said "yes" to all but six of those proposals.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27 Rain, cold and fog postponed the New York Mets one-night stand in Philadelphia this evening and sent them on to Pittsburgh with their fifth rainout in 17 days.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 27 An American serviceman guarding the United States Embassy residence killed a Dominican shoeshine boy today. United States military spokesmen described the incident as an accident.

The Greenwich Savings Bank has filed a mortgage foreclosure action on the former Saks-34th Street store building at Herald Square, which E.J. Korvette, Inc., plans to occupy with a new discount department store late next year.

WEST POINT, N.Y. April 27 (AP) Franklin (Pepper) Rodgers, backfield coach at the University of California, Los Angeles, and Gene Ellenson, assistant coach at the University of Florida, are among those who have been interviewed for the Army football coaching job.
GROSSINGER, N.Y., April 27-Dr. Joachim Prinz, president of the American Jewish Congress, warned tonight of "danger signals" that menace the continuation of Jewish life in this country.
There is a disquieting aspect to the continuing eagerness of the nation's great railroads to carry out mergers they conceived nearly than a decade ago.

Shares of the Great Northern and Northern Pacific railroads fell sharply in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as a wave of selling followed the Interstate Commerce Commission s rejection of their proposed merger.
LONDON, April 27 Princess Anne, 15-year-old daughter of Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip, was thrown from her horse yesterday, and broke her nose.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, called in the Senate today for the resignation of Frances G. Knight as head of the State Department's Passport Office. He said her tactics were "reminiscent of witch-hunting."

Edward J. Barber, president of the steamship line bearing his name, has been re-elected president of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York. It will be the eighth consecutive year of Mr. Barber's presidency of the 93-yearold association.

PEKING Signs of antiAmerican feeling are everywhere in China. Yet there is something fishy about it all. If the United States did not exist, the Central Committee of the Communist party would have to invent it.

IRVINGTON, N.J., April 27-Beginning with the opening of school this fall, the cultural diet of the 10,800 public and parochial school children, as well as the adults of this Essex County community nine miles from New York City will be enriched by a series of events in the performing and visual arts.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today the request by three big Western railroads to merge into one 26,000-mile system serving 17 states and Canada.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The Administration said today it expected soft coal prices to remain stable in the wake of the industry's new labor agreement with the United Mine Workers of America.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 27 Segregation returned to Alabama's mental hospitals today at the order of Gov. George C. Wallace.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has drawn some fine geographical and economic distinctions in approving the merger of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads while turning down the merger of the Great Northern, Northern Pacific and Chicago, Burlington Quincy in the West.
MONROE, Mich., April 27 (UPI) A storm pushed the waters of Lake Erie over a 100mile stretch of Michigan and Ohio lowlands today. Thousands fled their homes.
WASHINGTON April 27 Gardner Ackley, President Johnson's chief economic adviser, held out the hope to housewives today that food prices might be lower by the end of this year.

The Modern Jazz Quartet covered a wide swath of its past and present last night at Carnegie Hall. The group's concert, its first here in more than a year, was a benefit for the Manhattan School of Music, of which the quartet's pianist and musical director, John Lewis, is a trustee.
ALBION, Idaho, April 27 (AP) Ralph Harding, a former Representative from Idaho and special assistant to the Secretary of the Air Force, announced today he was a Democratic candidate for the Senate.
Judith Anderson will star as Clytemnestra in Aeschylus's trilogy "Oresteia" on a stage not far from home plate in a Michigan baseball stadium this summer.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 27 (UPI) Charles W. Hinman was convicted today on five counts of soliciting a magazine salesman to kill Murray Chotiner, onetime campaign manager for former Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The Treasury announced today that it would exchange $9.3-billion of securities that mature next month for an 18-month Treasury note, discounted ... counted to yield 4.98 per cent interest.
THE history of modern art can claim, among its great diversity of styles, certain modes of expression that seemed, until very recently, to define the outermost limits of the impersonal.
DALLAS, April 27 (AP) The former nightclub operated by Jack L. Ruby will soon become a boys' boxing gymnasium directed by the Dallas Police Association.
There is a college building in Brooklyn in which a student runs a risk of being tarred, and then feathered, in the routine pursuit of his studies.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued their downward path yesterday. At the close, prices of 433 issues were down, 262 were higher and 199 were unchanged.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The San Francisco Mining Exchange will go out of business, by Government order, at the close of trading Friday.
SAIGON, April 27 (AP) Vietcong terrorists have killed or abducted more than 4,000 Vietnamese Government officials in the last two years, official sources said today.
DETROIT, April 27 (UPI) Dr. Donald C. Bews of Montreal became today the first Canadian to be named president of the Industrial Medical Association.

BOSTON, April 27-Edward J. McCormack Jr., a nephew of Speaker of the House John W. McCormack, formally announced tonight his candidacy for Governor of Massachusetts. He is a former state Attorney General.

THERE'S a growing movement in field trials for the pointing breeds to eliminate the tract of land at the end of a course in which birds are concentrated in favor of having the birds seeded all along the course.

WASHINGTON, April 27 A man in Metuchen, N.J., writes to ask, "How can I tell how old I feel?" It seems that at a recent birthday celebration, while merrily hoisting his cup, a child had clapped him on the back and said, "Cheer up, Dad! You're only as old as you feel!"

William J. Diamond, Deputy Commissioner of Buildings, was cleared yesterday of any conflict of interest deriving from ownership by his family of real property "subject to inspection, by his department."

ST. VINCENT, Italy, April 27 The North American team was 24 international points behind the Italian world champions at the end of the first session of play in the crucial match of the 1966 world championship here this afternoon.

MOSCOW, April 27 Fortyfour young musicians from the United States will take part in the third international Tchaikovsky contests opening here next month, Yekaterina A. Furtseva, editor of Kultur, announced today. There are 240 entrants.

LONDON, April 27 Police officials testified today at the Pennine Moors murder trial that in pretrial interrogations the two defendants had denied killing Lesley Ann Downey although they had admitted that the little girl had been in their house.
A broad change in the senior management of the Union Carbide Corporation was announced here yesterday.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 27 The procession to follow Oginga Odinga into opposition in Kenya began to fall apart today as 12 members of Parliament declared that they had changed their minds.

The British pound rallied yesterday after several days of decline on foreign exchange markets here.

PITCAIRN, Pa., April 27 The telephone rang frequently tonight as eight railroaders sat around Bill Crawford's living room and talked about the merger of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central that was authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, April 28 (AP) A volcanic eruption in densely populated East Java has demolished one village and is spilling lava toward a major town, reports from the area said today.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 27 (AP) Bill Campbell, seeking his fourth North and South amateur golf title since 1950, won two matches today to lead the field into the quarter-finals.
MOSCOW, April 27 (Reuters) The Soviet Central Asian city of Tashkent groped back toward normal today, with damage reported to be less than originally feared after yesterday's severe earthquake.
