LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 27 The qualifying deadline for the July 26 primary elections in Arkansas passed at noon today and for the first time in 12 years the Democratic ticket did not include the name of Orval Eugene Faubus.
WASHINGTON, April 28 Senator Jacob K. Javits is preparing to announce over the weekend that he will not challenge Governor Rockefeller for the Republican gubernatorial nomination.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The Federal Power Commission believes that Federal safety standards are necessary to protect the public from injury and death as a result of accidents on the nation's natural gas pipeline system.

CZESTOCHOWA, Poland, April 28 The carpenters have planted a tall cross of raw lumber on the platform that will support the main altar on the ramparts of Jasna Gora Monastery. It is the age-old symbol of their craft for a job that is completed.

PEKING April 28 Sovietbloc diplomats walked out of a state banquet for the visiting Albanian Premier, Mehmet Shehu, when China praised Albania for standing in the forefront in the fight against revisionists led by the Soviet Communist party.
New York University's new School of the Arts has received $750,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation for its theater program.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 (AP) Lou Johnson drove in three runs and Don Drysdale gained his first victory in four starts tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers whipped Atlanta, 8-2, for their third straight victory.
WASHINGTON, April 28 Official sources said today that President Johnson alone would decide whether American planes would cross into Communist China on "hot pursuit" missions.

ALBANY, April 28 Regulations designed to increase safety and reduce noise in helicopter operations atop New York City's Pan-Am Building were approved today by the State Senate.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange turned quietly firmer yesterday on news of the exploratory talks between Britain and Rhodesia.
A proposed $75,000 liability limit for international airline flights was described by the Air Line Pilots Association yesterday as "an invitation to sabotage."

Governor Rockefeller proposed yesterday that the American Newspaper Publishers Association help solve job placement and relocation for employes displaced by the merger of three newspapers here. He offered the state's cooperation in a program that might include retraining.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 (AP) Juan Marichal pitched his fourth straight completegame victory today, shutting out Cincinnati on four hits as San Francisco defeated the Reds, 3-0. The triumph snapped the Giants' three-game losing streak.
Judge Frank Cacciatore of the New York City Criminal Court died yesterday of a heart ailment at the Astoria (Queens) General Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 30-75 29th Street, Astoria.

MEXICO CITY, April 28 (AP) The governing board of National University here tha said today a resignation that the university president, Ignaci Chavez, was forced to sign by rioting students was invalid.

LONDON, April 28 Lisa Shane, a 29-year-old Irish actress, braved and tamed what she called a "lynch mob" from the stage of the Prince of Wales Theater here tonight when she substituted for Barbra Streisand in "Funny Girl."
Parks Commissioner Thomas P. F. Hoving announced plans yesterday for what he called "the largest outdoor music festival in the world."
GENEVA, April 28 The Soviet Union ruled out today any accord for halting the spread of nuclear weapons if the accord did not bar West Germany's "association" with such arms.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) Governor Rockefeller said today that Federal aid for water pollution control "is of course, totally inadequate and unrealistic."
J. Howard Wood, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, was elected yesterday as president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association as it ended its 80th annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The City Gardens Club has chosen 12 private gardens and penthouse terraces on the East side for its 20th annual tour, to be held on the afternoons of Tuesday and May 10. Proceeds will provide scholarships at Audubon summer camps for qualified New York public school teachers.

Philip J. Levin, real-estate developer in New Jersey and a dissident director of MetroGoldwyn-Mayer. Inc., filed suit in United States District Court here yesterday to prevent a special meeting of M-G-M stockholders scheduled to be held May 24 in New York.

BRUSSELS, April 28 The official spokesman of the Executive Commission of the European Common Market expressed "solid optimism" today that the six member states would soon conclude successfully their long, often acrimonious negotiations over financing agricultural subsidies.
NEW DELHI, April 28 When Mrs. Indira Gandhi took office as Prime Minister 100 days ago, right-wing politicians here whispered ominously, "She'll be just a mouthpiece for Krishna Menon."
WASHINGTON, April 28 Communist China is preparing a third atomic explosion that may be larger and produce more radioactive fallout than the previous ones, the State Department said today.
A 15-year lease for 20,000 square feet below the ground level in the Empire State Building has been signed by the Electronic Computer Programming Institute, Inc.

EVANSTON, Ill., April 28 This year's winners of merit scholarships throughout the country, a record 2,250, who will be given more than $8-million to help finance their educations, were announced today by John M. Stalmaker, president of the National Merit Scholarship Corporation.

Worldwide industrial enterprises have become a prime generator of economic and trade expansion, Frederic G. Donner, chairman of General Motors, said yesterday in the first of three 1966 Columbia-McKinsey Foundation lectures at Columbia University.
Fuel Services, Inc. The plant recovers by chemical processes plutonium and other nuclear materials from the spent fuels of reactors.
The New York Jets and the New York Giants, rivals in the pro football war, will have a confrontation at the gate only twice in the coming season.
The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company's first-quarter earnings increased 103 per cent on a sales gain of 52 per cent, Claude O. Stephens, president, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 As copious evidence of a Soviet military build-up in Cuba, including the installation of antiaircraft missiles, poured into Washington in the summer of 1962, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, John A. McCone, had a strong hunch about its meaning.

Yellow and white daisies adorned the Plaza's Grand Ballroom last night for the 31st annual spring dance in behalf of the Boys Club of New York. Mrs. John R. Stevenson, general chairman of the party, and her husband were among the hosts there.

The heavyweight championship boxing bout between Cassius Clay, the champion, and Henry Cooper in London on May 21 will be televised live by the American Broadcasting Company. The program, which will be relayed across the Atlantic by the Early Bird communications satellite, will begin at 5 P.M. New York time.
TOKYO, April 29 (Reuters) Eleven Japanese-Americans were among 31 overseas Japanese honored by the Government today to mark Emperor Hirohito's 65th birthday.
DALLAS, April 28 (AP) A violent cloudburst struck the Dallas area before dawn today, drowning at least seven persons, flooding expressways and forcing hundreds from their homes.
Potential teachers at Hunter College are taking a special teaching course in nature.

PARIS, April 28 The fate of Europe's space program, recently cast in doubt by its rising cost and shrinking significance, was left unsettled today at the close of a seven-nation meeting that was supposed to have been decisive.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The final settlement of a 3-yearold Government suit against the Hanna Mining Company for overcharges on a nickel contract was apparently reached today. The total award given the Government, including interest and other charges, was $632,000.
WASHINGTON, April 28 The Treasury Department announced today that it is planning to make large corporations pay to the Government more promptly the income taxes they withhold from employes' wages.
WASHINGTON, April 28 Gen. Earle G. Wheeler was nominated by President Johnson today for a second two-year term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

President Johnson's civil rights message carries the nation's long campaign for equality into the final bastions of segregation and racial privilege the jury room and the residential neighborhood. There are many signs that this ultimate battle may be the hardest fought of all.
WASHINGTON, April 28 Ignoring President Johnson's pleas for economy, a rebellious House Appropriations Committee added nearly half a billion dollars today to his health and education budget.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) Bill Mazeroski's double, his third extra-base hit of the game touched off a four-run l0th inning today that gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 9-6 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

LIMA, Peru, April 28 (AP) A search party today reached the wreckage of a Peruvian airliner that crashed high in the Andes Mountains and reported that all 49 persons aboard were killed. Five were Americans.

Mayor Lindsay proposed a new city agency last night to provide legal service to protect the poor from being victimized by unscrupulous landlords, unfair credit terms: short-changing on relief and other invasions of basic rights.

The Ford Motor Company, the nation's second largest automobile producer, set sales and earnings records in the first quarter of this year, it was reported yesterday at its Dearborn, Mich,, headquarters.

OTTAWA, April 28 Gerda Munsinger once rejected as an immigrant to Canada on security and moral grounds, was admitted in 1955 through an "unexplainable error," the Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police testified today.
BONN, April 28 Despite the recent deterioration in relations between Bonn and Paris, Chancellor Ludwig Erhard has no misgivings about President de Gaulle's visit to the Soviet Union in June.

DUARTE, Calif., April 28 (AP) Sporadic brawling and fist fights broke out at Duarte High School today between Negro and white youths, and the school principal said it was "definitely a racial incident."

BALTIMORE, April 28 The Central Intelligence Agency dispatched five Washington lawyers to the Federal District Court here today to close the door of legal discovery on the agency's clandestine operations in this country. The lawyers succeeded.
First-quarter earnings of the St. Regis Paper Company rose 3.2 per cent over the yearearlier level on a sales rise of 8.7 per cent.
Alexander's Department Stores praised the decision last night as "making it all the more possible for us" to sell automobiles.
Although London prices for copper held firm and even showed a little improvement yesterday, copper futures here continued to decline in nearby positions, as they have done each day this week.
UNITED NATION, N.Y., April 28 Pasupuleti G. Krishnayya, who wrote about the United Nations for Indian journals, died Monday at Bellevue Hospital, He was 53 years old.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 Stockholders of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation were told today that first-quarter sales had risen to the highest level in the company's history.

The engagement of Miss Sarah Jocheved Tropper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Tropper of Brooklyn, to Rabbi Bernard B. Saperstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Saperstein of Manhattan, has been announced by the future bride's parents. An August wedding is planned.

PROBABLY the best thing that can be said about "The World of Jacques-Yves Cousteau." which was presented for an hour last night on Channel 2, is that it gave the viewer a, preliminary and spooky preview of what life in space may be like.
Last year I came before the Congress in an hour of crisis to recommend new and powerful guarantees of the right to vote.
A civil tax case in Federal Court, which took two days to try and the jury two-and-a-half days to reach a verdict, was won yesterday by the Government. The suit involved $40,000 in excise taxes.

Mayor Lindsay's testimony at a Senate hearing yesterday that $4 billion will be needed over the next decade for new subway construction in New York City was certainly dismaying. Unfortunately, the need is indisputably real. And no valid challenge is possible of the Mayor's conclusion that only the Federal Government can conceivably provide funds on the scale needed. The Government has spent billions to subsidize highways, shipping and aviation. Why not urban transportation?

The family of the late Adele Rosenwald Levy accused the city of bad faith yesterday and said that they would recommend the return of more than $600,000 in gifts made for a memorial playground for Mrs. Levy in Riverside Park.
Two more steel companies joned the ranks of other steel makers yesterday in reporting first-quarter declines in sales and earnings.

LONDON, April 28 (AP) Five defense ministers and their aides heard Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer urge today that the use of tactical, as well as strategic, nuclear weapons in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization remain under American control.

MONTEREY, Mass., April 28 Harold P. Winchester, former treasurer of the Williams Press, Inc., Menands, N.Y., and long a leader in welfare organizations died Monday at the Gould Farm here after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

ALBANY, April 28 The Public Service Commission was ordered today by the state's highest court to reconsider the controversial 5 per cent electricity rate increase it granted to Consolidated Edison two years ago.

BOSTON, April 28 The Boston Celtics won their eighth straight National Basketball Association title tonight by beating the Los Angeles Lakers, 95-93, and continued the longest championship reign in the 'history of major professional sports. This triumph in the seventh game of the final playoff gave the Celtics their ninth N.B.A, title in 10 years.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 111.5 on Wednesday from 111.9 on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 These are awkward days for Vice President Humphrey. His old liberal friends are condemning him. His former conservative enemies are praising him, and he is trapped politically somewhere between Lyndon Johnson and Bobby Kennedy.

Senator J.W. Fulbright warned here last night that "America is showing some signs of that fatal presumption, that overextension of power and mission, which brought ruin to ancient Athens, to Napoleonic France and to Nazi Germany."

Nobuo Sato, the Japanese figure skating champion, joined Petra Burka, Canada's premier skater and the 1965 world champion, in a brief drill at Iceland yesterday. They skated beautifully together, but there wasn't much conversation: Sato speaks no English.
Nicola Paone, 207 East 34th Street, 684-9692. Inasmuch as there are few very good Italian restaurants in New York City, there are several things to admire at Nicola Paone.
ROSCOE, N.Y. April 28 The day was all a spring day should be. The sun warmed the world and the things in it. Children rebelled against jackets, and shorts were resurrected from winter hiding places.

Jose Antonio Suarez, a 23year-old laundry worker, was arraigned on charges of multiple homicide in Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday before Judge Vincent P. Rao, in connection with the deaths late last Saturday night of Mrs. Maria Rivera Torres, 23, and her five children ranging in ages from 1 to 5 years.

PHAN THIET, Binhthuan Province, South Vietnam, April 28 The helicopters skitter into the dusk like crippled dragonflies as General Westmoreland's plane touches down. It is not the plane in which he started off the day. The first one lost an engine and its radio over Vietcong territory in the highlands.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 28 Portugal called on Secretary General Thant today to get a ruling on the legality of the Security Council's resolution of April 9 authorizing Britain to use force if necessary to prevent shipment of oil to (Rhodesia through Beira in Portuguese Mozambique.
The American Stock Exchange took its worst beating in more than a month yesterday as stocks retreated along a broad front.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 28 Miss Margery Schiffman and Robert Motzkin have made plans to be married Aug. 14.
NEWMARKET, England, April 28 (AP) Glad Rags finished a neck ahead of Berkeley Springs today for an upset victory in the 1,000 Guineas, a mile race for 3-year-old fillies. Both are American-owned.

ALBANY, April 28 (AP) Bills designed to provide immediate unemployment benefits for newspaper workers affected by the strike in New York City were filed Thursday with the rules committes of the Assembly and Senate.

Fifty years and almost 200 million hot dogs after Nathan and Ida Handwerker opened Nathan's Famous at Coney Island, they were honored last night at a dinner sponsored by the Coney Island Chamber of Commerce. Roast beef was served.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 25 A desperate search is under way to find candidates to oppose Gen. Rene Barrientos Ortuno in the presidential elections set for July 3.
HOLLYWOOD, April 28 Charles Chaplin's old movie studio, a landmark half a century old, may face extinction.

The election of Donald W. Davis, 44 years old, as president and chief executive officer of the Stanley Works, maker of steel hardware, was announced yesterday following the annual stockholder meeting in New Britain, Conn.
TOLEDO, Ohio, April 28 (AP) Freak winds that caused flooding along Lake Erie subsided today and thousands of residents returned to waterlogged homes along the lake front.
Salvatore (Bill) Bonanno was cruising around the scene of a recent shooting affair in Brooklyn in a white Lincoln Continental automobile, District Attorney Aaron E. Koota's aides suggested yesterday.

Major composers of Broadway and Hollywood and leading vocalists will participate in "Salute to ASCAP," a benefit show to be given at 8:30 Sunday night at Philharmonic Hall in behalf of the National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities.
LONDON, April 28 A photograph figured prominently in evidence today as the prosecution ended its case in the Pennine Moors murder trial.

Good music, straightforward presentation and a sense of personal dedication were the hallmarks of last night's "Music From Marlboro" concert at Town Hall. It was the last of three. The house was nearly packed, and everyone seemed to hate a good time.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) Vice President Humphrey bestowed the President's trophy for the Handicapped American of the Year today on a blind and deaf man from Brooklyn, N.Y.
The Government bond market experienced yesterday "what probably is the most quiet Treasury refunding on record," one dealer said last night.
TEL AVIV, April 28 A land mine, presumably laid by Arab terrorists, exploded today on one of Israel's major tourist routes, the road to Massada. No one was hurt.
The decline in stock prices gathered momentum yesterday.
Several Oklahoma Congressmen are pushing a littlenoticed bill which would seriously weaken the Land and Water Conservation Fund.
Longshoremen and their employers are heading into a court fight over arbitration of manning disputes arising out of new work rules that went into effect April 1.

The World Bank announced yesterday in Washington the appointment of James S. Raj as deputy executive vice president of the International Finance Corporation, an affiliate. The I.F.C. was formed by member governments in 1956 to aid the growth of the private sector in less-developed countries.
WASHINGTON, April 28Alcoholism is emerging as a critical cause of automobile deaths and injuries, a National Academy of Engineering traffic safety symposium indicated today.

Operations of the Shell Oil Company in the first quarter this year were the best in its history, Richard C. McCurdy, president, reported yesterday. Net income for the three months reached a record $61,657,000, equal to $1.01 a share, from $54,889,000 or 90 cents a share earned in the period a year ago, the executive told shareholders at the annual meeting here.

PITTSBURGH, April 28 (UPI) Thousands of soft coal miners, on strike since April 11, remained away from work today even though their union had signed a new 30-month contract with two major producer groups.
WASHINGTON, April 28 House Democrats who are writing a new antipoverty authorization bill have agreed to restore nearly all the cuts they had made in the budget for Community Action Programs.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 Testimony before a coroner's jury today failed to produce any clue to the murderer of Dow Wilson, a controversial union leader.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, criticized today the administration of Job Corps camps, which he compared with reformatories.
The election of Herbert W. Nannen and Donald C. Patterson as senior vice presidents was announced here yesterday by the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 The mortality of very tiny, sickly premature infants can be cut in half by feeding them intravenously soon after birth, a Chicago pediatrician reported here today.
WASHINGTON, April 28 Labor, management and Government were urged here today to close ranks and carefully review their positions in an effort to reach a mutually acceptable shipping policy.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 28 Considering it was the day after the Interstate Commerce Commission had rejected its merger bid, the Northern Pacific Railroad's annual meeting today was unusually quiet.
Impetus was given to the reorganization of the Actors Studio Theater, dormant since 1964, at a dinner-meeting of supporters last night in the 21 Club, 21 West 52d Street.

CHICAGO, April 28 Clarence L. Coleman Jr., retiring president of the American Council for Judaism, said to night that by supporting the "Zionist-dominated Jewish establishment" non-Zionist Jews shaved the responsibility for misconceptions held about American Jews.

YONKERS, April 28 The third straight weekly benefit for Cardigan Bay went the way of the first two tonight, the 10year-old New Zealand gelding winning the $50,000 National Championship Pace virtually as he pleased at rain spattered, Yonkers Raceway.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to improve yesterday in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7943, up 12 points from the preceding day's level.

CHICAGO, April 28 A conference of nearly 100 leaders from business, labor and the universities showed almost complete unanimity today in the view that the Government's wage-price guideposts were of little use in stopping inflation and could be harmful or unfair.
WASHINGTON, April 28 President Johnson asked Congress today to enact "the first effective Federal law against discrimination" on racial or religious grounds in the sale and rental of all housing.

DETROIT, April 28 The defending Stanley Cup champion Montreal Canadiens bounced back into title contention tonight by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 4-2, in the third game of the Stanley Cup playoff finals.
Ralph Bunker, a stage and screen actor, died yesterday at the Sanger Home, 500 West 57th Street, following a stroke. He was 77 years old and lived at 249 East 48th Street.
DETROIT, April 28 The General Motors Corporation said today it was "disappointed and concerned" over the Supreme Court's ruling.
A GOOD jockey can't win with a bad horse, and neither can a good oceanracing driver win with a bad boat.
The directors of the Fountain House Foundation elected Huyler C. Held as president of the board yesterday.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 28 (AP) Ward Wettlaufer and Dr. Ed Updegraff, former Walker Cup players: Gary Cowan, a former Canadian amateur champion, and unheralded Marion Heck won quarter-final matches today in the North and South amateur golf tournament.
SAIGON, April 28 United States officials said today they were unable to explain why the Soviet-built MIG fighters encountered by American pilots over Vietnam this week had done so little shooting.
WASHINGTON, April 28 President Johnson today accepted "with regret" the resignation of Thomas C. Mann as Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 28 The future of the multiracial University College of Rhodesia, whose continued existence has been threatened by demonstrations and strikes arising from political and racial friction, may be decided this weekend.
The manager of a Times Square movie theater was stabbed to death last night during an apparent robbery attempt, the police reported.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 28 Abe's Hope, an Illinois-bred owned by John Bartell and Robert Byfield, accomplished one of the biggest upsets of the thoroughbred racing season today. He beat the Darby Dan Farm's Graustark, winner of all seven of his previous races, in the $29,550 Blue Grass Stakes. He won the 1 1/8-mile event by a nose.

Espionage has always been among the most sordid of professions, and the cold war has made it more so, The New York Times survey on the clandestine operations of the Central Intelligence Agency has provided a chilling indication of the range of intriguefrom bribery and the buying of elections to coups and military action by proxy into which the United States has been plunged by the need for countering Communist subversion.

First-quarter net income of the Singer Company rose to $10,967,000, equal to $1.02 a share, from $9,634,000 in the first three months of last year, Donald P. Kircher, president, reported to 500 shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Hotel here.

MADRID, April 28 The Government has closed the University of Barcelona for an indefinite period after yesterday's violence involving students and the police. It was the first closing of a university in Spain in nearly 40 years.

Herbert Faus, a retired locomotive equipment engineer for the New York Central Railroad, died last Saturday while vacationing in Eustis, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived at 446 South Lexington Avenue, White Plains.
NOBODY, including Rudi Gernreich, believes his new topless nightgown will create half the furor his topless bathing suit did two years ago.
BOULEVARD, Calif., April 28 (UPI) A Coast Guard heli-, copter airlifted Tracy Barnes today from the east slope of 4,600-foot Mount Tule to a hospital in San Diego for treatment of a back injury.
LONDON, April 28 The British Monopolies Commission asserted today that Kodak, Ltd., was making "disproportionately high profits" from the sale of color film in Britain.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 28 Few rowing coaches have compiled a record of success equaling that of Harrison (Stork) Sanford at Cornell over the last decade.
VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Friday, April 29 (AP) More than 4,000 fresh United States troops landed in Vietnam today, bringing the total American strength in the Vietnamese war to nearly 250,000.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., April 28 Announcement has been made by George Blount of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Carolyn Blount, to Robert B. Cohen, son of Dr. and Mrs, Charles Cohen of Fort Lee, N.J.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The House passed today a bill designed to curb the stealing of pets and promote humane treatment of dogs and cats destined for scientific research.
The Feinstein Construction Corporation, specialists in construction and modernization projects in the metropolitan area, has appointed William Erdelyi as a vice president.

Time and careful questioning of prospective jurors can assure a fair trial for defendants about whom prejudicial news articles have been written, the United States Court of Appeals said yesterday in upholding the conviction of three men who plotted to dynamite national monuments.
The Transport Workers Union announced yesterday that its American Airlines members had voted to strike at midnight tomorrow.

THE new microwave relay system scheduled for early testing in New York is even more fascinating than was evident from its first announcement on Wednesday.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 28 (UPI)-Empress Farah of Iran gave birth to her third child, an 8 -pound boy, today. He is the second son born to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who divorced two previous wives when they failed to produce a male heir.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 28 Kenya's Parliament approved a constitutional amendment tonight forcing any member who quits the ruling Kenya African National Union to resign his seat and seek re-election. The vote on the amendment was 95 to 8.

TRENTON, April 28 Leaders of the Democratic party in New Jersey are trying to persuade former Gov. Robert B. Meyner to run against United States Senator Clifford P. Case, the liberal Republican who will seek a third term in November.
Two gifts totaling $1-million have been pledged to Barnard College on condition that the school raise a matching $1-million from among its 14,000 alumnae before June 30 of next year.

Net profit of the Martin Marietta Corporation in the first three months this year rose to $4,831,533 from $2,740,913 a year ago, George M. Bunker, president, reported to shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel here. Earnings were equal to 24 cents a ...

NEW HAVEN, April 28 What's on the mind of today's college student? More than is dreamed of by his elders or the opinion polls. The war in Vietnam, of course, and a young man's draft status, he cinema aboveground and underground.

A $54-million offering of 4 3/8 per cent revenue bonds of the Industrial Development Board of Camden, Ala., at a price of 100 was announced yesterday by Lazard Freres Co. and Lehman Brothers, joint managers of the underwriting syndicate.
WASHINGTON, April 28-Intercity truck tonnage and rail-freight ton-mileage in the latest week ended April 23 were both above the volume in the corresponding period of 1965.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 28 A new drive in the campaign against poverty this one against housing segregation that keeps poor Negroes in ghetto slums is being urged on the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity.

New York's liberalized divorce law, which adds several new grounds to the 179-yearold one-ground (adultery) statute, has among its ironies the probability that for many couples divorce will now be more difficult and time-consuming.

GROTON, Mass., April 28 Mr. and Mrs. William BentinckSmith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Bentinck-Smith, to Henry A. Erlich, son of Prof. and Mrs. Victor Erlich of Hamden, Conn.
The sale of the Ambassador Collection, one of the most complete collections of United States postage stamps, was completed last night and brought a total price of $277,683.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The Internal Revenue Service is investigating the financial affairs of Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut. Officials said today that there was "a probability" that a claim for unpaid back taxes would be filed against him.

Just after Al Davis had been appointed commissioner of the American Football League three weeks ago in Houston, his first task was to break up a fight involving Bud Adams, the owner of the Houston. Oilers, who started it, and a local newspaperman, Jack Gallagher of the Post.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has given up trying to persuade newspapers to run notices stating that "male" and "female" helpwanted columns are meant for both sexes.
Faced by about 125 irate property owners, the Board of Estimate backed away yesterday from approving a $32.7million Queens highway improvement that had been scheduled to pass.
The election of John Lawrence, R. Charles Clevenger and Prentis Cobb Hale as directors of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company was announced yesterday at the annual meeting in Topeka, Kan.
The common stock of the General Motors Corporation sold yesterday at 88 , registering its lowest price since mid-1964, and thereby hangs a market bellwether.

FRENCHMAN FLAT, Nev., April 28 (AP) An underground nuclear explosion last Monday accidentally leaked radioactivity that spread over five states, and as a result radioactivity in the thyroid glands of residents in two villages has increased, the Atomic Enerby Commission said today.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 28 Prof. Herbert Marcuse asserted today at a conference at the University of Notre Dame that the capitalistic system was fighting for existence in Vietnam and Southeast Asia.

HOUSTON, April 28 (UPI) Robin Roberts, with relief help from two pitchers, picked up his first victory of the season and 282d of his career tonight when the Houston Astros defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-2, with three runs in the second inning.
WARSAW, April 28 (AP) Poland has protested sharply to the United States that one of her cargo ships was damaged in a United States bombing raid last week near Haiphong in North Vietnam.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 28-United States troops shot and wounded seven Dominican demonstrators today, the first anniversary of the American military intervention here.

VENEZUELA LAST CHANCE FOR DE MOCRACY," a solid, onehour documentary offered last night on the National Educational Television's Channel 13 was the second program this week to remind us that Latin America's stubborn problems of underdevelopment remain unresolved and ominous even while most of our attention is focused on Vietnam and China.

HOUSTON, April 28 More than 900 members of one of the most expensive but least exclusive clubs in America gathered tonight in the Shamrock Hotel for an evening of entertainment and mingling with the President of the United States.

ADEN, April 28-Dissident troops attempted to kill the pro-British Sultan of Muscat and Oman during a military parade two days ago, but their assassination plot was crushed, reliable sources reported today.

New York City had to pay its highest interest rate in 34 years to borrow $241,755,000 yesterday to help meet the cost of municipal government. In obtaining the loan, the city was in much the same position as a man who has a good reputation for paying his debts, but is in sore need of a lot of cash because his income is not adequate to match his immediate expenses.
HANGCHOW, China People in China seem to be surprisingly lukewarm about the war in Vietnam.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., April 28 (AP) Nearly 70 years ago, when they were married, the Frederick Marslands of Tenafly, N.J., took a vow to remain together in sickness and in health.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., April 28 Miss Margaret Hinsdale Hall, retired headmistress of Miss Hall's School, a girls' boarding school here, died last night of a heart attack suffered just after she left a meeting of the Berkshire County Historical Society. She was 74 years old.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., April 28 William D. Dawson Sr., who formerly conducted technical training schools in New York and Newark, died yesterday at Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 36 Burnet Street here.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 28 (UPI) Indonesia is prepared to discuss peace with Malaysia, the official news agency Antara said today.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 28 The big question here on the eve of the 57th annual Drake Relays is whether Jim Ryun, the flying freshman from Kansas, can do it again.
The bankrupt New Haven Railroad reported yesterday a net railway operating loss of $4,233,840 for the first quarter this year, compared with a $5,735,532 loss a year earlier.

An impressive success by Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Sense of Rhythm in the $10,000 feature, the smallest crowd of the season and a jockey who rode in miserable weather despite his second penicilin shot in two days were among yesterday's developments at Aqueduct.

DAVID DIAMOND received a rather extraordinary tribute at last night's New York Philharmonic concert. Not one but two major works by him were presented, both in world premiere. Leonard Bernstein conducted the Fifth Symphony, and Mr. Diamond himself was on the podium for his Piano Concerto, with Thomas Schumacher as soloist.

WE were better fighters than businessmen, "said Georges Carpentier with a Gallic shrug of his shoul ders. "Tex Rickard offered us percentages of the gate receipts or flat guarantees. We took the guarantees. But how would we know that the fight would catch on the way it did? Voila! We could have made almost twice as much the other way."
WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) The House Armed Services Committee unanimously voted today to raise the pay of every serviceman by 3.2 per cent, effective July 1.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., April 28-The sensitive issue of Negro-Jewish relations including the emergence of a "Jewish backlash" in reaction to Negro anti-Semitism was discussed candidly today at the national convention of the American Jewish Congress.

Dr. Jane A. Carney, a teacher in public and private schools here more than half a century, died Wednesday morning at the Queens General Hospital in Jamaica. She was 82 years old and lived at 125 Prospect Park West in Brooklyn.
The Federal Reserve System a bringing steadily heavier pressure to bear on the credit markets, data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.
LONDON, April 28 (UPI) Britain took a 2-0 lead over New Zealand today in their European zone first-round Davis Cup tennis tie at the Queen's Club.
BALTIMORE, April 28 (AP) Mike Farmer, assistant coach and chief scout of the St. Louis Hawks, was named today as head coach of the Baltimore Bullets of the National Basketball Association.
The Penn Relays, America's oldest, largest, busiest and longest track and field carnival, begins today over the chewedup cinders of Franklin Field in Philadelphia.
Russ Togs. Inc., a leading apparel producer, announced yesterday its acquisition of A. R. Juniors (Aronoff Richling) for an undisclosed purchase price.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 28 (UPI) Gene Littler of La Jolla, Calif., and Larry Mowry, celebrating a new job at a country club near San Diego, shot 65's over the Oak Hills course today to lead the first round of the $80,000 Texas open golf tournament.
The Junior League of New York held its 65th annual meeting last evening in its clubhouse at 130 East 80th Street.

WASHINGTON, April 28-University of Rochester scientists reported here today the discovery of a new puzzle in the sky. It is an object that strongly emits gamma rays-the first such radiation source discovered to date.

CLEVELAND, April 28 (AP) The Cleveland Indians tied the major league record for consecutive victories at the start of the season, winning their 10th straight game tonight when they beat the California Angels, 2-1. The victory set an American League record.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 27 They are on the sunny side of middle age, Junior Leaguers and alumnae of Middle West state universities. They are rangy brunettes, delicate redheads, all sizes and shapes of blondes (including one who bears a startling resemblance to Baby Jane Holzer), and, for one reason or another, gray hairs are as scarce among them as dandelions in the desert.
WASHINGTON, April 28 Mayor Lindsay asked Congress today to help New York City pay for a $4-billion expansion and modernization of its subway system over the next 10 years.
LONDON, April 28 Although Britain and her rebellious colony of Rhodesia have decided to enter into exploratory talks, a formula for settling the Rhodesian crisis still eludes officials here.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The United States is seeking a limitation on future military spending by India and Pakistan as a condition for resumption of full-scale economic aid to the two countries, officials said today. India and Pakistan are understood to have responded coolly.

WASHINGTON, April 28 Officials said today that Gen. John P. McConnell, Air Force Chief of Staff, would send a team to Vietnam in a day or two to investigate the efficiency and tactical use of American air-to-air guided missiles.
The Newspaper Guild of New York reported a small step yesterday toward resolving its dispute over dismissals and the application of seniority in its strike against the World Journal Tribune, Inc.

Increased by more spring rains in the water shed, the city's water storage rose to 367.3 billion gallons, or 77.1 per cent of reservoir capacity, at 8 A.M. yesterday. The total represented a gain of 1.7 billion gallons since Wednesday morning when storage was at 76.7 per cent.
MEXICO CITY, April 28 The Inter American Development Bank approved here today a resolution to establish a pre-investment fund for Latin American integration.

ELK GROVE TOWNSHIP, Ill., April 28 W.A. Patterson, who stepped out today as chairman of United Air Lines at age 66, announced record first quarter profits of $5,748,500, compared with $767,000 last year.

Walter R. Fletcher of The New York Times, who writes dog-show news, was among those who received humanitarian-work awards at a dinner of the Institute for Human Animal Relationships at the Carnegie Endowment International Center last night.

The management of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, whose four highest officers have a collective age of 287 years, received an infusion of young blood yesterday with the election of Martin Davis, 39 year old, a vice president of the film company.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that although the city spent more on each school pupil than any other major city in the nation, "our educational system is not demonstrably better."

London Stock Exchange prices closed slightly lower in dull trading yesterday.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., April 29 (UPI)--Mr. and Mrs. Sargent Shriver have bought a rambling white clapboard house and seaside property 250 yards from the Kennedy compound for a price reported to be near $250,000.

CHICAGO, April 29--A rule of evidence laid down by the Supreme Court in 1961 has the result of safeguarding professional criminals, Charles S. Desmond, Chief Judge of the New York Court of Appeals, declared here today.

Mayor Lindsay was reported yesterday to have been assured that he could appoint the four civilians who are to join the Police Department's three-man complaint review board without making the board vulnerable to legal attack.

IN W.H. Auden's anthology, the 19th century undergoes an interesting change. There are fewer minstrels, little hymn singing and even less sentimental rumination over picturesque scenes. Instead the age taltes on a satiric and acerbic flavor that is welcome, even if it is a little surprising.
ST. VINCENT, Italy, April 29--North American hopes of winning the world bridge champioinship diminished this afternoon when the Italian blue team doubled its lead from 24 to 48 points.

The Equity Corporation has scheduled an annual meeting for May 10. The company did not hold one last year, according to its proxy material, because of "strong differences of opinion among members of the board relating principally to the selection of nominees to stand for election as directors."

New York City continues to pay a heavy price for its previous fiscal profligacy. YONKERS, April 29 Eaton Hall, an 8-year-old Australianbred pacer, died during the fifth race at Yonkers Raceway tonight. A shocked crowd of 27,236 looked on as the gelding wavered and fell at the 16th pole, the first time around, and lay motionless, while the other horses continued the race.

LONDON, April 29 Ian Brady took the stand today in the Pennine Moors murder trial and in a calm, firm voice gave his version of the events that led to the charge that he and Myra Hindley killed two children and a young man.
STOCKHOLM, April 29 (UPI) A good Swedish runner today got the chance to be much better by an American invitation.
Mayor Lindsay's tough water restrictions are almost certain to be continued through this summer even if, by some miracle, all the reservoirs are slopping over by June 1.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 John Charles Houlihan, former Mayor of Oakland, was indicted last night for embezzling $95,799 from an estate in which he was conservator.

The marriage of Miss Melissa Cameron to Jonathan Thorne McLane took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church, where the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Cosmopolitan Club.
Admiral Corporation stockholders received yesterday the news they had awaited anxiously for more than nine years. The company declared its first cash dividend since December, 1956.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Milton S. Gould of 35 East 75th Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Gould, to Francis Booth, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Booth of Islington, Mass.

WASHINGTON, April 29 Allegations that Senator Thomas J. Dodd improperly sought to further the interests of a public relations man who represents West German clients will be explored in public hearings by the Senate ethics committee.

Mayor Lindsay called last night for the designation today of a three-member fact-finding panel to make recommendations for settling the dispute between the newspaper unions and the World Journal Tribune, Inc.
MIDDLETOWN, N.J., April 29 Ken Burnette of Cedar Hill won pro individual honors and shared in the team prize today in a pro-amateur golf tournament at the Bam Hollow Country Club.

DALLAS, April 29 (AP) Thunderstorms swept toward northeast Texas today, leaving 12 persons dead and millions of dollars of damage in the DallasFort Worth area in what officials called the worst floods in recent history.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., April 29 A leading spokesman for Orthodox Judaism today called for government aid to religious education and set off an animated debate at the biennial convention of the American Jewish Congress.
NANUET N.Y., April 29 Philip J. Rieber, banker and retired merchant, died at his home, 111 South Middletown Road, early yesterday at the age of 69.
Summer will arrive early this year at branches of the New York and Brooklyn Public Libraries. They will begin summer schedules with shorter hours at the end of next week.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 Boys High of Brooklyn, with Jim Jackson running his usual sparkling anchor leg, set a meet record of 10 minutes 9.8 seconds today in winning the schoolboy distance medley in the Penn Relays. It was the first victory for a New York City school here since 1963.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) A continuing decline in hog prices helped push average farm prices down 2 per cent for the month ending April 15, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Mrs. Charles W. Carter Jr., an artist who was known by the professional name of Esther Flint Carter, died April 21 in Hendersonville, N.C., while returning to her Brookfield Center, Conn., home after a vacation. She was 71 years old.

The outlook for commuters on the bankrupt New Haven Railroad has been greatly improved by the Interstate Commerce Commission's approval of the Pennsylvania-New York Central merger, but they should not mistake the green light for a permanent guarantee of operation.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) Herbert F. Corn, managing editor of The Washington Evening Star until his retirement in 1962, died today at Doctors, Hospital after suffering a heart attack at his home in suburban-Maryland. He was 69 years old.
Senator Jacob K. Javits and Senator Robert F. Kennedy disagreed yesterday on the need for immediate establishment of a Federal Department of Consumers.
Representative Leonard Farbstein received backing for renomination and re-election yesterday from leaders of 7 of the 13 Democratic clubs in the 19th Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today a new suspension, effective immediately, in trading of stock of Great American Industries, Inc., of New York. The order is effective through May 8.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 29 A few painful hours spent in Nigeria five years ago provided James Madison Nabrit Jr. with a curious distinction: He is ...
MADRID, April 29 Madrid University students scuffled with policemen on the campus today in demonstrations of support for students in Barcelona.

William Lawrence Hanavan, an engineer who helped design and build parts of the subway system, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 75 Prospect Street in East Orange, N.J.

JERUSALEM, Iraeli Sector, Saturday, April 30 Israeli Army units struck across the Jordanian border at two points early today in retaliation against acts of sabotage. Three Israelis were slightly injured.

WASHINGTON, April 29 A spokesman for the bulk of American passenger shipping told Congress today that the best way to achieve maximum safety for American ship travelers was by assuring high United States safety standards and through barring unsafe foreien-flag ships.
The directors of Northeast Airlines, Inc., elected Forwood C. Wiser, Jr., yesterday as president, and promoted his predecessor, James W. Austin, to chairman. The changes are effective May 1.

BERLIN, April 29 Walter Ulbricht, East German chief of state, backed away today from plans for an exchange of visits next month between West German Social Democrats and East German Communists and said he wanted the project postponed at least until July.
DETROIT, April 29 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles scored seven runs in the third inning tonight and defeated the Detroit Tigers, 8-1.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 29 Provisional President Hector Garcia announced today that the Dominican police had taken over security duties in Santo Domingo from the Inter-American Peace Force.
The spot rate on the British pound declined yesterday in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7938, down 5 points from the previous day's level.
Cornell's heavyweight crews open their season in one of the three big cup regattas on today's program.
The General Dynamics Corporation achieved a 29 per cent increase in first-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 17 per cent, Roger Lewis, president, reported yesterday.
Somerset Hills, Piping Rock and Apawamis were winners yesterday as the second round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches was completed.
HONG KONG, April 29 Signs of strain in relations between Peking and Hanoi have been detected by specialists on Chinese Communist affairs.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 29 The flow of Communist supplies from Cambodia to South Vietnam via southern Laos is increasing, according to informed military sources here.

OTTAWA, April 29 (AP) The Air Transport Board has authorized Eastern Air Lines to operate scheduled services for passengers, goods and mail between Toronto and Buffalo, and Between Toronto and Miami via Tampa, Fla.

Canada's Roman Catholic, Anglican, Protestant and Eastern Orthodox church bodies, representing the main branches of a long-divided Christendom, will construct together a single Christian pavilion for the 1967 Montreal World's Fair.

Miss Florence Ann Gaudineer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Little Gaudineer of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Francis Treanor Leddy, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Leddy, also of the Bronx. The Rev. John A. Flaherty performed the ceremony in the Roman catholic Church of St. John.

Wall Street was trying to figure out last week which direction railroad securities were likely to take now that the Interstate Commerce Commission has erected two signposts that seem to point in opposite directions.

SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., April 30--Mr. and Mrs. Arlo Hints have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hults's daughter, Miss Joan Susanna MacDonald, to Mark Loebel Rose. His parents are Dr. and Mrs. Albert Rose of Princeton, N.J.

The Italian Line passenger, fleet carried 85,509 passengers between United States and Mediterranean ports last year and for the ninth straight year was the second largest North Atlantic passenger steamship carrier. Cunard Line is the largest.

While college students have been capturing the headlines with "new radicalism," the nation's campuses report a wave of interest in the study of religion. In the current issue of The Journal of Higher Education, Robert Michaelsen, chairman of the Department of Religious Studies at the University of California in Santa Barbara, calls the trend "a quiet revolution."
CHICAGO, April 30-Richard Korn of New York, newly elected president of the American Council for Judaism, Inc., took office today with a reiteration of the council's views.
Paula Strasberg, the drama coach, died Friday of a heart attack in Beth Israel Hospital. She was 55 years old and lived at 135 Central Park West.

WITH the inevitability of Niagara, the natural force known as Picasso works on-- and the cataract of books about him continues. The latest is PICASSO: The Artist sad His Model, and Other Recent Works (Harry N. Abrams, $30). With a text by the French writer, Helene Parmelin, the book presents is 118 full-color plates a body of Picasso work since 1962 ha series of artist-and-model ...
NATIVE wildlife will decorate the reverses of next year's Canadian Confederation centennial commemorative coins. This was announced recently by Canada's Ministry of Finance.

Business is suffering from a case of the jitters brought on by talks of increased taxes or, worse yet, direct control of prices and wages. Nervousness is heightened by the tact than an uninterrupted expansion has been going on each month for the last five years, a phenomenon in an economy conditioned for ups and downs rather than a continuing upward climb.

THE Trenton Kennel Club show, favorably situated, supported by many breed specialties and riding the high popularity that bench competition is experiencing almost everywhere has reached an entry peak. The event will be next Sunday on the grounds of the Trenton Artillery Armory ...

Tahitian Gardens, a 500-unit condominium apartment development under way in Tarpon Springs on the weest coast of Florida, has been granted the state's homestead tax-exemption. This is the first of Florida's many new condominiums to have such an advantage.

JOHN SINGLETON COPLEY was not only America's best Colonial painter but, with Thomas Eakins, the best portrait painter this country has produced and one of the best that any country has produced. This new and altogether admirable treatise devotes one volume to Copley's career in America and a second to his career in England, where he turned himself into a proficient painter of history pictures while anglicizing his manner in portraits.
OTTAWA, April 30 (Canadian Press)--French investment in Canada is growing slowly and outpaces Canadian investment in France, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics has reported.
The Bal International on May 19 in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom will benefit the National Association for Retarded Children.
PITTSBURGH, April 30-- In an avowed attempt to manipulate the television, ratings back in New York, the Pittsburgh Pirates scheduled today's game with the New York Mets for 3:35 P.M.
Families or individuals who like to rough it may buy remote land for fishing, hunting or camping retreats from the Department of the Interior.

TOKYO, April 30--Apparently through Japan's efforts, the forthcoming conference of Asia and Pacific nations in South Korea has been converted from a prospective anti-Communist forum into a vehicle for noncontroversial regional cooperation programs.
A group of Reform rabbis and layman listened to a Protestant "Death of God" theologian last week and came away wondering whether he was really radical.
'"O Save Us, overcrowded conditions, outraged alumni and Yale inefficiency. O Save Us from the giggling crowds, the domestic lecture and he home economics classes of a female infiltration."

PARIS, April 30--Secretary General Thant of the United Nations lunched with President de Gaulle today and said afterward that neither he nor the general saw a possibility of new peace moves for the time being to end the war in Vietnam.
Mayor Lindsay has rented a summer home in Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., it was learned yesterday. It is a large Colonial mansion overlooking Long Island Sound.
DARLINGTON, S. C., April 30 (UPI)--Richard Petty, the favorite, won the Rebel 400 late-model stock-car race today with the fastest average speed ever recorded here.

CAPE KFINNEDY, Fla., April 30 (UPI)--The space agency said today that the Centaur rocket had solved the problems of liquid hydrogen fuel on April 7, although it failed to reignite in orbit as planned.

Two of the finest fighters in the world--one U.S., and one of Soviet design--clashed in the skies above North Vietnam last week in a war that has become, in limited scope, a proving ground of new military technology.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 30--Miss Lucinda Ann Paddock and Henry Shields Day plan to be married on July 9.
Miss Karlyn Herrhammer, daughter of Earl A. Herrhammer and Mrs. Josephine Herrhammer, both of New York, was married yesterday to William James Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Smith of Hartford.

HAROLD ARLEN is well established in the top echelon of our popular composers as a peer of Gershwin, Kern, Rodgers, Porter and Berlin. But even in this celebrated company, Arlen has several unique distinctions.

AIR CANADA put its new twin-jet DC-9's into service on the New York-Montreal run last Sunday, and the next day into Montreal-Winnipeg-Vancouver service. Through rain, fog, heavy cloud overcast and, at 26,000 feet, bright sunshine, the sleek, 72-passenger, 555-mile-an-hour plane made the flight between New York and Montreal in 40 to 45 minutes.

ST. VINCENT, Italy--It is perhaps just as well that the North American team was able to take part in a serious contract bridge championship in London before starting play in the world title matches here last week.

JAMAICA, Vt.--This oncequiet Vermont town, which in winter serves as the gateway to the skiing activities at Stratton Mountain, takes on a festival air each May, when whitewater canoe and kayak championships are held on the nearby West River.

WALNUT, Calif., April 30 (AP)--Jim Grelle, normally a miler, won the 5,000-meter run, beating George Young in a blazing finish today at the Mount Antonio Relays. Both were timed in 14 minutes 10.8 seconds.

Miss Mary Lu Keill was married yesterday to Glenn I. Swartz in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by Rev. Bryant M. Kirkland. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Keill of Lincoln, Neb. Mr. Swartz is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Luther F. Swartz of New Philadelphia, Ohio.

KINGSTON, R.I., April 30-- A wedding on July 9 is planned here by Miss Mary Martha Walsh and Charles Edward Duross 2d. Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Walsh have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil B. Duross of New York.
Forty years ago in Vilna, Lithuania, the Yivo Institute for Jewish Research was established to record everything that could be learned about the Yiddish-speaking Jews of East Europe.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 30 --The engagement of Miss Linda Austin Reuter to Lieut. Jock Playman Patterson. U.S. A.F., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Reuter, Lieutenant Patterson is the son of Col. James T. Patterson, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Patterson of Maxwell Air Force Base in Montgomery, Ala.

AFTER the completion of 12 rounds in the recent 15-round international round robin at Mar del Plata, Argentina, the only American entry in this chess tournament, Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., was bogged down in a tie for seventh and eighth places with Raul Sanguinetti of Argentina.

By the time they're through they'll know how "alligatoring" can point to a "torch," how to talk to a "pyro," how to use a hydrocarbon detector, how the Fire Department works how the Fire Department works, and all the other information necessary to make a first-class fire marshal.

JUST what is this George Abbott trying to do, make a monkey out of time? At 79 (in June) shouldn't he be dozing in a rocking chair on a hotel porch in some sleepy little town designed for senior citizens? Sure, he should, but he isn't. He's beating up golf balls in the mornings, wearing out dancing slippers at night and in between trying to corner the laugh market for next season.

LONDON, April 30--A modern expedition in search of "Vinland" will be looking for bays, headlands and sandy beaches described in Norse sagas, including an awe-inspiring stretch of sand dunes called "wonderstrand."

The Chicago Bulls, the new team in the National Basketball Association, began stocking its roster yesterday by selecting 10 players--two from each of the five Eastern Division clubs in the league. The key selections, according to the Bulls' president, Dick Klein, are Nate Bowman, a center from the Cincinnati Royals; John Thompson, a forward from the Boston Celtics; Jerry Sloan, a forward-guard from the Baltimore Bullets, and Gerry Ward, a guard from the Philadelphia 76ers.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 30--Gov. George C. Wallace's foes are joining with his friends in predicting that his wife will come in first Tuesday in the Democratic governorsnip primary in Alabama.
LONDON, Apri1 30 (Reuters) --Cheered on by its wildly excited supporters, the Liverpool soccer team made certain of the English League championship today, beating Chelsea by 2-1.

BOSTON, April 30--Gov. John A. Volpe, a Republican who has yet to say whether he will run again, finds himself embroiled with politicians of both parties over the conduct of his Commissioner of Administration.
ATHENS, April 30--Greece and Turkey resumed friendly diplomatic contacts this weekend after nearly 10 months of mutual coolness.
Junius L. Powell, a partner in the insurance underwriting firm of Chubb Son until he retired in 1959, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 200 East 66th Street. He was 75 years old.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), April 30--The recent announcement of the appointment of an Israeli, Dr. Nachman Bench, to a consultative post in the New York City government has created a swirl of resentment in his native country.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)--President Johnson told 10 award-winning Federal career employer today that "I don't believe there is a higher cause than Government service."
DETROIT, April 30--The General Motors Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had moved to correct mechanical shortcomings on thousands of its 1964 Cadillac and 1966 Oldsmobile Toronado models.

STRATFORD-ON-HOUSATONIC, Conn., April 30--The yachtsman who wants to combine culture with sailing will find both Shakespeare and the sea, here, according to the associate producer of the American Shakespeare Festival.
NEWARK, April 30--A woman was fatally burned and about 200 person were driven from their homes this morning in six fires here.

HOLLYWOOD DANNY KAYE, attired in a burgundy velour sport shirt, slacks and a yellow baseball cap, strolled cheerfully into the Los Angeles Press Club last week, a press agent at each elbow. The comedian had returned from a two-and-onehalf-week tour of Vietnam the night before and now, as other entertainers had done before him, Kaye was prepared to volunteer his opinions of the war.

TODAY is May Day and the 1965-66 television season has about had it. In fact, one seems to recall there was earlier confirmation of this somewhere. Of 32 new shows on the networks last fall, 18 will not be back next season. Some already went thataway. vesting in TV program pro duction is no less speculative than the stock market.

AACHEN, Germany--Once the site of Charlemagne's imperial headquarters, this ancient spa is now a convenient departure point for international sightseeing. Within a few hours, visitors can sample, and compare, the way of life and customs of people in three countries.
The first major surfing meet of the Eastern season is scheduled for May 14 at the Southampton (L.I.) Town Beach, west of Shinnecock Inlet.
The Eastern Cruiser Association will stage 15 predicted-log contests this season instead of 13, as originally planned.

Senator J.W. Fulbright, in a speech before the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association: America is showing some signs of that fatal presumption, that overextension of power and mission, which brought ruin to ancient Athens, to Napoleonic France and to Nazi Germany. The process has hardly begun, but the war which we are now fighting can only accelerate it.
Materials, methods and mechanical monsters are making May a miserable month for reluctant mariners.
The Beatles were some 3,300 miles away and three months and 23 days from New York City, but their screaming fans, mostly young girls, raised pandemonium here yesterday.
A program to offer "healthful, out-of-door jobs" as agricultural laborers to city youths was announced yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va.--It is now 40 years since the late John D. Rockefeller Jr. set out to restore a drowsy Virginia town to its former 18th-century glory. Time has flowed swiftly for the "new" Williamsburg, and the Rockefeller experiment has matured into a historical showplace exerting a far-reaching influence in fields as diverse as archeology and gardening.

WHEN comedian Godfrey Cambridge comes onstage he fre quently trots up to the microphone and panting, tells the audience: "I hope you noticed how I rushed up here. No more shuffle after the Revolution. We gotta be agile."

Miss Margaret Mary McInerney daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrio D. McInerney of the Bronx, was married there yesterday to John Hugh Judge, son of Mrs. John A. Judge of Rockaway Beach, Queens, and the late Mr. Judge.

The Metropolitan Washington Committee for Project Hope will give its annual Hope Ball on May 23 at the Shoreham in Washington. Mrs. Andrew J. Somerville Jr. is chairman of the ball, and Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson is honorary chairman.

FOZ DO IGUACU, Brazil--The fantastic Iguacu cataracts prove that a waterfall is much more than a lot oaf water falling over a cliff. Iguacu Falls is a world of water falling over a world of cliffs. And, most important, it exists in the special atmosphere of a lush green tropical setting, far from big cities. Here hydroelectric plants are but a dream for the future.
MIAMI, April 30--The Cuban Government has conceded that there are strains in its economic relations with the Soviet bloc.
ROME, April 30--henry Cabot Lodge, Ambassador to South Vietnam, arrived today from Saigon for a private audience with Pope Paul VI. They are scheduled to meet Monday morning.
WASHINGTON, April 30 --The United States has established an Antarctic research base, 600 miles from the South Pole.
A man who began his career at 13 as an auto dealer's errand boy in the Bronx was elected president of the Greater New York, Long Island and Westchester Automobile Dealers Association last night.

JUST when I was convinced that New York City was the champion sink of corruption, along comes Nathaniel Benchley with a little muckraker on the insular peninsular of Hawley, a Down East Sodom that makes up in intensity what it lacks in size. Funny sewer contracts, poison-pen stuff, premeditated vandalism, latent McCarthyism, and even (gulp!) murder--little Hawley has samples of everything you can find in the larger centers of urban population.
The Administration in Washington is expected to make up its mind this week on the contention issue of passenger liability for international airlines.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 30--A modest departmentstore expansion and two parking-terrace construction programs are being viewed by the local financial community this week as the initial fruits of a controversial Convention Center construction project and proof of the viability of the downtown district in Utah's capitol city.

WASHINGTON, April 30--As the Vietminh closed the ring around the French army at Dienbienphu in 1954, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles called in bipartisan Congressional leaders to discuss the question of sending American aircraft to aid the French.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday he would hold public hearings at City Hall on May 12 and 13 to obtain additional information on the proposed World Trade Center that would be useful to the city in its negotiations with the Port of New York Authority.

SWITZERLAND'S tradition of ironclad banking secrecy has attracted funds from all over the world. It also has generated a vast amount of rumor. The mystery surrounding numbered accounts and the anonymity that cloaks the "gnomes of Zurich" have given rise to exaggerated and intriguing speculation about the amount of funds stashed away in Switzerland and about the astuteness, power and unscrupulousness of her bankers.

TOKYO, April 29--Nearly 100 million citizens of Japan, a nation that is becoming nearly as celebrated for hard playing as it has long been for hard work, began today the extraordinary annual festival called Golden Week.
MOSCOW, April 30--A vexatious problem caller the "41st hour" is giving Soviet economic officials headaches in their efforts to get the country on a five-day work week.

AT a luncheon press conference preceding the Chicago Automobile Show last February, Donald N. Frey, general manager for Ford Motor Company's Ford division in Dearborn, paused after a brief speech to answer questions. "When are you going to beat Chevrolet?" asked one reporter bluntly.

LONDON--Westerham is a pleasant Old World town some 20 miles southeast of London, but its historic quiet will soon be rudely broken by crowds of visitors. They will be coming to visit Chartwell, Sir Winston Churchill's home, which will be opened to the public this summer, possibly in early June.

WESTON, Conn., April 30-- The Norfield Congregational Church was the scene here this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Ann Florence Phelps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin James Phelps, to John Allen Depoy. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lawrence Depoy of Lyndon, Ohio.

There is one advantage to a cool, cloudy and damp spring --the flowers last longer. Just last week a magnificent star magnolia was getting around to opening its petals. In other springs the blooms had usually faded by the middle of the month.
The city's Department of Commerce and Industrial Development has created a "onestop" shopping center for new industrial sites in an effort to halt the exodus of industries from the five boroughs.
WARSAW, April 30 (UPI)-- The Polish Government has refused to permit American diplomats to attend church millennium services at Czestochowa Tuesday, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, April 30-- This is a great country for worriers, grumblers and protesters. No great nation in history ever had so little to worry, grumble and protest about at home, or did so much of all three. It is hard on the nerves, but probably good for the soul.

EAST CANAAN, Conn., April 30--The marriage of Miss Nancy Ann Svehla., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Paul Svehla, of Canaan Valley, to Robinson Drysdale Wright, son of John Aubrey Wright Jr. of Montclair, N.J., and the late Mrs. Wright, took place here today.

The publication of Dave Heath's "Dialogue With Solitude" (New York: Horizon Press, $6.50) after many delays comes almost as an anticlimax. This is because so much of it has been exhibited and reproduced from time to time.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 30 --Mr. and Mrs. Dallas S. Townsend Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Dallas Townsend, to Paul Herbert Hamlin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamlin of Hillsdale.

BLOOMING GROVE, Pa., April 30--Miss Joanne Cook Johnson was married here at noon today to Lieut. Robert Francis Rogel, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Rogel of Pittsburgh. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Eads Johnson Jr. of New Canaan, Conn.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)--Twenty-four close friends and relatives were announced tonight as attendants for the church wedding of President Johnson's younger daughter, Luci, 18 years old, and Patrick J. Nugent, 22, of Waukegan, Ill., on Aug. 6.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30-- White Plains High School, which passed up the first New York Relays to go after Penn Relays gold medals, won eight of them in the space of 15 minutes today.

STANTON, Del., April 30-- Ch. Mooremaides Maestro, a wire fox terrier owned by Mrs. Jane Esther Henderson of Stockton, N. J., topped a field of 1,097 today to gain best-inshow honors at the 25th annual Wilmington Kennel Club show.

NEWTOWN Conn., April 30 --Mr. and Mrs. Louis Tucker have announced the engagement of Mrs. Tucker's daughter, Miss Irene G. Buckley, to F. Wallace Knudsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Knud Ole Knudsen of Brooklyn.
The Brooklyn Dodgers will return to New York this fall as a franchise in the 10-team Continental Football League, a spokesman for the league announced yesterday.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., April 30--The American Jewish Congress today called on the Administration "to suspend indefinitely" the bombing of North Vietnam as a means of moving the war from the battlefield to the negotiating table.

ROCHESTER, April 30-- Mr. and Mrs. Sol Myron Linowitz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Linowitz, to Kenneth A. Mozersky. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Myer Mozersky of Winnipeg Man.
PHILADELPHIA, April 30-- The Philadelphia Museum of Art this summer will recreate a New York City apartment in which to display the extensive art collection of the late Louis E. Stern.

COLUMBUS, Ohio April 30 --About 1,310,000 Ohioans are expected to vote Tuesday to nominate party candidates for state offices, county offices and 24 Congressional seats.

The golf fan, once the forgotten man among sports spectators, is assuming a place of importance. Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus acknowledge his presence. Before and after a round they stop and give him an autograph. The tournament sponsor considers his comfort and safety and soon he may be in for a bit of pampering.

ITHACA, N. Y., April 30-- Cornell's lightweight crew won its third straight Geiger Cup against Columbia and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 30--The Second Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Melinda Sue Hill of Chicago, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Le Roy Hill of Prairie Village, Kan., to Donald I. Ball Jr., also of Chicago. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Donald I. Ball of Scarsdale, N.Y.

PAST and present meet in Camilla Bittle's "A Sunday World," a novel about the new South. With sympathy tempered by gentle irony, Mrs. Bittle tells a dramatic tale of Southern culture in turbulent transition, where a world of antique silver, voile dresses, colonnaded mansions, and devoted servants is traded for split-Level houses, pizza shops on rushing highways, day help and civil rights demonstrations.

JACKSON, Miss., April 30-- Six candidates in the Democratic Congressional primary set for June have asked the Federal courts to halt the election on the ground that a state law requires them to endorse segration and condemn the 1964 Civil Rights Act.

OMAHA, April 30--Mr. and Mrs. Fred D. Brodkey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Alice Brodkey, to Dr. Gordon Tavss Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Moore of Pittsburgh.

ANDOVER, Mass., April 30-- Mr. and Mrs. Harold Heifetz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Ann Heifetz, to Lyndel Joe Wishcamper. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Joe Henry Wishcamper of Fort Worth.

WASHINGTON, April 30-- Defense Department sources said today that West Germany, as it gains more knowledge about nuclear weapons systems, would eventually agree that the Western allies must not depend exclusively on a nuclear defense.

The Community Service Society of New York will benefit from guided tours of 13 apartments at 870 United Nations Plaza on May 24. Those taking the tour will visit apartments in the East Tower of the new building, situated between 48th and 49th Streets, and facing the gardens of the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, April 30--President Johnson's old guard at the White House this week was reduced to a one-man band--Bill D. Moyers.
RECIFE, Brazil, April 28--A massive literacy program is under way to teach a million adults to read and write in the poverty-stricken cities of Brazil's Northeast region.

Orient-by-the-Sea Marina on Gardiner's Bay in Orient Point, L.I., will be expanded this season, according to Albert E. Wolfe, its new owner.

Two Yale University doctors announced yesterday the successful use in primates of a birth control pill that can be taken up to six days after sexual relations.

H. Myron Lewis, who retired last June as chairman of the State Board of Standards and Appeals, died on Friday in his home at 145 East 84th Street. He was 71 years old.

IN 1841 at the Paris Opera a ballet called "Giselle" was given its first per formance. In the 115 years since that premiere it has been danced all over the world, countless times. RICHARD John Forbush is an exuberant young ornithologist who spends five months in isolation on an Antarctic cape observing a rookery full of penguins, over a thousand strong, who breed and rear their young against overwhelming odds. PARIS--French authorities are splitting hairs these days over a distinction between the un shaven clochards and the longhaired young men who are generically known as les beatniks. TORONTO, April 30 (Canadian Press)--The Rochester goaltender, Bob Perreault, blanked the Cleveland Barons as the Americans scored a 4-0 triumph in the opening game of the four-of-seven American Hockey League's, Calder Cup final series before 3,323 fans tonight.
