His case illustrates the problems the board faces in trying to end racial discrimination against one million Commonwealth immigrants.

OULTON PARK, England, April 30 (AP)--Dennis Hulme of New Zealand, driving a Lola 70 Chevrolet, won both legs of the Royal Automobile Club's Tourist Trophy Classic today for his second straight victory in the 386-mile race.
BABYLON, L.I., April 30-- Above-ground swimming pools in back yards--whether portable or permanent--are under strict regulation here.
Back on April 19, when the Cleveland Indians had played (and won) only four games, a visitor tried a variation of a standard sports sarcasm on Birdie Tebbetts, the Cleveland manager.
MILWAUKEE, April 30 (AP) --Warren Spahn, the leading left-handed winner in baseball history, said tonight he was considering an offer to pitch in the Texas League.

More than 400 guests are expected to attend "A Gambol on the Green," a dinner dance on May 9 for the benefit of the Legal Aid Society. Sponsored by the event will be held at the Tavern on the Green in Central Park, where dining will take place at outdoor tables, weather permitting.
ATHENS, April 30 (Reuters) --Athens' Hellenikon Airport has drawn so much air traffic that the original plans have had to be revised.
Loyalty Day parades were held in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday in support of Americans fighting in Vietnam.

MONTPELIER, Vt., April 30 --Mrs. Walter Gustav Nelson Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Nelson of Boston, to John Dennett Master, also of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Master of Washington.

Among the contributions that the late Felix Quaver made to the world of music, surely his discovery of Gino Vermicelli's "Suite for the Royal Fireworks" must rank as the most significant. It was during the last of his many trips to Spain, in June 1964, that Professor Quaver ran across a manuscript of the Suite, the only work of Vermicelli's known to have survived and certainly his masterpiece.

THE phone rang the the other day, and it was Abe Savage at the other end. Savage is an official of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians. "You won't believe this," said he, "but some wreckers broke the cornerstone of the building that used to belong to Local 310, and a bunch of old material fell out. Want to come up and take a look?"

WASHINGTON, April 30--A house subcommittee on Government Operations will consider next Wednesday a resolution to halt President Johnson's plan to put the new Federal Water Pollution Control Administration in the Department of the Interior.
BOSTON--The office walls are dead white, splashed with the vivid colors of project maps pinned to the cork surface.
CHICAGO, April 30--Dismay, confusion and often bitterness toward the Supreme Court for its series of decisions curbing police practices pervaded a twoday national conference that ended here today.

The theft of boating and fishing equipment is a constant hazard. And, often as not, the owner sometimes has only himself to blame.

DURHAM, N. C., April 30 (AP)--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that if the nation should adopt "the appeasement line of Senator William Fulbright in Vietnam we will be in World War III within four to five years."

Things have been looking up for the nation's railroads After years of chronic invalidism accompanied by frequent predictions of their imminent demise, they have been enjoying an unaccustomed spurt of rising profits.

AMHERST, Mass., April 30-- Amherst College will begin construction this fall on a 57-million science center with 140,000 square feet of floor space, Calvin H. Plimpton president of the school, said this week.

In a world captivated by "image," the image of the New York Mets these days is being projected most often by Ronald Alan Swoboda. Statistically, the "image" is 21 years old, has a 16 -inch neck, swings a 34-ounce baseball bat, once earned a "D" in a speech course in college--and is now one of the most sought-after public speakers in New York.
HARRIMAN, N. Y. April 30 --"Why are state legislatures in trouble?"
ADEN, April 30--"How do you like Aden?" a British banker casually asked an American visitor.

TORONTO, April 24--It was her second whisky sour, and the woman in the blue-flowered hat suggested to her companion: "The only reason some people come is to get a drink." It was a half-hour after the annual meeting of the Abitibi Paper Company, a major Canadian newsprint producer.

Congress was told last week that the Federal Government should not pay a construction differential subsidy for American merchant ships at a rate in excess of 55 per cent. A recent shipbuilding contract indicates a cost differential between domestic and foreign shipbuilding costs exceeding that figure.

The year was 1908 and the scene was Times Square on Lincoln's Birthday. A quarter of a million people jammed the area to see the start of what they believed impossible: An auto race to Paris by way of Chicago, Seattle, Japan (to be reached by steamer), across Siberia and on to the European continent and Paris. The New York Times was one of the sponsors.
A man tentatively identified as a Cuban national was found slain on a Bronx sidewalk last night.

Frederic S. Berman, Commis sioner of the City Rent and Rehabilitation Administration, announced over the weekend that the agency would not permit rent increases by landlords for most of the housing improvements ordered under the Legislature's 1965 amendments to the Multiple Dwelling Law.

WORTHINGTON, Minn., May 1 (UPI) A New Jersey parachutist failed today in his third attempt to break the world's free-fall record when equipment trouble forced him to make an emergency descent from a giant balloon at an altitude of 57,000 feet, He was seriously injured.
DETROIT, May 1 (AP) The league-leading Baltimore Orioles ran their winning streak to 10 today, riding Boog Powell's two-run homer and a tworun single by Brooks Robinson to a 4-1 victory over Detroit.

After wrestling with well-publicized doubts for several months Senator Javits has decided not to run for Governor. His reasons will touch off new political debate. No one knows, of course, whether he could have won a contest with Governor Rockefeller at next fall's nominating convention. But it seems certain that, whatever the outcome, neither winner nor loser would have escaped undamaged from the intraparty bitterness engendered by a fight to the finish.

"Seize the Day," written by Saul Bellow, author of the best seller "Herzog," will reach Broadway in the fall with the HB Playwrights Foundation as producer. It will be the first Broadway entry of the nonprofit group, formed in 1964, to test scripts in the Off Broadway area.

The Greater New York Fund is the largest network of local hospital, health and welfare agencies in the world. It provides every person who either lives or works in New York the chance to contribute at one time, at his place of business, to these agencies. The fund does not conduct house-to-house or neighborhood campaigns. It does, however, seek contributions from New York business and its employe groups.

The popular singing duo, Simon and Garfunkel, gave a concert in the McMillin Theater at Columbia University yesterday afternoon. The program, the pair's first major appearance in New York, displayed how strongly the two young men are speaking to, and perhaps for their student audiences.

SYRACUSE, Sicily, May 1 (Reuters) John Surtees of Britain won the Syracuse motor racing grand prix today in a new Formula I, 3-liter Ferrari.

The Irving Trust Company plans to build a statewide bank holding company system under the aegis of the Charter New York Corporation, the holding company it proposes to form with the Merchants National Bank and Trust Company of Syracuse.

MOSCOW, May 1 The massive missile carriers rumbling across the cobblestones of Red Square today were reflection of the changes in nearly half a century of Communist rule. Equally pointed was the contrast in the personalities of the lead ing Soviet Communists themselves, ...
More than 200 cyclists zipped freely like a string of disjointed roller coasters up and down the hills of Central Park yesterday morning.

Robert Livingston Clarkson Jr., president and director of Smith, Kirkpatrick Co., investment bankers of 110 Wall Street, died yesterday of a heart attack in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived at 1125 Fifth Avenue.
A broken-down but amiable carriage horse named Sunshine led 60 cyclists, politicians and other assorted humans in an antiautomobile demonstration in Central Park yesterday.
EASTON, Pa., May 1 Mr. and Mrs. John M. Coleman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Waite Coleman, to John Philip Mamana, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mamana.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 1 Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indonesia and Foreign Minister Narciso Ramos of the Philippines declared today that there was "a sound basis" for cooperation between their two countries and Malaysia.
PARIS, May 1 The Americanization of European industry stops when it comes to Government regulation of private companies.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 1 Bongo Drum, an aged brown gelding who came off the race track back in Nashua's day, won both the regular working hunter and amateur-owner hunter divisions at the 22d edition of the Rice Farm's Horse Show today. The event was held at Melody Farms.

BONN, May 1 West Germany will send a polite but firm reply to a French memorandum that asserted that French troops in West Germany would be withdrawn from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization command by July 1.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 1 The Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools has renewed the academic accreditation of the United States Naval Academy but a Navy spokesman said today that the association would require annual reports from the academy on a number of administrative reforms.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Dr. Michael E. DeBakey said today that artificial hearts capable of assuming the functions of human hearts could be available in three to five years.
KIRKBY, England, May 1 (UPI) Prime Minister Wilson appealed today to labor and industry to abandon "industrial conservatism" and help the Government modernize Britain's economy.
The drive to help India solve her critical food problem by means of a massive increase in fertilizer production facilities may receive a fresh impetus shortly.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 1 A sign on the outskirts of this drab Hudson River city proclaims, "Birthplace of the Republic, founded 1709."

The International Basic Economy Corporation (IBEC) reported yesterday net income for 1965 of $2,723,007, compared with a 1964 net of $1,527,301. Earnings per share of common stock were 71 cents in 1965, compared with 35 cents for 1964.

Hart Schaffner Marx, an apparel manufacturer and retailer, announced over the weekend the appointment of Mel Meyerson as merchandise manager of men's furnishings and sportswear for Wallachs, one of its retail outlets.

Three factory workers from Paterson, N.J., arrived yesterday at 7 A.M. at the Newsweek Building at 444 Madison Avenue, waited patiently for nearly two hours and were the first to cast absentee ballots here in Colombia's presidential election.
SAIGON, May 1 The increasing infiltration of North Vietnamese into South Vietnam, which United States military officials say has amounted to more than 20,000 troops

James E. Salvador, products manager of the Chef Boy-Ar-Dee and Dennison's divisions of American Home Food, Inc., New York, died Saturday of a heart attack while playing golf in Elmsford, N.Y. He was 48 years old and lived at 23 Primrose Avenue West, White Plains.

Lloyd M. Trafford, who retired in 1951 as a vice president of the Charles T. Wilson Company. Inc., New York, importers of spices and crude rubber, died Saturday night in Manhasset (L.I.) General Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 178 Latham Road, Mineola. L.I.
There's always hope, trainers of Kentucky Derby eligibles like to say, and Graustark's untimely injury ironically underscores this philosophy.
The Maritime Subsidy Board last week came out with a proposal to ease the current maritime manpower shortage by allowing ship's personnel to receive cash allowances in lieu of vacations.
BONN, May 1 The body of Prince Friedrich of Prussia was taken from the Rhine River near the city of Bingen today.

Spring is the traditional home-buying season, and families fortunate enough to find houses that suit their needs and desires will have to decide next on the types of insurance they will need as homeowners.
MOSCOW. May 1 Marshal Rodion Y. Malinovsky, Soviet Defense Minister, said today that United States troops in South Vietnam "were using the most cruel and barbaric means of annihilating people."
BROOKLYN'S most famous dragons have a new coat of gilt, the elegant, nineteentwenties mannequins are posing in the windows and the white marble Cleopatra has returned to her pedestal.
ANNISTON, Ala., May 1 Of the seven Negroes running for sheriff this year in Alabama, the Rev. Thomas E. Gilmore of Greene County has the best chance, mathematically, of winning.

David Carradine, who has a principal role in "The Royal Hunt of the Sun" on Broadway, will play the title role in "Shane," a television Western series based on the 1953 motion picture. It will begin Sept. 17 on the American Broadcasting Company network.
Some students at the Waterford School never go home on vacation--they would face arrest if they did.
Nachman Meisel, editor of the monthly magazine Yiddishe Kulter, 189 Second Avenue, from 1938 until 1964, died on Wednesday in Israel, where he had lived for the last two years. His age was 79.
A report issued yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union said the United States might be entering a period of repression.
A militant Puerto Rican community leader, Gilberto Gerena Valentin, has been named to the staff of the city's Commission on Human Rights.
Spain, which gained the challenge round for the first time last year, advanced to the second round of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis eliminations yesterday with a 4-1 victory over Yugoslavia.

GALVESTON, Tex., May 1 (AP)--Thousands of youths streamed back onto Galveston beaches today under the watchful eye of state, county and city officers guarding against a recurrence of yesterday's violence.
WASHINGTON, May 1 Four military officers have challenged Defense Department orders keeping them in uniform when they wish to resign or retire.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Col. Jack R. Metzdorf, a member of the Army Council of Review Board at the Pentagon, died yesterday of Leukemia at Walter Reed General Hospital. He was 46 years old.

A maritime liability limitation law enacted more than 100 years ago to protect the fledgling shipping industry from catastrophe has long been outmoded and should be revised or removed from the statute books, according to an admiralty law group.

ST. VINCENT, Italy, May 1 At the half-way stage in the world championship here, an eighth successive world title for the great Italian Blue team seems inevitable. It leads in all its matches by substantial margins: 74 against North America, 66 against Holland, 104 against Venezuela and 202 against Thailand.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 1 Former Mau Mau fighters, brought to a mass rally here today by President Jomo Kenyatta, said Oginga Odinga had offered to pay them to start a campaign of guerrilla warfare against the Government.

CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP) The White Motor Corporation reported at its annual shareholders meeting here that firstquarter sales and earnings were at record levels and the backlog of unfilled orders on April 1 also was at a peak.

DEAL, N.J., May 1 Miss Patricia Ann Denby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Michael Denby, was married today to Joel I. Rosenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Rosenberg of Bradley Beach. Rabbi Aaron A. Lefkowitz performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

Jon Vickers, a barrel-chested man with the easy stride and affable manner or a winning football coach, sang a couple of recitals in Philharmonic Hall Yesterday afternoon. Theoretically, it was just one recital, but with a sleight of programing he made the first and second halves of his New York recital debut so different that the event became a double-header.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota, said today the Senate ethics committee was prepared to judge Senator Thomas J. Dodd's dealings with a public relations man, but lacked precedent in dealing with the Connecticut Democrat's handling of political contributions.

FELTONVILLE, Pa., May 1 An Old English sheepdog, Ch. Fezziwig Raggedy Andy, owned and bred by Mr. and Mrs. Hendrik Van Rensselaer of Basking Ridge, N.J., was judged best in show today in a field of 1,061 at the 23d annual Penn Ridge Kennel Club event.

An official of the National Jewish Welfare Board urged yesterday that executives of major Jewish organizations meet to cope with what he described as a lack of understanding of Jewish life and Judaism by "most American Jews."

WASHINGTON, May 1 Highly qualified persons here insist that a shortage of bomb parts that came to light in South Vietnam last month was not the cause of a decline in the intensity and number of air attacks against the Vietcong.
Senator Jacob K. Javits formally bowed out of the 1966 race for Governor yesterday. At the same time he sought to strengthen his own chances for a place on the Republican national ticket in 1968.
WARSAW, May 1 Wladyslaw Gomulka, Polish Communist leader, departed from the emphasis of his recent speeches today by not pursuing a violent propaganda campaign against the Roman Catholic Church.

George Inselman of 1 Fifth Avenue, who retired two years ago as president of the Marine Office of America, New York, an underwriters group for several insurance companies, died Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 66 years old.

The 61st season of free Naumburg Orchestra concerts on the Mall in Central Park will begin on Memorial Day with a program conducted by Richard Burgin. The soloist will be McHenry Boatwright, bass-baritone.
ALBION, N.Y., May 1 (AP) Charles W. Howard, the "dean of Santa Clauses," is dead.
SHREVEPORT, La., May 1 (AP) Mickey Wright of Dallas won the second annual $9,500 Shreveport Kiwanis Club invitation golf tournament today with a 54-hole total of 217.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., May 1 A group of 80 students of state government called today for reform of legislatures to give them "maximum effectiveness in the changing Federal system."

TEL AVIV, May 1 Dr. Israel Beer, once a leading Israeli military analyst, died today in Shatta Prison where he was serving a 15-year sentence for espionage on behalf of a Communist power. His age was 54.

TEL AVIV, May 1 Dr. Israel Beer, once a leading Israeli military analyst, died today in Shatta Prison where he was serving a 15-year sentence for espionage on behalf of a Communist power. His age was 54.

Mao Tse-tong's absence from yesterday's Peking May Day celebration deepens the mystery surrounding his whereabouts and his health. Since he has not been seen publicly for almost half a year, many analysts speculate he may be dead or gravely ill, despite the official assertion last March that he is in good health.
CAIRO, May 1 President Gamal Abdel Nasser threatened tonight to invade and occupy parts of Saudi Arabia in the event of "any aggression or infiltration" into Yemen from Saudi territory.

GROSSINGER, N.Y. May 1 Rabbi Arthur J. Lelyveld of Cleveland was elected president of the American Jewish Congress today, at the closing session of the national biennial convention of the organization.

The City University's new master plan, with its proposal to offer by 1975 some further form of education to all New York high-school graduates, may sound utopian by present local yardsticks and by the prospect of imminent forced retreat from past achievements. Yet it merely reflects the approach to higher education that has already begun to be implemented in California.

Efforts to resolve the strike against the World Journal Tribune, Inc., will resume today when representatives of the New York Newspaper Guild and Typographical Union No. 6 hold new bargaining talks with the publishers.
The Cenco Instruments Corporation announced over the weekend the election as a director of Homer N. Chapin, executive vice president of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., May 1 A crewcut young man was selling buttons proclaiming "Liberate Cuba," "Win in Vietnam" and "Get the U.S. Out of the UN" at Civic Auditorium here this weekend and his sales were brisk.

Breaking with a centuries-old tradition, this country's bestknown Presbyterian leader insists that the eventual unity of American Protestantism can be achieved only when the separated bodies accept bishops as an integral part of the united church.

DETROIT, May 1 In a punishing game that saw the attackers worn down more than the attacked, the Montreal Canadiens scored the big victory they needed today and evened the Stanley Cup finals by edging the Detroit Red Wings, 2-1.

YONKERS, May 1--A normal run between Peekskill and Yonkers takes the New York Central Railroad 41 minutes with a stop at Harmon. A careful motorist can drive the distance in less than an hour. Today it took Ted Corbitt almost four hours and he didn't stop for one red light.

The shape and dimensions of the tax program to be imposed on the city are beginning to emerge from the political shadows. Out of the controversy and the confusion attendant on the effort to restore the city's fiscal stability, it now appears that about $100-million will be cut out of Mayor Lindsay's ...
HONG KONG, May 1 Peking celebrated May Day today with Mao Tse-tung's name conspicuously absent from the list of leaders reported to have made public appearances.
A demonstration that had been called yesterday to protest plans for a playground in Riverside Park wound up as a celebration instead.
WASHINGTON, May 1 The story of a troubled, uncertain and often divided Federal Open Market Committee during 1965 was disclosed today in the annual report of the Federal Reserve Board.

BOSTON, May 1 (AP) Hyman Hurwitz, a sports writer for The Boston Globe and the secretary-treasurer of the Baseball Writers Association of America, died today in Massachusetts General Hospital. His age was 56. He had been in the hospital since suffering a heart attack April 11.
New York State is gathering data to prove that at least some of the state's air pollution problem comes from New Jersey, particularly in the Bayonne area, Governor Rockefeller said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 1 The Federal Reserve Board renewed today, in urgent terms, its longstanding requests for statutory changes that would outlaw the payment of checks at less than par by the 1,500 small banks that still deduct an exchange charge.

There was a massive "And then I wrote ..." session last night at Philharmonic Hall. Billed as "A Salute to ASCAP," it might have been more accurate to call it a presentation of what has made the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers possible.

BOSTON, May 1 (AP) -- Jerry Stephenson became the first Boston pitcher to hurl a complete game this season, checking the California Angels on nine hits as the Red Sox won, 9-1, today and gained a split of their doubleheader.
PALM BEACH, Fla., May 1 (AP) Mrs. Mary Buchanan Sweatt, the wife of Harold W. Sweatt, a former chairman and president of Honeywell, Inc., died today in a hospital at the age of 74.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 1 The "Wayne and Howard" show is beginning to spice up Oregon's Democratic Senatorial primary campaign.
AALSMEER, the Netherlands Postwar prosperity in Western Europe has brought the prewar bloom back to the Dutch flower business. But with more cut flowers and potted plants coming to market every...

LONDON In men's fashions, what was Carnaby Street Mod and became Fad, is now Gear or de rigueur long the rainswept streets of London this spring. All over the fashionable London West End, the dashing English male is sporting shaped suits topped off with a ...

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 1 Victor L. Butterfield, president of Wesleyan University, and Mrs. Butterfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margot Butterfield, to Sherman Gilbert Cochran. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman George Cochran of Portland, Ore.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 (AP) Gaylord Perry of the San Francisco Giants limited the St. Louis Cardinals to four singles today as the Giants triumphed, 2-0, on an unearned run and a homer by Len Gabrielson.
Carnegie Hall, which will be 75 years old Thursday, will undergo a major refurbishing this summer. It will close in about three weeks and will reopen for the new season Sept. 8.

Charles A. Blackwell, a limited partner in the stock brokerage firm of Bache Co., died on Friday in Community Hospital at Glen Cove, L.I. He was 70 years old, and lived at 417 Park Avenue, New York, and at Valley Farms, Walpole, N.H.

PAUL ROBEY won the Marshall Chess Club champion ship recently by defeating Walter Browne in a playoff match after they had tied at 6 -2 in the regular club round-robin. Originally scheduled for two games, the match ended abruptly when Browne failed to appear for the second game and forfeited it. Thus, Robey scored 2-0 and won the title.

BECAUSE of his bristling pugnacity and a personality that often became abrasive, Red Auerbach would have won no popularity contests throughout the National Basketball Association except in Boston. They loved him there. Coaching genius that he is, the redhead had skillfully manipulated the Celtics to seven straight championships and there is no surer way of solidifying a hold on the affections of a populace.

SAIGON, May 1 -- Two more American planes have been shot down over North Vietnam, bringing to 225 the number of aircraft lost there since regular bombing began on Feb. 7, 1965, a United States military spokesman announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 1-- The Commander in Chief gave a group of wounded veterans of the war in Vietnam a personal tour of the White House today.

SAIGON, May 1 A hundred yards from the United States Embassy today, Vietnamese boys and men, apparently Communist agitators, scrawled "Americans Go Home" and "Stop the War of Race Extermination in Vietnam" on the pavement.

Mayor Lindsay grounded out. Mrs. Lindsay grounded out. But their team, the Lindsay Lancers, went on to a 10to-9 victory yesterday afternoon in a Central Park softball game against a team of newsmen called the Power Brokers.
A Harvard University bacteriologist believes he has proved that cigarettes can cause many lung and throat ailments, such as chronic bronchitis.

Although New York City's position is still uncertain, New York State and New Jersey will strongly reaffirm today their support for construction of a $525-million World Trade Center on Manhattan's lower West Side.

Michael Rubin, a 16-year-old pianist and a junior in Brooklyn's Abraham Lincoln High School, won the WQXR Young Artists Competition Saturday night. As the best pianist in New York City's public high schools, he won $750 (presented by Elliott M. Sanger, chairman of the board of WQXR), a solo recital on the station on Thursday and a solo appearance with the American Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall next season.
EVEN birthday cakes for youngsters go through "style" changes.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 1 (AP) Harold Henning, a South African who is not even listed in the Professional Golfers' Association player catalogue, won the rain-dampened $80,000 Texas open golf tournament by three strokes today.

Joseph Cole, a singer who made his New York debut in 1948 as a baritone and switched to tenor for a recital in 1955, appeared as a tenor in Town Hall last night. To fine accompaniments by Harold Wheeler he sang arias by Purcell and Weber and songs by Schubert, Griffes and Lora Aborn. The program ended with the singer's own "Suite of Spirituals on Departure and Expectation."

CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP) Sam McDowell pitched his second straight one-hitter today, allowing only a pop-fly double by Don Buford in the second inning as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Chicago White Sox, 1-0.

YONKERS, May 2 The Class A-3 one-mile, race that headed tonight's card at Yonkers Raceway, had a field of seven undistinguished pacers, but developed into a nervetingler with four horses winding up in a blanket finish.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 2 Iran's gift was warmly welcomed today in the United Nations Social Commission.

In a relay race, according to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's track and field guide, the last runner "must carry it [the baton] across the finish line." Villanova, however, won the two-mile relay at the Penn Relays Saturday without a baton, and the result will stand.

Brazil completed a 5-0 sweep of Denmark yesterday in the first round of the European Zone Davis cup tennis competition. The winners, led by Tomas Koch and Jose Edison Mandarino will meet Spain in the second round, United Press International reported.
LYDDA, Israel, May 2 Dr. Konrad Adenauer arrived in Israel tonight for an eight-day private visit. He was met by Israeli officials and political figures and by several dozen chanting demonstrators.
The United Federation of College Teachers criticized the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools yesterday for continuing its accreditation of St. John's University.

WASHINGTON. May 2 (AP) Social Security Commissioner Robert M. Ball predicted today that Medicare payments would provide a significant increase in revenues of nearly all hospitals participating in the program.
BALTIMORE, May 2 (AP) Moontrip and Twice As Gay Won the two divisions of the $23,100 Riggs Handicap today as Pimlico race course opened its 17-day spring meeting.
ALGIERS. May 2 Hocine Ait-Ahmed, the Berber Opposition leader, was reported today to have escaped from Maison Carree prison Saturday night.

The administration of St. John's University is celebrating a Pyrrhic victory in hailing the decision by the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools to continue the embattled institution's accreditation.
BUENOS AIRES, May 2 President Arturo U. Illia opened Argentina's 97th regular session of Congress yesterday with a stinging attack on domestic and foreign critics of his administration.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 (UPI) Swift currents and rising waters of the Ohio River forced cancellation yesterday of the paddlewheel race between the Belle of Louisville and the Delta Queen.
Valery Tarsis, anti-Communist Russian writer who was exiled earlier this year by the Soviet Government, arrived here yesterday for a lecture tour with a tale of discontent and unrest in his homeland.
CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I. May 2 "No, the police don't bother us much," the Negro boy said "They just do a little chasing."

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) The Commerce Department today asked exporters of cattle hides, calf and kip skins and bovine leathers to report the volume of their unshipped export commitments as of March 7. That was the date the department imposed export quotas on the hides and skins to insure a sufficient domestic supply.
MANCHESTER, England, May 2 (AP) Thad Spencer of Los Angeles pounded out a 10-round decision tonight over the former British heavyweight champion, Brian London.
ALBANY, May 2 Governor Rockefeller proposed today an air-pollution-control program, described by a state spokesman has "the most far-reaching legislation" of its kind in the nation.

The Citizens Committee for Children charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's $4.6-billion budget for 1966-67 had been presented in such confusing fashion that "magicians and Einsteins are needed to understand it."

John J. Powers Jr., president and chief executive officer of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., told a packed annual meeting yesterday at the Commodore Hotel that the company expected to "maintain a high level of activity throughout the year."
BONN, May 2 Sales of Volkswagenwerk, Western Europe's biggest automobile manufacturer, climbed by 13.1 per cent to $2.3-billion in 1965, the company disclosed in its annual report issued today.
James Jolly, pianist, who played at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, has a big, warm tone and a grand approach to his instrument.
WASHINGTON, May 2 The Supreme Court agreed today to review a group of cases testing the legality of a Utah state law on branch-banking and potentially similar restrictions of other states.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP) The Philadelphia 76ers discharged Dolph Schayes today even though he led the club to the National Basketball Association's Eastern title and was named N.B.A. coach of the year.
NEWARK, May 2 (AP) A South Plainfield real estate broker has won a court decision that may have a farreaching effect on realty boards' closed-multiple-listing services in New Jersey.
Sales in New York City department stores in April were even with the level of April, 1965.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) President Johnson denied today that his favorite girl friend had jilted him. He said reporters had misquoted her.

One man died and four others were rescued yesterday after a 78-foot tug, the Turecamo Boys, capsized near Coney Island. A small disabled tanker that the tug was towing veered off course and the tow line rolled the tug over. It sank in 15 feet of water.

Jay Gallagher of Xavier High School, seeded first, and Ed Mullin of Loyola, No. 2, led the field into the quarter-finals of the 51st annual Athletic Association of Private Schools tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
The London stock market maintained a firm tone yesterday, but trading was quiet in anticipation of the presentation of the national budget today.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., May 2 The Nassau-Suffo k Regional Planning Board recommended today immediate public acquisition of the former Republic Airfield in Farmingdale for use as a general aviation airport.

An investigation was under way yesterday into the throwing of a bomb into a basement window of the three-story building at 23 West 26th Street, which houses the national offices of the Communist party and the publication quarters of The Worker, a weekly newspaper.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 Dr. John M. Marshall, an author of scientific papers and a professor of anatomy at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, was killed Friday in an automobile accident in Uganda. He was 46 years old.
Haryou-Act has requested $6million for special programs for the central Harlem area this summer.

Jacklyn Schneider, a mezzosoprano from Pottstown, Pa., has been named winner of the eighth annual Town Hall recital award. Miss Schneider was chosen from 60 singers who participated in the 1965-66 "Joy in Singing" lecture-recital series, held annually at Town Hall under the direction of Winifred Cecil.
DETROIT, May 2 (AP) Directors of the American Motors Corporation voted today to omit a quarterly dividend payment, marking the third consecutive quarter in which they have done so.
WASHINGTON, May 2 A new level of contentiousness marked the Federal Aviation Agency's hearings today into the safety of jet air lanes as hearings resumed following a nine-day recess.
WASHINGTON, May 2 Draft registrants who are going to miss the Selective Service System college qualification test will have a second chance to take it.

Bernice Fisher, a founder and first national secretary of the Congress of Racial Equality, died at Beth Israel Hospital yesterday after a brief illness. She was 49 years old and lived at 34 Monroe Place, Brooklyn.
Alphonse A. Corona, a retired petroleum executive, died yesterday at Mercy Hospital in Rickville Centre, L.I. He was 69 years old and lived at 113 Buckingham Road, West Hempstead, L.I.
Profits of the average American corporation are about onethird higher this year than they were a year ago.
DALLAS, May 2 The Consultation on Church Union opened its fifth annual meeting here today amid a general feeling that the movement toward church union had reached a showdown stage.
PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., May 2 (UPI)--Doug Sanders continued to hold his lead today in the Professional Golfers' Association money-winning race with $51,950 in official money through the Texas open.
CHESTER, England, May 2--Ian Brady said in a resigned voice today that he expected to be convicted in the Pennine Moors murder trial here.
"The Fantasticks," which opened May 3, 1960, will reach its 2,506th performance tonight and thereby enter its seventh year at the 153-seat Sullivan Street Playhouse at 181 Sullivan Street.

WASHINGTON, May 2 The Supreme Court today denied rehearings to Ralph Ginzburg and Edward Mishkin and dashed eleventh-hour efforts by the two New York publishers to escape jail on obscenity convictions.

AN excellent study of Pablo Picasso, the artist and the man, will be repeated at 8:30 this evening over Channel 13. The chief virtue of the presentation is the availability of enough time for the introduction of exhaustive detail on each stage of the Spanish artist's career; the whole is an analysis of scholarly incisiveness all too rare on TV.

More material was added to the controversy over the wartime role of Pope Pius XII yesterday when Look magazine published excerpts from "Pope Pius XII and the Third Reich." a study by Saul Friedlander, a historian.

Pan American Airways said last night that it had canceled many flights scheduled for this summer between the United States and Europe so it could use the aircraft for military flights to South Vietnam.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 2 Harry M. Raphaelian, president of the carpet and Oriental rug company bearing his name at 1071 First Avenue, and author of books about carpets, died Saturday in his home at 2384 Palmer Avenue. He was 84 years old.
Universal Pictures has completed filming three two-hour motion pictures that will be televised next season by the National Broadcasting Company and then distributed in theaters.

Dallas sold two bonds issues yesterday totaling $19-million. The best bid for $10.6-million of street, transit system and city hall improvement bonds was submitted by a First National City Bank group, which bid 100,004 for coupons of 5, 4 7/8 3.55, 3.60 and one-tenth of 1 per cent. The resulting average annual interest cost was 3,615.

Broadway and Off Broadway gave mixed notices yesterday to the omission of a Pulitzer Prize for drama for the ninth time since the award was established in 1917, Comments ranged from "I agree" to "I'm thunderstruck."
Glore Forgan, Wm. R. Staats, Inc., and associates offered yesterday 497,200 shares of the common stock of Koret of California, Inc., at $24.75 a share.

CAIRO, May 2 Raymond A. Hare, Assistant Secretary of State, met with President Gamal Abdel Nasser today to discuss the deadlock over Yemen, presumably including Mr. Nasser's threat last night to invade Saudi Arabia if provoked.
AT the Metropolitan Opera House last night, the Bol- shoi Ballet offered a cast change in "The Rite of Spring" when Natalia Taborko replaced one of the co-chorepgraphers, Natalia Kasatkina.

Supporters of the World Trade Center said at public hearings yesterday that the proposed project would revitalize New York's port and provide thousands of jobs, but opponents said it would only depress the real estate and hotel markets here.

ALBANY, May 2 Mayor Lindsay has bowed to Democratic demands and removed all mayoral veto powers from his transportation unity plan for New York City. Neverthe- less, there were increasing signs today that the plan was facing serious trouble in both the City Council and the Legislature.
PARIS, May 2 The Shah of Iran announced today a gift of $700,000, which he said was the equivalent of one day's military budget, to the worldwide war against illiteracy.
WASHINGTON, May 2 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz clashed today with a corporate official over the performance of the National Labor Relations Board.
Mayor Lindsay has held a closed meeting in Greenwich Village with poets, writers and coffeehouse and cabaret owners to convince them he is not a "crack-down, clean-up" Mayor.

STRASBOURG, France, May 2 (AP). Secretary General Thant of the United Nations told European foreign ministers today he saw little or no chance for a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war at this time.
The Hess Oil and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that its offer to purchase 1,243,824 shares of the Amerada Petroleum Corporation from the British Government had been accepted.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday as late selling erased many early gains.

TRENTON, May 2--The New Jersey Legislature, occupied for the last three months with a controversial broad-based tax, moved on to other matters today, approving three measures in Gov. Richard J. Hughes's legislative program.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., May 2 The advertising agencies' annual exercise in self-examination and self-justification ended here today with everyone red in the face but it was only from the burning sun.
Sulphuric acid, which is a component in thousands of products, is moving steadily up in price.
ALBANY, May 2 The Republican State Committee moved today to close ranks behind Governor Rockefeller's third-term campaign.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 2 (AP) United, States troops will be rotated out of Dominican service next month and will be replaced by other units, a United States military spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, May 2 Budget-cutting forgotten for the moment, the House swiftly approved today a bill authorizing nearly $3-billion in college construction aid in the next three years.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 2 The marriage of Miss Lynn Taylor Affelder to Ens. William Swope Slease, U.S.N., took place here this evening in the Reformed Church. The Rev. Dr. Charles Copenhaver performed the ceremony.
The third annual Aspen Award, a $30,000 prize, has been won by Constantinos Doxiadis, a Greek city planner who calls his concept of total community development "ekistics."
The National League instructed its lawyers yesterday to carry its appeal of an adverse Milwaukee County court ruling against the Atlanta Braves up to the United States Supreme Court if necessary.
The Israeli Government made a final payment of $31,320,685 yesterday on the first Israeli bond issue floated in this country.

LEWISBURG, Pa., May 2 (UPI) Irving Scarbeck, a former State Department official paroled from Federal prison here today, said that although he had been convicted of passing classified information to Polish agents he was not a spy.

WASHINGTON, May 2 The theory that man is governed by biological clocks can only accelerate the unhappy trend toward medical interpretation of the news. In sports this trend has already reached the point where you can hardly tell what the score is any more without resort to surgical and orthopedic encyclopedias.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 2 Three years ago, Carlos Lleras Restrepo became a candidate for Colombia's Presidency. A year ago, he withdrew from the race. Last November, he re-entered it, and now he has won it.

ST. DAVIDS, Pa., May 2 Mr. and Mrs. Stanford R. Hanks have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Meredyth Ann Hanks, to John Patrick Davidson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs, Davidson of Chatham, N.J. The wedding is planned for June 26 at the Episcopal Church of St. Martin's in Radnor.
TOKYO, May 2 (Reuters) Japan's exports during the fiscal year ended March 31 exceeded her imports for the first time since the end of World War II, the Finance Ministry announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 2 President Johnson today announced his intention to nominate Walter P. McConaughy as Ambassador to Taiwan.

CLEVELAND, May 2 More than 1,000 stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation were assured by management today that domestic producers could supply the country's growing steel needs and that the steel industry planned to "do a great deal more" to restrain imports.

Mayor Lindsay summoned leaders of the 10 newspaper unions yesterday to meet with him at City Hall today to explore all possible ways to settle the eight-day strike against the merged World Journal Tribune, Inc.

THE kind of antiques show that dealers always talk about but seldom put together opens today for a twoweek run at The Lighthouse, 111 East 59th Street. It was assembled by 56 dealers of the Art and Antiques Dealers League of America, which is celebrating its 40th birthday, and includes loans from 26 collectors and five museums.
Net income of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company for the quarter ended March 31 rose to $30,026,127, or $3.32 a share, from $29,288,072, or $3.23 a share, in the corresponding period of 1965.

WASHINGTON, May 2 Manufacturers' sales, new orders and inventories all registered strong advances in March, with practically every industry participating in the gain, the Commerce Department reported today.
Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced the creation of a civilian-controlled board last night to examine complaints against policemen.
For the third time in four years, no American drama was given an award as the annual Pulitzer Prizes were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) Richard J. Gray, former president of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., died last night in Georgetown Hospital after lung surgery. He was 79 years old and a resident of the national capital.

BIRDIE TEBBETTS, the noblest Redman since Sitting Bull, will lead his marauding Indians into the Stadium today to lay ambush to the Yankees, palest faced of all the palefaces. The Indians rarely lose these days and the Yankees rarely win, a situation that causes Johnny Keane, the Custer of the home forces, to keep clutching at his scalp to make certain it still is in place.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., May 2 The girls of Mount Holyoke packed up their evening clothes this morning, put on their sandals and trudged to classes, weary after a whirlwind weekend that began with a musical spoof and ended with the clip-clop of horses' hooves.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., May 2 A $5-million gift to set up 25 professorships at the University of North Carolina, was presented here today by officials of the William R. Kenan Jr. Charitable Trust of New York.

Reflecting a sharp rise in sales, Combustion Engineering, Inc., reported yesterday firstquarter net income of $3,301,000, equal to 98 cents a share. This compares with $1.9-million, or 61 cents a share, a year ago. Net sales rose to $108,378,000 from $67,017,000.
Mrs. Harry Golden of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Wendy Lynn Golden, to Michael Vincent McGill. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. R. Bruce McGill of Wayland, Mass.

MOORESTOWN, N.J., May 2 M. Albert Linton, former board chairman of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia and a director of the Curtis Publishing Company, died of a heart attack tonight in his home. His age was 79.
Episcopal clergyman from the New York diocese were warned yesterday that extreme right wing activity threatened to produce a "financial and structural crisis" in their church.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 2 The third annual Kansas City jazz festival, held over the weekend, presented 22 local combinations and bands some supported by guest soloists and the Duke Ellington Band. About 8,500 people attended.
The election of Archie B. Albright to the board of the Ruberoid Company has been announced.

PARIS, May 2 Miss Josalee Douglas, daughter of Mrs. Helen Campbell Douglas of Cannes and of James Douglas of Phoenix, Ariz., was married today to Count Jean-Francois de Chambrun. He is the son of the Marquis de Chambrun of Paris and Marvejols and of Mrs. Hugot Gratry de Chambrun.

WASHINGTON, May 2 Members of the "watchdog" subcommittees that provide Congressional monitoring of the Central Intelligence Agency rejected today the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's request that some of its members be included.
The American General Insurance Company announced here yesterday the purchase for cash from the C.I.T. Financial Corporation of all the capital shares of the Patriot Life Lnsurance Company.

Jackie Robinson added another title yesterday to his current list of banker, insurance executive, baseball commentator, civil rights leader and political figure. He became the general manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers of the Continental Football League. The Continental is a minor league that wants to be major.
The stock market made a feeble attempt at a rally yesterday morning. The effort failed and prices dipped in slow trading, reaching their lowest levels of the day near the close.

WASHINGTON, May 2 A high State Department official expressed doubt today that it would be possible to comply with the desire of the Dominican Republic's provisional Government to have all foreign troops out of the country by July 1.

The state has suspended the licenses of two Long Island real estate brokers in violation of fair-housing laws. The brokers are Simon Goldstein of QueVille Realty, Inc., 211-19 Jamica Avenue, Queens Village, Queens, and Mrs. Dora Pariser, whose real estate office is at 129 West Olive Street, Long Beach, L.I.

Undeterred by bitter opposition inside and outside the Police Department, Mayor Lindsay has taken a constructive step in establishing a Civilian Complaint Review Board to pass upon charges of police brutality. This courageous fulfillment of a pledge originally made during his election campaign deserves the sympathetic support and cooperation of all citizens and of the police force.
BRUSSELS, May 2 The tempo of economic activity in the European Common Market "will probably be maintained or even stepped up in coming months," the trade bloc'a Executive Commission said today.
HUNTERS and fishermen in the United States paid $138-million, a record, for hunting and fishing licenses during 1965. The number of sportsmen increased to another high mark, a total of 34,827,066.
International cooperation in a United States drive to raise the safety standards of foreign-flag cruise ships operating out of American ports was predicted here yesterday by W. Averell Harriman.
Hill Knowlton, Inc., public relations counselors, announced today the election of four senior management officials.

IT is easier to list the qualities in Julio Cortazar's new novel that will put off the reader than it is to analyze the virtues that will hold him. The book is long and tightly written; it is low on narrative strength (though not in story-telling elements). It is full of puns, humorous alliterations, portmanteau words, extracts from magazines, newspapers, books, often arranged in the manner of Dos Passos' camera eye.

WASHINGTON, May 2 The White House was asked today to intercede in the case of Eerik Heine, an Estonian emigre who is suing an agent of the Central Intelligence Agency for slander for calling him "a dispatched Soviet intelligence operative."
Short-term interest rates continued to rise yesterday, while long-term Government bond prices declined and corporate bonds held steady, both on light volume.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 2 Steve Richman walked with the bases loaded in the 11th inning to force in the run that gave Columbia University a 4-3 victory over Rutgers in baseball today. It was the Lions' fourth triumph in a row.

Edward N. Snow, mechanical engineer and president and a director since 1950 of Liverpool Industries, Inc., 162 57th Street, Brooklyn, died Sunday in Maimonides Hospital after suffering a stroke at his home, 717 Ave nue R. Brooklyn. He was 50 years old.

The New York Legislature moves into its final weeks with important work still to do. The courage shown last week in passage of divorce-law reform inspires the hope that it will show equal courage on other issues demanding independence.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 3 The news made the front page of The Times of London today. If that was not enough to rock the hallowed traditions of a newspaper founded in the reign of George III, it offered a gossip column and a political cartoon, too.
Copper futures continued their uptrend yesterday, making it a second day of advance following a recent sharp decline.

A five-man mediation panel appointed by Vice President Humphrey met with representatives of the feuding Amateur Athletic Union and National Collegiate Athletic Association for seven hours yesterday at the New York Hilton and then adjourned until this morning.
A number of changes in its senior executives was announced here yesterday by Marsh McLennan, Inc., international insurance brokers.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 2 Scientists here are studying the results of simulated excursions over a mock lunar landscape by men "flying" in a cockpit attached to a bank of computers.
SELMA, Ala., May 2 A year ago, Sheriff James G. Clark Jr. had little patience with the Negroes demonstrating for the right to vote. He simply locked them up.

WASHINGTON, May 2 A group of university professors, lawyers and leaders of private foundations and associations has issued a report saying the administration of Federal civil rights laws is inadequate in many respects.
A proposal to permit the average New Yorker to buy taxexempt city bonds was made yesterday by Bertram L. Podell, Democratic Assemblyman from Brooklyn.

The latest annual report of the Federal Reserve Board calls for the elimination of a number of outdated banking practices. It makes a persuasive case for getting rid of two that are particularly anachronistic.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 2 (UPI ) The New York Mets lost a five-inning no-hitter to their Jacksonville farm team of the International League, 2-0, tonight.
SCARBOROUGH, England, May 2 (Reuters) The 45-foot yacht Griffin, with a six-man British crew, set sail from here today for North America over the Viking route shown in the controversial Vinland Map.

BONN, May 2 (UPI)--"Sing Out '66," a Moral Re-Armament musical play performed by 150 American youths, opened a four-week tour of Germany today by singing some of the show's tunes for Chancellor Ludwig Erhard.
ROME, May 2 (Reuters) Students today forced the resignation of Prof. Ugo Papi, rector of Rome University and target of a violent week-long campaign centering on his alleged Fascist past.
WASHINGTON, May 2 The Administration told business today that profits might be getting too high for the health of the economy.
Sunasco, Inc., made its debut as a merged company on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday morning, but at 11:23 A.M. the Big Board halted trading in both the common and preferred stocks.
Two British journalists who hope to set the United States to England trans-Atlantic rowing record, arrived here yesterday aboard the liner United States.
WHITE PLAINS, May 2 The Westchester County Board of Supervisors revised its proposed reapportionment system today to make the plan effective next Jan. 1 instead of a year later.

ALBANY, May 2 The New York State Thruway Authority today banned the drinking of alcoholic beverages or the possession of an open bottle anywhere on the 559-mile superhighway. Previously, only the sale of alcoholic beverages was prohibited.
The Ford Foundation yesterday appropriated $19-million to support international studies and, at the same time, called attention to critical gaps in such scholarship.
DETROIT, May 2 (AP) The United States automobile industry set its sights today on production of 853,000 cars this month, which would make it the biggest May output on record.

CHICAGO, May 2 This city's Building Department has summoned Claude M. Lightfoot, the top Communist party leader in Illinois, to answer charges of 14 building code violations at a hearing this Friday, it was disclosed today:

MIAMI, May 2 (AP) The father of Daniel Goldman, clinging desperately to a hope that his son still lives, said today that a man who may have been his kidnapper had gotten in touch with a rabbi in New York.

Gustav Leonhardt, a major artist in the ever-growing ranks of harpsichordists who give recitals, made his New York debut last night in the final recital of the 1965-66 Harpsichord Series in the Hunter College Playhouse.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) A Republican member of the House said today he was appalled that the Urban Renewal Administration had given the fashionable Washington suburb of Chevy Chase, Md., $80,000 to help build tennis courts.

Walter W. Heller, father of the "new economics" of the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, called yesterday for a temporary, across-the-board increase of $5-billion, or 6 per cent, in both individual and corporate income taxes.

The Lindsay administration expects to complete within a month a re-evaluation of the urban renewal program that had been instituted by Mayor Robert F. Wagner. Thirty neighborhoods proposed for aid by the Wagner administration are restlessly awaiting the outcome.
WASHINGTON, May 2 The United States announced today another in a series of "technical" drawings from the International Monetary Fund.

CZESTOCHOWA, Poland, May 2 Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski was tumultuously welcomed today to the most sacred shrine of this Roman Catholic nation as the personal representative of the Pope, whom the Polish Government refused to admit.
ROME, May 2 Henry Cabot Lodge, United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, was received today in private audience by Pope Paul VI.
The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, defeated the challenger, his compatriot Boris Spassky, in the 10th game of their title match at Moscow's Variety Theater last night.
DETROIT, May 2 The Chrysler Corporation acknowledged today that is was examining 182,000 of its 1966 models after reports of a production defect that could cause the cars to go out of control.
Commissioner William D. Eckert ratified a $12.6-million contract with the National Broadcasting Company yesterday for the television rights to the 1967 and 1968 All-Star and World Series games.

JACKSON, Miss., May 2 Mississippi's prohibition law of 1908 received another legal buffeting today when a Circuit Court judge upheld a lower court opinion that the state has voided its "dry" law by systematically taxing and regulating illegal liquor.

AN impressive congress of eminent Americans, in cluding Boob McNutt, Barney Google, Terry, Batman, Superman, Dick Tracy and Peanuts, has been assembled on the ninth floor of the World Press Center, 54 West 40th Street, where it may be visited today and tomorrow between 11 A.M. and 9 P.M.
JAKARTA, Indonesa, May 2 The powerful Action Command of Indonesian Students demanded today limitations one President Sukarno's authority.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson joined today in helping the Department of Agriculture promote a new shade three the Bradford pear tree they hope will be planted by cities across the country.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 2 The council of the multiracial University College has called for an urgent overhaul of administrative and disciplinary machinery following recent disturbances on the campus.
WASHINGTON, May 2 The Treasury bill rate rose noticeably this week, but did not attain the peaks reached earlier this year, the treasury disclosed tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, May 2 (AP) MRS. John Rathmell of Houston shot a two-under-par 71 to day and led the 32 qualifiers for the women's Southern amateur golf tournament. Match play begins tomorrow.
Governor Rockefeller was urged last night to give the "nod" that would get legislation to expand the City University out of committee and before the State Senate for action.

The Swedish American Line's new passenger ship Kungsholm arrived here yesterday for the first time. She came in with a bang. A 340-year-old bronze 24-pounder, recovered from the Swedish man-of-war Vasa, which sank in Stockholm harbor on her... maiden voyage 338 years ago, roared four times from its emplacement in Battery Park.

Joseph Solari, executive vice president of the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation, producer of petroleum coke and similar products, died Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in the Biltmore Hotel. The company's New York office is at 18 East 48th Street.
WASHINGTON, May 2 Yugoslavia has explored the possibility of joining the 48nation global communications satellite system. It is the first Communist nation to do so.
SAIGON, May 2 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky signed a decree last weekend setting up a committee to draft an election law, government sources said today.

That a little-known candidate backed by the former dictator, Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, should poll nearly 30 per cent of the vote in Colombia's Presidential election is disturbing but not altogether surprising. Eight years of Liberal-Conservative coalition government have made hardly a dent in Colombia's appalling economic and social problems.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 More than 70,000 persons will die in traffic accidents in 1975 unless a coordinated highway safety program is developed to reduce sharply the death-toll, an insurance executive said here tonight.

John Stuart Dudley, a leading real-estate lawyer here for many years and a theater enthusiast who wrote plays and acted minor roles in movies, died Sunday in Wilmington, N.C., after a short illness. He was 72 years old and lived at Masonboro Sound, N.C.
Police Commissioner Howard Leary and I join together this evening in announcing the creation of a new civilian review board for New York City.
The Association of Middle Income Housing has appointed Murray Kubit as director of housing.

For the first time, this year the Greater New York Fund's blue and orange flags will f1y along a oneway Fifth Avenue that boasts some of the finest business buildings in the world. The appearance of the... Fund's familiar flag means that the 28th campaign for its 425 hospital, health and welfare agencies has begun.

WASHINGTON, May 2 Robert S. McNamara, Secretary of Defense, said today that the United States would probably send more troops to South Vietnam to counter increasing infiltration of forces from North Vietnam.

Senator Jacob K. Javits agreed yesterday, at the request of Governor Rockefeller, to head the list of 15 Republican candidates for delegates at large to the 1967 convention that will rewrite the State Constitution.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) The Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, said today the fair housing section of President Johnson's new civil rights bill was "absolutely unconstitutional."
SAIGON, May 2 The question of the hour in Saigon is whether South Vietnam's national elections will take place as scheduled this fall.

WASHINGTON, May 2 Officials confirmed here today that the United States does not intend to seek renewal of agreements giving United States citizens special rights to invest in Philippine public utilities and extractive industries, once these agreements expire in 1974.

WASHINGTON, May 2 The severity, not to mention the vituperation, of some of the comment, including several in cartoon form, on Senator Fulbright's recent questionings of United States foreign policy strongly indicates that these critics have not read the documents through.
The General Motors Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 85 cents and a special dividend of 50 cents on its common stock for the second quarter.

SOUTH TAHOE CITY, Calif., May 2 Several years of governmental and citizen efforts to stop the incipient pollution of Lake Tahoe, a national beauty spot and one of the world's clearest bodies of water, are gaining impetus in the face of some still-formidable problems.

ROME, May 2 (AP) Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., and Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy scored easy victories today in the first round of the Italian tennis championship, first of the three big tournaments on the European circuit.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 2 A United States team of five sailors from Long Island Sound's Manhasset Bay Yacht Club won its first race today against a Bermuda team despite the disqualification of one boat at the first mark.

ST. VINCENT, Italy, May 2 Most of the 29 players in the world championship which began here last Tuesday have been playing an average of 40 deals a day, or rather more than five hours of maximum concentration. The Thailand team has been hard-pressed, because it has had only four players, with occasional help from its captain as a playing fifth.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 2 Jordan complained to the Security Council today that Israel had made an "unprovoked vicious attack" on two farm villages.

A private investor filed a suit in Federal Court here yesterday, charging the two major "odd-lot" dealers on the New York Stock Exchange with "conspiracy" and "restraint of trade." The complaint alleges that the two concerns Carlisle Jacquelin and DeCoppet Doremus have violated the Sherman Antitrust Act by "monopolizing" odd-lot trading on the Big Board and charging "excessive" fees.
Henry Kastor Kahn, chairman of Kastor, Foote, Hilton Atherton, Inc., New York advertising agency, died of a heart attack early yesterday in his home at 166 East 63d Street. He was 63 years old.

JOAO BELO, Mozambique, April 30 A "war of liberation" sputters fitfully in the Niassa bush hundreds of miles to the north. Black Africa aims its hostile oratory at Portuguese "colonialism" here and in Angola. The town of Joao Belo plods on, progressing by inches but, as the Governor says, "it is progress just the same."

Vincent D. McDonnell, the chairman of the State Mediation Board, conferred yesterday with representatives of the Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee in an effort to head off a threatened strike by 18,000 fleet taxi drivers.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2--Braulio Baeza, who lost his ride in the Kentucky Derby yesterday, got back into the race today without breaking stride.

WASHINGTON, May 2 The Supreme Court joined this afternoon with leading members of the Supreme Court bar to memorialize Associate Justice Sherman Minton, the Indiana farm boy who became the Court's 87th Justice.
JOEL SCHUMACHER, 24year-old fashion designer, has been appointed to a newly created executive post at Revlon, according to Warren Leslie, director of fashion relations.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 2 (Reuters) Thirty Kenyan Members of Parliament, outspoken or halfhearted opponents of President Jomo Kenyatta's policies, automatically lost their seats today when the President abruptly ended the current session of Parliament six months ahead of schedule.
SAIGON, May 2 United States Navy jets smashed a surface-to-air missile site 34 miles north-northwest of the North Vietnamese port of Vinh yesterday with bombs and Bullpup missiles.

MADRID, May 2 Seven United States students, including a blind youth and a granddaughter of former Secretary of State Christian A. Herter, were severely clubbed by Spanish policemen today during an affray at the University of Madrid.
A 6-foot, 140-pound jockey rode a winner at Aqueduct yesterday and nobody from the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals called for an investigation.

GENEVA, May 2 An Oil painting of the countryside near Falaise, Normandy, called "In The Winter," by Claude Monet,' chief of the French impressionists, was sold at auction here today for 191,000 francs (about $44.500).
Five composers have been named by the National Institute of Arts and Letters to receive a total of $11,500 in this year's grants in music.

Walter Malowan, noted bridge player and the only surviving founder of the Regency Bridge Club at 15 East 67th Street, died last evening of pneumonia at the Medical Arts Center Hospital, 57 West 57th Street.

The charity fashion show may be one of the oldest fundraising devices, but, oh, how it has changed. Gone is the mannequin with the good family name and nervous knees pressed into modeling before her female peers who consumed creamed chicken while watching a parade of innocuous clothes chosen to pique their buying interest.
The spot rate on the British pound eased in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The rate closed at $2,7937, down 1 from its level of last Friday.

MANILA, May 2 President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines said today a presidential committee was studying the question of abrogating a parity agreement with the United States before the pact's expiration date in 1974.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 110.5 on Friday from 111 on Thursday.
The election of Charles W. Buek as president of the board of trustees of the Young Men's Christian Association of the United States for a year that began Sunday was announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. James Butler of Locust Valley, L.I., and Edgartown, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Butler's daughter, Miss Merrill Scott MacLeod, to Eugene Lytton Scott. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lytton Scott of New York, St. James, L.I., and Lyford Cay in the Bahamas.
The shortest season of the International Ice Patrol, conducted annually by the United States Coast Guard since 1914, has come to an ed.
WASHINGTON, May 3--A special assistant to the President warned today that the world could run short of frequencies for satellite communications by 1970.
VUNGTAU, Vietnam, Wednesday, May 4 (AP)--The Australian troop transport Sydney arrived today with the first contingent of a new ...
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3-- Exhibitionist served notice that he was to be considered a strong candidate for Saturday's Kentucky Derby by winning the Derby Trial today.
A report combining sharp criticism of the city's personnel policies with major recommendations for their improvement was received yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
CANTERBURY, England, May 3 (AP)--The Rev. Alan Campbell Don, who was Dean of Westminster from 1946 to 1959, died today. He was 81 years old.
The spot rate on the British pound was unchanged yesterday at $2.7937 in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 3 --Dr. Adam Malik, Indonesia's Foreign Minister, said tonight that he had agreed that Indonesia would take steps to end her policy of confrontation against Malaysia.

ALBANY, May 3--A group of Democratic Senators denounced the State Commission for Human Rights today as in effective and partisan, but the Senate easily overrode their objections and approved a bill to enlarge the commission from seven to nine members.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 110.6 on Monday from 110.5 on Friday.
BERLIN, May 3--The East German Communists today postponed for at least two months technical discussions with West Germany's Social Democrats on an exchange of visits between party leaders.

George Norris, a former lawyer and libel expert for The New York Times, died yesterday in Hingham, Mass., after a long illness. He had been visiting his daughter there. His age was 81 and his home was at 24 Donnellan Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.
TORONTO, May 3--A royal commission investigating the collapse of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Ltd., held hearings today at the bedside of its former president, C.
MILWAUKEE, May 3--The director of the Milwaukee Art Center today banned "Happenings" from happening at the center.

WHITE PLAINS, May 3 (AP)--Herschel Jacobs of White Plains and Jimmy DuPree of New York signed yesterday for a 10-round fight in the White Plains Community Center on May 14. In two previous meetings between the light-heavyweights, DuPree scored a decision and they fought to a draw.
The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that special shows it was working on for next season included television adaptations of plays by Tennessee Williams and Arthur Miller.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the world's largest rubber producer, achieved record first-quarter sales and earnings for the third successive year with both showing increases of more than 18 per cent, Russell DeYoung, chairman, reported yesterday.
John Hawgood, Professor of American history at the University of Birmingham, England, has won the first $5,000 Western History Prize offered by Alfred A. Knopf, Inc.

PARIS, May 3 (AP)-- Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, discussed FrenchAmerican policy differences with Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville today. He will meet tomorrow with President de Gaulle.
The Hudson County Jail in Jersey City was a place where the comforts of home were available at a price, two Government witnesses testified here yesterday.
A bill designed to put strict legal curbs on air pollution here was unanimously adopted yesterday by the City Council. Supporters called the measure the toughest of its kind in the United States.
The Federal government acknowledged yesterday that it had failed in its search for quick solutions to de facto school segregation in Northern cities.
Lillian Gish and Peggy Wood yesterday received awards from the National Council on the Arts and Government for their championing of government aid to the arts.
More than $225-million of new bonds were placed on the market yesterday, and by late afternoon an estimated 70 per cent of them were sold.

ST. LOUIS, May 3--The New York Mets, who are traveling more than Vice President Humphrey these days, landed in St. Louis tonight after making Atlanta, Chicago, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Jacksonville, Fla., in a week. And that was a mistake.

WASHINGTON, May 3-- The United States Supreme Court admitted to practice today the following New York lawyers: Lawrence A.Kobrin, Frank Rinaldi, Paul E.Gelbard, Samuel C. Butler, Herman Odell, Frank A. Lopez and Carol Garfiel.
WHAT is so marvelous about George Balanchine's "Liebeslieder Walzer," which the New York City Ballet revived last night at the New York State Theater?
The appointment of John M. Fraser Jr. as the new chief executive of the Swedish American Line in the United States was announced here yesterday by Dan-Axel Brostrom, board chairman.
Mikulas Grosz, a blind violinist who has given recitals here for several years, appeared again in Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
DALLAS, May 3--Bernard Kilgore, chairman of the board of Dow Jones Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal and The National ...
WASHINGTON, May 3--Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and George McGovern of South Dakota proposed today that President ...

Petra Burka of Toronto, the current Canadian and North American women's figure skating champion and the 1965 world's champion, turned professional yesterday when she signed a contract to appear in a show, Holiday on Ice.
PUEBLA, Mexico, May 3 (AP)--Medical students at the University of Puebla invaded a building held by 2,000 striking preparatory students today, disrobed 22 of the strikers and burned the clothing.

RONNIE BUCKNUM of Playa del Rey, Calif., who has risen from small sports car racing to Formula One since he stared in 1958, is one of the many new drivers trying for riches and glory in this year's Indianapolis 500mile contest. He has just been assigned to the Chevrolet-powered ...

REHOVOTH, Israel, May 3 --Dr. Konrad Adenauer praised Israel today for having "made this most arid soil fruitful with faith in the future." He said the country's record should be an example to all nations.

MOSCOW, May 3--The European Communist bloc was reported today to be building up a broad diplomatic initiative toward Western Europe, aimed at reaching a European security agreement that would minimize United States influence on the Continent.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 (AP)--A $34-million antitrust suit involving a Phelps-Dodge Corporation subsidiary has been settled, it was disclosed in a ...

MADRID, May 3--The United States Embassy studied today the accounts of a number of American students clubbed by the Spanish police here yesterday. A protest was expected to be made tomorrow to the Foreign Ministry.

Alan Stiner of McBurney School upset Edward Mullin of Loyola, 5-7, 6-3, 6-4, in the quarter-finals of the Athletic Association of Private Schools tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, Mullin had been seeded second.
SAIGON--Perhaps the most obstinate enemy in South Vietnam is not the Vietcong but inflation. There are now 52 billion piasters in circulation ...
MONTREAL, May 3--The sixth game of the Stanley Cup hockey playoffs between the Montreal Canadiens and the Red Wings, scheduled for Detroit Thursday night, will be televised in New York, ...
BOSTON, May 3 (UPI)-- Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge, tanned and looking fit, arrived here today for a few days of rest with his family before reporting to President Johnson on the war in Vietnam.
The Alcoa Steamship Company said yesterday it had streamlined its cargo shipping operations, adopted a new stack mark and corporate symbol and improved its container services.
LONDON, May 3--Britain's gold and convertible currency reserves fell by 19-million ($53.2-million) to l,257,000,000 ($3,519,600,000), the Treasury announced today.

Howard Schwartz, formerly a vice president of the United Nuclear Corporation, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the Markite Corporation, manufacturer of conductive plastic potentiometers.
THE question about which fly to use perplexes the trout fisherman in much the same way that choosing a number or color perplexes a roulette player.
A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm D. Mogul of Pelham Manor, N.Y., on April 1 in the Lying-In Hospital.
Anchorage, Alaska, sold yesterday, subject to award, six lots of bonds totaling $21.97million to two syndicates.

A bid of $1,100 for each of 40 mink skins brought a dramatic close yesterday to what many in the industry consider New York's most exciting fur auction.

Edgar Hoover.

WASHINGTON, May 4--A Federal district judge dismissed today a four-year-old indictment against Gus Hall, Communist party official, who was charged with failing to register the party as a Soviet agent.

HOUSTON, May 4--Texans will launch a golf tournament here tomorrow with the hope it will gain as much attention as the Astrodome. The tournament is the $100,000 Houston champions international invitation, which will be played over the Champions Golf Club course.

At least a halfdozen major agencies have been free to do pretty much as they pleased, without consultation and often at cross-purposes.

WASHINGTON, May 4--For the first time, Roman Catholic organizations and nuns are participating in a conference sponsored by Planned ParenthoodWorld Population, the country's major group advocating birth control.

Floyd B. McKisick, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, asked Mayor Lindsay yesterday for an "immediate conference" to submit his objections to the Mayor's new plan for reviewing complaints against the police.

Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay paid tribute yesterday to the Day Care Council of New York, which represents 71 agencies in operating 93 day-care centers in the city.

WASHINGTON, May 4--Un expected opposition by Democratic members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has blocked efforts by the Administration to extricate itself from an impasse with the nations of Latin America.

A new type of weather balloon, designed to drift indefinitely at a predetermined height in the atmosphere, has circled the earth three times and is well into its fourth orbit, establishing a world's record for flight duration.
A State Supreme Court jury heard yesterday how principal stockholders in the Playboy Clubs decided to meet payoff demands allegedly made on them in return for a liquor license here.

ALBANY, May 4--The Assembly aproved today a bill for a Hudson River Valley Commission, designed to link this state, New Jersey and the Federal Government in a program to preserve and develop the valley.
