LONDON, May 4--The suit is conservative blue with discreet strips. The voice is quiet, the words, with their French accent, are cynical, often intended to shock.

WASHINGTON, May 4--The Defense Department denied today Congressional charges that it was wasting "untold millions of dollars" each year by premature and unnecessary disposal of military surplus items overseas.

Prices on the London stock market advanced moderately yesterday, although most issues closed below their highest levels of the day.

The rarely heard "Piano Study in Mixed Accents" by Ruth Crawford Seeger, written in 1930, was the surprise hit of the Composers' Showcase program last night at the Eisner and Lubin Auditorium of New York University.
MIAMI, May 4--Walter Sternberg, the man credited with having made Miami a four-season resort, died today in Jackson Memorial Hospital of a brain tumor. He was 60 years old.

The net income of the Greyhound Corporation in the first quarter this year climbed 29.5 per cent to $5,127,998, or 16 cents a share, from $3,960,781, or 12 cents a share, in the 1965 period. Revenues rose 7.7 per cent to $114,677,602 from $106,435,126.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) reported yesterday net income of $107million for the first nine months oof its fiscal year ended March 31.

Once "5 o'clock lightning" a sudden outburst of game-winning power was the dreaded trademark of the New York Yankee batting order. But that was in another era. At the moment, the Yankee offense is so puny that rival managers save their better pitchers for more formidable opposition.
Sears, Roebuck Co. and the J.C. Penney Company, two of the nation's largest chain stores, announced yesterday record sales in April and in the first three months of their fiscal years.
Ted Bates Co., Inc., the fifth largest agency, which operates facilities around the world, has made its first agency acquisition in the United States A. C. R. Advertising, Inc., in New York.

WASHINGTON, May 5 Former Senator Barry Goldwater charged today that the Johnson Administration was jeopardizing American troops in Vietnam by policies designed to "curry favor" with domestic critics of the war.

PARIS, May 5 An extraordinary delegation of prominent United States businessmen is coming here this weekend for unpublicized talks with equally prominent French businessmen on points of economic friction between the two countries trade policy, the American business invasion, and others.
ROME, May 5 An Italian parliamentary commission backed away hastily today from a proposal, vigorously opposed by the Roman Catholic Church, to permit limited civil divorce in Italy.

Dr. Timothy F. Leary, a psychologist who was convicted in Texas on charges of smuggling marijuana from Mexico, will be a participant in a television panel discussion of LSD, the hallucinatory drug. He will appear on "Open End" from 10 to 11 P.M. on Sunday, May 15, over Channel 11.

ATLANTA, May 5 (UPT) Hank Aaron rifled a double into deep left-center field in the seventh inning tonight to drive in Felipe Alou and provide the Atlanta Braves with a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
Trans World Airlines reported yesterday that Spain and Portugal had limited to last summer's level the number of flights the airline could fly to Madrid and Lisbon in this spring and summer.
DALLAS, May 5 The official representatives of eight major Protestant denominations reached agreement today on a set of principles for their merger into a 24-millionmember church.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 5 Scoring all its runs in the ninth inning, Penn defeated Navy, 5-4, today to hand the middies their first loss in four Eastern League games.

HOUSTON, May 5 Rain forced postponement today of the opening round of the $100,000 Houston Champions international golf tournament. After a survey of the Champions Golf Club layout, Jack Tuthill, the Professional Golfers' Association tournament supervisor, said that a two-day downpour had made the course unsuitable for play.

HONG KONG The remarkable thing about Chinese military aid to North Vietnam and the Vietcong is how little its delivery rate has been affected by the intensified course of the war. Peking chooses to regard the conflict as a "people's war," which apparently means the Vietnamese must do the fighting.
ALBANY, May 5 Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today his controversial proposal to replace the CondonWadlin law with a totally new statute against strikes by governmental employes.
The spot rate on the British pound improved in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The rate closed at $2.7939, up 5 points from the previous day's level.

Larry Brown, the seriously injured Cleveland Indians' shortstop, remained at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday. Brown suffered multiple compound fractures of the skull above and below the eyes when he ran into Leon Wagner, the Cleveland left fielder, in a Wednesday night game at Yankee Stadium. Both were chasing Roger Maris's pop fly, which fell for a double.
WASHINGTON, May 5 Intercity truck tonnage and rail freight ton-mileage for the latest week ended April 30 were both ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1965.
First-quarter sales and earnings of American Metal Climax, Inc., set a record for any quarter in the company's history, the annual meeting was told here yesterday.
Ron Rizzi hurled a six-hit shutout, collected three hits and drove in two runs yesterday to pace City College to a 12-0 victory over Queens at Macombs Dam Park.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, said today that he would press for early action on his proposed school prayer amendment to the Constitution.

COHASSET, Mass., May 5 Mr. and Mrs. Robert N.D. Arndt of Cohasset, formerly of St. Davids, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Channing Arndt, to Theodore Smith Ingalls. He is the son of Dr. andMrs. Theodore Hunt Ingalls of Wynnewood, Pa.
Two women went to Sam's Market at 543 Lenox Avenue yesterday at exactly 3:10 P.M. and bought two pounds of brisket beef at 45 cents a pound and three T-bone steaks at $1.19 a pound.
NEWTON CENTER, Mass., May 5 Miss Donna Gay Richmond and William Michael Carleton plan to marry in August.
DALLAS, May 5 Following is the text of the preamble to the "Principles of Church Union" approved today by the Consultation on Church Union:
GENEVA, May 5 Detailed bargaining for tariff concessions on steel began today in the Kennedy round of trade negotiations.

The plugging of the hole in cotton imports through restrictive quotas has opened the flood gates for European and Asian exports to the United States of knit good made of wool and man-made fibers, a leading spokesman for the United States knitwear industry declared yesterday.
LONDON, May Auberon Waugh, son of Evelyn Waugh, who died on April 10, used an article in the Spectator today to denounce the authors of some of the obituaries of his father as "literary jackals."

DENVER, May 5 In the face of several setbacks to his housing program, including one from the League of Women Voters, Robert C. Weaver, Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, made a plea here tonight for league support of three measures that he said were interrelated and necessary, to eliminate slums and housing discrimination.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 5 William B. Tollen, Pennsylvania's Commissioner of Public Assistance since July, 1959, collapsed and died today while on duty with the Army Reserve at Indiantown Gap Military Reservation. He was 56 years old.

The selection of Dr. Stephen J. Wright as president of the United Negro College Fund, with headquarters here, was announced yesterday. Dr. Wright, who is president of Fisk University in Nashville, will succeed Dr. Frederick D. Patterson on July 1.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 Eddie Neloy is a mite surprised to find himself here, but he is starting to get used to the idea. As the trainer for the Phipps family, Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phipps and her son, Ogden, he was the envy of the horsey set last winter because he was the guy with the mostest.

The Junior League of Brooklyn will give an "Up in Prospect Park Ball" at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn on May 14 to celebrate the park's centennial and to draw attention to the efforts of many Brooklynites to rehabilitate and restore it.
Robert Moses suggested yesterday that the city operate offtrack horse-race betting, with the proceeds committed exclusively to subway improvements.

LEXINGTON, Mass., May 5 The engagement of Miss Marthe Osborne to Stephen Norwick has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Melvin P. Osborne, parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Norwick is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Sydney Norwick of San Lorenzo, Calif.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 5 Bermudians were confident tonight that they would win back the King Edward VII Gold Cup this year. This annual twoof-three-races series has been won by Long Island sailors since 1962, but today Bermuda's Warren Brown so outsailed Arthur Knapp, the defender, that hopes were high in the Onion Patch.
HOUSTON, May 5 (AP) Jim Wynn's two-out single in the 13th inning scored Joe Morgan with the winning run tonight and gave the Houston Astros a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
CHESTER, England, May 5 The Judge in the Pennine Moors murder trial declared today that if the prosecution's case was correct, the two defendants were "sadistic killers of the utmost depravity."

Friends and stockholders of Establishment Discotheque, Ltd., which does business at (and under the name of) Arthur, 154 East 54th Street, will hold a meeting there next week to mark the club's first anniversary and the recoupment of its entire $82,000 investment.
HARPURSVILLE, N.Y. The Town of Colesville, including this hamlet, has 4,180 people and no physician. It has not had one for three years.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) Ignoring Republican charges of budget gimmickry and fiscal irresponsibility, the Senate approved today, 39 to 22, President Johnson's plan to shift some Government loans and mortgages to private investors.

GENEVA, May 5 Lord Chalfont, British Disarmament Minister, said today that the conclusion of a treaty with the Soviet Union to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons depended largely on "how quickly and how imaginatively" the West solved its own nuclearsharing problem.
PITTSBURGH, May 5 The Pennsylvania Railroad announced tonight plans for what it described as one of the most extensive downtown renewal projects ever proposed.

An elevator operator in an apartment house on West End Avenue who had shown "so much kindness, friendship and loyalty" to an elderly tenant has been left most of the tenant's estimated $300,000 estate.

RIDGEFIELD, N.J., May 5 The engagement of Miss Claire Ann Di Cesare, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius V. Di Cesare, to Walter H. Modarelli Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Modarelli of Union City, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

James S. Kemper Jr., president of the companies of the Kemper Insurance Group of Chicago, charged yesterday that Mr. Nader was guilty of "distortions and errors of fact" in his criticism of the insurance industry in Washington on Wednesday.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 The draw for the Kentucky Derby attracted 16 horses today as the next-to-the-final official step for Saturday's 92d running of the famous stakes was taken.

Truman Capote won prolonged applause last night from a Town Hall audience that paid from $2.50 to $20 to hear him read from his works. He gave the performance for the benefit of the Hampton Day School, an elementary school that will open in East Hampton, L.I., in September.

ROME, May 5 (AP)--An Italian journalist who said he had found the long-missing Cuban guerrilla chief, Ernesto Che Guevara, told today how he had been led to him. He said he had found him directing Communist underground campaigns from a hide-out high in the Andes in Peru.
CINCINNATI, May 5 (AP) Joey Jay, given home-run support by Don Pavletich and Pete Rose, became the first Cincinnati pitcher to win two games this season as the Reds crushed Pittsburgh, 10-6, tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) Rebuilding of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization under United States leadership was urged on Congress today by two former diplomatic officials.
WASHINGTON, May 5 The House Banking and Currency Committee approved today legislation that would commit the Federal Government to longterm aid to urban transit systems.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., May 5 The political and intellectual communities of this country seem to be farther apart today than in years. Washington is talking more about education and contributing more to the universities now than ever before and getting more criticism in return.
WASHINGTON, May 5 A program to give students the opportunity to help the mentally retarded and gain experience in that field was announced today by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
Industrial issues advanced on the London stock market yesterday after a quiet start. The rise carried the Financial Times index of 30 industrial issues to a new 1966 high.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 5 An international consortium has been organized to invest $600million in making Brazil an important exporter of steel as well as high-grade iron ore.
CHICAGO, May 5 A 14member commission was named by the American Bar Association today to seek a nonpartisan formula for modernizing Electoral College procedures in Presidential elections.

Seven gangs of longshoremen walked off a Brooklyn pier yesterday in a dispute over work assignments. They promised to return this morning after management had agreed temporarily to let the International Longshoremen's Association write its own interpreta tion of a new contractual working arrangement.

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) Leonard J. Kerpelman, a longtime courtroom champion of civil rights and the lawyer whose arguments prevailed in the Supreme Court's schoolprayer decision, says he opposes "any further extension of civil rights" for Negroes.

Students supporting and opposing the United States involvement in Veitnam traded blows and insults, yesterday at a City College rally held to endorse the Johnson Administration's Southeast Asian policies.

A 50-year-old woman was found strangled in her Chelsea apartment yesterday only an hour before she was scheduled to testify in Criminal Court against a man she had accused of raping and beating her last year.

The last of a two-day sale of duplicates from the rarebook collection of the Newberry Collection of Chicago at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, yesterday brought the total sales to $230,176.

WASHINGTON, May 5 Senator J.W. Fulbright said tonight that the United States, like other great nations in the past, is in danger of equating "its power with virtue and its major responsibilities with a universal mission."

We suppose Governor Rockefeller'e maneuver in putting Senator Javits at the top of the Republican delegate-at-large slate for the 1967 constitutional convention can be regarded as a clever political coup.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) May 5 Dr. Konrad Adenauer's visit to Israel was marred today by a violent demonstration on the campus of Hebrew University. Two dozen students and policemen were injured. WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) The Defense Department raised the draft back up to 26,500 men for July today compared with the 15,000 call for June.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday refused to permit Westchester residents to water shrubs and trees.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 5 The women's Job Corps program in this resort and retirement city is embroiled in a new controversy whether it should be allowed to move its center to a hotel on the downtown Tampa Bay waterfront.
An art gallery owner has brought $2-million legal suits against an art group that called his exhibition of Joan Miro works a fake and against the men who sent him the collection.
LONDON, May 5 Britain announced today that informal talks would begin here early next week to determine whether there is a basis for formal negotiations with Rhodesia.
The man chiefly responsible for the collection of revenue for the Government strongly advocated yesterday a slow approach to tax revisions.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 The arts will get a bigger subsidy from the city for 1967 than they received during the present fiscal year that ends June 30.
"I'M catering to the elderly," Rudi Gernreich an- nounced yesterday at the opening of his fall collection for Harmon Knitwear.
PARIS, May 5 A descendant of the Marquis de Sade was upheld yesterday in his claim that there is such a thing as excess in the theatrical exploitation of his peculiar ancestor.
Wayne Thornton, who punches very hard underwater, came to town yesterday to help promote a race riot.
Mayor Lindsay announced the appointment of Austin N. Heller yesterday as the city's $25,000a-year Commissioner of Air Pollution Control.

WASHINGTON, May 5 The Senate ethics committee will bar television cameras from its forthcoming public hearings on misconduct allegations against Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.

Mrs. Wilma Soss and Lewis D. Gilbert have worked together at annual meetings for many years seeking to bring corporate managements around to their views about "stockholder democracy." So when Mr. Gilbert telephoned Mrs. Soss Wednesday at midnight, she knew it must be important.
Mayor Lindsay was reported yesterday to be continuing his search for a mediator to help settle the newspaper strike, now in its 12th day.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 5 (AP)--A district court today ruled that Denmark should hand over to Iceland a collection of valuable Icelandic scriptures that have been in a private institution in Copenhagen for more than 200 years.
ST. LOUIS, May 5 (AP) Lynn Patrick, general manager and coach of the Los Angeles Blades of the Western League, was named general manager of the new St. Louis National Hockey League franchise today.

Three waiters at the de luxe dining rooms of the Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways whose a la carte service was said to include bookmaking were arrested yesterday by agents of the Internal Revenue Service on charges of falling to obtain $50 Federal gambling tax stamps.

The Maytag Company announced yesterday that Lewis B. Maytag Jr., 39 years old, has succeeded his father, L. B. Maytag Sr., 77, as a director. The Newton, Iowa, laundry appliance concern was founded by the Maytag family in 1893.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration has notified Riker Laboratories, Inc., of Northridge, Calif., that it proposes to withdraw approval of the concern's Norgesic tablets. The Federal agency said that approval of the pain-killing tablets had been based on false information supplied by a research organization.
NEW DELHI, May 5 A meeting of the Heads of government of nonaligned nations appears likely to take place here within the next three months.
WASHINGTON, May 5 Legislation that would give a better income tax break to artists, writers and composers was introduced in the House today by Representative Theodore R. Kupfarman.
Edward J. Logue, who may become the city's next housing director, urged yesterday a redevelopment program equal to the "shattering" problems of the worst slums here.
PHILADELPHIA, May 5 Mrs. Albert C. Barnes, widow of the founder of the Barnes Foundation in suburban Merion, died Friday in her home on the foundation grounds. She was 92 years old.

HONG KONG, May 5 A major struggle appears to be in progress within the Chinese Communist party between moderates and the exponents of the policies of Chairman Mao Tsetung.
The Federal Aviation Agency again turned down yesterday a request of airline pilots to widen jet air lanes over the Atlantic pending a final decision on the safety of the newly narrowed lanes.

MOSCOW, May 5 (Reuters) Soviet intellectuals, uneasy at party supervision of literature and art, were given a glimpse today of Communist China's new campaign against "bourgeois ideology" in the culture field.

NEWARK, May 5 A Federal court denied today a request for a retrial for Anthony (Tony Pro) Provenzano that was sought on the grounds that a member of the jury that convicted the teamster official of extortion in 1963 had been prejudiced.

BERLIN, May 5 Soviet and Western officials today discounted reports that Walter Ulbricht, the 72-year-old leader of Communist East Germany, was on his way out because of his espousal of talks between East German officials and the Social Democratic party of West Germany.
The money market continued in a squeeze yesterday as Federal funds, in a few "isolated" cases, traded at an interest level of 5 1/8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 5 Consumer installment credit outstanding increased by $649million in March, after adjustment for seasonal variations, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The total consumer installment credit outstanding at the end of March was $68.83-billion.
Scientists at the University of California have reported determining the complete chemical structure of human growth hormone, a vital substance produced by the body's master gland, the pituitary.
The Long Island Lighting Company announced yesterday in Mineola, N.Y., the election of John R. Gummersall Jr. as vice president for operating and customer services.
The trend toward tighter money is continuing, statistics released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.
HAVANA, May 5 (Reuters) Cuba violently denounced Yugoslavia today as "a tool of United States imperialist policy" and declared than peaceful coexistence was not an inviolate dogma.

At rare intervals an inspired gesture is made to lift the sights and rekindle the idealism of this troubled world. The Shah of Iran has done this by contributing his country's equivalent of one day's military budget, or $700,000, to the world fight against illiteracy of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

Sharp increases in first-quarter earnings were reported yesterday by the Royal DutchShell Group of companies, the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the Tidewater Oil Company and the British Petroleum Company, Ltd.

NORTH MERRICK, L.I., May 5 The Rev. Jeremiah J. Reilly, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart at Merrick Avenue and Old Mill Road here, died of a heart attack yesterday at the rectory, 710 Merrick Avenue. He was 64 years old.
The American Stock Exchange was bolted by its sharpest setback in more than two years yesterday as prices tumbled in active trading.

Breaking a 198-year-old tradition, the New York Chamber of Commerce, long an exclusively men's organization, elected its first woman member yesterday. She is Mrs. Mary McCrann Platz, president of the Bessemer Steel Corporation.

Oliver Rea, who was instrumental in the creation of the $2.25-million Tyrone Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, has resigned from the organization. Mr. Rea relinquishes the posts of president and co-managing director of the Minnesota Theater Company, which runs the repertory theater. He had been on leave since Feb. 13.

CHICAGO, May 5 The help of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was sought and rewards of $15,000 were offered today in efforts to solve the early morn-, ing shooting of Fred D. Hubbard, an independent Negro candidate seeking the Congressional seat of Representative William L. Dawson, one of the most powerful Negro politicians in the country.

ALBANY, May 5 (AP) The state's highest court dismissed today an appeal by Representative Adam Clayton Powell and his wife, Yvette, in a case stemming from a defamation-ofcharacter suit against Mr. Powell.

EVEN a wife who doesn't have a head for figures can sometimes help her husband out in business. Mrs. Henry Ford 2d paid a visit to Seventh Avenue yesterday to do her little bit in a project that involves no less than three industries.

A gravel-voiced Government witness with a prison record dating to 1927 testified in Federal Court yesterday that he had seen Warden Henry B. McFarland in the Hudson County jail with Mrs. Marilyn Jean Fraser, a convicted prostitute, and Israel Schwartzberg, a convicted basketball game fixer.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 5 Richard W. Blum, 43-year-old New York City patent lawyer, was killed yesterday evening on the New York State Thruway, the automobile in which he was driving struck a signpost.
BERLIN, May 5 East Germany disclosed today that it had placed Ghanaian diplomats and students under a travel ban following the rupture of relations with Ghana.

David Ross, former Off Broadway producer and director, died April 13 following a long illness, at the home of his mother, Mrs. Caroline Ross Dorshow, in St. Paul. The funeral was held the next day and no announcement of his death was made. Mr. Ross was 43 years old.

The Lykes Bros. Steamship Company and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, long at odds over the size of the licensed-engineer complement aboard new automated vessels have reached a temporary settlement.

WASHINGTON, May 5 President Johnson stood reverently in his Oval Room office in the White House today as the Chief Rabbi of Israel grey-bearded and patriarchal in appearance intoned a 2,000year-old "brocha" (blessing) that is recited only for a chief of state.
GUADALAJARA, Mexico, May 3 In a new building, one of many rising in this fastgrowing city, one of Latin America's most ambitious attacks on rural poverty is beginning to go into action.

ATHENS, Ga., May 5 (UPI) Joseph Howard Sims, a Ku Klux Klansman who was tried and acquitted in the 1964 murder of Lemuel Penn, a Washington Negro educator, shot his estranged wife in the face today, the police said.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 5 Josiah Kirby Lilly, a grandson of the founder of Eli Lilly Co., the pharmaceutical concern, and chairman of the board of the company, died yesterday of a heart ailment at Oldfields, his home here. He was 72 years old.

ALBANY, May 5 Governor Rockefeller urged today that all states adopt uniform standards for drivers' licenses, exchange information on problem drivers and periodically reexamine all drivers.

A contest between Senators Robert F. Kennedy and Jacob K. Javits in the fall election semed all but certain yesterday as Governor Rockefeller rejected Mr. Kennedy's appeal for mutiparty agreement on a slate of 15 delegates at large to the 1967 Constitutional Convention.
A preview and cocktail reception at William Bowie's Sculpture Studio, 202 East 77th Street, on May 16 will benefit the Greater New York chapters of the Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America.
Joseph E. O'Grady, who had planned to retire last month as chairman of the transit authority will continue in his position for "a matter of weeks," the authority announced yesterday.

PARIS, May 5 Francois Mitterrand, leader of the noncommunist French Left, announced today the formation of a "shadow cabinet" whose task it would be to study and, if necessary, contest every move made by the de Gaulle regime.
LOUISVILLE, May 5 In his stall at Churchill Downs this afternoon, Stupendous rested contentedly on the floor, his legs tucked under him.

ROME, May 5 (AP) Dennis Ralston and Marty Riessen, members of the United States Davis Cup squad, today joined an unbroken march of seeded favorites into the fourth round of the Italian international tennis tournament.

MADRID, May 5 Nearly 2,000 University of Madrid students rioted today, battling the police, disabling streetcars and briefly invading the unversity's Chancellor's office building.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 5 The Indonesian armed forces tonight postponed the meeting of the People's Provisional Congress scheduled to begin May 12.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) --The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of William Tapley Bennett Jr., Ambassador to the Dominican Republic, as Ambassador to Portugal.

William McChesney Martin Jr.'s demand for acrossthe board increases in corporate and individual income taxes to counter inflation represents a significant break in the solid front put up by the makers of economic policy in Washington.
DETROIT, May 5 The General Motors Corporation announced a limited production cutback today after all four major automobile manufacturers had reported declining sales.
OTTAWA, May 5 Two influential Canadians have called for a declaration of economic independence from the United States.

Robert B. Blaikie, long a dissident Democrat, charged yesterday that J. Raymond Jones, New York County leader, had engineered a judgeship deal that would give Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein the nomination for Surrogate.

After threatening yesterday to disband, a committee set up to draft a law for South Vietnam's scheduled national elections resumed its discussions today. A tentative compromise was worked out between the Government and opposition elements. [Page 1, Columns 3-4.]

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 5 A Rhodesian police spokesman today described as "absolute nonsense" reports from exiled African nationalists in Tanzania and Zambia that there had been renewed battles with guerrilla infiltrators in the northern part of Rhodesia.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 5 From now until midnight on Sept. 17, borscht (beet soup) and smetinah (sour cream) will be sharing billing in this Catskill resort area with standardbreds (trotters and pacers). And based on the evidence tonight, as the ninth season of harness racing got under way at Monticello Raceway, the competition will be on the keen side.
Earnings of the Bendix Corporation in the second fiscal quarter, ended March 31, rose 87 per cent to $9,856,831 above the $5,006,324 earned a year earlier.

CAIRO, May 5 The newspaper Al Ahram, which often reflects official views of the United Arab Republic, declared today in one of the strongest recent press attacks on Washington that the United States had "come out in its true colors as protector of King Faisal" of Saudi Arabia.
WASHINGTON, May 5 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach agreed today to exempt "Mrs. Murphy's boarding house" from the fair housing provision of the proposed Civil Rights Act of 1966.
The Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company has named Warren Gallagher vice president and manager of its Brooklyn office.
Voter resistance has resulted in the defeat of 11 of 39 school budgets in Nassau County and the rejection of a record $17million school budget by taxpayers in Brentwood in Suffolk County.

Industry in this country expects to spend $15.2-billion for research and development work this year, a rise of $1.3-billion above 1965.

AN increase in Federal laws to protect wildlife and enhance enforcement of pertinent criminal statutes concerning some species is being sought from Congress by the Bureau of Sports Fisheries and Wildlife of the Department of the Interior.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., May 5 Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won the opening oneday tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Glen Ridge Country Club today.

DETROIT, May 5 As hundreds cheered and thousands sat mute, Henri Richard slid into the Detroit net tonight, carry-, ing the puck with him for a 3-2 Montreal victory goal as anticlimactic an ending as the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup playoffs have produced in 40 years.

KEY WEST, Fla., May 5 (UPI) A Coast Guard helicopter crew searching through the darkness off the coast tonight pinpointed a tuna boat and landed a medic who gave emergency aid to two fishermen who mistakenly ate rat poison.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) John Harllee, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, told Congress today the United States "is heading for chaos in the air, on land and at sea, unless we move to unify our transportation complex."
MADRID,. May 5 The Madrid Roman Catholic newspaper Ya urged in an editorial today the establishment of diplomatic relations between Spain and the Soviet Union.
SAIGON, May 5 Vietcong deaths in combat last week were the lowest in 15 months, a United States military spokesman said tonight.

GENEVA, May 5 W. Averell Harriman, United States Ambassador at Large, arrived here today from London to confer with the International Red Cross Committee on the fate of American prisoners of war in Vietnam.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 5 (AP) A witness who refused to testify before a grand jury in the narcotics investigation of Dr. Timothy Leary has been given until Monday to show why she should not be penalized on a contempt citation.
WASHINGTON, May 5 President Johnson called on Government law enforcement agencies today to "redouble" their efforts to "rid our land of the menace of organized crime."

The first stakes race of the New York season for jumpers may have been low in talent at Aqueduct yesterday but it certainly provided a high in excitement as Mrs. Ogden Phipps's Jove won the $11,975 Aqueduct National Hurdles.

Flint, Mich., sold yesterday two bond issues totaling $6.92million to two groups. A syndicate led by Bear, Stearns Co. and Salomon Brothers Hutzler was the best bidder for $3.5million of water system revenue bonds with a bid of 100.0028 for seven different coupon rates. This set an annual average interest cost of 3.854 per cent. A Smith, Barney Co., Inc., group placed second with a bid that would have cost Flint 3.859.
WASHINGTON, May 5 John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, created a new post today to centralize and emphasize his department's birth control activities.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 5 (UPI) President Johnson flew, home to his Texas ranch today for a long weekend of "sunshine and, a few appointments." But a misty rain greeted him upon his arrival.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 5 The Government warned European and Asian businessmen here today to get more Africans into Kenya's commerce or face the risk that their businesses might be taken over.

LIKE the proud old operatic diva she is, the Metropoli- tan Opera House is not being content with merely one farewell performance. Having said good-by to all those golden larynxes three weeks ago, the Met audience offers its last homage to the golden toeshoes on Sunday, when the Bolshoi Ballet, and friends, wind up the final night's proceedings in the old house with a dance gala.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15 P.M.; National R.O.T.C. Band Competition, Philharmonic Hall, 8; Collegiate Chorale, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Robert Guralnik, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Edward Brewer, harpsichordist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Beaux Arts Trio, Hunter College Playhouse, 8:40.

BRUSSELS, May 5 (UPI) The economic integration of Europe was further slowed today when Common Market foreign ministers shelved plans for introducing a full customs union between their countries by mid1967.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 (AP) The San Francisco Giants lost an early 7-0 lead today and then rallied for a 9-8 victory in 10 innings over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
GUATEMALA, May 5 Rebels who kidnapped two officials yesterday said they would be held until the Government disclosed the fate of 15 political prisoners alleged to have been captured in February.

WASHINGTON, May 5 President Johnson announced today a 15 per cent increase in the acreage farmers may plant to wheat in 1967 to gain an estimated total of 200 million more bushels and to meet world food aid needs.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) A low yield nuclear device equal to a force of 20,000 tons of TNT or less was detonated underground today at the Nevada Test Site. The Atomic Energy Commission said it was the second of three tests scheduled in three days.

LANDING with the marines on Okinawa in 1945, Aus- tin Norman Heller had two problems: to survive the kamikaze attack that greeted him and, as a staff sanitary engineering officer, to find pure water and get it to the troops.

A Bronx factory worker who allegedly threatened his landlord with an organized campaign to gain a rent reduction from the city unless he was paid $3,000 was arraigned yesterday in Bronx Criminal Court.

TOKYO, May 5 To remind Japan's children of the traditional virtues of being Japanese, this highly industrailized country shut its roaring factories and bustling offices today for a symbolic reidentification with the Oriental past.
Two firemen were manhandled by neighborhood toughs while trying to extinguish a fire yesterday in the Williamsburgh section of Brooklyn.
Six floors with a total of 45,000 square feet of office space in the Loew Building, which houses Loew's State Theater, have been leased to two corporations by Loew's Hotels, Inc., the owner.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 5 (AP) The California Angels combined Norm Siebern's runscoring single in the first inning with four-hit pitching by Fred Newman and Bob Lee tonight for their third straight victory, a 1-0 triumph over the Kansas City Athletics.
CANNES, France, May 5 The 20th annual Cannes Film Festival got off to a curious start tonight with the showing of a massive Polish picture that built up anything but a festive air.
The public was invited yesterday to help Mayor Lindsay pick the four civilian members of the controversial civilian-dominated board for reviewing complaints against the police.
ALBANY, May 5 Controller Arthur Levitt asserted today that the state's Job Development Authority had exceeded its legal-powers, used questionable fiscal procedures and issued exaggerated reports.
WASHINGTON, May 5 A Presidential labor-management committee sought today to develop new ideas on fighting inflation to present to the Johnson Administration.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The National Association of Securities Dealers filed suit today in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in an attempt to block the creation of a mutual fund account by the First National City Bank of New York.
With the May potato futures contract moving toward its last trading day on Tuesday, commodity men were watching the price movement yesterday, along with the latest openinterest figures.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., May 5 Dr. Reid B. Brader, a physician with the Ritenour Health Center of Pennsylvania State University, died yesterday at Centre County Hospital, Bellefonte. He was 55 years old.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 5 Joaquin Balaguer, a candidate for President, has proposed to his opponent in the June 1 election, Juan Bosch, that the losing party become a loyal opposition.
WASHINGTON, May 5--The House Appropriations Committee, in its first big budgetcutting spree of the year, eliminated today funds for the President's ill-starred rent-supplement program.
The City Hall hearings on Mayor Lindsay's proposed expense budget all but erupted into violence yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The Federal National Mortgage Association said tonight it purchased a record $797.8-million in mortgages during the first three months of this year because of the tight money market.
NEW ORLEANS, May 5 (AP) Mrs. Judy Eller Street forged into the semi-finals of the Women's Southern amateur golf tournament today by routing the medalist, Mrs. Mary Ann Rathwell, in the rain.
Students and teachers will be the show and the audience at a benefit jazz and folk concert at 3 this afternoon at the High School of Music and Art.
The question of whether the United States will stay in the Warsaw Convention remained in doubt yesterday, as the time for a decision by May 13 got nearer.

Ralph Bergen, convicted in 1964 of conspiracy to bribe Martin C. Epstein, the State Liquor Authority chairman, returned to the courthouse yesterday to denounce L. Judson Morhouse as a fellow conspirator.

Conferred with Secretary of State Rusk, Defense Secretary McNamara and other officials about the Vietnam situation and Latin American affairs; met with Attorney General Katzenbach, F.B.I. Director Hoover and others on organized crime; ordered a 15 per cent increase in 1967 wheat acreage allotments to meet heavier export demands; met with Isser Uterman, the chief rabbi of Israel; flew to his Texas ranch for the weekend.
The Inter-American Press Association Scholarship Fund will award at least five grants for a year's study in Latin America to North American newspapermen and journalism graduates or students.

SELMA, Ala., May 5--The Justice Department charged today that local Democratic officials had improperly disqualified 1,672 Negro votes to save Sheriff James G. Clark Jr., a segregationist leader, from defeat in Tuesday's Democratic primary.
Robert O. Fickes, president and chief executive officer of the Philco Corporation since 1964, was appointed yesterday to the additional post of chairman.
The wholesale commodity pries index rose to 110.5 on Wednesday from 110.3 on Tuesday.

The City Center cast for "The Most Happy Fella" will join members of the Young Committee of the Friends of the City Center at a dinner dance at the Sheraton-East after the curtain comes down on the opening performance of the Frank Loesser musical Wednesday.

The annual dinner dance sponsored by the board of trustees and the women's auxiliary board of the Lenox Hill Hospital was held at the Plaza last night. The hotel's Grand Ballroom provided a setting of white and yellow spring flowers combined with blue irises for the event. Proceeds will be used for emergency equipment at the Charles R. Lachman Community Health Center, a hospital affiliate.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular, establishment.

BUFFALO, May 5 Alex F. Osborn, the nationally known advertising executive who made "creative thinking" and "brainstorming" household words, died of cancer today in Roswell Park Memorial Institute, where he had been a patient since April 1. He was 77 years old.
Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism presented its Alumni Awards to three newsmen yesterday in ceremonies held during the school's annual alumni meeting.

Howard J. Samuels, the upstate industrialist who has long been active in state Democratic politics, will announce with a dramatic flourish next Tuesday that he is a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
A new leader emerged yesterday in the Westchester series of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament.

Mrs. Henry Ford 2d said yesterday that she had received a telephone call from a man offering to return $50,000 worth of jewelry stolen from her hotel suite here Wednesday night. The police said the caller was probably a crank.

CHICAGO, May 6 Claude Lightfoot, an Illinois Communist leader, did not appear at a Building Department hearing today to answer charges of violations in a dilapidated slum building of which he was listed as owner.
CANTHO, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 7 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky said today his military regime intended to stay in power "at least for another year."
YOU never know what will turn up next at the Gal- lery of Modern Art on Co-lumbus Circle, but a last guess would have been "Treasures of Peruvian Gold," which turned up last week.

ST. VINCENT, Italy, May 6 North American hopes of a surprise world championship comeback against Italy disappeared here this afternoon.
The National Company has announced the election of Frank F. Oddi as president and chief executive officer. Formerly vice president, Mr. Oddi succeeds Herbert. A. Finke, who has resigned.

WASHINGTON, May 6 A Presidential emergency board dealt another blow to the Johnson Administration's wageprice guideposts today by asserting that it would not be bound by the guideposts in recommending a settlement for a major airline labor dispute.

HOUSTON, May 6 (UPI) The Atlanta Braves scored six runs with two out in the ninth inning tonight to back up the seven-hit pitching of Denny Lemaster and blank the Houston Astros, 6-0.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation will move ahead with construction of a major addition to Its computer and communications center in Pittsburgh, a spokesman said yesterday.

BRUSSELS, May 6 A pathbreaking report warned today that Western Europe must place more emphasis on investment and research and less on consumption to check inflation and avoid being swamped by the surging economy of the United States.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 6 New criticism was fired today at Clark Kerr and his administration of the University of California by a State Senate subcommittee on UnAmerican Activities. He fired back.

NEWARK, May 6 (AP) Schenley Industries, Inc., filed a $75-million antitrust suit today in Federal court against 59 defendants, including the New Jersey Wine and Spirits Wholesale Association, alleging conspiracy to fix prices.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 110.4 on Thursday from 110.5 on Wednesday.
Francis Aranyi, concert violinist and conductor, died at the General Hospital in Seattle on Thursday after surgery. He was 73 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) The appointment of two senior members of the National Security Council staff to assist Walt W. Rostow, President Johnson's national security affairs adviser, was announced today.
SAIGON, May 6 United States marines operating near the coastal enclave of Chulai, 350 miles northeast of Saigon, reported today a new Vietcong weapon exploding cucumbers.

Dr. Arthur I. Bernstein, chairman of social studies at Erasmus Hall High School and former president of the Association of Teachers of Social Studies, died Thursday of a heart attack in Coney Island Hospital. He was 43 years old and lived at 1021 East 27th Street, Brooklyn.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 6 A Federal district judge ordered the Dallas County Democratic Executive Committee today to appear for a hearing May 16 to show why it should not count disputed ballots in the county sheriff's race.

Wall Street was reassured yesterday that President Johnson's "take-it-easy" admonitions regarding capital expansion projects did not apply to the nation's railroads, at least insofar as their purchases of rolling stock were.
WASHINGTON, May 6 The accumulated mechanical ills of the American automobile were dumped into the public domain today, a development that raised at least as many questions as it answered.
Carey Transportation, Inc., was struck yesterday afternoon shutting down the company's bus service to and from Kennedy International, La Guardia and Newark Airports.

A new lunchtime movie oasis is flourishing on West 53d Street. Each Wednesday noon film fans are using the luncheon interval for a sampling of choice movie shorts in the basement auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art.

ST. PAUL, May 6 (UPI). The Minnesota Supreme Court ordered a new trial today on one of the issues involved in a $100,000 lawsuit against the Chrysler Corporation. The suit claims that a defective shaft in a power-steering assembly was the cause of a fatal traffic accident in 1954.

MIDLAND, Tex., May 6 (AP) Kathy Whitworth shot a four-under-par 67 today and took a one-stroke lead in the Tall City women's open golf tournament. The event is being played on the 6,100-yard Hogan Park course.
The request of two sisters of Billy Rose to be appointed temporary administrators of the showman's $30-million estate was denied yesterday by Surrogate Joseph A. Cox.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 6 Roy J. Grimley of 254 Prospect Street, retired lawyer, stamp collector and owner of a collection of letters written by Gen. Robert E. Lee, died Wednesday in the Bergen Pines Hospital in Paramus. He was 66 years old.
FREDERICK KIESLER, who died in December at the age of 70, was a man of unusual gifts.
Seventh Avenue will feel the repercussion of last week's Supreme Court decision against the General Motors Corporation, a prominent garment-center lawyer said here yesterday.
"It's great to be back," Leo Durocher said last night as he returned to town as manager of the Chicago Cubs and was greeted in Shea Stadium by 27,656 persons and the New York Mets.

WASHINGTON, May 6 India's Minister of Planning, Asoka Mehta, left for home today after having obtained a vague agreement in principle on future levels of United States aid but no specific commitments.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 (AP) Two Soviet ships from fishing fleets that have been operating off the Pacific Coast have been denied permission to enter United States territorial water, the Coast Guard said today.
LONDON, May 6 The British Petroleum Company said today it might be possible to bring some supplies of North Sea gas ashore by the end of this year months ahead of schedule.
THERE are city dwellers who spend every summer weekend surrounded by trees, cool green grass and brightly blooming flowers and never get involved in traffic jams.
WASHINGTON, May 6--The question of what to do with 12 million tons of radioactive sandpiles in the Colorado River basin was explored, but not resolved, in a Senate hearing today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) Investigating Senators were told today that the Pentagon had discarded 1,631 pieces of used equipment in Asia that could have overcome shortages facing United States forces in South Vietnam.
The election of D.L. Douglas to the new post of vice president for research was announced yesterday in St. Paul, Minn., by Gould-National Batteries, Inc.
ROME, May 6 (AP) Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif. and Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., gained the quarter-finals today in the Italian international tennis tournament.
The advisory panel on taxation appointed by City Council President Frank D. O'Connor yesterday approved a tax program substantially the same as that proposed by Mayor Lindsay.
The New York County Democratic executive committee designated Supreme Court Justice Arthur G, Klein yesterday for the party nomination for Surrogate.
WASHINGTON, May 6 The National Gallery's gemlike Flemish painting, "St. George and the Dragon," will be seen through a magnifying glass when it goes on public view tomorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) The Pennsylvania Railroad announced today that it had awarded a $20-million contract for 50 self-propelled electric passenger cars to the Budd Company here.

Herbert E. Simpson, founder and former president of the Brookhattan Trucking Company, 57 Front Street, and a sportsman, died Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived on Century Ridge Road in Harrison, N.Y.
"Copper was riding with the stock market downhill," a broker commented yesterday. As most observers knew, the stock market was riding with General Motors.

HONG KONG, May 6 (AP) Mao Tse-tung is recuperating from a heart condition and soon may be well enough to appear in public, a former Communist newsman was quoted today as having said in a Hong Kong newspaper.

WHITE POST, Va., May 6 Mrs. Christine Grote was married here at noon today to Charles Sprague Boit at Farnley, the home of Mrs. Higginson MacKay-Smith. The Rev. Claude M. Cook performed the Protestant ceremony.

Louis Appel, secretary-treasurer, a founder and former president of the Appel Contracting Corporation, 303 West 42d Street, died Thursday in a Manhattan nursing home after a long illness. He was 80 years old.
A retailer found guilty of possessing untaxed cigarettes is to be enjoined "early next week" from selling cigarettes for a specified period.

Albert Savin's Native Street, ridden by Brumfield, won the $60,550 Kentucky Oaks before a crowd of 32,500 Friday. Native Street, the favorite in the 11-16-mile race for 3-year-old fillies, finished a head in front of Justakiss, with Lady Pitt next. But Justakiss was disqualified and placed last.
DETROIT, May 6 The General Motors Corporation said today that all 23 of its auto assembly plants would be in full operation Monday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 6 Yemeni royalist forces have moved into areas evacuated in the last month by troops of the United Arab Republic in northern and northeastern Yemen and now have full control of the situation there, the Deputy Premier of the royalist Government declared here last night.

GENEVA, May 6 W. Averell Harriman, President Johnson's Ambassador at Large, emphasized Washington's concern for the United States prisoners of war in Vietnam at a meeting today with officials of the International Red Cross Committee.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy called Governor Rockefeller "arrogant and selfish" yesterday for opposing a nonpartisan selection of the 15 delegates at large to the 1967 State Constitutional Convention.

TEL AVIV, May 6 A scheduled visit by Dr. Konrad Adenauer to Bar-Ilan University, near here, was canceled today. His tour of the Hebrew University campus in Jerusalem yesterday led to clashes between policemen and students.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 6--Delegates of 36 African states decided at a meeting today to ask next Tuesday for an urgent meeting of the Security Council on Rhodesia.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 6 President Johnson an- nounced today the appointment of two assistant secretaries to the new Department of Housing and Urban Development.
CINCINNATI, May 6 (UPI) Home runs by Tony Perez and Art Shamsky paced the Cincinnati Reds to a 7-1 triumph over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight and gave Milt Pappas his first National League victory.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 6 A Brazilian one-year Treasury bill with a guaranteed 26 per cent return for investors has brought millions of dollars flowing into the financial market here.
Robert Guralnik has done some traveling abroad and given a lot of concerts since his debut here in 1962, and the pianist's third local program last night showed he has gained from experience.

Directors of the Holly Sugar Company voted yesterday to split the company's common stock on a two-for-one basis, subject to shareholders' approval at a meeting June 29.
The dispute over the United States' continued participation in the Warsaw Convention reached a new intensity yesterday in an atmosphere that grew increasingly bitter.
Westchester County's top official asked New York yesterday to allow Westchester residents to water trees and shrubs.
WASHINGTON, May 6 The country's four major automobile manufacturers disclosed today that they had called in 8,700,225 passenger cars since late 1959 for inspection and possible correction of defects.

The spot rate on the British pound eased further yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7933, down 6 points from the previous day's level.

ST. LOUIS, May 6 (UPI) Gaylord Perry, with eighth-inning relief help from Frank Linzy, won his fourth straight game and Jim Hart contributed a two-run triple in a first-inning San Francisco uprising tonight to give the Giants a 4-2 decision over the St. Louis Cardinals.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 6 (Reuters) The Congolese Cabinet decided today to raise the export tax on copper mined in the Congo from 17 to 30 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The Treasury reported today an unusually high "attrition" in its recent refunding, with public holders of 43 per cent of the two maturing issues demanding cash instead of the new security offered in exchange.

The ecumenical spirit continues to blow like a fresh breeze over the earth. The latest manifestation is the remarkable success of the Dallas Consultation on Church Union in drafting a set of principles for church union and winning approval by delegates from its eight large member churches.

The Rev. Dr. Luther A. Gotwald, who retired in July, 1963, as executive secretary of the division of foreign missions of the National Council of Churches, died Thursday in his home at 100 La Salle Street. He was 67 years old.
The city's top school officials replied yesterday to criticism by Mayor Lindsay when they asserted that the public schools here were better than those in any other city.
The new budget introduced by Britain's Labor Government is a novel attempt to cope with some old and acute problems.
The engagement of Miss Isabella Leavy to Conrad Levenson has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice C. Leavy, Neponsit, Queens. The wedding is planned for June 9.

FAURE'S Requiem and Walton's "Belshazzar's Feast" made up the final program of the Collegiate Chorale's 25th anniversary season, in Carnegie Hall last night, and two more dissimilar works would be hard to find in the choral repertory.

THESE two first novels could scarcely differ more in content, in setting, in tone and technique, in the author's at- titude to his people. The two worlds drawn could have come from different centuries and planets. Yet the characters are strangely one in their drives, their fears, their inability to communicate with those they cherish and love.
ATLANTA, May 6 Charges of inadequate voting facilities for Alabama Negroes during Democratic primacy Tuesday were made today by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday that it had approved loans totaling $34.2-million to a private Moroccan development finance company and to the Government of Colombia.

WASHINGTON, May 6--The nation's job situation continued strong in April and nonfood wholesale prices rose significantly further, Labor Department reports disclosed today. The two indicators together, the first available for April, showed a continuation of boom and some inflationary pressure in the economy.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 6 Plans of the school board to build a children's academy to help achieve integration suffered a setback today when a board member said he had changed his mind and now opposed it.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) Rear Adm. William S. Guest was awarded the distinguished service medal today for commanding the recovery operations of a United States hydrogen bomb off Palomares, Spain.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 6 Squeezing in a quick 18 holes of golf before work, a Huntington, L.I., general insurance agent and a Manhattan stockbroker stood one, two today after the first round of the Ray Torgerson Memorial tournament.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 In each of the last 20 Kentucky Derbies, Albert Beha has risked $24 to win on one horse.

SAIGON, Saturday, May 7 Troops of the United States Army's First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) have killed 362 enemy soldiers in fighting that began Thursday afternoon, a military spokesman said this morning.
HARRISON, N.Y., May 5 Hunter Mann, a former division manager for Reynolds Metals Company, died yesterday in his sleep at his home here, 112 Nelson Avenue. He was 81 years old.
Wheatley Stable's Bold Lad, on the comeback trail after being sidelined for a year, returned to Aqueduct yesterday and registered a healthy performance in winning the $10,000 Alerted.
Tomorrow will mark the end of the first year of the "Jewish TV Chronicle," a television show that has broken ground in two directions.

ALBANY, May 6-The Legislature's top Democrat, Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia, threw his support today hehind a plan empowering the City University of New York to borrow $400-million for new construction.
Waterfront employers yesterday said leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association were trying to block compliance with terms of the contract under which they are working.
ROME, May 6--Fourteen policemen and nine civilians, including a socialist Deputy, were hurt today as striking insurance company workers and riot policemen clashed in downtown Rome.

WASHINGTON, May 6-- Dr. Athelstan F. Spilhaus, dean of the University of Minnesota Institute of Technology, was granted a patent this week for an astronomical clock.
The First National City Bank has introduced a new simplified credit application that can be completed in a few minutes without need for an interview, the bank announced yesterday.

Within the next two weeks, 1,500 of the "wealthiest people in the world" will receive letters from the Neiman-Marcus Company in Dallas, informing them that the "finest mink coat in the world" is available for a special order. Its price tag will be about $80,000.
By its irresponsible dithering over the rent subsidy program the bipartisan majority in control of the House Appropriations Committee is bringing the whole legislative process into disrepute.
A bomb was found yesterday afternoon outside the apartment of a young woman on the second floor of an East Side apartment building.
DENVER, May 6 After a week of debate the League of Women Voters, by a margin of only six votes, defeated an attempt to commit it for the next two years to a study of discrimination in housing.

Mayor Lindsay and his outspoken chairman of the Commission on Human Rights, William H. Booth, gave new evidence yesterday that they do not agree on all city issues.
The Ingersoll-Rand Company, a manufacturer of heavy machinery, announced here yesterday the appointment of Wallace M. Stanton as a group vice president.
Carlos Alexander Cooks, leader of the African Nationalist Pioneer movement, died of a heart attack in his home at 43 West 131st Street yesterday. He was 53 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (UPI) Dick Groat singled home two runs with two out in the last half of the 11th inning tonight to cap a five-run explosion that carried the Philadelphia Phillies to an 8-7 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 6 The cancellation by Soviet authorities earlier this week of an exchange by the Israel Philharmonic and Moscow State Orchestras has puzzled and angered Jerusalem officials.

MONTREAL, May 6 (AP) The Corporation of Upper St. Lawrence River Pilots has protested to Transport Minister J. W. Pickersgill that United States dispatching authorities are disregarding a Transport Department ruling that Canadian pilots will not be required to pilot ships outside the limits of their district from Cornwall to Kingston, Ont.

The Court of Appeals has upheld the dismissal of grand larceny indictments against an official of a construction company and two officials of a consulting engineering firm that arose from construction of the New England section of the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) In an effort to step up development of the Trust Territory of the Pacific, the Peace Corps announced today that volunteers would be sent to the tropical islands.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 6 Government "visitations" on reputable journalists are intended as a general warning to South Africa's press, Laurence Gandar, editor in chief of The Rand Daily Mail, said today. He addressed the opening session of the annual congress of the South African Society of Journalists.
WASHINGTON, May 6 Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, filed a $5million libel and conspiracy suit today against Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson.
PARIS, May 6 Charles Wohlstetter, of Wall Street, made the preposterous claim here the other day that Americans talk more than Frenchmen.

A statement of a recent amendment to the state social welfare law relieving adults of the responsibility for the support of parents receiving any public assistance will be sent out to persons receiving welfare checks. The new provision includes the Federal Medicare program.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., May 6--John M. Mullin of 92 Sherwood Drive, president of Sprague Electrical Supplies, Inc., of Bridgeport and Hartford, died here yesterday He was 72 years old.

HOUSTON, May 6 Gov. John B. Connally Jr. and Senator Ralph W. Yarborough will fight for control of the Texas Democratic party in precinct elections in the state tomorrow night. The ultimate victor, however, will not be known at least until next week.

The Lindsay budget and tax programs have now been through the wringer of tumultuous public hearings. The final session, dealing with the needs of schools and City University, dramatized in the area of greatest public concern what is true of the whole budget, that $4.6 billion still falls short of the reasonably ideal for essential services.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) A Rumanian Evangelical minister stripped to the waist during a Senate hearing today to show 18 scars he said had been inflicted by Communist torturers.
SELMA, Ala., May 6 Local officials in three Black Belt counties kept Federal observers from watching white poll workers mark the ballots of illiterate Negroes in Tuesday's Democratic primary.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The House Agriculture Committee has approved, as part of the proposed $3.3-billion "Food for Freedom" bill, authorization to offer birth control assistance, when requested, to countries participating in the program. The vote was 30 to 3.
LONDON, May 6 (AP)--A floating dock broke in half today while being towed from Britain to Baltimore, Lloyd's Shipping Service reported.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) Four artillery battalions have been added to United States forces in Vietnam since January to strengthen the Army's ground firepower, Defense Department spokesmen said today.
Prices on the London Stock exchange rallied yesterday from morning declines set off by the Wall Street slump on Thursday, and gains predominated at the close.

At 3:30 P.M. yesterday, just as the stock market was closing, a secretary ran into the home office of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., at 70 Pine Street and announced: "It's raining outside! Would you believe it?"
WASHINGTON, May 6 The index of primary market prices declined one-tenth of 1 per cent to 105.1 during the week ended May 3, the bureau of labor statistics reported today.

Record sales and earnings were achieved by the California Packing Corporation in the fiscal year ended Feb. 28, it was reported yesterday. Directors raised the quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share from 22 cents, payable Aug. 15 to stockholders of record July 22.
SANA, Yemen The Bilkis movie house is staging its own quiet revolution in the Yemeni highlands, upsetting one of the most established customs of Yemeni men.

Supporters of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service gathered in the Plaza's ballroom last night to celebrate the 110th anniversary of the first ball held in behalf of the organization, when it was known as the Nursery and Child's Hospital.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 6 The New York Yankees made their Anaheim Stadium debut tonight before 31,690 spectators and fell back into the American League cellar by absorbing a 7-4 defeat at the hands of the California Angels.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 6 Giggles, a versatile 5-year- old bay gelding, took the lead for the large working-hunter championship today by winning one class and finishing third in another at the Junior Essex Troop Horse Show.

The cashier-manager of the Horn Hardart Automat at 461 Eighth Avenue, between 33d and 34th Streets, was shot in the left arm last night after he refused to surrender money to two armed men, who fled empty-handed.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 6 Warren Brown of Bermuda outsailed Arthur Knapp of Manhasset, L.I., today to win the King Edward VII Gold Cup for Bermuda for the first time since 1961. Brown lost the gold challenge trophy to the United States in 1962.

The Buildings Department warned yesterday that tenants could begin "a massive rent withholding in September" unless landlords corrected violations they had allowed to persist in buildings for six months.
Another sharp slide in stock prices came to an abrupt halt at 2:30 P.M. yesterday when the General Motors Corporation announced that all its plants would resume normal operations on Monday.
Mayor Lindsay charged yesterday that the "real estate lobby" was conducting a "misguided, unfair lobbying attempt" against the proposed increase in the city's real estate tax.

The annual spring luncheon sponsored by the Fight for Sight League of Manhattan will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel on Monday.

Governor Rockefeller has finally decided to give his full support to the exemplary proposals put forward by the Taylor commission for a new state law to prevent civil service strikes. The month of delay in sending a bill to the Legislature may prove costly, now that adjournment fever is taking hold at Albany.
BONN, May 6 West Germany's Defense Minister, KaiUwe von Hassel, flew to the United States today for 14 days of talks with Government and industry officials.

The Rev. Roscoe C. Hatch of 24 Park Place, Hyde Park, N.Y., who retired in 1950 as rector of St. John's Episcopal Church an Richfield Springs, N.Y., died Thursday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. His age was 84.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Amato of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Paula Amato, to David Bernard Loveman 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Loveman 2d of Teaneck, N.J.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) The Army plans to step up recruiting of women doctors for immediate active duty as commissioned officers.

HOLLYWOOD Two middle-aged women, one of them a prominent but fading actress, were gossiping at a party the other day about the frequent visits to Hollywood of Lynda Bird Johnson, the President's daughter.

Governor Rockefeller named an eight-member committee to be headed by Garson Meyer of Rochester yesterday to advise the State Office for the Aging on how to keep New York ahead of the rest of the nation in its provision for older Americans.
JACKSON, Miss., May 6 Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that there was "no future in the race issue" for either party in the South.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 6--Gov. Haydon Burns today withdrew his approval of this city's Job Corps center as a protest arose on plans to move the center into the Soreno Hotel.

Francis T. Mylott, a member of the State Public Service Commission since 1949, died Thursday night in Monteflore Hospital, the Bronx. He would have been 68 years old next Wednesday. He lived at 34-24 84th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The United States Treasury increased today the amount of Series E savings bonds that anyone may buy in a year to $20,000. The old limit was $10,000.

Representatives of the Bishops' Commission on Ecumenical Affairs of the Roman Catholic Church and of the North American Area of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches will meet for three days, beginning Thursday, on the campus of Fordham University.

MANILA, May 6 Narciso Ramos, the Philippine Foreign Secretary, said today that the government had formally proposed diplomatic-level talks on the abrogation of economic parity for United States citizens before 1974, the year the agreement on the subject expires.

All 13 city inspectors of new construction on Staten Island and five supervisors there will be transferred Monday, Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler announced yesterday.

WINTER visitors to historic Mount Vernon, Monticello, Kenmore and Colonial Williamsburg are often surprised to see colorful flower arrangements used as centerpieces and mantel decorations. They soon realize these bouquets are not fresh, but are made from carefully selected and dried flowers, pods and leaves. Closer inspection shows that they are flowers common to most gardens--daisies, peonies, hollyhocks, wormwood, beebalm, dock and lavender.

CONCORD, N.H.--The State Historical Commission will put up a roadside marker soon honoring both a name and a nickname. EVERYBODY has been hearing a lot about "underground" films, which is a loose and ambiguous term that covers a multitude of cinematic sins. It also covers a number of interesting experimental films-- or just plain unusual movies --that don't ordinarily reach the theaters. It is a term that has been so badly applied and misunderstood that it has shrouded an area of film making that was previously known simply as avant-grade.

THOMAS CARLYLE's dictum, "Biography is the only true history," has been around to plague us for well over a century. Unfortunately forgotten is a more accurate remark by the moody master of narrative history: "A well-written life is almost as rare as a well-spent one." Generally speaking, this clutch of multiple biographies would incline Carlyle to cancel the famous remark and underline the forgotten one.

VINCENT, Italy, May 7 --The world bridge championships will end here tomorrow and barring a sensational turnover in the final session of one of the two matches not yet completed, the final ranking will be: first, Italy, winning its eighth consecutive title in this series; second, North America; third, Venezuela; fourth, the Netherland, and fifth, Thailand.

Student groups from 18 colleges in the metropolitan area have formed a committee to coordinate the volunteer work of 2,500 students in disadvantaged neighborhoods. A group of 400 women, many accompanied by their young children, staged a march in protest against the war in Vietnam yesterday through throngs of startled midtown shoppers.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 8 Power revenues of $246.8-million for the first nine months of the fiscal year that ends June 30 were $24.5-million higher than in the period a year earlier, according to the Tennessee Valley Authority's quarterly report on power operations issued here today.

He won the Kentucky Derby with a glittering, front-running effort that was pretty much of a strategic masterpiece by Don Brumfield, a jockey making his Derby debut.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York repeated over the weekend its call for greater restraint in the economy Noting that "the economy continues to push ahead into new ... high ground with undiminished vigor," the bank pointed out that this expansion has been increasingly accompanied by higher prices.

Miss Marsha Silverstein, a magna cum laude graduate of Syracuse University, was married yesterday to Dr. Harold S. Mirsky, a magna cum laude, graduate of Brooklyn College. Rabbi Alexander Burstein performed the ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria.
