LONDON, May 8 (Reuters) Representatives of Britain's 23,000 family doctors agreed today to a Government-proposed 1,000 ($2,800) pay increase spread over two years.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 8 Two years ago the armed forces were being widely hailed for ousting the leftist, inflationary regime of President Joao Goulart. Today, flickers of discontent over the role of the military are commonplace, showing up on the stage, in art and in many other areas of Brazilian life.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 8 College-trained women now want both careers and children, but professional and graduate schools have done nothing to help them, the presidents of two women colleges said here this weekend.
PITTSBURGH, May 8 Reports from steel mills indicated last week declining demand in the automobile market but strong demand elsewhere.

HEWLETT, L.I., May 8 Miss Susan Miriam Levine, daughter of Mrs. Al Feinstein of Hewlett Bay Park and the late Benjamin Alva Levine, was married today to Moshe I. Dworkin, son of Mrs. Dora Dworkin of Detroit and Dr. Louis Dworkin of Toledo, Ohio.
LONDON, May 8 (AP) More than 1,000 British university students marched to the Soviet Embassy today with a petition demanding equal rights for Jews in the Soviet Union.
CINCINNATI, May 8 (AP) Jim O'Toole, with relief help from Billy McCool, pitched and batted the Cincinnati Reds to a 2-1 victory today over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP) Willie McCovey belted a threerun, pinch-hit homer on the first pitch in the sixth inning today to propel the San Francisco Giants to a 10-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. It was the eighth straight triumph for the Giants.
ST. LOUIS, May 8 (UPI) The San Francisco Giants acquired Ray Sadecki, a lefthanded pitcher, from the St. Louis Cardinals today in exchange for Orlando Cepeda, their slugging first basemanoutfielder.
Leopold Stokowski conducted the American Symphony Orchestra in Tchaikovsky's "Marche Solenelle" at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon to commemorate the hall's 75th birthday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 (UPI) Five officials of the painters union in the Bay area were placed under police protection today following the second gangland-type of slaying of a union official within a month.

BERLIN, May 8 Theodore C. Sorensen, former adviser to President Kennedy, has warned the Germans that they could face isolation in the world unless they renounce all claims to nuclear armament and accept the loss of Germany's former provinces in the east.

KANSAS CITY, May 8 (UPI) Bob Saverine's pinch-hit single in the 10th inning Washington's second hit of the game scored Willie Kirkland from second base today and enabled the Senators to beat the Kansas City Athletics, 3-2.
LOS ANGELES, May 8 (UPI) Three incidents of violence involving Negroes and law enforcement officers occured here today and late last night.
Incoming airline passengers trying to reach Manhattan without the strike-bound buses of Carey Transportation, Inc., experienced only minor delays at the three major airports early last evening.

HONG KONG, Monday, May 9 The Chinese Communists, pressing their nationwide purge of intellectuals, today denounced Teng To, one of their leading journalists and a key political figure. He was linked to an "antiparty group."

The marriage of Miss Barbara Jean Posen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Posen of Forest Hills, Queens, to Peter Carlyle Clapman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Clapman of Kew Gardens, Queens, took place yesterday. Rabbi Salamon Faber performed the ceremony in the Forest Hills Inn.

WHITE PLAINS, May 8 At the Temple Israel Center this evening, Miss Judith K. Rabinowicz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Oskar K. Rabinowicz of Scarsdale and Jerusalem, became the bride of Charles S. Tapiero. He is the son of Mrs. Andre Boudesky of Paris and the late Messod Tapiero.

WASHINGTON, May 8 Following is a digest of reports on mechanical defects in automobiles submitted to Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, by the four major American manufacturers. The reports are for the model years 1960 to, and including, 1966.

The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday charged that the Montpelier, Vt., School Board had revoked the contract of a high school teacher because "of his civil rights activities and his criticism of local educational policies."

YONKERS, May 8--The Cross County Shopping Center here, one of the first big suburban mercantile marts in the East, has announced a $10-million improvement program that will include enclosing its malls in air-conditioned arcades protected from the weather in all seasons.

Miss Carol Lynn Spector, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel V. Spector of New York, was married last evening to Gerald Ross Rodder. He is the son of Mrs. Samuel Rodder of Fresno, Calif., and the late Mr. Rodder.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 8 Officials here rolled out the municipal red carpet this weekend for two young women from Massachusetts who were turned out of the police station here on the night of Feb. 25, when their sports car broke down.

MIAMI, May 8 Dan Topping, the president of the New York Yankees, denied last night that the Columbia Broadcasting Company, the principal owner of the team, had had anything to do with his decision to dismiss Johnny Keane as manager.

BOEUF BOURGUIGNON, Spanish paella, eggplant parmesan, chicken momi the names roll down the cafeteria menu boards like exotic flowers in a garden of dai sies, a passport to food adventure for thousands of business people. Price: a single dollar bill.

Dr. Fabian Dane, president of the New York Academy of General Dentistry, died Saturday at the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 58 years old and lived at 142 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn.

ST. VINCENT, Italy, May 8 The Blue team of Italy won its eighth consecutive world championship when 13 days of play ended here this afternoon. In the final session the North American team gained 20 points, 46-26, but as expected the Italian lead of 77 points was unassailable.

NEW HAVEN, May 18 Eugene V. Rostow, Sterling Professor of Law and Public Affairs at Yale, will become the new master of the university's Trumbull College on July 1. His appointment was announced today by Yale's president, Kingman Brewster Jr.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., May 8 Dr. Glen Haydon, head of the department of music and Kenan Professor of Music at the University of North Carolina, died of a heart ailment today at the North Carolina Memorial Hospital. He was 69 years old.

LONDON, May 8 (UPI) President Gamal Abdel Nasser said in a television interview tonight that the United Arab Republic was thinking of developing nuclear weapons because "Israel is working in this field."
PALERMO, Sicily, May 8 (AP) Willy Mairesse of Belgium and Herbert Muller of Germany drove their PorscheCarrera 6 to victory today in the 50th Targa Florio road race.

HAMDEN, Conn., May 8 In Congregation Mishkan Israel yesterday, Miss Harriet Teresa Nahum, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis H. Nahum of New Haven, became the bride of Dr. Emanuel Rice, son of Mrs. Samuel Rice of New York and the late Mr. Rice. Rabbi Robert E. Goldburg performed the ceremony.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 8 Haitians have taken increasingly to asking one another, "Did you go to early mass?"

An estimated decline of $1billion in savings accounts at savings banks and savings-andloan associations has accentuated the fear that a shortage of credit for home building may develop during 1966, a survey of government and trade association economists indicated yesterday.
Bronx House, one of the more than 59 Greater New York Fund agencies in that
LONDON, May 8 (UPI) Heavy cigarette smoking more than doubles the risk of coronary disease, the Office of Health Economics reported today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 8 Peter T. Cooper of Greenwich, Conn., sailed Mischief, which he owns with two partners, to a 2-minute-28-second victory in a 14-boat International Class race on Long Island Sound today.

The annual patrons party of Plays for Living, a division of the Family Service Association of America, will be held tomorrow evening in the auditorium of the Time-Life Building. Mrs. Hiram D. Black and Mrs. Valentino Sarra are co-chairmen of the event.
WASHINGTON, May 8 Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson, the columnists, sent a letter to Senator Thomas J. Dodd today requesting him to be present to make a deposition in their lawyer's office on May 16.

HOUSTON, May 8 Yesterday's Texas election results confirmed the lesson of the Alabama primary that free access to the polls is no guarantee of victories for liberals in the South. Texas liberal and labor forces challenging the supremacy of Gov. John B. Connally's conservative Democratic estab ...
SAIGON, May 8 American fighter-bombers have cut the four major railroads serving Hanoi, a United States military spokesman asserted tonight.

Chief Justice Earl Warren urged the Jewish Theological Seminary of America last night to establish an institute on law and ethics to explore the effect of ethical insights on the law and, in turn, the effect of the law on ethical insights.
HOUSTON, May 8 The new $100,000 Houston Champions international golf tournament was rescheduled for Nov. 17 to 20 today because rains made the Champions Golf Club course unplayable.

ARMONK, N.Y., May 8 All eight seeded players, led by Donald Rubell of New York, reached the quarter-final round of the Westchester County tennis championship today. Because of rain, all the matches were played on the Armonk Club's indoor courts.
State mediators will meet today with representatives of 18,000 union taxi drivers and owners of the city's fleet cabs in an effort to avert a strike threatened for after next Sunday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 8 More than 3,000 people jammed into the Rutgers University gymnasium here this afternoon to hear Vladimir Horowitz play. It was the 62year-old pianist's first recital outside New York since 1953, and there a was the usual Horowitz hysteria before, during and after the concert. Mr. Horowitz played at Carnegie Hall last May 9 and again this April 17.

DALAT, South Vietnam, May 8 (UPI) Military authorities clamped a 24-hour curfew on Dalat today in the wake of renewed anti-Government demonstrations by students and ordered demonstrators to surrender themselves in 48 hours.
MOSCOW, May 8 (Reuters) Russia remained silent today on President Johnson's call for a treaty banning military activity and preventing sovereignty claims on the moon.

The New York Mets are an amazing team, all right. They allowed the Chicago Cubs two hits in the first game of a double-header yesterday and lost it, then allowed the Cubs five hits in the second game and won it.

AGOURA, Calif., May 8 A young musician named Joseph Spencer, attired in flowing gray robes and leotards, strolled through the meadow, his blackrobed girl friend trailing behind him at the end of a long iron chain. Occasionally he would playfully tug at the chain and command, "Faster, wench!"

Hearings will be held in Washington on May 24 on a bill to make poor neighborhoods, like Harlem in New York and Watts in Los Angeles eligible for Federal economic aid that up to now has been available only to whole cities.

WASHINGTON, May 8 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that he was confident that Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam would not delay elections and the transfer of power to a civilian government.
Hermann E. Adickes, a banker and yachtsman, died of a stroke yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 4 Sherman Avenue, in Bronxville, N.Y.
HOUSTON, May 8 (AP) Joe Morgan drove in the second of two runs in the ninth inning today to give the Houston Astros a 5-4 victory over the Atlanta Braves. Two errors helped the Astros' rally.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 8--Serendipity, an aged chestnut gelding from the stables of Dr. and Mrs. H. M. S. Smith champion, Highfield's Tulip, of Hanover, N. J., captured the large pony hunter championship at the Junior Essex Troop Horse Show today.

SAIGON, May 8 (AP) Premier Nguyen Cao Ky's military regime moved today to stifle any political agitation that might arise from the Premier's pledge to stay in power for another year. Its censors blotted the pledge out of Saigon's Vietnamese-language newspapers.

WHAT the fashionable woman wears under her short skirts in the next few months is likely to be stockings, that extend up to her waist. She will solve the problem of garters showing by simply eliminating them, hosiery manufacturers believe.

WASHINGTON, May 8 The United States and Europe are proposing to strengthen their cooperation in the peaceful development of atomic energy through a record-breaking sale of plutonium the fissionable material once used exclusively to make atomic bombs.
Cesar Leon, a guitarist from Equador who has studied extensively in Spain, made his Town Hall debut last night under the auspices of Andres M. Arrata, Consul General of Ecuador in New York.

LONDON, May 8 (AP) Three Rhodesian civil servants arrived today for secret talks with officials of the British Government on whether a deal is possible with the white settler regime, which declared its independence from Britain last November.

BALTIMORE, May 8 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles hit five home runs, including Frank Robinson's record shot out of Memorial Stadium, and trounced Cleveland, 8-2 and 8-3, in a double-header today. Baltimore thus moved into a first-place tie with the Indians in the American League.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., May 8 (AP) Linda Metheny of Tuscola, Ill., added two National Amateur Athletic Union titles last night, taking a first in both the free-exercise and balance-beam competition in the national gymnastics meet.
AN evening of exalted theater came to television last night in a revelation of Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman" that will stand as the supreme understanding of the tragedy of Willy Loman.

LOS ANGELES, May 8 (AP)--A policy committee representing the nation's independent oil operators voted today to try to plug loopholes in the Federal oil-import control program today and to postpone any renewed effort for a major overhauling of the program until next fall.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 8 President Johnson announced today the nomination of Bernard L. Boutin, deputy director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, to be head of the Small Business Administration.

Enoch Perkins of Taconic Road, Greenwich, Conn., vice president of William Mueller Co., Inc., a mining concern with headquarters in New York and the Netherlands, died Saturday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old.
TEL AVIV, May 18 Three young Israelis confessed in a Haifa court today that they had been Egyptian spies. They will be sentenced June 14.
Representative William E. Ryan, Democrat of Manhattan, endorsed yesterday plans for a private review of the Selective Service Act aimed at providing nonmilitary alternatives to the draft.

GLENSIDE, Pa., May 8 Mr. and Mrs. Hans-Herbert Walter have announced the engagement of Mrs. Walter's daughter, Miss Christine Gesa Martinoff, to Owen Chabot Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Chabot Smith of Weston, Conn.

ALAMEDA, Calif., May 8 (AP) Superior Court Judge Rupert G. Crittenden, who presided last year over the mass trial of University of California sit-in demonstrators, died today, apparently of a heart attack, after swimming with his son in the pool of the Encinal Yacht Club here. Judge Crittenden was 53 years old.

Earnings before taxes of Roan Selection Trust, Ltd., the African mining company, rose to 13,432,000 ($37,610,000) in the nine months ended March 31 from 11,380,000 ($31,864,000) in the period a year earlier.

TRENTON, May 8 Ch. Fezziwig Raggedy Andy, an Old English sheepdog belonging to Mr. and Mrs. Hendrik Van Rensselaer of Basking Ridge, N.J., strolled impassively with his deep rolling gait today to the best-in-show award of the Trenton Kennel Club event. It was a big victory because there were 3,092 dogs entered and there are few shows in the country of that size.

Miss Amy Gail Granowitz, daughter of Mrs. Shirlie Newman of New York and Sanford Monroe Granowitz of New York and Wilton, Conn., was married to Howard Rosenbloom yesterday evening. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Rosenbloom of Baltimore.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8 Kauai King was the center of attraction at the barns at Churchill Downs this morning, and quite properly, too. The Maryland-bred winner of the Kentucky Derby put in an ordinary day of rest after yesterday's splendid effort, but many fans came out to see him anyway.
DETROIT, May 8 The marriage of Miss Ronnie Lee Durchlag and Roger Alan Brooks, graduates of the University of Michigan, took place in Temple Israel today. Rabbi Leon Fram performed the ceremony.

A LAN KUSSACK won first prize in the Marshall Chess Club Candidates' Tournament recently, thereby qualifying for next year's club championship. He scored 8-1 in a nine-round Swiss system that included 34 players.
MIDLAND, Tex., May 8 (UPI) Kathy Whitworth got birdies on the last two holes today to defeat Mickey Wright by a stroke and win the Tall City open, her first tournament victory on the tour this year.
Lee Sims, pianist and composer who was a pioneer in coast-to-coast radio broadcasting, died Saturday at his home, the Sherman Square Studios. He was 68 years old, and had had cancer for three years.

A mediator appointed Friday by Mayor Lindsay met for four hours yesterday with representatives of 10 newspaper unions and officers of the World Journal Tribune, Inc., in an effort to resolve the 14-day-old strike against the merged New York newspapers.

CHICAGO, May 8 (UPI) Gates Brown doubled home two runs in the 11th inning today to give the Detroit Tigers a 3-1 decision over the Chicago White Sox. The second game of the scheduled double-header was postponed because of cold weather.

ROME, May 8 An Italian journalist who says he was given the only known interview with Ernesto Che Guevara since the Communist leader's disappearance from Cuba defended the article today against charges of forgery. He said he thought the interview had been granted to spur revolutionary morale among the Latins.
Mayor Lindsay has reappraised the city's public school system, finding it "the finest in the country."
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 8 A strong plea for a meeting of the Western Hemisphere heads of state to define the future of the Alliance for Progress was made today by President Raul Leoni of Venezuela.

William J. Halley, former president of P. Lorillard Company, the oldest tobacco company in the country, died of complications following pneumonia yesterday in his home at 85-33 215th Street in Queens Village, Queens. He was about 70 years old.

CANNES, France, May 8 Orson Welles, a perennial favorite with the crowds at Cannes film festivals, received his usual roaring welcome when he arrived tonight at the Palais des Festivals for the showing of his new film, "Chimes at Midnight." But the welcome the film is likely to receive from audiences that venerate Shakespeare more than they venerate Welles is something else again.

Jamaicans are about to get weaving in a big way to turn their production of craft wares into an organized industry. The colorful embroidery and woven baskets, bags, hats and mats Jamaica's traditional tourist souvenirs will just be ...
Completing a $10,610,887 transaction, the 72 Wall Street Company, headed by Isidore Korein, has taken title to the office building at 72 Wall Street.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 8 The sons of two of America's most prominent families are running for Congress in a campaign that tends to center on issues of great wealth and aancestral achievement.
LONDON, May 8 "If something really drastic is not done soon, the whole system must crack."

CRACOW, Poland, May 8 Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski strode the red-draped streets of this ancient royal capital of Poland today in a jubilant procession while most of Cracow's half-million people marched with him or acclaimed him thunderously from sidewalks, balconies and windows.
PARIS, May 8 (UPI) Toplevel delegations of American and French business leaders held an unexpected meeting tonight and began thrashing out French charges of an "American dollar invasion" of Europe.

PARIS, May 8 (UPI) Under chilly, overcast skies President de Gaulle laid a wreath today on the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at the Arc de Triomphe to lead France in observances marking the 21st anniversary of V-E Day.
Half the time on his job, John Onichowski pushes a rhythmic brush on the downbeat along the curbstone on Park Avenue from 34th to 42d Streets, to the brassy accompaniment of honking horns.
Baylor Robinson of 71 Bedford Street, general sales manager and a designer for the Pageant Wallpaper Corporation, New York, died of cancer in St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday. His age was 40.

Robert F. Hurleigh, president of the Mutual Broadcasting System, will announce today that a corporation organized for the purpose has been granted an option to purchase the national radio network by July 1.

ROME, May 8 (UPI) Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy eliminated fourth-seeded Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., from the Italian international tennis tournament today whipping the top-ranking American, 6-4, 6-1, 6-2, in a quarter-final match.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 8 A feeling of relief, tinged with sincere sympathy for the plight of Johnny Keane but basically hopeful that things would be better, permeated the atmosphere of the New York Yankee clubhouse last night and today.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 8 (AP)--Rico Petrocelli drove in five runs with a grand-slam home run and a single in the opener and George Scott and Dalton Jones hit homers in the finale as the Boston Red Sox swept a double-header from the Minnesota Twins today, 8-1 and 4-1.

More by accident than effort, the United States at the moment enjoys its best relations in a long time with nearly every country of Africa north of the Zambesi. The standings of the Soviet Union and Communist China have never been lower.
A Bronx grocer was seriously wounded yesterday as he scuffled with two holdup men in his store, the police reported.
NORTH CREEK, N.Y., May 8 (AP) Alan McGibben of Jericho, Vt., drove his small kayak through 7 miles of rapids today to win the ninth downriver White Water Derby near this Adirondack community.
WASHINGTON, May 8 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.

BUPRANG, South Vietnam, May 1 The 70 men of an American paratrooper reconnaissance platoon were about to walk at night through a mine field and into an area believed to be occupied by 30 times their number of North Vietnamese troops.

ON Wall Street yesterday, nobody seemed to be talking about Mother's Day or the Kentucky Derby or summer vacations or even whether the New York Stock Exchange might take its buttonwood tree and move out of town. "Everybody I know," said one broker, digging into
CAIRO, May 9 Premier Kosygin's visit to Egypt comes at a time when relations between the United States and the Nasser regime are deteriorating.

New York pumps more poisons into its air per square mile than any other major city in the United States 730 pounds of pollution for every resident in the course of a year. Only the city's open topography and the prevailing westerly winds have so far prevented a major disaster. But reliance on these factors is not enough; the time has come for resolute municipal action.

Joint bargaining sessions between the World Journal Tribune, Inc., and three newspaper unions began yesterday under the direction of David L. Cole, the nationally known mediator who was brought into the dispute by Mayor Lindsay.
The New York Mets open a three-game series against the Houston Astros tonight, but their eyes will be on the calendar, which, says that tomorrow is the final date for cutting major league rosters.

BEIRUT, Lebanon May 9 The Syrian Government radio declared tonight that "suspicious moves by reactionary elements at home and concentrations of Jordanian troops on Syria's southern border and of Israeli troops on Syria's southwestern border" were parts of a connected design.

Brotherhood-in-Action, a human-relations conference and training center, has arranged a dinner for Monday in the Americana's Imperial Ballroom to honor achievements in religious, human and civil rights.
The Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria will be the scene for the annual donor luncheon of the New York chapter of Hadassah tomorrow.

CONNELLSVILLE, Pa., May 9 (UPI) Attorney General Walter E. Alessandroni of Pennsylvania and three other persons were found dead tonight in the wreckage of a twin-engine plane on Laurel Ridge, six miles east of here.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 Merging the managements, facilities and operations of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads "will be the biggest, most complex and most challenging undertaking of its kind in the history of American industry," Allen J. Greenough, president of the Pennsylvania, said here today.

NATHAN (NAT) BADER likes the scenery at the Colony almost as much as the food. The labels on the coats and suits worn by the wellgroomed luncheon patrons are not visible, but Mr. Bader knows that a respectable number of them read "Originala."
HOLLYWOOD, May 9 A succession of leading educators warned today than the American university had entered a period of high peril that could lead to renewed student protest.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The appointment of Miss Margaret McLaughlin as chief nursing officer of the United States Public Health Service with rank of assistant surgeon general was announced today by Acting Surgeon General Leo J. Gehrig.
AMHERST, Mass., May 9 An Amherst College senior was charged today with assault and battery and the use of a harmful drug, believed to be LSD.

HONG KONG, May 9 Communist China announced today that it had successfully detonated a device containing "thermonuclear material." The Peking radio said the ex plosion, third in a series of nuclear tests, took place yesterday at 4 P.M., Peking time, over western China.
Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman," which delighted the critics Sunday night, also did well in the ratings but not well enough to displace "Bonanza" as king of the 9-to-10 P.M. slot.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Millions of workers now covered by private pension plans probably will never draw benefits from them, Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz testified today.
The spot rate on the British pound improved slightly yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7935, up points from its level of last Friday.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)--Senator Mike Mansfield proposed today that the United States recognize Mongolia, a Communist-controlled nation between Communist China and the Soviet Union in mainland Asia.

OSSINING, N.Y., May 9 William C. Hay, an Ossining real estate broker, drowned yesterday in a bathtub in his home on Underhill Road here. The Westchester County Medical Examiner's Office said the death was accidental. Mr. Hay was 82 years old.
Police station art is normally limited to posters of fugitives from justice, uninspiring mug shots above drab descriptions of the criminals and their crimes.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) A Government soil scientist cautions that pollution of the nation's soil could eventually render it unfit for food production.
Yesterday's sharp decline on Wall Street makes clear that there has been something seriously wrong in the market. It does not follow, however, that the economy is in for trouble.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 9 The family insurance agency of Robert A. Curcio, Suffolk Republican chairman, announced today that it would relinquish a major package of political patronage, the $880,000 county insurance program.

The name of R. Burdell Bixby, chairman of the State Thruway Authority and law partner of former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, was injected yesterday into the conspiracy and bribery trial of L. Judson Morhouse, former Republican state chairman.
TEL AVIV, May 9 David Ben-Gurion entertained Konrad Adenauer today in Sdeh Boker, the dusty Negev kibbutz where Mr. Ben-Gurion settled after he stepped down as Premier.
CHICAGO, May 9 The Most Rev. Bernard J. Sheil, 80-yearold founder of the Catholic Youth Organization, has been replaced, as Pastor of St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Parish.
DETROIT, May 9 (AP) The nation's auto building pace was slowed today as Ford joined General Motors in reducing May production schedules.

Consolidated net income of the Anaconda Company in the first quarter rose to $26,023,000, equal to $2.38 a share, from $19,260,000, or $1.77 a share in the initial three months last year, Charles M. Brinckerhoff, chairman, reported yesterday.
Mrs. Mary B. Nicholas, active for the last decade in developing city housing programs, has submitted her resignation as executive assistant to the Housing and Development Coordinator.

The Lindsay administration has been ordered to appear in court today to answer charges that its plan to revamp the Police Department's complaint review board is "illegal and invalid" and would create a "kangaroo court."
WASHINGTON, May 9--United States planes dropped 7,200 pounds of tear gas-producing powder on a Vietcong headquarters northwest of Saigon yesterday, Defense Department sources said today.
BERLIN, May 9 East Germany today put into operation an atomic power station at Rheinsberg, north of Berlin, the first such plant in all of Germany.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 9 (UPI) Indonesia's economic chief urged the Government today to consider private businessmen as "friends, in many cases even as partners and no longer as enemies."
THERE was an air of expectancy on a recent morning in Bonwit Teller's eighth-floor shoe department.

City antipoverty officials have been forced to call back for revision their entire program for the fiscal year beginning July 1 because they have approved projects costing about $20-million more than the city is scheduled to receive from Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 9 President Johnson's proposal for a United Nations treaty to prevent sovereign claims to the moon and planets represents a hope that arms control may be easier to attain in space than on earth.
Active in the fight against tuberculosis and other respiratory diseases is the Queens- boro Tuberculosis and Health Association, one of the Greater New York Fund's 425 affiliated agencies.
Edmund G. Burke, a former Bethel, Ohio, newsboy who became a leading real-estate developer here, died Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at the Regency Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 9 Important people are disappearing. Mao Tse-tung is the latest. Before him there was Che Guevara: One day they are right there in front of their publics flailing away at old devil imperialism or ordering the thought police to let a hundred flowers bloom, and the next they are just gone from the face of the earth.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9--Dr. Harold Stein, professor of public and international affairs at Princeton University, died last night at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 9 Senator Robert F. Kennedy called today for greater attention by the United States to the revolutionary currents at work in Latin America, and for a closer political identification of the Administration with leaders and groups that represent these currents.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 9 Following is the text of President Johnson's proclamation on the 82d birthday of former President Harry S. Truman:

JACKSON, Miss., May 9 (UPI) The State Supreme Court ruled "null and void" today the city of Clarksdale's parade permit ordinance and threw out the conviction of a civil rights worker for parading without a permit.
Genesco, Inc., has agreed to impose a series of tight controls to limit its trading in its own common stock by two employe stock-purchase plans and a company trust.
The police are investigating charges that LSD the hallucinatory drug, is easily obtainable in and around the High School of Music and Art at Convent Avenue and 135th Street.

Dr. George James, dean of the Mount Sinai Medical School and former Health Commissioner of New York City, was named yesterday as the recipient of the 1966 Meritorious Service Award of the National Foundation of Neuromuscular Diseases.

EVERYONE knew, of course, that the guillotine would land on the exposed neck of Johnny Keane. The only ques- tion was when the tumbrils would roll. Perhaps the Yankees were a little ashamed of what they felt obliged to do. They waited until the team was 3,000 miles away before ordering the sacrifice of their only available scapegoat, the manager.

LONDON, May 9 Spring and Noel Coward have arrived together in London this year. There is no novelty in Spring's coming it always does, sooner or later. But Mr. Coward has been absent from the London stage for 13 years.

THE research that scientists have done on the dolphin, which is regarded as one of the more intelligent sea creatures, indicates that the fish sometimes has impulses that can be helpful to human beings.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 A Federal Court jury was dismissed here tonight after it reported it was unable to reach a verdict in a controversial case of a rancher who shot a bald eagle, the national symbol, and a golden eagle.

PIMLICO, Md., May 9 (UPI) Paul Kallai brought Exceedingly to the fore heading into the stretch today and the 3year-old held off a strong bid by Red Music to win the $28,750 Survivor Stakes by a neck at Pimlico.
HONG KONG, May 9 A struggle within the Chinese Communist party appeared to be deepening today.

TURIN, Italy, May 2 The International Center for Advanced Technical and Vocational Training to teach the teachers of the skills needed to speed economic development in Asia, Africa and South America is completing its first series of courses here.

YONKERS, May 9 Atomic Sir, the 17-10 favorite to win the second race at Yonkers Raceway tonight, appeared to have the one-mile pace locked up. Suddenly, at the 16th pole, the 10-year-old chestnut gelding went offstride and the break also hurt a lot of chalk-players.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board assured the Hughes Tool Company and Trans World Airlines today that it would terminate proceedings involved in their long-standing and recently resolved stock ownership dispute.

Destro was the right filly indeed for many of the 28,068 fans at Aqueduct yesterday. The 3-year-old daughter of Ribot, racing in the silks of Ogden Phipps, was the 1-2 choice and won the six-furlong feature race with a thrilling final rush in 1:11 3-5.

The 13th game of the 24game title chess match between Tigran Petrosian, the world champion, and Boris Spassky, both of the Soviet Union, was postponed in Moscow last night because Petrosian was ill, according to Tass, the Soviet news agency. No details were given of the champion's illness.

LOS ANGELES, May 9 (UPI) The Occidental Petroleum Company said today that its Jefferson Lake Sulphur subsidiary had been granted sulphur rights by the State of Texas to 2,560 acres three miles offshore from Galveston.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 9 Mr. and Mrs. John Martin Johnston of Glen Cove and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Anne Johnston, to John Winston Elting, son of Mrs. James O. Heyworth of Libertyville, Ill., and Winston Elting of Chicago.

A 1,070-seat chamber-music hall is being planned for the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, William Schuman, president, announced yesterday. It will be named for Alice Tully, a music patron and former singer.
CORDELE, Ga., May 9 (AP) A Superior Court judge sentenced an Atlanta Negro to a year in public work camps after his conviction of flag desecration during a racial demonstration.

NEW DELHI, May 9 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared in Parliament today, that the Government would not permit the United States Central Intelligence Agency to use the proposed Indian-American Educational Foundation as a cover for its operations.
SAIGON, May 9 More than 14 months after the first United States combat troops arrived here, the progress of the war in Vietnam remains difficuit to assess.

NEW HAVEN, May 9 Harry W. Dorigan, a trustee of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad since 1961, died last night in Yale-New Haven Hospital after a short illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 468 Whitney Avenue here.
In a tense session, May potato futures rose sharply in heavy trading yesterday to close at $4.60 a hundred pounds, up from $4.27 cents on Friday.
The London stock market moved lower yesterday, reflecting concern over the Wall Street trend and the possible effects of seamen's strike in Britain.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 9 (AP) Frank L. Andrews, president of the New Yorker Hotel in New York from 1940 to 1954, died here today. He was 74 years old. Mr. Andrews moved to Miami Beach on 1955. Survivors include his widow, Dorothy Dunn Andrews, and a daughter, Mrs. Edward Schellenberg Jr. of Dallas, Pa.
Abraham Shamos, senior member of the law firm of Guggenheimer Untermyer, 80 Pine Street, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 120 East 89th Street.

The track coaches who had conceded next Saturday's Metropolitan Intercollegiate championship to Manhattan received a rude and unexpected jolt yesterday when one of their number claimed the title for his team.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 9 (AP) Ford's controversial single overhead cam racing engine will be unveiled on a stock car track Wednesday for a test run, with Fred Lorenzen as the driver, a spokesman close to the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing said today.

Just what role the long-range manned bomber will fill in future wars may be open to some doubt. But one point is clear in the sharp dispute over that issue between Secretary of Defense McNamara and the House Armed Services Committee: There is growing resentment in Congress against what the committee called the "passive role of supine acquiescence in programs handed to it by the Department of Defense."
ORANGE PARK, Fla., May 9 (UPI) Tornadic winds ripped the roofs from six houses, damaged a dozen other houses and uprooted trees here today. Two minor injuries were reported.

ALBANY, May 9 Republican legislative leaders are expected to announce this week the first step in a plan to put the City University under the control of the State University. The step is expected to be included in the Republican leaders' program to extend aid to the City University.
ALBANY, May 9 Two joint legislative committees declared today that the John Birch Society was a political organization and that any policeman who belonged to it violated the Penal Law.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 9 (UPI) Steve Hopper, a junior from Dickinson, won the Middle Atlantic Conference collegiate golf championship today, and Lehigh won the team title at the Saucon Valley Country Club.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 9 Graziano Zara, a 63-year-old contractor, received a suspended sentence here today in Supreme Court after pleading guilty to the theft of topsoil from a state highway project.

LONDON, May 9 (AP) Cassius Clay donned his cloak of humility today when the heavyweight champion landed after a delayed flight from New York for his May 21 title fight with Henry Cooper. The plane was delayed for four hours because of fog.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP) Johnny Podres of the Los Angeles Dodgers was traded today to the Detroit Tigers for cash and a player to be named later.

WASHINGTON, May 9 The United States is spending $560million on supplies and equipment for the civilian economy of South Vietnam in the year ending June 30 and a larger outlay is planned for the year ahead.
PARIS, May 9 (UPI) American and French business leaders met anew today for private talks on difficulties arising from the growing American economic influence in Europe.
ABSECON, N.J., May 9 The United States Maritime Administrator, Nicholas Johnson, said here, today that "we may very well end up sinking our fleet in the name of preserving our shipyards."

The Bolshoi Ballet not only could have danced all night it all but did. Early yesterday morning and not that early at that the indefatigable Russians went on twisting and swirling, laughing and talking, eating and drinking and, above all, dancing.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 10 (AP) Premier Chou En-lai has warned that, if United States troops attempt to invade Communist China, "they will certainly be annihilated," even if nuclear weapons are used in the attack.
WASHINGTON, May 9 The Pentagon urged Congress today not to bar it from shifting over gradually to a competitive basis for its worldwide military ocean freight business.

Consomme risi-bisi and chicken tidbits wakasaqi head the menu at the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria today for the 33d annual luncheon and fashion show of the Greater New York Women's Division of the National Jewish Hospital in Denver.

VLADIMIR Nabokov's objections to the contrary, it has never been possible to talk about the anti-heroes of his fiction without allusions to the imagined character of their creator. There are several immediate and obvious reasons for this.

HOW do you like the way the Yankees dropped the pilot the other night? They scuttled Johnny Keane 3,000 miles from New York, with a three-hour time-zone difference, missing the early editions of the two New York newspapers that were still publishing on Sunday in the
Bond prices, reacting largely to the steep decline in the stock market, advanced sharply yesterday.

PRESIDENT JOHNSON reflected softly, humorous- ly and wistfully on his boyhood in southcentral Texas in an hour-long documentary film shown last night on the National Broadcasting Company's network. In telling of his fondness for the country life along the sloping banks of the Pedernales River, the President left no doubt of the serenity he finds at the place where his family's roots go back four generations.

A number of grandiose plans have been suggested for deserted Ellis Island, but three iron workers who had ideas of their own were arrested on charges of stealing 2,000 pounds of copper cabling worth $1 a pound on the scrap market.
An attempt to settle the four-day-old strike by bus drivers of Carey Transportation, Inc. is scheduled for tomorrow by Abraham A. Desser of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration has formally closed the door against consideration of any proposal to test Krebiozen in humans.

The British American Oil Company, Ltd., Toronto, is planning to sell a wholly owned subsidiary in the United States the British American Oil Producing Company to the Toronto concern's American parent, the Gulf Oil Corporation, for $182,544,000.

A 24-year-old narcotics addict arrested Sunday night on burglary charges was identified early yesterday as the "polite and courteous" prowler who had terrorized Morning Side Heights residents last month.

TRENTON, May 9 A constitutional amendment that would bar the future imposition of a stock-transfer tax, should the New York Stock Exchange decide to move to New Jersey, was introduced in the Legislature today.
The Sand and Sea Club of Santa Monica, Calif., captured the National Amateur Athletic Union volleyball championship Sunday after losing the first games in the final two matches.
BRUSSELS, May 9--Memories of comradeship and a wartime struggle against a common enemy were rekindled in Belgium today as Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip arrived for a five-day state visit.

WHEN I began dreaming about new methods of garbage disposal a couple of weeks ago, I knew it was about time the Air Pollution Task Force finished up its work," said Norman Cousins, the group's chairman, as he drove down to City Hall yesterday afternoon.
Reform Democrats threatened yesterday to stage a primary fight for the Democratic nomination for Surrogate.
Three boys searching for a quiet place where they would not be bothered by anyone, wound up yesterday afternoon on the top of a tower of the Williamsburg Bridge.

Mrs. William M. Baer of Hollis, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joscelind Bergen Baer, to Dr. Lauro deBosis Storm Halstead, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon B. Halstead of White Plains.
ATLANTA, May 9 (AP) Two-run homers by Pete Rose and Art Shamsky in the third inning led the Cincinnati Reds to a 7-4 victory over the Braves tonight. The loss was the Braves' third straight.

DENVILLE, N.J., May 9 Danny Williams Jr. of The Knoll and Mike Burke of Deal set the pace as 32 pros qualified today at the Rockaway River Country Club for the third annual $25,000 Dodge open on May 1820 on the same course.

Jim Ryun and Dyrol Burleson will meet in the Amateur Athletic Union's national championship mile at Randalls Island, Ray Lumpp, the meet director, said yesterday. The meet will be held June 25 and 26.
LONDON, May 9 Representatives of the Rhodesian and British Governments began exploratory talks today in an atmosphere of secrecy.
East River Park will be the site this summer of a new series of concerts by the Goldman Band in addition to the band's regular series in Central and Prospect Parks.
KANSAS CITY, May 9 (UPI) The Kansas City Athletics got four runs in the fourth inning tonight and went on to whip the Boston Red Sox, 6-1.
A new plan was introduced yesterday by the Treasury Department to stimulate the use of United States Savings Bonds by corporations as charitable and educational contributions.
The State Department may accept a controversial plan for raising liability limits on international flights even though the plan may not have the full backing of domestic airlines.

WASHINGTON, May 9 Frederick L. Deming, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, warned today against "overly aggressive behavior on the part of some banks in competing for time deposits."
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 9 Old friends poured in on Harry S. Truman today and flooded him with memories.
At 4 P.M. (Peking time) on May 9, 1966, China successfully conducted over its western areas a nuclear explosion that contained thermonuclear material.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 9 A pair of cigar-chewing young professionals from the Pine Hollow Country Club were among the pace-setters today after the opening round of the Long Island Golf Association open championship.
WASHINGTON, May 9 United States officials surmised today that Communist China, with today's small-sized nuclear test in Sinkiang Province, was on the verge of developing a thermonuclear bomb.
The direction was down yesterday for most issues on the American Stock Exchange but the pace of trading was considerably less hectic than last Friday.
ALBANY, May 9 The Legislature's Republican and Democratic leaders announced agreement today on dividing control of 34 joint committees that have appropriations totaling $1,915,000.
Joseph Colombo, the immaculately dressed reputed head of the Mafia's Profaci "family," went to jail yesterday for the first time in his life.
There's a little metal plate on a door High in the Seagram Building inscribed with the name of an advertising agency, the "Lawrence Brown Co." Written in ink on that plate is: "$12,000,000 agency."
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 9 Congress was informed today that the new Federal education program for disadvantaged children was in many areas not reaching those who needed it most.
SAIGON, May 9 (UPI)--The relevant section of Premier Ky's news conference in Cantho Saturday, as recorded by the Voice of America, follows. The questions were asked by newsmen.
CANNES, France, May 9 The British staged a fast recovery from the embarrassments they got involved in Saturday with the showing of their new film "Alfie" tonight at the Cannes Film Festival.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 9 The Apawamis team of Cotton Dunn, a professional, and Ray Konopka and the Mount Kisco Country Club entry of Bob Johnson and Bill Camph tied for first place with a bestball score of 65 in the Westchester County Golf Association opening pro-amateur tourament on the Winged Foot's West course today.

"For the first time, I feel like a man," said Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson. "My family always treated me like a baby, put me in a baby carriage and pushed me through life. Now I feel like I got a mind of my own. I feel more mature. I can think for myself."

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) United States cotton production declined slightly last year but average output, per acre soared nine pounds higher than the previous record, the Agriculture Department reported today.
The Union Carbide Corporation announced here yesterday the appointment of James R. Johnstone as a vice president and of Fred B. O'Mara to succeed him as president of its Carbon Products division.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) A Federal court made permanent today an injunction barring the railroad firemen from striking in an effort to restore 18,000 jobs abolished by an arbitration board two years ago.

ATHERTON, Calif., May 9 Mrs. Ellis Jones has announced the engagement of her daugh- ter, Miss Elizabeth Ellis Fenno, to Dr. Arthur Adolph Bieder- mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Carl. Biedermann of Berkeley.

BELMONT, Mass., May 9 (UPI). The John Birch Society, which has been losing money and lagging in recruitment of new members, plans no cutback in its campaign to extend its influence, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, May 9 The State Department has submitted new passport legislation to Congress redefining and to an extent limiting the Government's authority to prevent travel to certain countries.

The Intramerican Life Corporation, which was described as "the nation's first multiracial financial enterprise," outlined plans yesterday for its recently licensed subsidiary, the Intramerica Life Insurance Company.
WASHINGTON, May 9 Sources here indicated today that President Johnson was considering a shift in three natural resources posts.
A 19-year-old part-time laborer was charged yesterday with the slaying in Brooklyn of a secretary last Tuesday.

Smith, Barney Co., Inc., announced yesterday the elections of C. Cheever Hardwick and Charles W. Kennard as vice chairmen of the board. The investment banking and brokerage concern also named its president, Nelson Schaenen, to the additional post of chairman of the executive committee.
NEW DELHI, May 9 (AP) India reported today signs of Communist Chinese troop movements near her northern border and said that on the Pakistan front there had been 14 "incidents" and some firing.
Milton E. Mohr was elected yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the Bunker-Ramo Corporation, a New York producer of electronic process control systems.
WASHINGTON, May 9 Administration forces were frankly gloomy tonight as they moved toward a House showdown tomorrow on providing funds for the President's rent supplement program.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 9 (AP) The Alabama Power Company and the Southern Electric Generating Company filed suits today seeking $6million in damages from the United Mine Workers of America.
WHAT and the passing thought struck home like an arrow were they trying to do to my mind? It was the only thing that did strike home during an extraordinarily long/short evening.

Last week's one-cent-a pound reduction in the price of lead will reduce annual earnings of the St. Joseph Lead Company by about 41 cents a share, Francis Cameron, president, told the annual meeting here yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 9 Diplomats and United Nations officials will be guests at a concert tomorrow night given by the North American Air Defense Command Band at Carnegie Hall.
ROME, May 9 (UPI) Roy Emerson of Australia, gained the semi-finals of the Italian international tennis tournament today by ousting Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., 1-6, 6-4, 6-4, 8-6.

A Sing Sing inmate who had served a sentence in Hudson County Jail testified yesterday in Federal Court that while in the jail at Jersey City he had been visited by prostitutes and twice had left the prison on business.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 9 Home runs by Mickey Mantle, Roger Maris and Joe Pepitone and impressive clutch pitching by Mel Stottlemyre brought the New York Yankees a 3-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight.

VAN WERT, Ohio, May 9 Dr. and Mrs. John Clinton Sharp have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Emily Sharp, to George McGiil Carter 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carter Jr. of Wayzata, Minn.
JASPER, Ala., May 9 (UPI) A record of 888,837 votes was set in the Democratic primary last week that nominated Mrs. George C. Wallace to succeed her husband as Governor.

MOSCOW, May 9--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin sets off for Cairo tomorrow on an official visit aimed at asserting Soviet interests in the Middle East. Talks to explore increased military cooperation, as well as economic and political relations, have been scheduled with President Gamal Abdel Nasser during Mr. Kosygin's eight-day tour of the United Arab Republic.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9 Dr. William H. Radford, director of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Lincoln Laboratory, Lexington, Mass., died this afternoon at the Emerson Hospital in Concord after a heart attack. He was 56 years old.
John P. Lawler has been elected a vice president of Texaco Experiment, Inc., a subsidiary of Texaco, Inc. He was formerly director of Washington operations for the unit.

Almost 200 Harlem leaders asked Mayor Lindsay yesterday to erect more public buildings in their community. These projects, they said, would spur private investment in the area and satisfy Harlem's most pressing need jobs.

PIERRE CARDIN, the 43year-old Paris designer who doggedly piped the tune of youth in haute couture until the rest of the fashion world caught up with him, explained yesterday the meaning of the word "young."

LONDON, May 9 (UPI) Bob Allotey, a Ghana bantamweight fighting out of Copenhagen, scored a technical knockout over Jackie Brown tonight when the Scottish fighter quit after the second round because of an injured left hand.

AMSTERDAM, May 9 The World Mixed Pair championship was won here tonight by an American pair Ivan Erdos and Mrs. Mary Jane Farell, both of Los Angeles. Second were the British pair of M.G. Weissberger and Mrs. J. Durran.

PRETORIA, South Africa, May 9 Abram Fischer, a 59year-old former Queen's Counsel who led the defense team at the sabotage trial of Nelson Mandela, Walter Sisulu and others in 1964, was sentenced today to life imprisonment.

LONDON, May 9 A spirited Opposition attack failed to produce any tax concessions tonight from Chancellor of the Exchequer James Callaghan, who was completing a weeklong budget debate in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, May 9 The Federal Trade Commission, by a 4-to-1 vote, held today that defendants in its civil cases were entitled only to limited access to commission documents containing the accusations against them.
Mayor Lindsay called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday to support a bill that would set up a $400-million construction fund to expand the City University.
Smith Industries International, Inc., has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the proposed sale of 159,800 shares of common stock.

Following are the sections of the report by Mayor Lindsay's Task Force on Air Pollution that give details of the sources and kinds of pollution with which New York City must cope, and the major elements of what the task force considers an effective remedial program:
An airline has teamed with show business to attract youngsters from age 12 through 21 to theaters by offering them half-price tickets.

Mario Procaccino, the city Controller, who has demanded an even greater stock transfer tax than that proposed by Mayor Lindsay, yesterday called the exchange's incorporation in New Jersey, "Just a scare tactic."

Jackie Coogan, who says he became a film actor when he was 2 years old in 1916, will make his Broadway stage debut in December at the age of 52. He will be starred in the title role of "Fatty," the Harry Essex drama based on incidents in the life of Fatty Arbuckle, silent film star.
WASHINGTON, May 9 Treasury bill rates moved in opposite directions at today's auction, with three-month bills falling from last week's rate and six-month bills rising, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 9 Uganda, to judge from the new Five-Year Plan, which was published today, is growing increasingly disillusioned with foreign aid.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 9 The traditionalist or conservative Arab regimes appear to be closing ranks, or at least taking precautions, in the face of threats from Cairo and growing Soviet influence among "revolutionary" Arabs.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) Representative L, Mendel Rivers, Democrat of South Carolina, accused the nation's commercial airlines today of "indifference" toward United States servicemen by keeping them stranded for hours in airports waiting for flights. The carriers disputed the charge.

A Texas Gulf Sulphur Company executive testified yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange knew, several hours after the trade was made, about his purchase of stock in the mining company on the day it announced a big copper discovery.
ROME, May 9 (AP) A group of 20 Roman Catholic priests from various nations began work today to plan a Vatican secretariat to deal with problems of world hunger and poverty in developing nations.

WASHINGTON, May 9 Former Senator Barry Goldwater tonight advised the militantly conservative youth group, Young Americans for Freedom, to avoid direct political action and remain "an educational group."
BONN, May 9 The Government has sent a note to six of its Western allies calling for better treatment of German civilians employed by allied forces stationed in West Germany.

William J. Powell, a former Commisioner of Sanitation, died of a heart ailment Sunday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. He was 77 years old and lived at 73-28 193d Street, Holliswood, Queens.

The architectural firm of Kahn Jacobs has been commissioned to design the skyscraper that Sam Minskoff Sons plan to erect on the site of the Astor Hotel at Broadway and 44th Street. Minskoff contracted to buy the Astor property last winter, and will take title to it July 1.
GENEVA, May 9 Senator Edward M. Kennedy arrived today for a 48-hour visit during which he will discuss the situation of American prisoners of war in Vietnam with the International Red Cross.
HOUSTON, May 9 Miss Deborah Inez Detering, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Eberhard Detering, was married tonight to William Presley Pannill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fitzhugh Hastings Pannill of Midland.

VIENNA, May 9 An elaborate Soviet proposal for an international effort to search for signals from other worlds has been set down for discussion at next year's General Assembly of the International Astronomical Union.

LONG BEACH, L.I., May 9 Nathan Goldstone, a retired executive who was active in many Jewish philantropies, died today at the Long Beach Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 210 East Broadway.

LONDON, May 5 International Communism, despite an extensive and expensive campaign, has failed thus far to win to its cause any significant number of black African states, peoples or political parties.
New York City has the most polluted air of "any major city in the United States," a report to Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

OTTAWA, May 9--Pierre Sevigny, former Associate Minister of Defense, denied under oath today that Gerda Munsinger was ever his mistress or that she had ever asked for or been given secret information.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. May 9 Secretary Genera Thant said today that "serious study" should be given the United States proposal for a United Nations treaty preserving the moon and other celestial bodies for peaceful exploration by all states.
ALBANY, May 9 Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia, the Legislature's top Democrat, said today he was considering proposing alternatives to Mayor Lindsay's tax program for New York City.

WASHINGTON, May 9 Secretary of State Dean Rusk strongly defended United States military involvement in South Vietnam today and promptly touched off an acerbic debate between Democratic members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
MILAN, Italy, May 9 (AP) Enzo Ferrari, the race car builder, maintained today that speed was not the cause of road accidents.

WHITE PLAINS, May 9 New York City eased its stand on water restrictions today and agreed to ask the Delaware River Basin Commission to permit the limited use of city water on trees and shrubs. All watering of outdoor greenery is now prohibited because of the drought.

Jules Irving, co-director of the Lincoln Center Repertory Company, reported yesterday that 72,608 seats have already been sold to 18,152 subscribers for next season's program four plays that have not been selected yet.

If you have an old revolving piano stool around the house, don't throw it away. It may come in handy some day for a performance of Claude Spies's net duo for viola and keyboard instruments. The work was introduced to New York last night by Samuel Rhodes and Richard Goode at Carnegie Recital Hall.
LONDON, May 9 The wife of a British Cabinet minister has caused a stir by proposing that London breed butterflies to brighten up its parks.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) Representative Elford A. Cederberg, Republican of Michigan, defended the auto industry today and said it "should be commended for its diligence in correcting any known defects."

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he planned to appoint a Health Services Administrator as the city's chief health officer. He will be responsible for coordinating the programs of the Departments of Health and Hospitals, which will remain independent agencies.

A dissident director of MetroGoldwyn-Mayer, Inc., Philip J. Levin, sent stockholders a brief letter yesterday urging them not to sign proxies for the company's special meeting on May 24 "until you hear further from me."
Stock prices were caught up in another full-scale retreat yesterday. Automotive news again was a factor in the topsyturvy market.

The appointment of Robert W. Sarnoff as national fund cochairman of the American Red Cross for the third successive term was announced yesterday by E. Roland Harriman, national chairman of the Red Cross.
The Mead Corporation plans to expand in the writing-paper business through a proposed merger with Westab, Inc., for stock valued at about $36-million.
Where are the butterflies of yesteryear? Are those gaily colored, fluttering symbols of summer serenity falling victim to civilization?

A $20-million offering of convertible debentures of Bankers International (Luxembourg) the first issue of its type to be sold overseas for the affiliate of a United States bank was priced yesterday for sale in Europe, Bankers International is an overseas financing affiliate of the Bankers Trust Company.

TRENTON, May 9 In a special message to the Legislature, Gov. Richard J. Hughes asked today for the passage of a comprehensive package of labor legislation that includes a minimum wage and higher unemployment and workmen's compensation benefits.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The Senate approved today the retirement of Gen. Bernard A. Schriever, long-time ballistic missile expert of the Air Force.

Larry Adler is, as the publicity for his current appearances at the Village Gate quite correctly states, a "world famous harmonica virtuoso." But this characterization merely labors the obvious. He is also the most charming performer to appear in a New York nightclub in years (at a guess, three years, which was the last time he appeared at the Gate) and, in addition, the most elusive.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., May 9--A former chairman of the American Conference of Academic Deans and Kenan Professor of History, Joseph C. Sitterson, was appointed today Chancellor of the University of North Carolina.
SAIGON, Tuesday, May 10 American military policemen fought a gun battle with Vietcong terrorists on the streets of downtown Saigon early this morning.
CINCINNATI, May 9 Carl B. Rubin resigned today as chairman of the three-member City Civil Service Commission.

Harry Horwitz, realty operator, has assembled a plot of 20,500 square feet of land at the northwest corner of Second Avenue and 40th Street as the site for an office building. He purchased three parcels to complete the assemblage, all tenements except a one-story taxpayer structure occupied by the Peter Reeves grocery chain.
WASHINGTON, May 9 Many differences exist between the dispute over the ballotcount in last week's Dallas County, Alabama, primary and that in Jim Wells County, Texas, in 1948.
DETROIT, May 9 The Ford Motor Company said today that it would produce about 18,000 fewer cars this month than it had planned.

March contracts for future construction in New York State had a total value of $405,475,000, an increase of 30 per cent over March, 1965, according to the F.W. Dodge Company, building-trade analysts, and a division of the McGraw-Hill, Inc.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 9 (UPI) Both Leonid I. Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist party, and Premier Chou En-lai of China will visit Bucharest "in the next few days," Rumanian officials said here tonight.

NOVES, France This is the- season when certain bear- ers of ill tidings sing their perennial dirge that the kitchens of France are on the wane. The traditions, they moan, are dead. The chefs have lost their esprit and nothing is left to feast on but cabbage and thistles.
BRUSSELS, May 9 The six Common Market members were deadlocked tonight on agricultural financing. Tomorrow is the "deadline" they have set for reaching an agreement.
SAIGON, May 9 Anti-Government Buddhist leaders in South Vietnam commented cautiously today on Premier Nguyen Cao Ky's weekend assertion that his junta would remain in power for at least another year.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J. May 9 (AP) A Jersey Central Railroad train rolled north through here just after 5:30 A.M. today and a Pennsylvania Railroad train followed a few minutes later over the newly repaired Raritan River railroad bridge.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The General Services Administration moved today to encourage expansion of domestic copper production.

The Metropolitan Opera was busy yesterday removing vestiges of its 83-year stay in its old home at Broadway and 39th Street. The final haul of equipment to the new house at Lincoln Center is expected to take place today when the old building is turned over to its leaseholder, Keystone Associates. Keystone plans to raze the house and replace it with a 40-story office building.
The City Council voted approval of Mayor Lindsay's tax program last night.
